div.head: 1. The Tale of the Heike: Scroll One

div.p:
[1.1.1]
The sound of the bells of the Gion Shōja echoes the impermanence of all things. The color of the śāla flowers reveals the truth that the prosperous must decline. The proud do not endure, they are like a dream on a spring night. The mighty fall at last, they are as dust before the wind. If we look closely at distant lands, Zhao Gao of Qin, Wang Mang of Han, Zhu Yi of Liang, and Lushan of Tang—these men all did not follow the government of their former lords and emperors, they indulged in pleasure, did not heed remonstrance, did not realize the world was in chaos, and did not know the grievances of the people; thus, they did not last long and perished. Looking closely at our own land, Masakado in the Jōhei era, Sumitomo in the Tengyō era, Yoshichika in the Kōwa era, and Nobuyori in the Heiji era—these men were each proud in spirit and fierce in deed, yet regarding the lay priest of Rokuhara, the former Grand Minister of State Taira no Ason Kiyomori, his circumstances are such that neither mind nor words can adequately describe what has been transmitted and heard.

[1.1.2] Seeking his ancestry, he is the eldest son of the Minister of Punishments Tadamori Ason, the grandson of the Governor of Sanuki Masamori, who was the ninth-generation descendant of Prince Kazurahara, the Minister of Ceremonial of the First Rank and fifth son of Emperor Kanmu. That Prince's son, Prince Takami, died without office or rank. It was in the time of his son, Prince Takamochi, that they were first given the surname Taira and became the Assistant Governor of Kazusa; from that point, they abruptly left the royal family and joined the ranks of subjects. His son, the General of the Defense of the North Yoshimochi, later changed his name to Kunika. From Kunika down to Masamori, for six generations they were governors of various provinces, but they were not yet permitted the registry of courtiers allowed into the Hall.

div.head: 1.2. The Night Attack in the Courtiers' Hall

div.p:
[1.2.1] However, when Tadamori was the Governor of Bizen, he built the Tokuchōju-in temple in fulfillment of the Retired Emperor Toba's vow, erecting a hall of thirty-three bays and placing one thousand and one Buddha images within. The dedication was on the thirteenth day of the third month of the first year of Tenshō. As a reward, it was ordered that he be given a vacant province. As the province of Tajima was open, he was given that. Because of the Retired Emperor's great admiration, he was permitted access to the Palace Courtiers' Hall. Tadamori first ascended to the Hall at the age of thirty-six. The people above the clouds [high courtiers] were jealous of this, and on the night of the twenty-third day of the eleventh month of that same year, during the Gosechi Toyonoakari festival, they plotted to ambush Tadamori in the dark. Tadamori heard of this and said, "I am not a civil official; I was born to a house of warriors. To meet with unexpected shame now would be a regret for my house and for myself. After all, there is a text that says one serves the lord by preserving one's life."
saying this, he made preparations in advance. Before going to the palace, he prepared a large dagger and wore it casually beneath his court dress; turning toward the dimly lit area, he slowly drew this sword and held it to his sidelocks, where it appeared like ice. The onlookers stared wide-eyed. Furthermore, among Tadamori's retainers was one called Sahyōe-no-jō Iesada, the son of Shin-no-Saburō Dayū Iefusa and grandson of Mokkō-no-suke Taira no Sadamitsu, who was originally of the same clan. Wearing a light green belly-guard under a light blue hunting robe and holding a sword carrying a bowstring bag under his arm, he waited reverently in the small garden of the Courtiers' Hall. The Head Chamberlain and others were suspicious and had a Sixth Rank official ask, "Who is that wearing plain clothes waiting near the bell rope by the 'Quiver Pillar'? This is outrageous behavior. Leave at once."
Iesada replied, "I have heard that my hereditary lord, the Governor of Bizen, is to be ambushed in the dark tonight, so I am waiting here to see how that will unfold. I absolutely cannot leave."
Because he waited there with such resolve, they must have thought it unwise, for there was no dark ambush that night.

[1.2.2] When Tadamori danced at the imperial command, the people changed the rhythm and jeered, "The Ise Heike is squint-eyed [sugame]!"
Although strictly speaking it is awe-inspiring to mention that these people are descendants of Emperor Kanmu, in recent times their residence in the capital had become unfamiliar, and they behaved entirely like provincials; having lived deep in Ise Province, people associated them with the vessels [su] of that province and called them the Ise Heike. Furthermore, because Tadamori's eyes were slanted [sugame], they jeered at him in this way. Without any way to respond, and before the entertainment had ended, he slipped away, handed the sword he had worn at his side to a palace servant to keep at the Shishinden, in a place where the other courtiers could see it, and left. Iesada was waiting for him and asked, "Well, how did it go?" Although Tadamori wanted to tell him, he thought that if he spoke, Iesada was the kind of man who would immediately slash his way up into the Hall, so he replied, "Nothing in particular happened."

[1.2.3] At the Gosechi festival, people only sing about amusing things like "White thin paper, crumpled paper, roll-top brush, brush shaft painted with comma designs," but in recent times there was a man named Dazai-no-Gon-no-Sotsu Suenaka-kyō. Because his complexion was very dark, people called him the Black Sotsu. When that person was still the Head Chamberlain and danced at the Gosechi, they changed the rhythm and jeered, "Oh how black, black, what a black head. What kind of person lacquered him?"
Also, when the former Grand Minister of State Lord Tadamasa of the Kazan-in family was still ten years old, having lost his father, the Middle Counselor Lord Tadamune, and being an orphan, the late Fujiwara Middle Counselor Ienari took him as a son-in-law while still Governor of Harima; when Tadamasa was treated splendidly, they jeered at the Gosechi, "Is the Harima rice scouring rush, or is it muku leaves, that polishes a person's appearance so?"
In ancient times such things happened but no trouble came of it. People said they were anxious about how it would be in these latter days.

[1.2.4] Just as expected, when the Gosechi ended, the courtiers all spoke in unison: "To attend a public banquet wearing a sword, or to be given weapons and enter and leave the palace, are rooted in ancient regulations governed by imperial order to protect formal etiquette. However, Tadamori Ason, calling upon a hereditary retainer, stationed a soldier in plain clothes in the small garden of the Hall, and he sat in the festival seat wearing a sword at his waist. These two articles are outrageous acts unprecedented in history. The matters have already piled up. It is difficult to escape the charge of crime. Quickly erase his name from the rolls and strip him of office," they each appealed; the Retired Emperor was greatly surprised and summoned Tadamori to question him. He defended himself, saying, "First, regarding the retainer waiting in the small garden, I knew absolutely nothing about it. However, perhaps because there were signs that people were recently conspiring together, a long-time retainer heard of the matter and, intending to save me from shame, came secretly without Tadamori's knowledge; this was a sequence of events beyond my power. If there is still blame to be assigned, perhaps that person should be summoned and surrendered. Next, regarding the sword, I left it in the custody of a palace servant. Should you not summon this and judge the nature of the blame based on whether it is a real sword or not?"
Saying this was reasonable, they summoned the sword and upon Imperial inspection, the outside was a dagger sheath lacquered black, but inside was a wooden sword covered with silver foil. "Although he appeared to carry a sword to escape the shame of the moment, his preparation in carrying a wooden sword, knowing there would be accusations later, is admirable. The strategy of one who takes up bow and arrow should indeed be like this. Furthermore, regarding the retainer waiting in the small garden, that is partly the custom of a warrior's retainer. It is not Tadamori's fault."
Thus, rather than being punished, he received Imperial praise, and there was no judgment of crime.
[1.3.1] His children became colonels of the guards and were granted access to the Hall, and people did not object to their joining the courtiers.
[1.3.2] Around that time, when Tadamori came up to the capital from Bizen Province, the Retired Emperor Toba asked, "How is Akashi Bay?"

lg.l: The moon at dawn was also bright in the bay wind of Akashi, I saw only the waves approaching.

div.p: [1.3.3] Because he recited this, he received Imperial praise. This poem was included in the Kin'yōshū anthology.

[1.3.4] Tadamori also frequently visited a favorite lady-in-waiting at the Retired Emperor's palace; once, he left a fan with a moon painted in the corner in that lady's room, and the other ladies laughed together, asking, "From where does this moonlight come? Its source is unclear."
The lady replied:

lg.l: Since it is a moon that has come simply [tadamori] from the clouds, I think I will not speak of it as hazy.

div.p: [1.3.5] Because she composed this, she was thought of with no small affection. She is the mother of the Governor of Satsuma, Tadanori. Since Tadamori was tasteful in the manner of "likeness attracts friends," that lady was also elegant. Thus Tadamori became Minister of Punishments, and on the fifteenth day of the first month of the third year of Ninpei, he died at the age of fifty-eight. Kiyomori, being the eldest son, succeeded to his estate.

[1.3.6] In the seventh month of the first year of Hōgen, when the Minister of the Left at Uji revolted, Kiyomori served as Governor of Aki on the Emperor's side and had merit; he was moved to become Governor of Harima and in the third year became Dazai-no-Daini. Next, in the twelfth month of the first year of Heiji, during Lord Nobuyori's rebellion, he defeated the rebels on the Imperial side; his merit was not singular, and saying the reward should be heavy, the following year he was promoted to Senior Third Rank, continuing to rise through Consultant, Commander of the Guards, Superintendent of the Police, Middle Counselor, and Major Counselor; furthermore, he reached the rank of Minister, and without passing through Left and Right, rose from Palace Minister to Grand Minister of State, Junior First Rank. Although not a General, he was granted armed guards and had retainers accompany him. He received a decree allowing ox carts and hand-drawn carriages, and entered and left the palace riding in them. He was exactly like a Regent. It is said, "The Grand Minister of State is a teacher to the One Man [Emperor] and a model for the Four Seas. He governs the country, discusses the Way, and harmonizes Yin and Yang. If the person is not right, let the post be vacant. " Therefore it is named the "Vacant Office." Though it is not an office that should be defiled by anyone other than the right person, since he held the whole world in the palm of his hand, there was nothing to be done about it.

[1.3.7] That the Heike prospered in this way was rumored to be the divine favor of the Kumano Gongen. The reason is, long ago when Lord Kiyomori was still Governor of Aki, he went by boat from the Ise Sea to Kumano; a large sea bass jumped into the boat, and the guide said, "This is a blessing from the Gongen. You must eat it quickly."
Kiyomori said, "In ancient times, a white fish jumped into the boat of King Wu of Zhou. This is an auspicious thing."
And, although he was on a pilgrimage observing the Ten Precepts and strictly abstaining from meat, he cooked it and fed it to his family and samurai. Perhaps because of this, auspicious events followed one after another, and he reached the height of Grand Minister of State. The official careers of his descendants were swifter than a dragon ascending the clouds. It was joyous that he exceeded nine generations of ancestors.

[1.4.1] Thus Lord Kiyomori, on the eleventh day of the eleventh month of the third year of Nin'an, at the age of fifty-one, was stricken with illness; to save his life he suddenly took the tonsure and became a lay priest. His Buddhist name was Jōkai. Perhaps due to this sign, his chronic illness healed instantly, and he fulfilled his natural lifespan. That people obeyed him was like grass and trees bending before a blowing wind. That the world looked up to him universally was the same as rain falling to moisten the earth.

[1.4.2] Speaking of the young lords of the Rokuhara family, no noble family or hero could face them or stand shoulder to shoulder with them. Thus, Lord Tokitada, the Major Counselor of the Taira and brother-in-law of the Lay Priest Chancellor, said, "Those who are not of this clan are not people." Because it was so, everyone, no matter who, schemed to form a connection with them. From the way clothes were worn to the way hats were folded, everything was called "Rokuhara style," and everyone in the world imitated it.

[1.4.3] Also, regarding the administration of any wise king or sage emperor, or the judgments of a Regent or Chancellor, it is the common custom for idlers who are dissatisfied with the world to slander and criticize them where no one can hear, but while this Zenmon [Kiyomori] was at his height, no one spoke even slightly carelessly. The reason is that by the Lay Priest Chancellor's design, three hundred boys of fourteen, fifteen, or sixteen years old were gathered, their hair cut in a bob [kaburo], wearing red hitatare robes, and were employed to permeate the capital and go back and forth. If there was anyone speaking ill of the Heike, if one heard it, he would summon the rest, break into that house, seize the assets and furnishings, bind the person, and drag them to Rokuhara. Therefore, although people saw with their eyes and knew in their hearts, no one expressed it in words. Since they were called the Kaburo of Rokuhara, horses and carriages passing on the road swerved to let them pass. Even when entering or leaving the palace gates, their names were not asked; it seemed the officials of the capital looked away because of this.

[1.5.1]
Not only did he reach the limit of his own glory, but the whole clan prospered together: his heir Shigemori was Palace Minister and General of the Left; his second son Munemori was Middle Counselor and General of the Right; his third son Tomomori was a Captain of the Third Rank; his eldest grandson Koremori was a Captain of the Fourth Rank; in all, sixteen high courtiers of the clan, over thirty courtiers with access to the Hall, and including provincial governors, guards, and officials, a total of over sixty people. It seemed there was no one else in the world.

[1.5.2] Long ago in the time of the Nara Emperor, in the fifth year of Jinki, the Middle Palace Guards were first established, and since the fourth year of Daidō when the Middle Palace Guards were renamed the Inner Palace Guards, brothers standing side by side in Left and Right happened only three or four times. In the time of Emperor Montoku, on the left was Yoshifusa, Minister of the Right and General of the Left, and on the right was Yoshimi, Major Counselor and General of the Right; these were the sons of the Minister of the Left of Kan'in, Fuyutsugu. In the reign of Retired Emperor Suzaku, on the left was Saneyori, Lord Ononomiya, and on the right was Morosuke, Lord Kujō; they were sons of Lord Teishin. In the time of Retired Emperor Go-Reizei, on the left was Norimichi, Lord Ō-Nijō, and on the right was Yorimune, Lord Horikawa; they were sons of the Midō Regent. In the reign of Retired Emperor Nijō, on the left was Motofusa, Lord Matsudono, and on the right was Kanezane, Lord Tsukinowa; they were sons of Lord Hosshōji. These were all sons of Regentsand Chancellors; for ordinary people, there is no precedent. For the descendants of a person who was denied access to the Hall to wear forbidden colors and patterned robes, to wrap themselves in damask and brocade, to become Ministers and Generals, and for brothers to stand side by side in Left and Right—though it is the latter days, these were strange events.

[1.5.3] Besides these, there were eight daughters. They all married happily in various ways. One was to be the wife of the Middle Counselor of Sakuramachi, Lord Shigenori, but although it was only a betrothal at age eight, after the Heiji Disturbance it was broken off, and she became the wife of the Minister of the Left of Kazan-in and had many children.

[1.5.4]
Now, the reason Lord Shigenori was called the Middle Counselor of Sakuramachi was that he was a person of exceedingly refined taste; he always loved Mount Yoshino, planted cherry trees in rows in his town, built a house among them, and lived there, so every spring people who saw it called it Cherry Town [Sakuramachi]. Cherry blossoms bloom and fall in seven days, so regretting their passing, he prayed to the Sun Goddess, and they lasted for three times seven days. Because the lord was a wise king, the gods let their divine virtue shine, and the flowers, having a heart, maintained their lifespan for twenty days.

[1.5.5] One daughter stood as Empress. A prince was born and stood as Crown Prince, and when he ascended the throne, she received a title and was called Kenreimon-in. Since she was the daughter of the Lay Priest Chancellor and also the Mother of the Nation, there is no need to speak further of it. One became the wife of the Regent of Rokujō. During the reign of Emperor Takakura, as the foster mother, she received a decree granting her status equivalent to the three empresses, was called the Lady of Shirakawa, and was a person of importance. One became the wife of Lord Fugenji. One was the wife of the Major Counselor of Reizei, Lord Takafusa. One was married to the Master of the Palace Repairs of Shichijō, Lord Nobutaka. Also, one born to a maid of Itsukushima in Aki Province was presented to the Cloistered Emperor Go-Shirakawa and was treated like a consort. Besides these, there was one born to the attendant Tokiwa of the Kujō-in. She was a high-ranking lady-in-waiting at the Kazan-in palace and was called the Lady of the Corridor.

[1.5.6] The dragonfly islands of Japan are merely sixty-six provinces, and the provinces governed by the Heike were more than thirty; they already exceeded half the country. Besides that, the number of manors and fields was unknown. Fine clothes filled the halls like flowers. Carriages and horses gathered so that the front of the gates made a market. Gold from Yangzhou, pearls from Jingzhou, damask from Wu, brocade from Shu—of the seven rarities and ten thousand treasures, not one was lacking. The foundations of song halls and dance pavilions, the playthings of fish, dragons, sparrows, and horses—it seemed that perhaps even the Imperial Palace and the Retired Emperor's Palace did not surpass this.

div.head: 1.6. Giō

div.p:
[1.6.1]
The Lay Priest Chancellor held the whole world in his palm, so fearing no slander from the world and paying no heed to the mockery of others, he did only strange things. For example, at that time there were skilled Shirabyōshi dancers famous in the capital, sisters named Giō and Ginyo; they were the daughters of a Shirabyōshi named Toji. Because the Lay Priest Chancellor loved the elder sister Giō most, the younger sister Ginyo was also treated by people with no small favor. He built a good house for their mother Toji and sent her one hundred koku of rice and one hundred kan of money every month, so the family was wealthy and their happiness was no small thing.

[1.6.2] Now, the beginning of Shirabyōshi in our country was when two people named Shima-no-Senzai and Waka-no-Mae danced during the reign of Retired Emperor Toba. In the beginning, they wore suikan robes, tall black hats, and white-sheathed daggers while dancing, so it was called "male dance." However, from sometime in between, the hats and swords were removed, and they used only the suikan robes; thus it was named Shirabyōshi [White Rhythm].

[1.6.3] Hearing of Giō's splendid fortune, some of the Shirabyōshi in the capital envied her, and some were jealous. Those who envied her said, "Oh, how splendid is Lady Giō's fortune. If we are the same entertainers, everyone would want to be like that. Surely this is because the character 'Gi' is in her name that she is so lucky. Come, let us also use it."
Thus some took names like Gi-ichi or Gi-ni, or Gi-fuku or Gi-toku. Those who were jealous said, "How could it depend on the name or the written character? Fortune is simply determined by birth in a previous life."
And there were many who did not use the name.

[1.6.4]
Thus three years passed, and another skilled Shirabyōshi famous in the capital appeared. She was from Kaga Province. Her name was Hotoke [Buddha]. It was said she was sixteen. People high and low in the capital made much of her, saying, "Although there have been many Shirabyōshi since ancient times, we have not yet seen such a dance."
Hotoke-gozen said, "Although I am famous throughout the land, it is a disappointment that I have not been summoned by the Heike Chancellor who now prospers so splendidly. It is the custom of entertainers; what harm could there be? I will go uninvited and see."
And so she went to Nishi-Hachijō. A person entered and announced, "Hotoke-gozen, who is currently famous in the capital, has come." The Lay Priest said, "Why, such entertainers attend only when summoned by others. Is there a precedent for coming uninvited without purpose? Whether god or Buddha [Hotoke], one cannot suit a place where Giō is present. Leave quickly. " Hotoke-gozen was spoken to harshly and was about to leave when Giō said to the Chancellor, "It is the usual custom for entertainers to come uninvited. Moreover, she is still young, and having set her heart on coming here occasionally, it is pitiful to speak harshly to her and send her away. How ashamed and embarrassed she must feel. Since it is the path I myself have walked, it does not feel like another's problem. Even if you do not watch her dance or listen to her song, if you would just meet her and then send her away, it would be a rare kindness. Just bend your principles, call her back, and meet her."
Upon her saying this, the Lay Priest said, "Well then, since you speak so strongly for her, I will see her and send her away."
And he sent a messenger to summon her. Hotoke-gozen had been spoken to harshly and had boarded her carriage and was about to leave, but being summoned, she returned. The Lay Priest came out to meet her and said, "Although I should not have seen you today, I wondered what Giō would think, and since she urged me excessively, I am meeting you like this. Since I am meeting you, how can I not hear your voice? Sing one imayō song."
Thus Hotoke-gozen said, "I obey," and sang one imayō.

lg.l: When I first see my lord, like the young pine that will endure a thousand years,
On Turtle Hill by the pond in the garden, cranes gather and seem to play.

div.p:
[1.6.5] Since she repeated this three times with a clear voice, the people who saw and heard were all astonished. The Lay Priest also seemed to find it interesting and said, "You are skilled at imayō. At this rate, your dancing must surely be good. I would like to see one dance. Summon the drum player."
So they were summoned. He had them play, and she danced one dance.

[1.6.6] Hotoke-gozen was beautiful in appearance and figure, beginning with her hair, and since her voice was good and her rhythm skilled, why should her dance be inferior? Because she danced exquisitely beyond imagination, the Lay Priest Chancellor admired the dance and transferred his heart to Hotoke. Hotoke-gozen said, "What sort of thing is this? Originally, I was sent away as an uninvited guest, and it was only due to Lady Giō's petition that I was called back; if I am kept here like this, I feel ashamed of what Lady Giō must be thinking in her heart. Please give me leave quickly and let me go."
But the Lay Priest said, "That shall absolutely not happen. However, do you hesitate because Giō is here? If that is the case, I shall send Giō away. " Hotoke-gozen said, "How could that be? Even if we were kept here together it would be painful, but much more so if you send Lady Giō away and keep me alone; Lady Giō's heart would feel ashamed. If you do not forget me in the future, even if summoned I will come again, but today I will take my leave. " The Lay Priest said, "Why should that happen? Giō, leave at once." And he sent a messenger three times. Although Giō had anticipated this path from the start, she did not expect it to be yesterday or today. Since he repeatedly told her to leave immediately, she swept her room, picked up dust, tidied up unsightly items, and it was decided she would leave. Even sheltering together under the shade of a single tree or drinking from the same stream makes parting sad. How much more so, since this was a place she had lived for three years, the memories were dear and sad, and useless tears spilled. Since it was not something she could change, Giō, thinking "now is the end," left, but perhaps thinking to leave a keepsake for when she was gone, she wrote a poem on the sliding door weeping.

lg.l: Sprouting or withering, the grasses of the field are the same; which of them can survive the autumn?

div.p:
[1.6.7] Then she boarded her carriage and returned to her home, collapsed inside the sliding doors, and did nothing but weep. Her mother and sister saw this and asked, "What is it, what is it?" but she could not even answer. Asking the maid who accompanied her, they learned that such a thing had happened. In time, the one hundred koku and one hundred kan sent every month were stopped, and the people related to Hotoke-gozen began to enjoy happiness and prosperity for the first time. People high and low in the capital said, "It seems Giō was given leave by the Lay Priest and has come out. Come, let us meet her and amuse ourselves."
Some sent letters, and some sent messengers. However, Giō felt she could not face people and play or joke now, so she did not accept letters, much less meet with messengers. Thinking of this, she was sad and sank only further into tears.

[1.6.8] Thus this year also ended. The following spring, the Lay Priest Chancellor sent a messenger to Giō: "How have you been since then? Hotoke-gozen looks too bored, so come, sing imayō, dance a dance, and comfort Hotoke. " Giō did not make any reply. The Lay Priest said, "Why does Giō not reply? Will she not come? If she will not come, state the reason. Jōkai has a plan." Her mother Toji heard this and was distressed, not knowing what to do; weeping, she admonished her: "Listen, Lady Giō, make some reply, rather than be scolded like this."
Giō said, "If it were a path I intended to take, I would reply that I would come immediately. Since I do not intend to go, I do not know what reply to make. His saying that he has a plan if I do not come this time surely means he will either banish me from the capital or take my life; it will not go beyond these two. Even if I am banished from the capital, it is not something to lament. Even if my life is taken, is my body something to be regretted? Once I have been thought of as disagreeable, I cannot face him a second time."
And she still did not reply, so her mother Toji admonished her again: "As long as you live under the heavens, you cannot disobey the Lay Priest's command. The connection between man and woman does not begin in this life. Even if they pledge for a thousand or ten thousand years, there are relationships that separate immediately. Even if they think it is for nothing, there are those who last until the end. The uncertainty of the world is the way of men and women. That you were loved for these three years was a rare kindness. Surely you will not be killed just because you do not go when summoned. You will simply be expelled from the capital. Even if you are expelled from the capital, since you young ones are young, it will be easy to pass the time even in the clefts of rocks and trees. But your old and feeble mother will be expelled from the capital. It is sad to think beforehand of living in an unfamiliar journey. Just let me live out my life within the capital. I will consider that filial piety for this life and the next."
Because she said this, although it was a path Giō found hateful, she decided not to disobey her parent's command; weeping, she set out, and the feeling in her heart was pitiful. Saying it was too melancholy to go alone, she took her sister Ginyo with her. Besides them, two other Shirabyōshi, four in all, rode in one carriage and went to Nishi-Hachijō. She was not allowed into the place where she was formerly summoned, but a seat was prepared in a place far below. Giō thought, "What is this? Though I have no fault, simply being abandoned is bad enough, but the misery of having my seat lowered. What shall I do?" And tears spilled out from the gaps of the sleeve she pressed to her face to hide them. Hotoke-gozen saw this and thought it too pitiful, so she said, "How is that? If she were in a place where she is not usually summoned, it would be fine. Summon her here. If not, give me leave. I will go out and meet her."
The Lay Priest said, "That shall strictly not happen." So she could do nothing and did not go out. After that, the Lay Priest, unaware of Giō's inner heart, said, "How have you been since then? Well now, Hotoke-gozen looks too bored, so sing one imayō."
Since Giō had come this far, she thought she must not disobey the Lay Priest's command no matter what, so suppressing her falling tears, she sang one imayō.

lg.l: The Buddha was once a common man, we too shall finally be Buddhas,
Though both share the Buddha-nature, how sad is the separation [between us].

div.p: [1.6.9] Because she sang this twice while weeping, the Heike nobles, courtiers, grandees, and samurai lined up in that seat all shed tears of emotion. The Lay Priest also seemed to find it interesting and said, "As for the occasion, you have sung admirably. Now I would like to see a dance, but today something confusing has come up. In the future, even if not summoned, come constantly to sing imayō and dance to comfort Hotoke. " Giō made no reply, suppressed her tears, and left.

[1.6.10] "Intending not to disobey my parent's command, I set out on a bitter path and have met with misery a second time; how wretched it is. If I remain in this world like this, I will face misery again. Now I intend only to throw myself [into the river]."
Saying this, her sister Ginyo said, "If my sister throws herself in, I too will throw myself in together. " Their mother Toji heard this and was so distressed she did not know what to do. Weeping, she admonished them again: "Truly, it is reasonable that you hold a grudge. How wretched that I admonished you without knowing such a thing would happen. However, if you throw yourself in, your sister says she will throw herself in too. If I am left behind by both my daughters, what use is it for an old and feeble mother to live on? I too intend to throw myself in with you. To cause a parent whose time of death has not yet come to throw herself in—would that not be one of the Five Grave Offenses? This world is a temporary abode. Shame or no shame, it is nothing. Only the darkness of the long night is miserable. This life is one thing. But how sad to head toward the evil paths in the next life."
Because she pleaded tearfully, Giō suppressed her tears and said, "Indeed, if that is the case, there is no doubt it would be one of the Five Grave Offenses. Then I will stop thinking of suicide. If I stay in the capital like this, I will see misery again. Now I will leave the capital."
So Giō became a nun at twenty-one, built a brushwood hut in a mountain village deep in Sagano, and spent her time chanting the Nembutsu. Her sister Ginyo said, "I pledged that if my sister threw herself in, I would throw myself in too; who would be inferior in despising the world?" And at nineteen she changed her appearance, secluded herself with her sister, and prayed for the afterlife; it was pitiable. Their mother Toji saw this and, saying that if even her young daughters changed their appearance, what use was it for an old and feeble mother to keep her gray hair in such a world, shaved her head at forty-five; the two daughters and she together devoted themselves strictly to the Nembutsu and earnestly prayed for the afterlife.

[1.6.11] Thus spring passed and summer ended; when the first wind of autumn blew, gazing at the star-meeting sky, they thought, "Is our longing like the mulberry leaves crossing the River of Heaven?" Seeing the evening sun hide behind the western mountain rim, they thought, "Where the sun sets is the Western Pure Land. When will we too be born there and pass time without worry?" And continuing to think of the sad things of the past in relation to this, strictly inexhaustible were their tears. When twilight had passed, they closed the woven bamboo door, trimmed the dim lamp, and the parent and children, three people, were chanting the Nembutsu when someone came and knocked 'hoto-hoto' on the woven bamboo door. At that time the nuns were terrified and said, "Ah, this must be a demon coming to disturb us, worthless ones chanting the Nembutsu. Since it is inside a brushwood hut in a mountain village where no one visits even by day, who would visit late at night? Since it is a slight woven bamboo door, it would be easy to break through without opening. I think it better to just open it and let them in. If they show no mercy and take our lives, we should strongly believe in Amida's original vow on which we have relied for years, and chant the Name without ceasing. Since it is the Holy Multitude who come to welcome us by seeking out the voice, why should there not be guidance to salvation? Be prepared and do not neglect the Nembutsu."
Warning each other thus, they opened the bamboo door, and it was not a demon, but Hotoke-gozen who had appeared. Giō said, "What is this? Is seeing Hotoke-gozen a dream or reality?" Hotoke-gozen suppressed her tears and said, "Though it may be tedious to say such things now, if I do not speak, I may become one who did not realize, so I will speak from the beginning. Originally I came uninvited and was sent away, but due to Lady Giō's petition I was called back; although I felt distressed that, a useless woman, I was detained against my will and my body was not my own, when you were summoned again sometime ago and sang imayō, I realized [the truth]. When I thought 'When will this be my own fate?', I did not feel happy at all. Regarding the traces of the brush you left on the sliding door writing 'Which of them can survive the autumn?', I thought indeed it is so. After that, I did not know where you were, but after hearing you were together like this having changed your appearance, I was so envious that I constantly asked for leave, but the Lay Priest would not use me [allow it]. Thinking deeply, the glory of the娑婆 [Saha world] is a dream within a dream; what is the use of enjoying prosperity? Human form is hard to receive, and the Buddha's teachings are hard to encounter. If I sink into hell this time, it will be difficult to float up even after vast eons. One cannot rely on youth. In the realm where old and young are uncertain, one cannot wait for the exhaled breath to be inhaled. It is more fleeting than gossamer or lightning. Saddened that I might boast of momentary pleasure and not know the afterlife, this morning I slipped out and have come here like this."
So saying, she pushed back the robe she was wearing over her head, and they saw she had become a nun. "Since I have come having changed my appearance like this, please forgive my past offenses. If you say you forgive me, we will chant the Nembutsu together and be born on the same lotus. If you still do not consent, I will wander from here to anywhere, collapse on whatever mossy mat or pine root, and chant the Nembutsu as long as I live, intending to fulfill my long-cherished desire for rebirth. " As she wept copiously, Giō suppressed her tears and said, "Truly, I did not dream you thought this much. Since it is the custom of this sad world, I should think of it as my own misfortune, but whenever it happened, I resented only you and did not think I could fulfill my desire for rebirth; I felt I had failed in both this life and the next, but seeing you have come changed like this, the past offenses do not remain even as dew or dust, and now rebirth is certain. That I can fulfill my desire this time is happier than anything. People said our becoming nuns was unprecedented, and I too thought so. But since I did it resenting the world and resenting myself, changing my appearance was reasonable. Compared to your leaving the world now, it was nothing. You have no resentment and no grief. That a person who is barely seventeen this year despises the Impure Land and desires the Pure Land like this, thinking so deeply, seems truly a great aspiration for the Way. What a joyous Good Friend [zenchishiki] you are. Come, let us pray together."
So the four of them secluded themselves in one place, offering flowers and incense before the Buddha morning and evening, and because they prayed without distraction, though sooner or later, it is said all four nuns fulfilled their desire for rebirth. Therefore, in the death register of the Cloistered Emperor Go-Shirakawa's Chōkōdō hall, the revered spirits of Giō, Ginyo, Hotoke, and Toji are entered together in one place. These were moving events.

div.note: [_] [1] Nihon Koten Bungaku Taikei (Tokyo: Iwanami Shoten, 1957, vol. 32; hereafter cited as NKBT) reads "did not know what to do".

div.p: [1.7.1] From ancient times to the present, when the Genji and Heike clans were employed by the Imperial House, if there were those who did not follow royal influence and made light of the court's authority, they chastised each other, so there was no disorder in the generations; but after Tameyoshi was cut down in Hōgen and Yoshitomo was executed in Heiji, the lesser Genji were either exiled or lost, and now only the Heike family prospers, and no one raises their head. It seemed uncertain what would happen even in future generations. However, after the demise of Retired Emperor Toba, military disturbances continued, and death penalties, exiles, dismissals, and suspensions were constantly carried out, so the country was not quiet. Society also did not settle down. In particular, from around the Eiryaku and Ōho eras, the Retired Emperor's close associates were chastised by the Emperor, and the Emperor's close associates were chastised by the Retired Emperor, so people high and low trembled in fear and had no peace of mind. It was like facing a deep abyss and treading on thin ice; although there should be no distance between father and son, Emperor and Retired Emperor, there were unexpected events. This is also because the world has reached the degenerate age, and people prioritize evil. Among the instances where the Emperor constantly contradicted the Retired Emperor's commands, there was one matter that astonished people's ears and eyes and greatly overturned the world.

[1.7.2] The Empress of the late Emperor Konoe, known as the Grand Empress, was the daughter of the Minister of the Right of Ōimikado, Lord Kinyoshi. After being left behind by the former Emperor, she moved to the Konoe Kawara Palace outside the nine-fold enclosure [the palace] and lived there. As a former Empress, she lived in seclusion, but around the Eiryaku era, she must have been twenty-two or twenty-three; she was a little past her prime. However, she was rumored to be the greatest beauty in the land, so the Emperor's heart was dyed with love; secretly ordering Gao Lishi [a reference to Yang Guifei's story, meaning a messenger], he sought her in the outer palace, and sent a love letter to this Grand Empress. The Grand Empress strictly would not listen. Therefore, it was revealed completely and openly, and an order was issued to the Minister of the Right's house that the Empress should enter the palace. Since this was an extraordinary event in the realm, the high courtiers held a council, and each stated their opinion. "First, checking the precedents of foreign lands, Empress Wu Zetian of China was the Empress of Taizong of Tang and the stepmother of Emperor Gaozong. After Taizong's demise, she stood as Gaozong's Empress. That is a precedent of a foreign land and a special case. However, in our country, from Emperor Jimmu down to over seventy generations of human emperors, we have never heard of an example of standing as Empress for two generations."
Thus the nobles spoke in unison. The Retired Emperor also advised that it should not be so, but the Emperor said, "The Son of Heaven has no parents; by the merit of the Ten Good Deeds I hold the precious throne of ten thousand chariots; why should a matter of this degree not be left to the Imperial Will?"
And since he immediately issued a decree for the day of entry into the palace, they were powerless.

[1.7.3] When the Grand Empress heard this, she sank into tears. She lamented, "In the early autumn of Kyūju when I was left behind by the former Emperor, if I had vanished like the dew on the same field, left home, and fled the world, I would not be hearing such bitter news." Her father, the Minister, comforted her saying, "It appears that not obeying the world makes one a madman. The Imperial command has already been issued. There is no room to argue details. You must simply go quickly. If a prince is born, you will be called Mother of the Nation, and this old man may be looked up to as the maternal grandfather; it may be an auspicious sign. This would be the height of filial piety to help this old man."
Although he said this, she made no reply. At that time, in the course of casual handwriting practice, the Grand Empress wrote:

lg.l: Unable to sink away in these painful joints [nodes of bamboo], will I flow on like the river bamboo leaving a name unparalleled in the world?

div.p: [1.7.4] How did it leak out to the world? People spoke of it as a pathetically touching example.

[1.7.5] When the day of entry arrived, her father the Minister sent her off with exceptional ceremony regarding the attending nobles and the ritual of the departure carriage. Since the Grand Empress was reluctant to leave, she did not board quickly. Long into the night, after midnight, she was finally forced into the carriage. After entering the palace, she lived in the Reikeiden. It was a situation where she earnestly advised on government affairs. In that Imperial residence, the Shishinden, the Sages' Screen was set up. There were images of Yi Yin, Diwu Lun, Yu Shinan, Taigong Wang, the Master of Village Gate, Li Ji, Sima, Long-arms, Long-legs, and horses; there was the Demon Room, and a screen that copied strictly the figure of General Li. That the Governor of Owari, Ono no Tōfū, wrote the calligraphy for the Sages' Screen seven times seemed reasonable. On the painted screen of the Seiryōden, it is said there was a moon at dawn over distant mountains painted long ago by Kanaoka. In the past when the late Emperor was still a young lord, he had casually scribbled on it and clouded it over; seeing it exactly as it was, unchanged, she must have longed for the past of the former Emperor.

lg.l: Did I ever think, while remaining in this miserable body, I would come around again to see the moon of the same palace [clouds]?

div.p: [1.7.6] Her life during that time was unspeakably sad and touching.

[1.7.7] Then, from around the spring of the first year of Eiman, the Emperor was rumored to be unwell, and when early summer came, he became exceptionally grave. Therefore, it was rumored that the First Prince of the current Emperor, born to the daughter of the Senior Assistant Minister of the Treasury Iki no Kanemori, who was two years old, would be set up as Crown Prince; on the twenty-fifth day of the sixth month, the decree for an Imperial Prince was suddenly issued, and the abdication took place that very night, so the world seemed somewhat flustered. The experts of that time discussed it: regarding examples of child emperors in our country, Emperor Seiwa received the abdication of Emperor Montoku at age nine. Comparing that to the Duke of Zhou acting for King Cheng, facing south and governing the myriad affairs of state for a day, the maternal grandfather Lord Chūjin supported the young lord. This was the beginning of the Regency. Retired Emperor Toba ascended at five, and Retired Emperor Konoe at three. We spoke of those as "sometime," but this one is two years old. There is no precedent. To say it was tumultuous is an understatement.

[1.8.1]
Then, on the twenty-seventh day of the seventh month, the Retired Emperor finally passed away. He was twenty-three. It was like a budding flower falling. Within the jeweled blinds and brocade curtains, everyone choked with tears. That very night, he was interred at Funaokayama, north of Rendaino, to the northeast of Kōryūji. At the time of the funeral, the masses of Enryakuji and Kōfukuji started a "Tablet Placing Dispute" and engaged in mutual violence. The protocol when moving the body to the gravesite after an Emperor has passed away is that the masses of the temples of the Southern and Northern Capitals all attend, and around the gravesite, they place the tablets of their respective temples. First, as Tōdaiji is Emperor Shōmu's vow and there is no temple to dispute it, they place Tōdaiji's tablet. Next, as Kōfukuji is Lord Tankai's vow, they place Kōfukuji's tablet. For the Northern Capital, they place Enryakuji's tablet facing Kōfukuji. Next, as Onjōji is Emperor Tenmu's vow and founded by Kyōdai Kashō and Chishō Daishi, they place Onjōji's tablet. However, the masses of the Mountain Gate [Enryakuji], thinking whatever they thought, went against precedent and placed Enryakuji's tablet next to Tōdaiji, above Kōfukuji; while the masses of the Southern Capital [Nara] were debating whether to do this or that, two well-known great evil monks from the West Golden Hall of Kōfukuji named Kannon-bō and Seishi-bō were there. Kannon-bō wore a belly-guard laced with black silk and held a long sword with a short tang, and Seishi-bō wore a belly-guard laced with light green and held a great sword lacquered in black; the two ran out abruptly, cut down Enryakuji's tablet, smashed it to pieces, and shouting, "Happy is the water, the water of the Naruhaki falls; even if the sun ends, sing that it will not cease!", they entered among the masses of the Southern Capital.

[1.9.1] If the masses of the Mountain Gate committed violence, the others should have fought back, but perhaps they aimed deeply for another direction. They did not utter a word. After the Emperor passed away, even the heartless grass and trees should have appeared sorrowful, but due to the wretchedness of this disturbance, high and low alike lost their wits and scattered in all directions. Around the hour of the Horse on the twenty-ninth, it was heard that the masses of the Mountain Gate were descending on the capital in great numbers, so warriors and police officials rushed to West Sakamoto to defend, but the monks disregarded them, broke through, and burst in. Whoever suggested it, it was heard that the Cloistered Emperor had ordered the masses of the Mountain Gate to chastise the Heike, so soldiers gathered at the palace and guarded the four gate encampments. The Heike clan all rushed to gather at Rokuhara. The Cloistered Emperor also hurriedly made a royal visit to Rokuhara. Lord Kiyomori was still a Major Counselor at that time, and he was greatly afraid and agitated. Lord Komatsu [Shigemori] calmed him, saying, "For what reason would such a thing happen right now?" but the clamor of high and low was intense.
The masses of the Mountain Gate did not attack Rokuhara but pushed onto the unrelated Kiyomizu Temple and burned down every single temple building and monk's quarter. It was heard that this was to wipe away the shame of the defeat on the night of the funeral. This was because Kiyomizu Temple was a branch temple of Kōfukuji. On the morning Kiyomizu burned, someone, perhaps as a prank, wrote on a placard "The pit of fire of Kannon changed into a pool—how is that?" and stood it in front of the great gate; the next day, a return placard was posted: "Through kalpas of mysterious power, it is beyond reach."

[1.9.2] When the monks returned up the mountain, the Cloistered Emperor returned from Rokuhara. Only Lord Shigemori accompanied him. His father the Lord did not go. It was heard that this was still for caution. When Lord Shigemori returned from the escort, his father the Major Counselor said, "I feel greatly afraid of the Cloistered Emperor's visit. This is rumored because he has thought of it beforehand and given orders; you must not let down your guard with him."
Shigemori replied, "You strictly must not reveal this matter in your expression or words; showing suspicion to others is on the contrary bad. In any case, if you do not go against the Imperial Will and show mercy for the sake of the people, the gods and Three Treasures will protect you. If that is so, your person will not be in danger."
When he stood to leave, his father the Lord said, "Lord Shigemori is a severely generous person. "

[1.9.3] After the Cloistered Emperor returned, when many close associates were present before him, he said, "Well, they have started a strange rumor. I never even thought of it."
Among the sharp-witted men in the palace was one called the Monk Saikō. He was serving close by and said, "Heaven has no mouth; it speaks through people. Since the Heike are exceedingly excessive, is it not the design of Heaven? " The people whispered to each other, "This is unwise. Walls have ears; frightening, frightening. "

[1.10.1] Because of this, the date for the Emperor's coming-of-age ceremony was postponed. On the twenty-fourth day of the same twelfth month, a Prince born to Kenshunmon-in, who was then still called the Lady of the East, received the decree of Imperial Prince.

[1.10.2] When the year opened, the era was changed and named Nin'an. On the eighth day of the tenth month of that year, the Prince who received the decree last year stood as Crown Prince at the Tō-Sanjō palace. The Crown Prince was the uncle at six years old, and the Emperor was the nephew at three years old; neither fit the proper order of generations. However, in the second year of Kanna, Emperor Ichijō ascended at seven. Emperor Sanjō stood as Crown Prince at eleven. It is not that there are no precedents. Since the Emperor received the abdication at two and the Crown Prince ascended on the nineteenth day of the second month when he was barely five, the Emperor abdicated the throne and was called the New Retired Emperor. Without yet having his coming-of-age ceremony, he had the honorable title of Retired Emperor. In China and our country, this was likely the first time.

[1.10.3] On the twentieth day of the third month of the third year of Nin'an, the new Emperor ascended at the Daigokuden. That this lord took the throne appeared to be increasingly the glory of the Heike. His mother Kenshunmon-in was of the Heike clan, and specifically the younger sister of the Lay Priest Chancellor's wife, the Lady of the Second Rank. Also, the Taira Major Counselor Lord Tokitada was the Empress's elder brother, so he was the Emperor's maternal relative. He appeared to be a minister holding power both inside and outside. Rank promotions and appointments were entirely at this Lord Tokitada's will. It was like Yang Guozhong prospering when Yang Guifei was favored. His worldly reputation and the sparkle of the times were splendid. Since the Lay Priest Chancellor discussed all matters of state great and small, the people of the time called him the Taira Chancellor.

[1.11.1]
Then, on the sixteenth day of the seventh month of the first year of Kaō, the Cloistered Emperor became a monk. Even after becoming a monk, since he administered the myriad affairs of state, there was no difference in the retired emperor's administration. For the nobles, courtiers, and upper and lower North Face guards employed closely in the retired emperor's palace, the ranks and stipends were all more than they deserved. However, since it is the nature of the human heart, they were still not satisfied, and friends who were not strangers whispered together in gatherings: "Ah, if that person died, that province would open up; if that person were lost, I would get that post. " The Cloistered Emperor also said privately, "Although there have been many who quelled enemies of the court since ancient times, there has never been a case like this. When Sadamori and Hidesato struck Masakado, when Yoriyoshi destroyed Sadatō and Munetō, and when Yoshiie attacked Takehira and Iehira, the rewards given did not exceed provincial governorships. That Kiyomori behaves as he pleases is indeed improper. This too is because the world has reached its end and the King's Law is exhausted."
Though he said this, since there was no occasion for it, there was no reprimand. Since the Heike also did not particularly resent the court, the root of the disturbance in the world began on the sixteenth day of the tenth month of the second year of Kaō; Lord Komatsu's second son, the New Captain of the Third Rank Lord Sukemori, who was then still Governor of Echizen and thirteen years old, was out when snow was falling lightly. The withered fields were truly scenic, so taking about thirty young samurai, he rode out to Rendaino, Murasakino, and the Ukon riding grounds, set many hawks, flushed out quail and skylarks, hunted all day, and returned to Rokuhara at twilight. The Regent at that time was Lord Matsudono, and he was returning from the Nakamikado Higashinotōin palace. Intending to enter through the Ikuhōmon gate, he went south on Higashinotōin and west on Ōimikado. Sukemori Ason met the Regent's procession nose-to-nose at Ōimikado Inokuma. The attendants called out, "Who is it? This is outrageous. It is a procession; get down from your mounts, get down."
But he was overly proud and spirited, treating the world as if it were not the world; moreover, the samurai he brought were all youths under twenty, and not one understood propriety or manners. Not caring that it was the Regent's procession, without any etiquette of dismounting, they tried to break through and pass; it was dark, and the attendants did not know at all that it was the Lay Priest's grandson. Or perhaps a few knew, but feigning ignorance, they pulled Sukemori Ason and the others off their horses, starting with Sukemori, and subjected them to considerable shame. Sukemori Ason crawled back to Rokuhara and complained of this to his grandfather, the Lay Priest Chancellor; the Lay Priest became very angry and said, "Even if it is the Regent, he should defer to Jōkai's family; that he gave shame without hesitation to a child is a matter of regret. From such things, one is despised by others. Unless I make him realize this, it will not do. I would take revenge on the Regent."
But Lord Shigemori said, "This should not matter in the slightest. If we were despised by Genji like Yorimasa or Mitsumoto, it would truly be a shame for the clan. That those calling themselves Shigemori's children met the Regent's procession and did not dismount is surely rude."
He summoned the samurai involved in the incident and said, "From now on, understand this well; think that you would like to apologize to the Regent for your discourtesy."
And he returned.

[1.11.2] After that, the Lay Priest Chancellor did not consult Lord Komatsu but gathered rough country samurai who thought there was nothing more fearful than the Lay Priest's command, led by Nanba and Seno, sixty men in all, and said, "On the coming twenty-first day, the Regent is to go out to determine the Emperor's coming-of-age ceremony. Lie in wait anywhere, cut off the topknots of the vanguard attendants, and wipe away Sukemori's shame. " The Regent did not dream of this; intending to stay in the palace office for a while for the determination of the Emperor's coming-of-age, capping, and appointments next year, he dressed more formally than usual, and intending to enter through the Taikenmon gate, went west on Nakamikado. Near Inokuma Horikawa, the Rokuhara soldiers, over three hundred horsemen in armor, lay in wait, surrounded the Regent, and raised a war cry all at once from front and rear. The vanguard attendants who had made today a gala occasion were chased here and cornered there, pulled from their horses, scattered and beaten, and one by one their topknots were cut off. Among the ten attendants, the topknot of the Right Officer of the Guards Takemoto was also cut. Among them, when cutting the topknot of the Chamberlain Takanori, they said, "Do not think of this as your topknot; think of it as your master's topknot."
They included this message as they cut. After that, they poked bow tips into the carriage, tore down the blinds, cut the ox's crupper and breast-strap, scattered everything, raised a shout of triumph, and returned to Rokuhara. The Lay Priest said, "Admirable."
Beside the carriage was a servant from Inaba called Kunihisamaru of Toba; though of low rank, he was a compassionate man, and weeping, he helped with the carriage and returned it to the Nakamikado palace. Suppressing tears with his ceremonial sleeves, the misery of the return procession was beyond description. Leaving aside Lord Tankai of the Taishokan, since Lord Chūjin and Lord Shōsen, we have never heard of a Regent or Chancellor meeting such an experience. This was the beginning of the Heike's evil deeds.

[1.11.3] Lord Komatsu was greatly agitated. The samurai who had gone were all punished. "Even if the Lay Priest ordered some strange thing, why did you not show even a dream of it to Shigemori? Generally, Sukemori is outrageous; sandalwood is fragrant from its two seed leaves. A person already twelve or thirteen should behave knowing propriety, but to display such boorishness and give the Lay Priest a bad name—the height of unfilial conduct lies with you alone."
And he expelled him to Ise Province for a while. Therefore, it was heard that both sovereign and subject admired this General.

[1.12.1] Because of this, the determination of the Emperor's coming-of-age was postponed for that day. On the twenty-fifth day, the determination of the coming-of-age took place in the Retired Emperor's Hall. Since the Regent could not continue as he was, on the ninth day of the twelfth month he received a concurrent decree, and on the fourteenth day was promoted to Grand Minister of State. Immediately on the seventeenth day there was a celebration, but the world looked on bitterly.

[1.12.2] Thus this year also ended. In the new year, on the fifth day of the first month of the third year of Kaō, the Emperor's coming-of-age took place. On the thirteenth day, there was a formal visit to the parents. The Cloistered Emperor and the In-Empress waited to receive him; how lovely they must have thought his appearance in his first crown. The Lay Priest Chancellor's daughter entered as a consort. She was fifteen. She was treated as the adopted child of the Cloistered Emperor.

[1.12.3] Around that time, the Great Lord of Myōon-in, who was then Minister of the Center and General of the Left, resigned his post as General. At that time, it was heard that the Major Counselor of Tokudaiji, Lord Sanesada, was appropriate for the position. Also, the Middle Counselor of Kazan-in, Lord Kanemasa, had a desire for it. Besides them, the third son of the late Fujiwara Middle Counselor Ienari of Nakamikado, the New Major Counselor Lord Narichika, applied earnestly. Since the Retired Emperor's mood was favorable, he began various prayers. First, he secluded one hundred monks at Hachiman and had them read the Great Perfection of Wisdom Sutra for seven days; in the midst of this, three turtledoves flew from the direction of Otokoyama to the mandarin orange tree in front of the Kōra Myōjin shrine, fought each other, and died. The dove is the primary messenger of the Great Bodhisattva Hachiman. Thinking there was no such strange event at the shrine temple, the superintendent of the time, the Seal of the Law Masakiyo, reported it. Divination was performed at the Department of Divinities. It foretold a disturbance in the realm. They said, "However, it is not a caution for the ruler, but a caution for a subject. " The New Major Counselor did not fear this, and since there were many eyes by day, he walked every night from his residence at Nakamikado Karasuma to the Upper Shrine of Kamo for seven nights continuously. On the night completing the seven, he returned to his residence, lay down in fatigue, and dreamed he went to the Upper Shrine of Kamo, pushed open the doors of the main hall, and heard a voice solemnly say:

lg.l: Do not resent the wind of the Kamo River, cherry blossoms; strictly, I could not stop the falling.

div.p:
[1.12.4]
The New Major Counselor still did not feel fear; he secluded a certain holy man at the Upper Shrine of Kamo, set up an altar in the hollow of a cedar tree behind the main hall, and had him perform the Dakini ritual for one hundred days; but thunder fell on that great cedar, lightning fire blazed up intensely, and the shrine precincts seemed in danger, so many shrine servants ran to gather and extinguished it. When they tried to drive out the holy man performing that heterodox ritual, he said, "I have a great vow of one hundred days of seclusion at this shrine; today is the seventy-fifth day. I absolutely will not leave."
And he did not move. When the shrine family reported this to the palace, a decree was issued: "Simply expel him according to the law. " At that time, the shrine servants pressed a white staff against the holy man's neck and drove him out south of First Avenue. They say the gods do not accept impropriety; perhaps because this Major Counselor prayed for a generalship that was not his lot, such strange events occurred.

[1.12.5] The appointments at that time were not by the Retired Emperor's design, nor by the judgment of the Regent or Chancellor, but entirely according to the Heike, so Tokudaiji and Kazan-in were not appointed; the Lay Priest Chancellor's heir Lord Komatsu was General of the Right, but he moved to the Left, and the second son Munemori was a Middle Counselor but surpassed several seniors and joined the Right; there was nothing to say. Among them, Lord Tokudaiji was the First Major Counselor, of noble lineage, a hero, talented, and head of his house, so that he was passed over was a matter of regret. People whispered privately that he would surely become a monk, but intending to watch the state of the world for a while, he resigned as Major Counselor and it was heard he stayed in seclusion.

[1.12.6] The New Major Counselor Lord Narichika said, "If I were passed over for Tokudaiji or Kazan-in, what could I do? To be passed over for the second son of the Heike is indeed uneasy. This too is the doing of one who has everything his way. Somehow I will destroy the Heike and achieve my true desire."
It was frightening that he said this. His father the Lord only reached Middle Counselor. As the youngest child, he rose to Senior Second Rank and Major Counselor, was given many great provinces, and his sons and retainers boasted of Imperial favor. What lack caused him to conceive such a mind? This seemed entirely the work of heavenly demons. In Heiji, as the Echigo Captain, he sided with Lord Nobuyori and was about to be executed, but Lord Komatsu pleaded in various ways and saved his life. However, forgetting that debt, he prepared weapons in a place with no outsiders, gathered soldiers, and besides that preparation did nothing else.

[1.12.7] Shishigatani, at the foot of Higashiyama, continued behind Miidera and was a formidable fortress. There was a mountain villa of the Administrator Shunkan. They constantly gathered there and spun plots to destroy the Heike. Once, the Cloistered Emperor also visited. The Seal of the Law Jōken, son of the late Minor Counselor Lay Priest Shinzei, served as attendant. At the banquet that night, when they discussed this matter with the Seal of the Law Jōken, he said, "Ah, how wretched; many people have heard. It will leak out immediately and become a major crisis for the realm."
When he made a great commotion, the New Major Counselor changed his expression, stood up suddenly, and catching his hunting robe sleeve on a wine bottle [heiji] standing before him, pulled it over; the Cloistered Emperor asked, "What is that?" The Major Counselor turned back and said, " The Heiji [Heike] have fallen. " The Cloistered Emperor smiled and said, "Someone enter and perform Sarugaku."
Taira magistrate Yasuyori entered and said, "Ah, there are too many heiji [Heike/bottles] here, so I am drunk. " Administrator Shunkan said, "Well then, what shall we do with them?" The Monk Saikō said, "There is nothing like taking their heads."
And he took the neck of the bottle and went in. The Seal of the Law Jōken was so appalled he could say nothing at all. Reflecting on it, these were fearful matters. Who were the conspirators? The Ōmi Captain Lay Priest Renjō (lay name Narimasa), the Hosshōji Administrator Shunkan, Governor of Yamashiro Motokane, Ministry of Ceremonial Senior Assistant Minister Masatsuna, Taira Magistrate Yasuyori, Sō Magistrate Nobufusa, New Taira Magistrate Sukeyuki, and starting with the Settsu Genji Tada no Kurando Yukitsuna, many of the North Face warriors conspired.

[1.13.1] This Administrator of Hosshōji was the grandson of the Kyōgoku Genji Major Counselor Lord Masatoshi and the son of the Seal of the Law Kanga of Kidera. His grandfather the Major Counselor was not of a house that took up the bow, but he was a very ill-tempered man; he would not let people pass easily in front of his residence at Sanjō Bōmon Kyōgoku, constantly standing at the middle gate, gnashing his teeth, and being angry. Perhaps because he was the grandson of such a person, this Shunkan, though a monk, was a man of fierce and arrogant heart, and thus participated in a useless rebellion. The New Major Counselor Lord Narichika called Tada no Kurando Yukitsuna and said, "I rely on you as the general of one side. If we accomplish this matter, you may request any province or manor. First, for bow-bag material."
And he sent him fifty rolls of white cloth.

[1.13.2] On the fifth day of the third month of the third year of Angen, Lord Myōon-in transferred to Grand Minister of State; in his place, surpassing Major Counselor Lord Sadafusa, Lord Komatsu became Minister of the Center. Being a General and Minister was splendid. Immediately a great banquet was held. It was heard that the guest of honor was the Minister of the Left of Ōimikado, Lord Tsunemune. Although the head of the clan was the priority, there was hesitation due to the precedent of his father, the Evil Minister of the Left of Uji.

[1.13.3] There were no North Face warriors in ancient times. Since they were first established in the time of Retired Emperor Shirakawa, there were many guards. Tametoshi, Morishige, and from childhood Senjumaru and Imainumaru—these were sharp men without equal. In the time of Retired Emperor Toba as well, Suenori and Sueyori, father and son, were both employed by the court and had occasions to transmit messages, but they all behaved within their station; however, the North Face warriors of this time were excessively extravagant, did not regard nobles and courtiers as anything, and had no propriety or manners. Some rose from Lower North Face to Upper North Face, and from Upper North Face were permitted into the Courtiers' Hall. Because it was conducted like this, arrogant hearts developed, and they participated in useless rebellions. Among them were Moromitsu and Narikage, who served the late Minor Counselor Lay Priest Shinzei. Moromitsu was an official of Awa Province, and Narikage was a man of the capital; they were lowly servants of base root. They were employed as foot soldiers or servants, but because they were clever, Moromitsu became a Lieutenant of the Left Gate Guards and Narikage a Lieutenant of the Right Gate Guards, and the two became Gate Guard Lieutenants at once. When Shinzei met his trouble, both became monks, called Lay Priest of the Left Gate Saikō and Lay Priest of the Right Gate Saikei; even after becoming monks, they were custodians of the Retired Emperor's storehouse.

[1.13.4] That Saikō had a son named Morotaka. He was also a sharp man, rose to Lieutenant of the Fifth Rank in the Police, and on the twenty-ninth day of the twelfth month of the first year of Angen, at the demon-expelling ceremony appointments, he was made Governor of Kaga. While conducting provincial affairs, he acted illegally and improperly, confiscated the manor lands of shrines and temples and powerful families, and did all manner of scattered [violent] things. Even if he were separated by the traces of Duke Shao, he should have administered peacefully, but he behaved as he pleased; in the summer of the second year, the Governor Morotaka's younger brother, the Magistrate Kondō Morotsune, was appointed Deputy of Kaga. At the beginning of the Deputy's arrival, there was a mountain temple called Ugawa near the provincial capital. The monks had boiled water and were bathing, when he intruded, chased them out, bathed himself, pulled down his miscellaneous followers, and had them wash horses and such. The monks were angry and said, "From ancient times, people of the province have not entered this place. Quickly follow precedent and stop the intrusion."
He said, "The previous Deputies were cowardly and thus despised. The current Deputy shall not be so. Just follow the law."
While he said this, the monks tried to drive out the provincial men. The provincial men used this as an excuse and tried to break in. While they hit and struggled, they broke the leg of a horse the Deputy Morotsune treasured. After that, both sides took up bows, arrows, and weapons, and fought shooting and cutting for several hours. Perhaps thinking he could not win, the Deputy retreated at nightfall. After that, he gathered the officials of the province, and with a force of over one thousand horsemen, attacked Ugawa and burned down every single monk's quarter. Ugawa is a branch temple of Hakusan. Who were the old monks who stepped forward to complain of this? Chishaku, Gakumyō, Hōdai-bō, Shōchi, Gakuon, and Tosa Ajari stepped forward. The masses of the three shrines and eight temples of Hakusan all rose up, a total force of over two thousand men, and on the evening of the ninth day of the seventh month, pressed near Deputy Morotsune's mansion. Today the sun set. Deciding on battle for tomorrow, they did not attack that day but shouted war cries. The autumn wind blowing the dew flipped the sleeves of their armor, and the lightning illuminating the clouds shone on the stars of their helmets. Perhaps thinking he could not win, the Deputy fled by night to the capital. At the hour of the Hare [6 am] the next day, they attacked and raised a war cry. There was no sound inside the castle. When they sent someone in to look, he reported they had all fled. The masses withdrew, powerless. "Then let us appeal to the Mountain Gate," they said, and adorning the shrine palanquin [mikoshi] of the Middle Shrine of Hakusan, they carried it up to Mount Hiei. Around the hour of the Horse on the twelfth day of the eighth month, just as the shrine palanquin of Hakusan arrived at East Sakamoto of Mount Hiei, thunder rang out heavily from the direction of the northern provinces and rolled up toward the capital. White snow fell and buried the ground, covering the mountaintop and the capital, and even the treetops of the evergreen mountains turned white.

[1.14.1] They placed the shrine palanquin in the Marōdo [Guest] Shrine. The Guest is the Hakusan Myōri Gongen. Speaking of which, they are father and son. Without knowing the success or failure of the previous matter, the joy of this life lay only in this. It surpassed Urashima meeting his descendant of the seventh generation, and exceeded the one in the womb seeing the father on Spirit Vulture Peak. Three thousand monks followed one after another, the shrine servants of the seven shrines lined their sleeves, and the constant offerings of Dharma and prayers were beyond words.

[1.14.2] The masses of the Mountain Gate reported that the Governor of Kaga Morotaka should be exiled and the Deputy Kondō Magistrate Morotsune should be imprisoned. Because the judgment was slow, the nobles and courtiers said, "Ah, there should be a quick judgment; from ancient times the appeals of the Mountain Gate are different from others; the Minister of the Treasury Tamefusa and the Dazai-no-Gon-no-Sotsu Suenaka were heavy ministers of the court, but due to the appeal of the Mountain Gate, they were exiled. How much more so for Morotaka; should he be considered a matter of consequence? Is there any need for detail?"
They agreed, but as it is said, "Great ministers value their stipends and do not remonstrate; lesser subjects fear crime and do not speak," so everyone closed their mouths. "The water of the Kamo River, the dice of Sugoroku, and the Mountain Monks—these are the things that do not follow my heart," Retired Emperor Shirakawa is said to have spoken. In the time of Retired Emperor Toba, when Heisenji in Echizen was attached to the Mountain Gate, because of his deep faith in that mountain, he issued a decree saying "Take wrong as right," and the In-decree was handed down. As Lord Masafusa, the Governor of Ōe, said, "If they shake the shrine palanquin at the camp gates and appeal, how will the ruler handle it?" He replied, "Indeed, the appeal of the Mountain Gate is hard to ignore. "

[1.14.3] On the second day of the third month of the second year of Kahō, when the Governor of Mino Minamoto no Yoshitsuna Ason demolished the newly established manor of that province, he killed En'ō, a long-resident monk of the Mountain. Because of this, the shrine officials of Hiyoshi and temple officials of Enryakuji, over thirty in all, presented a petition and came to the camp gates, but the Regent of Go-Nijō ordered the Yamato Genji Junior Assistant Minister of Central Affairs Yoriharu to defend against them. Yoriharu's retainers loosed arrows. Eight people were shot dead on the spot, over ten were wounded, and the shrine and other officials scattered in four directions. It was heard that the upper ranks of the Mountain Gate were coming down to the capital to report the details, so warriors and police officials rushed to West Sakamoto and turned them all back.

[1.14.4]
At the Mountain Gate, since the judgment was delayed, they shook up the shrine palanquins of the seven shrines at the Main Hall, and before them read the Great Perfection of Wisdom Sutra for seven days to curse the Regent. The officiating monk for the final day was the Seal of the Law Chūin, then still called Chūin Gubu; he ascended the high seat, struck the bell, and in the words of the pronouncement said, "Gods whom we have raised from the two seed leaves of the rape plant, loose one whistling arrow at the Regent of Go-Nijō and strike him, Great Hachiōji Gongen."
Thus he prayed loudly. Immediately that night there was a strange event. The sound of a whistling arrow came from the Hachiōji hall, and people saw in dreams that it went toward the royal castle. The next morning, when they raised the lattice of the Regent's palace, a branch of shikimi wet with dew, as if just brought from the mountain, was standing there; it was terrifying. Soon, saying it was the punishment of the Mountain King, the Regent of Go-Nijō caught a grave illness; his mother, the Great Lord's wife, lamented greatly, disguised her appearance, imitated a lowly woman, secluded herself at the Hiyoshi shrine, and prayed for seven days and nights. For the public prayer, one hundred performances of field music, one hundred items, horse racing, mounted archery, one hundred wrestling matches, one hundred lectures on the Benevolent Kings, one hundred lectures on the Medicine Buddha, one hundred one-and-a-half-hand-span Medicine Buddhas, one life-size Medicine Buddha, and statues of Shakyamuni and Amida were created and dedicated. Also, in her heart, she made three vows. Since they were matters of her heart, how could people know? But the strange thing was, on the night completing the seven, among the many pilgrims at the Hachiōji shrine, a child medium who had come all the way from Mutsu suddenly fainted around midnight. They carried him far out and prayed, and soon he revived, and immediately stood up and danced. People looked on with a sense of wonder. After dancing for about half an hour, the Mountain King possessed him, and the oracle was terrifying. "Sentient beings, listen well. The wife of the Great Lord has secluded herself before me today for seven days. She has three vows. One is: Save the Regent's life this time; if you do so, I will mingle with the ugly ones in the lower shrine and serve morning and evening for one thousand days. For the wife of the Great Lord, who passes her time without regard for the world, to be lost in the path of thinking of her child, forgetting gloom, and saying she will mingle with wretched ugly ones and serve morning and evening for one thousand days—think of this as truly pitiful. Two is: I will build a corridor from the Hatodono of the Great Shrine to the Hachiōji Shrine. Thinking it painful for the three thousand monks during rain or shine when visiting the shrine, if a corridor is built, how splendid it will be. Three is: If you save the Regent's life this time, I will conduct the Lotus Sutra Dialogue Lecture at the Hachiōji Shrine every day without fail. None of these are foolish, but the first two can be dispensed with. The daily Lotus Sutra Dialogue Lecture is truly desirable. However, the recent appeal was a matter that should have been very easy, but there was no judgment, and shrine servants were shot dead and wounded; weeping, they came to appeal, and it was so wretched that I do not feel I can forget it for any generation. Moreover, the arrows that struck them stand in the skin of my Manifestation. See if this is truth or falsehood."
Saying this, he bared his shoulder, and under the left armpit, a hole the size of the mouth of a large earthenware cup was visible. "Since this is so wretched, no matter what you say, the final outcome will not be granted. If the Lotus Sutra Dialogue Lecture is certain, I will extend his life by three years. If you think that is insufficient, I am powerless."
And the Mountain King ascended. Since the mother had told no one of the vows, wondering who had leaked them, she did not doubt at all.
