Because the oracle matched exactly the things in her heart, she felt it pierce her liver and thought it particularly holy; weeping, she said, "Even for one day or half an hour, I would be grateful; how much more so that you extend his life by three years—it is appropriate."
And weeping, she descended. Hurrying into the capital, she donated the place called Tanaka Manor in Kii Province, a domain of the Regent, to the Hachiōji Shrine in perpetuity. From then on, we hear that the Lotus Sutra Dialogue Lecture has continued every day without fail until the present age.

[1.14.5] While this was happening, the Go-Nijō Regent's illness lightened, and he became as before. While high and low rejoiced, three years passed like a dream, and it became the second year of Eichō. On the twenty-first day of the sixth month, the Go-Nijō Regent developed a bad boil at his hairline and took to his bed; on the twenty-seventh day of the same month, he finally passed away at the age of thirty-eight. Though he was a fierce-hearted and strongly reasonable man, when matters became truly urgent, he regretted his life. Indeed, it must be regretted. It is sad that he passed away before the Great Lord without even reaching forty. Although there is no rule that the father must die first, it is the custom to follow the law of birth and death; even the World-Honored One of perfect virtue and the Bodhisattvas of the ten stages are powerless in these matters; since the Mountain King of full compassion is a means to benefit beings, it does not seem there would be blame.

[1.15.1]
Then, although the masses of the Mountain Gate appealed repeatedly that the Governor of Kaga Morotaka be exiled and the Deputy Kondō Magistrate Morotsune be imprisoned, since there was no judgment, they stopped the Hiyoshi festival, and on the thirteenth day of the fourth month of the third year of Angen at the first point of the hour of the Dragon [8 am], they adorned the shrine palanquins of the three shrines of Jūzenji, Marōdo, and Hachiōji, and shook them [carried them violently] to the camp gates. At Kudari-matsu, Kire-zutsumi, Kamo Riverbed, Tadasu, Umetada, Yanagihara, and around Tōhoku-in, the white-robed monks, shrine servants, and palace workers filled the way, their numbers unknown, and the palanquins entered westward on First Avenue. The divine treasures shone in the heavens, and people were startled, wondering if the sun and moon had fallen to earth. Because of this, the generals of both Genji and Heike clans were ordered to fortify the four gate encampments and defend against the monks. For the Heike, Lord Shigemori, the Minister of the Center and General of the Left, with a force of over three thousand horsemen, fortified the three gates of Yōmeimon, Taikenmon, and Ikuhōmon on the Omiya side. His younger brothers Munemori, Tomomori, Shigehira, and uncles Yorimori, Norimori, Tsunemori, and others fortified the southwest encampments. For the Genji, the Guardian of the Palace Grounds Lord Yorimasa of the Third Rank, with the Watanabe Provincial Governor as his core, and a force of barely three hundred horsemen, fortified the north gate, the Nuidono encampment. The place was wide, the force was small, and they appeared sparse.

[1.15.2] Because the force was small, the masses tried to bring the palanquins in through the north gate, the Nuidono encampment. Lord Yorimasa was a man of character, so he dismounted, removed his helmet, and bowed to the palanquins. His soldiers all did the same. He sent a messenger among the monks to convey a message. That messenger was a man called Chōshichi Tonau of Watanabe. Tonau that day wore a hitatare of rough silk, armor with small cherry blossom patterns in yellow, a copper-fitted sword, white-feathered arrows on his back, a lacquered rattan bow under his arm; removing his helmet and hanging it on a high cord, he reverently addressed the front of the palanquin: "Lord Yorimasa of the Third Rank says to the monks: The justice of the Mountain Gate's appeal this time goes without saying. Even from a distance, he feels regret that the judgment is delayed. Therefore, bringing in the palanquins requires no detailed discussion. However, Yorimasa has a small force. Moreover, if you enter through a gate that is opened to let you in, the urchins of the capital might say 'The masses of the Mountain Gate wanted to pass through', and would that not be a difficulty for later days? If I let the palanquins in, it resembles disobeying the decree. Yet if I defend against them, I who have bowed my head to the Medicine King and Mountain King for years will part from the way of the bow and arrow after today. Saying this or saying that, either way seems difficult to cure. The east camp is fortified by Lord Komatsu with a large force. Perhaps you should enter through that camp."
Because he sent this message, and Tonau defended with these words, the shrine servants and palace workers wavered for a while.

[1.15.3] Among the young monks, many said, "Why should we care about that? Just bring the palanquins in through this camp!" but among the old monks, the Kenmotsu of Settsu, Gōun, known as the foremost debater of the Three Pagodas, stepped forward and said, "What is said is most reasonable. If we put the palanquins in front and make our appeal, we should break through a large force to be heard of in future generations. In particular, this Lord Yorimasa is of the direct legitimate line of the Genji since Prince Rokuson, and since taking up the bow and arrow, we have not heard of his failure. Generally, not limited to military arts, he also excels in the way of poetry. During the reign of Retired Emperor Konoe, at an impromptu poetry gathering, the topic 'Flowers in the Deep Mountains' was given; while people struggled to compose, this Lord Yorimasa composed:

lg.span: The cherry tree which did not seem to be a treetop of the deep mountains has revealed itself in flowers.

div.p:
[1.15.4] For such a graceful man who composed a famous poem and received Imperial praise, how can we mercilessly give him shame when facing him? Turn back this palanquin."
When he proposed this, the thousands of monks, from the vanguard to the rear guard, all agreed it was most right. So, placing the palanquins in front, they tried to enter through the Taikenmon gate at the head of the east camp, but violence suddenly broke out, and the warriors shot scatteringly. Many arrows struck even the palanquin of Jūzenji. Shrine servants and palace workers were shot dead, and many monks were wounded. The voices of screaming and shouting could be heard even to the Brahma Heaven, and it seemed the Earth Deity was startled. The monks abandoned the palanquins at the camp gate and, weeping, returned up the mountain.

[1.15.3] The young monks said, "Why should there be any hesitation? Just bring the Sacred Palanquin in through this camp!" Although there were many of this group who spoke thus, among the old monks, the Incumbent Gōun of Settsu, known as the foremost debater of the Three Pagodas, stepped forward and spoke: "What you say is most reasonable. However, if we place the Sacred Palanquin at the front and make a lawsuit, breaking through a large force, it will surely affect our reputation in future generations. In particular, this Lord Yorimasa is of the direct legitimate lineage of the Genji since the Sixth Grandson King, and since taking up the bow and arrow, we have not yet heard of any failure on his part. Furthermore, he is not limited to martial arts, but also excels in the Way of Poetry. During the reign of Emperor Konoe, when there was an impromptu poetry gathering with the topic 'Flowers in the Deep Mountains,' and people were struggling to compose, this Lord Yorimasa,

lg.span: The cherry trees, whose treetops were indistinguishable among the trees of the deep mountains, have revealed themselves in their blossoms.

div.p:
[1.15.4] composed this famous poem; to such a gentle man who received imperial praise, how could we heartlessly give shame at this moment? Turn this Sacred Palanquin back!"
When he argued thus, the thousands of monks, from the vanguard to the rearguard, all agreed, saying, "Right, right." So, placing the Sacred Palanquin in front, they tried to enter from the Taiken Gate at the head of the eastern camp, but violence suddenly broke out, and the warriors shot scattered arrows. Many arrows also struck the Palanquin of Jūzenji. Shrine servants and shrine officials were shot dead, and many monks suffered wounds. The voices of screaming and shouting were heard even in the Brahma Heaven, and it felt as though the Earth Deity must have been startled. The monks abandoned the Sacred Palanquin at the head of the camp and, weeping, climbed back up to the main mountain.

[1.16.1] Orders were given to the Chamberlain and Minor Controller of the Left Kanemitsu, and a council of nobles was suddenly held in the courtyard. In the seventh month of the fourth year of Hōan, when the Sacred Palanquin entered the capital, orders were given to the Abbot, and it was placed in the Sekizan Shrine. Again, in the fourth month of the fourth year of Hōen, when the Sacred Palanquin entered the capital, orders were given to the Administrator of Gion, and it was placed in the Gion Shrine. Saying that this time should follow the precedent of Hōen, orders were given to the Administrator of Gion, Provisional Senior Vicar Chōken, and upon the lighting of lamps, it was placed in the Gion Shrine. The arrows standing in the Sacred Palanquin were pulled out by Shinto priests. The fact that the monks of the Mountain Gate have shaken the Sacred Palanquin of Hiyoshi at the camp head has happened six times from the Eikyū era down to Jishō. Although warriors were summoned to defend each time, the shooting of the Sacred Palanquin is considered the first instance of such an act. "If the Holy Spirit produces anger, disasters will fill the crossroads, it is said. Fearful, fearful."
Thus people spoke to one another.

[1.16.2] Around midnight on the same 14th day, it was heard that the monks of the Mountain Gate were descending to the capital again, so in the middle of the night the Emperor boarded a palanquin and made a royal visit to the Retired Emperor's palace, Hōjūji-dono. The Empress boarded a carriage and made a procession. The Minister of Komatsu, wearing ordinary court dress, bore arrows and served in attendance. His heir, the Provisional Assistant Master of the Left Division Major General Koremori, wearing formal court dress, bore a flat quiver and attended. Starting with the Regent, the Prime Minister and the nobles below him, and the courtiers, all rushed to attend, vying with one another. In general, the high and low of the capital, and the upper and lower classes within the palace, made a tremendous noise and clamor. At the Mountain Gate, because arrows had stood in the Sacred Palanquin, shrine servants and officials had been shot dead, and many monks had suffered wounds, the three thousand monks held a council together to burn away everything—the Great Shrine, the Second Shrine and below, the Lecture Hall, the Central Hall, leaving not a single building of the various halls—and to mingle with the mountains and fields. Hearing that there would be a judgment regarding the monks' complaints, the upper ranks of the Mountain Gate climbed the mountain to inform the monks of the details, but the monks got angry and turned everyone back from West Sakamoto.

[1.16.3] Major Counselor Taira no Tokitada, who was at that time still the Captain of the Left Gate Guards, stood as the High Commissioner. The Three Pagodas met in the garden of the Great Lecture Hall, intending to seize the High Commissioner and twist him about. "Knock off his wrinkled cap, bind his body, and sink him in the lake!" Thus they debated. It seemed it would come to this, but Lord Tokitada said, "Please quiet down for a moment. I have something to say to the assembly of monks."
Saying this, he took a small inkstone and folding paper from his bosom, wrote one stroke, and sent it into the midst of the monks. When they opened and looked at it, it was written: "That the assembly of monks commits reckless evil is the act of the Devil. That the enlightened King adds prohibitions is the protection of the Buddha (Sugata). " Seeing this, they did not go so far as to twist him about; all agreed "Right, right," and descended to their valleys and entered their quarters. Lord Tokitada, who with one paper and one phrase quieted the anger of the three thousand monks of the Three Pagodas and escaped public and private shame, was indeed impressive. People had thought that the monks of the Mountain Gate were only about noisy uprisings, but they were impressed that the monks also knew reason.

[1.16.4] On the 20th day of the same month, with Provisional Middle Counselor of Kazan-in Tadachika as High Commissioner, the Governor of Kaga, Morotaka, was finally stripped of his post and exiled to Idota in Owari. The Deputy Judge Moritsune was imprisoned. Also, the six warriors who shot the Sacred Palanquin on the past 13th day were sentenced to prison. Lieutenant of the Left Gate Guards Fujiwara Masazumi, Lieutenant of the Right Gate Guards Masasue, Lieutenant of the Left Gate Guards Ōe Iekane, Lieutenant of the Right Gate Guards Ōe Iekuni, Lieutenant of the Left Military Guards Kiyohara Yasuie, and Lieutenant of the Right Military Guards Kiyohara Yasutomo; these were all retainers of the Lord of Komatsu.

[1.16.5] On the 28th day of the same fourth month, around the Hour of the Boar (10 PM), a fire broke out from Higuchi Tominokōji, and since the southeast wind was blowing violently, much of the capital was burned. Flames like great cartwheels flew diagonally across three to five blocks toward the northwest; to call it fearful would be an understatement. The Chigusa Palace of Imperial Prince Tomohira, the Kōbai Palace of the Kitano Tenjin, the Haimatsu Palace of Tachibana no Hayanari, the Demon Palace, the Takamatsu Palace, the Kamoi Palace, the Higashi Sanjō Palace, the Kan'in Palace of Minister Fuyutsugu, the Horikawa Palace of Lord Shōsen—beginning with these, more than thirty famous places of past and present, and even sixteen residences of court nobles, were burned. Besides those, the houses of courtiers and grandees were beyond counting. Eventually, it blew onto the Imperial Palace; beginning with the Suzaku Gate, the Ōten Gate, the Kaishō Gate, the Great Hall of State (Daigokuden), the Burakuin, the various offices, the eight ministries, and the government quarters became ground of ash and cinders within a single hour. The diaries of families and the documents of generations, the seven rarities and ten thousand treasures, all turned to dust and ash. How great was the cost of that time? The number of people burned to death was several hundred; the cattle and horses were numberless. This was not a mere accident; it was said to be the reprimand of the Mountain King, and it appeared in people's dreams that large monkeys, two or three thousand of them, came down from Mt. Hiei, torches in hand, and burned the capital. The Great Hall of State first burned in the 18th year of Jōgan, during the reign of Emperor Seiwa; thus, on the 3rd day of the first month of the 19th year, the enthronement of Retired Emperor Yōzei took place in the Burakuin. Construction began on the 9th day of the fourth month of the first year of Genkei, and it was completed on the 8th day of the tenth month of the second year. In the reign of Retired Emperor Go-Reizei, on the 26th day of the second month of the fifth year of Tenki, it burned again. Although construction began on the 14th day of the eighth month of the fourth year of Jiryaku, it was not completed before Retired Emperor Go-Reizei passed away. In the reign of Retired Emperor Go-Sanjō, it was completed on the 15th day of the fourth month of the fourth year of Enkyū; scholars offered poems, and musicians played music to mark the moving of the Emperor. Now it has become the end of the world, and the power of the country has entirely declined, so after that it was finally never rebuilt.

[2.1.1]
On the fifth day of the fifth month of the first year of Jishō, the Tendai Abbot, Archbishop Myōun, was suspended from official duties; furthermore, the Chamberlain acting as Imperial Messenger recalled the principal image of Nyoirin and dismissed his serving monks. Already, officers of the Police Commission were attached to him, and he was summoned as the ringleader of the monks who had recently shaken the Sacred Palanquin at the Palace. There was a manor belonging to the Abbot's quarters in the province of Kaga. Because the Governor, Morotaka, had suspended and abolished this, out of long-held resentment, Myōun had persuaded the monks to file a lawsuit. Because the priest Saikō and his son slanderously reported that this had already reached the level of a grave crisis for the Imperial House, the Retired Emperor was greatly displeased. It was rumored that he would be punished with a heavy sentence. Since the Retired Emperor's mood was bad, Myōun returned the seal and keys and resigned as Abbot. On the 11th day of the same month, the Seventh Prince of the Toba Retired Emperor, Cloistered Prince Kakukai, became the Tendai Abbot. He was a disciple of the Archbishop Gyōgen of the Shōren-in. On the same 12th day, in addition to stripping the former Abbot of his post, two police commissioners were assigned to him; they covered the well and poured water on the fire, subjecting him to the torture of water and fire. Because of this, it was rumored that the monks would enter the capital again, and the capital was once more in an uproar.

[2.1.2] On the 18th day of the same month, thirteen nobles, from the Prime Minister on down, attended at the Palace, took their seats in the council hall, and deliberated on the crime of the former Abbot. Middle Counselor of Hachijō, Lord Nagakata—who was at that time still Controller of the Left and Consultant—was in the lowest seat, but he spoke up: "According to the written opinion of the legal experts, strictly speaking, the death penalty should be reduced by one degree and he should be exiled; however, the former Abbot, Archbishop Myōun, has studied both Exoteric and Esoteric Buddhism, maintains pure conduct and discipline, has conferred the great vehicle sutras upon the Imperial House, and has administered the pure bodhisattva precepts to the Retired Emperor. For the Master of the Sutras and the Master of the Precepts to be punished with a heavy sentence makes it difficult to fathom the reflection of the unseen gods. Should he not be pardoned from returning to lay life and exile?"
When he spoke thus without hesitation, the nobles present all agreed with Nagakata's opinion, but because the Retired Emperor's anger was deep, it was decided that he would still be exiled. The Lay Priest Prime Minister [Kiyomori] also went to the Retired Emperor's palace intending to speak on this matter, but since the Retired Emperor claimed to have a cold and did not summon him to his presence, Kiyomori withdrew, looking dissatisfied. As is the custom when punishing a monk, his ordination certificate was recalled, he was made to return to lay life, and was given the secular name Fujii Matsue, Assistant Master of the Grand Council. This Myōun was the sixth generation descendant of the Seventh Prince of Emperor Murakami, Imperial Prince Tomohira, and the son of Major Counselor Lord Akimichi of Koga. Truly he was a peerless master of virtue, the number one high priest in the realm, so both Sovereign and subjects revered him, and he held the posts of Administrator of Tennōji and Hosshōji. However, the Head of Yin-Yang, Abe no Yasuchika, criticized him, saying, "I do not understand why a wise man of such standing names himself Myōun. Above, the light of the sun and moon are aligned (Myō), but below there is a cloud (Un). " On the 20th day of the second month of the first year of Nin'an, he became the Tendai Abbot. On the 15th day of the third month of the same year, he performed his worship at the hall. When the treasury of the Central Hall was opened, among various heavy treasures, there was a box one foot square. It was wrapped in white cloth; when the Abbot, who had been chaste all his life, opened that box and looked, there was one scroll written on yellow paper. The Great Master Dengyō had recorded the names of future Abbots in advance. It is the custom to look as far as where one's own name is, and not to look beyond that, rolling it back as it was. So this Archbishop, too, must have done so. Though he was a noble person, he could not escape the karma of previous lives. These were pitiful events.

[2.1.3] On the 21st day of the same month, his place of exile was decided as Izu Province. Although people spoke in various ways, because of the slanderous report of the priest Saikō and his son, it was conducted in this manner. Saying that he must be expelled from the capital this very day, the officials of the expulsion went to the residence at Shirakawa to drive him out. The Archbishop, weeping, left the residence and entered the branch temple of the Complete Sutras near Awataguchi. At the Mountain Gate, they said, "In short, our enemies are none other than Saikō and his son," and writing the names of that father and son, they placed them under the left foot of General Kumbhira, one of the Twelve Divine Generals enshrined in the Central Hall, and screamed and shouted curses: "Twelve Divine Generals, Seven Thousand Yakshas, take the lives of Saikō and his son without letting the hour pass!" It was terrifying even to hear.

[2.1.4] On the 23rd day of the same month, he headed from the branch temple of the Complete Sutras to his place of exile. To have a person such as the Archbishop of the Dharma Seal driven on by low-ranking expulsion officers, leaving the capital this day and heading for the east of the barrier—his inner feelings can be surmised, and it is pitiful. When he reached the beach of Uchide at Ōtsu, the eaves of the Monju Tower appeared white in the distance, but he did not look at them twice; he pressed his sleeve to his face and choked with tears. Although there were many elders and masters at the Mountain Gate, Chōken Hōin, who was then still a Sōzu, regretting the parting too much, escorted him as far as Awazu; but since it could not go on forever, he took his leave there to return. The Archbishop, feeling the depth of his devotion, transmitted to him the blood lineage of the Three Views in One Mind, which he had kept secret in his heart for years. This Law was entrusted by Shakyamuni, transmitted sequentially from the Monk Aśvaghoṣa of Varanasi and Bodhisattva Nagarjuna of Southern India, and he bestowed it upon the feelings of this day. Even though our country is a borderland scattered like millet and this is a defiled age of the Latter Law, the heart of Chōken, who received this entrustment and returned up to the capital wringing the sleeves of his priestly robes, was indeed noble. At the Mountain Gate, the monks rose up and deliberated. "From Preceptor Gishin down to the fifty-fifth generation of Tendai Abbots, we have never heard of a precedent for exile. Carefully considering the heart of the matter, since the time of Enryaku when the Emperor established the Imperial Capital and the Great Master climbed this mountain and spread the teachings of the Four Clarities in this place, women of the five hindrances have ceased to leave traces, and three thousand pure monks have occupied the dwellings. On the peaks, the recitation of the One Vehicle continues through the years; at the foot, the miraculous efficacy of the Seven Shrines is new every day. That Spirit Vulture Peak in India is the secluded cave of the Great Saint to the northeast of the Royal Castle. This Mt. Hiei of Japan also towers at the Demon Gate of the Imperial Capital and is the spiritual ground for the protection of the nation. Generations of wise Kings and intelligent ministers have occupied altars in this place. Just because it is the Latter Age, how can we allow a blemish to be put on this mountain? It is regrettable."
Saying this, amidst screaming and shouting, the monks of the whole mountain all descended to East Sakamoto.

div.head: 2.2. The Affair of Ajari Ichigyō

div.p:
[2.2.1] "Now we must go to Awazu and snatch back our Head Priest. However, since there are expulsion officers and escort envoys, it will be difficult to take him back without incident. There is nothing to rely on but the power of the Great Master of the Mountain King. If we are truly to take him back without particular difficulty, show us a good omen first here."
The old monks crushed their livers and gall bladders [exerted themselves to the utmost] in prayer.

[2.2.2] Here, a youth named Tsurumaru, aged eighteen, belonging to the Vinaya Master Jōen, a priest of Mudōji, tormented in mind and body, sweating from his five limbs, suddenly began to act madly. "I am Jūzenji taking possession. Even if it is the Latter Age, how can the Head Priest of my mountain be moved to another province? It is regrettable life after life, world after world. If that happens, what is the use of my leaving traces at this foot of the mountain?"
Saying this, he pressed his left and right sleeves to his face and shed tears in drops. The monks wondered at this and said, "If it is truly the oracle of the Jūzenji Avatar, we will offer a test; return them to their original owners without a single mistake."
So four or five hundred old monks threw the rosaries they held in their hands up onto the great floor of the Jūzenji shrine. This possessed person ran around, gathered them up, and without a single mistake, returned each one to its original owner. The monks, at the nobility of the fresh miraculous efficacy of the god, all joined their palms and shed tears of gratitude and joy. "If that is the case, go forth and snatch him back!" No sooner was this said than they set out like clouds and mist. There were monks walking continuously along the beach road of Shiga and Karasaki. There were monks pushing boats out onto the lake at Yamada and Yabase. Seeing this, the expulsion officers and escort envoys, who had seemed so strict, all fled in four directions.

[2.2.3] The monks arrived at the Kokubun-ji temple. The former Abbot was greatly surprised and said, "It is said that a person under Imperial censure does not even stand in the light of the sun and moon. How much more so when the Retired Emperor's decree and Imperial order say I must be quickly driven out of the capital; I cannot rest even for a moment. Monks, please return up quickly."
Sitting near the edge of the room, he proclaimed: "Since leaving the house of the Three Ministers and entering the window of the Four Clarities and Hidden Valley, I have broadly studied the teachings of the Perfect Sect and learned both Exoteric and Esoteric doctrines. I have thought only of the prosperity of our mountain. Also, I have not been negligent in praying for the state. My desire to nurture the monks has also been deep. The Two Manifestations of the Mountain King must surely be observing. There is no error in myself. Though I suffer the heavy penalty of exile due to a false crime, I bear no grudge against the world, people, gods, or Buddhas. The kindness of you monks who have visited me this far is hard to repay fully."
As he spoke, he could not stop wringing the sleeves of his dyed priestly robes, and the monks all shed tears as well. Bringing a palanquin close, they said, "Please get in quickly." But he said, "In the past I was the Head Priest of three thousand monks, but now that I have become such an exile, how can I be carried up by noble scholars and wise monks? Even if I am to go up, I should tie on straw sandals and walk up in the same manner."
And he would not get in.

[2.2.4] Here, there was an evil monk living in the West Pagoda named Ajari Yūkei of the Kaijō-bō. He was about seven feet tall; wearing armor laced with black leather with gold mixed in the large spacing under his long robes, he had taken off his helmet and given it to a lowly priest to hold, and leaning on a large halberd with a white shaft, he said, "Make way!" Pushing through the midst of the monks, he went straight to where the former Abbot was. Glaring with large eyes, he stared at him for a moment and said, "It is because of that heart of yours that you meet with such an experience. Please get in quickly."
Because of the fearfulness, he hurriedly got in. In the joy of having snatched him back, it was not lowly priests but noble scholars who lifted the palanquin and carried him up, screaming and shouting; people took turns, but Yūkei did not change; carrying the front of the palanquin, gripping it as if to crush the shaft of his halberd and the shaft of the palanquin, he went up the steep Eastern Slope as if walking on flat ground. Setting the palanquin down in the garden of the Great Lecture Hall, they deliberated: "Now we have gone to Awazu and snatched back and detained our Head Priest. How can it be right to take a person who has already incurred Imperial censure and been exiled, detain him, and treat him as Head Priest?"
They deliberated. Ajari of the Kaijō-bō again stepped forward as before and argued: "Now, this mountain is the peerless spiritual site of Japan, the practice hall for the protection of the state; the majesty of the Mountain King is flourishing, and the Buddhist Law and the Kingly Law act as the horns of a cow. Therefore, regarding the intentions of the monks, there is no parallel; the world does not make light of even the lowly priests. How much more so for one who is high and noble in wisdom and is the Head Priest of the three thousand. Now he is heavy in virtue and conduct and is the Master of the whole mountain. Without crime, he suffers punishment. Is this not the resentment of the mountain and the capital, the mockery of Kōfuku-ji and Onjō-ji? At this time, losing the Master of Exoteric and Esoteric Buddhism, it would be regrettable for the many scholar-monks to neglect their diligent study. In short, let Yūkei be named the ringleader, be imprisoned or exiled, or have his head cut off; it will be an honor in this life and a memory for the underworld."
Saying this, tears fell in drops from both his eyes, and the monks all agreed, saying "Right, right." From that time on, Yūkei was called Ikame-bō (Grim Monk). His disciple, Vinaya Master Eikei, was called Ko-ikame-bō (Little Grim Monk) by the people of the time.

[2.2.5] The monks placed the former Abbot in the Myōkō-bō in the Southern Valley of the East Pagoda. It seems that even incarnate beings cannot escape the unexpected disasters of the time. Long ago in Great Tang, the Ajari Ichigyō (Yi Xing) was the chaplain to Emperor Xuanzong, but rumors arose about him and Xuanzong's consort, Yang Guifei. Long ago and now, in great countries and small, the malice of people's mouths is something without trace, but based on that suspicion, he was exiled to the Kingdom of Kara. There are three roads to that country. The Rinchidō is the Imperial road; the Yūchidō is the road commoners travel; the Anketsudō (Dark Cave Road) is the road on which heavy criminals are sent. So, because that Ajari Ichigyō was a great criminal, he was sent on the Dark Cave Road. For a period of seven days and seven nights, he journeyed without seeing the light of the sun or moon. It was dark with no people, he lost his way in his walking, and the forests were deep and silent. There was only [_][1] the sound of a bird in the mountain valley; unable to dry his wet clothes of moss, suffering the heavy penalty of exile for a false crime, the Way of Heaven took pity on him, and the Nine Luminaries appeared in form and protected Ajari Ichigyō. At that time, Ichigyō bit off his right finger and drew the forms of the Nine Luminaries on his left sleeve. The Mandala of the Nine Luminaries, which is the principal image of Shingon in both Japan and China, is this.

div.note: [_] [1] The kanji in our copy-text is New Nelson 3330.

div.p:
[2.3.1] The Retired Emperor heard that the monks had detained the former Abbot and was exceedingly displeased. The priest Saikō said, "Although it is not the first time that the monks of the Mountain Gate have engaged in disorderly appeals, this time is exceptionally outrageous. I have never heard of such violence. Please admonish them severely."
Thus he spoke. Without reflecting that his own body was about to perish, and without concern for the divine will of the Great Master of the Mountain King, he spoke thus and troubled the Imperial mind. It is said that slanderous subjects disturb the country. Truly, "Though the clustered orchids try to flourish, the autumn wind destroys them; though the King tries to be clear, slanderous subjects darken him."
Should one speak of such things? It was heard that this matter was planned by the New Major Counselor Lord Narichika and his close associates, and that the mountain would be attacked; but hearing that some monks privately followed the Retired Emperor's command, saying that the monks of the Mountain Gate should not be so arrogant in the King's land as to disobey Imperial orders, the former Abbot Archbishop Myōun, sitting in the Myōkō-bō, heard that the monks were of two minds and said forlornly, "In the end, what kind of experience will I meet?"
However, there was no order for exile.

[2.3.2] Because of the disturbance at the Mountain Gate, the New Major Counselor Lord Narichika temporarily suppressed his personal long-held resentment. Indeed, although the internal deliberations and preparations were various, it did not seem that this rebellion could succeed with righteous strength alone, so Tada no Kurando Yukitsuna, who had been relied upon so much, realized it was futile. He had the cloth sent for bow bags cut and sewn into hitatare and katabira, dressed his retainers in them, and sat blinking his eyes; observing the flourishing state of the Taira family, he realized they could not easily be overthrown at this time. He had participated in a useless matter. If this matter leaked out, Yukitsuna would be the first to be destroyed. Before it leaked from another's mouth, he decided to turn loyal and save his life.

[2.3.3] Late at night on the 29th day of the same fifth month, Tada no Kurando Yukitsuna went to the Lay Priest Prime Minister's residence at Nishi-Hachijō and had it announced: "Yukitsuna has something to report, so I have come." The Lay Priest said, "What business brings someone who doesn't usually visit? Go hear it."
And he sent out the Master of the Stables Magistrate Morikuni. Since he said, "It is not a matter to be spoken through a messenger," the Lay Priest said, "Very well," and came out to the corridor of the middle gate himself.
"The night must be far advanced; right now, what is the matter?" When he asked this, Yukitsuna said, "Since eyes are many during the day, I have come under the cover of night. Lately, the people of the Retired Emperor's court have been preparing weapons and summoning soldiers; what have you heard about this?"
"I hear that is to attack the mountain," he replied as if it were nothing.
Yukitsuna drew closer and lowered his voice: "It is not that; I hear it is entirely directed at your family." "Well then, does the Retired Emperor know of this?"
"Does it need details? Lord Narichika's summoning of soldiers is done by calling it an Imperial Decree. Shunkan acted thus, Yasuyori said this, Saikō said that."
He pointed out everything from the beginning without omission, revealing it all, and then took his leave and went out. The Lay Priest was greatly surprised and shouted for his samurai in a loud voice; it was tremendous to hear. Yukitsuna, fearing he might be detained as a witness for having brought up such a half-hearted matter, felt as if fire had been set to a great plain; holding up the hem of his trousers though no one was chasing him, he hurriedly fled outside the gate. The Lay Priest first called Sadayoshi and ordered: "Rebels intending to overthrow this house fill the capital. Inform the members of the clan and summon the samurai." Sadayoshi ran around summoning them. Major Captain of the Right Lord Munemori, Middle Captain of the Third Rank Tomomori, Head Chamberlain Middle Captain Shigehira, Head of the Left Stables Yukimori, and others put on armor, strapped on bows and arrows, and gathered. Besides them, soldiers gathered like clouds and mist. During that night at Nishi-Hachijō, it appeared there were six or seven thousand mounted soldiers. When dawn came, it was the first day of the sixth month. While it was still dark, the Lay Priest summoned Police Commissioner Abe no Sukenari and said: "Go quickly to the Retired Emperor's palace. Summon Nobunari and say: 'Close associates have plotted to destroy this clan and disturb the realm. I shall arrest them one by one and investigate. Say that the Sovereign should not be aware of this.' " Sukenari hurried there, called out the Master of the Great Table Nobunari, and told him this; Nobunari lost his color. When he went before the Retired Emperor and reported this, the Retired Emperor thought, "Ah, the matter we planned in secret has leaked," and he was appalled.
Even so, he only said, "What is this?" and gave no clear reply.
Sukenari hurried back and reported this to the Lay Priest Prime Minister, who said, "Just as I thought. Yukitsuna spoke the truth. If Yukitsuna had not informed me of this matter, would Jōkai [Kiyomori] be safe?"
He ordered the Governor of Hida Kageie and the Governor of Chikugo Sadayoshi to arrest the rebels. Accordingly, two hundred horsemen, three hundred horsemen, attacked here and there and arrested them.

[2.3.4] The Lay Priest Prime Minister first sent a low-ranking official to the residence of the New Major Counselor Narichika at Naka-mikado Karasuma, saying, "There is a matter to discuss. Please drop by quickly."
The Major Counselor, not knowing at all that it concerned himself, thought, "Ah, this must be to stop the Retired Emperor's plan to attack the mountain. His anger seems deep. It likely cannot be helped." Dressing gracefully in a soft unlined hunting robe, riding in a splendid carriage, and bringing three or four samurai, he had even his servants and ox-drivers dress better than usual. Indeed, he only realized later that this was his end. When he came near Nishi-Hachijō and looked, soldiers filled the area for four or five blocks. "Oh, how tremendous. What is this?" With his heart pounding, he got out of the carriage and stepped inside the gate; inside, too, soldiers filled every gap. At the entrance of the middle gate, many terrifying warriors were waiting; they took the Major Counselor's left and right hands and pulled him, saying, "We must bind you."
The Lay Priest Prime Minister looked out from behind the blinds and said, "That should not be done."
So the warriors surrounded him front, back, left, and right, pulled him up onto the veranda, and pushed him into a single room. The Major Counselor felt as if he were dreaming and could not feel anything at all. The samurai who had accompanied him were pushed away and scattered. The servants and ox-drivers lost their color, abandoned the ox carriage, and fled.

[2.3.5] In the meantime, the Omi Middle Captain Lay Priest Renjō, the Hosshōji Administrator Sōzu Shunkan, the Governor of Yamashiro Motokane, the Senior Assistant Minister of Ceremonial Masatsuna, the Taira Magistrate Yasuyori, the Sō Magistrate Nobufusa, and the New Taira Magistrate Sukeyuki were also captured and brought in.

[2.3.6] The priest Saikō heard this and, wondering if it concerned himself, whipped his horse and galloped to the Retired Emperor's palace, Hōjūji-dono. The Taira samurai galloped to meet him on the road and said, "You are summoned to Nishi-Hachijō. Come quickly."
He said, "I have a matter to report, so I am going to Hōjūji-dono. I will go there immediately after."
But they said, "Evil priest! What is it that you would report? Do not let him speak."
They pulled him down from his horse, bound him amidst them, and dragged him to Nishi-Hachijō. Since he was a principal participant from the very beginning, they bound him especially tightly and dragged him into the courtyard. The Lay Priest Prime Minister stood on the great veranda and said, "That is the figure of the scoundrel who tries to overthrow the Lay Priest. Drag the fellow here."
He had him dragged to the edge of the veranda, and while wearing his footwear, he trampled hard on Saikō's face. "Originally, you were a person of low rank who should not have been employed by the Sovereign, but you were given an office you should not have had, and while I watched you and your son behaving beyond your station, you managed to get the faultless Tendai Abbot exiled, brought about a great crisis in the realm, and furthermore, you are the scoundrel who participated in a rebellion to destroy this clan. Speak the truth."
Thus he spoke. Since Saikō was originally an exceptionally strong-willed person, he did not change color in the slightest, nor did he look intimidated. Sitting up straight, he laughed scornfully and said, "Just so, it is Lord Lay Priest who speaks beyond his station. I do not know about before others, but in Saikō's hearing, you cannot speak such things. Since I am a servant in the Retired Emperor's court, there is no way I could say I did not participate in a matter instigated by the Chief Administrator Lord Narichika as an Imperial Decree. I did participate. However, you say things that grate on the ears. Although you are the son of the late Minister of Punishments Tadamori, until you were fourteen or fifteen you did not serve at court, and when you entered the service of the late Middle Counselor of Nakamikado, Lord Ienari, the children of the capital called you Taka-Heida. around the Hōen era, when you captured thirty pirate ringleaders by order of the Great General, even getting the fourth rank and being called Junior Assistant of the Gate Guards of the Fourth Rank was considered excessive by the people of the time. For the descendant of a person who was shunned even in the interaction of courtiers to rise to Prime Minister—is that not excessive? It is not without precedent or parallel for persons of the samurai class to become provincial governors or police commissioners. Why should it be excessive?"
Because he spoke without hesitation, the Lay Priest was too angry to speak. After a while, he said, "Do not cut off the fellow's head simply. Torture him well. " Matsuura no Tarō Shigetoshi received the order and tortured him in various ways, crushing his hands and feet. Since he did not deny it from the start, the interrogation was strict. He confessed ruthlessly. His confession was recorded on four or five sheets, and then, saying "Tear the fellow's mouth," they tore his mouth and beheaded him at Gojō Suzaku. His heir, the former Governor of Kaga, Morotaka, had been exiled to Idota in Owari, but he was killed by order to the resident of that province, the District Official of Ogoma, Koresue. The second son, Magistrate Moritsune, who was imprisoned, was dragged from prison and executed at the Rokujō riverbed. His younger brother, Lieutenant of the Left Gate Guards Morihira, and three retainers also had their heads cut off. These men, excelling among the worthless, meddled in matters they should not have touched, managed to get the faultless Tendai Abbot exiled, and perhaps their luck ran out; incurring the immediate divine punishment of the Great Master of the Mountain King, they met with such a fate.

[2.4.1] The New Major Counselor was pushed into a single room, soaking with sweat, thinking, "Alas, what we have been doing lately must have leaked out. Who could have leaked it? It must surely be one of the North Face warriors," and as he sat pondering continuously, footsteps sounded loudly from the rear; thinking, "Now warriors are coming to take my life," he waited. The Lay Priest himself stomped loudly on the floorboards and suddenly opened the sliding door behind where the Major Counselor was sitting. Wearing a short unlined silk garment with the hem of his white trousers tucked up, and wearing a sword with a hilt of raw wood pushed loosely through his sash, he looked exceedingly angry; he glared at the Major Counselor for a while and said, "Now, you should have been executed during the Heiji Disturbance, but the Minister of the Center [Shigemori] exchanged his own life to plead for you, and your head was reattached; how can this be? With what grudge have you planned to destroy this clan? One who knows gratitude is called a human; one who does not know gratitude is called a beast. However, because the destiny of this house is not yet exhausted, we have apprehended you. I will hear the details of your recent plot directly. " The Major Counselor said, "There is no such thing at all. It must be someone's slander. Please investigate carefully."
Before he could finish speaking, the Lay Priest shouted, "Is anyone there? Is anyone there?" Sadayoshi entered. "Bring Saikō's confession."
When ordered, he brought it. Taking it, he read it repeatedly two or three times to him, saying, "Ah, how hateful! After this, what can you say?" And throwing it suddenly in the Major Counselor's face, he slammed the sliding door shut and went out. The Lay Priest, unable to contain his anger, called "Tsunetō, Kaneyasu," and Senoo no Tarō and Namba no Jirō entered. "Take that man and drag him down to the garden."
When he said this, they did not move immediately, saying, "How will Lord Komatsu's mood be?" The Lay Priest Prime Minister became very angry: "Enough, enough! You fellows respect the Minister of the Center's life and make light of the Lay Priest's orders, it seems. Then there is nothing to be done."
Seeing that this might be bad, the two men stood up and dragged the Major Counselor down to the garden. At that time, the Lay Priest seemed pleased and said, "Throw him down and make him scream. " The two men put their mouths to the Major Counselor's left and right ears and whispered, "Please let out your voice in any way," and when they pulled him down, he screamed two or three times.
That appearance seemed no different from sinners in the underworld being weighed on the scales of karma or facing the crystal mirror, and being tortured by the demons of hell according to the weight of their sins. Xiao He and Fan Kuai were imprisoned; Han Xin and Peng Yue were pickled. Chao Cuo was executed; Zhou Yi was punished. For example, Xiao He, Fan Kuai, Han Xin, and Peng Yue were all loyal subjects of Gaozu, but due to the slander of small men, they suffered the shame of destruction; should one speak of such things?

[2.4.2] The New Major Counselor, seeing himself in this state, worried about what kind of experience his son, the Minor Captain of Tanba Naritsune, and his young children would meet, and he was uneasy. In the intense heat of the sixth month, without even loosening his clothes, the heat was unbearable; he felt as if his chest would burst, and sweat and tears struggled to flow. "Even so, Lord Komatsu will not abandon me," he said, but he did not know through whom he should speak.

[2.4.3] Minister Komatsu, after a long time had passed, arrived carrying his heir, the Provisional Assistant Master Major General Koremori, in the back of his carriage, accompanied by four or five guards and two or three attendants, without bringing a single soldier, looking particularly casual. Beginning with the Lay Priest, people all looked on unexpectedly. When he got out of the carriage, Sadayoshi quickly came up and said, "Why have you not brought a single soldier for such a great matter?"
He replied, "A 'great matter' refers to a great matter of the realm; is there any reason to call such a private matter a great matter?"
The men carrying weapons looked ashamed. Wondering where the Major Counselor had been placed, he opened sliding doors here and there and looked; there was a place where a sliding door had been tied shut with a cross-knot. Thinking it might be here, he opened it, and the Major Counselor was there. Choked with tears, he lay face down and did not meet his eyes. "How is it?" he said. At that moment, seeing him, the look of joy on his face seemed like that of sinners in hell seeing the Bodhisattva Jizō, and it was pitiful. "What is this matter? I have met with such an experience. Now that you have come, I rely on you that it will be alright. I was to be executed during the Heiji Disturbance, but through your favor my head was reattached, and I rose to become a Major Counselor of the Senior Second Rank, and my age is already over forty. Your favor is difficult to repay fully in life after life. This time as well, please save my worthless life. If only my life is spared, I will become a monk, seclude myself at Kōya or Kokawa, and perform services for the afterlife."
Thus he pleaded. "Be that as it may, surely your life will not be lost. Even if it were so, since Shigemori is here, I would exchange my own life for yours."
Saying this, he left. Sitting before his father the Lay Priest, he said, " regarding the execution of Lord Narichika, you must consider it very carefully. Since his ancestor, the Master of the Palace Repairs Aquisue, served Retired Emperor Shirakawa, he has risen to become a Major Counselor of the Senior Second Rank, unparalleled in his family, and is currently the favorite of the Sovereign. How can it be right to behead him immediately? To send him out of the capital should be sufficient. The Kitano Tenjin, due to the slander of Minister Tokihira, had his name washed away by the waves of the four seas; the Minister of Nishi-no-miya, due to the slander of Tada no Manju, entrusted his resentment to the clouds of Sanyō. Although each was innocent, they were exiled. These are handed down as the errors of the holy era of Engi and the Emperor of Anna. It was like this even in ancient times. How much more so in the Latter Age. Since you have already arrested him, even if you do not kill him quickly, what pain is there? It is seen in the texts: 'Treat doubtful punishments lightly. Treat doubtful merits heavily.'
Although it is a personal matter, Shigemori is married to that Major Counselor's younger sister. Koremori is also his son-in-law. Since we have become close in this way, you may think I speak for that reason. That is not the case. I speak for the sake of the world, for the sake of the Sovereign, and for the sake of our house. Some years ago, during the regency of the late Lay Priest Minor Counselor Shinzei, he carried out the death penalty which had not been performed for twenty-five generations of Sovereigns, from the time Emperor Saga executed the Captain of the Right Gate Guards Fujiwara no Nakanari until the Hōgen era; he dug up the corpse of the Evil Minister of the Left of Uji and inspected it; these seemed like excessive government. Therefore, the ancients also passed down: 'If the death penalty is carried out, rebels within the seas will not cease.'
Following these words, after two years, the world was disturbed again in the Heiji era; Shinzei, who had been buried, was dug up, his head was cut off, and it was paraded through the main streets. Thinking that what he carried out in Hōgen returned upon himself before long, it was terrifying. This man is not a significant enemy of the court. In every way, there should be fear. Since there is nothing lacking in your glory, you probably do not think of it, but I desire prosperity for your children and grandchildren. It is seen that the good and evil of ancestors inevitably extend to descendants. I hear that 'A house that accumulates good surely has leftover blessings; a gate that accumulates evil surely has leftover disasters.' In any case, it is not right that his head be cut off tonight."
When he spoke thus, the Lay Priest Prime Minister perhaps thought it was true, and decided against the death penalty.

[2.4.4] After that, the Minister went out to the middle gate and said to the samurai, "Even if it is an order, you must not kill the Major Counselor without question. If the Lay Priest does something rash in a fit of anger, he will surely regret it later. Do not do something wrong and bear a grudge against me."
When he said this, the soldiers all stuck out their tongues and trembled with fear. "Also, that Tsunetō and Kaneyasu treated the Major Counselor without mercy this morning is repeatedly outrageous. Why did they not fear what Shigemori would hear later? Boors from the country are like this."
When he said this, both Namba and Senoo were terrified. Speaking thus, the Minister returned to the Komatsu residence. In the meantime, the samurai who had accompanied the Major Counselor ran back to the residence at Naka-mikado Karasuma and reported this; the wife and the ladies-in-waiting below her cried and screamed without sparing their voices. "Already warriors are heading here. It is rumored that beginning with the Minor Captain, the young lords will be arrested. Please hide anywhere quickly."
When they said this, she replied, "Now that I have come to this state, what is the use of being safe even if I remain behind? I only wish to vanish like the dew of the same night. Even so, the sadness of not knowing that this morning was the end!"
And she threw herself down and wept. Hearing that the warriors were already approaching, and thinking it would be shameful and unpleasant to see such a sight, she put her ten-year-old daughter and eight-year-old son into a carriage and sent them out without a specific destination. Since she could not remain, she went up Omiya and stayed at Unrin-in in the Kitayama area. Leaving her at a monk's quarters in that vicinity, the escorts, finding it hard to throw away their own lives, took their leave and returned. Now, left with only young people, with no one to ask questions of, the heart of the wife was pitiful to surmise. Looking at the fading light, she thought that the Major Counselor's dew-like life was limited to this evening, and thinking of it, she felt she would perish. Although there were many ladies-in-waiting and samurai, no one cleaned up things, no one even pushed the gates shut. Although horses stood lined up in the stables, there was not a single person to feed them grass. When dawn came, horse carriages used to line up at the gate, guests lined up in seats, playing and dancing, not thinking of the world as the world; people close by did not even speak loudly, but stood in awe until yesterday; the state changed overnight, and the principle that the prosperous must decline appeared before their eyes. The traces of the brush of Oe no Sukemoto, who wrote 'Pleasure is exhausted and sorrow comes,' were realized now.

[2.5.1] The Tanba Minor Captain Naritsune was on night duty at the Retired Emperor's palace, Hōjūji-dono, that very night and had not yet left; the Major Counselor's samurai hurriedly ran to the palace, called out the Minor Captain, and when they reported this, he said, "Why was there no notice from the Consultant until now?"
Before he could finish speaking, a messenger came from the Consultant. This Consultant was the younger brother of the Lay Priest Prime Minister; his residence was inside the main gate of Rokuhara, so he was called the Consultant by the Gate. He was the father-in-law of the Tanba Minor Captain. "Whatever the matter, say that the Lay Priest Prime Minister says to bring him quickly to Nishi-Hachijō," he had said. The Minor Captain understood this matter, called out the close ladies-in-waiting, and said, "Last night the world was somehow unsettled, but I thought it was just the mountain monks coming down and considered it unrelated; but it was already about Naritsune. Since the Major Counselor is to be beheaded tonight, Naritsune will surely share the same guilt. I would like to go to the Palace once more and see the Sovereign, but since I have already become such a person, I have reservations. " When the ladies-in-waiting went before the Retired Emperor and reported this, the Retired Emperor was greatly surprised; "Just as I thought, the Lay Priest Prime Minister's messenger this morning had a reason. Ah, the matter planned secretly by these men has leaked."
He was appalled. "Even so, bring him here."
Since he indicated this, he entered. The Retired Emperor shed tears and had no commands to give. The Minor Captain was also choked with tears and had nothing to say. After a while, since it could not go on forever, the Minor Captain pressed his sleeve to his face and left weeping. The Retired Emperor watched him go for a long time, thinking that the Latter Age was indeed wretched and that this might be the last time he saw him, and he shed tears, which was awe-inspiring. The people in the palace held the Minor Captain's sleeves, clung to his hem, regretted the parting, and there was no one who did not shed tears.

[2.5.2] When he went to his father-in-law the Consultant's place, his wife was close to giving birth, but adding this grief from this morning, she felt as if her life was fading away. Since the Minor Captain had left the palace, his flowing tears had not ceased; seeing his wife's condition, he seemed even more helpless. Among the Minor Captain's wet nurses was a lady named Rokujō. "I began nursing you and held you from inside your diapers; as the months and days piled up, I did not lament the passing of my own years, but only rejoiced in thinking of your growing up into an adult; though I thought it was for nothing, already twenty-one years have passed without my leaving you for a moment. Even when you went to the palace and came out late, I felt anxious; what kind of experience are you to meet now?"
She wept. The Minor Captain said, "Do not grieve so painfully. Since the Consultant is here, surely he will beg for my life at least."
Although he comforted her, she writhed in weeping, heedless of others' eyes.

[2.5.3] Since messengers from Nishi-Hachijō came incessantly, the Consultant said, "We must go facing it, and let it happen as it may," and went out; the Minor Captain rode in the back of the Consultant's carriage and they went out. Since the Hōgen and Heiji disturbances, the people of the Taira family had only pleasure and glory, and no sorrow, but only this Consultant, because of a worthless son-in-law, suffered such grief. When they came near Nishi-Hachijō, stopped the carriage, and announced their arrival, the Lay Priest Prime Minister said, "The Tanba Minor Captain must not enter inside here."
So they dropped him off at a samurai's house nearby, and only the Consultant entered inside the gate. Before long, soldiers surrounded and guarded the Minor Captain. He was separated from the Consultant Lord he had relied upon. The Minor Captain's heart must have been wretched. The Consultant sat at the middle gate, but the Lay Priest did not meet him. He sent a message through Minamoto Magistrate Suesada: "I regret repeatedly having become close to a worthless person, but it is of no use. The personage married to him has been ill recently, and if she adds this grief from this morning, her life will surely end. Why should it matter? Please place the Minor Captain in Norimori's custody for a while. Since Norimori is here, why would I let him do anything wrong?"
Suesada went and reported this. "Ah, the usual Consultant does not understand things."
And he did not reply immediately. After a while, the Lay Priest said, "The New Major Counselor Narichika plotted to destroy this clan and disturb the realm. This Minor Captain is that Major Counselor's heir. Be he distant or close, you cannot plead for him. If this rebellion had succeeded, ask him if you would be safe."
Thus he spoke. Suesada returned and reported this to the Consultant Lord; he looked truly dissatisfied and spoke again: "Since the Hōgen and Heiji eras, in repeated battles, I have thought to take your place and die. Hereafter, too, I intend to defend against rough winds first; even if Norimori is old, since I have many young children, how could we not serve as a defense for one side? Yet, when I say I will take custody of Naritsune for a while, your lack of acceptance implies you think Norimori is a person of two minds. Being thought of with such suspicion, what is the use of living in this world? Now, just give me leave; I will become a monk, seclude myself in a remote mountain village, and solely perform services for the afterlife. It is a useless association with the sad world. Because we are in the world, we have desires; because desires are not fulfilled, we have resentment. Nothing is better than loathing the sad world and entering the True Way."
Thus he spoke. Suesada went and said, "The Consultant Lord has already made up his mind. Please arrange things somehow."
The Lay Priest was greatly surprised and said, "Whatever the case, becoming a monk is too extreme. If that is the case, say that I entrust the Minor Captain to you for a while. " Suesada returned and reported this to the Consultant Lord, who said, "Ah, one should not have children. If I were not tied by bonds to my child, I would not crush my heart like this."
And he went out.

[2.5.4] The Minor Captain waited for him and asked, "Well, how did it go?" He replied, "The Lay Priest was very angry and would not meet Norimori in the end. Although he frequently said it was impossible, perhaps because I said I would become a monk, he said to keep you at my residence for a while, but I do not think it will be good in the end."
The Minor Captain said, "Just so, Naritsune too will prolong his life for a while through your favor. In connection with that, what have you heard about the Major Counselor?"
"I have not even thought as far as that," he said. At that time, tears fell in drops from his eyes: "Truly, that my life should survive for a while through your favor is appropriate, but the reason I regret my life is that I wish to see my father once more. If the Major Counselor is executed, what is the use of Naritsune living a worthless life? Please arrange it so that we may meet our fate in one place."
When he said this, the Consultant looked very pained and said, "Well now, I spoke this and that about you. I did not think as far as that, but regarding the Major Counselor, since the Minister of the Center spoke in various ways this morning, I hear that for a while he is safe."
When he said this, the Minor Captain wept and joined his hands in joy. "Who but a child would put aside his own situation right now and rejoice to this extent? The true bond is indeed between parent and child. Should one have a child?"
And immediately he reconsidered his thoughts. So, riding in the same carriage as in the morning, they returned. At the residence, the ladies-in-waiting felt as if a dead person had come back to life, and gathering together, everyone rejoiced and wept.

div.head: 2.6. The Admonition

div.p:
[2.6.1]
Although the Lay Priest Prime Minister had bound up many people in this way, perhaps he still felt unsatisfied. He wore a hitatare of red brocade, a belly-wrap armor laced with black silk, and over the breastplate with white metal fittings, he carried under his arm the small halberd with silver spiral wrapping that he had received in a dream from the Great Deity of Itsukushima when he was Governor of Aki years ago, which he never let away from his pillow; appearing thus in the corridor of the middle gate. His appearance looked generally terrifying. He summoned Sadayoshi. [_][2] Governor of Chikugo Sadayoshi, wearing a hitatare of magnolia cloth and armor laced with scarlet, waited in awe before him. After a while, the Lay Priest said, "Sadayoshi, what do you think of this matter? In the Hōgen era, more than half the clan, beginning with Taira no Uma-no-suke, went to the side of the New Retired Emperor [Sutoku]. As for the First Prince, since he was the foster child of the late Minister of Punishments [Tadamori], it was difficult in many ways to abandon him, but following the last injunctions of the Late Retired Emperor [Toba], I led the vanguard on this side. This is the first service. Next, in the twelfth month of the first year of Heiji, when Nobuyori and Yoshitomo seized the Palace, barricaded themselves in the Imperial Compound, and turned the world to darkness, the Lay Priest threw away his life, drove out the rebels, and arrested Tsunemune and Korekata; I have repeatedly been on the verge of losing my life for the Sovereign. No matter what anyone says, how could he abandon this clan for seven generations? Yet, heeding the words of Narichika, a useless fellow, and Saikō, a lowly scoundrel, the Retired Emperor's plan to destroy this clan is a matter of regret. If there are slanderers hereafter, I suspect a decree to hunt down this house will be issued. Once we become enemies of the court, no matter how much we regret it, it will be of no use. Until the world is quieted, I intend to move the Retired Emperor to the Seinan Palace at Toba, or otherwise, compel a royal visit here; what do you think? In that case, the North Face warriors may shoot an arrow. Warn the samurai to be prepared for that. Generally, the Lay Priest has given up on service to the Cloistered Emperor's side. Saddle the horse. Bring out the long robe (kisenaga)."
Thus he spoke.

[2.6.2] Master of the Stables Magistrate Morikuni hurriedly galloped to Lord Komatsu and reported, "The world has already come to this." The Minister could not bear to hear it. "Ah, has Lord Narichika's head been cut off?" When he asked this, Morikuni replied, "It is not that, but the Lay Priest has called for his armored robe. The samurai have all set out and are preparing to attack Hōjūji-dono. They intend to confine the Retired Emperor at Toba Palace, but secretly it is planned to exile him to the Chinzei (Kyushu) region."
When he reported this, the Minister thought, "How can such a thing be?" but thinking that given the Lay Priest's mood this morning, such madness might occur, he rushed his carriage and went to Nishi-Hachijō.

[2.6.3] Getting out of the carriage in front of the gate and stepping inside, he saw that while the Lay Priest wore belly-wrap armor, dozens of nobles and courtiers of the clan, in hitatare of various colors, wore armor of their choice and were seated in two rows in the corridor of the middle gate. Besides them, provincial governors, guard officers, and officials overflowed on the veranda and sat packed in the garden. They pulled banner poles aside, tightened horse girths, and tightened helmet cords; just as they all looked ready to set out, Lord Komatsu, wearing an eboshi and nōshi, holding the sides of his large-patterned trousers, rustled in; it looked extraordinary.

[2.6.4] The Lay Priest looked down; thinking, "Ah, the usual Minister of the Center behaves as if to pacify the world; he must intend to admonish me greatly," and though he was his son, since he was a person who maintained the Five Precepts inwardly and put compassion first, and outwardly did not disturb the Five Virtues and corrected proprieties, he must have felt ashamed to face him wearing belly-wrap armor in that attire; he pulled the sliding door shut a little, and wearing a plain silk robe over his armor in a flurry, he kept pulling the chest of the robe across repeatedly to hide the metal fittings on the breastplate that were slightly visible. The Minister took a seat above his younger brother Lord Munemori. The Lay Priest did not speak out, and the Minister did not speak either.

[2.6.5] After a while, the Lay Priest spoke: "The rebellion of Lord Narichika is of no account. It was entirely the plan of the Retired Emperor. Until the world is quieted, I intend to move the Retired Emperor to the Seinan Palace at Toba, or otherwise, compel a royal visit here; what do you think?"
When he said this, the Minister could not bear to hear it and wept profusely. The Lay Priest was dumbfounded: "What is this? What is this?"
The Minister suppressed his tears and said, "Hearing this command, I feel that your fortune has already come to an end. When a person's fortune is about to decline, he inevitably plans evil things. Also, your appearance does not seem like reality. Although our country is called a borderland scattered like millet, since the descendants of Amaterasu Ōmikami became masters of the country and the descendants of Ame-no-Koyane-no-Mikoto administered the government, is it not against propriety for a person who has reached the post of Prime Minister to wear armor? In particular, you are a monk. To cast off the priestly robes, the banner of liberation of the Buddhas of the three worlds, and suddenly put on armor and carry a bow and arrows—inwardly you invite the sin of breaking precepts and lack of shame, and outwardly you violate the laws of benevolence, righteousness, propriety, wisdom, and faith. Although this is a fearful thing to say, I cannot leave my intent at the bottom of my heart. In previous lives, there are four debts of gratitude. The debt to Heaven and Earth, the debt to the King, the debt to parents, and the debt to sentient beings; these are they. Among them, the heaviest is the debt to the Court. Under the wide heavens, there is no place that is not the King's land. Thus, we hear that even the sage who washed his ears in the waters of the Ying River and picked ferns on Mount Shouyang knew the propriety that Imperial commands are hard to disobey. How much more so, you have attained the post of Prime Minister, unheard of among our ancestors. So-called Shigemori, with a body of no talent and stupidity, has reached the rank of Minister. In addition, more than half the provinces and counties have become the domain of our clan, and fields and gardens are all at the disposal of our house. Is this not an unprecedented Imperial favor? Now, forgetting these immense favors and trying to overthrow the Retired Emperor violently will go against the divine will of Amaterasu Ōmikami and Hachiman Bodhisattva. Japan is the land of the gods. The gods do not accept incivility. Therefore, the point you have set your mind upon is utterly unreasonable. Though this clan has pacified the enemies of the court for generations and quieted the rebellious waves of the four seas, which is unparalleled loyalty, to boast of that reward is arrogant. In the Seventeen-Article Constitution of Prince Shōtoku, it is seen: 'Men all have hearts; hearts each have clingings. They consider right what we consider wrong; we consider right what they consider wrong. Who can determine the principle of right and wrong? Both are wise and foolish. It is like a ring without an end. Therefore, even if others are angry, rather fear one's own faults.'
However, since your fortune is not exhausted, the rebellion has already been exposed. Moreover, since Lord Narichika, who was consulted, has been arrested, even if the Sovereign plans some strange thing, what is there to fear? Since the appropriate punishment will be carried out, if you withdraw, explain the circumstances, exert yourself in loyal service for the Sovereign, and extend compassion and care for the people, you will receive the protection of the gods and will not go against the hidden will of the Buddhas. If the gods and Buddhas respond, why would the Sovereign not reconsider? Comparing the Sovereign and the subject, there is no way to distinguish intimacy. If one compares reason and unreason, how can one not side with reason?

div.note: [_] [2] Nihon Koten Bungaku Taikei (Tokyo: Iwanami Shoten, 1957, vol. 32; hereafter cited as NKBT) reads 筑後守貞能、木蘭地の直垂に.

div.head: 2.7. The Affair of the Beacon Fires

div.p:
[2.7.1] Since justice is with the Sovereign, even if it is not possible, I shall guard the Retired Emperor's palace, Hōjūji-dono. The reason is that from Shigemori's conferral of rank up to now being General and Minister, there is nothing that is not the Sovereign's favor. Thinking of the weight of that favor, it exceeds a thousand or ten thousand jewels; considering the depth of that color, it surpasses the crimson of repeated dyeing. Therefore, I shall go to the palace and confine myself there. If that is the case, there must be a few samurai who have pledged to take Shigemori's place and die for him. If I take them and guard the Retired Emperor's palace, Hōjūji-dono, indeed it will be an exceedingly great matter. Alas, if I try to fulfill the loyalty of service to the Sovereign, I am about to quickly forget the favor of my father, which is higher than the peak of Mount Sumeru. It is painful; if I try to escape the sin of unfilial conduct, I will become a rebellious subject disloyal to the Sovereign. Advance or retreat, I am in a valley. Right and wrong are hard to distinguish. The conclusion of my request is: simply take Shigemori's head. I cannot guard the palace. I cannot accompany an attack on the palace. That Xiao He, because his great merit exceeded others, reached the office of Chancellor of State, and was permitted to ascend to the hall wearing his sword and shoes; but when he went against the Imperial will, Gaozu bound him heavily and punished him deeply. Thinking of such precedents, having reached the extremities of wealth, glory, Imperial favor, and high office, it is not difficult for fortune to end. To what end should I live and see the world in disorder? Only that Shigemori's karma to be born in the Latter Age and meet such sorrow is clumsy. Just order a single samurai to drag me out into the garden; for Shigemori's head to be cut off is an easy thing. Listen, everyone."
Saying this, he shed tears enough to wring the sleeves of his robe and lamented; the members of the clan, those with heart and those without, all dampened their sleeves.

[2.7.2] Even the Lay Priest Prime Minister, hearing the Minister of the Center upon whom he relied completely speak thus, seemed powerless: "No, no, I have not thought as far as this. I only thought that since he listens to the words of evil gangs, some wrong might occur."
The Minister said, "Even if some wrong occurs, how could you do anything to the Sovereign?"
Standing up, he went out to the middle gate and ordered the samurai: "Did you hear what Shigemori said just now? I have been here since this morning intending to calm these matters, but seeing it appeared excessively tumultuous, I was returning. regarding accompanying an attack on the palace, do so after seeing Shigemori's head taken. Now, come!"
And he returned to the Komatsu residence. He summoned Master of the Stables Magistrate Morikuni and ordered: "Shigemori has heard of a grave matter of state. Announce that those who consider themselves my men should all arm themselves and gallop here."
The announcement was made. "Since a person who does not usually make noise has made such an announcement, there must be a special reason."
Everyone armed themselves and galloped there, vying with one another. Soldiers overflowing in the villages of Yodo, Hazukashi, Uji, Okaya, Hino, Kajūji, Daigo, Ogurisu, Umezu, Katsura, Ohara, Shizuhara, and Seryō galloped in confused haste, some wearing armor but not yet helmets, others carrying arrows but not yet bows, stepping in one stirrup or not.
Since it was heard that there was a disturbance at Lord Komatsu's, the several thousand horsemen who were at Nishi-Hachijō, without saying a word to the Lay Priest, clamored and went together, all galloping to Lord Komatsu's. Not a single person who handled a bow and arrow remained. At that time, the Lay Priest was greatly surprised and summoned Sadayoshi: "What is the Minister thinking to call these men? As he said, perhaps he is directing an attack force against the Lay Priest."
Sadayoshi shed tears in drops and said, "People depend on people. How could such a thing be? The things you said here must all be regrets now."
The Lay Priest perhaps thought it would be bad to be at odds with the Minister. He stopped thinking of giving orders to the Retired Emperor, took off his belly-wrap armor, put a stole over his plain silk robe, and engaged in recitation which did not truly arise from his heart.

[2.7.3] At Lord Komatsu's, Morikuni received them and kept the arrival register. The forces that galloped there were noted as over ten thousand horsemen. After inspecting the register, the Minister went out to the middle gate and said to the samurai, "It is admirable that you have come without violating our daily agreement. There is a precedent for this in a foreign land. King You of Zhou had a most beloved consort named Baosi. She was the number one beauty in the world. However, the one thing that did not please King You's heart was that Baosi did not smile; this consort never laughed at all. In the custom of that foreign land, when a military revolution arises in the realm, there is a stratagem to light fires in various places and beat great drums to summon soldiers. This is named 'Beacon Fire.' Once, when a military disturbance arose in the realm and beacon fires were raised, the consort saw this and said, 'Oh how strange, there are so many fires,' and laughed for the first time. When this consort laughed once, there were a hundred charms. King You considered this a happy thing, and without any cause, he constantly raised beacon fires. The feudal lords came, but there was no enemy. Since there was no enemy, they left. Since this happened repeatedly, there were none who came. At one time, evil rebels arose from a neighboring country and attacked King You's capital; though he raised the beacon fires, the soldiers, accustomed to the consort's fires, did not come. At that time the capital fell, and King You finally perished. It is terrifying that this consort became a wild fox and ran away. Since such things exist, from now on, too, if I summon you, you must all come like this. Shigemori heard a strange thing and summoned you. However, I have heard it correctly now; it was a mistake. Return quickly."
So they were all sent back. In truth, he had not heard any such thing, but following the words with which he had admonished his father, he ascertained whether the forces would attach to himself or not; also, he did not intend to make war between father and son, but it was a stratagem to soften the Lay Priest Prime Minister's rebellious intent. "Though the ruler is not a ruler, the subject cannot be a non-subject; though the father is not a father, the son cannot be a non-son. Be loyal to the ruler, be filial to the father."
It did not differ from what the Literate King (Confucius) proclaimed. The Sovereign heard this and said, "Though it is not a new thing, the Minister's heart is admirable. He has repaid malice with grace. " The people of the time were impressed, saying, "Because his karma is splendid, he has reached General and Minister. His appearance and carriage surpass others; his talent and learning also excel in the world. It is said, 'If there is a remonstrating minister in the country, that country is at peace; if there is a remonstrating child in the house, that house is surely correct.' He is a Minister rare in both ancient times and the Latter Age."

div.head: 2.8. The Exile of the New Major Counselor

div.p: [2.8.1] On the second day of the same sixth month, the New Major Counselor Lord Narichika was brought out to the seat of the nobles and offered food, but his chest was choked and blocked, and he could not even lift his chopsticks. When the carriage was brought close and they said "Quickly, quickly," the Major Counselor got in against his will. Soldiers surrounded him front, back, left, and right.
