There was not a single person on his side. "I wish to see Lord Komatsu once more," he said, but that too was not granted. "Even for one suffering a heavy sentence and going to a distant province, is there no one who can accompany me?" He lamented inside the carriage, and the guarding warriors all dampened the sleeves of their armor. Going south from Nishi-Suzaku, he looked at the Imperial Palace as something now distant. Down to the servants and ox-drivers he had been accustomed to seeing for years, there was none who did not shed tears and wring their sleeves. The hearts of the wife and young people remaining in the capital can be surmised to be pitiful. Passing the Toba Palace, he thought, "When there were royal visits to this palace, I never missed accompanying them once," and he passed by looking from afar at his own mountain villa, the Suhama-dono. Coming out to the south gate, they hurried him, saying the boat was late. "Where is this going? If I am to be killed anyway, let it be here near the capital," he said, which was a compelling point.

[2.8.2] He asked a warrior close by, "Who is it?" and he replied, "Namba no Jirō Tsunetō." "Is there anyone from my side in this vicinity? Before I get on the boat, I have something to leave word of. Find them and bring them."
Although he ran around the area searching, there was not a single person who said he was on the Major Counselor's side. "When it was my world, there must have been one or two thousand people who followed me. The sadness that there is no one to see me off in this state, even from a distance!"
When he wept, even the fierce warriors all dampened their sleeves. The only things accompanying him were endless tears. For pilgrimages to Kumano or Tennōji, he used to ride in a boat built with three ridges of two tiles, with twenty or thirty following boats rowed in succession; now, forced into a wretched roofed boat, with a large curtain pulled around it, accompanied by unfamiliar soldiers, leaving the capital this day for the last time, heading far over the waves—his heart can be surmised to be pitiful. That day they arrived at Daimotsu Bay in Settsu Province.

[2.8.3] That the New Major Counselor, a person who should have been executed, was pardoned with exile was due to Lord Komatsu speaking in various ways. When this man was still a Middle Counselor and administered Mino Province, in the winter of the first year of Kaō, shrine servants of the Hirano Manor, a holding of the Mountain Gate, came to the Deputy Governor, Lieutenant of the Gate Guards Masatomo, to sell arrowroot; the Deputy Governor got drunk on sake and put ink on the arrowroot. When the shrine servants resorted to abuse, he said, "Do not let them speak," and beat them scatteringly. Thereupon, hundreds of shrine servants broke into the Deputy Governor's place. The Deputy Governor defended himself according to the law, and more than ten shrine servants were beaten to death. Because of this, on the third day of the eleventh month of the same year, the monks of the Mountain Gate rose up tremendously and petitioned that the Governor, Lord Narichika, be exiled and the Deputy Governor, Lieutenant of the Gate Guards Masatomo, be imprisoned. Although he was sent out as far as Nishi-shichijō to be exiled to Bitchū Province, the Sovereign perhaps wondered about it, and recalled him after five days. Although it was heard that the monks of the Mountain Gate cursed him tremendously, on the fifth day of the first month of the second year, he concurrently held the post of Captain of the Right Gate Guards and became Head of the Police Commission. At that time, Lords Sukekata and Kanemasa were passed over. Lord Sukekata was an old man and an elder. Lord Kanemasa was a person of splendor. That the head of the house was passed over was regrettable. This was a reward for the construction of the Sanjō Palace. On the 13th day of the fourth month of the third year, he was promoted to Senior Second Rank. At that time, Middle Counselor of Nakamikado Lord Muneie was passed over. On the 27th day of the tenth month of the first year of Angen, he rose from Former Middle Counselor to Provisional Major Counselor. People mocked him, saying, "He should have been cursed by the monks of the Mountain Gate." However, perhaps because of that now, he met with such sorrow. In general, the punishment of gods and the curses of men are sometimes fast and sometimes slow; they are not uniform.

[2.8.4] On the third day, there was a commotion at Daimotsu Bay that a messenger had come from the capital. The New Major Counselor heard it and thought, "Is it to kill me here?" But it was not so; it was a messenger saying he should be exiled to Kojima in Bizen. There was a letter from Lord Komatsu. "I spoke so much to try somehow to have you placed in a remote mountain village near the capital, but that it was not granted is because I have no worth in the world. However, I have requested your life at least."
Also, to Namba he sent word: "Make sure not to go against his wishes in your service," and he had prepared and sent detailed provisions for the journey. The New Major Counselor was separated from the Sovereign he had thought so gracious, parted from his wife and young children whom he thought he could not leave even for a moment, and thought, "Where is this going? It is unlikely I will return to my hometown again and see my wife and children. Years ago, when I was exiled due to the lawsuit of the Mountain Gate, the Sovereign regretted it and recalled me from Nishi-shichijō. Then, this is not the Sovereign's admonition. How did this happen?"
Looking up at heaven and bowing down to earth, he wept and grieved, but it was of no avail. When dawn came, they pushed the boat out and went down; all along the way he only choked with tears, not thinking he would live long, but his dew-like life did not vanish. Separated by the white waves in his wake, the capital gradually became distant; as the days piled up, the distant province drew near. Rowing to Kojima in Bizen, they placed him in a wretched brushwood hut of a commoner's house. As is the custom of an island, behind was the mountain, in front was the sea; the pine wind on the beach, the sound of the waves, all were endlessly sad.

[2.9.1] It was not limited to the Major Counselor alone; there were many fellows who suffered punishment. It was heard that the Lay Priest Middle Captain of Ōmi, Renjō, was sent to Sado Province; the Governor of Yamashiro, Motokane, to Hōki Province; the Senior Assistant Minister of Ceremonies, Masatsuna, to Harima Province; the Magistrate of Religion, Nobufusa, to Awa Province; and the New Heike Magistrate, Sukeyuki, to Mimasaka Province.

[2.9.2] At that time, the Lay Priest Prime Minister was at his villa in Fukuhara; on the 20th of the same month, he sent Settsu no Saemon Morizumi as a messenger to the Middle Counselor of the Gate [Norimori], saying, "I have something in mind. Have the Minor Captain of Tamba come here immediately."
When this was conveyed, the Middle Counselor said, "Well then, if it were as times used to be, whatever happened would be fine, but what shall we do now? It is sad to make him worry anew."
But since he said the Minor Captain must go down to Fukuhara, the Minor Captain departed weeping. The ladies-in-waiting lamented, saying that since it was a hopeless matter, the Middle Counselor should just speak on his behalf. The Middle Counselor said, "I have said all I can. Other than abandoning the world, what is there to say now? However, even if I end up in some distant bay, you must visit me as long as I live. " The Minor Captain had a young child who was turning three this year. Usually, as he was a young man, he did not pay such deep attention to his children, but now that the end had come, it naturally weighed on his mind. "I want to see this little one once more."
Thus he spoke. The nurse brought the child in her arms. The Minor Captain placed the child on his knees, stroked his hair, and shedding tears profusely, said, "Alas, when you turned seven, I thought I would make you a man and present you to the Lord. But now it is useless to speak of it. If you survive and grow up, become a monk and pray for my afterlife."
Although the child's young mind could hardly distinguish what was said, he nodded; beginning with the Minor Captain, the mother, the nurse, the ladies-in-waiting, and the people sitting in that room, whether sensitive or insensitive, all soaked their sleeves. The messenger from Fukuhara said he must go as far as Toba this very night, but the Minor Captain said, "Since I will not live long anyway, I wish to spend at least tonight within the capital."
But as the messenger insisted, he went out to Toba that night. The Middle Counselor, in his excessive resentment, did not even accompany him to the carriage this time.

[2.9.3] On the 22nd, when he arrived down in Fukuhara, the Lay Priest Prime Minister ordered Seno no Tarō Kaneyasu to exile him to Bitchū Province. Kaneyasu, fearing where the Middle Counselor might hear of this, respectfully comforted him in various ways along the road. However, the Minor Captain was not comforted in the slightest. Day and night he only chanted the name of the Buddha and lamented over his father. The New Major Counselor was at Kojima in Bizen, but the warrior in charge, Namba Jirō Tsunetō, thinking this was still too close to the boat crossing and thus bad, moved him inland, placing him in a mountain temple called Ariki-no-Bessho in the village of Niwase, on the border of the two provinces of Bizen and Bitchū. Since the distance between Seno in Bitchū and Ariki-no-Bessho in Bizen was less than fifty town-lengths (chō), the Minor Captain of Tamba must have felt nostalgic for the wind from that direction; once, he summoned Kaneyasu and asked, "How far is the road from here to Ariki-no-Bessho in Bitchū, where the Major Counselor is said to be?" Kaneyasu must have thought it would be bad to let him know directly, so he said, "It is twelve or thirteen days one way."
At that time, the Minor Captain shed tears profusely and said, "Japan used to be thirty-three provinces in ancient times, but in the middle ages it was divided into sixty-six provinces. Thus, Bizen, Bitchū, and Bingo were originally one province. Also, the two provinces of Dewa and Mutsu heard of in the east were anciently one province of sixty-six districts, but then twelve districts were split off to establish the province of Dewa. Thus, when the Middle Captain Sanekata was exiled to Oshu, saying he wanted to see the famous place of that province, the Akoya Pine, he wandered searching through the province; on the road back, unable to find it, he met an old man and asked, 'Hey, you look like an old-fashioned person; do you know the place called the Akoya Pine, a famous spot in this province?' The old man replied, 'It is not in this province at all; it must be in Dewa Province.' Sanekata said, 'So, you do not know it either. It is the end of the world, and people have quickly lost track of the famous places of the province.' As he was about to pass by in vain, the old man held back the Middle Captain's sleeve and said, 'Ah, my lord,

lg.l: Hidden by the Akoya Pine of Michinoku, the moon that should come out does not emerge.

div.p:
[2.9.4] Are you asking about the famous Akoya Pine of this province with the heart of this poem in mind? That is a poem composed when the two provinces were one. After the twelve districts were split off, it must be in Dewa Province. ' When he said this, the Middle Captain Sanekata said 'In that case,' and crossed over to Dewa Province to see the Akoya Pine. For the 'Red-Belly' Messenger to go up to the capital from Dazaifu in Tsukushi, the one-way journey is fixed at fifteen days. If you say twelve or thirteen days, that is almost going down to Chinzei from here. Even if you say it is far, the distance between Bizen and Bitchū surely cannot exceed two or three days. You speak of what is near as far because you do not want Naritsune to know the place where the Major Counselor is."
After saying this, although he missed him, he did not ask again.

[2.10.1] Meanwhile, the Administrator of Hosshōji, Provisional Senior Vicar Shunkan, the Taira Magistrate Yasuyori, and this Minor Captain were together exiled to Kikai-ga-shima in the Satsuma Gulf. That island is a place one reaches after leaving the capital and braving the waves for a great distance. Ordinarily, ships do not go there. People are rare on the island. Although there are people naturally, they are unlike the people of this land. Their color is black like oxen. Hair grows thick all over their bodies, and they do not understand speech. Men do not wear caps, and women do not tie up their hair. Since they have no clothing, they do not look like humans. Since they have no food, they only make killing their priority. Since they do not cultivate humble mountain fields, there are no rice or grains; since they do not pick mulberry in gardens, there are no silks. In the middle of the island, there is a high mountain. Fire burns constantly. It is full of a substance called sulfur. Therefore, it is also named Sulfur Island. Thunder constantly rumbles up and down, and rain is frequent at the foot. It does not seem like a place where human life could endure for even a moment of a single day.

[2.10.2] Meanwhile, the New Major Counselor thought things might relax a little, but hearing that his son, the Minor Captain of Tamba Naritsune, had already been exiled to Kikai-ga-shima, he thought, "What is there to hope for now with things so heartless?" and expressing his desire to become a monk, he sent word to the Lord of Komatsu via an opportunity; the Lord inquired of the Cloistered Emperor, and permission was granted. He immediately became a monk. Changing from his glorious robes, he wasted away in ink-dyed sleeves, estranged from the floating world.

[2.10.3] The wife of the Major Counselor was living in hiding in the vicinity of Urin-in in the northern hills of the capital. Even in normal times, a place one is not used to living in is gloomy, and as she was hiding deeply, the passing days and months seemed hard to dawn and hard to darken. Although there were many waiting women and samurai, some feared the world, and some were concerned about public eyes, so not a single person visited. However, among them, a samurai named Genzaemon-no-jō Nobutoshi, whose compassion was especially deep, constantly visited. Once, the wife summoned Nobutoshi and said, "Indeed, I heard he was at Kojima in Bizen, but lately I hear he is at a place called Ariki-no-Bessho or something. Somehow, I wish to send even a fragile written note and hear news of him. " Nobutoshi suppressed his tears and said, "Since I was young, I have received your mercy and have not left your side for a moment. When he went down, I asked by any means to serve as his attendant, but since it was not permitted by Rokuhara, I could do nothing. The voice with which he summoned me remains in my ears, and the words with which he admonished me are engraved on my liver; I have not forgotten them for a moment. Whatever fate this body may meet, I will take your letter and go. " Thus he spoke. The wife was exceedingly happy, and immediately wrote it and gave it to him. The young people also each had letters. Nobutoshi received these and went far down to search for Ariki-no-Bessho in Bizen Province. First, he explained his request to the warrior in charge, Namba Jirō Tsunetō, who was moved by the extent of his intent and immediately let him see the Major Counselor. The Lay Priest Major Counselor was just then speaking only of things in the capital and was sunk in grief when it was announced, "Nobutoshi has come from the capital."
"Is it a dream?" he said, hardly daring to listen, and correcting his posture, he summoned him, "Here, here."
When Nobutoshi entered and looked at him, first the wretchedness of his dwelling was one thing, but seeing his ink-dyed sleeves, Nobutoshi felt his eyes go dark and his spirit fade. He explained in detail the commands he had received from the wife, and took out the letters and presented them. When the Major Counselor opened and looked at them, the handwriting was obscured by tears and he could not tell who it was, but it was written, "The young people miss you and grieve so much, I can no longer bear the endless thoughts of my own body."
He grieved that his daily longing was as nothing compared to this. Thus four or five days passed, and Nobutoshi said, "I will stay here and see how you are at your final moment," but the warrior in charge, Namba Jirō Tsunetō, insisted it was not permitted, so unable to do otherwise, the Major Counselor said, "Then, go up. " "I will likely be gone soon. If you hear that I am no longer in this world, strictly pray for my afterlife."
Thus he spoke. He wrote a reply and gave it to him; Nobutoshi received it and said, "I will come again," and took his leave to go out, but the Major Counselor said, "I do not think I can wait for the time you come again. I miss you so much, just a moment more." And he called him back again and again. But since it could not be, Nobutoshi suppressed his tears and returned up to the capital. When he presented the letter to the wife, she opened it and looked; sensing that he had already become a monk, she found a lock of his hair in the back of the letter; she could not look at it a second time. Saying that a keepsake is now only a source of pain, she threw herself down and wept. The young people also wept and grieved with their voices raised.

[2.10.4] Meanwhile, the Lay Priest Major Counselor was finally killed on the 19th day of the same eighth month, at a place called Kibi-no-Nakayama in the village of Niwase, on the border of the two provinces of Bizen and Bitchū. His final moments were heard to be in various ways. They put poison in sake and urged him to drink, but since it did not work, they planted water chestnuts (spikes) at the bottom of a cliff about twenty feet high, and when they pushed him down from the top, he was pierced by the spikes and died. It seemed utterly cruel and pitiful. The wife of the Major Counselor, hearing that he was no longer a person of this world, had not changed her appearance until today, thinking she might somehow see him and show him her unchanged form once more. But now, asking what was the use, she went to a temple called Bodai-in, changed her appearance, performed the Buddhist services as prescribed, and prayed for his afterlife. This wife was the daughter of the Governor of Yamashiro, Atsukata. She was a surpassing beauty and was the unparalleled beloved of the Cloistered Emperor Go-Shirakawa, but it is said she was given to Lord Narichika, who was a person of rare favor. It was pathetic that the young children broke off flowers and scooped up water for offerings to pray for their father's afterlife. Thus, as time moved and things passed, the changing state of the world was no different from the Five Signs of Decay of a heavenly being.

[2.11.1] Here, the Major Counselor Lord Tokudaiji Sanesada had been passed over for General by the Taira's second son, Lord Munemori, and shut himself away for a while. When he announced he would become a monk, his retainers and samurai lamented together, wondering what to do. Among them was a retainer named Tō-kurōdo Shigekane. He was a man who understood many things; on a certain moonlit night, when Lord Sanesada had the shutters of the south face raised and was reciting poetry alone at the moon, Tō-kurōdo came, perhaps thinking to comfort him. "Who is it?" "It is Shigekane." "Why, what is the matter?" He replied, "Tonight the moon is especially clear and clarifies all hearts, so I have come."
The Major Counselor said, "It is admirable that you have come. I was feeling excessively lonely and bored with nothing to do." After that, they spoke of various idle things to comfort him. The Major Counselor said, "Looking carefully at the state of this world, the age of the Heike is increasingly prosperous. The Lay Priest Prime Minister's heir and second son are the Generals of the Left and Right. Soon there is the third son Tomomori, and the heir's son Koremori. If this one and that one follow in order, it does not seem that people of other families will ever be appointed General. Therefore, this is the end. I will become a monk. " Shigekane shed tears profusely and said, "If my Lord becomes a monk, everyone in your household, high and low, will become wanderers. Shigekane has devised a rare plan. For example, the Heike reverence Itsukushima in Aki exceedingly; what harm could there be? Please go to that shrine and make a prayer vow. If you remain in prayer for about seven days, there are many graceful dancing maidens called Naishi at that shrine. Make them think you are rare and treat them well. If they ask what prayer vow you are there for, tell them the truth. Then, when you go up, they will likely regret parting. Take the principal Naishi with you and go up to the capital. If they go up to the capital, they will surely visit West Hachijō. If asked, 'For what prayer vow did Lord Tokudaiji go to Itsukushima?' the Naishi will surely speak the truth. The Lay Priest Prime Minister is a man who especially loves such things, so thinking it happy that you went and prayed to the god he reveres, I believe there will be a favorable arrangement. " Lord Tokudaiji said, "This is something I had not thought of. What a rare scheme. I will go at once."
And suddenly beginning purification, he went to Itsukushima.

[2.11.2] Truly, at that shrine there were many women called Naishi who were graceful. While he remained for seven days, day and night they attended him and treated him without limit. During the seven days and seven nights, there were dances and music up to three times. Since they played biwa and koto, and performed Kagura, dances, and songs, Lord Sanesada also thought it delightful, and for the religious joy of the gods, he sang Imayō and Rōei, and there were rare court songs like Fuzoku and Saibara. The Naishi said, "It is the young lords of the Heike who usually visit this shrine; this visit of yours is rare indeed. For what prayer vow are you remaining here?" He replied, "Since I was passed over for General by another, it is for that prayer." So, having finished the seven days of seclusion, when he took his leave of the Great Myōjin and went up to the capital, more than ten of the principal young Naishi, regretting the parting, pushed off a boat and escorted him for a one-day journey. He took his leave, but saying that the parting was still too regrettable, he said "Just one more day's journey, just two more days' journey," and took them with him all the way to the capital. He brought them into the Tokudaiji residence, treated them in various ways, and sent them back with various gifts.

[2.11.3] The Naishi, saying that since they had come up this far, how could they not visit their master the Lay Priest Prime Minister, went to West Hachijō. The Lay Priest Prime Minister hurriedly came out to meet them and said, "Well, Naishi, what is this group visit?" "Lord Tokudaiji visited and secluded himself for seven days, and when he was going up, we escorted him for a one-day journey; but he said the parting was too regrettable, saying 'Just one more day, two days,' and brought us with him this far. " When he asked, "For what prayer vow did Tokudaiji go as far as Itsukushima?" they replied, "He said it was for the prayer of being General."
At that time, the Lay Priest nodded and said, "Ah, how touching. Leaving aside the many holy Buddhas and holy shrines in the Royal City, that he went to the god I revere and prayed is admirable. Since his intent is this earnest..." He had his heir Lord Komatsu, who was Minister of the Center and General of the Left, resign, passed over his second son Major Counselor Munemori who was General of the Right, and made Tokudaiji the General of the Left. Ah, what a splendid scheme. The New Major Counselor, not employing such wise strategies, raised a useless rebellion, destroyed himself, and caused his son and retainers to see such sorrow; it was truly pitiable.

[2.12.1] Meanwhile, the Cloistered Emperor, taking Archbishop Kōken of Miidera as his master, was to receive the secret rites of Shingon; having received the secret rites of the three parts—the Dainichi Sutra, the Diamond Peak Sutra, and the Susiddhikara Sutra—it was rumored that the initiation (abhiseka) would take place on the 4th of September at Miidera. The monks of the Mountain Gate complained in anger, "From ancient times, it is the precedent that Imperial initiations and precepts are all performed at this mountain. In particular, the guidance of the Mountain King is for precepts and initiation. If this is now performed at Miidera, we will burn the temple down completely."
Thus they spoke. Thinking this would be useless, the Emperor concluded his preparatory practices and stopped. However, thinking it was still his original intent, he took Archbishop Kōken of Miidera with him, made a royal visit to Tennōji, built the Chikō-in, used the water of Kamei as the Wisdom Water of the Five Vases, and performed the Dharma Transmission Initiation at the spiritual site of the first Buddhism.

[2.12.2] In order to quiet the disturbance of the Mountain Gate, the initiation was not held at Miidera, but on the mountain, disagreeable matters arose between the Hall Monks (Dōshū) and the Students (Gakushō), leading to battle many times. Each time the Scholar Monks were defeated, it seemed to be the destruction of the Mountain Gate and a great crisis for the Imperial House. The Hall Monks were originally children who were servants of the Students and became monks, or intermediate monks, who from the time of the governance of the mountain by the Abbot of Kongōju-in, Provisional Archbishop Kakujin, formed groups in the Three Pagodas, called themselves the Summer Assembly, and offered flowers to the Buddha. In recent years, calling themselves Practitioners (Gyōnin), they did not share matters with the Great Assembly, and thus won in these repeated battles. The Hall Monks disobeyed the orders of their masters and planned battles; the Great Assembly reported to the Court and appealed to the Warrior Houses that they should be quickly punished. Due to this, receiving a decree from the Lay Priest Prime Minister, the resident of Kii Province, Yuasa no Gon-no-kami Muneshige, and others, leading more than two thousand horsemen of the Kinai, joined the Great Assembly to attack the Hall Monks. The Hall Monks, who had been at Tōyōbō, went down to the Three Manors of Omi, led a large force, climbed the mountain again, built a fort at Hayao-zaka, and barricaded themselves in.

[2.12.3] On the 20th of the same September, at the first point of the Hour of the Dragon (8 AM), three thousand of the Great Assembly and over two thousand horsemen of the Government Army, a total force of over five thousand, pressed upon Hayao-zaka. Thinking that this time it would be settled, the Great Assembly tried to make the Government Army go first, and the Government Army tried to make the Great Assembly go first; as they argued, their hearts were divided, and they did not fight effectively. From inside the fort, crossbows were loosened and fired, so the Great Assembly and Government Army were shot down in great numbers. The Evil Bands allied with the Hall Monks were the burglars, robbers, mountain bandits, and pirates of the provinces. Since they were fellows of blazing greed who knew neither death nor life, they fought with the resolution of "I alone," and so this time too, the Student Army was defeated.

[2.13.1] After that, the Mountain Gate became increasingly desolate; apart from the Twelve Meditation Monks, residing monks were rare; the lectures of the valleys ceased, and the ascetic practices of the halls also declined. The windows of study were closed, and the floors of sitting meditation were empty. The spring flowers of the Four Teachings and Five Periods had no fragrance, and the autumn moon of the Three Truths as One was clouded. There was no one to trim the lamp of the Law of three hundred years, and the smoke of the incense of the Six Hours had likely ceased. The temple halls towered high, their three-story structures inserted into the blue sky; the ridgepoles excelled in the distance, their four-sided eaves hanging amidst the white mist. However, now the offerings to the Buddha are left to the mountain storm, and the golden faces are wet with red tears. The night moon trims the lamp, leaking through the gaps in the eaves; the dawn dew hangs jewels, adorning the lotus pedestal. Indeed, reaching the vulgar age of the End Times, the Buddhism of the Three Countries has gradually declined. Looking far to the Buddha's sites in India, the Bamboo Grove Monastery and the Jetavana Garden where the Buddha once preached the Law have now become the dens of foxes and wolves, and only the foundation stones likely remain. The water has ceased in the White Heron Pond, and only grass grows deep. The stupas of "Dismount from Palanquins" have become moss-covered and tilted. In China as well, Mt. Tiantai, Mt. Wutai, Baima Temple, and Yuquan Temple now lack resident monks and have fallen into ruin in various ways; the Dharma gates of the Greater and Lesser Vehicles have likely rotted at the bottom of boxes. In our country too, the Seven Great Temples of the Southern Capital have fallen into ruin, the Eight Sects and Nine Sects have died out, and although Atago and Takao once lined their temple eaves together, having been ruined in a single night, they have ended up as dens for Tengu. Perhaps because of this, people with heart all lament that the Tendai Buddhism, which was so noble, has now in Jishō ended in destruction. A monk leaving the mountain wrote a poem on the pillar of his quarters.

lg.l: The planted timber of the peak where I came to pray, has it completely changed to become a peak without people?

div.p: [2.13.2] Was this composed recalling the time when the Great Master Dengyō, in the ancient days of the mountain's founding, prayed to the Buddhas of Anuttara-samyak-sambodhi? It sounded very graceful. Although the eighth day is the day of Yakushi, there is no voice chanting "Namu." Although the Fourth Month is the month of the Manifestation, there is no one offering cloth strips. The vermillion fence has grown old and divine, and only the sacred rope likely remains.

[2.14.1] At that time, there was a rumor that Zenkōji had burned down. That Tathāgata was the supreme spiritual image of Jambudvipa, the Amida Triad of one foot and a half, which was cast and manifested when Shakyamuni, Maudgalyayana, and the rich man Moon-Canopy united their hearts, using Jambunada gold obtained from the Dragon Palace Castle at the request of the rich man Moon-Canopy when five kinds of evil diseases arose in the the land of Shravasti in ancient India and many people died. After the Buddha's Nirvana, it remained in India for over five hundred years, but by the principle of Buddhism moving East, it moved to the land of Paekche; after one thousand years, during the reign of King Seimei of Paekche, reaching the reign of Emperor Kinmei of our country, it moved from that country to this country, and passed years and months at the Bay of Naniwa in Settsu Province. Since it constantly emitted golden light, the era was named Konkō (Golden Light). In the first ten days of the third month of the third year, a resident of Shinano Province named Honda Yoshimitsu (Zenkō) of Omi came up to the capital, met that Tathāgata, and immediately inviting it, went down to Shinano Province—Zenkō carrying the Tathāgata by day, and Zenkō being carried by the Tathāgata by night—and enshrined it in the District of Minochi; since then, over five hundred and eighty years have passed, and we hear this is the first instance of burning. It is said, "When the King's Law is about to end, the Buddha's Law perishes first."
Perhaps because of this, it was said that the destruction of so many noble spiritual mountains was a portent that the King's Law had reached its end.

div.head: 2.15. Yasuyori's Prayer

div.p: [2.15.1] Meanwhile, the exiles of Kikai-ga-shima did not think their dew-like lives, hanging on the tips of grass blades, were worth regretting, but since clothing and food were constantly sent from the estate of the Minor Captain of Tamba's father-in-law, the Taira Middle Counselor Norimori, at Kanose in Hizen Province, the Abbot Shunkan and Yasuyori managed to live on. Yasuyori had become a monk at Murozumi in Suō when he was being exiled. He was given the Dharma name Shōshō. Since becoming a monk was his original desire,

lg.l: It is regrettable that I did not sooner abandon the world, which in the end I have turned away from like this.

div.p:
[2.15.2] Since the Minor Captain of Tamba and the Lay Priest Yasuyori were originally men of faith in Kumano, they said they wanted to somehow invite the Three Gongen of Kumano to this island and pray for their return to the capital, but the Abbot was by nature a man of no faith and did not join in. The two of them, with the same mind, searched around the island for a place that might resemble Kumano; there was the beauty of woods and ponds, with the appearance of red brocade and embroidery in various grades, and the wonder of cloud-topped peaks, with colors of jasper and silk not limited to one. The scenery of the mountain, down to the stands of trees, was superior to elsewhere. Looking to the south, the sea was boundless, and the waves of cloud and billows of smoke were deep; looking back to the north, from a towering mountain peak, a waterfall of one hundred shaku plunged down. The sound of the waterfall was especially terrible, and the wind in the pines was a divine dwelling; it closely resembled the Nachi Mountain where the Flying Waterfall Gongen resides. So, they immediately named that place the Nachi Mountain. Naming this peak Hongū (Main Shrine), that one Shingū (New Shrine), and calling the minor shrines "The Standard Prince," "That Prince," and so on, with Lay Priest Yasuyori as the leader and the Minor Captain of Tamba accompanying him, they imitated the Kumano Pilgrimage every day and prayed for their return to the capital. "Namu Gongen Diamond Youth, we pray you to bestow your mercy, let us return to our old home, and let us see our wives and children once more."
Thus they prayed. As the days accumulated, having no pure robes to change into, they wrapped themselves in hemp clothes; when they scooped water from the marsh for purification, they thought of it as the clear stream of the Iwada River, and when they climbed to a high place, they envisioned it as the Gate of Awakening (Hosshinmon). Every time they paid homage, the Lay Priest Yasuyori offered a prayer; having no paper for offerings, he broke off flowers and offered them, saying:

div.div: In the current year, the first year of Jishō, the sign being Hinoto-Tori, the months being the tenth month and second month, the number of days being over three hundred and fifty, choosing a lucky day and favorable time, with awe we speak: before the vast presence of the teachings of Japan's foremost great miracle, the Kumano Three Place Gongen, the Flying Waterfall Great Being (Mahasattva), the Great Patron of Faith, the Palace Guard Fujiwara no Naritsune, and the Novice Shōshō, exerting the sincerity of a pure single mind and extracting the will corresponding to the three actions, reverently speak. Indeed, the Bodhisattva of Witness (Shōjō) is the Lord of Teachings who saves from the sea of suffering, the King of Awakening of the perfection of the three bodies. Or, he is the Master of the Eastern Pure Lapis Lazuli Medicine King, the Tathāgata who completely removes all sicknesses. Or, he is the Master who teaches in the Southern Potalaka, the Great Being who enters the heavy gate of mystery. The Young Prince is the original master of the Saha World, the Great Being who bestows fearlessness. Manifesting the Buddha-face on the summit, he fulfills the desires of sentient beings. Therefore, from the One Man above down to the ten thousand people below, or for peace in the present world, or for a good place in the afterlife, in the morning they scoop pure water to rinse away the filth of defilement, and in the evening they face the deep mountains and chant the precious titles, and the response is never negligent. We liken the height of the towering peaks to the height of the divine virtue, and compare the depth of the steep valleys to the depth of the great vow; parting the clouds we climb, and braving the dew we descend. If we do not rely on the ground of benefit here, how can we move our steps on the precipitous path? If we do not look up to the virtue of the Gongen, why would you necessarily reside in this secluded boundary? Therefore, Great Gongen of Witness, Great Being of the Flying Waterfall, line up your eyes of blue-lotus compassion, prick up your deer-like ears, perceive our peerless sincerity, and accept our earnest intentions one by one. If so, then the Two Gongen of Musubi and Hayatama, following each capacity, to guide sentient beings with affinity and to save the flocks without affinity, abandoning the dwelling adorned with seven treasures, softening your light of eighty-four thousand kinds, have become the same as the dust of the Six Paths and Three Existences. Therefore, fixed karma can also be turned; worshipping to seek long life and obtain long life, we link our sleeves and offer cloth and gifts without a gap. Layering the robes of forbearance, offering the flowers of the way of awakening, shaking the floor of the sanctuary, clearing the water of faith, we fill the pond of bringing benefit to living beings. If the gods accept this, why should our desires not be fulfilled? Looking up, we pray: Twelve Place Gongen, align your wings of benefit, fly far into the sky of the sea of suffering, stop the grief of exile, and let us accomplish the long-cherished desire of returning to the capital. Re-worship.

div.p: [2.15.3] Thus Yasuyori offered the prayer.

[2.16.1] The Minor Captain of Tamba and the Lay Priest Yasuyori constantly visited the Three Gongen and sometimes held all-night vigils. Once, the two held a vigil and sang Imayō songs all night long. Toward dawn, the Lay Priest Yasuyori dozed off a little; in a dream, a small boat with white sails rowed in from the offing, and from within the boat, twenty or thirty ladies in red hakama came up, beat hand-drums, and tuning their voices, sang:

lg.l: More than the vows of ten thousand Buddhas, the vow of the Thousand-Armed One is reliable;
Even withered grass and trees, we hear, suddenly bloom and bear fruit.

div.p:
[2.16.2] Singing this clearly three times, they vanished as if wiped away. After waking from the dream, Lay Priest Yasuyori felt a sense of wonder and said, "This must be a manifestation of the Dragon God. Among the Three Gongen, the Western Deity is in original form the Thousand-Armed Kannon. Since the Dragon God is one of the Twenty-Eight Attendants of the Thousand-Armed One, his acceptance is reliable."
Also, one night when the two were holding a vigil and similarly dozing, in a dream, the wind blowing from the offing blew two leaves onto the sleeves of the two men; when they casually picked them up and looked, they were leaves of the Nagi tree of Kumano. On those two Nagi leaves, a poem had been written in worm-eaten holes.

lg.l: Since prayers to the mighty gods are frequent, why should you not return to the capital?

div.p: [2.16.3] The Lay Priest Yasuyori, in his longing for his old home, as a desperate measure, made one thousand stupas, and wrote the Sanskrit letter 'A', the year, month and day, his kana name, his real name, and two poems.

lg.l: That I am here on a small island in the offing of the Satsuma Gulf, tell my parents, O eight-fold salt wind.
Consider this: even on a journey thought to be short, one still longs for one's old home.

div.p:
[2.16.4] He took these out to the shore and said, "Namu Kimyō Chōrai, Brahma, Indra, the Four Heavenly Kings, the Earth Deity, the various guardian deities of the Royal City, and especially the Kumano Gongen and the Itsukushima Great Deity, please convey even just one to the capital."
Saying this, every time the white waves of the offing approached and retreated, he floated a stupa on the sea. Since he put them in the sea as he made them, as the days accumulated, the number of stupas also accumulated. Perhaps his thoughtful heart became a convenient wind. Or perhaps the gods and Buddhas sent them. Among the thousand stupas, one washed up on the beach in front of the Great Deity of Itsukushima in Aki Province.

[2.16.5] Here, a monk related to the Lay Priest Yasuyori, thinking that if there were a suitable opportunity he would somehow cross to that island and hear of his fate, set out on a pilgrimage to the western provinces, and first visited Itsukushima. There, a layman in hunting attire, who appeared to be a shrine official, came out. While this monk was telling an idle story, he asked, "Although it is said that the benefits of 'softening the light and mingling with the dust' are various, by what karma does this deity form a bond with the scales of the vast ocean? " The official answered, "This is the third princess of the Dragon King Sāgara, a manifestation of the Womb Realm."
He recounted the profound and miraculous events from the time of the deity's manifestation on this island up to the present salvation and benefits. Perhaps because of this, the eight shrines lined up their roof tiles, and since the shrine is by the ocean, the moon becomes clear with the ebb and flow of the tide. When the tide is full, the great Torii gate and the scarlet fence look like lapis lazuli. When the tide ebbs, though it is a summer night, frost seems to lie on the white sand before the shrine. Feeling increasingly reverent, he sat making an offering of the Law; gradually the sun set and the moon rose, and as the tide came in, among the swaying seaweed and debris, the shape of a stupa appeared; when he casually picked it up and looked, it was the words "I am here on a small island in the offing," written in a flowing hand. Since the characters had been carved in, they were not washed away by the waves and appeared clearly. Saying "Ah, how miraculous," he stuck it in his portable shrine, went up to the capital, and showed it to Yasuyori's old mother, the nun, and his wife and children, who were living in hiding at a place called Murasakino, north of Ichijō. They grieved, saying, "If so, why did this stupa not drift toward China, but transmit itself all the way here, only to make us worry anew?"
Reaching the distant Imperial hearing, the Cloistered Emperor looked at it and said, "Ah, how pitiful. So these fellows are still alive."
It was awe-inspiring that he shed tears. Since he sent it to the Minister of Komatsu, the Minister showed it to his father, the Lay Priest Prime Minister. Kakinomoto no Hitomaro thought of the boat hidden by the island; Yamabe no Akahito gazed at the crane in the reeds. Sumiyoshi Myōjin thought of the gable; Miwa Myōjin pointed to the gate where cedars stand. Ever since Susanoo-no-Mikoto began the thirty-one syllable Waka in ancient times, various gods and Buddhas have expressed thoughts of a hundred thousand kinds through poetry. Since the Lay Priest was not made of rock or wood, he spoke pitiably.

[2.17.1] Since the Lay Priest Prime Minister showed pity, there was no one in the capital, high or low, old or young, who did not hum the song of the exile of Kikai-ga-shima. Even so, since he made up to a thousand stupas, they must have been quite small. That it was transmitted all the way from the Satsuma Gulf to the capital is miraculous. Was it because he thought so excessively that it had such an effect?

[2.17.2] Long ago, when the Han Emperor attacked the Hu country, first Li Shaoqing was made Great General and 300,000 horsemen were directed there, but the Han army was weak and the Hu battle was strong, so the government army was completely destroyed. Moreover, the Great General Li Shaoqing was captured alive by the Hu King. Next, Su Wu was made Great General and 500,000 horsemen were directed there. Still the Han army was weak and the Barbarian battle was strong, so the government army was completely destroyed. Over six thousand soldiers were captured alive. Among them, starting with the Great General Su Wu, over 630 main soldiers had one leg cut off and were banished. There were those who died instantly, and those who died after some time. However, among them, Su Wu did not die. Having become a body without one leg, he climbed mountains to pick nuts, picked parsley in marshes in spring, and gleaned fallen ears in the fields in autumn to sustain his dew-like life. Since the many wild geese in the fields became used to Su Wu and did not fear him, he thought with nostalgia, "These are the ones who go to my old home," and writing his thoughts in one note, he instructed them, "Strictly deliver this to the Han Emperor," tied it to a goose's wing, and released it. The wild geese of the fields, being diligent, always fly from the northern path to the capital in autumn; when Emperor Zhao of Han was on an excursion in the Shanglin Park, the evening sky was thinly clouded and the moment was somewhat sad, when a line of geese flew over.
From among them, one goose flew down and dropped the jeweled letter tied to its wing that it had bitten off. An official took this and presented it to the Emperor. When he opened and looked at it, it was written: "Long ago I was shut in the cave of a rocky cavern, spending the sorrow and lament of three springs; now I am abandoned in the furrows of a vast field, becoming a one-legged man of the Hu barbarians. Though my corpse may be scattered in the Hu land, my soul will serve by the Lord's side a second time. " From that time, letters have been called "Goose Writing" and named "Goose Notes." "Ah, how pitiful, it is the trace of Su Wu. He must still be in the Hu country."
Saying this, this time orders were given to a general named Li Guang, and one million horsemen were sent. This time, the Han battle was strong, and the army of the Hu country was defeated. Hearing that his side had won the battle, Su Wu crawled out from the wilderness and announced his name, "This is the ancient Su Wu. " Having spent nineteen years, and with one leg cut off, he was carried in a palanquin and returned to his old home. Although Su Wu was sent to the Hu country at the age of sixteen, somehow he had hidden the banner given by the Emperor, and kept it without parting from his person. Now taking it out and entering the Emperor's presence, both the Lord and subjects were moved beyond measure. Since his great merit for the Lord was unparalleled, he was given many great provinces, and furthermore, it is heard he was given the office of Chancellor of Dependent States.

[2.17.3] Li Shaoqing remained in the Hu country and never returned. Although he lamented, wishing somehow to return to the Han court, the Hu King did not permit it, so he could not. The Han Emperor, not knowing this, thought he was a person disloyal to his Lord, dug up the corpses of his two parents who had passed away, and beat them. Besides that, his six relations were all punished. Li Shaoqing heard this, and his resentment became deep. However, still longing for his old home, he composed a scroll explaining his lack of disloyalty to the Lord and sent it; the Emperor said, "Then it was a pitiable thing," and regretted that he had dug up and beaten the corpses of the parents.
Su Wu of the Han house sent a writing on a goose's wing to his old village; Yasuyori of our country transmitted a poem to his old home via the waves. That was the diversion of a brush, this was two poems; that was the ancient age, this is the end age; the Hu country and Kikai-ga-shima are separated by borders, and though the eras are different, the sentiment is the same sentiment. These were rare things.

[3.1.1] On the first day of the first month of the second year of Jishō, the paying of respects was performed at the Cloistered Emperor's palace, and on the fourth day, the Imperial Visit to Parents took place. Although nothing was different from the usual precedents, since the New Major Counselor Narichika and many close attendants had been lost in the summer of the previous year, the Cloistered Emperor's anger had not yet ceased; he considered the government of the world with indifference, and his heart was not at ease. The Lay Priest Prime Minister, too, after Tada no Kurōdo Yukitsuna had informed him, thought of his Lord as someone to be guarded against; although on the surface it seemed there was no trouble, underneath he was cautious and only smiled bitterly.
[3.1.2] On the 7th day of the same first month, a comet appeared in the east. It is also called the Breath of Chiyou. It is also called Red Breath. On the 18th day, its light increased.

[3.1.3] Meanwhile, the Lay Priest Prime Minister's daughter, Kenreimon-in—who at that time was still known as the Empress (Chūgū)—became ill, causing grief above the clouds and below the heavens. Sutra readings began at various temples, Imperial messengers were sent to various shrines, physicians exhausted their medicines, Yin-Yang masters exhausted their arts, and great and secret rites were performed without leaving a single one undone. However, her illness was not merely ordinary; it was heard that she was pregnant. The Emperor is eighteen this year, and the Empress is becoming twenty-two. However, neither a Prince nor a Princess has yet been born. If it is a Prince, how splendid it will be; the people of the Heike rejoiced together as if the Prince were already born. People of other families also said to one another, "The prosperity of the Heike has found its time; there is no doubt it will be the birth of a Prince. " Since the pregnancy was confirmed, orders were given to high and noble priests of proven efficacy to perform great and secret rites, praying to the stars, Buddhas, and Bodhisattvas for the birth of a Prince. On the first day of the sixth month, the Empress donned the maternity sash. The Omuro of Ninnaji, Cloistered Imperial Prince Kakuhō, visited the palace and performed incantations using the Rite of the Peacock Sutra. The Abbot of Tendai, Cloistered Imperial Prince Kakukai, also visited and performed the Rite of Transforming into a Male.

[3.1.4] While this was happening, as the Empress's months accumulated, her body suffered greatly. One could imagine that Lady Li of Han, whose single smile had a hundred charms, looked like this on her sickbed in the Zhaoyang Palace; she seemed even more piteous than Yang Guifei of Tang, like a branch of pear blossom bearing spring rain, drooping in the wind like a lotus, or heavy with dew like a maiden flower. Coinciding with the time of such illness, terrifying possessing spirits took hold of her. Caught in the net of the Bright Kings, the mediums revealed the spirits. Specifically, they were said to be the spirit of the Sanuki Retired Emperor, the malice of the Evil Minister of the Left of Uji, the dead spirit of the New Major Counselor Narichika, the evil spirit of the Monk Saikō, and the living spirits of the exiles of Kikai-ga-shima. Because of this, the Prime Minister said that both living and dead spirits must be appeased; at that time, the posthumous title was immediately given to the Sanuki Retired Emperor, naming him Emperor Sutoku. The Evil Minister of the Left of Uji was granted posthumous office and rank, being awarded Prime Minister and Senior First Rank. It was heard that the Imperial Messenger was the Minor Internal Secretary Koremoto. The grave in question was in the province of Yamato, Soekami District, village of Kawakami, at the burial ground of Hannyano. After being dug up and discarded in the autumn of Hōgen, the corpse had become soil by the roadside, and year after year only spring grass grew lushly. Now that the Imperial Messenger has come seeking it and read the edict, how happy the departed soul must have felt. Vengeful spirits are indeed terrifying things. Thus, the deposed Crown Prince Sawara was named Emperor Sudō, and Imperial Princess Inoue was restored to the rank of Empress. These were all strategies to appease vengeful spirits. That Retired Emperor Reizei went mad, and Cloistered Emperor Kazan slipped from the fixed position of the ten virtues and ten thousand chariots, was due to the spirit of the Minister of Popular Affairs Motokata. That Emperor Sanjō's eyes were blinded was due to the spirit of the chaplain Kansan.

[3.1.5] The Middle Counselor of the Gate [Norimori], hearing rumors of such things, spoke to the Lord of Komatsu: "Prayers for the Empress's delivery are being said in various ways. Whatever is said, I do not believe there is anything better than an extraordinary amnesty. Above all, what merit or root of goodness could compare to recalling the exiles of Kikai-ga-shima?"
When he said this, the Lord of Komatsu sat before his father, the Zen Initiate, and said, "It is pitiful that the Middle Counselor grieves so intensely about the matter of that Minor Captain of Tamba. Regarding the Empress's illness, as I hear it, it is rumored to be especially the dead spirit of Lord Narichika. Even if you think to appease the dead spirit of the Major Counselor, you should recall the Minor Captain who is alive. If you put people's thoughts to rest, your own thoughts will be fulfilled; if you grant people's wishes, your own wish will be accomplished, the Empress will soon give birth to a Prince, and the glory of our house will be increasingly prosperous."
When he spoke thus, the Lay Priest Prime Minister, unlike his usual self, softened unexpectedly and said, "Well then, what of Shunkan and the Monk Yasuyori? " "They too should be recalled together. If even one is left behind, it would conversely be a sin." When he said this, the Lay Priest replied, "The matter of the Monk Yasuyori is one thing, but Shunkan is a man who became somebody entirely through my recommendation. Yet, with so many places available, he built a fortress at my mountain villa in Shishigatani, and touching on matters, engaged in outrageous behavior; therefore, Shunkan is out of the question. " The Lord of Komatsu returned, called for his uncle the Middle Counselor, and said, "The Minor Captain will soon be pardoned. Please set your mind at ease." The Middle Counselor joined his hands and rejoiced. "I felt that when he was sent down, why did I not ask to accompany him? Every time I see Norimori, I shed tears; it is pitiful." The Lord of Komatsu said, "Truly, you must feel that way. Whoever the child, it is sad; I will speak well for him." And he went inside.

[3.1.6] Meanwhile, it was decided that the exiles of Kikai-ga-shima should be recalled, and a letter of pardon was issued from the Lay Priest Prime Minister. The messenger had already left the capital. The Middle Counselor, in his excessive joy, added a private messenger to the official one and sent him down. Although the instruction was "Turn night into day and go down quickly," since the sea route does not follow one's heart, braving wind and waves on the journey, though they left the capital in late July, it was around the 20th of the Long Month (September) that they arrived at Kikai-ga-shima.

[3.2.1] The messenger was a man named Tan no Saemon-no-jō Motoyasu. Landing from the boat, he called out loudly, "Are the Minor Captain of Tamba and the Taira Magistrate Lay Priest, who were exiled from the capital, here? " The two men were doing their usual Kumano pilgrimage and were not there. Abbot Shunkan alone remained; hearing this, he said, "Is this a dream because I think too much of it? Or is it the Devil of the Sixth Heaven speaking to deceive my heart? It does not seem like reality."
Flustered and confused, half-running, half-falling, he rushed before the messenger and announced his name, "What is it? This is Shunkan, exiled from the capital."
The attendant took out the Lay Priest Prime Minister's letter of pardon from a letter bag hanging around his neck and presented it. When he opened and looked at it, it read: "Heavy crimes are exempted from distant exile; thoughts of returning to the capital should be formed quickly. Due to prayers for the Empress's delivery, an extraordinary amnesty is granted. Therefore, the Kikai-ga-shima exiles, Minor Captain Naritsune and the Monk Yasuyori, are pardoned."
Only this was written; there were no characters for "Shunkan." Thinking it must be on the wrapping paper, he looked at the wrapping paper, but it was not seen. He read from the end to the beginning, and from the beginning to the end, but only "two persons" was written; "three persons" was not written.

[3.2.2] By then, the Minor Captain and the Lay Priest Magistrate also came out; when the Minor Captain took it and read it, and when the Lay Priest Yasuyori read it, only "two persons" was written, and "three persons" was not written. Such things happen in dreams; trying to think it a dream, it is reality; thinking it reality, it is again like a dream. Furthermore, for the two men, there were many letters of tidings from the capital, but for Abbot Shunkan, there was not a single letter of inquiry. Thinking that his relatives had left no trace in the capital, it was unbearable to imagine. "After all, we three committed the same crime and are in the same place of exile. Why is it that at the time of pardon, two are recalled and one must remain here? Is it a lapse of memory by the Heike, or an error by the scribe? What kind of things are these?"
He looked up to heaven and threw himself on the ground, weeping and grieving, but it was to no avail. Clinging to the Minor Captain's sleeve, he said, "That Shunkan has come to this is due to the useless rebellion of your father, the late Major Counselor. Therefore, you should not think of it as someone else's affair. Even if there is no pardon, put me on this boat and take me to the land of Kyushu, even if I cannot go as far as the capital. While we were each here, like the swallows in spring and the wild geese of the fields in autumn bringing tidings, I naturally heard news of home. From now on, how shall I hear?"
He writhed in agony. The Minor Captain said, "Truly, you must feel that way. The joy of our recall is one thing, but seeing your condition as we leave you, I feel no desire to go. Even if we were to take you aboard and go up, since the Imperial Messenger says it is impossible, and moreover, if it were heard that all three left the island when there was no pardon, it would be bad for you. Naritsune will go up first, discuss with people, watch the mood of the Lay Priest Prime Minister, and send someone to fetch you. Until then, please wait, thinking of it as you have lived these past days. In any case, life is the most precious thing; though you are left out this time, in the end, why should there not be a pardon?"
Though he comforted him thus, Shunkan wept and writhed, heedless of being seen. As they clamored that the boat should launch, the Abbot would get on and then get off, and get off and then get on, acting indecisively. As a keepsake for the Minor Captain, he left his night quilt, and for the Lay Priest Yasuyori, he left a copy of the Lotus Sutra. When the mooring rope was untied and they pushed off, the Abbot clung to the rope, waist-deep and armpit-deep in water, dragged out until he could stand no longer; when he could no longer stand, he clung to the boat and pleaded, "Now, how can you all finally abandon Shunkan? I did not think it would come to this. The friendship of past days now counts for nothing. Just bend the rules and let me on. At least as far as the land of Kyushu."
Although he pleaded, the Imperial Messenger from the capital said, "It is by no means possible," and pulling away the hands clinging to the boat, the boat finally rowed out.
The Abbot, helpless, climbed onto the beach and fell down; like a small child longing for a nurse or mother, he stamped his feet (ashi-zuri) and screamed, "Let me on and go! Take me with you!" But as is the way of a boat rowing away, only white waves remained behind. Although the boat was not yet far, it could not be seen through his tears, so the Abbot ran up to a high place and beckoned toward the offing. Even Matsura Sayohime, waving her scarf as she longed for the boat to China, could not have exceeded this, it seemed. The boat rowed out of sight and the sun set, but he did not return to his wretched sleeping place; letting the waves wash his feet and withering in the dew, he spent the night right there. "Surely, since the Minor Captain is a man of deep feeling, he will speak in a good way for me"—hanging his hope on this, the heart that did not cast itself into that current was indeed fragile. The sorrow of Zhuang Li and Xi Li being abandoned on the sea-rock mountain in ancient times—now he truly understood it.

[3.3.1] Meanwhile, these people left Kikai-ga-shima and arrived at Kanose Manor in Hizen Province, the territory of the Taira Middle Counselor. The Middle Counselor sent a person down from the capital saying, "Within the year the wind and waves are violent, and the journey is uncertain; take good care of yourselves there, and come up when it becomes spring."
So the Minor Captain spent the end of the year at Kanose Manor.

[3.3.2] Meanwhile, from the Hour of the Tiger (4 AM) on the 12th day of November of the same year, the Empress showed signs of labor, and Rokuhara and the whole capital were in an uproar. The place of birth was the Ikedono at Rokuhara, and the Cloistered Emperor also made a royal visit there. Starting with the Regent, the Prime Minister, and the nobles and courtiers below them—everyone who counted as a person in the world, who had hopes for official rank, or who held estates and offices—not a single one was absent. As for precedents, there are cases where a great amnesty is performed when a Consort or Empress faces childbirth. On the 11th day of the ninth month of the second year of Daiji, when Taikenmon-in gave birth, there was a great amnesty. Taking that as a precedent, many serious offenders were pardoned this time, but that Abbot Shunkan alone was not pardoned was indeed pitiful.

[3.3.3] Vows were made that if the birth were safe, processions would be made to Yawata, Hirano, Oharano, and other shrines. The Seal of the Law Sengen offered the invocation. As for shrines, starting with the Grand Shrine of Ise, over twenty locations; as for Buddhist temples, Tōdaiji, Kōfukuji, and sixteen locations below them received Imperial sutra readings. The messengers for the sutra readings were those among the palace guards who held office. Fellows in plain hunting robes wearing swords, carrying various sutra reading offerings, swords, and robes, continued one after another from the Eastern Dais across the Southern Garden and out the Western Middle Gate. It was a splendid sight.

[3.3.4] Since the Minister of Komatsu was a person who was never flustered by good or bad, after a long interval, he had the carriages of his heir, the Provisional Assistant Master of the Left Division Major General, and other young lords follow, and presented forty sets of various robes and seven silver swords placed on wide lids, and had twelve horses led in. It was heard that this followed the precedent of the Lord of the Mido presenting horses when Jōtōmon-in gave birth in the Kankō era. Since this Minister was the Empress's older brother, and they had the bond of father and child [Note: Shigemori acted as a foster father figure], it was reasonable for him to present horses. The Major Counselor of Gojō, Lord Kunitsuna, presented two horses. People said, "Is it the utmost of intent, or an excess of wealth?" Furthermore, sacred horses were dedicated to over seventy places, starting from Ise and reaching as far as Itsukushima in Aki. Even in the palace, dozens of horses from the Bureau of Horses were led out with paper strips attached. The Omuro of Ninnaji performed the Rite of the Peacock Sutra; the Abbot of Tendai, Cloistered Imperial Prince Kakukai, the Rite of the Seven Medicine Buddhas; the Chief Priest of the Temple, Cloistered Imperial Prince Enkei, the Rite of the Diamond Youth; besides these, the Five Great Space Repository Bodhisattvas, the Six Kannons, the One-Syllable Golden Wheel, the Five Altar Rites, the Six-Syllable Wheel-Turner, the Eight-Syllable Manjusri, and even Fugen of Long Life—rites were performed without leaving any place. The smoke of the goma fire filled the palace, the sound of bells echoed in the clouds, and the voices of the rites made one's hair stand on end; no matter what evil spirit it might be, it did not seem possible for it to face this. Furthermore, orders were given to the Seal of the Law of the Buddhist workshop to begin making life-size statues of Yakushi and the Five Great Kings.

[3.3.5] Although this was done, the Empress only suffered frequently without pause, and the birth did not happen quickly. The Lay Priest Prime Minister and the Lady of the Second Rank placed their hands on their chests and were bewildered, asking what to do. Although people spoke to them, he just said, "Anyhow, make it a good way." Later he said, "If it were a battle formation, Jōkai [Kiyomori] would not be this cowardly." As for the healers, the two Archbishops Kakusō and Un, the Seal of the Law Shungyō, the two Provisional Bishops Gōzen and Jissen, each raising the verses of the Sangha, rubbed rosaries for the Three Treasures of their main temples and mountains and the principal images they had possessed for years, praying intensely. While it seemed truly impressive and holy, the Cloistered Emperor, who was scheduled to visit the New Kumano Shrine and was in purification, took his seat near the brocade curtain and recited the Thousand-Armed Sutra; perhaps because of this, things changed completely, and the violent struggling of the mediums also quieted for a while. The Cloistered Emperor said, "Whatever evil spirit it may be, while this old monk is here like this, how can you approach? In particular, the vengeful spirits appearing now are all persons whom I made into men through my Imperial favor. Even if you do not harbor a heart of gratitude, how can you cause obstruction? Withdraw immediately." Playing on the idea that when a woman faces difficulty in childbirth and evil spirits obstruct her, if one recites the Great Compassion Dharani with sincerity, the demons will disperse and she will give birth in comfort, he rubbed his crystal rosary; not only was the birth safe, but it was indeed a Prince.

[3.3.6] The Head Chamberlain and Middle Captain Lord Shigehira, who was at that time still the Assistant Master of the Empress's Household, suddenly came out from within the bamboo blinds and announced loudly, "The birth is safe; a Prince is born! " Starting with the Cloistered Emperor, the Regent and the Ministers, Nobles, and Courtiers below him, the assisting monks, the many healers, the Head of Yin-Yang, the Head of Medicine, and generally those above and below the hall, all raised a voice of joy together that echoed outside the gate and did not quiet down for some time. The Lay Priest, in his excessive joy, raised his voice and wept. "Weeping for joy" must refer to this. The Lord of Komatsu went to the Empress's quarters, placed ninety-nine gold coins by the Prince's pillow, and said, "Let Heaven be your father, and Earth be your mother. May your life maintain the age of the wizard Dongfang Shuo, and may Amaterasu Ōmikami enter into your heart."
And using a mulberry bow and wormwood arrows, he had the four directions of heaven and earth shot.

[3.4.1] As for the wet nurse, the wife of the former General of the Right Lord Munemori had been decided upon, but since she died in a difficult childbirth in the seventh month of last year, the wife of the Taira Major Counselor Lord Tokitada served as wet nurse. Later she was called the Sotsu-no-Tenji. The Cloistered Emperor immediately had his return carriage brought to the front of the gate. The Lay Priest Prime Minister, in the excess of his joy, presented one thousand ryo of gold dust and two thousand ryo of Fuji silk to the Cloistered Emperor. People whispered privately that this was inappropriate.

[3.4.2] In this birth, there were many ridiculous things. First, the Cloistered Emperor acting as healer. Next, when an Empress gives birth, there is a ritual of rolling a steamer from the ridge of the palace. For the birth of a Prince, it is dropped to the south; for the birth of a Princess, it is dropped to the north; but this time, they dropped it to the north, so amidst uproar of "What is this?" they took it up and dropped it again, but people said it was an ominous thing. What was funny was the bewildered state of the Lay Priest Prime Minister; what was splendid was the conduct of the Minister of Komatsu; what was regrettable was that the former General of the Right Lord Munemori, having lost his most beloved wife, resigned both his offices of Major Counselor and General and stayed in seclusion; if both brothers had served, how splendid it would have been. Next, seven Yin-Yang masters were summoned to perform a thousand purifications; among them was an old man named Head of the Sweeping Bureau Tokiharu. He had few attendants. Since so many people had gathered, crowded like bamboo shoots, like rice, hemp, bamboo, and reeds. Saying "Official coming through, open up," he pushed his way through, but his right shoe was stepped on and pulled off; while he stood there resting a moment, even his cap was knocked off. On such an occasion, when an old man in correct formal court dress paraded out with his topknot exposed, the young courtiers could not contain themselves and burst into laughter all at once. We hear that Yin-Yang masters and the like perform a gait called "henbai" and do not step vainly on the ground. Although such a strange thing happened to him, at the time it did not seem like anything, but later there were many things that came to mind in connection with it. The people who came to Rokuhara for the birth were: Regent Matsu-dono, Prime Minister Myōin-in, Minister of the Left Ōimikado, Minister of the Right Tsukinowa-dono, Minister of the Center Komatsu-dono, General of the Left Sanesada, Minamoto Major Counselor Sadafusa, Sanjō Major Counselor Sanefusa, Gojō Major Counselor Kunitsuna, Tō Major Counselor Sanekuni, Inspector Sukekata, Nakamikado Middle Counselor Muneie, Kazan-in Middle Counselor Kanemasa, Minamoto Middle Counselor Masayori, Provisional Middle Counselor Sanetsuna, Tō Middle Counselor Sukenaga, Ike Middle Counselor Yorimori, Captain of the Left Gate Guards Tokitada, Administrator Tadachika, Middle Captain of the Left Council of State Saneie, Middle Captain of the Right Council of State Sanemune, New Middle Captain of the Council of State Michichika, Taira Middle Counselor Norimori, Rokkaku Middle Counselor Iemichi, Horikawa Middle Counselor Yorisada, Controller of the Left Middle Counselor Nagakata, Controller of the Right Third Rank Toshitsune, Commander of the Left Military Guards Shigenori, Commander of the Right Military Guards Mitsuyoshi, Master of the Empress's Household Asakata, Master of the Left Capital Naganori, Dazaifu Senior Assistant Controller Chikanobu, New Third Rank Sanekiyo; these thirty-three men, except for the Controller of the Right, wore ordinary court dress. As for those who did not attend, it was heard that former Prime Minister of Kazan-in Lord Tadamasa, Ōmiya Major Counselor Lord Takakuni, and more than ten others went to the Lay Priest Prime Minister's West Hachijō residence on a later day wearing hunting robes.

[3.5.1] Upon the conclusion of the rites, rewards were distributed. The Omuro of Ninnaji was to repair Tōji. Also, orders were given that the Latter Seven Days Rite, the Great Origin Rite, and Initiations should be performed. His disciple, Bishop Kakusei, was promoted to Seal of the Law. The Abbot Prince requested the Second Order and the decree for an ox carriage. Because the Omuro of Ninnaji had supported him, the Eye of the Law Enryō was made Seal of the Law. It was heard that there was no time to enumerate the other rewards. Since the days had passed, the Empress returned from Rokuhara to the Palace. When this daughter was established as Empress, the Lay Priest Prime Minister and his wife together prayed, "Ah, somehow let a Prince be born. Let him ascend the throne, that we may be looked up to as maternal grandfather and maternal grandmother." Saying they would ask Itsukushima in Aki, whom they revered, they began monthly pilgrimages and prayed; the Empress immediately became pregnant, and that it was a Prince as they wished was indeed splendid.

[3.5.2] Now, asking how the Heike began to believe in Itsukushima of Aki: in the reign of Retired Emperor Toba, when Lord Kiyomori was still Governor of Aki, he was ordered to use the province of Aki to repair the Great Pagoda of Kōya; appointing Watanabe Endō Rokurō Yorikata as agent, the repairs were completed in six years. After the repairs were finished, Kiyomori went up to Kōya, worshipped at the Great Pagoda, and visited the Inner Sanctuary; an old monk, coming from nowhere, with frost hanging on his eyebrows and waves folded on his forehead, leaning on a deer-horn staff, appeared. They spoke for a rather long time. "From ancient times until now, this place has controlled the Esoteric Sect without decline. There is no other in the realm. The Great Pagoda has already finished repair. Now, Itsukushima in Aki and the Kehi Shrine in Echizen are manifestations of the Two Realms; while the Kehi Shrine prospers, Itsukushima has fallen into ruin as if it does not exist. Next, report to the Throne and repair it. If you do so, there will be no one to stand shoulder to shoulder with you in official rank."
Saying this, he departed. A strange fragrance perfumed the place where the old monk had sat. When he sent someone to watch, he was seen for about three chō, and after that, he vanished as if wiped away. This was no ordinary person. Thinking "That was the Great Master [Kōbō Daishi]," he felt increasingly reverent; as a memory of the Saha world, he painted Mandalas in the Golden Hall of Kōya; he had the painter Seal of the Law Jōmyō paint the West Mandala. Kiyomori said he would paint the East Mandala himself, and painted it with his own hand; whatever he was thinking, it is heard that he painted the jeweled crown of the central deity of the Eight Leaves using blood from his own head.

[3.5.3] So he went up to the capital, visited the Retired Emperor, and reported this; the Lord was impressed beyond measure. His term was extended, and he repaired Itsukushima. He replaced the Torii gates, rebuilt the various shrines, and built a corridor of one hundred and eighty bays. When the repairs were finished, Kiyomori visited Itsukushima and held a vigil; in a dream, a heavenly boy with hair tied up came out from the Treasure Hall and said, "This is a messenger of the Great Deity. With this sword, you shall pacify the one heaven and four seas, and be the guardian of the Imperial House." He dreamed he was given a small halberd with silver wrappings; when he awoke and looked, it was actually standing by his pillow. The Great Deity gave an oracle: "Do you know or have you forgotten the words spoken through a certain holy man? However, if there are evil deeds, it will not be granted to your descendants." And the Great Deity ascended. It was a splendid matter.

[3.6.1] During the reign of Retired Emperor Shirakawa, the daughter of the Great Lord of Kyōgoku was established as Empress, known as Kenshi-no-Chūgū, and was most beloved. The Emperor, desiring a Prince to be born from her womb, summoned Raigō Ajari of Miidera, who was known at that time as an effective monk, and ordered, "Pray for the birth of a Prince from this Empress's womb; if the vow is fulfilled, the reward shall be according to your wish. " Saying "It is easy," he returned to Miidera, and when he prayed for one hundred days crushing his liver and gall, the Empress immediately became pregnant within the hundred days, and on the 16th day of the twelfth month of the first year of Jōhō, The birth was safe, and a Prince was born. The Lord was impressed beyond measure and summoned Raigō Ajari of Miidera, asking, "What is your desire?"
When he asked this, Raigō requested the establishment of an ordination platform at Miidera. The Emperor said, "This is an unexpected request. I thought you would ask for something like the first rank of Bishop. Generally, that a Prince is born and the Imperial Line is continued is for the sake of peace within the seas. If I grant your request now, the Mountain Gate [Enryakuji] will be angry, and the world will not be quiet. If the Two Gates fight, the Buddhism of Tendai will perish," and permission was not granted.

[3.6.2] Raigō, saying it was regrettable, returned to Miidera and decided to starve himself to death. The Emperor was greatly startled and summoned Oe no Masafusa, known then as the Governor of Mimasaka, saying, "You have a master-disciple bond with Raigō. Go and try to persuade him."
When the Governor of Mimasaka, receiving the Imperial command, went to Raigō Ajari's lodgings and tried to explain the purport of the Imperial order, Raigō shut himself in a strangely smoky Buddha hall and said in a terrifying voice, "In the Emperor there are no playful words; I hear the Imperial Word is like sweat [once issued, it cannot be taken back]. Since this much of a request is not granted, as it is a Prince I prayed forth, I will take him and go to the Devil's Path."
And he finally did not even meet him. The Governor of Mimasaka returned and reported this. Raigō immediately starved himself to death. The Emperor was alarmed, wondering what would happen. The Prince soon fell ill; although there were various prayers, they did not seem likely to work. A white-haired old monk, holding a tin staff, stood by the Prince's pillow; he appeared in people's dreams and stood in visions. Fear was an understatement.

[3.6.3] Meanwhile, on the 6th day of the eighth month of the first year of Jōryaku, the Prince finally passed away at the age of four. This was Imperial Prince Atsufumi. The Emperor's grief was not shallow. He summoned to the palace the Abbot of the Western Capital at the Mountain Gate, Archbishop Ryōshin, known then as the Bishop of Enyūbō and an effective monk, and asked, "What shall be done about this?"
He replied, "Whatever it may be, such a vow is accomplished by the power of our Mountain. It was because the Minister of the Right of Kujō made a vow to Great Archbishop Jie that the Prince of Retired Emperor Reizei was born. It is an easy matter."
Returning up to Mt. Hiei, he prayed to the Mountain King Great Master, crushing his liver and gall for one hundred days; the Empress immediately became pregnant within the hundred days, and on the 9th day of the seventh month of the third year of Jōryaku, the birth was safe, and a Prince was born. This was Emperor Horikawa. Vengeful spirits were thus terrifying in the past as well. This time, although a great extraordinary amnesty was performed for such a splendid birth, that Abbot Shunkan alone was not pardoned was indeed pitiful.
