[3.6.4] On the 8th day of the same twelfth month. The Prince was established as Crown Prince. It was heard that the Tutor was the Minister of the Center Komatsu, and the Master of the Household was the Ike Middle Counselor Lord Yorimori.

div.head: 3.7. The Minor Captain Returns to the Capital

div.p:
[3.7.1] When the new year dawned, in late January of the third year of Jishō, the Minor Captain of Tamba Naritsune left Kanose Manor in Hizen Province and hurried toward the capital; but since the lingering cold was still severe and the sea was very rough, following the coast and following the islands, it was around the tenth of February that he arrived at Kojima in Bizen.
From there, he sought out and entered the place where his father, the Major Counselor, had lived; looking at the playful brushstrokes written on bamboo pillars and old sliding doors, he said, "As a keepsake of a person, there is nothing that exceeds their handwriting. If he had not written and left this, how could I see it?" Together with the Lay Priest Yasuyori, he read and wept, wept and read. It was written: "Became a monk on the 20th of the seventh month of the third year of Angen; Nobutoshi came down on the 26th of the same month." Thus he knew that Genzaemon-no-jō Nobutoshi had visited. On the wall nearby, it was written: "The welcoming of the Three Deities is convenient; birth in the Nine Grades of the Pure Land is without doubt." Seeing this keepsake, he said, "Indeed, he had the desire to seek the Pure Land."
Even amidst his boundless grief, he spoke as if somewhat encouraged.

[3.7.2] When he searched for and saw the grave, there was no proper mound built within the clump of pine trees. At a place where the earth was slightly raised, the Minor Captain arranged his sleeves, and speaking as if to a living person, wept and said, "I heard faintly on the island that you had become a distant guardian, but since this is a sorrowful world that does not follow one's heart, I could not come quickly. That Naritsune was exiled to that island, and with my dew-like life not yet extinguished, spent two years there and was recalled is a joyful thing; but only if I could see you alive in this world would there be any worth in long life. I hurried this far, but from today onwards, I do not feel I can hurry." Thus he lamented and wept. "Truly, if you were alive, Lay Priest Major Counselor, you would speak in some way, but there is nothing as resentful as the custom that separates the living and the dead. Who beneath the moss can answer? It is only the sound of the pines murmuring in the storm.

[3.7.3] After that, all night long, together with the Lay Priest Yasuyori, he walked around the grave chanting the Nembutsu; when day broke, they built a new mound, set up a fence, built a temporary hut in front of it, and for seven days and seven nights chanted the Nembutsu and copied sutras. On the day of conclusion, they erected a large stupa, wrote "The Past Spirit Leaves Birth and Death and Attains Great Enlightenment," and under the date, wrote "Filial Son Naritsune"; there was no one, even among the heartless rustics of the mountain, who did not shed tears and wring their sleeves, saying there is no treasure greater than a child. Though years go and years come, what is hard to forget is the old debt of upbringing. It is like a dream, like an illusion. What is hard to exhaust are the present tears of longing. The holy multitude of Buddhas of the three worlds and ten directions must have had pity, and how happy the departed soul and revered spirit must have felt. "I should stay a while longer and accumulate the merit of Nembutsu, but the people waiting in the capital must be anxious. I will come again."
Taking leave of the dead, he left that place weeping. Even the shades of the grass must have felt the regret of parting.

[3.7.4] On the 16th of March, the Minor Captain arrived at Toba wearing light mourning clothes. The late Major Counselor's mountain villa, called the Suhama Palace, was in Toba. Since it had been left to ruin for years, though there were earthen walls there was no roof, and though there was a gate there were no doors. When he entered the garden and looked, human traces were cut off and the moss was deep. Looking around the edge of the pond, the spring breeze blew on the autumn mountain [artificial hill], white waves constantly splashed, and purple mandarin ducks and white gulls wandered freely. Tears are the things that are inexhaustible in longing for the person who once enjoyed this. Though the house remained, the railed gates were broken, and the shutters and sliding doors were completely gone. "Was it here that the Major Counselor sat? Did he go in and out through this door? Did he plant that tree himself?"
Speaking thus, attached to every leaf, he spoke longingly of his father. Since it was the sixth day of the middle of March, the flowers still retained their traces. The branches of the bayberry, peach, and plum were colorful, as if knowing the time. Though the master of old is gone, the flowers do not forget the spring. The Minor Captain approached beneath the flowers:

lg.l: "The peach and plum do not speak, yet how many springs have passed? The smoke and mist leave no trace; who lived here in the past?"
If it were a world where the flowers of the old home could speak, how I would ask them of the past.

div.p: [3.7.5] As he hummed this old poem, the Lay Priest Yasuyori also felt the moment to be pitiable, and moistened his ink-dyed sleeves. Though waiting for darkness, the parting was so regrettable that they stayed until the night deepened. As it grew late, true to the custom of a ruined dwelling, the moonlight leaking through the gaps in the old eaves was without shadow. The cock-cage mountain was about to brighten, but he could not hurry on the road home. But since it could not be helped, thinking it heartless to keep the vehicles sent to meet them waiting, he left the Suhama Palace weeping; the hearts of the people returning to the capital must have been both sad and happy. Although there was a vehicle to meet the Lay Priest Yasuyori, he did not ride in it, saying, "Now the parting is too regrettable," and rode in the rear of the Minor Captain's carriage as far as the Shichijō riverbed. There they went their separate ways, but he could not bear to go. Half a day's guest under the blossoms, a one-night friend before the moon—when travelers stop under the shade of a single tree as a passing shower goes by, the regret of parting is great. How much more so for these two, who shared the dwelling of a sorrowful island, in a boat, on the waves, bodies feeling the same karma; they must have realized that their bond from previous lives was not shallow.

[3.7.6] The Minor Captain entered the residence of his father-in-law, the Taira Prime Minister. The Minor Captain's mother was at Ryōzen, but she had come to the Prime Minister's residence yesterday to wait. Seeing the Minor Captain's figure at a glance, she said only, "Because you are alive..." She pulled her robe over her head and lay down. The ladies-in-waiting and samurai of the Prime Minister's household gathered around, and all wept with joy. How much more so must the hearts of the Minor Captain's wife and the nurse Rokujō have been happy. Rokujō's hair, once black, had turned completely white from endless worry, and the wife, though once bright and beautiful, had wasted away so that she did not look like the same person. The young person who was parted from at age three when the Minor Captain was exiled had grown tall and was old enough to have his hair tied. Also, seeing a small child of about three beside him, the Minor Captain asked, "Who is that?"
Rokujō said only, "This is..." and pressed her sleeve to her face, shedding tears; he recalled with sadness, "So, when I went down, I left her in a pitiful condition, but she has raised it without incident. " The Minor Captain was summoned to serve the Cloistered Emperor as before, and was promoted to Captain-Middle Captain.
[3.7.7] The Lay Priest Yasuyori had a mountain villa at Sōrin-ji in Higashiyama, so he settled there and first composed:

lg.l: Moss has grown in the gaps of the eaves of my old home; the moon leaks through not as much as I thought.

div.p: [3.7.8] Immediately shutting himself in there, continuing to think on his hair [monkhood] and the sorrowful past, it is heard he wrote a tale called the Hōbutsu-shū (Collection of Treasures).

[3.8.1] Meanwhile, of the three exiles exiled to Kikai-ga-shima, two were recalled and went up to the capital. That Abbot Shunkan alone became the guardian of the sorrowful island was indeed pitiful. The Abbot had a servant boy he had used with pity since he was small. His name was Ariō. Hearing that the exiles of Kikai-ga-shima were entering Kyoto today, he went out as far as Toba to look, but his master was not to be seen. When he asked "How is it?", he heard, "He was left on the island, being considered still deep in crime."
His grief was beyond words. He constantly loitered around Rokuhara and listened, but heard no news of a pardon. He went to the place where the Abbot's daughter was living in hiding and said, "Being left out of this opportunity, he has not come up. I have decided to somehow cross to that island and seek his whereabouts. Please give me a letter."
When he said this, she wrote one weeping and gave it to him. Thinking that even if he asked for leave, his parents surely would not permit it, he did not inform his father or mother. Since the moorings of the Tang ships are untied in the fourth or fifth month, he perhaps thought leaving in summer clothes would be too late. Leaving the capital at the end of March, braving many wave-paths, he went down to the Satsuma Gulf. At the harbor crossing from Satsuma to that island, people were suspicious and stripped him of the things he wore, but he did not regret it in the slightest; thinking only not to let people see the young lady's letter, he hid it inside his topknot. So, boarding a merchant ship and crossing to the island to look, what he had faintly heard in the capital was as nothing. There were no rice fields. There were no dry fields. There were no villages. There were no hamlets. Though there were people naturally, he did not understand their spoken words. Thinking that among such people there might be one who knew his master's fate, he said "I would speak," and they answered "What is it?" When he asked, "Do you know the fate of a person called the Administrator Priest of Hosshōji, who was exiled from the capital here? ", if they knew of Hosshōji or Administrator, they might answer. They just shook their heads and said, "Don't know." Among them, one person understood and said, "Ah, yes, there were three such people here, but two were recalled and went up to the capital. One was left behind, and although he wanders here and there in confusion, his whereabouts are unknown. " Uncertain of the mountain direction, he pushed far in, climbing peaks and descending into valleys, but white clouds buried the traces, and the path of coming and going was not clear; the mountain storm broke his dreams, and he did not see his face. Finally failing to find him in the mountains, he came to the seaside to search; other than the gulls carving prints on the sand and the plovers gathering on the white shoal of the offing, there was no one to ask for traces.

[3.8.2] One morning, from the direction of the rocky shore, a person emaciated like a dragonfly came staggering out. Thinking he must have been a monk originally, his hair had grown up toward the sky, he was covered in all kinds of seaweed, and looked as if he were wearing thorns. His joints were visible and his skin hung loose; as for what he wore on his body, neither silk nor cloth could be distinguished. In one hand he held rough seaweed he had picked up, and in the other he held a fish he had received from a fisherman; he tried to walk, but made no progress, staggering as he came out. "I saw many beggars in the capital, but I have never seen such a person. It is said 'All Asuras reside by the great ocean,' and that the Three Evil Paths and Four Realms of Asuras are by deep mountains and great oceans; I wonder if I have come searching into the Realm of Hungry Ghosts." While he thought this, the figure gradually walked closer. "Perhaps such a person might know my master's fate." He said, "I would speak." The figure answered, "What is it?" When he asked, "Do you know the fate of a person called the Administrator Priest of Hosshōji, who was exiled from the capital here?", the boy had forgotten his face, but how could the Abbot forget? Before he could say "I am he," the things he held in his hands fell, and he collapsed onto the sand. Thus Ariō knew his master's fate. He immediately fainted; Ariō took him onto his knees and said, "Ariō has come. I braved many waves to search this far, but without avail; how can you show me such a miserable sight?" As he spoke weeping, after a while, the Abbot regained his senses a little, and being helped up, said, "Truly, the extent of your intent in searching this far is admirable. Day and night, I thought only of the capital, and the faces of my beloved ones appeared in dreams and stood in visions. But after my body became terribly weak, I could not distinguish dream from reality. So I feel that your coming is only a dream. If this is a dream, what shall I do after I wake?" Ariō said, "It is reality. It is miraculous that your life has lasted until now in this condition. " The Abbot said, "Indeed. You can only guess the despair in my heart after I was abandoned by the Minor Captain and the Lay Priest Magistrate last year. I tried to throw myself into that current, but relying foolishly on the useless consolation of the Minor Captain, who said 'Wait for one more message from the capital,' I tried to survive; but since this island is a place with absolutely no human food, while I had strength in my body, I went up the mountain to gather sulfur and exchanged it for things when meeting merchants from Kyushu; but as I grew weaker day by day, now I cannot do even that. When the day is calm like this, I go out to the rocky shore, rub my hands and bend my knees to the net-men and anglers to beg for fish; at low tide I pick up shellfish and gather rough seaweed; hanging my dew-like life on the moss of the shore, I have survived until today. Otherwise, you must wonder how I have managed to pass through this sorrowful world."
The Abbot said, "Though I wish to say many things here, come to my house."
Ariō thought, "How strange that he has a house even in this condition."
As they went, inside a clump of pines, drifted bamboo was used for pillars, reeds were tied and crossed for beams, and pine needles were thickly piled on top and bottom, so that wind and rain could not accumulate. In the past, as the Administrator of Hosshōji, he controlled the affairs of over eighty manors, and within his roofed gates and flat gates, he was surrounded by four or five hundred servants and retainers. It was strange indeed to see him suffer such misery before one's eyes. Karma takes various forms. It is said there is karma for the present life, karma for the next life, and karma for subsequent lives. Everything the Abbot used for his body during his lifetime was nothing other than the temple goods and Buddha goods of the great cathedral. Thus, it seemed he was experiencing the retribution for the sin of using offerings without shame already in this life.

[3.9.1] The Abbot, deciding it was reality, said, "By the way, when the Minor Captain and Lay Priest Magistrate were fetched last year, there was no letter from my family. Even now with your opportunity, does the lack of tidings mean they are no more?"
Ariō, choked with tears, looked down and did not speak for a while. After a time, he rose, suppressed his tears, and said, "When my Lord went out to West Hachijō, immediately police officials came, seized the people of the household, interrogated them about the rebellion, and they were all executed. Your wife, unable to hide the young one, was hiding deep in Kurama; only this boy visited from time to time to serve, and although your wife's grief was not shallow, the young master missed you so excessively that every time I visited he would pester me, saying 'Ariō, take me to Kikai-ga-shima.' But in the second month of last year, he passed away from smallpox. Your wife, sinking under the grief of that and the events concerning you, grew weaker day by day, and on the second day of the third month of the same year, finally passed away. Now only the young lady is living with her aunt in Nara. Here is a letter from her."
And he took it out and presented it. When he opened and looked, it was written just as Ariō had said. At the end, it was written: "Why is it that of three people exiled, two were recalled, but you have not come up until now? Ah, whether high or low, there is nothing as wretched as the body of a woman. If I were a man, why would I not come to search for you, even to the island where you are? Accompanied by this Ariō, please come up quickly. " "Look at this, Ariō. The fragility of the way this child writes. It is resentful that she writes 'Accompanied by him, come up quickly.' If Shunkan's body were free to follow his heart, why would I spend three years of springs and autumns here? I think the boy would be twelve this year; if he had not passed away like this, he would be seen by people, serve at court, and support himself." He wept, showing that although a parent's heart is not darkness, it wanders on the path of thinking of the child. "After being exiled to this island, having no calendar, I do not know the changing days and months; only by seeing the flowers scatter and leaves fall do I distinguish spring and autumn; when the cicada voices herald the wheat harvest, I think it is summer; seeing the accumulation of snow, I know it is winter. Seeing the waxing and waning of the white moon and black moon, I distinguish the thirty days; counting on my fingers, I thought the young one would be twelve this year, but it seems he has already gone ahead. White moon and black moon refer to the phases of the moon. When I went out to West Hachijō, and this child yearned to go too, I persuaded him to stay saying I would return soon; I remember it now. If I had known that was the end, why did I not look at him for even a moment longer? Becoming parent and child, forming the bond of husband and wife, all are promises limited to this one life. Why then, when they had gone ahead like that, did you not let me know even in a dream or illusion until now? Regardless of shame before others, the reason I wished somehow to keep my life was to see them once more. Only the matter of the daughter is painful, but since she is alive, she will get by despite her grief. To survive only to show myself to you in such misery would be too shameless even for me."
Saying this, he stopped his own eating, devoted himself to chanting the name of Amida, and prayed for right mindfulness at the end. On the twenty-third day after Ariō crossed over, he finally passed away inside that hut. It was heard his age was thirty-seven. Ariō clung to the empty body, looked up to heaven and threw himself on the ground, weeping and grieving, but it was to no avail. When he had wept to his heart's content, he said, "I should follow you immediately to the afterlife, but only the young lady remains in this world. There is no one to pray for her afterlife. I will live for a while to pray for you." Without changing the sleeping mat, he broke down the hut, covered him with withered pine branches and dried reeds, and turned him into the smoke of salt-burning; when the cremation was finished, he gathered the white bones, hung them around his neck, and waiting for the convenience of a merchant ship, arrived in the land of Kyushu.

[3.9.2] He went to the place where the Abbot's daughter was and told her the details from the beginning. "Seeing the letter conversely made his grief increase. Since there was neither inkstone nor paper, he could not make a reply. The thoughts in his heart all vanished into the sky. Now, though we pass life after life and are separated by vast kalpas, how can we hear his voice or see his figure?"
When he said this, she fell down and wept, sparing no voice. Immediately becoming a nun at the age of twelve, she went to Hokke-ji in Nara and purified herself, praying for the afterlife of her father and mother; it was pathetic. Ariō hung the remains of Abbot Shunkan around his neck, climbed Mt. Kōya, deposited them at the Inner Sanctuary (Okunoin), became a monk at Renge-dani, and traveled through the provinces and seven circuits praying for his master's afterlife. It is terrifying to think of the end of the Heike, where the grief and lamentation of people accumulated like this.

[3.10.1] On the 12th day of the same fifth month, around the Hour of the Horse (noon), a whirlwind blew violently in the capital, overturning many houses. The wind rose from Naka-mikado Kyōgoku and blew toward the southwest; blowing through roofed gates and flat gates, it went for four or five chō to ten chō; girders, beams, and pillars were scattered in the empty sky. Items like cypress bark and roofing shingles were like winter leaves disordered in the wind. The sound of its tremendous roaring seemed not to be exceeded even by the karma-wind of hell. Not only were houses damaged, but many people lost their lives. Cattle and horses were killed in numbers beyond counting. This was no ordinary matter. Saying there should be a divination, a divination was held at the Department of Deities. "Within the next hundred days, there is a warning for a Minister of heavy emolument; specially, it is a grave matter for the realm, and furthermore, both Buddhism and the King's Law will decline, and warfare will continue."
Thus both the Department of Deities and the Bureau of Yin-Yang divined.

[3.11.1] The Minister of Komatsu, hearing of such things, must have felt uneasy about everything. At that time, there was a pilgrimage to Kumano. Before the Shōjō-den of the Main Shrine, he prayed all night: "Seeing the state of my father, the Lay Priest Prime Minister, his evil and treason are unprincipled, and he frequently distresses the Emperor. Though I, Shigemori, as his eldest son, frequently remonstrate with him, since I am unworthy, he does not accept it. Looking at his behavior, his lifetime of glory is precarious. It is difficult for branches and leaves to continue, to manifest the parents and raise the name. At this time, Shigemori has a humble thought. To remain reluctantly in the ranks and float and sink in the world is by no means the way of a good subject or filial son. Therefore, I would rather escape the name, retreat physically, cast away fame and hope in this life, and seek enlightenment in the next. However, being a common mortal on thin ground, confused by right and wrong, I still do not follow my will freely. Namu Gongen Diamond Youth, I pray: if my descendants are not to cease flourishing and are to serve the court, soften the Lay Priest's evil heart and let him obtain the safety of the realm. If glory is limited to one generation and shame is to extend to posterity, shorten Shigemori's destiny and save me from the wheel of suffering in the afterlife. For these two requests, I rely entirely on unseen aid."
As he prayed, crushing his liver and gall, something like the light of a lantern came out of the Minister's body and vanished as if wiped away. Although many people saw it, they feared and did not speak of it.

[3.11.2] Also, on his way back, when crossing the Iwata River, his heir the Provisional Assistant Master Major General Koremori and the other young lords were wearing light purple robes under their pure white robes; since it was summer, as they played casually in the river water, their pure robes got wet and the color transferred to the robes, looking exactly like mourning colors; Chikugo-no-kami Sadayoshi saw this and blamed them, saying, "What is this? Those pure robes look exceedingly ominous. You should change them. " The Minister said, "My prayer has already been fulfilled. Those pure robes must not be changed." Specially from the Iwata River, he sent an offering of gratitude to Kumano. People thought it strange, but did not understand his heart. However, that these young lords soon wore the true colors [of mourning] was indeed miraculous.

[3.11.3] Not many days after returning, he fell ill. Saying that the Gongen had already accepted him, he did not take treatment. He also did not perform prayers. At that time, a surpassing famous physician from the Song Dynasty had crossed over and was resting in this country. The Lay Priest Prime Minister was at his villa in Fukuhara, but using Etchū-no-kami Moritoshi as a messenger, he spoke to the Lord of Komatsu: "I hear that your illness is increasingly serious. By chance, a surpassing famous physician from the Song Dynasty has crossed over. I am pleased. Invite him and let him add medical treatment. " When this message was sent, the Lord of Komatsu was helped up, called Moritoshi before him, and said, "First, regarding the medical treatment, I respectfully acknowledge the order. However, you listen too. Although Emperor Engi [Daigo] was such a wise king, that he allowed a foreign physiognomist into the capital is seen even in the latter age as an error of a wise king and a shame to our country. How much more so, for an ordinary person like Shigemori to bring a foreign physician into the Royal City, is this not a national shame? Han Gaozu governed the world wielding a three-foot sword, but when he fought Qing Bu of Huainan, he was hit by a stray arrow and wounded. The Empress Lu welcomed a good physician and had him look at it; the physician said, 'This wound can be cured. However, if you give me fifty catties of gold, I will cure it.' Gaozu said, 'While my protection was strong, I met with many battles and received wounds, but they did not pain me. Luck has already run out. Life is strictly in Heaven. Even if you were Bian Que, what use would it be? However, it would seem like I grudge the gold.' And giving the fifty catties of gold to the physician, he finally did not have it treated. The former words are in my ears; now I accept them with a willing heart. Shigemori humbly ranks among the Nine Ministers and has ascended to the Three Terraces. Measuring that destiny, it resides in the will of Heaven. Why should I not examine the will of Heaven and foolishly trouble with medical treatment? If it is fixed karma, then adding medical treatment will be of no use. If it is not fixed karma, then even without treatment, I should be able to be saved.
The Great Enlightened World-Honored One, when the medical arts of Jivaka did not suffice, announced his Nirvana by the Ajita River. This was to demonstrate that illness of fixed karma cannot be healed. If fixed karma could still be affected by medical treatment, would Shakyamuni have entered Nirvana? It is clear that fixed karma cannot be cured. The one being treated is the Buddha-body. The one treating is Jivaka. However, Shigemori's body is not the Buddha-body. A famous physician also cannot reach Jivaka. Even if he mirrors the books of the Four Parts and excels in the hundred treatments, how can he seek to cure a defiled body that has an end? Even if he is detailed in the theories of the Five Classics and heals the multitude of sicknesses, how can he cure the karma-sickness of previous lives? If I were to survive relying on his medical arts, it would seem as if the medical way of our country were naught. If the medical arts have no effect, meeting him is pointless. In particular, for a high minister of this country to be seen by a floating visitor from a foreign court is partly a shame to the country and partly a decline of the Way. Even if Shigemori's life is lost, how can I not harbor a heart that thinks of the country's shame? Tell him this."
Thus he spoke.

[3.11.4] Moritoshi returned to Fukuhara and reported this weeping; the Lay Priest Prime Minister said, "I have never heard in ancient times of a Minister who thought of the country's shame to this extent, and I do not think there will be one in the latter age. Since he is a Minister inappropriate for Japan, he will surely die this time."
And weeping, he hurriedly went up to the capital.

[3.11.5] On the 28th of the same seventh month, the Lord of Komatsu became a monk. He took the Dharma name Jōren. Soon, on the first day of the eighth month, dwelling in right mindfulness at the end, he finally passed away. His age was forty-three; while the world seemed to be at its peak, these were sorrowful things.

[3.11.6] Even though the Lay Priest Prime Minister acted violently, because this person [Shigemori] corrected and soothed him, the world was stable. Saying "What kind of things will happen in the realm after this?", high and low in the capital lamented together. People on the side of the former General of the Right Lord Munemori rejoiced that the world would now come to the General. The custom of a parent thinking of a child is such that it is sad even if a foolish one goes first. How much more so since he was the pillar of this house and a wise man of the present age; the parting of affection and the decline of the house left overflowing sorrow. Therefore, in the world they lamented the loss of a good minister, and in the house they grieved the abandonment of military strategy. In general, this Minister was beautiful in letters, harbored loyalty in his heart, excelled in talents, and combined virtue in his words.

[3.12.1] By nature, this Minister was a miraculous person; perhaps he realized future events beforehand, for what he saw in a dream on the 7th of last April was miraculous. For example, as he was walking far along an unknown beach path, there was a great Torii gate by the side of the road; when he asked, "What Torii is that?", he was told, "It is the Torii of Kasuga Great Deity. " Many people were gathered. Among them, they held up a monk's head. When he asked, "Well, what head is that?", he felt the answer was, "Because the evil deeds of the Taira Prime Minister have been excessive, the Great Deity of this shrine has taken it."
And he awoke from the dream. This house, since Hōgen and Heiji, has quelled repeated enemies of the court, rewards have exceeded our status, and gratefully as maternal relatives of the Sovereign of the one heaven, the promotions of the clan number over sixty people. For the past twenty years or more, there has been nothing but pleasure and glory, but because the Lay Priest's evil deeds are excessive, the destiny of the clan is already about to end; continuing to think of things past and future, he choked with tears.

[3.12.2] Just then, there was a knocking at the door. "Who is it? Go hear." It was reported, "Seno no Tarō Kaneyasu has come." "Why, what is the matter?" He replied, "Just now, I had a miraculous experience, and since waiting for dawn seemed too slow, I have come to report it. Please dismiss those present. " The Minister dismissed the people to a distance and met him. When Kaneyasu recounted in detail the dream he had seen from beginning to end, it did not differ in the slightest from the dream the Minister had seen. So the Minister felt impressed that Seno no Tarō Kaneyasu was a man who communicated with the gods.

[3.12.3] That morning, when his heir the Provisional Assistant Master Major General Koremori was going out to attend the Cloistered Emperor's palace, the Minister called him and said, "As a parent, to say such things is extremely foolish, but you seem superior among my children. However, I feel uneasy about how the state of this world will be. Is Sadayoshi there? Offer sake to the Major General."
Sadayoshi came to pour. "I would like to have the Major General take this cup first, but since you surely would not drink before your parent, Shigemori will take it first and offer it to the Major General."
He accepted it three times and offered it to the Major General. When the Major General accepted it three times, he said, "Well, Sadayoshi, bring the gift." Receiving the order with awe, he brought out a long sword in a brocade bag. Thinking, "Ah, this must be the sword called Kogarasu (Little Crow) handed down in the family," he looked at it with great joy, but it was not that; it was an unornamented sword (Mumon) used at the funeral of a Minister.
At that time, the Major General's expression changed and he looked at it with great distaste; the Minister shed tears profusely and said, "Well, Major General, that is not Sadayoshi's fault. As for the reason, this sword is an unornamented sword used at the funeral of a Minister. Although I kept it intending to wear it and attend when the Lay Priest passed away, now since Shigemori will go before the Lord Prime Minister, I present it to you. " Hearing this, the Major General could not make any reply. Choked with tears, he looked down; he did not go to court that day, but pulled his robe over his head and lay down. After that, the Minister went on pilgrimage to Kumano, returned, fell ill, and without much time finally passed away; then indeed the truth of it was realized.

[3.13.1] In all things, this Minister had a deep will to extinguish sin and produce good; lamenting the uncertainty of the future, at the foot of Higashiyama, modeling it on the forty-eight great vows, he built a temple of forty-eight bays, and hanging forty-eight lanterns in the forty-eight bays, one in each bay, the nine grades of lotus pedestals shone before his eyes, and the radiant light polishing a mirror seemed to overlook the grounds of the Pure Land. Lighting them on the 14th and 15th of every month, he invited and gathered many beautiful, young, and blooming ladies-in-waiting from his own and other houses, six in each bay, two hundred and eighty-eight in forty-eight bays, established them as the congregation, and during those two days, with one mind chanting the Name without ceasing, it truly seemed that the compassionate vow of welcoming and guidance manifested there, and the light that grasps and never abandons shone upon this Minister. Making the midday of the 15th the conclusion, holding a great Nembutsu service, the Minister himself joined in that procession, faced west, and prayed, "Namu Lord of the World of Peace and Sustenance, Amida Sugata, universally save the sentient beings of the three realms and six paths."
When he made this transfer of merit and vow, those who saw it gave rise to compassion, and those who heard it were moved to tears. Because of this, people called this Minister the Lantern Minister.

[3.14.1] Furthermore, the Minister thought that no matter what great roots of goodness he planted in our country, it was difficult for descendants to continue and pray for him. Wishing to plant some root of goodness in another country to pray for his afterlife, around the Angen era, he summoned a boat captain named Myōden from Chinzei, dismissed people to a distance, and met him. He summoned three thousand five hundred ryo of gold and said, "Since you are a very honest man, I give you five hundred ryo. Take the three thousand ryo to the Song Dynasty, go to Mt. Ayuwang (King Ashoka), give one thousand ryo to the monks, and present two thousand ryo to the Emperor; ask for rice fields to be donated to Mt. Ayuwang, and have them pray for my afterlife. " Myōden received this, braved the misty waves of ten thousand li, and crossed to the Great Song Country. Meeting the Abbot of Mt. Ayuwang, Zen Master Fozhao Deguang, he reported this; the Master rejoiced and admired it, gave one thousand ryo to the monks, presented two thousand ryo to the Emperor, and fully reported the Minister's request; the Emperor was greatly impressed and donated five hundred chō of rice fields to Mt. Ayuwang.
Therefore, we hear that the prayers for the good place in the afterlife of the Japanese Minister, Taira no Ason Shigemori, have not ceased even now.

[3.15.1] The Lay Priest Prime Minister, having lost the Lord of Komatsu, must have felt helpless in all things; he rushed down to Fukuhara and remained there with his gates closed. On the night of the 7th of the same November, around the Hour of the Dog (8 PM), the earth shook violently for a long time. The Head of Yin-Yang, Abe no Yasuchika, rushed to the Palace and said, "The earthquake tonight, according to the divination texts, indicates a caution that is not light. Looking at the explanation in the Kongi-kyō among the Three Sutras of our way, it is seen: 'If it gains the year, it does not exit the year; if it gains the month, it does not exit the month; if it gains the day, it does not exit the day.' It is exceedingly urgent." And he shed tears profusely. The person who reported to the Throne also lost color, and the Emperor was startled. The young nobles and courtiers laughed together, saying, "Yasuchika is usually not a strange fellow; what is this weeping about? What could happen?" However, this Yasuchika was the fifth-generation descendant of Seimei; he had mastered the origins of astronomy, and his deductions were like pointing to his own palm. Since not a single thing was incorrect, he was called the "Finger God." Although lightning had struck him, while the sleeves of his hunting robe were burned by the thunder fire, his body was unharmed. Yasuchika was indeed rare in both ancient and modern times.

[3.15.2] On the 14th of the same month, the Lay Priest Prime Minister, who had been in Fukuhara until recently, whatever he may have thought, led several thousand mounted soldiers and entered the capital; although the capital did not know the details, high and low trembled with fear. Who could have suggested it? It was announced that the Lay Priest Prime Minister bore a grudge against the Imperial House. The Regent, perhaps hearing rumors privately, hurriedly visited the Palace and reported, "The Lay Priest Prime Minister's entry into the capital this time is a plot solely to destroy Motofusa. What kind of sorrowful fate will I meet?" The Emperor was greatly startled and said, "Whatever fate you meet, I will meet it with you alone."
It was awe-inspiring that he shed tears. Truly, the government of the realm depends on the plans of the Emperor and the Regent; what kind of events are these? The divine will of Amaterasu Ōmikami and Kasuga Daimyōjin was hard to measure.

[3.15.3] On the 15th of the same month, hearing it was certain that the Lay Priest Prime Minister bore a grudge against the Imperial House, the Cloistered Emperor was greatly startled and sent Seal of the Law Jōken, the son of the late Minor Counselor Shinzei, as a messenger to the Lay Priest Prime Minister. He sent word saying: "In recent years the Court has not been quiet, people's hearts are not in harmony, and the world is becoming unsettled; I lament this in general terms. However, since you are there, I have relied on you for everything. Yet, not only have you not quieted the realm, but to hear that you are in an uproar and moreover bear a grudge against the Imperial House—what is the meaning of this? " Seal of the Law Jōken went as a messenger to the West Hachijō residence. Although he waited from morning until evening, there was no word; thinking "So this is how it is" and that it was useless, he had Minamoto no Taifu Hangan Suesada convey the purport of the Imperial command, saying "I will take my leave," and started to go out; at that moment the Lay Priest came out saying, "Call the Hōin." Calling him back, he said, "Well, Hōin-no-gobo, is what Jōkai says a mistake? First, regarding the death of the Minister of the Center [Shigemori], thinking of the destiny of our house, I, the Lay Priest, have spent my time suppressing tears of sorrow. Please surmise this in your own heart. Since Hōgen, rebellions have continued one after another, and the Sovereign has not passed his time with an easy heart; I, the Lay Priest, have only managed general affairs. It was the Minister of the Center who acted and crushed his body to rest the Imperial wrath on repeated occasions. Besides that, in extraordinary crises and morning and evening government affairs, a meritorious subject like the Minister of the Center must be rare. Thinking of the past based on this, when Taizong of Tang lost Wei Zheng, in the excess of his grief, he wrote the inscription 'Anciently King Wuding of Yin obtained a good assistant in a dream; now I, having awakened, have lost a wise subject,' and erected it at his tomb; such was his grief. In our country too, we have seen such things nearby. When the Minister of Popular Affairs Akiyori passed away, the late Retired Emperor grieved especially, postponed the Imperial visit to Yawata, and held no musical entertainments. In general, when a subject dies, the Emperors of every generation mourn. Therefore, it is said that the relationship between Lord and Subject is closer than parents and more intimate than children. However, during the intermediate mourning period for the Minister of the Center, there was an Imperial visit to Yawata and musical entertainments were held. I saw not a single sign of grief. Even if he has no pity for the Lay Priest's sorrow, how can he forget the Minister of the Center's loyalty? Even if he forgets the Minister of the Center's loyalty, how can he have no pity for the Lay Priest's lamentation? That both father and son have been turned against by the Imperial will causes me to lose face even now. This is one thing. Next, regarding Echizen Province, although there was a promise that it should not be changed for my children and grandchildren, immediately after the Minister of the Center died, it was confiscated; for what negligence was this? This is one thing. Next, when the position of Middle Counselor was vacant, although the Lay Priest strongly recommended the Middle Captain of the Second Rank [Motomichi] who desired it, finally consent was not given, and the Regent's son was appointed; what of this? Even if the Lay Priest were proposing something unreasonable, why should he not be listened to once? Furthermore, to disregard the fact that he is the heir of the house and his rank, where reason admits no debate, and to pass him over, I consider a regrettable plan. This is one thing. Next, that the New Major Counselor Narichika and others gathered at Shishigatani and planned rebellion was absolutely not a private scheme. It was entirely because the Lord gave permission. Although it is saying something present-day [impertinent], how could he abandon this clan for seven generations? Yet, he has made plans to destroy us whenever possible, even within the short remaining life of the Lay Priest who has reached seventy. Furthermore, it is difficult for my descendants to continue serving the Imperial House. In general, to lose a child in old age is no different from a withered tree having no branches. Now, in this short floating world, even if I exhaust my heart, what use is it? I have decided to let things be as they may. " As he spoke, partly in anger and partly shedding tears, the Hōin felt both fear and pity, and became soaked in sweat. At that moment, anyone would have found it difficult to make a single word of reply. Moreover, he himself was a close attendant [of the Emperor]. Since he had seen and heard correctly about the gathering at Shishigatani, thinking he might be seized and imprisoned immediately as one of that number, he felt like he was stroking a dragon's beard or stepping on a tiger's tail; but the Hōin was also a man of courage, and without being flustered in the slightest, he said: "Indeed, your repeated service is not shallow. There is reason for you to express resentment for a time. However, regarding official rank and stipends, you are completely satisfied personally. Therefore, the Lord has been impressed by your enormous merit. However, that close subjects disturbed matters and the Lord gave permission must have been the disastrous harm of plotting subjects. To trust the ears and doubt the eyes is a common evil of the vulgar. Giving weight to the floating words of small men, alienating the Imperial favor—regarding the intention to turn against the Lord, both in the unseen and visible worlds, the fear is not small. Generally, the mind of Heaven is vast and hard to fathom; the Imperial will is surely fixed on this propriety. For a subordinate to go against a superior—is this the propriety of a subject? You should consider this well. In the end, I will announce this purport."
Saying this, he left; the people sitting in rows said, "Ah, how terrifying. With the Lay Priest angry to that extent, not fearing in the slightest, he made a reply and stood up."
There was no one who did not praise the Hōin.

[3.16.1] When the Hōin went to the Palace and reported this, the Cloistered Emperor also found the reason extreme, and there was no way to give orders. On the 16th, since this was something the Lay Priest Prime Minister had planned for some days, starting with the Regent, the Prime Minister and the nobles and courtiers below them, forty-three people, were suspended from office and confined. The Regent [Motofusa] was demoted to Dazai-no-Sotsu and exiled to Chinzei (Kyushu). Thinking "In such a world, let come what may," he became a monk at a place called Furukawa near Toba. His age was thirty-five. Saying that he was a person who knew propriety well and was a cloudless mirror, the world's regret was not shallow; since it is the way that an exile who has become a monk is not sent to the appointed province, although initially it was decided as Hyūga Province, because he became a monk, he was kept at a place called Ido-basama near the provincial capital of Bizen.

[3.16.2] As for precedents of exiling Ministers, starting with Minister of the Left Soga no Akae, Minister of the Right Toyonari, Minister of the Left Uona, Minister of the Right Sugawara [Michizane], Minister of the Left Takaakira, and Minister of the Right Fujiwara no Korechika, there are already six people. However, we hear this is the first instance of exiling a Regent or Kanpaku.

[3.16.3] Since the son of the late Inner Minister, the Middle Captain of the Second Rank Motomichi, was the Lay Priest's son-in-law, he was made Minister and Regent. In the reign of Retired Emperor En'yū, on the first day of the eleventh month of the third year of Tenroku, when the Ichijō Regent Lord Kentoku passed away, his younger brother, the Horikawa Regent Lord Tadayoshi, was at that time still a Middle Counselor of the Junior Second Rank. Since his younger brother, the Great Lay Priest of Hōkō-in [Kaneie], was a Major Counselor and General of the Right, Lord Tadayoshi had been surpassed by his younger brother, but now he surpassed him back, rising to Minister of the Center and Senior Second Rank, and received the decree of Nairan (Imperial Examiner); people called this a promotion that startled the eyes and ears of all, but this [Motomichi's promotion] exceeded even that. I have not yet heard of someone becoming Minister and Regent from Non-Councillor Middle Captain of the Second Rank without passing through Major Counselor. This is Lord Fugenji. From the Premier to the Major Controller and Grand Scribe, everyone seemed dumbfounded.

[3.16.4] The Prime Minister Morinaga was suspended from office and exiled to the east. In the past Hōgen era, due to the guilt by association with his father, the Evil Minister of the Left, four brothers were exiled; the elder brother General of the Right Kanenaga, the younger brother Middle Captain of the Left Takanaga, and the Zen Master Norinaga—these three did not wait for a return to the capital but died at their places of exile. This one [Morinaga] spent nine springs and autumns at Hata in Tosa, was recalled in the eighth month of the second year of Chōkan, restored to his original rank, raised to Senior Second Rank in the first month of the following year, and rose from Former Middle Counselor to Provisional Major Counselor in the tenth month of the first year of Nin'an. Since there was no vacancy for Major Counselor at the time, he was added as a supernumerary. This was the first time there were six Major Counselors. Also, becoming Provisional Major Counselor from Former Middle Counselor, outside of the Nochi-no-Yamashina Minister Lord Sanemori and the Uji Major Counselor Lord Takakuni, I have not heard of it. Since he had mastered the way of music and excelled in talents, his successive promotions did not stagnate, and he reached the ultimate post of Prime Minister; now, as retribution for what sin, is he exiled again? In the old days of Hōgen, he was moved to Tosa in the southern sea; now in Jishō, it is Owari Province or something in the eastern barrier. Since seeing the moon at a place of exile without any original crime is something men of heart desire, the Minister did not make a fuss. Recalling the ancient times when the Tang Guest of the Crown Prince, Bai Letian (Bo Juyi), rested by the Xunyang River, gazing far at the tide path of the Narumi Lagoon, he constantly looked at the clear moon, whistled in the bay breeze, played the biwa, composed waka, and spent his days and months in idleness. Once, he went on a pilgrimage to the Third Shrine of that province, Atsuta Myōjin. That night, for the pleasure of the deity, he played the biwa and recited poetry; but since the place was originally a border of ignorance, there was no one who understood the sentiment. Village elders, country women, fishermen, and rustic old men lowered their heads and pricked up their ears, but they could not distinguish clear from muddy notes nor know the pitch pipes. However, when he played the lute of Hu Ba, fish scales leaped and danced; when he sang the song of Yu Gong, the dust on the beams moved and shook. When one masters the mystery of things, it stands to reason that nature is moved; everyone's hair stood on end, and the whole assembly felt a sense of wonder. Gradually, as the night deepened, within the tune of the fragrant wind, he included the scent of fragrant flowers; within the melody of flowing springs, he competed with the light of the clear moon. Reciting the prayer "May the worldly literary works of this life, the errors of wild words and fancy phrases..." and playing secret pieces, the deity could not withstand the response, and the treasure hall shook greatly. Saying, "If not for the evil deeds of the Heike, how could I have worshipped this auspicious sign now?", the Minister shed tears of emotion.

[3.16.5] The son of the Inspector Major Counselor Lord Sukekata, the Minor Captain of the Right Gate Guards and Governor of Sanuki, Minamoto no Suketoki, was suspended from his two offices. The Consultant, Provisional Master of the Empress's Household and Commander of the Right Military Guards Fujiwara no Mitsuyoshi; the Minister of the Treasury, Master of the Right Capital and Governor of Iyo Takashina no Yasutsune; the Chamberlain, Minor Controller of the Left and Provisional Senior Assistant Master of the Empress's Household Fujiwara no Motochika—all were suspended from their three offices. Orders were given to the Tō Major Counselor Sanekuni and the Doctorate Judge Nakahara no Norisada that the Inspector Major Counselor Lord Sukekata, his son the Minor Captain of the Right, and his grandson the Minor Captain of the Right Masakata—these three—should be immediately expelled from the capital; and so they were expelled from the capital that very day. The Major Counselor said, "Though the three realms are wide, there is no place to put this five-foot body. Though a lifetime is short, one day is hard to pass." In the middle of the night, he slipped out of the Nine-Fold Enclosure and headed beyond the Eight-Fold Clouds. Taking the road of Mt. Oe and Ikuno, they rested for a while at a place called Murakumo in Tamba Province, but finally they were found there, and it is heard they went to Shinano Province.

[3.17.1] Among the samurai of the former Regent Matsu-dono, there was a man named Go-no-Taifu Hangan Narishige. Since the Heike were ill-disposed toward him too, hearing that they were already marching from Rokuhara to seize him, he took his son Go-no-Saemon-no-jō Ieshige and fled without a destination; riding up Inari Mountain, they dismounted and father and son spoke together: "I thought to flee from here to the eastern provinces and rely on the exile of Izu Province, the former Assistant Commander of the Military Guards Yoritomo, but he is currently under Imperial censure and can hardly manage even himself. Is there any place in Japan that is not a Heike manor? Since we cannot escape anyway, it would be shameful to show ourselves to people in places where we have lived for years. Let us just return from here, and if there are messengers from Rokuhara, nothing would be better than to cut our bellies and die."
So they turned back toward their dwelling at Kawarazaka. As expected, Minamoto no Taifu Hangan Suesada and Settsu no Hangan Morizumi from Rokuhara, with over three hundred horsemen in full armor, pressed upon the dwelling at Kawarazaka and raised a battle cry. Go-no-Taifu Hangan stepped out onto the veranda and said, "Look at this, everyone; report this manner at Rokuhara."
Setting fire to the mansion, both father and son cut their bellies and burned to death in the flames.

[3.17.2] Asking why so many high and low perished like this, it is said to be because of the dispute between the Middle Captain of the Second Rank [Motomichi], who was made Regent at this time, and the son of the former Regent, the Middle Captain of the Third Rank [Morota], over the post of Middle Counselor. If so, the Regent alone might meet with some fate, but should it affect as many as forty-odd people? Although the posthumous title was given to the Sanuki Retired Emperor last year, and posthumous office and rank were given to the Evil Minister of the Left of Uji, the world is still not quiet. In general, it seems it will not be limited to this. Hearing that the Devil of the Sixth Heaven had entered the heart of the Lay Priest Prime Minister and he could not contain his anger, high and low in the capital trembled with fear, wondering what would happen in the realm next.

[3.17.3] At that time, the one known as the Former Minor Controller of the Left Yukitaka was the eldest son of the late Middle Counselor of Nakayama, Lord Akitoki. In the reign of Emperor Nijō, he joined the Controllers and was impressive, but for the past ten years or more he had been suspended from office; unable even to change clothes for summer and winter, and with morning and evening meals not following his will, he lived in a state of barely existing. The Prime Minister Lay Priest sent word to him: "I have something to say. Come quickly."
Yukitaka was greatly terrified and agitated, thinking, "For these past ten years or more, I have not mixed in any affairs; someone must have slandered me."
His wife and children wept and grieved, asking "What kind of fate will you meet?" But since there was a messenger standing in a row from West Hachijō, he could do nothing but borrow a carriage from someone and go out to West Hachijō. Contrary to his thoughts, the Lay Priest immediately came out and met him. "Since your father the Lord was a person with whom I discussed matters great and small, I do not think of you lightly. Although I felt pity for your seclusion in recent years, since the government was under the Cloistered Emperor, I could do nothing. Now, please serve. I will give orders regarding your official path. So, return quickly."
Saying this, he went inside. When he returned, at his dwelling the ladies-in-waiting felt as if a dead person had come back to life, pointed and gathered, and all wept with joy.

[3.17.4] The Lay Priest Prime Minister sent many documents of manors he was to govern via Minamoto no Taifu Hangan Suesada. First, saying "This should do for now," he sent one hundred rolls of silk, one hundred ryo of gold, and loads of rice. Saying it was for the materials of his service, he arranged and sent everything down to servants, ox-drivers, and ox carriages. Yukitaka did not know where his hands danced or his feet stepped, and was astounded, asking "Is this a dream? Is it a dream?" On the 17th of the same month, he was appointed to the Chamberlain of the Fifth Rank, and became Minor Controller of the Left again. He was fifty-one this year, and felt young again. It seemed but a fleeting glory.

div.head: 3.18. The Exile of the Cloistered Emperor

div.p:
[3.18.1] On the 20th of the same month, soldiers surrounded the four sides of the Cloistered Emperor's palace, Hōjūji-dono. Since it was heard that, just as Nobuyori had done in Heiji, they would set fire to it and burn everyone to death, the ladies-in-waiting and servant girls of high and low rank ran out in panic and confusion, not even covering themselves. The Cloistered Emperor was also greatly startled. The former General of the Right Lord Munemori brought a carriage near and reported, "You must board quickly." When the Cloistered Emperor asked, "What is the meaning of this? I do not think I have any fault. Are you going to move me to a distant province or a faraway island like Narichika and Shunkan? Since the Emperor reigns, I only offer words on government affairs. If that too is inappropriate, from now on I will not do so," Lord Munemori replied, "That is not the intention. My father the Lay Priest says that until the world quiets down, you should make a royal visit to Toba-dono." "Then, Munemori, come with me immediately." Although he said this, awed by his father the Zen Initiate's mood, he could not go. "Ah, in this too, he is unexpectedly inferior to his brother the Minister of the Center. Because he [Shigemori] restrained and stopped it, replacing me with his own body whenever I might have met with such an experience even for a moment, I was at ease until today. Because there is no one to remonstrate, he does this. The future, too, is not to be relied upon."
It was awe-inspiring that he shed tears.

[3.18.2] So he boarded the carriage. Not a single noble or courtier accompanied him. Only a low-ranking lady of the North Face, and a carriage servant called Kaneyuki, went with him. In the rear of the carriage, one nun rode. This nun was the Cloistered Emperor's wet nurse, the Nun of the Second Rank from Kii. The royal procession went west on Shichijō and south on Suzaku. Even the lowly men and women said, "Ah, the Cloistered Emperor is being exiled," and there was no one who did not shed tears and wring their sleeves. "The great earthquake on the night of the past 7th was a portent that it would be like this; since it answered to the bottom of the sixteen layers of earth, it stands to reason that the Earth Deity was startled and agitated." Thus people spoke.

[3.18.3] When he entered Toba-dono, the Master of the Palace Table Nobunari, who had somehow mixed in and come along, was waiting near him; he summoned him and said, "In any case, I think I will be killed tonight. I wish to take a bath; what shall we do?"
Nobunari, who had been out of his wits since morning anyway, appeared astounded, but grateful to receive this command, he tucked up his hunting robe with a sash, broke the brushwood fence, tore up the posts of the great floor, and prepared the hot water as if he were a water-drawer.

[3.18.4] Also, Seal of the Law Jōken went to the Lay Priest Prime Minister's West Hachijō residence and said, "Hearing that the Cloistered Emperor made a royal visit to Toba-dono this evening, and that there is not a single person attending him, I feel it is utterly wretched. Whatever the trouble, please at least allow Jōken. I will go." Since the reply was "Quickly, quickly, since you are a person who will not make mistakes," he was permitted. When the Hōin went to Toba-dono, got off his carriage in front of the gate, and entered inside the gate, just then the voice of the Cloistered Emperor reciting sutras loudly could be heard especially dreadfully. When the Hōin entered directly and saw the tears falling profusely onto the sutra he was reading, in the excess of his sadness, he pressed the sleeve of his priestly robe to his face and went before him weeping. Only the nun was in attendance. "Well, Hōin-no-gobo, since the Lord took a meal yesterday morning at Hōjūji-dono, he has not eaten last night or this morning. He did not sleep all night long. His life seems already in danger."
When she said this, the Hōin suppressed his tears and said, "Since there is a limit to everything, the Heike have enjoyed prosperity for over twenty years. However, their evil deeds exceed the measure, and they will soon perish. How could Amaterasu Ōmikami and the True Hachiman Shrine abandon you? Above all, if the vows of the Seven Shrines of Hiyoshi Sannō, on whom the Lord relies for the protection of the One Vehicle, do not change, they will surely soar on the Eight Scrolls of the Lotus Sutra and protect the Lord. Thus, the government will become the Lord's reign, and the evil band will vanish like foam on the water."
Since he spoke thus, the Emperor was comforted a little by these words.

[3.18.5] The Emperor [Takakura] had lamented the exile of the Regent and the destruction of many subjects, but after hearing that the Cloistered Emperor was confined at Toba-dono, he did not partake of food at all. Saying he was ill, he constantly went only into the night bedchamber. Starting with the Empress, the ladies-in-waiting attending him did not know what to do.

[3.18.6] After the Cloistered Emperor was confined at Toba-dono, calling it an extraordinary divine service, the Emperor worshipped the Great Shrine of Ise every night on the lime altar of the Seiryōden. This was solely a prayer for the Cloistered Emperor. Although Retired Emperor Nijō was a wise king, perhaps because he said that a Son of Heaven has no parents and constantly acted against the Cloistered Emperor's orders, he did not remain as the successor Lord. Thus, Retired Emperor Rokujō, who received his abdication, also passed away at the age of thirteen on the 14th of the seventh month of the second year of Angen. It was a wretched matter.

[3.19.1] It is said, "Among the hundred actions, filial piety is the foremost. An enlightened king governs the realm with filial piety. " Thus, it is seen that Yao of Tang honored his senile mother, and Shun of Yu respected his obstinate father. How splendid was the Imperial intent that followed the precedents of those wise kings and holy lords. At that time, there was a secret letter from the Palace to Toba-dono. It was written: "In such a world, what is the use of remaining in the Palace? Visiting the past of Kanpyō [Retired Emperor Uda] and seeking the old days of Kazan, I should leave the house, escape the world, and become a pilgrim wandering the mountains and forests." In the Cloistered Emperor's reply, it was written: "Do not think that. That you are there is my one reliance. If you were to disappear without a trace, what reliance would there be? You must only see how this foolish old man ends up." The Emperor pressed this reply to his Dragon Face and sank even deeper into tears. The ruler is the ship; the subject is the water. The water can float the ship; the water can also overturn the ship. The subject can maintain the ruler; the subject can also overturn the ruler. In the time of Hōgen and Heiji, although the Lay Priest Prime Minister maintained the ruler, now in Angen and Jishō, he slights the ruler. It does not differ from the text of the history books. The Great Omiya Prime Minister [Koremichi], the Sanjō Inner Minister [Kinyoshi], the Hamuro Major Counselor, and the Nakayama Middle Counselor have also passed away. Now, as for old people, there are only Narinori and Chikanori. These people too, saying "In such a world, what is the use of serving the court, establishing oneself, and passing through Major and Middle Counselor?", left their houses and escaped the world while still in their prime; it is heard that the Lay Priest Minister of Popular Affairs Chikanori accompanied the frost of Ohara, and the Lay Priest Prime Minister Narinori mixed with the mist of Kōya, doing nothing other than preparing wholly for enlightenment in the afterlife. In ancient times too, there were people who hid in the clouds of Mount Shang and cleared their hearts in the moon of the Ying River; were they not widely read and pure, having escaped the world? Among them, the Lay Priest Prime Minister Narinori, who was at Kōya, hearing rumors of these things, said, "Ah, they escaped the world with quick hearts. Like this, even hearing it feels like the same thing, but if I were mixing intimately with them and saw it, how painful it would be. I thought the disturbances of Hōgen and Heiji were wretched, but as the world ends, such things happen. After this, what extent of things will arise? I wish to part the clouds and climb higher, to put mountains between us and enter deeper."
Thus he spoke. It did not seem like a world where anyone with heart would stay.

[3.19.2] On the 23rd of the same month. Because the Abbot of Tendai, Cloistered Imperial Prince Kakukai, repeatedly resigned, the former Abbot, Archbishop Myōun, was reinstated. Although the Lay Priest Prime Minister had scattered things like this, his daughter was the Empress. The Regent was also his son-in-law. Perhaps he felt at ease in all things. Saying "Government affairs should be wholly at the Emperor's discretion," he went down to Fukuhara. The former General of the Right Lord Munemori hurriedly visited the Palace and reported this; the Emperor said, "If it were a world where the Cloistered Emperor had delegated it, fine. Just consult with the Regent quickly, and manage things somehow, Munemori," and he did not accept it.

[3.19.3] Since half of winter had passed while the Cloistered Emperor was at the Detached Palace of Jōnan [Toba], only the sound of the storm on the fields and mountains was fierce, and the light of the moon in the cold garden was clear. Only snow fell and piled up in the garden, and there was no one to tread traces; ice closed over the pond, and the birds that used to gather could not be seen. The sound of the bell of the great temple startled the listening of I-ai Temple; the color of the snow on the western hills urged the gaze of Xianglu Peak. The sound of the fulling block, cold in the night frost, faintly reached his pillow; the tracks of the carriage crushing the dawn ice lay far before the gate. The travelers passing the crossroads, the busy appearance of the war horses—the state of passing through the floating world was realized, and it was pathetic. He said it was awe-inspiring to wonder what bond from a previous life led the barbarians guarding the palace gates to perform guard duty day and night now. In general, touching upon things and following events, there was nothing that did not pain his heart. As it was, continuing to think of those occasional excursions, the pilgrimages to various places, and the splendid events of celebrations, the tears of nostalgia were hard to suppress. The year left and the year came, and it became the fourth year of Jishō.

[4.1.1] On the first day of the first month of the fourth year of Jishō, at the Toba Palace, since the Prime Minister did not permit it and the Cloistered Emperor was also fearful, during the first three days of the New Year, there was no one who came to pay respects. However, only the son of the late Lay Priest Shōnagon Shinzei, Sakuramachi Chūnagon Shigenori-kyō, and his younger brother Sakyō-no-Daibu Naganori were permitted to visit. On the twentieth of the same first month, although there were joyous events such as the Crown Prince’s donning of trousers and the first eating of fish, the Cloistered Emperor was at the Toba Palace and heard of them only as distant rumors.

[4.1.2] On the twenty-first of the second month, forcing the abdication of His Majesty, who was suffering from no particular illness, the Crown Prince ascended the throne. This was the doing of the Lay Priest Prime Minister, just as he desired in all things. People whispered together that the times had become grave. The Divine Mirror and the Sacred Jewel and Sword of the Naishidokoro were transferred. The High Nobles gathered at the guard station and proceeded according to ancient precedents; Ben-no-Naishi stepped forward for the Sword. At the western side of the Seiryōden, Captain Taimichi received it. Bitchū-no-Naishi brought out the box of the Sacred Jewel. Minor Captain Takafusa received it. Regarding the box of the Sacred Jewel of the Naishidokoro, thinking that perhaps only tonight could they lay hands upon it, amidst the deep pathos of what the ladies-in-waiting must have been feeling in their hearts, Shōnagon-no-Naishi ought to have brought out the Jewel box, but hearing people say that if one laid hands on it tonight, one would not become a new lady-in-waiting for a long time, she declined at that moment and did not bring it out. She was already advanced in years. Saying that she could not expect a second prime of life, people despised her, but Bitchū-no-Naishi, though only sixteen years of age and still physically immature, intentionally requested it at that moment and brought it out; it was a graceful manner. The various officials received the transmitted Imperial Regalia item by item and transferred them to the new Emperor’s Imperial Palace at the Gojō Palace. At the Kan'in Palace, even the shadows of lights were dim, the voices of the guards ceased, and the inquiries of the Takiguchi guards were cut off; the old attendants felt forlorn, and amidst the joyous celebration, they shed tears and pained their hearts. The Minister of the Left came out to the guard station, and hearing the commands regarding the abdication, those with sensitive hearts shed tears and dampened their sleeves. Even when one abdicates the throne to the Crown Prince of one's own accord and thinks to be at peace amidst the Mount Makoya, it is the custom that there is much sorrow. How much more so, since this was not his will but a forced abdication, the sadness is essentially beyond words.

[4.1.3] The new Emperor is three years old this year; the people of the time whispered to one another, "Ah, what a pitiful abdication." Hei-Dainagon Tokitada-kyō, because he was the husband of the Emperor's wet nurse, the Sotsu-no-Suke, said, "No matter what kind of abdication this is, who can object to it? In foreign lands, King Cheng of Zhou was three, Emperor Mu of Jin was two; in our court, Emperor Konoe was three, Emperor Rokujō was two; though these were all wrapped in swaddling clothes and did not have their robes and sashes properly adjusted, it is seen that either a Regent carried them on his back to ascend the throne, or the Mother Empress held them to face the court. Emperor Xiaoshang of Later Han ascended the throne at one hundred days after birth. The precedents of a Son of Heaven treading the throne are like this in Japan and China." When he said this, the knowledgeable people of the time murmured together, "Ah, how terrifying, do not speak such things. So, are those auspicious precedents?"
Since the Crown Prince ascended the throne, the Lay Priest Prime Minister and his wife, as the maternal grandfather and maternal grandmother, received the decree of Jusangū (status equal to the three Empresses), were granted annual stipends and rights to recommend rank, and employed courtiers. Decorated samurai entered and exited, and it was strictly like the residence of a Retired Emperor or Empress. It appeared that even after taking the tonsure and entering the priesthood, his glory was not exhausted. A person who has entered the priesthood receiving the decree of Jusangū is the precedent of the Great Lay Priest of the Hōkōin, Lord Kaneie.

[4.1.4] In the first ten days of the third month of the same year, it was rumored that the Retired Emperor would undertake a pilgrimage to Itsukushima in Aki Province. Since an Emperor who has yielded the throne usually makes his first pilgrimage to shrines like Hachiman, Kamo, or Kasuga, people were suspicious, asking why he was going as far as Aki Province. A certain person said, "Retired Emperor Shirakawa went to Kumano, and Go-Shirakawa went to Hiyoshi Shrine. I do not know; it is within His Majesty's mind." There was a deep prayer in his heart. Furthermore, since the Heike clan revered this Itsukushima extraordinarily, it was rumored that it was for the purpose of praying that outwardly he would be in accord with the Heike, but inwardly that the Lay Priest Prime Minister's rebellious heart—keeping the Cloistered Emperor confined at Toba Palace for no reason—might be softened. The monks of the Mountain Gate (Mt. Hiei) expressed their anger. "If it is not to Iwashimizu, Kamo, or Kasuga, the pilgrimage should be to Sannō of our mountain. What kind of custom is a pilgrimage to Aki Province? If that is the case, bring down the portable shrines and stop the pilgrimage." Because they discussed this, there was a temporary delay. Since the Lay Priest Prime Minister appeased them in various ways, the monks of the Mountain Gate quieted down.

[4.1.5] On the seventeenth of the same month, as the departure for the Itsukushima pilgrimage, he entered the Lay Priest Prime Minister's West Eighth Avenue residence. Towards the evening of that day, he summoned the Former Major Captain of the Right Munemori-kyō and said, "Tomorrow, on the occasion of the pilgrimage, I wish to go to the Toba Palace and enter the presence of the Cloistered Emperor; what do you think? Would it be bad to do so without informing the Lay Priest Prime Minister?" Munemori-kyō shed tears profusely and said, "Why should that be a matter [of concern]? The Lay Priest will surely think it is a splendid thing." "Then, Munemori, tell this situation to the Toba Palace immediately tonight," he commanded. Former Major Captain of the Right Munemori-kyō hurriedly went to the Toba Palace and reported this; the Cloistered Emperor thought it was too much to expect, and said it must be a dream.

[4.1.6] On the nineteenth of the same month, Omiya Dainagon Takasue-kyō came while it was not yet deep in the night and urged the pilgrimage. The pilgrimage to Itsukushima that had been rumored for days finally proceeded from West Eighth Avenue. Although the third month was half over, the dawn moon clouded by mist was still dim. Even the calls of the returning wild geese pointing toward the northern lands in the clouds were heard with sadness at this season. While it was not yet night, he made a pilgrimage to the Toba Palace. Descending from his carriage in front of the gate and entering inside the gate, people were scarce, the trees were dark, and the dwelling seemed lonely; he thought it pathetic first of all; spring was already ending, and it had become summer groves. The color of the blossoms on the treetops had faded, and the voice of the palace warbler had grown old. On the sixth day of the first month of last year, when there was a royal visit to the Hōjūji Palace for the morning greeting, Ranjō music was played in the music chamber, the nobles stood in rows, the guards drew up their ranks, the court nobles of the In-no-Tsukasa came to meet him, the curtained gates were opened, the Bureau of Housekeeping laid out the path-mats, but of that solemn ceremony, there was not a single thing. Today he thought it was only a dream.

[4.1.7] When Chūnagon Shigenori announced his presence, the Cloistered Emperor moved to the room of the step-cover of the main hall and waited for him to enter. The Retired Emperor was twenty years old this year; shining in the light of the dawn moon, his imperial person looked all the more beautiful. Because he looked painfully like his mother, Kenshun-mon'in, the Cloistered Emperor first remembered the late Empress and could not hold back his tears. The seats of the two Emperors were arranged close together. Their dialogue was not something others could hear. Only the nun was in attendance before them. They spoke for a good while. Long after the sun had risen high, he took his leave and boarded a boat from Kusatsu in Toba. The Retired Emperor looked upon the Cloistered Emperor’s detached palace, the old residence, his secluded and lonely dwelling, with a painful heart; the Cloistered Emperor, in turn, felt anxious about the Retired Emperor's lodging on the journey, on the waves, and his state aboard the ship. Truly, setting aside the Ancestral Shrines, Hachiman, and Kamo, and making a pilgrimage as far as Aki Province—how could the gods not accept this? It seemed there was no doubt his prayers would be fulfilled.

[4.2.1] On the twenty-sixth of the same month, he arrived at Itsukushima; the lodging of the Lay Priest Prime Minister’s most beloved lady-in-waiting became the Imperial Palace. Staying for two days in between, sutra chanting and musical performances were conducted. The officiating priest was rumored to be Sōjō Kōken of Mii-dera. Ascending the high seat, striking the bell, he said in the words of the invocation, "Leaving the Nine-Fold Capital, parting the eight-fold sea paths, the gratitude for the Imperial Will in coming here..." Because he spoke loudly, both Lord and subjects were moved to tears. Starting with the Great Shrine and the Guest Shrine, he made pilgrimages to all the shrines and places. About five chō from the Great Shrine, circling the mountain, he visited the Waterfall Shrine. Sōjō Kōken composed one poem and wrote it on a pillar of the worship hall.

lg.l: To the white threads of the waterfall falling from the clouds, how joyful to tie a bond.

div.p: [4.2.2] The Shinto priest Saeki Kagehiro was promoted in rank to Senior Fifth Rank, Upper Grade; the Governor Fujiwara Aritsuna was raised in rank and promoted to Junior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade; and he was permitted access to the Retired Emperor's court. The head priest Son'ei was made a Hōin. It seemed that the divine will moved, and the heart of the Lay Priest Prime Minister also worked.

[4.2.3] On the twenty-ninth of the same month, the Retired Emperor decorated his boat and began his return. Because the wind was fierce, the boat was rowed back, and he stayed at Arinoura within Itsukushima. The Retired Emperor said, "In regret for parting from the Great Deity, compose a poem." Minor Captain Takafusa:

lg.l: Since it is the Bay of Ari where parting regrets return again and again, the white waves [gods] also hang their mercy.

div.p: [4.2.4] Around midnight, the waves became calm and the wind quieted, so the boat was rowed out; that day he arrived at the harbor of Shikina in Bingo Province. At this place, in the past during the Ōho era, at the time of the pilgrimage of the Cloistered Emperor, there was a palace built by the Governor Fujiwara Tamenari, which the Lay Priest Prime Minister had prepared and equipped, but the Retired Emperor did not go up to it.

[4.2.5] Thinking that today is the first day of the fourth month, the day of the Changing of Robes, while everyone thought fondly of the Capital and amused themselves, the Retired Emperor saw deeply colored wisteria hanging on a pine tree on the shore; summoning Dainagon Takasue, he commanded, "Go and break off that flower." He summoned the Left Recorder Nakahara Yasusada, who was rowing past the Imperial presence in a small boat, and sent him to break it off. He broke off the wisteria flower and, leaving it attached to the pine branch, brought it back. Saying that he had good taste, the Emperor was impressed.
