"There should be a poem about this flower," he said. Dainagon Takasue:

lg.l: Upon your Lordship's age of a thousand years, the waves of wisteria have hung even upon the pine branch.

div.p: [4.2.6] After that, many people were in attendance before him, and when there was some playful talk, the Retired Emperor laughed and said, "The lady-in-waiting wearing white robes has her heart set on Lord Kunitsuna, doesn't she?" While the Dainagon was vehemently denying it, a servant girl carrying a letter arrived and held it up, saying, "To the Gojō Dainagon." Saying, "Just as I thought," the whole company spoke of it as an amusing matter. When the Dainagon took it and looked at it:

lg.l: Wringing the sleeves of my robe of white waves, it is indeed because of you that I cannot leave.

div.p: [4.2.7] The Retired Emperor said, "Consider this gracefully. There must be a reply to this." Immediately he handed down his inkstone. In the Dainagon's reply:

lg.l: Imagine my damp sleeves, every time the rising waves of your image approach.

div.p: [4.2.8] From there, they arrived at the harbor of Kojima in Bizen Province.

[4.2.9] On the fifth day, the sky was clear, the wind was quiet, and the sea was calm; starting with the Imperial boat, all the people’s boats set out together, parting the waves of clouds and waves of mist, and at the hour of the Rooster on that day, they arrived at the bay of Yamada in Harima Province. From there he took a palanquin and entered Fukuhara. On the sixth, although the accompanying people hurried to return to the Capital even one day sooner, the New Retired Emperor stayed and toured the various places of Fukuhara. He viewed the mountain villa of Ike-Chūnagon Yorimori-kyō, as far as Arata.

[4.2.10] On the seventh, upon leaving Fukuhara, Dainagon Takasue received an imperial order, and rewards for the house of the Lay Priest Prime Minister were carried out. The Lay Priest's adopted son, Governor of Tanba Kiyokuni, was made Senior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade; the Lay Priest's grandson, Echizen Minor Captain Sukemori, was made Junior Fourth Rank, Upper Grade, it was rumored. That day, he arrived at Terai. On the eighth, as he entered the Capital, the welcoming High Nobles and courtiers went as far as Kusatsu in Toba. At the time of his return, there was no visit to the Toba Palace; he entered the Lay Priest Prime Minister’s West Eighth Avenue residence.

[4.2.11] On the twenty-second of the same fourth month, the enthronement of the New Emperor took place. Although it ought to have been at the Daigokuden, since the fire of a previous year, it had not yet been rebuilt. It was decided that it should be held at the Dajōkan (Grand Council of State) office, but Lord Kujō at that time said, "The Dajōkan office, if taken as a commoner's house, is the place for Kumonjo (archives/administration). Since there is no Daigokuden, the enthronement should surely be at the Shishinden." Because he said this, the enthronement took place at the Shishinden. "Long ago on the first day of the eleventh month of the fourth year of Kōhō, the enthronement of Emperor Reizei at the Shishinden was because the Emperor, due to illness/madness, could not go to the Daigokuden. How can that precedent be appropriate? We should just rely on the auspicious example of the Enkyū era of Emperor Go-Sanjō and hold it at the Dajōkan office," people argued, but regarding Lord Kujō's plan, there was nothing to be done. The Empress moved from the Kokiden to the Jijuden, and the manner in which she went to the High Throne was magnificent. Among the people of the Heike clan who all served, the children of the Komatsu Lord (Shigemori), because the Minister had died last year, shut themselves away in mourning.

[4.3.1] Chamberlain Semon-no-Gon-no-Suke Sadanaga recorded in minute detail on about ten sheets of thick paper how there were no disturbances and how magnificent the recent enthronement was, and when he presented it to the Lay Priest Prime Minister’s wife, the Nii-Dono of Hachijō, she smiled and was pleased. Although there were such colorful and magnificent things, the world was still not quiet.

[4.3.2] At that time, the Cloistered Emperor's second prince, called Prince Mochihito, was the son of the daughter of Kaga Dainagon Suenari-kyō. Since he lived at Sanjō-Takakura, he was called the Takakura Prince. Long ago, on the sixteenth of the twelfth month of the first year of Eiman, at the age of fifteen, concealing himself, he had his coming-of-age ceremony at the Ōmiya Palace in the Konoe riverbed. His calligraphy was beautiful, and his talent and learning were superior, so he ought to have ascended the throne, but due to the jealousy of the late Kenshun-mon'in, he was kept in confinement; during spring excursions under the blossoms, he wielded a purple brush and wrote his own compositions, and at autumn banquets before the moon, he blew a jade flute and personally played elegant tunes; while he passed his days and nights in this way, in the fourth year of Jishō, he became thirty years of age.

[4.3.3] At that time, the Lay Priest of the Third Rank Minamoto no Yorimasa, who was serving at the Konoe riverbed, secretly visited this Prince's palace one night and spoke fearful things. "Your Highness is the forty-eighth generation descendant of Amaterasu Ōmikami, and corresponds to the seventy-eighth generation from Emperor Kanmu. Though you should have stood as Crown Prince and ascended the throne, do you not find it bitter to pass your time as a mere Prince until thirty? Looking at the state of the present world, though outwardly they seem to obey, inwardly are there not those who do not despise the Heike? Please raise a rebellion, destroy the Heike, put at ease the heart of the Cloistered Emperor who is endlessly confined at the Toba Palace, and you yourself assume the throne. This would be the utmost of filial piety. If you decide to do this and issue a command, there are many Genji who will rejoice and race to join you." And he continued speaking. "First, in the Capital, there are the children of the Former Governor of Dewa Mitsunobu: Iga-no-Kami Mitsumoto, Dewa Hangan Mitsunaga, Dewa Kurando Mitsushige, Dewa Kaja Mitsuyoshi; in Kumano, the youngest son of the late Rokujō Hangan Tameyoshi, Jurō Yoshimori, is in hiding. In Settsu Province, there is Tada Kurando Yukitsuna, but at the time of the rebellion of the New Dainagon Narichika-kyō, though he was a conspirator, he turned traitor, so he is an unrighteous man and not worth mentioning. Nevertheless, his younger brother Tada Jirō Tomozane, Teshima Kaja Takayori, Ōta Tarō Yorimoto; in Kawachi Province, Musashi-no-Gon-no-Kami Nyūdō Yoshimoto, his son Ishikawa Hangandai Yoshikane; in Yamato Province, the children of Uno Shichirō Chikaharu: Tarō Ariharu, Jirō Kiyoharu, Saburō Nariharu, Shirō Yoshiharu; in Ōmi Province, Yamamoto, Kashiwagi, Nishikori; in Mino and Owari, Yamada Jirō Shigehiro, Kawabe Tarō Shigenao, Izumi Tarō Shigemitsu, Urano Shirō Shigetō, Ajiki Jirō Shigeyori, his son Tarō Shigesuke, Kida Saburō Shigenaga, Kaiden Hangandai Shigekuni, Yashima Senjō Shigetaka, his son Tarō Shigeyuki; in Kai Province, Henmi Kaja Yoshikiyo, his son Tarō Kiyomitsu, Takeda Tarō Nobuyoshi, Kagami Jirō Tōmitsu, the same Kojirō Nagakiyo, Ichijō Jirō Tadayori, Itagaki Saburō Kanenobu, Henmi Hyōe Ariyoshi, Takeda Gorō Nobumitsu, Yasuda Saburō Yoshisada; in Shinano Province, Ōuchi Tarō Koreyoshi, Okada Kaja Chikayoshi, Hiraga Kaja Moriyoshi, his son Shirō Yoshinobu, and the second son of the late Tatewaki Senjō Yoshikata, Kiso Kaja Yoshinaka; in Izu Province, the exile Former Captain of the Right Guard Yoritomo; in Hitachi Province, Shida Saburō Senjō Yoshinori, Satake Kaja Masayoshi, his son Tarō Tadayoshi, the same Saburō Yoshimune, Shirō Takayoshi, Gorō Yoshisue; in Mutsu Province, the youngest son of the late Captain of the Left Stables Yoshitomo, Kurō Kaja Yoshitsune; these are all descendants of Prince Rokuson, the posterity of Tada Shin-Hotschi Manju. In quelling enemies of the court and achieving long-held desires, there was no superiority or inferiority between Genji and Heike, but now, separated by clouds and mud, we are even inferior to the courtesies of masters and servants. In the provinces we obey the Governors, in the manors we are employed by the estate managers, driven by public duties and miscellaneous tasks, and have no peaceful thoughts. How bitter this must be. If Your Highness decides to stand and grants a command, we will race up continuing night into day, and in destroying the Heike, we shall not waste time and days. Though I, the Lay Priest, am old, I shall lead my children and serve you." Thus he spoke.

[4.3.4] The Prince wondered how this could be and for a while did not consent, but the son of Bingo-no-Zenji Suemichi, grandson of Akomaru Dainagon Munemichi-kyō, called Shōnagon Korenaga, was a superior physiognomist, so the people of the time called him Physiognomy Shōnagon. That person saw this Prince and said, "You have the physiognomy to ascend the throne. You must not abandon the affairs of the realm." Since he said this, and the Lay Priest of the Third Rank Minamoto also spoke in this way, [the Prince thought], "Then it must be so. Perhaps it is an oracle of Amaterasu Ōmikami." And so. He earnestly made up his mind. He summoned Jurō Yoshimori, who was in Kumano, and made him a Kurando (Chamberlain). Renaming him Yukiie, he sent him down to the eastern provinces as the messenger of the command.

[4.3.5] Leaving the Capital on the twenty-eighth of the same fourth month, beginning with Ōmi Province, he informed the Genji of Mino and Owari in order along the way, and on the tenth of the fifth month, he arrived down at Hōjō in Izu and presented the command to the exile Former Captain of the Guard (Yoritomo). Shida Saburō Senjō Yoshinori, thinking "He is my elder brother, I will tell him," went down to Ukishima in Shida, Hitachi Province. Kiso Kaja Yoshinaka, thinking "He is my nephew, I will consult him," headed for the mountain roads.

[4.3.6] The Kumano Bettō of that time, Tanzō, was deeply loyal to the Heike, but somehow he must have leaked the news: "Shingū no Jurō Yoshimori has received the command of the Takakura Prince, has alerted and mobilized the Genji of Mino and Owari, and has already raised a rebellion. The people of Nachi and Shingū will surely side with the Genji. I, Tanzō, have received the favor of the Heike like heaven and mountains; how can I disobey them?" Intending to shoot a single arrow at the people of Nachi and Shingū and report the details to the Heike, he set out for the harbor of Shingū with one thousand men in armor. At Shingū, there were Torii Hōgen and Takabō Hōgen; among the samurai, Ui, Suzuki, Mizuya, and Kame-no-Kō; at Nachi, there was the Administrator Hōgen and others; in total, their force was over two thousand men. Making war cries and exchanging arrows, they shot "For the Genji!" and "For the Heike!" mutually; without pause in the shouts of arrows, and without a gap in the sound of whistling arrows, they fought for about three days. Kumano Bettō Tanzō had many of his retainers and followers struck down, was wounded himself, and barely keeping his miserable life, fled up to the Main Shrine.

[4.4.1] Meanwhile, the Cloistered Emperor said, "Am I to be exiled to a distant province or moved to a remote island?" but at the Jonan Detached Palace, this year became his second year [of confinement]. Around the hour of the Horse on the twelfth of the same fifth month, weasels ran wildly in great numbers through the palace. The Cloistered Emperor was greatly surprised and performed a divination; summoning the Governor of Ōmi Nakakane—who at that time was not yet called Kurando—he said, "Take this divination form to Yasuchika's place, have him divine it immediately, and bring back the divination report."
Nakakane received this and went to the place of the Head of Yin-Yang Abe no Yasuchika, but he was not at his lodging at that time. Being told he was at a place in Shirakawa, he sought him there, met Yasuchika, and when he spoke the purport of the imperial order, Yasuchika immediately presented the divination report. Nakakane returned to the Toba Palace and tried to enter through the gate, but the guarding warriors did not permit it. Knowing the layout, he crossed the earthen wall, crawled under the main floor, and presented Yasuchika's divination report through a floorboard. When the Cloistered Emperor opened it and looked, it said, "Within three days, joy and grief."
The Cloistered Emperor said, "Joy should be so. Having come to this state, I wonder what kind of grief there will be again."

[4.4.2] Meanwhile, since Former Major Captain of the Right Munemori-kyō pleaded repeatedly regarding the Cloistered Emperor, the Lay Priest Prime Minister gradually reconsidered, and on the thirteenth of the same month, let him leave the Toba Palace and made him move to the Bifukumon-in Palace at Hachijō Karasuma. The joy within three days referred to this.

[4.4.3] While this was happening, Kumano Bettō Tanzō reported the details of the Takakura Prince's rebellion to the Capital via express messenger; Former Major Captain of the Right Munemori-kyō was greatly alarmed, and since the Lay Priest Prime Minister was at Fukuhara at the time, he reported this to him; without waiting to hear the end of it, he immediately raced up to the Capital and proclaimed, "There is no need for discussion. Arrest the Takakura Prince and exile him to Hata in Tosa."
The senior noble was Sanjō Dainagon Sanefusa, and the official was Head Chamberlain Mitsumasa, it was rumored. Minamoto no Tayū Hangan Kanetsuna and Dewa Hangan Mitsunaga received [the order] and headed for the Prince's palace. This Minamoto no Tayū Hangan was the second son of the Lay Priest of the Third Rank. The reason he was included in this number was because the Heike did not yet know that the Lay Priest of the Third Rank had recommended the rebellion to the Takakura Prince.

[4.5.1] The Prince was composing poetry on the moon between the clouds on the night of the fifteenth of the fifth month, not thinking of any destination, when a messenger from the Lay Priest of the Third Rank Minamoto arrived hurriedly carrying a letter; the Prince’s foster brother, Rokujō-no-Suke-no-Tayū Munenobu, took it, went before the Prince, opened it and saw: "Your Highness's rebellion has already been exposed, and saying you are to be exiled to Hata in Tosa, officials are coming to get you. Please leave the palace quickly and go to Mii-dera. The Lay Priest also will come soon." Thus it said. "What shall I do?" While he was in a panic, there was a man called the Prince's samurai chief, Hyōe-no-Jō Nobutsura. "There is no other way. Please leave in the attire of a lady-in-waiting." Because he said this, "That is right," the Prince said, and messing his hair, wearing layered robes, he put on a traveler's hat. Rokujō-no-Suke-no-Tayū Munenobu held a paper umbrella and accompanied him. A servant boy named Tsurumaru carried things in a bag on his head; looking for all the world like a young samurai escorting a woman, they set out; as they fled north from Takakura, there was a large ditch, and the Prince crossed it very lightly, so a passerby on the road stopped and said, "That is a brazen way for a lady-in-waiting to cross a ditch." Because he looked at them suspiciously, they passed by all the more quickly.

[4.5.2] Chōhyōe-no-Jō Nobutsura was left as a guard at the palace. He made the few ladies-in-waiting who were there hide here and there, and thinking that if there were unsightly things he would tidy them up, while looking around, he saw the flute called "Koeda" (Little Branch) which the Prince treasured so much, forgotten right now by the pillow in his usual living quarters; he thought he would want to take it even if he had to return. Nobutsura found this and saying, "Ah, how terrible. The flute the Lord treasures so much," he chased after them within five chō and presented it. The Prince was extraordinarily impressed and said, "If I die, put this flute in my coffin." "Accompany me immediately," he said, but Nobutsura replied, "Since officials are coming to the palace right now to get you, if there is not a single person in Your presence, it would be extremely regrettable. It is a fact known to high and low that Nobutsura serves at this palace; if I am not there tonight, it will be said, 'He too fled that night,' and for one who takes up the bow and arrow, even a false reputation is regrettable. I will deal with the officials for a while, defeat them, and then come to you immediately." So saying, he ran back.

[4.5.3] Chōhyōe's attire that day was a light blue hunting robe, under which he wore green-laced belly armor, and he carried a guardsman's sword. He opened both the main gate facing Sanjō and the small gate facing Takakura and waited. Minamoto no Tayū Hangan Kanetsuna and Dewa Hangan Mitsunaga, with a total force of over three hundred horsemen, pressed upon the Prince's palace at the hour of the Rat on the night of the fifteenth. Minamoto no Tayū Hangan, feeling there was a reason [knowing the plot], held back far outside the gate. Dewa Hangan Mitsunaga rode his horse inside the gate, stopped in the garden, and raising a great voice said, "Because there is a rumor of rebellion, we officials have received a Bettō order and have come to get you. Come out quickly." When he said this, Chōhyōe-no-Jō stood on the main veranda and said, "This is not currently the Imperial Palace. It is a place of religious abstinence. What is the matter? Speak the details." When he said this, [Mitsunaga said], "Why, if not this palace, where would he be? Do not let him say that. Men, go in and search." Hearing this, Chōhyōe-no-Jō said, "What a way for ignorant officials to speak. Even entering inside the gate while mounted on a horse is outrageous, but to say 'Men, go in and search'—how can you say that? Sahyōe-no-Jō Hasebe Nobutsura is here. Do not approach closely or let him pass." Among the servants of the bureau, a powerful man named Kanetake fixed his eyes on Chōhyōe and leaped up onto the main veranda. Seeing this, fourteen or fifteen comrades followed. Chōhyōe cut the sash of his hunting robe and threw it away; though it was a guardsman's sword, he drew the blade he had prepared with care and slashed wildly. Though the enemies behaved violently with great swords and great halberds, they were cut down by Nobutsura's guardsman's sword and fell into the garden with a thud, like leaves scattering in a storm.

[4.5.4] With the moon of the fifteenth night of the fifth month appearing from the clouds and shining brightly, the enemy was unfamiliar with the layout, but Nobutsura was the guide; chasing them to that passageway, he cut them down with a clap; chasing them to this dead end, he cut them down with a thud. "Why do you do this to the messengers of the Imperial Order?" they said; "What is an Imperial Order?" he replied, and when swords were bent, he jumped back, straightened them, stepped back in, and on the spot cut down fourteen or fifteen capable men. About three inches of his sword tip broke off; intending to cut his belly, he felt for his waist, but his dagger had fallen and was gone. Powerless, he spread his arms wide and was about to run out from the small gate facing Takakura, when a man holding a great halberd approached; Nobutsura tried to jump over the halberd and leaped, but missed his jump, was pierced through the thigh as if sewn, and though his heart was fierce, he was hemmed in by a great force and was taken alive.

[4.5.5] After that, they searched the palace, but the Prince was not there. Binding only Nobutsura, they took him to Rokuhara. The Lay Priest Prime Minister was sitting behind the blinds. Former Major Captain of the Right Munemori-kyō stood on the main veranda, had Nobutsura dragged into the main courtyard, and said, "Is it true that you, a paltry man, said 'What is an Imperial Order?' and cut people? Furthermore, you injured and killed servants of the bureau. In the end, interrogate him, investigate the details of the matter thoroughly, and after that drag him out to the riverbed and cut off his head." Nobutsura was not the least bit flustered; he laughed scornfully and said, "Recently, night after night, suspicious things have been spying on that palace, so I wondered what was happening, and while I was unprepared, men in armor broke in; when I asked 'Who is it?', they named themselves 'Messengers of the Imperial Order.' I have heard before that mountain bandits, pirates, and robbers call themselves 'Nobles entering' or 'Messengers of the Imperial Order,' so saying 'What is an Imperial Order?', I cut them. Generally, if I had prepared my armor as I wished and held a good iron sword, I would by no means have let a single official return safely. Also, where has the Prince gone? I do not know. Even if I did know, would a man of true samurai spirit, having decided not to speak, speak upon being interrogated?" Saying this, he spoke no more after that.

[4.5.6] The Heike samurai who were sitting in rows said to each other, "Ah, what a brave man. To have such a precious man beheaded is a pity." Among them, a certain person said, "That is the Sahyōe-no-Jō who, when he was at the place years ago, chased six robbers that the Great Watch Guards could not stop, all by himself, cut down four, and took two alive; that is when he was appointed. This is indeed what one calls a warrior worth a thousand." Because they all expressed regret, whatever the Lay Priest Prime Minister thought, he was exiled to Hino in Hōki. When it became the era of the Genji, he went down to the eastern provinces, attached himself to Kajiwara Heizō Kagetoki, and when he explained the root of the matter one by one, the Lord of Kamakura thought it divine and felt impressed, and it was rumored that he received favors in Noto Province.

[4.6.1] The Prince went north from Takakura, east from Konoe, crossed the Kamo River, and entered Mount Nyoi. Long ago, when the Emperor of Kiyomihara was still the Crown Prince, he was attacked by rebels and entered Mount Yoshino; it was then that he borrowed the guise of a maiden. Now, the condition of this Prince also did not differ from that in the slightest. Because he pushed through unknown mountain paths all night, for one unaccustomed to such things, the blood coming from his feet dyed the sand like crimson. The dew amidst the overgrown summer grass must also have felt overwhelming to him. Thus, at dawn, he entered Mii-dera. When he said, "In the regret of a worthless life, I rely on the monks and have entered here," the monks were awed and pleased, prepared the Hōrin-in as a palace, brought him in there, and prepared and served meals according to form.

[4.6.2] When day broke on the sixteenth, and it was said that the Takakura Prince had raised a rebellion and disappeared, the disturbance throughout the Capital was extraordinary. The Cloistered Emperor heard this and said, "Leaving the Toba Palace is the joy. And also the grief. When Yasuchika presented the divination report, this is what he spoke of."

[4.6.3] Now, regarding the Lay Priest of the Third Rank Minamoto, for years and days he had been as he was. If one asks with what intent he raised a rebellion this year, it is because the second son of the Heike, Former Major Captain of the Right Munemori-kyō, did something he should not have done; therefore, when a person is in the world, one must be very thoughtful about doing things one should not do and saying things one should not say even in jest.

[4.6.4] For example, the heir of the Lay Priest of the Third Rank Minamoto, Nakatsuna, possessed a famous horse known throughout the Nine-Fold Palace. It was a fawn-colored horse, an unparalleled masterpiece; its riding and galloping and temper were such that another could not be imagined. Its name was called "Konoshita" (Under the Tree). The Former Major Captain of the Right heard of this, sent a messenger to Nakatsuna, and said, "I wish to see the famous horse rumored of." In the reply of the Governor of Izu (Nakatsuna), he said, "I did possess such a horse, but because I rode it too much recently and injured it, thinking to rest it for a while, I sent it to the country." "If that is so, there is no helping it," [Munemori] said, and after that there was no order, but the Heike samurai who were sitting in large numbers said, "Alas, that horse was here until the day before yesterday; it was here yesterday too; it was ridden in the garden this morning." When they said this, [Munemori said], "Then he is begrudging it. Bad. Ask for it." He made samurai run, sent letters, and asked five or six times, seven or eight times in a single day; the Lay Priest of the Third Rank heard this, called the Governor of Izu, and said, "Even if it were a horse made of gold, is there any reason to begrudge what a person asks for to that extent? Send that horse to Rokuhara immediately." The Governor of Izu, powerless, wrote one poem along with it and sent it to Rokuhara.

lg.l: If you long for it, come and see it; how can I let go of the shadow attached to my body?

div.p: [4.6.5] Munemori-kyō did not make a reply to the poem, but said, "Ah, the horse, the horse is indeed a fine horse. However, since the owner begrudging it was hateful, brand the owner's name on it immediately." Making a brand saying "Nakatsuna," they stood it in the stable. When guests came and said, "We wish to see the famous horse rumored of," he would say, "Saddle that Nakatsuna. Ride Nakatsuna. Whip Nakatsuna, come on." Because he said such things, the Governor of Izu heard this and was greatly angered, saying, "Though it was a horse I thought of as my own life, if it were just taken due to authority, so be it; but to have Nakatsuna become the laughingstock of the realm because of a horse is not peaceful." The Lay Priest of the Third Rank heard this and facing the Governor of Izu said, "Underestimating what might happen, the people of the Heike speak such foolish things. If that is the case, what is the use of living? One should look for an opportunity." Thinking privately but not standing on his own, it was rumored later that he encouraged the Prince.

[4.6.6] In connection with this, the people of the realm remembered the Minister Komatsu (Shigemori) fondly. Once, when Lord Komatsu visited the Palace, and next went to the Empress's quarters, a snake about eight shaku long crawled around the left loop of the Minister's hakama trousers; thinking that if Shigemori made a fuss, the ladies-in-waiting would also make a fuss and the Empress would be startled, he held down the snake's tail with his left hand, took the neck with his right hand, pulled it into the sleeve of his court robe, and without making the slightest fuss, stood up and called, "Is there a Sixth Rank here? Is there a Sixth Rank here?" The Governor of Izu—was he still a Guard Chamberlain at that time?—named himself Nakatsuna and came forward, and Shigemori gave him this snake. Receiving it, he passed through the Archery Hall, went out to the small courtyard of the Privy Chamber, called a servant of the Treasury, and said, "Take this." The servant shook his head greatly and fled. Powerless, he summoned his own retainer, the Takiguchi guard Kiō, and gave it to him. He received it and threw it away. That morning, Lord Komatsu saddled a good horse and sent it to the Governor of Izu's place, saying, "Now, your behavior yesterday was indeed elegant. This is a first-class horse. Please use it when commuting to a lover's place from outside the guards' camp in the dead of night." Since it was a reply from the Minister, the Governor of Izu said, "I have reverently received your horse. Now, your behavior yesterday resembled the 'Returning to the Castle' dance." Why was Minister Komatsu so dignified, while Munemori-kyō was not so? Furthermore, asking for and taking a horse a person held dear and bringing about a crisis in the realm was indeed terrible.

[4.6.7] Entering the night of the sixteenth of the same month, the Lay Priest of the Third Rank Minamoto no Yorimasa, his heir the Governor of Izu Nakatsuna, his second son Minamoto no Tayū Hangan Kanetsuna, Rokujō Kurando Nakaie, his son Kurando Tarō Nakamitsu and others, a total force of over three hundred horsemen, set fire to their mansions, burned them down, and went to Mii-dera. Among the samurai of the Lay Priest of the Third Rank, there was a man called Watanabe Genzō Takiguchi Kiō. He was late and stayed behind; the Former Major Captain of the Right summoned Kiō and said, "Why did you stay and not accompany the Lay Priest of the Third Rank?" Kiō bowed and said, "Though I have always thought that if something happened, I would be the very first to offer my life, I wonder what he thought; he did not tell me anything." "Well then, do you intend to side with the enemy of the court, Yorimasa? Or since you are a man who serves here as well, do you intend to think of your future glory and serve this house? Speak the truth." Thus he spoke. Kiō shed tears profusely and said, "Though hereditary friendship is such a thing, how could I side with a person who has become an enemy of the court? I will serve in the Palace." When he said this, [Munemori said], "Then serve. It shall not be in the least inferior to the favors Yorimasa the Priest gave you." And he went inside.

[4.6.8] "Is Kiō there?" "I am here." "Is Kiō there?" "I am here." Thus he served from morning until evening. The sun gradually set, and the General came out. Kiō bowed and said, "It is true, I hear the Lay Priest of the Third Rank is at Mii-dera. Surely a punitive force will be directed there. It is not difficult. There are the monks of Mii-dera, and then my close comrades of the Watanabe clan. I should select and strike them, but the horse I had to ride to meet the matter was stolen by a close fellow. Could I be granted one horse?" The General said that was quite right, and gave him a white-dappled horse called "Nantei" which he treasured, saddled with a fine saddle. Kiō returned to his quarters and said, "Let the sun set quickly; I will whip this horse and race to Mii-dera, and die fighting at the very forefront of the Lay Priest of the Third Rank." As the sun gradually set, he made his wife and children hide here and there, and his heart as he set out for Mii-dera was indeed pitiable.

[4.6.9] Wearing a hunting robe with a flat crest and large chrysanthemum stitching, over which he wore ancestral red-laced armor, tightening the cords of a helmet with white stars, carrying a formidable looking great sword, bearing twenty-four large black-feathered arrows, and perhaps not forgetting the bone structure of a Takiguchi guard, he added one set of target arrows fletched with hawk feathers. Holding a lacquered rattan bow, he whipped Nantei, accompanied by one spare mount, had a servant carry his gear under his arm, set fire to his quarters burning them down, and raced to Mii-dera. At Rokuhara, saying that fire had broken out from Kiō's lodging, they made a clamor. Munemori-kyō hurriedly came out and asked, "Is Kiō there?" but they said, "He is not here." "Alas, I have been deceived by that fellow being so gentle. Chase him and kill him," he commanded, but Kiō was originally a superior strong archer, a skilled soldier with rapid fire, and a powerful man; with twenty-four arrows, he would kill the first twenty-four men. Saying "Make no sound," there was no one who faced him. At Mii-dera, just then there was talk of Kiō. The Watanabe party said, "We should have brought Kiō with us; remaining at Rokuhara, what terrible fate is he meeting?" The Lay Priest of the Third Rank knew his heart and said, "That man will surely not be captured or bound helplessly. He is a man deeply loyal to the Lay Priest (me); now watch. He will come right now." Before he finished speaking, Kiō arrived swiftly. "Just as I said," he declared. Kiō bowed and said, "In place of the Governor of Izu's 'Konoshita', I have taken Rokuhara's 'Nantei' and come. I present it to you." The Governor of Izu drove it inside the gate around midnight. When he put it in the stable and it bit at the other horses, the servants were startled and said, "Nantei has arrived." The General hurriedly came out to look and saw that it was branded "Formerly Nantei, Now Taira no Munemori Nyūdō." The General said, "Unforgivable. It is regrettable that I was deceived by Kiō's gentleness. This time when we attack Mii-dera, by all means capture Kiō first. I will cut off his head with a saw." Though he jumped up and down in anger, Nantei grew back his tail hair, and the brand also never disappeared.

div.head: 4.7. The Mt. Hiei Appeal

div.p: [4.7.1] At Mii-dera, conch shells and bells were rung, and the great assembly deliberated. "Considering the state of the world in recent days, the decline of the Buddha's Law and the imprisonment of the Imperial Law correspond exactly to this time. If we do not admonish the violent wickedness of the Lay Priest Kiyomori now, what day can we expect? The matter of the Prince's entry here, is it not the protection of the True Hachiman Shrine and the divine aid of the Shinra Great Deity? The heavenly host and earthly kin manifest themselves, and how could the Buddha-power and God-power not add their subjugation? Furthermore, the Northern Peak (Mt. Hiei) is the academic ground of the one-flavor Tendai sect, and the Southern Capital (Nara) is the ordination platform for gaining years of monkhood. If we send letters, why should they not join us?" Deliberating with one mind and one heart, they sent letters to the Mountain and to Nara. First, the letter to the Mountain Gate said:

div.div:
Onjō-ji (Mii-dera) sends this to the office of Enryaku-ji.
Specifically, a letter thinking that you might offer cooperation and help save this temple from destruction. Right: The Lay Priest Jōkai (Kiyomori) selfishly destroys the Imperial Law and wishes to destroy the Buddha's Law. In a place of extreme grief, on the night of the fifteenth, the Second Prince of the Cloistered Emperor secretly entered this temple. Here, designating it an Imperial Command, although there was a demand to hand him over, we could not hand him over. Therefore, there is a rumor that government troops will be dispatched. The destruction of this temple corresponds exactly to this time. Why should the various monks not grieve? Especially, Enryaku-ji and Onjō-ji, though divided into two lineages, what we study is the same teaching of the Perfect and Sudden One Vehicle. For example, it is like the left and right wings of a bird. Also, it resembles the two wheels of a cart. If one side is lacking, how could there not be grief? If so, specifically offering cooperation, if you save this temple from destruction, we shall quickly forget the grudges of years past and return to the old days of dwelling on the mountain. The deliberation of the assembly is like this. Thus, the letter is sent as above.

div.p: [4.7.2] Jishō 4th Year, 5th Month, 18th Day. The Great Assembly, etc.
[4.7.3] Thus it was written.

div.head: 4.8. The Southern Capital Appeal

div.p: [4.8.1] The monks of the Mountain Gate opened and viewed this letter, and said, "What is this? While being a branch temple of this mountain, the clause writing that they are like the left and right wings of a bird, or resemble the two wheels of a cart, is outrageous." And so, they did not send a reply. Moreover, since the Lay Priest Prime Minister commanded the Tendai Abbot, Great Sōjō Meiun, that the monks should be quieted, the Abbot hurriedly ascended the mountain and quieted the great assembly. While this was happening, they reported to the Prince that the situation was uncertain. Also, the Lay Priest Prime Minister donated twenty thousand koku of Ōmi rice and three thousand bolts of Orinobe silk from the northern provinces. As these were being pulled up to the valleys and peaks, since it was a sudden matter, there were monks who took great amounts all by themselves. Also, there were monks who came up empty-handed and took not a single thing. Wondering whose doing it was, someone wrote a satirical graffiti.

lg.l: The Orinobe robes of the Mountain Priests are thin; indeed, they could not hide their shame.

div.p: [4.8.2] Also, perhaps a monk who did not get any silk composed this:

lg.l: Even we, who did not obtain a single scrap of Orinobe, enter [the mountain] without hiding our slight shame.

div.p: [4.8.3] Also, the letter to the Southern Capital (Nara) said:

div.div: Onjō-ji sends this to the office of Kōfuku-ji. Specifically, a letter asking that you might offer cooperation and help save this temple from destruction. Right: The excellence of the Buddha's Law is for the sake of protecting the Imperial Law; the longevity of the Imperial Law, in turn, depends on the Buddha's Law. Here, the Lay Priest Former Chancellor Taira no Ason Kiyomori, Dharma name Jōkai, selfishly steals the prestige of the state, disorders the government of the court, and creates grudges and grief both internally and externally; meanwhile, on the night of the fifteenth of this month, the Second Prince of the Cloistered Emperor, in order to escape an unforeseen calamity, suddenly entered this temple. Here, although there was a demand saying it was an Imperial Command to hand him over, the monks entirely regret this. Therefore, that Zenmon (Kiyomori) intends to send warriors into this temple. Whether one speaks of Buddha's Law or Imperial Law, both are about to be destroyed at once. Long ago when the Emperor Wuzong of Tang caused the destruction of the Buddha's Law with military soldiers, the monks of Mt. Qingliang fought battles and defended against this. Even Royal Authority is like this. How much more so regarding a fellow of rebellion and the eight treasons? Especially, the Southern Capital has had, without precedent, its innocent head monks exiled. If not this time, on what day shall we accomplish revenge? We pray that if the monks internally help prevent the destruction of the Buddha's Law and externally drive away the companions of treason, it would be the utmost of unity and would satisfy our long-held desires. The deliberation of the assembly is like this. Thus, the letter is sent as above.

div.p: [4.8.4] Jishō 4th Year, 5th Month, 18th Day. The Great Assembly, etc.
[4.8.5] Thus it was written.
[4.8.6] The Great Assembly of the Southern Capital opened and viewed this letter, and immediately sent a reply. That reply said:

div.div: Kōfuku-ji sends this to the office of Onjō-ji. The contents were contained in one sheet of the incoming letter. Right: Regarding the matter that for the sake of the Lay Priest Jōkai, the Buddha's Law of your temple is about to be destroyed. The letter states: Although Gyokusen and Gyokuka establish the doctrines of two houses, the golden texts and golden phrases come from the teachings of the same lifetime. Both the Southern Capital and Northern Capital are disciples of the Tathagata. Whether one's own temple or another temple, we must mutually subdue the demonic hindrances of Devadatta. Now, the Lay Priest Kiyomori is the dregs of the Taira clan, the dust of the warrior houses. His grandfather Masamori served in a house of the Fifth Rank Chamberlain, and took the whip of a Governor of various provinces. In the old days when Lord Treasurer Tamefusa was Governor of Kaga, he was appointed to the Kebiishi (Police Commissioner); in the old days when Master of Repairs Aquisue was Governor of Harima, he was appointed to the post of Stable Master. However, when his real father Tadamori was permitted access to the Hall, the old and young of the Capital and country all regretted the flaw in the Imperial Court, and the glory of inside and outside lamented the prophecy of Mt. Ma. Though Tadamori preened his wings for the blue clouds, the people of the world still despised the seed of a white (common) house. Young samurai who value their name did not aspire to that house. However, since the first year of Heiji, in the twelfth month, when the Retired Emperor, feeling the merit of a single battle, conferred unmatched rewards, he has since climbed high to the Prime Ministership, and additionally been granted military escort. His sons disgrace the court ranks, or are listed in the Palace Guards. His daughters fill the post of Empress, or receive the decree of Jusangū. His flock of brothers and bastard children all walk the thorny path, and his grandsons and nephews all divide the bamboo tallies (governorships). In addition, he controls the Nine Provinces, advances or retreats the hundred officials, and treats them all like slaves and servants. If one hair differs from his mind, he imprisons them even if they are royalty; if a single word goes against his ear, he binds them even if they are high nobles. Because of this, wishing to prolong their lives for a moment, or thinking to escape insult for a short time, the Sacred Lord of Ten Thousand Chariots makes a face of flattery, and the Lords of hereditary houses conversely perform the courtesy of walking on their knees. Though he steals the hereditary domains of generations, Imperial Judgment fears him and rolls up its tongue; though he takes the manors inherited by the Palaces, fearing his authority, they say nothing. Riding too much upon his victory, in the eleventh month of last year's winter, he seized the residence of the Retired Emperor and exiled the Lord Regent. The excess of his treason is truly unprecedented in ancient and modern times. At that time, we should have by all means marched against the rebel host and questioned their crimes, but hesitating due to divine will, or because they called it an Imperial Order, we suppressed our gloom and passed the time; meanwhile, he has again raised military troops and surrounded the palace of the Second Prince of the Cloistered Emperor; at this point, the Hachiman Shrine, Kasuga Great Deity, secretly manifesting themselves, have lifted up the Imperial Palanquin, sent him to your temple, and entrusted him to the doors of Shinra. It is clear that the Imperial Law should not be exhausted. Consequently, the fact that your temple risks its life to protect him—who among sentient beings would not rejoice? We, being in a distant region, were feeling this sentiment, when we faintly heard the rumor that the Lay Priest Kiyomori, still raising his mad temper, intends to enter your temple; thus we were making preparations. On the 18th, at one point in the hour of the Dragon (8 AM), we roused the great assembly, sent letters to various temples, issued orders to branch temples, and after obtaining soldiers, we intended to send a guide, when a blue bird flew in and dropped your fragrant letter. The gloom of many days has dissolved at once. Even the monks of that one mountain of Qingliang in the Tang house turned back the government troops of Wuzong. How much more so the monks of the two gates of North and South in Japan—why should we not sweep away the wicked kind of scheming subjects? Solidify well the left and right camps of the Liang Garden; you should wait for the announcement of our advance. Observe the situation, and do not harbor doubts. Thus we send this letter.

div.p: [4.8.7] Jishō 4th Year, 5th Month, 21st Day. The Great Assembly, etc.
[4.8.8] Thus it was written.

[4.9.1] At Mii-dera, the great assembly rose again and deliberated. The Mountain Gate has changed its mind; the Southern Capital has not yet arrived. It would be bad to delay this matter. "Let us press upon Rokuhara and make a night attack. If we do that, divide the old and young into two groups; the old monks should head for the rear gate from Mt. Nyoi. If we send four or five hundred foot soldiers ahead to set fire to the houses in Shirakawa and burn them, the people in the Capital and the warriors of Rokuhara will say, 'Alas, a matter has arisen,' and rush toward it. At that time, setting fires here and there at Iwasaka and Sakuramoto, while holding them off and fighting for a while, the main force, with the Governor of Izu as Great General, and the warrior monks pressing upon Rokuhara, setting fire from upwind and attacking in one crush—how could the Lay Priest Prime Minister not be flushed out and killed?" Thus they deliberated.

[4.9.2] Among them, Ichinyobō Ajari Shinkai, who prayed for the Heike, led dozens of disciples and fellow lodgers, stepped forward into the deliberating garden, and said, "If I speak like this, you may think I am a partisan of the Heike. Let that be as it may. How can we break the principles of the monks and risk the name of our temple? Long ago, Genji and Heike contended left and right and were the guardians of the Imperial House, but recently the fortune of the Genji has declined, the Heike have taken the world for over twenty years, and there are no plants or trees in the realm that do not bow to them. The condition of their private mansions is such that they cannot be easily taken by a small force. You should plan your strategy well externally, mobilize forces, and attack on a later day." Thus, in order to delay the time, he deliberated at great length.

[4.9.3] Here, there was an old monk called Jōenbō Ajari Keishū. Wearing belly armor under his robes, carrying a large sword in his apron, wrapping his head, and leaning on a white-handled great halberd as a staff, he stepped forward into the deliberating garden and said, "One should not cite evidence from outside. When the founder of our temple, Emperor Tenmu, was still the Crown Prince, fearing Prince Ōtomo, he left the depths of Yoshino and passed through Uda District in Yamato Province with a force of only seventeen horsemen; nevertheless, crossing over to Iga and Ise, using the forces of Mino and Owari, he destroyed Prince Ōtomo and finally ascended the throne. There is a text that says, 'A bird in straits enters the bosom; humanity pities this.' I do not know about others, but as for the disciples of Keishū, press upon Rokuhara tonight and die fighting!" Thus he deliberated. Enman-in no Tayū Minamoto no Kaku stepped forward and said, "The deliberation is too much; the night is deepening, hurry and advance!"

[4.10.1] For the old monks heading for the rear gate, the Great General was the Lay Priest of the Third Rank Minamoto no Yorimasa; Jōenbō Ajari Keishū, Risseibō Ajari Nichiin, Sotsu Hōin Zenchi, Zenchi's disciple Gihō, and Zen'ei headed the group; in total, a force of one thousand men, holding pine torches in their hands, headed for Mt. Nyoi. For the main force, the Great Generals were the heir Governor of Izu Nakatsuna, the second son Minamoto no Tayū Hangan Kanetsuna, Rokujō Kurando Nakaie, his son Kurando Tarō Nakamitsu; among the monks, Enman-in no Tayū Minamoto no Kaku, Jōki-in no Ara-Tosa, Risseibō Iga-no-Kimi, Hōrin-in no Oni-Sado; these were warriors worth a thousand men, said to be able to meet demons or gods with their physical strength and skill with bow and arrow and weapons. From Byōdō-in, Inabarissha Ara-Dayū, Sumi-Rokurōbō, Shima Ajari, Tsutsui Hōshi, Gō Ajari, Aku-Shōnagon; from the North Cloister, the Six Tengu of Konkō-in: Shikibu-no-Tayū, Noto, Kaga, Sado, Bingo, etc. Matsui Higo, Shōnan-in Chikugo, Kaya Chikuzen, Ōya Toshinaga, Gochi-in Tajima; among the sixty room-mates of Jōenbō Ajari Keishū, Kaga Mitsunori, Gyōbu Toshihide; at Hōshihara, no one surpassed Ichirai Hōshi. Among the hall monks, Tsutsui Jōmyō Meishū, Ogozongetsu, Son'ei, Jikei, Rakujū, Tekken Gen'ei; among the samurai, led by the Watanabe clan—Habuku, Harima Jirō, Sazuku, Satsuma Hyōe, Chōshichi Tonau, Kiō Takiguchi, Atae Umanojō, Tsuzuku Genta, Kiyoshi, Susumu—a total force of over one thousand five hundred men set out from Mii-dera.

[4.10.2] After the Prince had entered, they dug moats at the Great Barrier and Small Barrier, set up abatis, bridged the moats, and removed the abatis, and while doing this, time passed, and the cocks on the barrier road were crowing together. The Governor of Izu said, "With the birds crowing here, we will be attacking Rokuhara in broad daylight. What shall we do?" Enman-in no Tayū Minamoto no Kaku again stepped forward as before and deliberated: "Long ago, in the time of King Zhaoxiang of Qin, when Lord Mengchang was imprisoned, with the help of the Queen, he escaped with three thousand soldiers and reached the Hangu Pass. Unless the roosters crowed, the gate of the pass would not open. Among Lord Mengchang's three thousand guests, there was a soldier called Tenkatsu. He was skilled at imitating the crow of a rooster, so he was called Keimei (Rooster Crow). That Keimei ran up to a high place and imitated a rooster's crow, so the roosters on the barrier road heard it and all crowed. At that time, the guard of the barrier was fooled by the false sound of the bird, opened the gate of the barrier, and let them pass. This too may be the crowing of an enemy stratagem; just attack!" Thus he spoke. While this was happening, the short night of the fifth month faintly dawned. The Governor of Izu proclaimed, "I thought 'even so' regarding a night attack, but a day battle will not do at all. Call them back." So the rear guard was called back from Mt. Nyoi. The main force turned back from Matsuzaka. The young monks said, "The night has dawned because of Ichinyobō Ajari's long deliberation. Attack and cut down his quarters!" And they slashed his quarters to pieces. Dozens of disciples and fellow lodgers who defended it were killed. Ichinyobō Ajari crawled to Rokuhara, shedding tears from his old eyes, and appealed this situation, but at Rokuhara, tens of thousands of military troops had gathered, and there was no commotion.

[4.10.3] At dawn on the twenty-third of the same month, thinking that this temple alone would not suffice, Mt. Hiei had changed its mind, and the Southern Capital had not yet arrived; thinking it would be bad if it became a later date, the Prince left Mii-dera and entered the Southern Capital (Nara). This Prince possessed two bamboo flutes known as Semiori and Koeda. Regarding that Semiori (Cicada Break), long ago in the time of Retired Emperor Toba, he sent one thousand ryō of gold to the Emperor of the Song Dynasty; thinking it a return gift, he sent a single joint of bamboo flute with nodes like a living cicada. Thinking, "How can I casually cut such a heavy treasure?" he ordered the Great Priest of Mii-dera, Kakusō, to stand on the altar and perform incantations for seven days, and it was a flute carved [after that]. Once, when Takamatsu Chūnagon Sanehira-kyō visited and played this flute, he forgot himself as if it were an ordinary flute and placed it below his knee; perhaps the flute admonished him, for at that time it broke like a cicada. Thus it was named Semiori. Because of the flute's capacity, it was transmitted to this Prince. However, perhaps thinking this was the end, he left it with the Miroku of the Golden Hall. Thinking it was for the sake of meeting at the dawn of the Dragon Flower (Maitreya's coming), it was a pitiable matter.

[4.10.4] He gave leave to all the old monks and made them stay behind. The young monks and warrior monks who were fit came along. Led by the group of the Lay Priest of the Third Rank Minamoto, the force was rumored to be one thousand men. Jōenbō Ajari Keishū, clinging to a pigeon-headed staff, came before the Prince, shedding tears profusely from his old eyes, and said, "I would serve you anywhere, but my age has already reached eighty, and walking is difficult. I will send my disciple Gyōbubō Toshihide. This is the son of the resident of Sagami Province, Yamauchi Sudō Gyōbu-no-Jō Toshimichi, who served in the band of the late Captain of the Left Stables Yoshitomo during the Heiji Battle years ago and died fighting at the Rokujō riverbed. Because we have some connection, I have raised him in my bosom, and I know the bottom of his heart well. Please take him with you anywhere." And suppressing his tears, he stayed behind. The Prince also thought it moving, wondering for what karma he spoke thus, and could not hold back his tears.

[4.11.1] Between Uji and the temple, the Prince fell from his horse six times. Saying this was because he had not slept the previous night, they removed three bays (approx. 6 meters) of the Uji Bridge, brought him into the Byōdō-in, and let him rest for a while. At Rokuhara, saying "There, the Prince is fleeing to the Southern Capital. Chase and kill him," the Great Generals were Sahyōe-no-Kami Tomomori, Tō-no-Chūjō Shigehira, Sama-no-Kami Yukimori, Satsuma-no-Kami Tadanori; the Samurai Generals were Kazusa-no-Kami Tadakiyo, his son Kazusa Tarō Hangan Tadatsuna, Hida-no-Kami Kageie, his son Hida Tarō Hangan Kagekata, Takahashi Hangan Nagatsuna, Kawachi Hangan Hidekuni, Musashi Saburō Saemon-no-Jō Arikuni, Etchū Jirō Hyōe-no-Jō Moritsugu, Kazusa Gorō Hyōe Tadamitsu, led by Aku-Shichibyōe Kagekiyo; in total, a force of over twenty-eight thousand horsemen crossed Mt. Kowata and pressed upon the end of the Uji Bridge. Seeing the enemy in the Byōdō-in, they made war cries three times; on the Prince's side, they also joined their voices in war cries. The vanguard shouted, "They have pulled up the bridge, do not cross!" but the rearguard did not hear this, and while advancing to be first, over two hundred horsemen of the vanguard were pushed off, drowned in the water, and floated away. They stood at both ends of the bridge and exchanged arrows.

[4.11.2] On the Prince's side, the arrows shot by Ōya Toshinaga, Gochi-in Tajima, Watanabe Habuku, Sazuku, and Tsuzuku Genta pierced through without being stopped by armor or shields. The Lay Priest of the Third Rank Minamoto wore a hitatare (robe) under armor of raw silk, and armor with fern-patterned leather lacing. Perhaps thinking this day would be his last. He intentionally did not wear a helmet. His heir, the Governor of Izu Nakatsuna, wore a hitatare of red brocade and armor with black thread lacing. Intending to draw his bow strongly, he also did not wear a helmet. Here, Gochi-in Tajima removed the sheath of a large halberd and advanced alone onto the bridge. The Heike side saw this and saying, "Shoot him down, men," the skilled archers lined up their arrowheads, nocked and pulled, and shot furiously. Tajima was not the least bit flustered; he ducked under the high arrows, leaped over the low arrows, and cut down the arrows coming straight at him with his halberd. Enemy and ally alike watched. From that time on, he was called "Arrow-cutting Tajima."

[4.11.3] Among the hall monks, Tsutsui no Jōmyō Meishū wore a coarse brown hitatare, armor with black leather lacing, tightened the cords of a five-plate helmet, carried a black-lacquered sword, bore twenty-four arrows with black horo feathers, held a lacquered rattan bow, and taking a favorite white-handled large halberd, advanced onto the bridge. Raising a great voice, he named himself: "In days past you have heard of me by rumor; now look with your eyes. At Mii-dera, I am not hidden. Among the hall monks, I am Tsutsui Jōmyō Meishū, a warrior worth a thousand. Those who think themselves worthy, come forward, let us meet." And he shot the twenty-four arrows he carried furiously, nocking and pulling rapidly. Instantly shooting twelve men to death and wounding eleven, one arrow remained in his quiver. He threw away his bow with a clatter, and untied and threw away his quiver too. Taking off his fur boots and becoming barefoot, he ran across the bridge beam with a patter. Although people feared it and did not cross, to Jōmyō-bō's feeling, he behaved as if on the great avenues of Ichijō or Nijō. With his halberd he mowed down five enemies facing him; meeting a sixth enemy, his halberd broke in the middle and he threw it away. After that he drew his sword and fought; the enemy was a great force, but he cut in spider, square, cross, dragonfly-return, and water-wheel patterns, leaving no opening in eight directions. Instantly cutting down eight men, he struck the helmet bowl of the ninth enemy too hard, and the sword broke at the rivet with a snap; throwing it away, he pulled out a dagger and plunged into the river with a splash. Relying on his waist sword (dagger), he fought madly as if intending only to die.

[4.11.4] Here, there was a powerful and agile man called Ichirai Hōshi, whom Jōenbō Ajari Keishū employed. He fought following behind, but the beam was narrow, and there was no way to pass by the side. Placing a hand on the brim of Jōmyō-bō's helmet, saying "Pardon me, Jōmyō-bō," he leaped over his shoulder and fought. Ichirai Hōshi died fighting. Jōmyō-bō crawled back, stripped off his armor on the grass in front of the gate of Byōdō-in, and when he counted the arrow marks standing on his armor, there were sixty-three; there were five places where arrows had scratched the lining, but as they were not serious wounds, he treated them with moxa here and there, wrapped his head, put on a pure white robe, cut his bow to use as a staff, put on flat sandals, and chanting Amida Buddha, he went toward Nara.

[4.11.5] Taking Jōmyō-bō's crossing as a model, the monks of Mii-dera and the Watanabe party ran continuously, saying "Me too, me too," and crossed the beam. Some took heads and returned; some were wounded severely, cut their bellies, and jumped into the river; the battle on the bridge was fought until fire came out. Seeing this, the Heike Samurai General Kazusa-no-Kami Tadakiyo went before the Great General and said, "Look there. The battle on the bridge is fierce. We should cross the river now, but it is the season of the fifth month rains, and the water has risen. If we cross, many horses and men will be lost. Should we head for Yodo or Imoarai? Or should we go via the Kawachi road?" While he was saying this, a resident of Shimotsuke Province, Ashikaga Matatarō Tadatsuna, stepped forward and said, "Regarding Yodo, Imoarai, and the Kawachi road, are you going to summon warriors from India or China to send there? We ourselves shall head there. If we enter the Southern Capital without killing the enemy before our eyes, the forces of Yoshino and Totsukawa will race to gather, and it will become an even greater crisis. On the border of Musashi and Kōzuke, there is a great river called the Tone River. The Chichibu and Ashikaga clans were at odds and constantly fought; the main force attacked from the Nagai Crossing, and the rear force from the Koga-Sugi Crossing; here, the resident of Kōzuke Province, Nitta Nyūdō, was persuaded by the Ashikaga, and intending to attack from the Sugi Crossing, when all the prepared boats were destroyed by the Chichibu side, he said, 'If we do not cross here right now, it will be a lasting flaw on our bow and arrow (reputation). If we drown in the water and die, let us die; come, let us cross!' and making horse rafts, they crossed. As is the custom of Bandō warriors, facing an enemy, in a battle separated by a river, is there such a thing as disliking the depths or shallows? The depth and swiftness of this river surely do not differ much from the Tone River. Follow me, men!" So saying, he plunged in first of all. The men who followed—Ōgo, Ōmuro, Fukasu, Yamagami, Nawa Tarō, Sanuki Hirotsuna Shirō Dayū, Onodera Zenji Tarō, Heyako Shirō; and among the retainers Ubukata Jirō, Kiryū Rokurō, Tanaka Sōta leading the way—over three hundred horsemen followed. Ashikaga raised a great voice and commanded: "Place the strong horses upstream and the weak horses downstream. As long as the horses' feet can reach, give them the reins and walk them. If they bounce (lose footing), manipulate them and make them swim. Have the people on foot hold on to the tips of the bows. Link hands, align shoulders, and cross. Sit firmly in the saddle basin and tread strongly on the stirrups. If the horse's head sinks, pull it up. Do not pull too hard and make it fall over. If water pools [downstream], ride onto the back of a third horse. Be weak with the horse, but strong against the water. Do not draw bows in the river. Even if the enemy shoots, do not shoot back. Always tilt your neck-plates. Do not tilt too much and let them shoot the crown of your helmet. Cross diagonally and do not be pushed down. Bend to the water and cross, cross!" Directing them thus, the three hundred and more horsemen, without losing a single mount, crossed swiftly to the opposite bank.

[4.12.1] Ashikaga wore a hitatare of withered-leaf patterned silk, armor with red leather lacing, tightened the cords of a high-horned helmet, carried a sword with gold fittings, bore arrows with speckled feathers, held a lacquered rattan bow, rode a dappled gray horse with coin patterns, saddled with a gold-rimmed saddle depicting an owl on an oak tree. He stood up pressing on his stirrups, raised a great voice, and named himself: "Hear it by rumor from afar, see it with your eyes up close. I am the tenth generation from Tawara Tōta Hidesato, who long ago destroyed the enemy of the court Masakado and received a reward; the son of Ashikaga Tarō Toshitsuna, Matatarō Tadatsuna, seventeen years of age; for a person like me with no office and no rank to face the Prince and draw a bow and loose an arrow is a matter of no small fear of heaven, but the bow and arrow and the extent of divine favor are with the Heike. Those on the side of the Lay Priest of the Third Rank who think themselves worthy, come forward, let us meet!" And he attacked and entered inside the gate of Byōdō-in and fought.

[4.12.2] Seeing this, the Great General Sahyōe-no-Kami Tomomori commanded, "Cross, cross!" So the twenty-eight thousand horsemen all plunged in and crossed. Blocked by horses and people, the water of the Uji River, which was already fast, rose up. In the water that missed its course, anything that could not withstand it was washed away. Because the common soldiers crossed holding on downstream of the horses, there were many who did not get wet above the knees. Whatever happened, the government soldiers of Iga and Ise provinces had their horse-rafts broken, drowned in the water, and over six hundred horsemen were washed away. The sight of various colors of armor—green, scarlet-laced, red-laced—bobbing up and down, floating and sinking, was no different from the autumn evening on the Tatsuta River, when maple leaves of Mt. Kannabi, invited by the storm on the peak, hang on the weir and cannot flow. Among them, seeing three warriors wearing scarlet-laced armor caught in the fishing weirs and being washed by the waves, the Governor of Izu saw them and composed:

lg.l: The warriors of Ise all wear scarlet-laced armor; indeed, they are caught in the fishing weirs of Uji.

div.p: [4.12.3] These three were all residents of Ise Province. They were Kuroda-no-Go-Heishirō, Hino Jurō, and Otobe Yashichi. Among them, Hino Jurō was a veteran; he twisted the tip of his bow into a crevice in the rocks, climbed up, pulled up the other two men, and saved them, it was rumored. The great army all crossed, and entering inside the gate of Byōdō-in, they fought in turns. In this confusion, they sent the Prince ahead toward the Southern Capital, and the group of the Lay Priest of the Third Rank Minamoto remained and shot defensive arrows.

[4.12.4] The Lay Priest of the Third Rank, over seventy years old, fought; he was shot in the left knee and, suffering a severe wound, intended to commit suicide calmly; he retreated inside the gate of Byōdō-in, but the enemy swarmed upon him; his second son, Minamoto no Tayū Hangan Kanetsuna, wearing a hitatare of dark blue brocade and armor with Chinese twill lacing, riding a white-dappled horse, turned back again and again to fight defensively to let his father escape. An arrow shot by Kazusa Tarō Hangan struck Kanetsuna inside his helmet; while he was in pain, Kazusa-no-Kami's servant boy, a strong fellow called Jirōmaru, rode alongside him, grappled with him, and they fell with a thud. Minamoto no Tayū Hangan was severely wounded inside his helmet, but being known for great strength, he took the servant boy, pressed him down, and cut off his head; as he tried to stand up, fourteen or five horsemen of the Heike fell upon him in a pile and killed Kanetsuna. The Governor of Izu Nakatsuna also suffered many severe wounds and committed suicide at the Fishing Pavilion of Byōdō-in. Shimokōbe Tōsaburō Kiyochika took his head and threw it under the main floor. Rokujō Kurando Nakaie and his son Kurando Tarō Nakamitsu also fought furiously, took many heads, and finally died fighting. This Nakaie was the heir of the late Tatewaki Senjō Yoshikata. Being an orphan, the Lay Priest of the Third Rank made him his adopted son and treated him with pity; not changing their pledge of many days, it was indeed pitiable that they died in the same place. The Lay Priest of the Third Rank summoned Watanabe Chōshichi Tonau and said, "Cut off my head." But in the sadness of cutting off his master's living head, he shed tears profusely and said, "I cannot bring myself to do it. After you have committed suicide, I will receive it." "Truly," he said, and facing west, he loudly chanted the Ten Invocations; his final words were moving.

lg.l: Like a fossilized tree which never bore flowers, sad is the end of my life which bore no fruit.

div.p: [4.12.5] With this as his final word, he thrust the tip of his sword into his belly, pierced through to his face, and died. Although it was not a time to compose poems, since it was a path he had loved intensely since his youth, he did not forget it even at the moment of death. Tonau took the head, and weeping, tied it to a stone, slipped out through the enemy, and sank it in a deep part of the Uji River.

[4.12.6] The Heike samurai watched for Kiō Takiguchi, intending to capture him alive by any means, but Kiō realized this beforehand, fought furiously, suffered severe wounds, cut his belly, and died. Enman-in no Tayū Minamoto no Kaku perhaps thought that by now the Prince had escaped far away. Holding a great sword and great halberd in left and right hands, he broke through the enemy, jumped into the Uji River, and without discarding a single piece of gear, dove to the bottom of the water, reached the opposite bank, climbed up to a high place, raised a great voice saying, "How about that, gentlemen of the Heike, farewell for now!" and returned to Mii-dera.

[4.12.7] Hida-no-Kami Kageie was an old soldier, so [he thought] during this confusion, the Prince must be fleeing ahead to the Southern Capital; so, not engaging in battle, he whipped his stirrups with a force of over five hundred horsemen and chased after him. Just as he thought, the Prince was fleeing with about thirty horsemen; catching up to him in front of the Torii of Mt. Kōmyō, they shot like rain; though he did not know whose arrow it was, a single arrow struck the Prince in his left side; he fell from his horse and had his head taken. Seeing this, the attendants Oni-Sado, Ara-Tosa, Ara-Dayū, Richijōbō Iga-no-Kimi, Gyōbu Toshihide, the Six Tengu of Konkō-in, saying "For what should we value our lives?", shouted and screamed, and died fighting.

[4.12.8] Among them, the Prince's foster brother, Rokujō-no-Suke-no-Tayū Munenobu, seeing the enemy following and his horse weak, jumped into the pond of Niino, covered his face with duckweed, and while he crouched trembling, the enemy passed him by. After a while, among the soldiers returning noisily with four or five hundred horsemen, seeing a headless corpse wearing a pure white robe being carried on a shutter, he wondered who it was and looked; it was the Prince. The flute rumored to be Koeda, about which he had said "If I die, put this flute in my coffin," was still thrust in his waist. He thought he would run out and cling to it, but because he was afraid, he could not even do that. After the enemy had all returned, he climbed out of the pond, wrung out his wet clothes and put them on, and when he went up to the Capital weeping, there was no one who did not despise him.

[4.12.9] Meanwhile, the great assembly of the Southern Capital, over seven thousand men in full armor, came to welcome the Prince. The vanguard advanced to Konazu, and the rearguard was still trembling at the Nandaimon of Kōfuku-ji. Hearing that the Prince had already been killed in front of the Torii of Mt. Kōmyō, the monks were all powerless, suppressed their tears, and stopped. The fate of the Prince, who was killed without waiting for them for just another fifty chō, was indeed terrible.

[4.13.1] The heads of the Prince, the family of the Lay Priest of the Third Rank, and the monks of Mii-dera, totaling over five hundred, were pierced on the tips of swords and halberds, raised high, and as evening approached, the Heike men returned to Rokuhara. The soldiers' shouts of triumph were tremendous. To say it was terrifying would be an understatement. Among them, the head of the Lay Priest of the Third Rank Minamoto was not seen, as Chōshichi Tonau had taken it and sunk it in a deep part of the Uji River. The heads of his children were all found here and there. Among them, regarding the Prince's head, since there were no people who visited him in recent years, there was no one who knew him by sight. Thinking that the Chief of Medicine Sadanari, who had been summoned for medical treatment in previous years, would know him, he was summoned, but claiming illness, he did not come. A lady-in-waiting who had constantly served the Prince was sought out and brought to Rokuhara. Since she had been loved not shallowly and had borne his child and was most beloved, how could she fail to recognize him? Taking just one look, she pressed her sleeve to her face and shed tears; thus they knew it was the Prince's head.

[4.13.2] This Prince had many children by various mothers. By a lady-in-waiting called Sanmi-no-Tsubone, the daughter of the Governor of Iyo Morinori, who served Hachijō-in, there was a seven-year-old Young Prince and a five-year-old Princess. The Lay Priest Prime Minister spoke to Hachijō-in through his younger brother, Ike-Chūnagon Yorimori-kyō: "I hear there are many children of the Takakura Prince living there. I will not speak of the Princess, but please hand over the Young Prince immediately." In Hachijō-in's reply, she said, "At the dawn when such rumors arose, perhaps the wet nurse or someone, lacking heart, took him along and disappeared; he is not at this palace at all." Yorimori-kyō, powerless, reported this to the Lay Priest Prime Minister. "Why, if not at that palace, where would he be? If that is the case, soldiers shall go and search." Thus he proclaimed. This Chūnagon was married to the lady-in-waiting called Saishō-dono, Hachijō-in's wet nurse, so he constantly visited there and she had thought fondly of him for days, but since he came to speak of the matter of this Prince, she now felt him to be estranged, like a stranger. The Young Prince said to Hachijō-in, "Since it has come to such a serious matter, I surely will not escape in the end. Please send me out quickly." Hachijō-in shed tears profusely and said, "A child of seven or eight usually does not understand anything. Yet, feeling painful that a serious matter has arisen because of you, how pitiful it is that you speak in this way. Having become accustomed to a person of no consequence for these six or seven years, to see such a sad fate." She could not hold back her tears. Since Yorimori-kyō spoke repeatedly that the Prince should be handed over, Hachijō-in, powerless, finally sent the Prince out. Since this was a parting for this life, how regretful his mother, Sanmi-no-Tsubone, must have felt. Weeping, she dressed him in his robes, smoothed his hair, and as she sent him out, she thought it was only a dream. Starting with Hachijō-in, down to the ladies of the room and the servant girls, there was no one who did not shed tears and wring their sleeves.

[4.13.3] Yorimori-kyō received the Prince, put him in a carriage, and transferred him to Rokuhara. Former Major Captain of the Right Munemori-kyō looked at this Prince, sat before his father, the Lay Priest Prime Minister, and said, "Whatever the situation, looking at this Prince, I feel exceedingly pained. Bending the principles, please grant the life of this Prince to Munemori." The Lay Priest proclaimed, "Then make him take the tonsure immediately."
Munemori-kyō reported this to Hachijō-in, and Hachijō-in said, "There should be no other way; just do it quickly." So they made him a monk, fixed him in the Buddhist family, and made him a disciple of the Omuro of Ninna-ji. Later, the First Chief Abbot of Tōji, called Yasui-no-Miya Sōjō Dōson, was this Prince.

[4.14.1] Also, there was one child in Nara. His wet nurse's husband, Governor of Sanuki Shigehide, had him take the tonsure, took him along, and fled down to the northern provinces; when Kiso Yoshinaka went up to the Capital, intending to make him his Lord, he took him along, went up to the Capital, and had him perform his coming-of-age ceremony, so he was called Kiso's Prince. Also, he was called the Returned-to-Laity Prince. Later, since he lived at Noyori in the Saga area, he was called the Noyori Prince.

[4.14.2] Long ago, there was a physiognomist called Tsūjō. He said that regarding the Uji Lord and the Nijō Lord, the Regents of three reigns, both would live to eighty, and he was not mistaken. He said that the Sotsu-no-Uchi-Daijin had the physiognomy of exile, and he was not mistaken. Prince Shōtoku said that Emperor Sushun had the physiognomy of a violent death, and he was killed by Minister Umako. People who should be so are not necessarily professional physiognomists, but it was indeed admirable. Was this not a failure of Physiognomy Shōnagon? In the middle ages, Prince Kanema and Prince Tomohira, called the Former Nakatsukasa Prince and Later Nakatsukasa Prince, were both princes of wise kings and sage lords, but they did not ascend the throne. However, did they raise a rebellion? Also, the third son of Retired Emperor Go-Sanjō, Prince Sukehito, was superior in talent and learning, so when Retired Emperor Shirakawa was still Crown Prince, Go-Sanjō left a testament saying, "After your reign, make this Prince ascend the throne." However, whatever Retired Emperor Shirakawa thought, he finally did not let him ascend the throne; as a forced measure, he granted the surname of Genji to Prince Sukehito's son, raised him from no rank to Third Rank all at once, and immediately made him a Middle Captain. A first-generation Genji going from no rank to Third Rank, other than the son of Emperor Saga, Dainagon Sadamu-kyō of the Yōin, this is heard to be the first time. This is the matter of the Minister of the Left of Hanazono, Lord Arihito.

[4.14.3] During the rebellion of the Takakura Prince, rewards were given to the high monks who received the order for and performed the rituals of subjugation. The son of Former Major Captain of the Right Munemori-kyō, Chamberlain Kiyomune, was made Third Rank, so he was called the Third Rank Chamberlain. This year he was merely twelve years old. His father, the Lord, was a Captain of the Guards at this age. That one should suddenly rise to the High Nobles, other than the children of the Prime Minister/Regent, we have not yet heard of it. In the decree of appointment, it was written as a reward for pursuing Minamoto no Mochihito and the priest Yorimasa and his son. Minamoto no Mochihito referred to the Takakura Prince. To strike down a Prince of the legitimate Retired Emperor is bad enough, but to make him a commoner is truly appalling.

div.head: 4.15. The Nue

div.p: [4.15.1] Now, the Lay Priest of the Third Rank Minamoto no Yorimasa was the fifth generation from Settsu-no-Kami Yorimitsu, the grandson of Mikawa-no-Kami Yoritsuna, and the son of Hyōgo-no-Kami Nakamasa. At the time of the Hōgen Battle, though he was in the vanguard for the Imperial side, he did not receive any significant reward; also in the Heiji disturbance, though he abandoned his relatives and joined [the winning side], the rewards for this were sparse. Although he was the Guardian of the Palace Grounds for many years, he was not permitted access to the Courtiers' Hall. After he had advanced in years and his age declined, he composed one waka poem of grievance and was finally permitted access to the Hall.

lg.l: Unknown to others, the mountain guard of Ouchiyama watches the moon only from behind the trees.

div.p: [4.15.2] Due to this poem he was permitted access to the Hall, and stayed at Senior Fourth Rank Lower Grade for a while, but setting his heart on the Third Rank:

lg.l: A body with no means to climb (ascend rank), picks up chestnuts (Fourth Rank) under the tree, and passes through the world.

div.p: [4.15.3] And so he became Third Rank. Immediately taking the tonsure, he was called the Lay Priest of the Third Rank Minamoto; this year he became seventy-five. What is thought to be the greatest fame of this person's life is that during the reign of Emperor Konoe, around the Ninpei era, the Emperor was frequently frightened and terrified at night. They ordered high and noble monks with spiritual power to perform great and secret rituals, but they had no effect. The affliction occurred around the hour of the Ox; a clump of black clouds would come from the direction of the forest of Tō-Sanjō and cover the palace, and he would invariably be frightened. Because of this, the nobles held a deliberation. Long ago in the Kanji era, during the reign of Emperor Horikawa, similarly, the Emperor was frightened night after night. The General at that time, Yoshiie Ason, was serving on the main veranda of the Southern Hall; when the time of the affliction arrived, he plucked his bowstring three times and announced his name in a loud voice, "Former Governor of Mutsu, Minamoto no Yoshiie," and everyone's hair stood on end, and the affliction ceased. Therefore, following precedent, saying that a warrior should be ordered to guard, they chose from among the soldiers of the two houses of Genji and Heike, and it was rumored that this Yorimasa was selected. At this time he was still called Hyōgo-no-Kami. Yorimasa said, "From ancient times, the placement of warriors at the Imperial Court has been to drive away rebels and destroy those who disobey imperial commands. I have never heard of an order to deal with invisible shapeshifting things." Though he said this, since it was an Imperial Order, he responded to the summons and attended the palace. Yorimasa brought only one person, his trusted retainer, a resident of Tōtōmi Province named I no Hayata, making him carry arrows fletched with eagle feathers. He himself wore a double hunting robe, took two pointed arrows made with pheasant tails along with a lacquered rattan bow, and served on the main veranda of the Southern Hall. The reason Yorimasa held two arrows was because Masayori-kyō, who was then still a Minor Controller of the Left, had selected him saying, "The person to deal with the shapeshifter is Yorimasa"; so, if he missed the shapeshifter with the first arrow, he intended to shoot the neck bone of Controller Masayori with the second arrow. Not differing from what people had said for days, when the time of the affliction arrived, a clump of black clouds came from the direction of the forest of Tō-Sanjō and trailed over the palace. When Yorimasa looked up sharply, there was the shape of a strange thing in the clouds. He thought that if he missed this, he should not live in this world. Nevertheless, he took an arrow, nocked it, prayed in his heart "Namu Hachiman Daibosatsu," drew fully, and shot with a twang. He felt the hit, and it struck with a thud.
