He gave the archer's shout, "Got it!" I no Hayata rushed up, found the place where it fell, pressed it down, and pierced it nine times in succession. At that time, high and low lit fires in their hands and looked at it; the head was a monkey, the body a tanuki, the tail a snake, and the limbs were the shape of a tiger. Its crying voice resembled a nue bird. To say it was terrifying implies too little. The Emperor was exceedingly impressed and bestowed upon him a sword called "Lion King." The Minister of the Left of Uji received this and passed it down; as he descended about halfway down the steps of the hall to give it to Yorimasa, since it was around the tenth of the fourth month, a cuckoo called two or three times in the clouds as it passed. At that time, the Minister of the Left said:

lg.l: The cuckoo raises its name to the clouds (palace) indeed.

div.p: [4.15.4] Because he spoke thus, Yorimasa knelt on his right knee, spread his left sleeve, and looking slightly sideways at the moon, said:

lg.l: Leaving it to the setting of the bow-stretching moon (crescent moon).

div.p: [4.15.5] Replying thus, he received the sword and withdrew. "Not only is he unparalleled in taking up the bow and arrow, he also excels in the Way of Poetry." So saying, both Lord and subjects were impressed. Then, it was rumored that they put that shapeshifting thing into a hollow boat and floated it away.

[4.15.6] Long ago during the Ōho era, in the reign of Emperor Nijō, a monster bird called a nue cried in the palace and frequently troubled the Imperial heart. Following precedent, Yorimasa was summoned. Since it was the evening past the twentieth of the fifth month, the nue called only once and did not call a second time. It was a darkness where one could not see one's fingers, and the shape was not visible, so it was difficult to determine where to aim the arrow. Yorimasa first took a large whistling arrow, nocked it, and shot it up over the Palace where the voice of the nue had been. The nue was startled by the sound of the whistling arrow and fluttered in the sky for a moment. For the second arrow, he took a small whistling arrow, nocked it, shot it cutting through the air, and brought down the nue alongside the whistling arrow in front of him. The palace was in an uproar, the Emperor was extraordinarily impressed, and bestowed a robe upon him; at that time, the Minister of the Right of Ōimikado, Lord Kinyoshi, received it and passed it to Yorimasa, praising him: "Yang Youji of old shot a goose beyond the clouds; Yorimasa of today shot a nue in the rain."

lg.l: In the darkness of May, making the name known tonight.

div.p: [4.15.7] Because he addressed him thus, Yorimasa replied:

lg.l: Though I thought the twilight hour had passed.

div.p: [4.15.8] Replying thus, he hung the robe on his shoulder and withdrew. After that, he was granted Izu Province, his son Nakatsuna became a Governor, he himself became Third Rank, administering the Five Manors of Tanba and Tōgūgawa in Wakasa; for a person who should have lived thus, to raise a pointless rebellion, causing the loss of the Prince and the destruction of himself and his descendants is indeed terrible.

div.note: [_] [1] The kanji in our copy-text is New Nelson 6976 or Nelson 5357 (Nue).

div.p: [4.16.1] For days, the monks of the Mountain Gate had made disorderly appeals, but this time, intending peace, they made no sound. Mii-dera and the Southern Capital (Nara) either received the Prince or came to welcome the Prince. Therefore, they are enemies of the court. Thus, saying that Mii-dera and the Southern Capital should be attacked, on the twenty-seventh of the same fifth month, with the Lay Priest's fourth son, Tō-no-Chūjō Shigehira as Great General, and Satsuma-no-Kami Tadanori as Vice-General, a total force of over ten thousand horsemen set out for Onjō-ji (Mii-dera). At the temple too, they dug moats, set up shields, pulled up abatis, and waited. They exchanged arrows at the hour of the Hare (6 AM) and fought all day until dark. Over three hundred defenders, including monks and priests, were killed. It became a night battle, the darkness was pitch black, and the government troops invaded the temple and set fire to it. The places that burned were Hongaku-in, Jōki-in, Shinnyo-in, Hanazono-in, Fugendō, Taihō-in, Seiryu-in, the main quarters of Kyōtai Oshō, along with the principal images, the Great Lecture Hall of eight bays on four sides, the Bell Tower, the Sutra Repository, the Abhiseka Hall, the shrine altar of the Dharma-Protecting Benevolent Deities, the Treasure Hall of Imagumano; in total, six hundred and thirty-seven temple buildings and towers, one thousand eight hundred and fifty-three lay houses in Otsu, over seven thousand scrolls of all the scriptures transmitted by Chishō (Enchin), and over two thousand Buddhist statues instantly became smoke; it was indeed sad. The five wondrous musics of the heavens were exhausted forever at this time, and it seemed that the three heat sufferings of the Dragon Gods became all the more intense.

[4.16.2] Now, regarding Mii-dera, it was the private temple of the Great District Lord of Omi, Otomo no Yasu, who donated it to Emperor Tenmu, making it an Imperial Prayer Temple. The principal Buddha was the main deity of that Emperor; Kyōtai Oshō, rumored to be a living Maitreya, practiced there for one hundred and sixty years and entrusted it to the Great Master (Enchin). It is heard that he descended from the Mani Treasure Hall in the Tushita Heaven and waits in the distance for the dawn of the Dragon Flower Tree descent; how could such things happen? The Great Master made this place a sacred site for transmitting the Dharma Abhiseka (baptism), and because he scooped up the water of the well-flower, it was named Mii-dera (Three Wells Temple). Although it was such a magnificent sacred site, now it is nothing. The Exoteric and Esoteric doctrines were destroyed in an instant, and the temple complex has no trace left. Since there is no training hall for the Three Mysteries, the sound of bells is not heard. Since there are no flowers of the summer retreat, the sound of water offerings is not made. The famous masters, elders and virtues, are negligent in practice and learning, and the disciples who inherit the Dharma are separated from the sutras and teachings. The Chief Abbot of the temple, Cloistered Imperial Prince Enkei, was dismissed as Bettō of Tennō-ji. Besides him, thirteen high-ranking monks were stripped of their posts and all handed over to the Kebiishi (Police Commissioners). As for the warrior monks, down to Tsutsui Jōmyō Meishū, over thirty men were exiled. People said that such disturbance in the realm and commotion in the land did not seem like a trivial matter, but perhaps a portent that the era of the Heike had reached its end.

[5.1.1] On the third day of the sixth month of the fourth year of Jishō, the Capital was in an uproar, saying there would be an Imperial Procession to Fukuhara. Although it had been rumored for some days that there would be a relocation of the Capital, no one thought it would happen so suddenly, today or tomorrow, so high and low were in a commotion. Furthermore, although it had been decided for the third day, it was moved up one day, and took place on the second. At the hour of the Hare (6 AM) on the second, when the Imperial Palanquin for the procession was already brought forward, since His Majesty was three years old this year and still young, he was taken without understanding anything. When His Majesty travels while young, the Empress Mother usually rides in the same palanquin, but this time that was not the case. The wife of his wet nurse's husband, Taira no Dainagon Tokitada-kyō, known as Sotsu-no-Suke-dono, rode in the same palanquin. The Empress, the Cloistered Emperor, and the Retired Emperor proceeded. Starting with the Lord Regent, the Prime Minister, and the court nobles and courtiers below him, everyone vied to accompany them. On the third day, they entered Fukuhara. The residence of Ike-Chūnagon Yorimori-kyō became the Imperial Palace. On the fourth day, as a reward for Yorimori's house, he was promoted to Senior Second Rank. The son of Lord Kujō, Major Captain of the Right Yoshimichi-kyō, was passed over. It was rumored that this was the first time that a son of a Regent subject, a second son of a common man, was passed over in promotion of rank.

[5.1.2] Meanwhile, the Lay Priest Prime Minister gradually reconsidered regarding the Cloistered Emperor, let him leave the Toba Palace, and brought him into the Capital, but due to the rebellion of the Takakura Prince, he was again greatly angered; having him proceed to Fukuhara, he boarded up the four sides, made a wooden room of three bays with only one opening, and confined him; for the guarding warriors, only Harada no Tayū Tanenao served. Since there was no way for people to visit easily, the children called it the "Cage Palace." It was a matter ominous and terrifying even to hear. The Cloistered Emperor did not think in the slightest that he wished to govern the world now; he said he only wished to wander mountains and temples and console himself as he pleased. Generally, the evil deeds of the Heike had reached their limit. Since the past Angen era, they exiled or destroyed many nobles and courtiers, exiled the Regent, made his own son-in-law the Regent, moved the Cloistered Emperor to the Jonan Detached Palace, killed the second Prince, the Takakura Prince, and now since the relocation of the Capital was the only thing remaining, people said he must be doing this.

[5.1.3] Relocating the capital is not without precedent. Emperor Jimmu was the Emperor of the fifth generation of Earthly Deities, the fourth prince of Hikonagisatakeugayafukiaezu-no-Mikoto; his mother was Tamayori-hime, the daughter of the Sea God. Receiving the traces of twelve generations of the Age of Gods, he is the Imperial Ancestor of the hundred kings of the Human Age. In the Kanototori year, in Miyazaki District of Hyūga Province, he succeeded to the Imperial Throne, and in the tenth month of the Tsuchinoto-hitsuji year called the fifty-ninth year, he campaigned to the East, stayed in Toyoashihara-no-Nakatsukuni, selected Mount Unebi in what is now called Yamato Province, established the Imperial Capital, cleared the land of Kashihara, and built a palace. This was named the Palace of Kashihara. From then on, the Emperors of successive generations moved the capital to other provinces and other places more than thirty times, reaching forty times. For the twelve generations from Emperor Jimmu to Emperor Keikō, they established capitals in the districts of Yamato Province and never moved to other provinces. However, in the first year of Emperor Seimu, he moved to Ōmi Province and established the capital in Shiga District. In the second year of Emperor Chūai, he moved to Nagato Province and established the capital in Toyoura District. Since the Emperor passed away at that capital in that province, the Empress Jingū Kōgō took over the reign, and as a woman, she attacked and subjugated Kikai, Koryo, and Khitan. After pacifying the armies of foreign lands and returning to the court, a Prince was born in Mikasa District of Chikuzen Province; that place is called the Umi Palace. It is awe-inspiring to mention, but this is the matter of Hachiman. Upon ascending the throne, he was called Emperor Ōjin. After that, Empress Jingū moved to Yamato Province and resided at the Iware Wakazakura Palace. Emperor Ōjin lived at the Karushima Akira Palace in the same province. In the first year of Emperor Nintoku, he moved to Naniwa in Tsu Province and resided at the Takatsu Palace. In the second year of Emperor Richū, he moved to Yamato Province and established the capital in Tōchi District. In the first year of Emperor Hanzei, he moved to Kawachi Province and lived at the Shibagaki Palace. In the forty-second year of Emperor Ingyō, he moved again to Yamato Province and resided at the Asuka Palace. In the twenty-first year of Emperor Yūryaku, he resided at Hatsuse Asakura in the same province. In the fifth year of Emperor Keitai, he moved to Tsudzuki in Yamashiro Province, and in the twelfth year, later resided at Otokuni. In the first year of Emperor Senka, he returned again to Yamato Province and resided at the Hinokuma Iwareno Palace. In the first year of Taika of Emperor Kōtoku, he moved to Nagara in Settsu Province and lived at the Toyosaki Palace; in the second year of Emperor Saimei, he returned again to Yamato Province and resided at the Okamoto Palace. In the sixth year of Emperor Tenji, he moved to Ōmi Province and lived at the Ōtsu Palace; in the first year of Emperor Tenmu, he returned again to Yamato Province and lived at the South Palace of Okamoto. This was called the Emperor of Kiyomihara. The two holy reigns of Jitō and Monmu resided at the Fujiwara Palace in the same province. From Emperor Genmei to Emperor Kōnin, seven generations lived in the Capital of Nara. However, Emperor Kanmu, on the second day of the tenth month of the third year of Enryaku, moved from the village of Kasuga in the Capital of Nara to Nagaoka in Yamashiro Province; in the first month of the tenth year, he sent Dainagon Fujiwara no Oguromaro, Sangi Sadaiben Ki no Kosami, Daisōzu Genkei and others to inspect the village of Uda in Kadono District of this province; the two men reported together saying: "Looking at the form of this land, it is a land corresponding to the Four Gods: Blue Dragon on the left, White Tiger on the right, Red Vermilion Bird in front, and Black Tortoise in the rear. It is indeed sufficient to establish the Imperial Capital," they said. Therefore, reporting this to Kamo Daimyōjin in Otagi District, on the twenty-first day of the eleventh month of the thirteenth year of Enryaku, he moved from the Capital of Nagaoka to this Capital; since then, thirty-two generations of Emperors have welcomed and sent off the springs and autumns of over three hundred and eighty years. Saying that although successive Emperors since ancient times established many capitals in various provinces and places, there is no excellent land like this, Emperor Kanmu was especially attached to it; consulting with ministers, high nobles, and men of talent in various paths, saying it should be for a long duration, he made an eight-foot doll out of clay, dressed it in iron armor and helmet, gave it an iron bow and arrow, and buried it on a peak in Higashiyama facing west. He made a promise that if in future generations there should be an attempt to move this capital to another province, it would become a guardian deity. Therefore, when an incident is about to occur in the realm, this mound invariably shakes. It exists even now as the Shogun's Mound. Emperor Kanmu is the ancestor of the Heike. Above all, he named this capital Heian-jō (Castle of Peace and Tranquility) and wrote it as the Capital of Peace and Safety. It is a capital the Heike should especially revere. It is appalling that the capital to which the Ancestral Emperor was so attached is being moved to another province and another place without any compelling reason. In the time of Emperor Saga, when the Former Emperor Heizei disturbed the world upon the advice of the Naishi-no-Kami, he was about to move this capital to another province, but because the ministers, high nobles, and people of the provinces opposed it, it was not moved and stopped. It is terrifying that the Lay Priest Prime Minister, as a subject, moved the capital which even the Lord of the Whole Heaven, the Master of Ten Thousand Chariots, could not move.

[5.1.4] The Old Capital was indeed a deeply moving and magnificent capital. The guardian shrines protecting the Royal Castle softened their light in the four directions, the temples of superior spiritual efficacy lined their roof tiles high and low, the hundred names and ten thousand people were without trouble, and the Five Home Provinces and Seven Roads were convenient. However, now the intersections are all dug up, and carriages and such cannot easily pass. People going by chance ride in small carts and pass through by picking their way. The dwellings of people who vied for eaves-space become desolate as the days pass. Houses are broken down into the Kamo River and Katsura River, assembled into rafts and floated, goods and miscellaneous tools are loaded onto boats, and transported down to Fukuhara. It is sad that the Flowery Capital has simply become countryside. Wondering whose doing this was, two poems were written on a pillar of the Palace in the Old Capital.

lg.l: Having passed four cycles of one hundred years, will the village of Otagi (Kyoto) now fall into ruin?

lg.span: Abandoning the Flowery Capital that is blooming, the end of the wind-blown field (Fukuhara) is precarious indeed.

div.p: [5.1.5] On the ninth day of the same sixth month, saying that the ground-breaking for the New Capital should take place, the Senior Nobles were Tokudaiji Sadaijō Sanesada-kyō and Tsuchimikado Saishō Chūjō Michichika-kyō; the controlling official was Kurando Sashōben Yukitaka; taking officials along, they selected the field west of Wada no Matsubara and laid out the land for the Nine Avenues, but although there was space from First Avenue down to Fifth Avenue, there was none below Fifth Avenue. The administrative officials returned and reported this. Then there was a deliberation of high nobles asking if it should be Inamino in Harima or perhaps Koyano in Settsu, but it did not seem that the matter would proceed.

[5.1.6] The Old Capital has already been abandoned, the New Capital has not yet proceeded, and all the people feel as if they are floating clouds. Those who originally lived in this place grieve the loss of their land, and those moving now lament the trouble of construction. In general, these were things that seemed only like a dream. Tsuchimikado Saishō Chūjō Michichika-kyō said, "It is seen that in foreign lands, they opened a broad road of three lines and set up twelve gates. How much more so, in a capital that has up to Fifth Avenue, why should we not build a Palace? There was a council saying that a temporary village palace should be built, and the Lay Priest Prime Minister arranged that Gojō Dainagon Kunitsuna-kyō should be given Suō Province temporarily and make him build it. Since this Kunitsuna-kyō is a man of great wealth, there is no question he can build it, but how could there not be expense to the province and trouble to the people? Setting aside the pressing great matters, such as the Great Thanksgiving Festival which should be held, moving the capital and building a palace in such a chaotic world is not in the least appropriate. In the wise reigns of old, they thatched the palace with thorns and did not even trim the eaves; seeing that smoke was scarce, they remitted even the limited tribute. This is because they showed mercy to the people and helped the country. It is said that Chu built the Zhanghua Terrace and harassed the black-haired people, and Qin raised the Epang Palace and the realm was disordered. There were surely worlds where thatch was not trimmed, oak rafters were not planed, boats and carriages were not decorated, and clothes had no patterns." Therefore, people said that Tang Taizong built the Lishan Palace, but perhaps fearing the expense to the people, finally without visiting it, pines grew on the tiles and ivy flourished on the walls, and it was abandoned; there is a difference indeed.

[5.2.1] It was determined that the ground-breaking for the New Capital would be on the ninth of the sixth month, the roof-raising on the tenth of the eighth month, and the transfer of the Emperor on the thirteenth of the eleventh month. As the Old Capital falls into ruin, the present Capital flourishes. The wretched summer passed, and it had already become autumn. As autumn gradually reached its half, the people residing in the New Capital of Fukuhara, intending to view the moon at famous places, or longing for the traces of the Genji General (Prince Genji) of old, went along the coast from Suma to Akashi, crossed the strait of Awaji, and viewed the moon at the rocky shore of Ejima. Or there were people who composed poems on the dawn moon at Shirara, Fukiage, Wakanoura, Sumiyoshi, Naniwa, Takasago, and Onoe, and returned. People remaining in the Old Capital viewed the moon at Fushimi and Hirosawa.

[5.2.2] Among them, Tokudaiji Sadaijō Sanesada-kyō, longing for the moon of the Old Capital, went up from Fukuhara after the tenth of the eighth month. Everything had changed completely; at the houses rarely remaining, the grass was deep in front of the gates, and the dew was heavy on the grounds. Amidst thickets of mugwort and fields of cogon grass, dilapidated like the nests of birds, with the voices of insects lamenting, it had become a field of yellow chrysanthemums and purple asters. As a remnant of the old home, only the Great Palace at the Konoe riverbank remained. The Great General went to that palace, and first had his attendant knock on the main gate; a woman's voice from inside asked, "Who is it, at a place where there is no one to brush away the dew of the mugwort?" He blamed her, saying, "The Great General has come from Fukuhara." "The main gate is locked. Please enter from the small gate on the east side." Since she said this, the General said "Then so be it," and entered from the east gate. The Great Palace (Dowager Empress), in her boredom, must have been remembering the past; she had the lattice shutters on the south side opened and was playing the biwa; when the General arrived, she said, "How is this? Is it a dream or reality? Come in, come in."
In the Uji chapters of The Tale of Genji, the daughter of the Ubasoku Prince, regretting the fading of autumn, played the biwa and calmed her heart all night long; when the dawn moon appeared, perhaps unable to bear it, she beckoned it with her plectrum; now indeed this was understood.

[5.2.3] A lady-in-waiting called Matsuyoi no Kojijū (Waiting-Evening Little Chamberlain) also served at this palace. The reason this lady was called Matsuyoi was because once at the palace, there was an inquiry: "Which is more moving, the waiting evening or the returning morning?"

lg.l: When I hear the voice of the bell as the waiting evening deepens, the bird of the returning morning is nothing at all.

div.p: [5.2.4] Because she composed this, she was called Matsuyoi. The General called out that lady, and they talked of things past and present; as the night gradually deepened, he sang in the imayō style about the ruin of the old capital.

lg.span: Coming to look at the Old Capital, it has run wild as a field of cogon grass; the light of the moon is without shadow, and only the autumn wind pierces the body.

div.p: [5.2.5] Because he sang this clearly three times, starting with the Dowager Empress, the ladies-in-waiting throughout the palace all dampened their sleeves.

[5.2.6] Meanwhile, as day broke, the General took his leave and returned to Fukuhara. He summoned a Kurando (Chamberlain) who was in attendance and said, "Kojijū seemed exceedingly regretful of the parting; go back and say something to her." The Kurando ran back and said, "'Say something,' he commanded." And:

lg.l: Though you said "it is nothing," why is the sound of the bird this morning so sad?

div.p: [5.2.7] The lady, suppressing tears:

lg.span: If I were waiting, the deepening bell would be nothing; it is the sound of the bird of parting without satisfaction that is gloomy.

div.p:
[5.2.8] The Kurando returned and reported this, and the General was greatly impressed, saying, "That is why I sent you."
From that time on, he was called the "Monokawa" (It is nothing) Kurando.

[5.3.1] After the capital was moved to Fukuhara, the people of the Heike had bad dreams, were constantly agitated, and there were many shapeshifting things. One night, at the place where the Lay Priest was sleeping, a face large enough to fill a room appeared and peered at him. The Lay Priest Prime Minister was not the least bit flustered and glared at it fiercely, so it simply vanished. At the place called the Hill Palace, since it was newly built, there were no large trees that should be there, but one night there was the sound of a large tree falling, and voices like those of twenty or thirty people laughing loudly. Since this was considered the work of Tengu no matter how one looked at it, they established what was called the Whistling Arrow Watch; assembling a watch of one hundred men at night and fifty men by day, they had them shoot whistling arrows; when they shot facing the direction where the Tengu were, there was no sound, and when they shot facing the direction where they seemed not to be, there was laughter like "Ha!"

[5.3.2] Also, one morning the Lay Priest Prime Minister came out from his curtained dais, pushed open the double doors, and looked into the courtyard; dead people's skulls, number unknown, filled the garden; they moved up and down, rolled together and rolled apart; those on the edge rolled into the middle, and those in the middle came out to the edge. Because they rattled together tremendously, the Lay Priest Prime Minister called, "Is anyone there? Is anyone there?" but just then no one came. While this happened, the many skulls solidified into one, became large enough to fill the courtyard, and became like a mountain that seemed to be fourteen or fifteen jo (approx. 45 meters) high. In that single large head, thousands of eyes like the eyes of living people appeared, and they glared fiercely at the Lay Priest Prime Minister without blinking. The Lay Priest was not the least bit flustered. He stood and glared back fiercely. Because the large head was glared at too strongly, like frost or dew struck by the sun, it disappeared without a trace. Besides that, in the tail of a horse that was kept in the First Stable, attended by many servants, and groomed and fed without pause morning and evening, rats built a nest and gave birth to young in a single night. Thinking this was no ordinary matter, he had a Yin-Yang master divine it, and he said it was a grave portent requiring caution. This horse was presented to the Lay Priest Prime Minister by the resident of Sagami Province, Ōba Saburō Kagechika, as the best horse in the eight eastern provinces. It was a black horse with a white forehead. It was named Mochizuki (Full Moon). It was given to the Head of Yin-Yang Abe no Yasuchika. Long ago in the time of Emperor Tenji, rats built a nest and gave birth to young in the tail of a horse of the Bureau in a single night; it is seen in the Nihon Shoki that fierce rebels of a foreign land rose up in rebellion.

[5.3.3] Also, a dream seen by a young samurai serving at the place of Minamoto no Chūnagon Masayori-kyō was terrifying. In a place that seemed like the Jingikan (Department of Divinities) of the Imperial Palace, many high-ranking nobles in formal court dress were present, and there was something like a council; a person in the lowest seat, who seemed to be a partisan of the Heike, was driven out from among them. That young samurai, in the dream, asked an old man, "What kind of high nobles are those?" He answered, "Itsukushima Daimyōjin." After that, an elder looking noble on the seat of honor said, "The Sword of Command (setto) that has been entrusted to the Heike for these days shall now be given to the exile of Izu Province, Yoritomo." An elder who was still by his side said, "After that, please give it to my grandsons too." Seeing this dream where this was said, he asked about them in order. Seeing the dream where it was said: "The one who said 'Give the sword to Yoritomo' was Hachiman Daibosatsu; the one who said 'After that give it to my grandsons too' was Kasuga Daimyōjin; the old man who speaks thus is Takeuchi no Daimyōjin," he told this to people; eventually the Lay Priest Prime Minister heard of it, and sent Minamoto no Tayū Hangan Suesada to Masayori-kyō's place, ordering "Send the young samurai who saw the dream here immediately," so the young samurai who saw the dream fled instantly. Masayori-kyō hurriedly went to the Lay Priest Prime Minister's place and explained, "There is no such thing at all," so there was no further action. However, there was a strange thing: when Lord Kiyomori was still Governor of Aki, on the occasion of worshipping at the shrine, he received a divine dream and was given a small halberd with a silver wrapped handle by the Great Deity of Itsukushima in reality (upon waking); he never let it leave his usual pillow and displayed it, but it is strange that one night it suddenly disappeared. The Heike for days were the guardians of the Imperial House and protected the realm, but now that they disobey Imperial Commands, perhaps the Sword of Command is being recalled; it was heard with uneasiness. Among them, Saishō Nyūdō Nariyori who lived on Kōya, hearing these things transmitted, said, "Alas, the era of the Heike is finally becoming the end; there is a reason why it is said Itsukushima Daimyōjin sided with the Heike. However, since she is the third princess of the Dragon King Sagara, I hear she is a female deity. It is reasonable that Hachiman Daibosatsu said to give the Sword of Command to Yoritomo. I do not understand why Kasuga Daimyōjin said 'After that give it to my grandsons too.' Does that mean after the Heike are destroyed and the era of the Genji is exhausted, the descendants of the Great Weaver Crown (Kamatari), the lords of the Regent House, will become the Shoguns of the realm?" Thus he spoke. Also, a certain monk who came at that time said, "Generally, since deities manifest in various expedient means, sometimes they appear as lay bodies, sometimes they become female deities. Truly, although Itsukushima Daimyōjin is called a female deity, since she is a spiritual god of the Three Knowledges and Six Supernatural Powers, it should not be difficult for her to manifest in a lay body." Thus he spoke. Having detested the sad world and entered the true path, strictly speaking there should be no concern for worldly affairs other than enlightenment in the next life, but one is moved hearing of good government and grieves hearing of sorrow; this is all human custom.

[5.4.1] On the second day of the same ninth month, the resident of Sagami Province, Ōba Saburō Kagechika, reported to Fukuhara by fast horse: "On the past seventeenth of the eighth month, the exile of Izu Province, Former Sahyōe-no-Suke Yoritomo, sent his father-in-law Hōjō Shirō Tokimasa and attacked the Deputy of Izu, Izumi Hangan Kanetaka, in a night attack at the Yamaki mansion and killed him. After that, leading over three hundred horsemen starting with Doi, Tsuchiya, and Okazaki, he barricaded himself at Ishibashiyama; I, Kagechika, leading over one thousand horsemen who harbor loyalty to your side, pressed and attacked; Hyōe-no-Suke (Yoritomo) was reduced to seven or eight horsemen, fought disheveled, and fled into Sugiyama in Doi. After that, Hatakeyama served your side with over five hundred horsemen. The children of Miura Daisuke Yoshiaki, siding with the Genji with over three hundred horsemen, fought at the bay of Yui and Kotsubo; losing the battle to Hatakeyama, they retreated to Musashi Province. After that, the Hatakeyama clan, combining with Kawagoe, Inage, Oyamada, Edo, Kasai, and generally the other soldiers of the Seven Parties, totaling over three thousand horsemen, pressed upon the castle of Miura Kinugasa and attacked. Daisuke Yoshiaki was killed. His children all boarded boats from the bay of Kurihama and crossed to Awa and Kazusa." Thus he reported.

[5.4.2] The excitement of the Heike people for the capital relocation quickly cooled. The young nobles and courtiers said, "Ah, let the matter happen quickly; we will go as a punitive force." How fleeting. Hatakeyama Shōji Shigetada, Oyamada Bettō Arishige, and Utsunomiya Saemon Asatsuna were in the Capital at the time for Great Watch duty. Hatakeyama said, "It must be a mistake. Since they have become close relatives, I do not know about Hōjō. But surely the others would not side with an enemy of the court. We will hear the correction soon." While some said "Indeed," there were many who whispered, "No, no, right now it will become a great crisis in the realm." The Lay Priest Prime Minister's anger was extraordinary. "Yoritomo ought to have been executed already, but because the late Ike-dono (Zenni) pleaded strongly, I commuted it to exile. However, forgetting that favor, it seems he draws a bow against this house. How could the Gods and the Three Treasures forgive him? Yoritomo will receive the punishment of Heaven right now." Thus he proclaimed.

[5.5.1] Now, seeking the beginning of enemies of the court in our country, in the fourth year of the reign of Emperor Jimmu (Nihon Iwarehiko no Mikoto), in Takao village, Nagusa District, Kii Province, there was a spider; its body was short, its legs and arms long, and its strength surpassed that of men. Because it harmed many people, government troops were dispatched, read an Imperial Decree to it, tied nets of vines, and finally covered and killed it. Since then, those who harbored ambition and tried to destroy Imperial prestige include: Ōishi no Yamamaru, Prince Ōyama, Minister Moriya, Yamada no Ishikawa, Soga no Iruka, Ōtomo no Matori, Bunya no Miyata, Tachibana no Hayanari, Hikami no Kawatsugu, Prince Iyo, Dazai Shōni Fujiwara no Hirotsugu, Emi no Oshikatsu, Prince Sawara, Empress Inoue, Fujiwara no Nakanari, Taira no Masakado, Fujiwara no Sumitomo, Abe no Sadatō, Tsushima-no-Kami Minamoto no Yoshichika, the Evil Minister of the Left (Yorinaga), and the Evil Captain of the Gate Guards (Nobuyori); in all, over twenty people. However, not a single one achieved their original desire. Their corpses were exposed in fields and mountains, and their heads were hung at the prison gates.

[5.5.2] In this age, indeed, the throne is treated exceedingly lightly. Long ago, when an Imperial Decree was read to them, withered plants and trees bloomed and bore fruit, and flying birds obeyed. It happened in the middle ages; Emperor Daigo (Engi) made a procession to Shinsen-en, and seeing a heron at the edge of the pond, summoned a Sixth Rank Chamberlain and commanded, "Catch that heron and bring it here." Although he thought "How can I catch it?", since it was an Imperial Command, he walked toward it. The heron groomed its feathers and was about to fly away. When he said "It is an Imperial Command," it crouched down and did not fly away. He caught it and presented it. "That you obeyed the Imperial Command and came is admirable. Immediately make it Fifth Rank." So saying, he made the heron Fifth Rank. He wrote a tablet saying "After today, you shall be the King of Herons," hung it on its neck, and released it. It was not at all for the sake of the heron, but only to let the extent of Royal Authority be known.

[5.6.1] Also, seeking a precedent in a foreign land, a man called Prince Dan of Yan was imprisoned by the First Emperor of Qin and suffered confinement for twelve years; Prince Dan shed tears and said, "I have an old mother in my home country; please grant me leave to see her." When he said this, the First Emperor laughed scornfully and said, "I shall wait until horns grow on a horse and a crow's head becomes white to grant you leave." Yan Dan looked up to heaven and bowed down to earth, praying, "Please make horns grow on a horse and make a crow's head white. I wish to return to my hometown and see my mother once more." That Bodhisattva Myōon went to the Pure Land of Vulture Peak and admonished unfilial people; Confucius and Yan Hui appeared in China and initiated the way of loyalty and filial piety. Since the Three Treasures of the unseen and visible worlds pity the will of filial piety, horns grew on a horse and it came into the palace, and a crow's head became white and it perched on a tree in front of the garden. The First Emperor, surprised by the miracle of the white-headed crow and horned horse, and believing that Imperial Words must not be reversed, pardoned Prince Dan and sent him back to his home country. The First Emperor regretted it afterwards; there is a country called Chu on the border of the Qin country and Yan country. A great river flows there. The bridge crossing that river is called the Bridge of Chu. The First Emperor sent government troops and arranged it so that when Yan Dan crossed, if he stepped on the bridge in the middle of the river, he would fall; when Yan Dan crossed, how could he not fall in? He fell into the middle of the river. However, he did not drown in the water at all, but walked as if on flat ground and arrived at the opposite bank. Thinking "How can this be?", when he looked back, turtles, number unknown, had floated up on the water and lined up their shells for him to walk on. This too was because the unseen and visible worlds pitied his will of filial piety.

[5.6.2] Prince Dan harbored a grudge and did not obey the First Emperor again. When the First Emperor sent government troops and intended to strike Yan Dan, Yan Dan was terrified and enlisted a soldier called Jing Ke (Keika) and made him a minister. Jing Ke in turn enlisted a soldier called Master Tian Guang (Denkō). That Master said, "Do you rely on me thinking this body is young and vigorous? Though a Qilin flies a thousand li, when it is old it is inferior to a sluggish horse. Now I cannot do it at all. I will enlist a soldier for you." As he was about to return, Jing Ke said, "Regarding this matter, be absolutely sure not to reveal it to others." The Master said, "There is no greater shame than being suspected by others. If this matter leaks, I will be suspected." So saying, he smashed his head against a plum tree in front of the gate and died. Also there was a soldier called Fan Yuqi (Hanoki). He was a man of the Qin country. Having had his father, uncles, and brothers destroyed by the First Emperor, he fled and hid in the country of Yan. The Qin Emperor issued an Imperial Order to the Four Seas proclaiming: "To the person who cuts off Fan Yuqi's head and presents it, I will give five hundred kin of gold." Jing Ke heard this, went to Fan Yuqi, and said, "I hear. Your head is rewarded with five hundred kin of gold. Lend me your head; I will take it and present it to the First Emperor. When he is pleased and looks at it, it will be easy to draw a sword and stab his breast." When he said this, Fan Yuqi jumped up, sighed greatly, and said, "My parents, uncles, and brothers were destroyed by the First Emperor; thinking of this night and day, it pierces my marrow and is hard to bear. Truly, if I can destroy the First Emperor, giving my head is easier than dust." So saying, he cut off his head with his own hand and died.

[5.6.3] Also there was a soldier called Qin Wuyang (Shin Buyō). He was also a man of the Qin country. At the age of thirteen he killed an enemy and fled to hide in the country of Yan. He was an unparalleled soldier. When he faced someone in anger, even a large man would faint. And when he faced someone with a smile, even an infant would be held by him. Enlisting him as a guide to the capital of Qin and taking him along, on a night when they stayed near a certain remote mountain, hearing music being played in a nearby village, he divined the success of their intent by the tone: the enemy's side was Water, his own side was Fire. Meanwhile, the sky dawned. A white rainbow pierced the sun but did not pass through. "It is difficult for us to achieve our intent," he said.

[5.6.4] Nevertheless, since they could not return, they arrived at the First Emperor's capital, Xianyang Palace. When they reported that they had brought the map of Yan and the head of Fan Yuqi, he intended to receive it via a subject. Since they reported, "We will absolutely not give it through a person, we will present it directly," he said "Then so be it," arranged the ceremony of a festival gathering, and summoned the envoys of Yan. The Xianyang Palace measured eighteen thousand three hundred and eighty li around the capital. They built up the palace three li high from the ground and it stood upon that. There was the Hall of Long Life and the Gate of Eternal Youth; they made a sun of gold and a moon of silver. Pearl sand, lapis lazuli sand, and gold sand were spread. On the four sides they built iron walls forty jo high, and over the palace as well they stretched an iron net. This was to prevent messengers from the netherworld from entering. Since there was an obstruction to free flight for the geese of the fields in autumn and those returning to the northern lands in spring, they named a gate in the wall the Wild Goose Gate, and opened the iron gate to let them pass. Among them was the Epang Palace, a hall where the First Emperor usually went to conduct affairs of state. The height was thirty-six jo, nine chō east-west, five chō north-south; under the main floor, five-jo flagpoles were erected but still did not reach. The top was roofed with lapis lazuli tiles, and the bottom was polished with gold and silver. Jing Ke held the map of Yan, and Qin Wuyang held Fan Yuqi's head, and they ascended the jeweled steps. Seeing the magnificence of the Palace, Qin Wuyang trembled uncontrollably, so the subjects were suspicious and said, "Wuyang has a rebellious heart. One does not place a criminal by the lord's side; a gentleman does not approach a criminal; approaching a criminal is the way to treat death lightly." Jing Ke turned back and said, "Wuyang has absolutely no rebellious heart. It is only that he is accustomed to rural baseness, and because he is not used to the Imperial Palace, his mind is confused." So the subjects all calmed down first. Thus they approached the King. When he put the map of Yan and Fan Yuqi's head in for inspection, at the bottom of the box containing the map, a sword like ice was visible; the First Emperor saw this and immediately tried to flee. Jing Ke grabbed the King's sleeve firmly and pressed the sword to his breast. It seemed that this was the end. Although tens of thousands of soldiers lined their sleeves in the courtyard, they had no power to save him. They only grieved together that the Lord was being violated by a rebellious subject. The First Emperor spoke: "Grant me a moment of leave. I wish to hear the sound of the koto of my most beloved consort one more time." Because he said this, Jing Ke did not attack him for a moment. The First Emperor possessed three thousand consorts. Among them sat a superior koto player called Lady Huayang. Generally, upon hearing the sound of this consort's koto, the anger of fierce warriors softened, flying birds fell, and grass and trees swayed. How much more so, as she played weeping, intending it for the Imperial hearing for the last time, it must have been beautiful. Jing Ke also lowered his head and pricked up his ears, and his thoughts as a scheming subject relaxed. At that time the consort began to play another song. "Though the seven-foot screen is high, if you jump, how could you not cross it? Though a single strand of silk is strong, if you pull, how could it not break?" Thus she played. Jing Ke did not understand this, but the First Emperor understood, tore off his sleeve, jumped over the seven-foot screen, and fled and hid behind a copper pillar. Jing Ke was angry and threw the sword at him. Just then, a physician on duty in the Imperial presence threw his medicine bag at Jing Ke's sword. Though the sword was impeded by the medicine bag, it cut halfway through the copper pillar with a diameter of six shaku. Since Jing Ke did not have another sword, he did not throw a second time. The King returned, summoned his sword, and cut Jing Ke into eight pieces. Qin Wuyang was also killed. Sending government troops, he destroyed Yan Dan. Since the Azure Heaven did not pardon him, the white rainbow pierced the sun but did not pass through, Qin Shi Huang escaped, and Yan Dan was finally destroyed. Therefore, people flattered, saying that the present Yoritomo will also surely be like that.

[5.7.1] Now, concerning that Yoritomo: in the twelfth month of the first year of Heiji, due to the rebellion of his father, Captain of the Left Stables Yoshitomo, at the age of fourteen, on the twentieth day of the third month of the first year of Eiryaku, he was exiled to Hirugashima in Izu Province, where he passed twenty years of springs and autumns. Though he had spent many years there, if one asks with what intent he raised a rebellion this year, it is said that the High Priest Mongaku of Takao encouraged him. That Mongaku was originally the son of Watanabe no Endō Sakon-no-Shōgen Mochitō; called Endō Musha Moritō, he was a retainer of Jōsai-mon'in. At the age of nineteen, developing a desire for the Way, he took the tonsure; intending to go out for ascetic practice, he said, "How great a matter is ascetic practice? I shall test and see." Under the blazing sun of the sixth month, when not even the grass stirred, he crawled into a thicket on a remote mountain, lay face up, and though horseflies, mosquitoes, bees, ants, and other poisonous insects attached themselves tightly to his body and stung and bit him, he did not move his body in the slightest, and did not rise until seven days had passed. On the eighth day, he rose up and asked people, "Is ascetic practice as great a matter as this?" When they said, "If it were to that extent, how could one's life survive?", he said, "Then it is easy," and immediately went out for ascetic practice.

[5.7.2] He went to Kumano and intended to seclude himself at Nachi; as a trial of his practice, intending to stand under the famous waterfall for a while, he went to the base of the waterfall. Since it was past the tenth day of the twelfth month, the snow had fallen and piled up, forming icicles; the sound of the valley stream had ceased, the wind on the peaks blew freezing, the white threads of the waterfall had become hanging ice, and everything was lined in white cloth, so that the treetops in all directions could not be distinguished. Nevertheless, Mongaku immersed himself in the waterfall basin, soaking up to his neck, and began fulfilling the spell of Fudō (Jikyū-no-shu); after two or three days, or rather four or five days, unable to bear it, Mongaku floated up. Since it was a waterfall cascading down thousands of jō, how could he stay put? He was dashed down with a crash, and amidst the sharp rock edges like sword blades, floating and sinking, he was washed downstream for five or six chō. At that time, a beautiful youth came and took Mongaku's left and right hands and pulled him up. People thought it a miracle, and when they built a fire and warmed him, since his life was not yet destined to end, his breath returned before long. Mongaku regained his senses a little, opened his large eyes wide in anger, and said, "I have a great vow to stand under this waterfall for three times seven days and fulfill three hundred thousand recitations of the Fudō spell. Today is barely the fifth day. When even seven days have not passed, who is it that has pulled me out here?" When he said this, those who saw it had their hair stand on end and could say nothing. Again he returned to the waterfall basin, stood, and was struck by the water.

[5.7.3] On the second day, eight youths came and tried to pull him up, but he struggled furiously and did not come up. On the third day, Mongaku finally passed away. Perhaps not wishing to defile the waterfall basin, two heavenly youths with their hair bound up descended from the top of the waterfall, and from the top of Mongaku's head to the tips of his fingers and toes, rubbed him down with extremely warm and fragrant hands; as he felt this, he felt like he was dreaming and breathed out. "Now, what kind of persons are you that you pity me so?" he asked. "We are the two attendants of the Great Holy Fudō Myōō, Kongara and Seitaka. Because Mongaku has made a supreme vow and attempted brave austerities, by the command of the Myōō saying 'Go and lend him strength,' we have come." Thus they answered. Mongaku made his voice angry and asked, "Well then, where is the Myōō?" "In the Tosotsu Heaven." Answering thus, they ascended far into the clouds. He joined his palms and worshipped them. "Then, even the Great Holy Fudō Myōō has come to know of my austerities." Thinking this reliably, he again returned to the waterfall basin, stood, and was struck. Truly, because there were auspicious signs, the blowing wind did not penetrate his body, and the falling water was like hot water. Thus, having finally fulfilled the great vow of three times seven days, he secluded himself at Nachi for a thousand days, went to Ōmine three times, Katsuragi twice, Kōya, Kokawa, Kinpusen, Hakusan, Tateyama, the peaks of Fuji, Izu, Hakone, Togakushi in Shinano, Haguro in Dewa; generally traveling around all places in Japan without exception; yet still perhaps longing for his hometown, he returned to the Capital; he was rumored to be a miracle worker with powers sharp enough to pray down flying birds.

div.head: 5.8. The Subscription List

div.p: [5.8.1] Later, he settled in the depths of a mountain called Takao and devoted himself to practice. At that Takao, there is a mountain temple called Jingo-ji. It is a temple built long ago in the time of Empress Shōtoku by Wake no Kiyomaro. Since there had been no repairs for a long time, in spring it was shrouded in haze, in autumn mixed with mist; the doors fell to the wind and rotted under fallen leaves; the roof tiles were invaded by rain and dew, and the Buddhist altar was completely exposed. Since there was no resident priest, the only thing that rarely entered was the light of the moon and sun. Mongaku raised a great vow to repair this somehow, and holding a subscription list (Kanjinchō), he went around urging donors in all directions; at one time, he went to the Hōjūji Palace of the Retired Emperor. Although he reported that he sought a contribution, it was the occasion of a musical gathering, and he was not listened to. Mongaku was by nature a fearless and supreme rough saint. Not knowing the internal situation of the Imperial presence, thinking only "I have reported it," he forced his way into the courtyard without right or wrong, raised a great voice and said, "Since you are a Lord of Great Mercy and Compassion, why should you not listen?" And spreading out the subscription list, he read it loudly.

div.div: The Novice Mongaku respectfully speaks. Specifically, receiving the assistance of high and low, priest and layman, I request to build a temple on the sacred ground of Mt. Takao, and perform the great profit of peace in the two worlds. A letter of solicitation. Considering this: Absolute Reality is vast. Although it cuts off the temporary names of sentient beings and Buddhas, the clouds of following delusion in the Dharma-nature cover thickly; since living in line on the peaks of the Twelve Links of Dependent Origination, the moonlight of the innate lotus of the heart is dim, and has not yet appeared in the great void of the Three Virtues and Four Mandalas. How sad. The Buddha-sun set early, and the crossroads of the cycle of birth and death are dark. Only indulging in lust, indulging in wine. Who will apologize for the delusion of the mad elephant and leaping monkey? In vain slandering people, slandering the Dharma. How can one escape the blame of King Yama and his jailers? Here, although Mongaku has just brushed off worldly dust and decorated himself with priestly robes, evil deeds are still vigorous in his heart, created day and night; good seedlings go against his ear and are abandoned morning and evening. How painful. To return again to the fire pits of the Three Paths, and revolve forever in the wheels of suffering of the Four Births. For this reason, the non-dual scriptures are in thousands and ten thousands of scrolls; scroll by scroll they clarify the cause of the Buddha-seed; of the Dharmas of following conditions and perfect sincerity, there is not one that does not reach the other shore of Enlightenment. Therefore, Mongaku sheds tears at the gate of contemplation on impermanence, encourages the true and secular of high and low, moves steps toward the High Rank Lotus Pedestal, and intends to build a sacred place for the King of Equal and Wondrous Enlightenment. Now, Takao: the mountain is high, representing the treetops of Vulture Peak; the valley is quiet, spreading the moss of the Shangshan cave. The rock spring chokes and draws a cloth; the mountain monkeys scream and play on the branches. Human villages are far and there is no noise or dust; close by there is only faith. The terrain is superior; truly one should revere the Buddha-heaven. Though the contribution be small, who would not assist? I hear in the wind: gathering sand to make a Buddha stupa instantly attains the Buddha-cause. How much more so regarding treasure and wealth of a single paper or half a coin? I pray that the construction be accomplished, and the Imperial Vow of the Golden Gate and Phoenix Calendar be fulfilled; and further, from the Capital to the countryside, far and near, neighbors and people, intimates and strangers, may sing of the non-action rule of Yao and Shun, and open the smile of a reunion like the Camellia leaf. Especially, may the spirits of the dead, obscure rituals, former and latter, great and small, quickly reach the terrace of the One Buddha True Gate, and inevitably enjoy the moon of the Three Bodies and Ten Thousand Virtues. Thus, the purport of the solicitation practice is generally like this.

div.p: [5.8.2] Jishō 3rd Year, 3rd Month, Day. Mongaku
[5.8.3] Thus he read aloud.

[5.9.1] At that time in the Imperial presence, the Prime Minister Myōon-in strummed the biwa and recited poetry magnificently. Azechi Dainagon Sukekata-kyō kept the beat and sang Fuzoku and Saibara songs. Sama-no-Kami Suketoki and Fourth Rank Chamberlain Morisada strummed the wagon (Japanese zither), singing imayō in various ways; inside the jeweled blinds and brocade curtains they made merry, and since it was truly delightful, the Cloistered Emperor also deigned to join in the singing. Into this, Mongaku's great voice intruded, and the tone differed, and the rhythm was completely disordered. "Who is it? Strike him on the neck!" Such was the command given. Among the impetuous young men advancing saying "Me too, me too," a man called Hangan Sukeyuki ran out and said, "What kind of thing are you saying? Get out!" Mongaku said, "Unless a manor is donated to Jingo-ji in Takao, Mongaku will absolutely not leave." And he did not move. When Sukeyuki approached and tried to strike him on the neck, Mongaku re-gripped the subscription list, struck Sukeyuki Hangan's eboshi hat with a "thwack" knocking it off, clenched his fist, struck him on the chest, and knocked him over backwards. Hangan Sukeyuki, with his topknot loose, fled up onto the main veranda screaming. After that, Mongaku pulled out from his bosom a sword wrapped in horse hair, looking like ice, and waited for anyone who would come at him to strike. Since he ran around with the subscription list in his left hand and the drawn sword in his right hand, as it was an unexpected and sudden event, it looked as if he held swords in both left and right hands. The nobles and courtiers made a commotion saying "What is this, what is this?", and the musical gathering was quickly ruined. The disturbance in the palace was extraordinary. A resident of Shinano Province, Andō Musha Sukemune, who was then serving in the Mushadokoro (Warriors' Office), said "What is the matter?", drew his sword, and ran out. Thinking it would be bad to cut him in such a place like the Imperial Garden, he reversed his sword to hold the back, and struck Mongaku's arm holding the sword hard. While Mongaku flinched slightly from the blow, Sukemune threw away his sword, shouted "Got you!", and grappled with him. While being grappled, Mongaku poked Andō Musha's right elbow. While being poked, Sukemune squeezed him. Since both were of unmatched great strength, they rolled up and down; then, looking wise, high and low gathered around and bound Mongaku securely where he moved. However, he made nothing of this and shouted abuse all the more. They dragged him outside the gate and gave him to the servants of the Kebiishi. They took him and bound him. While being bound and standing there, he glared in the direction of the Palace, raised a great voice and said, "You may not make a contribution. Since you have shown Mongaku such a painful time, I will make you realize it later. The Three Worlds are all a burning house. Even if it is a Royal Palace, it cannot escape that difficulty. Even if you boast of the Imperial Throne of the Ten Good Deeds, after you go on the journey to the Yellow Springs, you will not escape the torture of the Ox-headed and Horse-headed demons." Thus he spoke, jumping up and down. Saying this priest is outrageous, he was immediately put in prison. Hangan Sukeyuki, in the shame of having his eboshi knocked off, did not appear for duty for a while. Andō Musha, as a reward for grappling Mongaku, was made Uma-no-Jō without going through the ranks of seniority. Meanwhile, at that time Bifukumon-in passed away, and since there was a general amnesty, Mongaku was pardoned before long. He should have practiced anywhere for a while, but not doing so, he again held up the subscription list and solicited; when refused, he went around saying only fearful things like, "Alas, this world will soon be in chaos, and both Lord and subjects will be destroyed." "We cannot keep this priest in the Capital; exile him." So saying, he was exiled to Izu Province.

[5.9.2] Since the heir of the Lay Priest of the Third Rank Minamoto, Nakatsuna, was then the Governor of Izu, he handled the matter; saying he should be sent down by boat via the Tōkaidō, two or three low-ranking officials (hōmen) were assigned to take him to Ise Province. These men said, "It is the custom of the servants of the Office that in such matters we have our own reliance (tips). Well, Holy Priest, meeting such a fate and being exiled to a distant province, do you not have acquaintances? Please ask for things like souvenirs and food provisions." When they said this, Mongaku said, "I do not have friends to whom I should speak of such necessary matters, but I do have a friend in the vicinity of Higashiyama. Well then, I will send a letter." They found some crude paper and gave it to him. "There is no way to write on such paper." And he threw it back. Saying "Then...", they found thick paper and gave it to him. Mongaku laughed and said, "The priest cannot write; so you guys write." "Write this: 'Mongaku, with the intent of building and dedicating Jingo-ji in Takao, was soliciting, but meeting with such a reign, I have not accomplished my vow. I was imprisoned and furthermore exiled to Izu Province. It is a long road. Things like souvenirs and food provisions are important. Give them to this messenger.'" When he told them to write this, they wrote exactly as he said, and asked, "Now, to whom shall we address it?" "Write: To Kannon-bō of Kiyomizu." "This is deceiving the servants of the Office," they said. "Nevertheless, Mongaku relies deeply on Kannon. Otherwise, to whom should I speak of my business?" Thus he spoke.

[5.9.3] They boarded a boat from the port of Anotsu in Ise Province and went down, but at Tenryū-nada in Tōtōmi Province, a great wind suddenly blew and great waves rose, about to capsize the boat. The sailors and helmsmen tried to save it somehow, but since the wind and waves became increasingly rough, some chanted the name of Kannon, and others reached the final ten invocations. However, Mongaku made nothing of this. He was lying down snoring loudly, but whatever he thought, when it seemed it was the end, he jumped up suddenly, stood at the bow of the ship, glared at the open sea, raised a great voice and shouted, "Is the Dragon King there? Is the Dragon King there?" "Why do you try to wreck a ship carrying a saint who has made such a great vow? You Dragon Gods will receive the punishment of Heaven right now!" Thus he spoke. Perhaps because of that, the wind and waves quieted before long, and they arrived in Izu Province. Mongaku had made a vow from the day he left the Capital. "If I am to return to the Capital and perform the construction and dedication of Jingo-ji in Takao, I shall not die. If this vow is to be in vain, I shall die on the road." So, from the Capital until arriving in Izu, since there was often no favorable wind and they went along the coast and islands, for a period of thirty-one days, he completely fasted. Nevertheless, his energy did not diminish in the slightest, and he sat performing austerities. Truly, there were many things that did not seem like an ordinary person. He was entrusted to a man called Kondō Shirō Kunitaka and lived in the depths of Nagoya in Izu Province.

div.head: 5.10. The Fukuhara Imperial Decree

div.p: [5.10.1] Meanwhile, he constantly visited Hyōe-no-Suke (Yoritomo), and while they amused themselves telling stories of past and present, at one time Mongaku said, "In the Heike, Lord Komatsu was the only one strong in heart and superior in strategy. Perhaps the fate of the Heike is coming to an end; he passed away last year in the eighth month. Now among the Genji and Heike, there is no one who possesses the physiognomy of a Shogun to your extent. Quickly raise a rebellion and take possession of the country of Japan." Hyōe-no-Suke said, "What unexpected things you say, Holy Priest. Since I had my worthless life saved by the late Nun of the Ike, I do nothing but read the Lotus Sutra every day to pray for her afterlife." Mongaku spoke again: "If one does not take what Heaven gives, one conversely receives the blame. There is a text that says if one does not act when the time comes, one conversely receives the disaster. Since I speak like this, do you think I am speaking to test your heart? Look at the color of my deep sincerity toward you." And from his bosom, he took out a skull wrapped in white cloth. Hyōe-no-Suke asked, "What is that?" "This is the head of your father, the late Captain of the Left Stables. After Heiji, it was buried under the moss in front of the prison, and there was no one to pray for his afterlife, but Mongaku, having a thought, begged the prison guard for it, hung it around my neck for these ten-plus years, went around worshipping at mountains and temples, and prayed for him, so by now he has surely been saved for a kalpa. Therefore, Mongaku is a servant even for the sake of the late Captain." When he said this, Hyōe-no-Suke, though he did not know if it was certain, hearing it was his father's head, first shed tears in nostalgia. After that, he opened up and spoke. "However, unless the Imperial Censure against Yoritomo is pardoned, how can I raise a rebellion?" "That is an easy matter; I will go up immediately and get a pardon." "Even so, for you, a priest who is also under Imperial Censure, to say you will get someone pardoned, your estimation is very unreliable." "If I said I would get my own Censure pardoned, that would be wrong. Why should it be difficult to speak of your matter? To go up to the present capital, the New Capital of Fukuhara, will not take more than three days. To ask for the Imperial Decree will take a stay of one day. In total, it should not exceed seven or eight days." Saying this, he rushed out. Returning to Nagoya, he told his disciples that he had an intent to seclude himself for seven days in the mountains of Izu hidden from people, and left. Truly, in three days he went up to the New Capital of Fukuhara, and since he had a slight connection with Former Sahyōe-no-Kami Mitsuyoshi-kyō, he went there and said: "The exile of Izu Province, Former Sahyōe-no-Suke Yoritomo, says that if he is pardoned from Imperial Censure and receives an Imperial Decree, he will mobilize the housemen of the eight provinces, destroy the Heike, and pacify the realm." Hyōe-no-Kami said, "Well now, I myself have been suspended from three offices at present, and it is a painful time. The Cloistered Emperor is also confined, so how will it be? Nevertheless, I will try to ask." When he secretly reported this, the Cloistered Emperor immediately issued an Imperial Decree. The saint hung this around his neck, and again in three days arrived down in Izu Province. Hyōe-no-Suke was sitting worrying without pause, thinking "Alas, this Holy Priest has rashly proposed a useless thing, and what kind of trouble will Yoritomo meet with again?" when around the hour of the Horse on the eighth day, he arrived and presented it, saying "Here is the Imperial Decree!" Hyōe-no-Suke, grateful to hear it was an Imperial Decree, washed his hands and rinsed his mouth, put on a new eboshi and hunting robe, bowed three times to the Imperial Decree, and opened it.

div.div: Since recent years, the Taira clan has despised the Imperial Influence and has no hesitation in the way of government. They destroy the Buddha's Law and try to ruin the Imperial Prestige. Now, our country is a land of the Gods; the Ancestral Shrines stand together and the Divine Virtue is ever new. Therefore, since the founding of the Court, for several thousand years, there has been no one who tried to overturn the Imperial Plan and endanger the state who was not defeated. If so, then partly relying on the invisible aid of the Way of the Gods, and partly observing the intent of the Imperial Order, quickly punish the Taira clan and drive away the enemies of the Imperial House. Succeed to the military strategy of generations of bow and arrow, excel in the loyal service of your ancestors, establish yourself and raise your house; thus speaks the Imperial Decree. Therefore, I execute and transmit it as above.

div.p: [5.10.2] Jishō 4th Year, 7th Month, 14th Day. Former Sahyōe-no-Kami Mitsuyoshi (respectfully).
[5.10.3] Respectfully to: Former Sahyōe-no-Suke Dono.
[5.10.4] Thus it was written. It is said that Hyōe-no-Suke put this Imperial Decree in a brocade bag and hung it around his neck even at the time of the Battle of Ishibashiyama.

div.head: 5.11. Fuji River

div.p:
[5.11.1] Meanwhile, there was a council of nobles at Fukuhara stating that a punitive force should be sent down quickly before they gathered strength; the Great General was Komatsu Gon-no-Suke Shōshō Koremori, the Vice-General was Satsuma-no-Kami Tadanori; with a total force of over thirty thousand horsemen, they left the New Capital on the eighteenth of the ninth month, arrived at the Old Capital on the nineteenth, and immediately set out for the eastern provinces on the twentieth. The Great General Gon-no-Suke Shōshō Koremori was twenty-three years old; his appearance and bearing were difficult to describe with painting or brush. His ancestral armor called Karakawa (Chinese Leather) was put in a Chinese chest and carried. On the road, he wore a hitatare of red brocade and armor with light green thread lacing, and rode a dappled gray horse with coin patterns, saddled with a gold-rimmed saddle. The Vice-General Satsuma-no-Kami Tadanori wore a hitatare of dark blue brocade and armor with black thread lacing, and rode a thick and powerful black horse saddled with a lacquer-dusted saddle. From horses, saddles, armor, helmets, bows, arrows, to long and short swords, they were outfitted so that they shone; it was a magnificent sight. Satsuma-no-Kami Tadanori had for some years visited a certain lady-in-waiting born of a Prince; once when he was there, a high-ranking lady came as a guest to that lady's place, and they talked for a long time. The guest did not return until the night had deepened far. Tadanori rested for a while at the edge of the eaves and used his fan roughly; the Prince-born lady elegantly and gently recited, "The sound of insects gathering in the fields," so Satsuma-no-Kami immediately stopped using it and returned home. Later, when he was there again, the Prince-born lady asked, "By the way, why did you stop using your fan the other day?" He said, "Well, since I heard you say 'noisy' (kashigamashi), I stopped using it."
From that lady's place, sending a single layer of small-sleeved robe to Tadanori, in the sadness of a parting of a thousand li, she sent one poem.

lg.l: More than the sleeves that will part the grasses of the Eastern Road, the dew of my hem that does not stand [for the journey] spills.

div.p: [5.11.2] In Satsuma-no-Kami's reply:

lg.l: Why should I lament the parting road? As I cross the Barrier, I think of it as the traces of the past.

div.p: [5.11.3] His composing "The Barrier as the traces of the past" perhaps recalled the time when Taira General Sadamori went down to the eastern provinces to pursue Masakado; it sounded most elegant.

[5.11.4] In the past, a general heading to outer lands to quell an enemy of the court first visited the Palace and received the Sword of Command (Setto). The Emperor appeared in the Southern Hall, the guards drew up ranks at the foot of the steps, the nobles of the Inner and Outer Desks took their places, and a ceremonial banquet of middle protocol was held. The Great General and Vice-General each corrected their etiquette and received this. Saying that the traces of the Jōhei and Tengyō eras are too old to be comparable, this time, following the precedent of when Sanuki-no-Kami Masamori went down to Izumo Province to pursue Former Tsushima-no-Kami Minamoto no Yoshichika, they were given only a bell, put it in a leather bag, had an attendant hang it around his neck, and went down. Anciently, a general leaving the capital to destroy an enemy of the court had three awarenesses. On the day he receives the Sword of Command, he forgets his home; when he leaves his home, he forgets his wife and children; when he fights the enemy on the battlefield, he forgets himself. Therefore, the present Taira Generals Koremori and Tadanori must surely have been aware of such things. These were moving matters.

[5.11.5] On the twenty-first of the same month, the New Retired Emperor again made a pilgrimage to Itsukushima in Aki Province. There was a pilgrimage in the past third month as well. Perhaps because of that, for a month or two the world was governed peacefully and there was no trouble for the people, but due to the rebellion of the Takakura Prince, the realm was again disordered and the world was not quiet. Because of this, it was rumored that it was partly for the peace of the realm, and partly to pray for the indisposition of the Emperor. Since this time the pilgrimage was from Fukuhara, there was no trouble of travel lodging. He wrote the petition with his own hand, and the Regent Lord made the fair copy.

div.div: I humbly hear: The clouds of Dharma-nature are quiet. The moon of the fourteenth and fifteenth is high and clear, the wisdom of provisional manifestation is deep, and the wind of Yin and Yang blows everywhere. Now, the shrine of Itsukushima is a place where the name is heard universally, a site of peerless efficacy. The distant peaks surround the shrine altar, naturally manifesting the high towering of Great Compassion; the shrine buildings reaching the great sea show in the sky the depth and breadth of the Great Vow. Considering this: formerly, with a mediocre and obscure body, I unworthily trod the rank of Emperor. Now, I play with wise policies in the group of spiritual realms, and enjoy leisure in the dwelling of Mt. Ye. However, secretly extracting the sincerity of one heart, I visit the secluded shrine of the solitary island, look up to invisible grace under the auspicious fence, concentrate my earnest thoughts and shed sweat, and receive a divine oracle within the treasure palace. There is a notification inscribed in my heart. Especially, pointing to the period of fear and caution, it corresponds entirely to the season of late summer and early autumn. Illness suddenly invades, and medical arts still show no effect. The duckweed and cassia (status) turn frequently. I know more and more that divine response is not empty. Though I seek prayer, the mist and dew are hard to scatter. Therefore, extracting the will of my heart, I intend to undertake the practice of travel again. At the bottom of the vast cold storm, lying in a travel lodge, dreams are broken; before the dreary faint sun, facing a long road, I strain my eyes. Finally arriving at the site of the shrine, I reverently spread a pure seat, and offer a copy of the Lotus Sutra in colored paper and ink characters, the opening and closing sutras, Amida and Heart Sutras, one scroll each. One scroll of the Devadatta Chapter written in gold dust with my own hand. At this time, in the shade of green pines and green oaks, together adding seeds of good principle, the tide goes and comes, echoing in the sky, harmonizing with the voice of chanting. Though the disciple (I) bid farewell to the clouds of the Northern Palace and seasons have not cycled much, I have braved the waves of the Western Sea twice, and deeply know that the opportunity and connection are not shallow. The guests who pray in the morning are not one. Those who offer thanks in the evening are nearly a thousand. However, though the reverence of the noble is great, a visit by a Retired Emperor has not yet been heard of. The Cloistered Emperor Zenjō began this ceremony. The disciple (I), with insignificant body, deeply transports his will; before the moon of Mt. Songgao, Emperor Wu of Han did not yet worship the shadow of softened light. At the bottom of the clouds of the Penglai cave, heavenly immortals vainly separated the dust of manifestation. I reverently pray, Great Deity, I humbly beg, may the One Vehicle Sutra newly illuminate my sincere prayer, and grant a unique response.

div.p: [5.11.6] Jishō 4th Year, 9th Month, 28th Day. Retired Emperor.
[5.11.7] Thus it was written.

[5.11.8] Meanwhile, these people left the Nine-Fold Capital and headed for the distant Tōkai road. The prospect of returning safely to the Capital was truly perilous; sometimes borrowing lodging in the dew of fields and plains, sometimes sleeping on the journey on the moss of high peaks, crossing mountains and piling up rivers, as days passed, on the sixteenth of the tenth month, they arrived at Kiyomi-ga-Seki in Suruga Province. Although they left the Capital with over thirty thousand horsemen, recruiting soldiers along the way, it was rumored to be over seventy thousand horsemen. The vanguard advanced to Kanbara and Fujikawa, while the rearguard was still held up at Tegoshi and Utsunoya. The Great General Gon-no-Suke Shōshō Koremori summoned the Samurai General Kazusa-no-Kami Tadakiyo and said eagerly, "In Koremori's opinion, let us cross Ashigara and fight in the Bandō region." Kazusa-no-Kami said, "When we left Fukuhara, the Lay Priest's order was that he would entrust the battle to Tadakiyo. Since the soldiers of the eight provinces have all followed Hyōe-no-Suke, how many tens of thousands of horsemen must there be? Although our force is called over seventy thousand, they are conscripted warriors from the provinces. Both horses and men are exhausted. It is not yet even seen that the forces of Izu and Suruga will join us. Perhaps we should just keep the Fuji River in front of us and wait for our forces." Since he said this, powerless, they hesitated.

[5.11.9] Meanwhile, Hyōe-no-Suke crossed the Ashigara mountains and arrived at the Kise River in Suruga Province. The Genji of Kai and Shinano raced there and united. At Ukishimagahara, there was a muster of forces. It is recorded as two hundred thousand horsemen. A servant of Hitachi Genji Satake Tarō was going up to the Capital carrying a letter on his master's errand; the Heike vanguard Kazusa-no-Kami Tadakiyo stopped him, seized the letter he carried, opened and looked at it, but it was a letter to a lady-in-waiting. Saying it would not be harmful, he let him pass. "Now, how large is Hyōe-no-Suke-dono's force?" he asked. "Generally, for eight or nine days' journey, they continue closely; fields, mountains, seas, and rivers are all warriors. I, a lowly servant, know numbers up to four or five hundred thousand, but I do not know above that. I do not know if it is many or few. Yesterday at the Kise River, people were saying that the Genji force is two hundred thousand horsemen." Hearing this, Kazusa-no-Kami said, "Alas, there is nothing more regrettable than the Great General's delay. If you had sent down the punitive force even one day sooner, crossed the Ashigara mountains, and gone to the eight provinces, why would the Hatakeyama clan and the Ōba brothers not have joined us? If only they had joined, there would be no grass or tree in Bandō that would not bow to us." Though he regretted it, it was of no use.

[5.11.10] Also, the Great General Gon-no-Suke Shōshō Koremori summoned Nagai Saitō Bettō Sanemori as a guide to the eastern provinces and asked, "Well Sanemori, how many strong archers and elite soldiers like you are there in the eight provinces?" Saitō Bettō laughed scornfully and said, "If you say that, do you think Sanemori is a great archer? I only draw thirteen hand-breadths. There are any number of men in the eight provinces who shoot as well as Sanemori. Those who are established as Great Archers do not pull less than fifteen hand-breadths, and regarding the strength of the bow, five or six strong men string it. When such elite soldiers shoot, even if you layer two or three sets of armor, they easily shoot through them. A single Daimyo, even if his force is small, is not less than five hundred horsemen. Once mounted on a horse, they do not know the way to fall off. Though they gallop over bad terrain, their horses do not fall. In battle, even if a parent is killed or a child is killed, they ride over their dead bodies and fight. In the battles of the western provinces, if a parent is killed, they perform funeral rites, wait for the mourning period to end, and then attack; if a child is killed, in that grief, they do not attack. If military rice runs out, in spring they plant fields and in autumn harvest and attack; in summer they say it is hot, in winter they dislike the cold. In the eastern provinces, generally there is no such custom. The Genji of Kai and Shinano know the terrain. They will probably go around to the rear from the foot of Fuji. Since I speak thus, you may think I say it to frighten you. That is not the case. It is transmitted that battle depends not on numbers but on strategy. Sanemori does not expect to survive this battle and return to the Capital again." When he spoke thus, the Heike soldiers heard this and all trembled and shook.

[5.11.11] Meanwhile, it became the twenty-third of the tenth month. It was decided that tomorrow the Genji and Heike would exchange arrows at the Fuji River; entering the night, when they looked across at the Genji camp from the Heike side, the people and peasants of Izu and Suruga, fearing the battle, had entered the fields or hidden in the mountains, or boarded boats and floated on the sea and river, and their campfires were visible; the Heike soldiers said, "Ah, the immense number of distant fires in the Genji camp! Truly, fields, mountains, sea, and river are all enemies. What shall we do?" And they panicked. Around midnight that night, the water birds flocking in great numbers in the Fuji marshes were startled by something and rose up all at once with a clamor; the sound of their wings sounded like a great wind or thunder, so the Heike soldiers said, "There, the great army of the Genji is attacking!
