Just as Saitō Bettō said, surely they are circling to the rear. If we are surrounded, it will be hopeless. Let us retreat from here and defend the Owari River and Sunomata!" And without even taking their belongings, they fled, vying to be first. In their extreme haste and panic, those taking bows did not know arrows, those taking arrows did not know bows; I rode another's horse, another rode my horse. Or, riding tethered horses, they circled around the stakes endlessly. Among the courtesans and entertainers brought from nearby post stations to entertain them, many had their heads kicked and split or their waists trampled and broken, and screamed and shouted.

[5.11.12] At the hour of the Hare (6 AM) on the following twenty-fourth day, the great Genji army of two hundred thousand horsemen pressed upon the Fuji River and raised war cries three times, to the extent that the heavens echoed and the earth shook.

[5.12.1] On the Heike side, there was no sound. When they sent someone to look, he reported, "They have all fled."
There were those who took armor forgotten by the enemy and brought it back. There were those who took large curtains abandoned by the enemy and brought them back. "In the enemy camp, not even a fly is buzzing," they reported. Hyōe-no-Suke got off his horse, took off his helmet, washed his hands and rinsed his mouth, bowed toward the Royal Capital, and said, "This is absolutely not Yoritomo's private achievement; it is the plan of Hachiman Daibosatsu."
Saying that it was a place they had immediately conquered, he entrusted Suruga Province to Ichijō Jirō Tadayori, and Tōtōmi to Yasuda Saburō Yoshisada. Though he should have continued to attack the Heike, saying that the rear was uneasy, he withdrew from Ukishimagahara and returned to Sagami Province. The courtesans and entertainers of the post stations along the sea road laughed together, saying, "Ah, how detestable. The wretchedness of the fleeing Great General of Archers without shooting a single arrow. In war, even 'seeing and fleeing' is considered a shameful thing, but this was 'hearing and fleeing'!" There were many satirical graffiti. Since the Great General in the Capital was called Munemori (Ridge-Prosperity) and the Punitive General was called Gon-no-Suke (Assistant), they punned Heike (Taira House) with hiraya (flat house/one-story house):

lg.l: How agitated must be Munemori of the flat house, having dropped the Assistant (support beam) he relied on as a pillar.
Faster than the water crossing the rocks of the rapids of the Fuji River, the Ise Heishi fall (flee).

div.p: [5.12.2] This was composed about Kazusa-no-Kami Tadakiyo abandoning his armor at the Fuji River.

lg.l: At the Fuji River he threw away his armor; Tadakiyo (only pure) in ink-dyed robes for the afterlife.
Tadakiyo rode on a fleeing horse; putting a crupper on a Kazusa (horse) was useless.

div.p: [5.12.3] On the eighth of the eleventh month, Great General Gon-no-Suke Shōshō Koremori arrived up at the New Capital of Fukuhara. The Lay Priest Prime Minister was greatly angered and proclaimed: "Exile Great General Gon-no-Suke Shōshō Koremori to Kikai-ga-shima; execute Samurai General Kazusa-no-Kami Tadakiyo." On the ninth, the Heike samurai, old and young, met and deliberated: "What shall be done about the execution of Tadakiyo?" Among them, Shume Hangan Morikuni stepped forward and said, "I have never heard from old times that Tadakiyo was a cowardly man; I remember when he was eighteen, two villains of the Five Home Provinces fled into the Treasure House of the Toba Palace, and there was no one who said they would go in and arrest them; this Tadakiyo, in broad daylight, alone crossed the earthen wall, jumped in, killed one, captured one alive, and raised his name for later generations. The failure this time does not seem like a trivial matter. In connection with this, you should be very cautious about military disturbances."

[5.12.4] On the tenth of the same month, Great General Gon-no-Suke Shōshō Koremori became a Middle Captain of the Right Guards. "Though he was called the General of the Punitive Force, he did not achieve anything significant. What kind of reward is this?" People whispered to each other.

[5.12.5] Long ago, for the pursuit of Masakado, Taira General Sadamori and Tawara Tōta Hidesato received the order and set out for the Bandō region, but since Masakado was difficult to destroy easily, there was a council of nobles saying a punitive force should be sent again; Uji Minbu-kyō Tadabumi and Kiyohara no Shigefuji were given the post of Military Inspector and went down. On the night they stayed at Kiyomi-ga-Seki in Suruga Province, that Shigefuji looked out at the vast sea and loudly recited a Chinese poem: "The lights of fishing boats are cold and burn the waves; the sound of bells on the station road passes the night mountain"; Tadabumi felt it was elegant and shed tears of admiration. Meanwhile, Sadamori and Hidesato finally killed Masakado. While they were coming up carrying the head, they met at Kiyomi-ga-Seki. From there, the earlier and later Great Generals went up to the Capital together. When rewards were given to Sadamori and Hidesato, there was a council of nobles asking if there should be rewards for Tadabumi and Shigefuji as well. Kujō Udaijin Morosuke-kō said, "Although the punitive force went to Bandō, since Masakado was difficult to destroy easily, at the time these men received the command and went to the east of the barrier, the enemy of the court was already destroyed. Therefore, why should there not be a reward?" Though he spoke thus, the Regent of that time, Lord Ononomiya, said, "Since the text of the Book of Rites says 'Do not do what is doubtful'," and finally did not grant it. Tadabumi took this as a regrettable matter, and swearing "I will make the descendants of Lord Ononomiya into servants; I will become a guardian deity for the descendants of Lord Kujō for all generations," he starved himself to death. Therefore, although the descendants of Lord Kujō have flourished magnificently, there are no significant people among the descendants of Lord Ononomiya, and now they have completely died out.

[5.12.6] Meanwhile, the Lay Priest Prime Minister's fourth son, Tō-no-Chūjō Shigehira, became a Middle Captain of the Left Guards. On the thirteenth of the same eleventh month, the Palace was completed in Fukuhara, and the Emperor transferred there. The Great Thanksgiving Festival (Daijō-e) should have taken place, but the Great Thanksgiving Festival involves a procession to the East River at the end of the tenth month and purification. They build a purification site in the field north of the Palace and prepare divine garments and tools. In front of the Daigokuden, below the altar of the Dragon Tail Path, they build a dressing hall, and [the Emperor] takes a bath. Beside the same altar, they build the Daijō Palace and offer divine meals. There is an Imperial Banquet. There is music. There is a Grand Ceremony at the Daigokuden. There is Sacred Music (Kagura) at the Seishodō. There is a banquet at the Burakuin. However, in this New Capital of Fukuhara, there is no Daigokuden, so there is no place to perform the Grand Ceremony. Since there is no Seishodō, there is no way to perform Sacred Music. Since there is no Burakuin, the banquet also cannot be held. There was a council of nobles saying that this year there should only be the Niiname Festival and the Gosechi dances, and the Niiname Festival was carried out at the Jingikan in the Old Capital.

[5.12.7] Regarding the Gosechi: in the time of Kiyomihara (Emperor Tenmu), at the Yoshino Palace, on a night when the moon was white and the wind fierce, as he calmed his heart and played the koto, a celestial maiden descended and flipped her sleeves five times. This is the origin of the Gosechi.

[5.13.1] Regarding this relocation of the capital, both Lord and subjects grieved. Since Mt. Hiei and Nara, and all the temples and shrines, appealed together that it should not be so, even the Lay Priest Prime Minister, who usually forced his way through everything, said "Then there shall be a return to the capital," and the Capital was in an uproar.

[5.13.2] On the second of the same twelfth month, the return to the capital suddenly took place. The New Capital was high along the mountains in the north, and low near the sea in the south. The sound of waves was constantly noisy, and it was a place where the salt wind was fierce. Therefore, the New Retired Emperor was constantly indisposed, so he hurriedly left Fukuhara. Starting with the Regent Lord, the Prime Minister and the nobles and courtiers below him vied to accompany him. Starting with the Lay Priest Prime Minister, the nobles and courtiers of the Heike clan vied to go up first. Who would remain even for a moment in the New Capital that had been so wretched? Since the past sixth month, they had broken down houses, transported goods and tools down, and built it up formally, but now, crazily, there was a return to the capital, so without any particular order, they abandoned everything and went up. Everyone was without a dwelling, so relying on Hachiman, Kamo, Saga, Uzumasa, Nishiyama, and the edges of Higashiyama, even high-ranking people stayed in temple corridors and shrine worship halls.

[5.13.3] If one asks what the true intent of this capital relocation was: the Old Capital was close to the Southern Capital and Northern Peak (Mt. Hiei), and at the slightest thing, they would bring out the Divine Tree of Kasuga or the Divine Palanquin of Hiyoshi, and it was disorderly. Fukuhara is separated by mountains and piled with inlets, and the distance is considerable, so they thought such things would not be easy; it is said that this was the plan devised by the Lay Priest Prime Minister.

[5.13.4] On the twenty-third of the same twelfth month, intending to attack the rebellion of the Ōmi Genji, with Sahyōe-no-Kami Tomomori and Satsuma-no-Kami Tadanori as Great Generals, a total force of over twenty thousand horsemen set out for Ōmi Province, attacked and destroyed the overflow Genji such as Yamamoto, Kashiwagi, and Nishikori one by one, and immediately crossed into Mino and Owari.

[5.14.1] In the Capital, moreover, when the Takakura Prince entered Onjō-ji (Mii-dera), the monks of the Southern Capital (Nara) agreed with him and even went to welcome him; this constitutes being an enemy of the court. Therefore, while it was said that both the Southern Capital and Mii-dera should be attacked, the monks of Nara rose up in tremendous force. Although the Lord Regent sent down word saying, "If you have a grievance, you may appeal as many times as you wish," they did not heed it at all. When the ranking Bettō Tadanari was sent down as an Imperial Messenger, the monks made an uproar saying, "Drag him down from his vehicle! Cut off his topknot!" so Tadanari lost color and fled back to the capital. Next, Uemon-no-Suke Chikamasa was sent down. Regarding him as well, since the monks clamored "Cut off his topknot!", he fled back without even taking his belongings. At that time, the topknots of two servants of the Kangaku-in were cut off.

[5.14.2] Also, in the Southern Capital, they made a large ball for the gitchō game, named it the head of the Lay Priest Prime Minister Taira, and shouted, "Hit it! Stomp on it!" It is said, "Easily leaked words are the medium that invites disaster. Failure to be cautious with words is the path to ruin." This Lay Priest Prime Minister is, awe-inspiring to mention, the maternal grandfather of the current Emperor. That the monks of the Southern Capital spoke like this seemed entirely the work of heavenly demons.

[5.14.3] Hearing these things transmitted, how could the Lay Priest Prime Minister think well of it? Intending to temporarily quell the violence of the Southern Capital, the resident of Bitchū Province, Senoo Tarō Kaneyasu, was appointed to the Kebiishi (Police Commission) of Yamato Province. Kaneyasu set out for the Southern Capital with over five hundred horsemen. "Make sure, even if the monks commit violence, you must not do so. Do not wear armor. Do not carry bows and arrows." Although he went with these instructions, the monks did not know of this internal order; they captured over sixty of Kaneyasu's remaining men, cut off all their heads one by one, and lined them up hanging by the edge of Sarusawa Pond. The Lay Priest Prime Minister was greatly angered and said, "Then attack the Southern Capital!" The Great General was Tō-no-Chūjō Shigehira, and the Vice-General was Chūgū-no-Suke Michimori; with a total force of over 40,000 horsemen, they set out for the Southern Capital. The monks, disregarding old and young, numbering over 7,000 men, tightened their helmet cords, dug ditches across the two roads of Narazaka and Hannyaji, built walls and shields, pulled up abatis, and waited. The Heike divided their 40,000 horsemen into two groups and pressed upon the two fortifications of Narazaka and Hannyaji, raising a great war cry. The monks were all on foot wielding melee weapons. The government troops galloped their horses around and around, chasing them here and there, nocking and pulling their bows rapidly and shooting scatteringly, so the defending monks exhausted their numbers and were killed. They began exchanging arrows at the hour of the Hare (6 AM) and fought all day until dark. Entering the night, both fortifications at Narazaka and Hannyaji were breached. Among the fleeing monks, there was a warrior monk named Saka no Shirō Eikaku. In wielding weapons, taking up bow and arrow, and in physical strength, he surpassed the Seven Great Temples and the Fifteen Great Temples. Over a green-laced belly guard, he wore armor laced with black thread. Tightening the cords of a five-plate helmet over a hat, holding a large white-handled naginata curved like a reed leaf and a black-lacquered great sword in his left and right hands, with over ten fellow monks standing before and behind him, he fought his way out from the Tegai Gate. This held them back for a while. Many government soldiers had their horses' legs cut and were killed. However, the government army was a great force, and since they attacked in waves, the fellow monks defending in front, behind, left, and right of Eikaku were all killed. Although Eikaku was fierce alone, his rear became exposed, so he fled toward the south.

[5.14.4] It became a night battle, and it was pitch dark; the Great General Tō-no-Chūjō Shigehira stood in front of the gate of Hannyaji and commanded, "Bring out fire." Among the Heike forces, a man named Jirō Dayū Tomokata, the district manager of Fukui Manor in Harima Province, broke shields to make torches and set fire to the houses. Since it was the night of the twenty-eighth of the twelfth month, the wind was fierce; although the source of the fire was single, the blowing and wandering wind blew it onto many temples. Those who felt shame and valued their name died fighting at Narazaka or were killed at Hannyaji. Those capable of walking fled toward Yoshino and Totsukawa. Old monks who could not walk, ordinary scholars, children, and women fled, vying to be first, into the Great Buddha Hall (Daibutsuden) and the Yamashina-dera (Kōfuku-ji). Over a thousand people climbed up to the second floor of the Great Buddha Hall, and to prevent the enemy from following, they pulled up the ladders. The raging fire pressed right upon them. It seemed that the screaming voices of the sinners at the bottom of the flames of the Scorching Heat, Great Scorching Heat, and Avici Hells could not surpass this.

[5.14.5] Kōfuku-ji was the vow of Lord Tankai (Fujiwara no Fuhito), the ancestral temple of the Fujiwara clan. The statue of Shakyamuni, the first in the Buddha's Law, residing in the Eastern Golden Hall; the statue of Kannon which emerged naturally from the earth, residing in the Western Golden Hall; the four-sided corridors lined with lapis lazuli; the two-story tower mixed with vermilion; the two pagodas whose nine rings shone in the sky—it is sad that they instantly turned to smoke. Regarding Tōdai-ji, considering it the living Buddha of the eternal and indestructible Land of Actual Reward and Tranquil Light, the sixteen-jo (approx. 48 meters) gold and copper Vairochana Buddha which Emperor Shōmu polished and erected with his own hands—its ushnisha appeared high, hidden in the clouds of the mid-sky, and the noble face of the full moon with its newly worshipped white curl (urna)—the head burned and fell to the earth, and the body melted into a mountain. The eighty-four thousand physical marks were hidden early by the five-layered clouds of the autumn moon, and the jewels of the forty-one stages drifted vainly in the wind of the ten evils of the night stars. Smoke filled the mid-sky, and flames left no gap in the void. Those who saw it up close could not turn their eyes to it; those who heard of it from afar lost their spirits. Of the sacred teachings of the Hossō and Sanron sects, not a single scroll remained. Not only in our country, but even in India and China, it is not thought that such a destruction of the Dharma has occurred. The purple gold polished by King Udayana and the red sandalwood carved by Vishvakarman were merely life-sized Buddhas. How much more so, regarding this unique and peerless Buddha in Jambudvipa, no one thought there would ever be a time of decay or damage, but now mixing with the dust of toxic affinity, it has left sorrow for a long time. It seemed that Brahma, Indra, the Four Kings, the Dragon Gods, the Eight Legions, and the officials and multitudes of the Underworld must all be startled and agitated. What must the Kasuga Great Deity, protector of the Hossō sect, have thought? Thus, the color of the dew on Kasuga Field changed, and the sound of the storm on Mt. Mikasa was heard as if resentful. When they recorded the number of people burned to death in the flames, there were over 1,700 on the second floor of the Great Buddha Hall, over 800 in the Yamashina-dera (Kōfuku-ji), over 500 in a certain hall, over 300 in another hall; recording in detail, it was over 3,500 people. Of the monks killed on the battlefield, over a thousand; some heads were hung at the gate of Hannyaji, and some heads were carried up to the Capital.

[5.14.6] On the twenty-ninth, the Tō-no-Chūjō destroyed the Southern Capital and returned to the Northern Capital (Kyoto). Only the Lay Priest Prime Minister cleared his anger and rejoiced. The Empress, the Cloistered Emperor, the Retired Emperor, the Regent, and those below them grieved, saying, "Even if one destroys evil monks, should one destroy the temples?"
It was rumored that the heads of the monks would originally be paraded through the main streets and hung on the tree at the prison gate, but due to the appalling destruction of Tōdai-ji and Kōfuku-ji, no order was given. They were discarded in ditches and moats here and there. In the written record by the Imperial hand of Emperor Shōmu, it was written: "If my temple prospers, the realm shall also prosper; if my temple declines, the realm shall also decline."
Therefore, it seemed there was no doubt that the realm would decline. The terrible year ended, and it became the fifth year of Jishō.

div.head: 6.1. The Death of the Retired Emperor

div.p: [6.1.1] On the first day of the first month of the fifth year of Jishō, at the Imperial Palace, due to the military disturbances in the eastern provinces and the fire in the Southern Capital, the morning court ceremony was cancelled, and the Emperor did not appear. No music was played, no dance was performed, the people of Yoshino did not come to pay tribute, and not a single Fujiwara noble attended, due to the burning of their clan temple. On the second day, there was no banquet in the Courtiers' Hall. Men and women were hushed, and the Palace seemed ominous. It was appalling that both the Buddha's Law and the King's Law had come to an end. The Cloistered Emperor said, "I maintain the precious throne of ten thousand chariots due to the residual merit of the ten good deeds. The Emperors of four generations are, when I think of it, my children and grandchildren. Why must I have the administration of the myriad affairs of state stopped and spend my years and months in vain?" Thus he lamented.

[6.1.2] On the fifth day of the same month, the high-ranking monks of the Southern Capital were stripped of their offices, public invitations were stopped, and their positions were confiscated. The monks, old and young, were either shot to death, cut to death, or did not escape the smoke and choked in the flames, so that many died; the few who remained fled into the mountains and forests, and not a single person remained. The Bettō of Kōfuku-ji, Karin-in Sōjō Eien, seeing the Buddhist statues and sutra scrolls rise as smoke, was shocked and heartbroken, saying "Ah, how terrible," and falling ill from the distress, he finally passed away before long. This High Priest was an elegant and emotional person. Once, hearing the cry of a cuckoo:

lg.l: Because it is rare every time I hear it, the cuckoo always feels like the first song.

div.p: [6.1.3] Because he composed this poem, he was called the Hatsune (First Song) Sōjō.

[6.1.4] However, since the Gosai-e (Imperial Vegetarian Feast) should be held even if only formally, there was discussion about the names of the monks; since the high priests of the Southern Capital had been stripped of office, there was a council of nobles asking if it should be conducted using the high priests of the Northern Capital (Kyoto). But since the Southern Capital should not be completely abandoned, students of the Sanron sect who had completed their studies and were hiding in Kajū-ji were summoned, and the Gosai-e was conducted according to form. The Retired Emperor (Takakura), distressed by such things as the confinement of the Cloistered Emperor at Toba Palace the year before last, the killing of the Takakura Prince last year, and the appalling disorder of the realm with the moving of the capital, had fallen ill and was constantly heard to be unwell; hearing that Tōdai-ji and Kōfuku-ji had been destroyed, his illness became all the more serious. While the Cloistered Emperor grieved extraordinarily, on the fourteenth of the same first month, at the Ike-dono of Rokuhara, the Retired Emperor finally passed away. During his reign of twelve years, his virtuous administration had thousands of aspects; he revived the abandoned ways of poetry and benevolence, and continued the interrupted traces of peaceful rule. Since it is a path that even Arhats with the Three Knowledges and Six Supernatural Powers cannot escape, and even avatars with magical arts and transformations cannot flee, although it is the custom of impermanence in the conditioned world, it felt unreasonable. Immediately that night, he was transferred to Seikan-ji at the foot of Higashiyama, and ascending with the evening smoke, he became the spring haze. Chōken Hōin hurried down from the mountain intending to attend the funeral, but seeing that he had already become empty smoke:

lg.l: Asking today about the Imperial Procession I always saw, it is sad to hear it is a journey of no return.

div.p: [6.1.5] Also, a certain lady-in-waiting, hearing that the Lord had hidden himself, thought thus:

lg.l: Hearing that the light of the moon I saw far in the future above the clouds has vanished is sad.

div.p: [6.1.6] His age was twenty-one. Internally he kept the ten precepts, externally he did not violate the five constant virtues, and he corrected etiquette and righteousness. Since he was a wise king of the latter days, the world's regret for him was like losing the light of the sun and moon. Thus, human wishes are not fulfilled, and the boundary of human life where the people's fortune is clumsy is sad indeed.

[6.2.1] People said, "Even if one speaks of the Emperors of Engi and Tenryaku, how could they surpass this one in the way people thought of him with elegance and grace?" Generally, raising the name of a concurrently wise king and performing acts of benevolence are things done after the Lord has grown up and distinguished purity from impurity, but this Lord, from the time he was a very young master, received a nature that was gentle. In the past Jōan era, at the beginning of his reign, when he was about ten years old, he loved autumn leaves exceedingly; he had a small hill built at the north guard station, planted wax trees and maple trees that had turned beautiful colors, named it the Hill of Autumn Leaves, and looked at it all day, yet was never satisfied. However, one night a storm blew violently, scattering all the autumn leaves, and the fallen leaves were quite disorderly. The servants of the Palace Caretakers, saying they were cleaning the court, swept them all away and discarded them. They raked up the remaining branches and scattered leaves, and since it was a cold windy morning, they used them as firewood to warm sake at the Sewing Bureau guard station. The Kurando in charge, hurrying to go and look before the Emperor's visit, found no trace of them. "What happened?" he asked. "Such and such," they said. The Kurando was greatly shocked and lamented, "Ah, how terrible. The wretchedness of doing such a thing to the autumn leaves the Lord was so attached to. I do not know, you will all be imprisoned or exiled right now, and I too will likely incur some imperial wrath." Just then, the Emperor hurriedly left the night palace and went there to look at the autumn leaves; since they were gone, he asked "What happened?" The Kurando had no way to answer, but reported the truth. His mood seemed especially good, and he laughed, saying, "Who taught them the heart of the poem 'Warming sake in the forest, burning autumn leaves'? They have done an elegant thing." And since he was conversely impressed, there was absolutely no imperial censure.

[6.2.2] Also, in the Angen era, when there was a directional taboo procession, even otherwise the crowing of the roosters at dawn was enough to startle the sleep of a wise king, so he was prone to waking up and could not sleep soundly at all. How much more so on a night of freezing frost, he thought about how cold the people of the land must be in the holy era of Engi, and even took off his robes in the night palace, lamenting that his imperial virtue did not reach far enough. When it reached somewhat deep into the night, there was the voice of a person screaming in the distance. The accompanying people did not notice it, but the Emperor heard it and commanded, "Who is screaming now? Go quickly and see." The courtiers on night watch ordered the servants on duty. They ran out and searched, and at a certain intersection, there was a girl of low status holding the lid of a long chest and weeping. "What is the matter?" they asked. She said, "My mistress is a lady-in-waiting serving at the Retired Emperor's palace; she finally managed to have a set of robes made, and as I was bringing it, just now two or three men came, snatched it, and left. If I had the robes now, she could serve at the palace. There is no close relative she can rely on properly. Thinking of this, I weep." They took the girl along and reported this. The Emperor heard it and said, "Ah, how pitiable. Whose doing could this be? The people of Yao's reign took Yao's honest heart as their own, so they were all honest. The people of the present age take my heart as their own, so violent people exist in the court and commit crimes. Is this not my shame?" "Now, what color were the robes that were taken?" he asked. "Such and such a color," they reported. It was when Kenreimon-in was still the Empress. He asked her quarters, "Are there robes of such a color?" and when they brought some that were far more beautiful than the previous ones, he gave them to the said girl. "It is still deep in the night, and you might meet such a fate again." So saying, he attached servants on duty and had her escorted to the room of her mistress; how grateful it was. Therefore, from the lowly men to the lowly women, everyone prayed only for the thousand autumns and ten thousand years of this Lord's precious reign.

[6.3.1] Among the pitiful matters, there was a girl attendant used by a lady-in-waiting serving in the Empress's quarters, who unexpectedly came close to the Dragon Face (Emperor). Although she was of ordinary birth, the Emperor constantly summoned her. Since his affection was truly deep, her mistress no longer treated her as a servant, but conversely served her like a master. In the old ballads it is said: "Do not despise the birth of a girl. Do not rejoice in the birth of a boy. A boy is not even enfeoffed as a Marquis, but a girl becomes a Consort." Thus it says she stands as Empress. This person would be treated as a Nyogo or Empress, and looked up to as Mother of the Country or Retired Empress. Saying what fortunate happiness, since her name was Aoi-no-Mae, privately people whispered "Aoi-no-Nyogo" and so on. The Emperor heard this, and after that did not summon her. It was not that his affection was exhausted, but only that he feared the censure of the world. Therefore, he was constantly prone to reciting poetry and only entered the night palace.

[6.3.2] The Regent of that time, Matsudono (Motofusa), thought it a painful matter. Intending to console him, he hurriedly visited the palace and reported, "Regarding the matter of your heart being set in that way, what is the problem? I think the attendant lady should be summoned quickly. There is no need to ask about her rank; I, Motofusa, will immediately make her my adopted daughter." When he reported this, the Emperor said, "Well now. What you say is true, but there seem to be examples of such things after abdicating the throne. While properly on the throne, such a thing would be a censure for future generations." And he did not listen. The Regent Lord, powerless, suppressed his tears and withdrew. After that, on green thin paper of especially deep color, the Emperor wrote an old poem, remembering it.

lg.l: Though I hide it, my love appears in my face, so that people ask if I am thinking of something.

div.p: [6.3.3] Reizei Shōshō Takafusa received this handwriting and passed it to the said Aoi-no-Mae; she blushed, and saying she felt unwell, returned to her home, lay down for five or six days, and finally passed away. "For the sake of one day of the Lord's favor, the concubine mistakes a hundred years of life." This refers to such a thing. Long ago, when Tang Taizong intended to bring the daughter of Zheng Renji into the Yuanguan Hall, Wei Zheng remonstrated, "That daughter is already betrothed to the Lu clan." So he stopped bringing her into the palace; the Emperor's heart did not differ from this in the slightest.

[6.4.1] The Emperor was sunk in thoughts of longing. Intending to console him, a lady-in-waiting called Kogō-dono was presented from the Empress's quarters. This lady was the daughter of Sakuramachi Chūnagon Shigenori-kyō, the greatest beauty in the palace, and a master of the koto. She was a lady whom Reizei Dainagon Takafusa-kyō had courted when he was still a Minor Captain. The Minor Captain at first composed poems and wrote letters, grieving in love, but there was no sign of her yielding; however, perhaps her heart weakened at his lamentations, and she finally yielded. However, now that she was summoned by the Lord, in her helpless sadness, she could not dry her sleeves soaked with tears of insatiable parting. The Minor Captain constantly visited the palace, hoping to catch a glimpse of Kogō-dono even from afar. Though he walked back and forth and loitered around the blinds near the room where she was, Kogō-dono thought that since she had been summoned by our Lord, whatever the Minor Captain said, she should not exchange words or look at letters, and she did not even give him a message. The Minor Captain, hoping for a chance, composed a poem and threw it inside the blinds where Kogō-dono was.

lg.l: Unable to bear the thought, my heart is in the sky (void); though Chika no Shiogama in Michinoku is near, it is of no use.

div.p: [6.4.2] Kogō-dono thought she wanted to reply immediately, but perhaps feeling guilty towards the Lord, she did not even take it in her hand to look. Immediately she had a girl attendant pick it up and throw it out into the courtyard. The Minor Captain felt it was heartless and resentful, but fearing someone might see, he felt dread, hurriedly picked it up, put it in his bosom, and left. Turning back again:

lg.l: Will you not even take the letter in your hand now? Even if you have abandoned me in your heart.

div.p: [6.4.3] Since it was difficult to meet in this world now, rather than living and suffering, he wished only to die.

[6.4.4] The Lay Priest Prime Minister heard this; the Empress was his daughter, and Reizei Shōshō was his son-in-law. Having two sons-in-law taken by Kogō-dono, he proclaimed, "No, no, as long as Kogō exists, the world will not be good. I will summon her and destroy her." Kogō-dono leaked this news and said, "Whatever happens to me is fine, but it is painful for the Lord." And leaving the palace at dusk one day, she disappeared, her whereabouts unknown. The Emperor's grief was extraordinary; during the day he entered the night palace and choked on tears, and at night he appeared in the Southern Hall and consoled himself by looking at the moonlight. The Lay Priest Prime Minister heard this and said, "The Lord is depressed because of Kogō. If that is so..." And he did not allow the attending ladies-in-waiting to serve, and since he despised the subjects who visited the palace, fearing the Lay Priest's authority, no one visited. The Palace seemed all the more ominous.

[6.4.5] Thus it became past the tenth of the eighth month. Although the sky was clear without shadows, the Emperor, clouded by tears, saw the moonlight dimly. As it reached late night, he called "Is anyone there? Is anyone there?" but no one answered. Danjō-no-Shōhitsu Nakakuni happened to be on night watch that night and was waiting far in the distance; when he answered "Nakakuni," the Emperor said, "Come closer. I have an order to give." Wondering what it was, he approached the Emperor, who asked, "Do you perhaps know the whereabouts of Kogō?" Nakakuni said, "How could I know? I absolutely do not know." "Is it true? There is someone who says Kogō is in a house with a single folding door or something in the vicinity of Saga. Even if you do not know the owner's name, could you find her?" When he said this, Nakakuni said, "Unless I know the owner's name, how can I find her?" "Truly," the Emperor said, and shed tears from his dragon face.

[6.4.6] Nakakuni thought carefully; truly, Kogō-dono played the koto. In this moonlight, remembering the Lord, she surely would not fail to play the koto. When she played at the palace, Nakakuni was summoned for the role of flute, so he would know the sound of that koto anywhere. How many houses can there be in Saga? If he went around searching, why should he not hear it? Thinking thus, he said, "If that is so, even if I do not know the owner's name, I will try to go and find her. However, even if I find her, if I speak without a letter from you, she may think it is empty talk. I will go receiving your letter." The Emperor said "Truly," wrote a letter, and gave it to him. "Go riding a horse of the Bureau," he commanded.
Nakakuni received a horse of the Bureau, raised his whip in the bright moon, and went wandering without knowing the specific place. Recalling the poem "In this mountain village where small deer cry," the autumn season in the vicinity of Saga must have felt particularly moving. Whenever he found a house with a single folding door, thinking "Is she in here?", he stopped and listened, but there was no place where a koto was being played. Thinking she might have gone to a temple, he went around checking temples starting with Shakadō, but he did not see any lady resembling Kogō-dono. To return empty-handed would be worse than not going at all. He thought he would wander anywhere from here, but everywhere is the King's land, and there is no lodging to hide oneself. He worried about what to do. Truly, Hōrin-ji is near; perhaps invited by the moonlight she has gone to worship there? Thinking this, he turned his horse in that direction.

[6.4.7] Near the side of Kameyama, in the direction where there was a grove of pines, he heard a faint koto. Wondering if it was the storm on the peak or the wind in the pines, or the sound of the koto of the person he sought, though unsure, he urged his horse on; inside a place with a single folding door, a koto was being played clearly. Stopping to listen, it was unmistakably the sound of Kogō-dono's plectrum. When he listened to what the music was, it was the piece called "Sōfuren" (Thinking of the Husband), which sings of longing for a husband. Indeed, remembering the Lord, though there are many pieces, the elegance of playing this piece! Feeling grateful, he pulled out his flute from his waist, played a little, and knocked on the gate "hoto-hoto"; immediately the playing stopped. In a loud voice he said, "This is Nakakuni, come as a messenger from the Palace. Please open up." Though he knocked again and again, no one answered. After a while, there was the sound of someone coming out from inside; thinking happily, he waited; unfastening the lock, opening the gate a crack, a young lady-in-waiting, lovely, poked only her face out and said, "You must have the wrong gate. This is not a place to receive a messenger from the Palace." Thinking it would be bad if she replied thus, shut the gate, and fastened the lock, he pushed it open and entered. Sitting on the edge of the veranda by the double doors, he said, "Why are you living in such a place? The Lord is depressed because of you, and his life seems already in danger. You may think I speak idly. I have come bringing a letter." And he took it out and presented it. The lady-in-waiting from before took it and passed it to Kogō-dono. When she opened and looked at it, it was truly the Lord's handwriting. Immediately she wrote a reply, tied it, added a set of lady's robes, and put it out. Nakakuni hung the lady's robes on his shoulder and said, "If I were another messenger, receiving a reply would be enough, but how can you forget the service when Nakakuni was summoned for the role of flute when you played the koto daily in the Palace? To return without hearing a direct reply is exceedingly regrettable." When he said this, Kogō-dono perhaps thought it true, and replied herself. "You must have heard it there too. Since I heard that the Lay Priest Prime Minister said only exceedingly fearful things, in my wretchedness I fled the Palace; since this is such a dwelling, I have not played the koto recently, but since I cannot stay here, and I have decided to go to the depths of Ohara starting tomorrow, the mistress of the house urged me, saying 'Regretting the parting of just tonight, and now the night is late, there will be no one listening,' so indeed, longing for the past was nostalgic, and while I played the familiar koto, you easily found me." Saying this, she could not hold back her tears, and Nakakuni also dampened his sleeves. After a while, Nakakuni suppressed his tears and said, "That you decide to go to the depths of Ohara starting tomorrow must mean you intend to change your appearance (become a nun). You must absolutely not do so. Now, what shall be done about the Lord's grief? Do not leave here." So saying, leaving the horse grooms and attendants he had brought to guard the house, he whipped the Bureau horse and returned to the Palace; it was faintly dawning. "By now he must have retired. Through whom should I report?" So saying, he had the Bureau horse tied up, hung the lady's robes on the partition of the Ha-ne-uma, and went to the Southern Hall; the Emperor was still in his night seat. "Flying south, facing north, it is hard to entrust cold and warmth to the autumn hawk. Coming out in the east, flowing to the west, I only entrust my gaze to the dawn moon." While he was reciting this, Nakakuni came forward directly. He presented Kogō-dono's reply. The Emperor was impressed not in a common way, and commanded, "You, bring her here immediately tonight." Although he feared the Lay Priest Prime Minister hearing of it, since this was also an Imperial Command, he arranged a carriage with servants and ox-drivers cleanly, went to Saga, and though she said in various ways she would not come, he persuaded her in various ways, put her in the carriage, and brought her to the Palace; hiding her in a secluded place, she was summoned nightly, and eventually a Princess was born. This Princess was Bōmon-no-Nyoin. How did the Lay Priest Prime Minister hear of it? "That Kogō had disappeared was a lie without a trace." So saying, he captured Kogō-dono, forced her to become a nun, and released her. Although taking the tonsure was Kogō-dono's original desire, being made a nun against her will, at the age of twenty-three, she wasted away in dark ink-dyed robes and lived in the vicinity of Saga. These were terrible matters. It is rumored that due to such things, the Emperor fell ill and finally passed away.

[6.4.8] For the Cloistered Emperor, grief only continued thick and fast. In the past Eiman era, his first son, Emperor Nijō, passed away. In the seventh month of the second year of Angen, his grandson Emperor Rokujō passed away. Pointing to the stars of the Milky Way, pledging that if in heaven they would be birds with shared wings, if on earth trees with joined branches, Kenreimon-in, with whom his bond was not shallow, was invaded by the autumn mist and vanished like the morning dew. Although years and months have piled up, thinking of it like a parting of yesterday or today, his tears had not yet exhausted when in the fifth month of the fourth year of Jishō, the second Prince, Takakura Prince, was killed. Since even the New Retired Emperor, whom he relied on for this life and the next, had preceded him, anyhow, only uncontrollable tears proceeded. "Of sorrows, the most sorrowful is none other than being old and left behind by a child. Of regrets, the most regretful is none other than dying young before one's parents." Now indeed he realized the trace of the brush written by Minister Chōkō (Sugawara no Michizane) when he was left behind by his son Chōmei. Thus, he did not neglect the recitation of the One Vehicle Sutra, and accumulated the practice of the Three Mysteries. Since the realm was in mourning, the people of the Great Palace also lined up, and their flowery sleeves must have drooped.

[6.5.1] Perhaps thinking it fearful that he had behaved so painfully and heartlessly, the Lay Priest Prime Minister, intending to console the Cloistered Emperor, presented the daughter of the lady-in-waiting of Itsukushima in Aki, born to her, who had turned eighteen and was elegant and beautiful, to the Cloistered Emperor. Many high-ranking ladies-in-waiting were selected to accompany her. Many nobles and courtiers attended, and it was just like the entry of a Nyogo. Since not even fourteen days had passed since the Retired Emperor passed away, people whispered privately that it should not be so.

[6.5.2] Meanwhile, at that time in Shinano Province, it was heard that there was a Genji called Kiso Kaja Yoshinaka. He was the son of Tatewaki Senjō Yoshikata, the second son of the late Rokujō Hangan Tameyoshi. His father Yoshikata was killed by the Evil Genta Yoshihira of Kamakura on the sixteenth of the eighth month of the second year of Kyūju. At that time Yoshinaka was two years old; his mother held him weeping, crossed to Shinano, went to Kiso Chūzō Kanetō, and said, "Please raise this child somehow and show him as a man." Kanetō received him and raised him devotedly for over twenty years. As he gradually grew up, his strength was superior in the world, and his heart was peerlessly brave. A rare strong archer and elite soldier, on horse or on foot; people said that even Tamuramaro, Toshihito, Shōgun Yogo, Muneyori, Yasumasa, his ancestor Yorimitsu, or Yoshiie Ason of ancient times—how could they surpass him?

[6.5.3] One time he summoned his foster father Kanetō and said: "Hyōe-no-Suke Yoritomo has already raised a rebellion, subjugated the eight eastern provinces, and is coming up from the Tōkaidō intending to chase down the Heike. I, Yoshinaka, wish to subjugate the Tōsandō and Hokurikudō, attack and defeat the Heike even one day sooner, and be called, for example, the two Shoguns of Japan." When he hinted this, Chūzō Kanetō was greatly awed and pleased, saying, "It is for that purpose that I have raised you until now. Speaking thus, you truly seem like a descendant of the Hachiman Lord." And he immediately planned a rebellion.

[6.5.4] Accompanying Kanetō, he constantly went up to the Capital and observed the behavior and condition of the Heike people. When he performed his coming-of-age ceremony at thirteen, he went to Hachiman, and before Hachiman Daibosatsu said, "My grandfather of four generations back, Yoshiie Ason, became the son of this deity and was named Hachiman Tarō. I should follow his traces." And tying up his topknot before the treasure front of Hachiman Daibosatsu, he named himself Kiso Jirō Yoshinaka. Kanetō, saying "First a circular letter should be sent," persuaded Nei no Koyata and Unno no Yukichika in Shinano Province, and they did not disobey. Starting with them, there was no grass or tree among the soldiers of Shinano Province that did not bow to him. In Kōzuke Province, due to the friendship of the late Tatewaki Senjō Yoshikata, the soldiers of Tago District all followed him. Taking the opportunity of the end of the Heike, he intended to fulfill the long-held desire of the Genji.

[6.6.1] The place called Kiso is at the southern edge of Shinano, bordering Mino, so it is quite close to the Capital. The Heike people heard rumors and made a commotion, saying, "Even the rebellion of the eastern provinces is enough, and now the northern provinces too; what is this?" The Lay Priest Prime Minister said, "That person is not frightening. Even if the soldiers of Shinano Province follow him, in Echigo Province there are the descendants of Shōgun Yogo, Jō no Tarō Sukenaga and the same Shirō Sukeshige; they are brothers with a large force. If I give the order, they will easily kill him." Though he said this, many whispered privately, "How will it be?"

[6.6.2] On the first of the second month, the resident of Echigo Province, Jō no Tarō Sukenaga, was appointed Governor of Echigo. It was rumored that this was a plan to make him pursue Kiso. On the seventh of the same month, at the houses of Ministers and below, dedications of Sonshō Darani, Fudō Myōō, and copying of sutras were performed. This was also for caution against military disturbance.

[6.6.3] On the ninth of the same month, hearing that Musashi-no-Gon-no-Kami Nyūdō Yoshimoto, residing in Ishikawa District of Kawachi Province, and his son Ishikawa Hangandai Yoshikane had betrayed the Heike, communicated with Hyōe-no-Suke Yoritomo, and were about to flee to the eastern provinces, the Lay Priest Prime Minister immediately sent a punitive force. The generals of the punitive force were Minamoto no Tayū Hangan Suesada and Settsu Hangan Morizumi, setting out with a total force of over three thousand horsemen. Inside the castle, led by Musashi-no-Gon-no-Kami Nyūdō Yoshimoto and his son Hangandai Yoshikane, the force did not exceed about one hundred horsemen. Making war cries and exchanging arrows, they fought repeatedly for several hours. The soldiers inside the castle fought to the limit of their ability, and many died fighting. Musashi-no-Gon-no-Kami Nyūdō Yoshimoto died in battle. His son Ishikawa Hangandai Yoshikane was severely wounded and taken alive. On the eleventh of the same month, the head of the priest Yoshimoto entered the Capital and was paraded through the main streets. Parading a rebel head during Imperial mourning was rumored to follow the precedent of parading the head of Former Tsushima-no-Kami Minamoto no Yoshichika at the time of Emperor Horikawa's death.

[6.6.4] On the twelfth of the same month, an express messenger arrived from Chinzei (Kyushu); Usa Daigūji Kimimichi reported that the people of Kyushu, starting with Ogata Saburō, down to Usuki, Hetsugi, and the Matsura Party, had all turned against the Heike and sided with the Genji; "Even the eastern and northern provinces turning is bad enough, but what is this?" they said, clapping their hands and clamoring together.

[6.6.5] On the sixteenth of the same month, an express messenger arrived from Iyo Province; since around the winter of last year, starting with Kōno Shirō Michikiyo, the people of Shikoku all turned against the Heike and sided with the Genji; the resident of Bingo Province, Nuka no Nyūdō Saijaku, being deeply loyal to the Heike, crossed over to Iyo Province and killed Kōno Shirō Michikiyo at Takanao Castle on the border of Dōzen and Dōgo. When his son Kōno Shirō Michinobu's father was killed, he was at the place of his maternal uncle, Nuta Jirō, a resident of Aki Province, so he was not present. Michinobu was a man who could not rest having had his father killed. He watched for a chance to kill Saijaku by any means. Nuka no Nyūdō Saijaku, after killing Kōno Shirō Michikiyo, quelled the violence in Shikoku, and on the fifteenth of the first month of this year, crossed to Tomo in Bingo, gathered courtesans and entertainers, played and drank; while he was drunk and lying down unaware of front or back, Kōno Shirō, conspiring with over one hundred desperate men, attacked with a shout. Although there were over three hundred men on Saijaku's side, since it was a sudden event, they panicked unexpectedly; shooting down and cutting down those who stood to fight, they first captured Saijaku alive, crossed to Iyo Province, dragged him to Takanao Castle where the father had been killed, and it was rumored they cut off his head with a saw. Also, it was rumored they crucified him.

[6.7.1] After that, the people of Shikoku all followed Kōno Shirō. Kumano Bettō Tanzō also had received heavy favors from the Heike, but it was heard that he too turned and sided with the Genji. In general, the eastern and northern provinces have all turned. The Southern Sea and Western Sea are like this. The uprising of barbarians startles the ear, and omens of rebellion are reported frequently. The Four Barbarians have suddenly risen. Saying the world will be lost right now, even those who were not necessarily of the Heike clan, people with hearts, all grieved and lamented.

[6.7.2] On the twenty-third of the same month, there was a council of nobles. Former Major Captain of the Right Munemori-kyō said, "Although a punitive force went to Bandō, they did not achieve anything significant. This time, Munemori will accept the Great Generalship and go." When he said this, the various nobles flattered him, saying, "It will be magnificent." It was ordered that nobles and courtiers, those holding military offices, and those involved with bow and arrow should accompany Munemori-kyō as Great General to pursue and strike the villains of the eastern and northern provinces.

[6.7.3] On the twenty-seventh of the same month, it was heard that Former Major Captain of the Right Munemori-kyō had already departed for the eastern provinces to pursue the Genji, but because the Lay Priest Prime Minister felt unwell, he stayed behind. Saying that he fell seriously ill from the following twenty-eighth, the Capital and Rokuhara whispered, "Alas, it is done." From the day the Lay Priest Prime Minister fell ill, he could not even pass water down his throat, and the heat within his body was like burning fire. For anyone entering within four or five bays (approx. 10 meters) of where he lay, the heat was unbearable. The only thing he said was "Hot! Hot!" It did not seem like a trivial matter at all. They brought down water from the Senju Well on Mt. Hiei, filled a stone boat, and lowered him into it to cool him, but the water boiled up tremendously and soon became hot water. Thinking it might help, they let water from a conduit flow on him, but the water splattered and did not touch him, as if hitting burning stone or iron. The water that hit him by chance turned into flames and burned, so black smoke filled the hall, and flames swirled up. This reminded one of long ago when Sōzu Hōzō went at the invitation of King Yama, asked for his mother's place of birth, and King Yama, pitying him, sent him to the Scorching Heat Hell accompanied by prison guards. When he entered inside the iron gate, flames rose into the sky like meteors, reaching many hundreds of yojana; now indeed this was realized.

[6.7.4] The dream seen by the Lay Priest Prime Minister's wife, the Nii-Dono, was terrifying. A carriage burning fiercely with raging fire entered the gate. Among those standing in front and behind, there were some with faces like horses, and some with faces like oxen. In front of the carriage, they stood an iron tablet on which only the character "Mu" (No/Not) was visible. The Nii-Dono, in the dream, asked, "Where is that from?" They answered, "We have come from the office of Enma (Yama) to welcome the Lay Priest Prime Minister of the Taira."
"Now, what is that tablet?" she asked. "Because of the sin of burning the sixteen-jo gold and copper Vairochana Buddha in Jambudvipa, it has been decided in the office of Enma that he shall fall to the bottom of the Mugen (Avici/Uninterrupted) Hell; the 'Mu' has been written, but the character 'Gen' has not yet been written." Thus they spoke. The Nii-Dono woke up startled, sweating profusely, and when she told this to people, everyone who heard it had their hair stand on end. Though they donated gold, silver, and seven treasures to sacred Buddhas and shrines, and brought out everything from horses, saddles, armor, helmets, bows, arrows, to long and short swords to pray, there was no effect. The sons and daughters gathered by his pillow and lamented and grieved what to do, but it did not seem there was any hope.

[6.7.5] On the second of the intercalary second month, although the heat was hard to bear, the Nii-Dono approached his pillow and said weeping, "Seeing your condition, hope seems to diminish day by day. If you have any thoughts left in this world, speak them while you are still somewhat conscious." The Lay Priest Prime Minister, who had been so vigorous in days past, now truly in pain, said under his breath: "Since Hōgen and Heiji, I have quelled enemies of the court many times, rewards have exceeded my status, and I have unworthily reached the position of Prime Minister, the ancestor of the Emperor, and glory extends to my descendants. I have no regrets left in this life. However, the one thing I regret is not seeing the head of the exile of Izu Province, Former Sahyōe-no-Suke Yoritomo. After I die, you must not build temples or pagodas, nor perform Buddhist services for me. Immediately send a punitive force, cut off Yoritomo's head, and hang it in front of my grave. That will be my memorial service." That he spoke thus was deeply sinful.

[6.7.6] On the fourth of the same month, tormented by illness, as a last resort, they poured water on a board and he rolled on it, but he did not feel relieved. Fainting in agony, he finally died in convulsions. The sound of horses and carriages rushing about echoed in the heavens and shook the earth. Even if it were the death of the Lord of the Whole Heaven, the Master of Ten Thousand Chariots, it seemed it would not surpass this. This year he became sixty-four; though it should not be called a death of old age, since his fate suddenly ran out, the efficacy of great and secret rituals was gone, the majesty of the Gods and Three Treasures vanished, and the Deities did not protect him. How much more so regarding ordinary measures? Though tens of thousands of soldiers who pledged loyalty to die in his place lined up above and below the hall, they could not fight back the demon of impermanence, invisible to the eye and unrelated to strength, even for a moment. He must have gone alone to the sky of the journey of the Mountain of Death, the River of Three Crossings, and the Intermediate State of the Yellow Springs, from which no one returns. Perhaps only the sins he created day by day became the jailers and came to welcome him. These were pitiful matters. Since he could not remain as he was, on the seventh of the same month, he was cremated at Otagi, and Enjitsu Hōgen hung his bones around his neck, went down to Settsu Province, and placed them in Kyō-no-shima. Though he was a person who raised his name and shook his authority throughout the single province of Japan, his body became smoke for a moment rising into the sky of the Capital, and his remains rested for a while, played with by the sand of the beach, and became empty earth.

[6.8.1] Immediately on the night of the funeral, there were many strange occurrences. The West Eighth Avenue residence, made of polished jewels and inlaid with gold and silver, suddenly burned down that night. Although houses burning is a common custom, it was an appalling event. Wondering whose doing it was, it was rumored to be arson. Also that night, to the south of Rokuhara, voices of twenty or thirty people, if they were human, beat out a rhythm saying "Joyful is the water sound, the water of the waterfall," danced and leaped, and laughed loudly. In the past first month, the Retired Emperor had passed away, and the realm was in mourning. After an interval of only a month or two, the Lay Priest Prime Minister died. Down to the lowly men and women, who would not grieve? This was considered the work of Tengu no matter how one looked at it, so among the Heike samurai, over one hundred impetuous young men followed the laughing voices, searched and looked; at the Cloistered Emperor's Hōjūji Palace, where the Cloistered Emperor had not visited for the past two or three years, there was a palace guard named Bizen-no-Zenji Motozune. Twenty or thirty acquaintances of that Motozune had gathered under cover of night and were drinking sake; at first they drank saying "Make no sound at such a time," but gradually getting drunk, they danced and leaped like this. With a shout, they rushed in, captured about thirty drunken men without letting a single one escape, brought them to Rokuhara, and dragged them into the courtyard where Former Major Captain of the Right Munemori-kyō was. When he investigated the details carefully, saying "Truly, one should not kill men who are drunk to that extent," he pardoned them all. After a person dies, even people of low status strike bells morning and evening and read the daily repentance liturgy as is the custom, but after this Zenmon (Kiyomori) died, there was no preparation for offerings to Buddha or monks. Morning and evening, other than strategies for war and battle, there was nothing else.

[6.8.2] In general, the manner of his final illness was terrible, but there were many things that did not seem like an ordinary person. When he visited Hiyoshi Shrine, many nobles of his own and other houses accompanied him, and people said that even the pilgrimage to Kasuga or the visit to Uji by the Regent Lord could hardly surpass this. Also, more than anything, his construction of Kyō-no-shima (Sutra Island) at Fukuhara, so that ships coming and going up and down have no trouble until the present age, is magnificent. That island began construction in the first ten days of the second month of the first year of Ōho, but in the eighth month of the same year, a great wind suddenly blew and great waves rose, washing it all away. In the last ten days of the third month of the third year, with Awa Minbu Shigeyoshi as the administrator, they had it built; although there was a council of nobles saying human pillars (sacrifices) should be set up, saying it was a sin, they wrote all the sutras on the faces of stones and built it; therefore it was named Kyōgashima (Sutra Island).

div.head: 6.9. Jishinbō

div.p: [6.9.1] Old people said, "Although Lord Kiyomori is thought to be an evil man, in truth he is the reincarnation of Jie Sōjō." The reason is, there is a mountain temple called Seichō-ji in Settsu Province. The resident monk of that temple, Jishinbō Son'e, was originally a scholar monk of Mt. Hiei, a holder of the Lotus Sutra for many years. However, developing a desire for the Way, he left the mountain and spent years and months at this temple, so everyone took refuge in him. On the night of the twenty-second of the twelfth month of the past second year of Jōan, as he was leaning on an armrest reading the Lotus Sutra, around the hour of the Ox (2 AM), neither dream nor reality, a man of about fifty wearing a white robe and tall eboshi, with straw sandals and leggings, came holding a standing letter. Son'e asked, "Where are you from?" "I am a messenger from the Palace of King Yama. Here is a decree." And he handed the standing letter to Son'e. When Son'e opened and looked at it:

div.div: Invitation. Jishinbō Son'e of Seichō-ji, Settsu Province, Great Japan, Jambudvipa. On the coming 26th, at the Daigokuden of the Castle of Enma-ra (Yama), ten thousand sutra holders shall recite ten thousand copies of the Lotus Sutra. Therefore, you must attend. By the order of King Yama, the invitation is as above.

div.p: [6.9.2] Jōan 2nd Year, 12th Month, 22nd Day. Office of Enma.

[6.9.3] Thus it was written. Since it was not something Son'e could refuse, he felt he should write a letter of acceptance immediately, and woke up. Thinking entirely that he would die, he told this matter to the head of the cloister, Kōyōbō. Everyone thought it a miracle. Son'e chanted the name of Amida with his mouth, and in his heart contemplated the compassionate vow of welcoming to the Pure Land. Gradually, when the night of the twenty-fifth deepened, he went before the usual Buddha, leaned on his armrest as usual, and chanted the Nembutsu and read sutras. Around the hour of the Rat (midnight), feeling very sleepy, he returned to his living quarters and lay down. Around the hour of the Ox, two demons dressed in white robes as before came and urged him saying "You must come quickly"; when he tried to decline the King Yama's order, he was very afraid. When he tried to go, he had absolutely no robe or bowl. When he thought this, a priestly robe naturally wrapped around his body and hung on his shoulders, and a gold bowl descended from heaven. Two youths, two attendant monks, ten lower monks, and a great carriage of seven treasures appeared in front of the temple quarters. Son'e rejoiced extraordinarily and immediately boarded the carriage. The attendant monks faced northwest, flew through the sky, and before long arrived at the Palace of King Yama.

[6.9.4] Looking at the form of the Royal Palace, the outer walls were vast, and the inside was spacious. Inside there was a Daigokuden made of seven treasures. It was high, wide, and golden, not something ordinary people could praise. After the service of that day ended, when the invited monks were all returning, Son'e stood at the south central gate and looked across at the Daigokuden; the officials and multitudes of the Underworld were all bowing before the Dharma King Enma. Son'e thought it a rare pilgrimage. Taking this opportunity, intending to ask about the afterlife, he went to the Daigokuden. While the two youths pointed the way, the two attendant monks held boxes, and the ten lower monks formed a line, as they gradually walked closer, the Dharma King Enma and the officials and multitudes of the Underworld all descended to welcome him. Tamon and Jikoku manifested as the two youths, Yakuō Bosatsu and Yūse Bosatsu transformed into the two attendant monks. The Ten Raksasa Daughters manifested as the ten lower monks, following and serving him. King Yama asked, saying, "The other monks have all returned. Why has the Holy Priest come?" "To inquire about the place of the afterlife." "However, rebirth or non-rebirth depends on a person's belief or disbelief, etc." King Yama again ordered the officials of the Underworld, saying, "The box of writings of good deeds of this Holy Priest is in the southern treasure house. Take it out and show him the record of his life's practice and converting others." The officials obeyed, went to the southern treasure house, and brought back one document box. Immediately opening the lid, they read it all to him. Son'e lamented and wept, saying, "I only pray, please pity me, teach me the method to leave birth and death, and show me the direct path to realize great enlightenment." At that time King Yama pitied and taught him, reciting various verses. The officials dipped their brushes and wrote them down one by one.

div.div: Wife, children, throne, wealth, and retainers, When one dies, not one comes to accompany. Only the karma-demons constantly follow, Binding me, suffering and screaming without end.

div.p: [6.9.5] King Yama finished reciting this verse and immediately entrusted that document to Son'e. Son'e rejoiced extraordinarily and said, "A person called the Great Prime Minister of Japan has selected Wada-no-Misaki in Settsu Province, built houses over ten chō on four sides, invited many sutra holders like today's assembly of ten thousand monks, seated them on one side in each quarter, and is performing diligent service of preaching and reading sutras." When he said this, King Yama rejoiced and admired, saying, "That Lay Priest is not an ordinary person; he is an incarnation of Jie Sōjō. For the sake of protecting the Tendai Buddha Dharma, he has been reborn in Japan. Therefore, there is a text for bowing to him three times every day. Take this text and present it to that person." And:

div.div: Respectful bow to Great Sōjō Jie, Protector of the Tendai Buddha Dharma, Manifesting initially as a Shogun, Benefiting sentient beings of evil karma equally.

div.p: [6.9.6] Son'e received this, and when he left the south central gate of the Daigokuden, ten officials stood outside the gate, put him in the carriage, and followed in front and behind. Again, they flew through the sky and returned. Feeling like he was dreaming, he breathed out. Son'e took this, went to West Eighth Avenue, and presented it to the Lay Priest Prime Minister; he rejoiced extraordinarily, treated him in various ways, gave him various gifts, and as a reward made him a Risshi (Master of Discipline). Thus people knew that Lord Kiyomori was the reincarnation of Jie Sōjō.

[6.10.1] Also, a certain person said that Lord Kiyomori was not Tadamori's son, but in truth was the son of Retired Emperor Shirakawa. The reason is, in the past Eikyū era, there was a favorite called the Gion Lady (Gion-no-Nyogo). The dwelling of that lady was in the vicinity of Gion at the foot of Higashiyama. Retired Emperor Shirakawa constantly visited her. One time, taking along one or two courtiers and a few North Guards (Hokumen), he made a secret visit; since it was the evening past the twentieth of the fifth month, it was a darkness where one could not see one's fingers, and the May rain made it dark and truly gloomy; near the lodging of that lady there was a chapel. Beside the chapel a glowing thing appeared. Its head sparkled like polished silver needles, and it raised what seemed to be left and right hands; in one hand it held something like a mallet, and in the other hand it held a glowing object. Both Lord and subjects said, "Ah, how terrifying. This must be a real demon. The thing in its hand must be the famous Uchide-no-Kozuchi (Magic Mallet). What shall we do?" While they were in a panic, Tadamori was at that time still a low-ranking North Guard accompanying them; [the Emperor] summoned him and said, "Among these, you are the one. Shoot that thing to death, or cut it down." Tadamori bowed, received the order, and advanced. Privately he thought, "This thing does not look so fierce. It must be a fox or tanuki. If I shoot it or cut it to death, it would be extremely regrettable. I will capture it alive." He approached it. It flashed brightly now and then, two or three times; Tadamori ran up and grappled with it firmly. Being grappled, it panicked, saying "What is this?" It was not a shapeshifter, it was a human. At that time, high and low lit fires in their hands and looked at it; it was a priest of about sixty. For example, he was a servant priest of the chapel, intending to offer lights; he had put oil in a vessel called a hand-jar, and in one hand held an earthenware dish with fire. The rain was falling heavily; not wanting to get wet, he had tied wheat straw on his head like a hat and wore it; the wheat straw shone in the fire of the earthenware dish, looking like silver needles. The nature of the matter was revealed one by one. "If we had shot or cut this to death, how regrettable it would have been. Tadamori's behavior was indeed thoughtful. One who takes up bow and arrow is elegant." So saying, as a reward, he gave the Gion Lady, whom he loved so much, to Tadamori.

[6.10.2] Now, since that lady was pregnant with the Retired Emperor's child, he said, "If the child born is a girl, I will make her my child. If it is a boy, make him Tadamori's son and raise him to take up the bow and arrow." And she gave birth to a boy. Although he looked for a chance to report this, there was no suitable opportunity; once when Retired Emperor Shirakawa made a pilgrimage to Kumano, he rested his palanquin for a while at a place called Itoga-saka in Kii Province. There were many nukago (yams) in the thicket; Tadamori put them in his sleeve, went before the Emperor, and said:

lg.l: The potato's (imo/beloved's) child has become of crawling age.

div.p: [6.10.3] When he said this, the Retired Emperor immediately understood and replied:

lg.l: Tadamori take it and raise it.

div.p: [6.10.4] Thus he added the phrase. From then on, he treated him as his own child. Since this young lord cried excessively at night, the Retired Emperor heard of it, composed one poem, and sent it down.

lg.l: Though he cries at night, Tadamori raise him; in the latter age, he may become pure (Kiyo) and prosperous (Mori).

div.p: [6.10.5] Thus, he was named Kiyomori. At the age of twelve he became Hyōe-no-Suke. At the age of eighteen he became Fourth Rank Hyōe-no-Suke; people who did not know the details said, "This is for a person of noble family." Retired Emperor Toba also knew of this and said, "Kiyomori's nobility is not inferior to anyone."

[6.10.6] Long ago, Emperor Tenji gave a pregnant consort to the Great Weaver Crown (Kamatari), saying, "If the child born of this consort is a girl, I will make her my child; if it is a boy, make him the minister's child." And she gave birth to a boy. This was the founder of Tōnomine, Jōe Oshō. Since there was such a precedent in ancient times, in the latter age, was it because the Great Prime Minister Taira was truly the son of Retired Emperor Shirakawa that he thought of such difficult things as the great matter of the realm and moving the capital?

[6.11.1] On the twentieth of the same intercalary second month, Gojō Dainagon Kunitsuna-kyō passed away. He was a person whose bond with the Great Prime Minister Taira was deep and whose loyalty was not shallow. Perhaps due to the depth of their bond, he fell ill on the same day and died in the same month. This Dainagon was the descendant of the eighth generation from Kanesuke Chūnagon, and the son of Former Umanosuke Morikuni. He did not even become a Kurando (Chamberlain), but served as a Shinshi-no-Zōshiki (Advanced Student Servant); in the time of Emperor Konoe, around the Ninpei era, a fire suddenly broke out in the Palace. Although the Emperor appeared in the Southern Hall, not a single Palace Guard attended, and he stood there bewildered; this Kunitsuna had a hand-carriage carried up and said, "At such a time, please ride in such a palanquin." The Emperor rode in it and went out. "Who are you?" he asked. "Shinshi-no-Zōshiki Fujiwara no Kunitsuna," he named himself. "Such a clever person exists; employ him." He was taken in by the Regent of that time, the Lord of Hosshōji, given many estates, and employed; during the same Emperor's reign, when there was a procession to Hachiman, the Ninjō (Dance Master) got drunk on sake, fell into water, wet his costume, and the Sacred Music was delayed; this Kunitsuna said, "Although I am not worthy, I have brought a Ninjō costume." And he brought out a set; wearing this, they prepared and performed the Sacred Music. Although the time had passed a little, the singing voice was clear, and the dancing sleeves matched the rhythm and were delightful. Gods and humans alike are moved by things that penetrate deeply and are delightful. Now indeed one realized even the matter of the Age of Gods when the Rock Door of Heaven was pushed open long ago.

[6.11.2] Furthermore, among this Kunitsuna's ancestors was a man called Yamakage Chūnagon. His child was called Nomu Sōzu (Bishop Like-Nothing), a monk whose wisdom and talent exceeded his status, and who was virtuous and kept the precepts. Around the Shōtai era, when the Cloistered Emperor Kanpyō (Uda) made a procession to the Ōi River, the son of the Minister of the Interior of Kajūji, Lord Takafuji, Izumi-no-Taishō Sadakuni, had his eboshi blown into the river by the storm of Mt. Ogura; holding his topknot with his sleeve, he stood helpless, when this Nomu Sōzu took out an eboshi from his robe box [and gave it to him]. That Sōzu, when his father Yamakage Chūnagon became Dazai Daini and went down to Chinzei (Kyushu), was two years old; his stepmother was evil and, pretending to hold him briefly, dropped him into the sea intending to kill him; his real mother who had died, when alive, saw a cormorant fisherman of Katsura about to feed a turtle to his cormorant, took off the small-sleeved robe she was wearing, exchanged it for the turtle, and released it; intending to repay that kindness, when this young lord was dropped in, the turtle floated up on the water, and carrying him on its shell, saved him. That was a matter of ancient times, so who knows? In the latter age, Kunitsuna-kyō's fame was a rare thing. In the time of the Lord of Hosshōji, he became Chūnagon. After the Lord of Hosshōji passed away, the Lay Priest Prime Minister, having an intent, approached and befriended this person. Since he was a man of great wealth, whatever it was, he invariably sent one kind of gift to the Lay Priest Prime Minister's place every day. Saying that a friend in this life should not surpass this person, he adopted one of his sons, made him take the name Kiyokuni, and also the Lay Priest Prime Minister's fourth son, Tō-no-Chūjō Shigehira, became that Dainagon's son-in-law.

[6.11.3] When the Gosechi of the fourth year of Jishō was held at Fukuhara, courtiers intruded into the Empress's quarters; a certain courtier recited the poem "Bamboo is spotted at the Xiang River bank"; this Dainagon overheard it and said, "Ah, how appalling. I hear this is taboo. I will not listen even if I hear such a thing." And he quietly slipped out. For example, the meaning of this recitation is: Long ago Emperor Yao had two princesses. The elder was called Ehuang, and the younger was called Nüying. Both were consorts of Emperor Shun. After Emperor Shun passed away, when they sent him to the fields of Cangwu and he became smoke, the two consorts, regretting the parting, followed him as far as a place called Xiangpu (Xiang River bank), and as they wept and grieved, their tears fell on the bamboo of the bank and dyed it spotted. After that, they constantly went to that place and played the zither to console themselves. Now if one looks at that place, the bamboo on the bank stands spotted. Clouds trail over the traces where they played the koto; this moving sentiment was made into a fu (poem) by Minister Tachibana. Although this Dainagon was not particularly elegant in literary talent or poetry, since he was such a clever person, he took notice even of such matters. This person never even thought of becoming Dainagon, but his mother went to Kamo Daimyōjin and prayed with all her heart for a hundred days, saying, "I pray, let my child Kunitsuna become Head Chamberlain (Kurando-no-Kami) even for one day." One night she dreamed that a carriage with palm-leaf roofing came and stood at the carriage entrance of her house; when she told this to people, they interpreted it saying, "That means he will become the wife of a high noble." She said, "My years are already advanced. I do not think such a thing will happen now." But her son Kunitsuna becoming Head Chamberlain was fine; his rising to Senior Second Rank Dainagon was indeed magnificent.

[6.11.4] On the twenty-second of the same month, the Cloistered Emperor made a procession to the Retired Emperor's Palace at Hosshōji. That palace was built on the fifteenth of the fourth month of the past third year of Ōho, and the New Hiei and New Kumano shrines were invited nearby; everything down to the landscape and trees was as he wished, but for the past two or three years, due to the evil deeds of the Heike, he could not visit. Since Former Major Captain of the Right Munemori-kyō reported that the dilapidated parts of the palace should be repaired and a procession made, saying there should be no other way, he went immediately. First, looking at the quarters of the late Kenreimon-in, feeling that the pines on the bank and the willows on the shore had aged and the trees had grown tall, facing the lotus of Taiye and the willow of Weiyang, how could tears not come forth? Now indeed he realized the traces of the past of the Southern Palace and Western Palace.

[6.11.5] On the first of the third month, it was ordered that the high priests of the Southern Capital should be restored to their original offices and administer their branch temples and manors as before. On the third of the same month, the rebuilding of the Great Buddha Hall began. The administrator for the beginning of the work was rumored to be Kurando Sashōben Yukitaka. This Yukitaka had visited Hachiman in a previous year and spent the night; in a dream, a heavenly youth with bound hair came out from inside the treasure hall and said, "This is the messenger of the Great Bodhisattva. When you are the administrator of the Great Buddha Hall, you shall hold this." Seeing a dream where he was given a shaku (baton), when he woke and looked, it was there in reality. "Ah, how strange. At present, for what reason should I become the administrator of the Great Buddha Hall?" Putting it in his bosom, he returned to his lodging and stored it deeply; but due to the evil deeds of the Heike, during the burning of the Southern Capital, this Yukitaka was selected from among the Controllers and served as the administrator for the beginning of the work; how magnificent his karma was.

[6.11.6] On the tenth of the same third month, the Deputy of Mino Province reported to the Capital by express horse that the Genji of the eastern provinces had already attacked up to Owari Province, blocked the roads, and were not letting people pass; so a punitive force was immediately dispatched. The Great Generals were Sahyōe-no-Kami Tomomori, Sachūjō Kiyotsune, and Komatsu Shōshō Arimori, setting out with a total force of over thirty thousand horsemen. Not even fifty days had passed since the Lay Priest Prime Minister passed away; even saying it was a disordered age, these were appalling matters.
