On the Genji side, Jurō Kurando Yukiie and Hyōe-no-Suke's younger brother, Gien, with a total force of over six thousand horsemen, took up positions on both sides of the Owari River (Sunomata River), separating Genji and Heike.

[6.11.7] Around midnight on the sixteenth of the same month, the Genji force of over six thousand horsemen crossed the river and charged shouting into the midst of the thirty thousand Heike horsemen. When day broke on the seventeenth, they exchanged arrows from the hour of the Tiger (4 AM) and fought until dawn, but the Heike side was not the least bit flustered. "The enemy has crossed the river, so their horses and armor are all wet; mark that and kill them!" Saying this, they surrounded them with a large force; "Do not let them escape, do not let them leak out!" Because they attacked thus, the Genji force was reduced to a few remnants, and Great General Yukiie, barely escaping with his life, retreated east from the river. Kyōkō Gien penetrated too deeply and was killed. The Heike immediately crossed the river and went chasing and shooting the Genji. The Genji turned back here and there to defend, but the enemy was a large force, and their side was a small force. It did not seem they could prevail. "It is said, 'Do not put water or marshes behind you.' The strategy of the Genji this time was foolish." Thus people spoke.

[6.11.8] Meanwhile, Great General Jurō Kurando Yukiie crossed into Mikawa Province, pulled up the bridge of the Yahagi River, built walls and shields, and waited. Since the Heike immediately pressed and attacked, unable to hold out, that place too was conquered. If the Heike had continued to attack immediately, the forces of Mikawa and Tōtōmi would likely have followed them, but Great General Sahyōe-no-Kami Tomomori, claiming illness, returned to the Capital from Mikawa Province. This time too, although they broke one formation, since they did not attack the remaining rebels, it was as if they had achieved nothing. For the Heike, the year before last Minister Komatsu died. This year again the Lay Priest Prime Minister passed away. Since it was apparent that their fate was coming to an end, other than those who had received favors for years, there was no one who followed them. In the eastern provinces, even grass and trees all bowed to the Genji.

[6.12.1] Meanwhile, the resident of Echigo Province, Jō no Tarō Sukenaga, was appointed Governor of Echigo. Grateful for the Imperial favor, intending to pursue Kiso, he led soldiers of Echigo, Dewa, and the four districts of Aizu, a total force of over thirty thousand horsemen, and set out on the fifteenth of the same sixth month; at the hour of the Hare (6 AM) on the following sixteenth, as he was about to depart, around midnight, a great wind suddenly blew, heavy rain fell, thunder sounded tremendously, and after the sky cleared, a large hoarse voice in the clouds shouted three times, "Here are those who side with the Heike who burned the sixteen-jo gold and copper Vairochana Buddha in Jambudvipa; seize them!" and passed by. Starting with Jō no Tarō, everyone who heard this had their hair stand on end. The retainers said, "Since there is such a terrifying warning from Heaven, please bend reason and stay." But saying "For one who takes up bow and arrow, there is no way to rely on that," he left the castle at the hour of the Hare on the sixteenth and went only a little over ten chō. A clump of black clouds appeared and seemed to cover Sukenaga; suddenly his body became paralyzed, his heart dazed, and he fell from his horse. Carried back to his mansion in a palanquin, he lay down for about three hours and finally died. When this was reported to the Capital by express messenger, the Heike people were greatly agitated.

[6.12.2] On the fourteenth of the same seventh month, the era was changed and named Yōwa. On that day, Chikugo-no-Kami Sadayoshi was given the two provinces of Chikuzen and Higo, and set out for the western provinces to quell the rebellion in Chinzei; on that day also, an extraordinary amnesty was held, and the people exiled in the past third year of Jishō were recalled. The Matsudono Lay Priest Regent came up to the Capital from Bizen Province; the Prime Minister Myōon-in came up from Owari Province. It was heard that Azechi Dainagon Sukekata-kyō returned to the Capital from Shinano Province.

[6.12.3] On the twenty-eighth of the same month, Myōon-in-dono visited the Retired Emperor. At the time of his return to the Capital in the past Chōkan era, he played "Gaōon" (Celebrating Royal Favor) and "Kanjōraku" (Returning to Castle Music) on the veranda before the Emperor, but for this return to the Capital in Yōwa, he played "Shūfūraku" (Autumn Wind Music) at the Retired Emperor's Palace. His heart in thinking of the atmosphere and occasion in everything was indeed magnificent. Azechi Dainagon Sukekata-kyō also visited the Retired Emperor that day. The Cloistered Emperor said, "How is it? You must feel like it is a dream. Living in an unaccustomed countryside, I thought you would have forgotten court music and such by now, but let us have one imayō first." Since he had seen the imayō "The Kisoji River that is in Shinano," the Dainagon kept the beat and sang "The Kisoji River that was in Shinano"; this was famous at the time.

[6.13.1] On the seventh day of the eighth month, a Great Benevolent King Assembly (Dai-Ninnō-e) was held at the Dajōkan office. It was heard this was the precedent of the pursuit of Masakado. On the first of the ninth month, as a precedent of the pursuit of Sumitomo, iron armor and helmets were offered to the Great Shrine of Ise. The Imperial Messenger was the Head Priest Jingi-Gon-no-Taiyu Ōnakatomi no Sadataka; leaving the Capital, he fell ill at the Kōka Station in Ōmi Province and died at the detached palace of Ise. The Great Ajari of Gōzanze, who received the order for the Five Altar Ritual to subjugate the rebels, died in his sleep at the Higan place of the Great Performance. It was conspicuous that neither the Gods nor the Three Treasures accepted [the prayers]. Also, when Jitsugen Ajari of Anshō-ji, who received the order for the Daigen Ritual, presented the scroll of his performance, and they opened and viewed it, it was terrifying that he had noted that he prayed for the subjugation of the Heike. "What is this?" they asked. "You ordered me to subjugate the enemies of the court. Looking at the state of the present world, the Heike appear to be the exclusive enemies of the court. Therefore, I subjugate them; what fault should there be?" Thus he spoke. "This priest is outrageous. Death or exile?" There was such talk, but amidst the busyness of great and small matters, it was mixed up and there was no further action. After it became the era of the Genji, the Lord of Kamakura was impressed, saying "Divine," and as a reward made him a Daisōjō (Great High Priest), it was rumored.

[6.13.2] On the twenty-fourth of the same twelfth month, the Empress received the title of Retired Empress (In-gō) and was called Kenreimon-in. We hear this is the first time for an Empress Mother to receive an In-gō while the Emperor is still young. Meanwhile, this year also ended, and it became the second year of Yōwa.

[6.13.3] On the twenty-first of the second month, Venus invaded the Pleiades. The Tenmon Yōroku says: "If Venus invades the Pleiades, the Four Barbarians will rise." Also it is seen: "The General receives an Imperial Command and leaves the borders of the country."

[6.13.4] On the tenth of the third month, appointments were held, and the people of the Heike generally advanced in office and rank. On the tenth of the fourth month, Former Gon-no-Shōsōzu Kenshin performed a reading of ten thousand copies of the Lotus Sutra according to the rules at Hiyoshi Shrine. To form a connection, the Cloistered Emperor also made a procession. Perhaps because someone had suggested it, it was rumored that the Retired Emperor ordered the monks of the Mountain Gate to pursue and strike the Heike; so military soldiers came to the Palace and guarded the heads of the four directions. The Taira clan all raced to gather at Rokuhara. Hon-Sanmi Chūjō Shigehira-kyō went to Hiyoshi Shrine with a force of over three thousand horsemen to welcome the Cloistered Emperor. At the Mountain Gate, it was heard that the Heike were going to attack the mountain and were ascending with a force of hundreds of horsemen, so the monks all descended to Higashi-Sakamoto and deliberated, saying "What is this?" The disturbance on the mountain and in the capital was extraordinary. The accompanying nobles and courtiers lost color, and among the North Guards, many panicked so much that they vomited yellow bile. Hon-Sanmi Chūjō Shigehira-kyō met the Cloistered Emperor in the vicinity of Anō and escorted him back. "If it is always like this, after this, perhaps I will not be able to make pilgrimages as I please," he said. In truth, there was no plan for the Mountain Gate monks to pursue the Heike. Nor was there a plan for the Heike to attack the mountain. These were groundless matters. People said, "It must be that the heavenly demons are running wild." On the twentieth of the same fourth month, there were extraordinary offerings (Kanpei). This was due to famine and epidemic.

[6.13.5] On the twenty-fourth of the same fifth month, the era was changed and named Juei. On that day also, the resident of Echigo Province, Jō no Shirō Sukeshige, was appointed Governor of Echigo. Since his elder brother Sukenaga had passed away, saying it was inauspicious, he declined frequently, but since it was an Imperial Order, he was powerless. He changed his name from Sukeshige to Nagashige.

[6.13.6] On the second of the same ninth month, Jō no Shirō Nagashige, for the purpose of pursuing Kiso, led soldiers of Echigo, Dewa, and the four districts of Aizu, a total force of over forty thousand horsemen, and set out for Shinano Province. On the ninth of the same month, he encamped at Yokotagawara in that province. Kiso was at Yoda Castle, but hearing this, he left Yoda Castle and raced to face them with over three thousand horsemen. By the stratagem of Shinano Genji Inoue Kurō Mitsumori, they suddenly made seven red banners, divided the three thousand horsemen into seven groups, and raising the red banners in their hands from this peak and that cave, they approached; seeing this, Jō no Shirō was encouraged, saying "Ah, there are people in this province too who side with the Heike." While they were shouting in triumph, as they gradually came closer, determining a signal, the seven groups became one, and raised a war cry all at once. They suddenly raised the white banners they had prepared. The Echigo forces saw this, lost color saying "How many tens of thousands of horsemen is the enemy? What shall we do?", panicked, and were driven into the river or pushed down into bad places; those saved were few, those killed were many. The famous soldiers Jō no Shirō relied on completely, Yama Tarō of Echigo and Jōtanbō of Aizu, were all killed there. He himself was wounded, and barely escaping with his life, retreated to Echigo Province along the river.

[6.13.7] On the sixteenth of the same month, in the Capital, the Heike did not treat this as a matter of concern; Former Major Captain of the Right Munemori-kyō returned to the post of Dainagon, and on the third of the tenth month became Minister of the Interior (Naidaijin). On the seventh of the same month, there was a formal expression of gratitude. Twelve nobles of his house attended, and sixteen courtiers, starting with the Head Chamberlain, rode ahead. The Genji of the eastern and northern provinces had risen together like bees and were about to attack up to the Capital right now; in such a state, not knowing whether waves were rising or wind was blowing, their colorful affairs seemed conversely worthless to mention.

[6.13.8] Meanwhile, it became the second year of Juei. The festivals and such were as usual. The Heike Minister of the Interior, Lord Munemori, served as Naiben (Inner Controller). On the sixth of the first month, the Emperor made a procession to the Cloistered Emperor's Palace at Hōjūji for the New Year's Greeting (Chōkin). It was heard that the Chōkin procession of Retired Emperor Toba at age six was the precedent. On the twenty-second of the second month, Lord Munemori was promoted to Junior First Rank. Immediately on that day, he resigned as Minister of the Interior. It was heard that this was due to caution regarding the military disturbance. The monks of the Southern Capital and Northern Peak, the monks of Kumano and Kinpusen, down to the head priests and officials of the Ise Grand Shrine, all turned against the Heike and communicated with the Genji. Although they issued decrees to the four directions and sent Imperial Decrees to the provinces, considering the Imperial Decrees and orders to be merely the commands of the Heike, there was no one who followed them.

[7.1.1] In the first ten days of the third month of the second year of Juei, there was a matter of disagreement between Hyōe-no-Suke and Kiso Kaja Yoshinaka. Hyōe-no-Suke set out for Shinano Province with a force of over one hundred thousand horsemen to pursue Kiso. Kiso was at Yoda Castle, but hearing this, he left Yoda Castle and encamped at Mt. Kumasaka on the border of Shinano and Echigo. Hyōe-no-Suke arrived at Zenkō-ji in the same Shinano Province. Kiso sent his foster brother Imai Shirō Kanehira as a messenger to Hyōe-no-Suke's place. "What is the reason that you say you will attack Yoshinaka? You have subjugated the eight eastern provinces and are attacking up from the Tōkaidō, intending to chase down the Heike. I, Yoshinaka, have also subjugated the Tōsandō and Hokurikudō, intending to attack and defeat the Heike even one day sooner. For what reason should you and I be at odds and be laughed at by the Heike? However, since Jurō Kurando-dono, saying he has a grudge against you, came to Yoshinaka's place, and Yoshinaka could not treat him coldly, we have joined together. Yoshinaka absolutely holds no grudge against you." Thus he sent word. In Hyōe-no-Suke's reply: "Though you speak thus now, there are those who say there is definitely a plot of rebellion to attack Yoritomo. I cannot rely on that." Saying this, and hearing that a punitive force led by Doi and Kajiwara was already being sent against him, Kiso, in order to demonstrate that he truly had no grudge, sent his heir Shimizu Kaja Yoshishige, a young Kaja of eleven years, accompanied by famous soldiers such as Unno, Mochizuki, Suwa, and Fujisawa, to Hyōe-no-Suke's place. Hyōe-no-Suke said, "After this, truly there is no grudge. Yoritomo does not yet have an adult child. Good, good, then I shall make him my son." So taking Shimizu Kaja along, he returned to Kamakura.

div.head: 7.2. Going Down to the Northern Provinces

div.p: [7.2.1] Meanwhile, hearing that Kiso had subjugated the Tōsandō and Hokurikudō and was already attacking up to the Capital with a force of over fifty thousand horsemen, the Heike had announced since last year, "Next year, when there is grass to feed the horses, there will be a battle." Therefore, soldiers of the San'in, San'yō, Nankai, and Saikai regions raced to gather like clouds and mist. From the Tōsandō, soldiers of Ōmi, Mino, and Hida gathered, but from the Tōkaidō, no one east of Tōtōmi gathered; those west of it all gathered. From the Hokurikudō, not a single soldier north of Wakasa gathered. Intending to first pursue and strike Kiso Kaja Yoshinaka and then attack Hyōe-no-Suke, they sent a punitive force to the Hokurikudō. The Great Generals were Komatsu Sanmi Chūjō Koremori, Echizen Sanmi Michimori, Tajima-no-Kami Tsunemasa, Satsuma-no-Kami Tadanori, Mikawa-no-Kami Tomonori, Awaji-no-Kami Kiyofusa; the Samurai Generals were Etchū-no-Zenji Moritoshi, Kazusa no Tayū Hangan Tadatsuna, Hida no Tayū Hangan Kagekata, Takahashi Hangan Nagatsuna, Kawachi Hangan Hidekuni, Musashi Saburō Saemon Arikuni, Etchū Jirō Hyōe Moritsugu, Kazusa Gorō Hyōe Tadamitsu, led by Aku-Shichibyōe Kagekiyo; in total, six Great Generals, over three hundred and forty appropriate samurai, and a force of over one hundred thousand horsemen left the Capital at the hour of the Dragon (8 AM) on the seventeenth of the fourth month of the second year of Juei, and headed for the northern provinces. Since they were granted [provisions for] one way, starting from the barrier at Ausaka, they feared nothing and seized one by one the taxes and official goods of powerful families and influential houses they met on the road. As they passed through Shiga, Karasaki, Mikawajiri, Mano, Takashima, Shiozu, and Kaizu, gradually plundering along the way, the people could not endure it and all fled into the mountains and fields.

[7.3.1] Although the Great Generals Koremori and Michimori advanced, the Vice-Generals Tsunemasa, Tadanori, Tomonori, and Kiyofusa were still holding back at Shiozu and Kaizu in Ōmi Province. Among them, Tsunemasa was a person skilled in poetry and music, so even in such turmoil, he cleared his mind, rode out to the edge of the lake, looked across at the island far in the offing, summoned Tōhyōe Arinori who was accompanying him, and asked, "What is that called?" "That is the famous Chikubushima," he replied. "Indeed it is so. Come, let us visit it." Taking along Tōhyōe Arinori, Yasuhyōe Morinori, and five or six other samurai, he boarded a small boat and crossed to Chikubushima. Since it was the eighth day of the fourth month, the treetops appearing green seemed to retain the feeling of spring; the voice of the warbler in the valley stream had aged, and the cuckoo, whose first song was longed for, announced it knowingly at this season. Waves of wisteria hung blooming on the pines, and it was truly delightful, so he hurriedly got off the boat, climbed the bank, and looked at the scenery of this island; neither heart nor words could reach it. When Qin Shi Huang and Emperor Wu of Han sent boys and girls or made magicians search for the elixir of immortality, saying they would not return without seeing Penglai, and aged in vain on ships, with the sky and water vast and unable to obtain what they sought—it seemed that the appearance of the Penglai cave must have been like this. A text of a certain sutra says: "In Jambudvipa there is a lake; in it is a crystal wheel mountain born from the Golden Wheel horizon, a place where heavenly maidens dwell." It says. This is indeed this island. Tsunemasa knelt before the Great Deity and said, "The Great Benzaiten of Merit and Virtue is a Tathagata of ancient times, a Bodhisattva of the Dharma Body. Although the names of the two deities Benzai (Eloquence) and Myōon (Wondrous Sound) are distinct, their original ground is one body, saving sentient beings. I hear that those who visit once have their prayers fulfilled perfectly. It is reliable indeed." While he made offerings of the Law for a while, gradually the sun set, the moon of the eighteenth night appeared, shining over the sea, and the shrine altar also shone more brightly, being truly delightful; the resident monks said, "We have heard of you," and presented a biwa; when Tsunemasa played the secret pieces "Jōgen" and "Sekijō," the inside of the shrine became clear, and the Great Deity, unable to bear the response, appeared as a white dragon on Tsunemasa's sleeve. In the excess of awe and joy, weeping, he composed thus:

lg.l: Because my prayer to the mighty God was granted, the color (sign) has appeared clearly.

div.p: [7.3.2] Therefore, rejoicing that there was no doubt he would subdue the enemies before his eyes and crush the villains right now, he boarded the boat again and left Chikubushima.

[7.4.1] While Kiso Yoshinaka himself remained in Shinano, he built Hiuchi Castle in Echizen Province. The forces barricaded in that castle, starting with the head of Heisen-ji, Saimei Igishi, Inazu no Shinsuke, Saitōta, Hayashi Rokurō Mitsuaki, Togashi Nyūdō Bussei, Tsuchida, Takebe, Miyazaki, Ishiguro, Nyūzen, and Sami, numbered over six thousand horsemen. Hiuchi was originally an excellent fortification. Crags towered around it, and peaks were lined up on four sides. It had a mountain behind and a mountain in front. In front of the castle flowed the Nomi River and the Shindō River. At the confluence of the two rivers, they cut large trees and pulled them as abatis, and built up fences extensively, so that damming the water at the base of the eastern and western mountains, it was like facing a lake. The reflection soaked the southern mountain, blue and vast. The waves sank the western sun, red and secluded. At the bottom of Lake Anavatapta, gold and silver sand is spread; on the shores of Lake Kunming, boats of tortoise shell floated. In the constructed pond of this Hiuchi Castle, they built dikes and muddied the water to deceive people's minds. Since there was no way to cross easily without boats, the great army of the Heike camped on the opposite mountain and spent days in vain.

[7.4.2] The head of Heisen-ji, Saimei Igishi, who was inside the castle, was deeply loyal to the Heike, so he went around the base of the mountain, wrote a message, put it inside a whistling arrow, and secretly shot it into the Heike camp. "That lake is not an ancient abyss; they have temporarily dammed up the mountain river. Entering the night, send foot soldiers to cut down the weir; the water will drain before long. The footing for horses is good, so please cross quickly. I will shoot a rear arrow (signal). This is the petition of Saimei Igishi, head of Heisen-ji." Thus it was written. The Great General rejoiced greatly, immediately sent foot soldiers, and cut down the weir. Although it looked formidable, since it was indeed a mountain river, the water drained before long. The great Heike army, without a moment's delay, crossed over. The soldiers inside the castle held out and defended for a while, but the enemy was a large force and their side was a small force, so it did not seem they could prevail. The head of Heisen-ji, Saimei Igishi, sided with the Heike and performed loyalty. Inazu no Shinsuke, Saitōta, Hayashi Rokurō Mitsuaki, and Togashi Nyūdō Bussei fled from here, still defying the Heike, retreated to Kaga Province, and barricaded themselves at Kawachi in Hakusan. The Heike immediately crossed into Kaga and burned down the two castles of Hayashi and Togashi. They did not seem to face any opposition. They sent express messengers from nearby post stations and reported this to the Capital, and the joy of the Minister and the remaining family members was extraordinary.

[7.4.3] On the eighth of the same fifth month, there was a muster of forces at Shinohara in Kaga Province. Dividing the military force of over one hundred thousand horsemen into two groups, they headed for the main approach and the rear approach. The Great Generals of the main force were Komatsu Sanmi Chūjō Koremori and Echizen Sanmi Michimori; the Samurai Generals were Etchū-no-Zenji Moritoshi and others; with a total force of over seventy thousand horsemen, they headed for Mt. Tonami on the border of Kaga and Etchū. The Great Generals of the rear force were Satsuma-no-Kami Tadanori and Mikawa-no-Kami Tomonori; led by the Samurai General Musashi Saburō Saemon, with a total force of over thirty thousand horsemen, they headed for Mt. Shiho on the border of Noto and Etchū. Kiso was at the provincial capital of Echigo, but hearing this, he raced to face them with over fifty thousand horsemen. Saying it was a lucky precedent for his army, he divided them into seven groups. First, his uncle Jurō Kurando Yukiie headed for Mt. Shiho with over ten thousand horsemen. He dispatched Nishina, Takanashi, and Yamada Jirō with over seven thousand horsemen to the rear at North Kurosaka. He sent Higuchi Jirō Kanemitsu and Ochiai Gorō Kaneyuki with over seven thousand horsemen to South Kurosaka. He hid over ten thousand horsemen at the mouth of Mt. Tonami, the foot of Kurosaka, Yanagihara in Matsunaga, and Guminoki-bayashi. Imai Shirō Kanehira crossed the Washi-no-Se with over six thousand horsemen and took up position at Himiya-bayashi. Kiso himself, with over ten thousand horsemen, crossed the Oyabe ford and took up position at Hanyū at the northern edge of Mt. Tonami.

div.head: 7.5. The Written Vow

div.p: [7.5.1] Kiso proclaimed: "Since the Heike are surely a large force, they will cross Mt. Tonami, come out into the open, and engage in a meeting battle. However, a meeting battle depends on the number of forces. If they rely on their large numbers and surround us, it will be bad. First, send flag bearers ahead; if we raise white banners, the Heike will see this and say, 'Ah, the Genji vanguard faces us. They must be a large force. If we go out into the open without thought, the enemy knows the terrain and we do not; if we are surrounded, it will be hopeless. Since this mountain is rocky on all four sides, they surely won't circle to the rear; let us dismount for a while and rest the horses.' And they will dismount in the mountains. At that time, I, Yoshinaka, will pretend to negotiate/hesitate for a while, wait for the sun to set, and intend to drive the great Heike army down into the Kurikara Valley." So saying, he first sent thirty white banners ahead and planted them on top of Kurosaka. Just as he thought, the Heike saw this and said, "Ah, the Genji vanguard faces us; they must be a large force. If we go out into the open without thought, the enemy knows the terrain and we do not. If we are surrounded, it will be bad. This mountain is rocky on all four sides. They surely won't circle to the rear. The grass and water for the horses are both good; let us dismount for a while and rest the horses." And they dismounted in the midst of Mt. Tonami, at a place called Saru-no-Baba (Monkey's Riding Ground). Kiso took up position at Hanyū and looked around quickly in all four directions; through the green trees on the peak of the summer mountain, a vermilion jewel fence was faintly visible, and there was a shrine built in katasogi style. A torii gate stood in front. Lord Kiso summoned a guide of the province and asked, "What shrine is that called, and what god is worshipped?" "That is Hachiman. Indeed, this place is a Hachiman manor." Thus he spoke. Lord Kiso rejoiced greatly, summoned Tayūbō Kakumei who was serving as his scribe, and said, "I, Yoshinaka, fortunately approaching the treasure hall of the New Hachiman, am about to engage in battle. I feel that somehow I will win this battle without fail. If that is so, partly for future generations, and partly as a prayer for the present, I wish to write a written vow and offer it; what do you think?" Kakumei said, "It is most appropriate." And getting off his horse, he prepared to write. Kakumei's appearance: wearing a hitatare of red ground and armor laced with black leather, carrying a black-lacquered sword, bearing twenty-four arrows with black horo feathers, holding a lacquered rattan bow under his arm, he took off his helmet and hung it on the high cord, took out a small inkstone and folding paper from his quiver, and bowed before Lord Kiso to write the vow. He appeared indeed as a master of both the literary and martial ways. This Kakumei was originally a Confucian scholar. Called Kurando Michihiro, he was at the Kangaku-in, but took the tonsure and named himself Saijōbō Shinkyū. He constantly visited the Southern Capital. Years ago when the Takakura Prince entered Onjō-ji, they sent letters to the Mountain and Nara; the monks of the Southern Capital had this Shinkyū write the reply. "Kiyomori is the dregs of the Taira clan, the dust of the warrior houses." Because he wrote this, the Lay Priest Prime Minister was greatly angered: "How dare that Shinkyū priest write that Jōkai is the bran of the Taira clan and the dust and trash of the warrior houses? Capture that priest and execute him!" Since he said this, Shinkyū fled the Southern Capital, went down to the northern provinces, became the scribe of Lord Kiso, and named himself Tayūbō Kakumei. The written vow said:

div.div: Taking refuge and bowing my head, Hachiman Daibosatsu is the main lord of the Imperial Court of the Sun Domain (Japan), the ancestor of wise rulers of successive generations. To protect the Precious Throne and benefit the people, he manifested the golden form of the Three Bodies, and pushed open the provisional doors of the Three Places. Here, in recent years, there is a person called Taira no Shōkoku (Prime Minister), who controls the Four Seas and causes suffering to the ten thousand people. He is already an enemy of the Buddha's Law, a foe of the King's Law. I, Yoshinaka, unworthily born in a house of bow and horse, barely continue the dust of my ancestors' work. Considering his violence, I cannot look back in contemplation. Entrusting my fate to the Way of Heaven, I throw my body to the state. Tentatively raising a righteous army, I wish to drive away the weapon of evil. However, though the fighting houses have joined battle, the soldiers have not yet obtained the courage of unity; while I feared in my divided heart, now at this one camp, on the battlefield where I raise my flag, suddenly I worship the shrine altar of the Three Places' softened light. The maturity of the opportunity and response is clear. The punishment of the villains is not in doubt. Tears of joy spill, and longing dyes my liver. Especially since my great-grandfather, Former Governor of Mutsu Yoshiie Ason, entrusted his body to the clan of the Ancestral Shrine and took the name Hachiman Tarō, there has been no one among his descendants who did not revere it. Yoshinaka, as his descendant, has inclined his head for many years. Now raising this great merit is like measuring the great ocean with a baby's shell, or a mantis raising its axe against a high carriage. However, I raise this for the sake of the country and the Lord; I do not raise this for the sake of my house or myself. The arrival of my will has divine response in heaven. How reliable. How joyful. I humbly pray, may the unseen and visible add their authority, combine the power of spiritual gods to decide the victory at once, and drive the enemies to the four directions. If my sincere prayer matches the unseen thought, and the mysterious mirror grants protection, please first show one auspicious sign.

div.p: [7.5.2] Juei 2nd Year, 5th Month, 11th Day. Minamoto no Yoshinaka. Respectfully spoken.

[7.5.3] Having written this, starting with himself, thirteen people pulled out the humming bulbs of their best arrows, attached them to the vow, and offered them to the Great Bodhisattva's treasure hall. How reliable! perhaps Hachiman Daibosatsu observed the lack of duplicity in his true sincerity from afar; three mountain doves flew out from the clouds and fluttered over the white banners of the Genji.

[7.5.4] Long ago when Empress Jingū attacked Silla, when her side's battle was weak and the foreign army was strong, and it seemed it was the end, the Empress made a prayer to Heaven; three spiritual doves flew down and appeared on the face of a shield, and the foreign army was defeated. Also when the ancestor of these people, Yoriyoshi Ason, attacked Sadatō and Munetō, when his side's battle was weak and the rebels' army was strong, Yoriyoshi Ason faced the enemy camp and set fire to it, saying "This is absolutely not my fire, it is divine fire." The wind suddenly blew toward the barbarians, and Sadatō's fortress at Kuriyagawa burned. After that, the army was defeated and Sadatō and Munetō were destroyed. Lord Kiso did not forget such precedents; getting off his horse, taking off his helmet, washing his hands and rinsing his mouth, his heart as he worshipped the spiritual doves now was indeed reliable.

[7.6.1] Meanwhile, the Genji and Heike camps met. The distance between the camps closed to a mere three chō. The Genji did not advance, and the Heike did not advance. From the Genji side, fifteen elite horsemen advanced to the front of the shields, and shot fifteen humming bulb arrows into the Heike camp. The Heike, not knowing it was a stratagem, sent out fifteen horsemen and shot back fifteen humming bulbs. When the Genji sent out thirty horsemen and had them shoot, the Heike sent out thirty horsemen and shot back thirty humming bulbs. When they sent out fifty, they sent out fifty to match; when they sent out a hundred, they sent out a hundred to match; both sides advanced a hundred horsemen each to the front of the camp. Although they were eager to settle the victory mutually, they were restrained from the Genji side and not allowed to fight decisively. The Genji spent the day in this manner, plotting to drive the great Heike army down into the Kurikara Valley, but the Heike did not realize this in the slightest, and spending the day negotiating together was indeed foolish.

[7.6.2] As it gradually grew dark, the rear guard force of over ten thousand horsemen circling from north and south met near the Kurikara Hall, beat their quivers, and raised a war cry with a roar. When the Heike looked back, white banners were raised like clouds. Since they thought, "This mountain is rocky on all four sides, they surely won't circle to the rear," they panicked, saying "What is this?" Meanwhile, Lord Kiso joined in the war cry from the main force. The force of ten thousand horsemen hiding in the Yanagihara of Matsunaga and Guminoki-bayashi, and Imai Shirō's over six thousand horsemen at Himiya-bayashi also raised war cries together. The shouting voices of forty thousand horsemen front and rear sounded as if mountains and rivers were crumbling at once. Just as planned, the Heike. It gradually became dark, the enemy attacked from front and rear; although there were many who said "It is shameful, turn back, turn back!", since the great force was stampeding, it was difficult to turn back left or right, so vying to be first, they fell into the Kurikara Valley. Since they could not see those who fell first, thinking "There must be a path at the bottom of this valley," if a parent fell, the child fell; if a brother fell, the younger brother followed. If a master fell, the retainers fell. Horses on people, people on horses, falling and piling up; a single deep valley was filled by the Heike force of over seventy thousand horsemen. The rock spring flowed with blood, and the corpses formed a mountain. Therefore, it is heard that arrow holes and sword marks remain in the vicinity of that valley even now. On the Heike side, the mainly relied upon Kazusa no Tayū Hangan Tadatsuna, Hida no Tayū Hangan Kagekata, and Kawachi Hangan Hidekuni were also buried in this valley and lost. The famous strongman, resident of Bitchū Province Senoo Tarō Kaneyasu, was captured alive there by the hand of resident of Kaga Province Kuramitsu Jirō Narizumi. The head of Heisen-ji, Saimei Igishi, who had betrayed them at Hiuchi Castle in Echizen, was also captured. Lord Kiso said, "He is too hateful, kill that priest first." And he was killed. The Taira Generals Koremori and Michimori barely escaped with their lives and retreated to Kaga Province. Out of over seventy thousand horsemen, only a little over twenty horsemen escaped.

[7.6.3] On the following twelfth day, two fine horses were presented to Lord Kiso from Hidehira of Mutsu. One was a cream-colored horse, the other was a dappled gray. Immediately putting mirror saddles on them, he dedicated them as sacred horses to the Hakusan Shrine. Lord Kiso said, "Now I have no worries. However, Jurō Kurando-dono's battle at Shiho is concerning. Come, let us go see." And from the over forty thousand horsemen, selecting horses and men, he raced there with over twenty thousand horsemen. When they were about to cross the Himi湊 (inlet/harbor), since the tide happened to be full and they did not know the depth, they drove in about ten saddled horses. They were submerged up to the saddle flaps, and arrived at the opposite bank without incident. "It is shallow, cross!" And the great force of over twenty thousand horsemen all plunged in and crossed. Just as he thought, Jurō Kurando Yukiie had been severely beaten and retreated; where he was resting his horses, Lord Kiso said "Just as I thought," and with fresh troops of over twenty thousand horsemen, shouting, charged into the midst of the Heike's over thirty thousand horsemen, and attacking furiously, fought until fire came out. The Heike soldiers held out and defended for a while, but unable to endure, that place too was finally conquered. On the Heike side, Great General Mikawa-no-Kami Tomonori was killed. He was the youngest son of the Lay Priest Prime Minister. Many samurai were lost. Lord Kiso crossed Mt. Shiho and took up position in front of the Prince's Mound at Odanaka in Noto.

[7.7.1] There he donated divine lands to various shrines. To Hakusan Shrine he donated Yokoe and Miyamaru; to Sugō Shrine, the Nomi Manor; to Tada Hachiman, the Chōya Manor; to Kehi Shrine, the Iihara Manor. To Heisen-ji, he donated the seven villages of Fujishima.

[7.7.2] The men whom Hyōe-no-Suke-dono had defeated at the Battle of Ishibashiyama some years ago had fled up to the Capital and were on the Heike side. The main ones were Matano Gorō Kagehisa, Nagai Saitō Bettō Sanemori, Itō Kurō Sukeuji, Ukisu Saburō Shigechika, and Mashimo Shirō Shigenao; saying they would rest until there was a battle, they gathered every day and amused themselves by passing the sake cup. First, on the day they gathered at Sanemori's place, Saitō Bettō said, "Looking carefully at the state of the world, the Genji side is strong, and the Heike side appears to be losing. Come, let us all go to Lord Kiso." When he said this, everyone agreed, saying "Indeed." The next day when they gathered at Ukisu Saburō's place, Saitō Bettō asked, "Now, what about the matter we spoke of yesterday, everyone?" Among them, Matano Gorō stepped forward and said, "We are, after all, well known to everyone in the eastern provinces as men of name. To go here and there according to preference would be unsightly. I do not know about others. As for Kagehisa, I will stick with the Heike side, whatever happens." When he said this, Saitō Bettō laughed scornfully and said, "Truly, I spoke only to test everyone's heart. Furthermore, Sanemori has decided to die in this coming battle. I have told people that I will not return to the Capital a second time. I have also reported this to the Minister." When he said this, everyone agreed with this decision. Thus, perhaps not to break that promise, it is pitiable that the men present there all died in the northern provinces without a single one remaining.

[7.7.3] Meanwhile, the Heike rested their men and horses and took up position at Shinohara in Kaga Province. At the hour of the Dragon (8 AM) on the twenty-first of the same fifth month, Kiso pressed upon Shinohara and raised a war cry with a roar. On the Heike side, Hatakeyama Shōji Shigetada and Oyamada Bettō Arishige, who had been imprisoned since the past Jishō era, were told "You are men of old standing. Plan the battle strategy." And they were sent to the northern provinces. These brothers advanced to the front of the array with over three hundred horsemen. From the Genji side, Imai Shirō faced them with over three hundred horsemen. Imai Shirō and Hatakeyama at first sent out five or ten horsemen each to fight decisive matches, but later both sides mixed together and fought. At the hour of the Horse (noon) on May 21st, under a sun shining so hot that not even the grass stirred, as they fought not to be outdone, sweat poured from their whole bodies, no different from flowing water. Many soldiers on Imai's side also died. Hatakeyama, having his retainers reduced to a few, retreated powerless. Next, from the Heike side, Takahashi Hangan Nagatsuna advanced with over five hundred horsemen. From Lord Kiso's side, Higuchi Jirō Kanemitsu and Ochiai Gorō Kaneyuki raced to face them with over three hundred horsemen. They held and fought for a while, but since the Takahashi force consisted of conscripted warriors from the provinces, not a single horseman stayed to fight; vying to be first, they fled. Though Takahashi's heart was fierce, since his rear was exposed, he retreated powerless. As he was fleeing alone, a resident of Etchū Province, Nyūzen Kotarō Yukishige, spotting him as a good enemy, matched his stirrups and whipped his horse, raced up, rode alongside, and grappled him. Takahashi grabbed Nyūzen, pressed him against the front rim of his saddle, and said, "Who are you? Name yourself, let me hear." He replied, "Resident of Etchū Province, Nyūzen Kotarō Yukishige, age eighteen." "Ah, how pitiable. If the child I, Nagatsuna, lost last year were alive this year, he would be eighteen. Though I should twist off your head and throw it away, I will save you." So saying, he released him. He himself got off his horse and rested, intending to wait for his side's forces for a while. While Nyūzen was sitting thinking, "Though he saved me, alas, what an enemy! I wish to kill him somehow," Takahashi relaxed and chatted. Nyūzen, being a soldier of superior quickness, drew his sword, attacked, and stabbed Takahashi twice inside his helmet. Meanwhile, Nyūzen's retainers, three horsemen, came racing up and joined them. Although Takahashi's heart was fierce, perhaps his luck had run out; the enemy was many, and he was wounded; finally, he was killed there.

[7.7.4] Also from the Heike side, Musashi Saburō Saemon Arikuni shouted and attacked with about three hundred horsemen. From the Genji side, Nishina, Takanashi, and Yamada Jirō raced to face him with over five hundred horsemen. They held and fought for a while, but many of Arikuni's force were killed. Arikuni fought penetrating deeply; having exhausted all his arrows and had his horse shot, he became a foot soldier, drew his sword and fought, but taking many enemies, he was shot with seven or eight arrows and died standing. Since the General ended thus, his force all fled.

[7.8.1] Also, the resident of Musashi Province, Nagai Saitō Bettō Sanemori, though his side had all fled, turned back again and again alone to defend and fight. Having a specific intent, he wore a hitatare of red brocade, armor laced with light green thread, tightened the cords of a helmet with hoe-shaped crests (kuwagata), carried a sword with gold fittings, bore arrows with speckled feathers, held a lacquered rattan bow, and rode a dappled gray horse saddled with a gold-rimmed saddle. From Lord Kiso's side, Tezuka Tarō Mitsumori, spotting him as a worthy enemy, called out, "Ah, how brave. What kind of person are you that, while your forces have all fled, you remain alone? It is admirable. Name yourself." When he addressed him thus, Sanemori said, "Who are you who speaks thus?" "I am the resident of Shinano Province, Tezuka Tarō Kanasashi Mitsumori," he named himself. "Then we are mutually worthy enemies. However, it is not that I am hiding my name from you, but having a specific intent, I will not name myself. Come, let us grapple, Tezuka!" As they rode alongside each other, Tezuka's retainer raced up from behind, intending not to let his master be killed, and came between them, grappling firmly with Saitō Bettō. "Ah, you scoundrel, do not grapple with the strongest man in Japan!" Saying this, he pulled him close, pressed him against the front rim of his saddle, cut his throat, and threw him away. Tezuka Tarō, seeing his retainer killed, went around to the left side, lifted the skirt of Sanemori's armor, stabbed him twice, and as he weakened, grappled him and fell. Although Saitō Bettō's heart was fierce, he was exhausted from battle, and moreover was an old warrior, so he ended up beneath Tezuka. Another of Tezuka's retainers who came up late took his head; Tezuka raced to Lord Kiso's presence and said, "Mitsumori has grappled and killed a strange warrior. If I thought he was a samurai, he was wearing a brocade hitatare. If I thought he was a Great General, he had no following troops. Though I pressed him repeatedly to name himself, finally he did not name himself. His voice was a Bandō (eastern) voice." When he said this, Lord Kiso said, "Ah, this must be Saitō Bettō. If so, when Yoshinaka crossed into Kōzuke, I saw him briefly, and he had white hair mixed with gray. By now he must certainly have become white-haired, so it is strange that his beard and sideburns are black. Higuchi Jirō has associated with him and should know him; summon Higuchi." So he was summoned. Higuchi Jirō took just one look and said, "Ah, how pitiable, it is indeed Saitō Bettō." Lord Kiso asked, "If so, he is now over seventy and should have become white-haired; why are his beard and sideburns black?" Higuchi Jirō shed tears profusely and said, "Since you ask, I intended to explain the reason, but it is so moving that unintended tears spill. A warrior, even in trivial matters, should prepare words of remembrance beforehand. Saitō Bettō met Kanemitsu (me) and constantly said in conversation, 'When I exceed sixty and head for the battle camp, I will dye my beard and sideburns black and appear young. The reason is that it would be unseemly to compete with young men for the lead. Also, it would be regrettable to be despised by people as an old warrior.' He said this, and indeed he has dyed it. Have it washed and see." Thinking it might be so, they had it washed and looked; it had indeed become white hair.

[7.8.2] Regarding the wearing of the brocade hitatare, when Saitō Bettō visited the Minister to bid farewell, he said, "It is not just about Sanemori alone, but when we went to the eastern provinces some years ago, startled by the sound of water birds, we fled up from Kanbara in Suruga Province without shooting a single arrow; this is the only shame of my old age. This time heading to the northern provinces, I intend to die in battle. If that is so, although Sanemori was originally a person of Echizen Province, in recent years due to my estate, I have resided in Nagai of Musashi. There is a proverb. It says 'Return to your hometown wearing brocade.' Please permit me a brocade hitatare." When he said this, the Minister said, "What an elegant thing to say." And it was heard that he permitted the brocade hitatare. Zhu Maichen of old fluttered his brocade sleeves at Mt. Guiji; the present Saitō Bettō raised his name in the streets of the northern land he came to. It is sad that leaving only an imperishable empty name, his corpse became dust at the end of the Koshi road.

[7.8.3] Considering the situation where they left the Capital with over one hundred thousand horsemen on the seventeenth of the past fourth month, it did not seem they could face anyone, but now returning in the last ten days of the fifth month, the force was merely over twenty thousand horsemen. "When you drain the stream to fish, though you get many fish, next year there are no fish. When you burn the forest to hunt, though you get many beasts, next year there are no beasts. Considering the future, they should have left a few behind." There were people who spoke thus.

[7.9.1] Kazusa-no-Kami Tadakiyo and Hida-no-Kami Kageie had both taken the tonsure when the Lay Priest Prime Minister died the year before last, but hearing that their children had all perished in the northern provinces this time, perhaps due to the accumulation of grief, they finally died of sorrow. Starting with this, parents were left behind by children, wives were separated from husbands; generally in distant provinces and near provinces it must have been so. In the Capital, houses closed their gates, voices chanting the Nembutsu were heard, and the sounds of weeping and screaming were immense.

[7.9.2] On the first of the sixth month, Kurando Uemon-no-Gon-no-Suke Sadanaga summoned Jingi-Gon-no-Shōyū Ōnakatomi no Chikatoshi to the lower entrance of the Courtiers' Hall, and conveyed the order that if the military disturbance was quelled, there should be an Imperial Procession to the Great Shrine (Ise). The Great Shrine descended from the High Plain of Heaven; in the twenty-fifth year of the reign of Emperor Suinin, in the third month, moving from the village of Kasanui in Yamato Province to the upper reaches of the Isuzu River in Watarai District of Ise Province, erecting the great shrine pillars on the bedrock below, since the first worship, it is peerless among the more than three thousand seven hundred and fifty shrines, great and small, of the sixty-plus provinces of Japan. However, there had been no Imperial visits by successive Emperors; but in the time of the Emperor of Nara (Shōmu), there was a person named Ukon'e-no-Gon-no-Shōshō and Dazai Shōni Fujiwara no Hirotsugu, the grandson of Sadaijin Fuhito and son of Sangi Shikibu-kyō Umakai. In the tenth month of the fifteenth year of Tenpyō, in Matsura District of Hizen Province, enlisting tens of thousands of rebels, he was about to endanger the state. Therefore, with Ōno no Azumabito as Great General, when Hirotsugu was pursued, it is said that for the first time there was an Imperial Procession to the Great Shrine; this was heard to be the precedent. That Hirotsugu possessed a horse that could go up and down from Matsura in Hizen to the Capital in one day. Even when he was pursued, after his rebel forces fled and were all destroyed, he rode that horse and galloped into the sea, it was rumored. His vengeful spirit raged, and there were many terrifying incidents; among them, on the eighteenth of the sixth month of the sixteenth year of Tenpyō, at the dedication of Kanzeon-ji in Dazaifu, Mikasa District, Chikuzen Province, the officiating priest was heard to be Sōjō Genbō. When he ascended the high seat and struck the bell for the invocation, suddenly the sky clouded over, thunder sounded tremendously, fell upon Genbō, took his head, and went into the clouds. It was rumored that this was because he had performed rituals to subjugate Hirotsugu.

[7.9.3] This Sōjō (High Priest) crossed over accompanying Minister Kibi when he went to Tang China, and was the person who transmitted the Hossō sect. The people of Tang laughed at the name Genbō, divining, "Genbō sounds like 'return and perish' (gen-bō). Whatever happens, he is a person who will meet with an incident after returning to court." On the eighteenth of the sixth month of the nineteenth year of Tenpyō, a skull with the inscription "Genbō" fell into the courtyard of Kōfuku-ji, and in the sky, voices like those of a thousand people laughed loudly. This was because Kōfuku-ji is a temple of the Hossō sect. The disciples of that Sōjō took it, built a mound, placed the head in it, named it the Head Tomb (Kōbe-zuka), and it exists to this day. This was indeed the doing of Hirotsugu's spirit. Therefore, that vengeful spirit is worshipped, and is now called the Mirror Shrine (Kagami-no-Miya) of Matsura.

[7.9.4] In the time of Emperor Saga, when the Former Emperor Heizei disturbed the world on the advice of the Naishi-no-Kami, for the sake of prayer, the Emperor offered his third daughter, Imperial Princess Uchiko, to the Kamo Shrine as Saiin (High Priestess). This is the beginning of the Saiin. In the reign of Suzaku-in, due to the military disturbances of Masakado and Sumitomo, the Extraordinary Festival of Hachiman was begun. This time too, using such precedents, various prayers were begun.

div.head: 7.10. Kiso's Letter to Mt. Hiei

div.p: [7.10.1] Kiso arrived at the provincial capital of Echizen and summoned his retainers for a council. "Now, Yoshinaka intends to enter the Capital via Ōmi Province, but perhaps the usual mountain monks will resist. It would be easy to break through and pass, but the Heike at present do not respect the Buddha's Law, destroying temples and killing monks, committing evil deeds. If I, who am going up to the Capital for protection, fight against the monks of the Mountain Gate just because they unite with the Heike, it would be a repetition of the same folly, differing not at all. This is indeed a difficult matter. What shall we do?" When he said this, Tayūbō Kakumei, who was accompanying him as scribe, stepped forward and said, "The monks of the Mountain Gate number three thousand; they are not necessarily of one mind and one heart, but all have various thoughts. There may be monks who say they will side with the Genji, and there may be monks who say they will agree with the Heike. Please send a letter and see. The nature of the matter will appear in the reply." When he said this, "This opinion is quite right; then write it," he said, and having Kakumei write the letter, sent it to the Mountain Gate. The letter said:

div.div: Yoshinaka, carefully observing the treason of the Heike: since Hōgen and Heiji, they have long lost the propriety of subjects. Although high and low bind their hands and priests and laity lift their feet (in reverence/fear), they selfishly manipulate the Imperial Throne and plunder provinces and districts to satisfaction. Without discussing right or wrong, they pursue powerful families; without speaking of guilt or innocence, they destroy nobles and attendants. Taking their property, they give it all to their retainers; confiscating their manors, they brazenly leave them to their descendants. Especially, in the eleventh month of the third year of Jishō, they moved the Cloistered Emperor to the detached palace of Jonan, and exiled the Regent to the remote region of the Western Sea. The multitude does not speak, but the roads cast eyes (of disapproval). In addition, in the fifth month of the fourth year of the same, they surrounded the red pavilion of the Second Prince, startling the dust of the Nine-Fold Palace. Here, when the Imperial Son, to escape undue harm, secretly entered Onjō-ji, Yoshinaka, having previously received an Imperial Command, was about to raise the whip, but enemies filled the streets, blocking the road to participation. The Genji of nearby borders still did not attend, how much less those of distant borders. However, since Onjō-ji had limited means, he headed for the Southern Capital, and fought at Uji Bridge. Although the Great General, Lay Priest of the Third Rank Yorimasa and his son, treating life lightly and righteousness heavily, strove for the merit of a single battle, they could not escape the attack of the great force, exposing their corpses to the moss of the old bank and letting their lives flow in the waves of the long river. Engraving the purport of the Command in my liver, I erase the sorrowful souls of my kin. Therefore, the Genji of the eastern and northern provinces each plan to go up to the Capital and wish to destroy the Heike. Last autumn, on the day I raised my flag, took my sword, and left Shinshu to achieve my long-held desire, the resident of Echigo Province, Jō no Shirō Nagashige, led tens of thousands of soldiers and set out; we fought at Yokotagawara in that province. Yoshinaka, with only three thousand and more horsemen, defeated those tens of thousands of soldiers. As the rumor spread widely, the Taira General led one hundred thousand soldiers and set out for the northern land. At the fortresses of Esshū, Kashū, Tonami, Kurosaka, Shiozaka, Shinohara and others, we fought several times. Moving strategy within the command tent, we obtained victory within a short distance. Thus, when we attack, they inevitably bow; when we assault, they inevitably surrender. It is no different from the autumn wind breaking the banana plant. It is the same as the winter frost withering the flock of leaves. This is entirely the help of the Gods and Buddhas, not at all Yoshinaka's military strategy. Since the Taira clan has been defeated, I plan to go up to the Capital. Now I must pass the foot of Mt. Hiei and enter the streets of Luoyang (Kyoto). At this time, I secretly have doubts. Are the monks of Tendai in agreement with the Heike, or cooperating with the Genji? If you help those rebels, I must fight against the monks. If I fight, the destruction of Mt. Hiei will follow on my heels. How sad, that while the Taira clan troubles the Imperial Heart and destroys the Buddha's Law, and I raise a righteous army to quiet the treason, I should suddenly engage in an unforeseen battle against the three thousand monks. How painful, that deferring to the Healing King and the Mountain King, if I delay my journey, I will be slandered as a negligent subject of the Court and leave a lasting flaw on my military strategy. Bewildered in advancing or retreating, I open my guide. I hope that the three thousand monks, for the sake of the Gods, for the sake of the Buddha, for the sake of the country, for the sake of the Lord, will agree with the Genji, punish the villains, and bathe in great transformation. I cannot bear the depth of my sincerity. Yoshinaka, with fear and trembling, respectfully speaks.

div.p: [7.10.2] Juei 2nd Year, 6th Month, 10th Day. Minamoto no Yoshinaka.
[7.10.3] Presented to: Ekōbō Risshi-gobō.
[7.10.4] Thus it was written.

div.head: 7.11. The Reply

div.p: [7.11.1] Just as expected, the monks of the Mountain Gate opened and viewed this letter, and opinions were divided. There were monks who said they would side with the Genji, and monks who said they would agree with the Heike. Thoughts were various, and dissenting opinions were divided. The old monks deliberated: "In the end, we pray exclusively for the long life of the Golden Wheel Holy Lord (Emperor) like heaven and earth. The Heike are the maternal relatives of the current reign, and show reverence to the Mountain Gate. Therefore, until now we have prayed for their prosperity. However, their evil deeds exceed the law, and all people turn against them. Though they send punitive forces to the provinces, they are conversely destroyed by the rebels. Since recent years, the Genji have won repeated battles and their destiny is opening. Why should this mountain alone agree with the Heike whose fate is exhausted, and turn against the Genji whose destiny is opening? We should overturn the meaning of our connection with the Heike and submit to the purport of cooperating with the Genji." Deliberating with one mind, they sent a reply. Lord Kiso again summoned his retainers and had Kakumei open this reply.

div.div: The letter of the 10th of the sixth month arrived on the 16th of the same; upon opening and reading it, the gloom of many days dissolved at once. Generally, the treason of the Heike has extended for many years, and the disturbance of the Court has no time of cessation. The matter is in the mouths of people, and cannot be lost. Now, regarding Mt. Hiei, as the benevolent shrine of the northeast of the Imperial Capital, we perform pure prayers for the peace of the state. However, the whole heaven has long been invaded by that premature rebellion, and the four seas are not calm and have not obtained safety. It is as if the Dharma wheels of Exoteric and Esoteric Buddhism do not exist, and the divine authority of protection is frequently obsolete. Here, your noble house, fittingly born in a family of military preparation for generations, is fortunately the benevolence of pure selection at this time. Planning strange stratagems beforehand, you suddenly raise a righteous army. Forgetting life amidst ten thousand deaths, you establish the merit of a single battle. Your toil has not yet exceeded two years, but your name already flows through the four seas. The monks of our mountain tentatively receive this with joy. For the sake of the state, for the sake of your family, we are impressed by your military merit and military strategy. If this is so, then we rejoice that the pure prayers on the mountain were not in vain, and know that the protection within the seas has not been negligent. Our temple, other temples, the permanent Buddha Dharma, the main shrine, branch shrines, the gods of festivals, will surely rejoice that the teaching will flourish again, and rejoice that reverence will return to the old ways. In the hearts of the monks, we ask only for your wise consideration. If so, in the unseen world, the Twelve Divine Generals, as messengers of the Healing King Sugata, will join the brave warriors in pursuing the villains, and in the visible world, the three thousand monks will temporarily stop the diligent practice of study and admiration to help the government army punish the evil companions. The Brahma wind of the Ten Vehicles of Cessation and Contemplation will sweep the treacherous companions outside the Japanese court, and the Dharma rain of the Three Mysteries of Yoga will return the customs of the time to the ancient days of Yao. The council of the multitude is like this. Carefully observe this.

div.p: [7.11.2] Juei 2nd Year, 7th Month, 2nd Day. The Great Assembly, etc.
[7.11.3] Thus it was written.

div.head: 7.12. The Heike and Mt. Hiei Joint Signature

div.p: [7.12.1] The Heike did not know this even in a dream; since Kōfuku-ji and Onjō-ji were in a time of harboring resentment, they would not yield even if persuaded. Our house has not yet formed a grudge against the Mountain Gate, and the Mountain Gate also does not harbor disloyalty toward our house. Praying to the Mountain King Great Master (Sannō Daishi), intending to win over the three thousand monks, ten high nobles of the clan wrote a written vow with joint signatures and unanimous mind, and sent it to the Mountain Gate. The letter said:

div.div: Respectful Statement. Regarding treating Enryaku-ji as the clan temple and Hiyoshi Shrine as the clan shrine, and solely revering the Tendai Buddha Dharma. Right: The members of this clan have a special prayer. If asked the purport: Mt. Hiei, since the reign of Emperor Kanmu, after Dengyō Daishi returned from Tang, spread the Perfect and Sudden Teaching in this place, and transmitted the Shana Great Precepts within it; since then, it has been exclusively the spiritual cave of the flourishing Buddha Dharma, preparing the training ground for protecting the state. Just now, the exile of Izu Province, Minamoto no Yoritomo, does not regret his own guilt, but conversely mocks the court laws. In addition, participating in treacherous plots, the Genji who agree, Yoshinaka, Yukiie and others, forming parties, are numerous. They plunder neighboring and distant provinces, and seize local products and tribute items. Therefore, either pursuing the traces of ancestral merit, or relying on the present arts of bow and horse, we unworthily receive the Imperial Command to quickly pursue the rebels and subjugate the evil parties, and plan a punitive expedition. Here, the formations of fish-scales and crane-wings do not bring advantage to the government army; the authority of star banners and lightning halberds seems to let the rebel kind ride on victory. If not for the protection of Gods and Buddhas, how can we quell the chaotic disturbance of rebellion? Therefore, we solely take refuge in the Tendai Buddha Dharma, and together rely on the divine grace of Hiyoshi. How much more so, unworthily, if we think of the ancestors of us subjects, we should be called the remaining descendants of the main vow. We should revere it more and more, we should respect it more and more. From now on, if there is joy in the Mountain Gate, we shall make it the joy of the whole clan; if there is anger in the Shrine family, we shall make it the anger of the whole house; transmitting this to each descendant, we shall never let it fall for eternity. The Fujiwara clan takes Kasuga Shrine and Kōfuku-ji as clan shrine and clan temple, and has long taken refuge in the Hossō Mahayana sect. The Taira clan takes Hiyoshi Shrine and Enryaku-ji as clan shrine and clan temple, and will encounter the Perfect, Real, Sudden Enlightenment teaching before our eyes. That is the relic of the past; for the sake of the house, they think of glory. This is the vow of the present; for the sake of the Lord, we ask for punishment. We look up and pray: Mountain King Seven Shrines, Prince Attendants, Dharma-Protecting Sacred Multitudes of East and West, Twelve Superior Vows Healing King Sugata, Sunlight and Moonlight Twelve Divine Generals, illuminate our non-dual sincerity, and grant a unique response. Meanwhile, may the thieves of evil plots and rebellious hearts bind their hands at the military gate, and the fellows of violent cruelty pass their heads to the capital earth. Therefore, the high nobles of this house, with different mouths but the same voice, make obeisance and vow as above.

div.p: [7.12.2] Junior Third Rank, Acting and Concurrent Governor of Echizen, Taira no Ason Michimori
[7.12.3] Junior Third Rank, Acting and Concurrent Middle Captain of the Right Guards, Taira no Ason Sukemori
[7.12.4] Senior Third Rank, Acting Provisional Middle Captain of the Right Guards and Concurrent Governor of Iyo, Taira no Ason Koremori
[7.12.5] Senior Third Rank, Acting Middle Captain of the Left Guards and Concurrent Governor of Harima, Taira no Ason Shigehira
[7.12.6] Senior Third Rank, Acting Captain of the Right Gate Guards and Concurrent Governor of Ōmi and Tōtōmi, Taira no Ason Kiyomune
[7.12.7] Sangi (Councillor), Senior Third Rank, Master of the Empress Dowager's Household and Concurrent Master of Repairs, Governor of Kaga and Etchū, Taira no Ason Tsunemori
[7.12.8] Junior Second Rank, Acting Chūnagon and Concurrent Captain of the Left Gate Guards, Seii Taishōgun, Taira no Ason Tomomori
[7.12.9] Junior Second Rank, Acting Gon-Chūnagon and Concurrent Governor of Hizen, Taira no Ason Norimori
[7.12.10] Senior Second Rank, Acting Gon-Dainagon and Concurrent Inspector of Dewa and Mutsu, Taira no Ason Yorimori
[7.12.11] Junior First Rank, Taira no Ason Munemori
[7.12.12] Juei 2nd Year, 7th Month, 5th Day. Respectfully spoken.
[7.12.13] Thus it was written.

[7.12.14] The Head Abbot pitied this and did not announce it immediately. He secluded himself in the hall of the Jūzenji Gongen, performed incantations for three days, and then announced it to the monks. A poem that had not seemed to be there at first appeared on the outer wrapping of the written vow.

lg.l: Even the dwelling where flowers bloom peacefully (Taira), as years pass, becomes the moon inclining to the west.

div.p: [7.12.15] This meant that the Mountain King Great Master pitied them, and the three thousand monks should join forces. However, since their behavior over the years and days had gone against the divine will and betrayed human hope, though they prayed, it was not granted, and though they persuaded, no one yielded. The monks truly pitied the state of affairs, but saying, "We have already sent a reply of agreement to the Genji. We cannot now lightly change that decision." And there was no monk who accepted this.

[7.13.1] On the fourteenth of the same seventh month, Higo-no-Kami Sadayoshi quelled the rebellion in Chinzei, and taking along the Kikuchi, Harada, Matsura Party and others, over three thousand horsemen, went up to the Capital. Although Chinzei was temporarily pacified, the armies of the eastern and northern provinces did not quiet down at all.

[7.13.2] Around midnight on the twenty-second of the same month, there was a tremendous disturbance in the vicinity of Rokuhara. They saddled horses, tightened girths, and carried goods to hide in east, west, south, and north. It seemed as if the enemy had broken in right now. After daybreak, it was heard: there was a man called Sado Uemon-no-Jō Shigesada of the Mino Genji. In the Battle of Hōgen some years ago, Chinzei Hachirō Tametomo was defeated and became a fugitive; as a reward for capturing him, Shigesada, who was originally a Hyōe-no-Jō, became Uemon-no-Jō at that time. Because of this, he was alienated by his clan and flattered the Heike; around midnight that night, he raced to Rokuhara and reported: "Kiso has already attacked up from the northern provinces with over fifty thousand horsemen and filled Higashi-Sakamoto on Mt. Hiei. His retainer Tate Rokurō Chikutada and scribe Tayūbō Kakumei, with over six thousand horsemen, raced up Mt. Tendai, and the three thousand monks all agreed, saying they would attack into the Capital right now." The Heike people panicked greatly and directed punitive forces in various directions. The Great Generals were Shin-Chūnagon Tomomori-kyō and Hon-Sanmi Chūjō Shigehira-kyō; with a total force of over three thousand horsemen, they left the Capital and first camped at Yamashina. Echizen Sanmi Michimori and Noto-no-Kami Noritsune guarded the Uji Bridge with over two thousand horsemen. Sama-no-Kami Yukimori and Satsuma-no-Kami Tadanori guarded the Yodo Road with over one thousand horsemen.

[7.13.3] On the Genji side, it was heard that Jurō Kurando Yukiie was entering from Uji Bridge with several thousand horsemen. They also said that the son of Mutsu Shin-Hangan Yoshiyasu, Yada Hangandai Yoshikiyo, was coming up to the Capital via Mt. Ōe. Hearing that the Genji of Settsu and Kawachi were likewise invading the Capital like clouds and mist, the Heike people called back all the punitive forces sent in various directions to the Capital, saying "If it has come to this, let us handle it in one place." The Imperial Capital, place of fame and profit, is never peaceful when the cock crows. Even in a peaceful world it is like this. How much more so in a disordered world. They thought they would go into the depths of the depths of Mt. Yoshino, but the provinces of the Seven Roads had all rebelled. Which bay would be safe? "The Three Worlds are without peace, just like a burning house"; since this is the Golden Word of the Tathagata and the exquisite text of the One Vehicle, why should it differ even slightly?

[7.13.4] As the night of the twenty-fourth of the same seventh month deepened, Former Minister of the Interior Munemori-kō went to the Rokuhara Palace where Kenreimon-in was residing and said, "Regarding the state of this world, though I thought 'even so,' now it seems it has come to this. Although people say we will manage somehow within the Capital, it is regrettable to show you misery before your eyes, so I have decided that we should take the Retired Emperor and the Emperor and make a procession to the western provinces." When he said this, the Retired Empress said, "Now, whatever happens, it must be by your arrangement." And she could not hold back the tears that overflowed her sleeves. The Minister also appeared to wring the sleeves of his robe.

[7.13.5] Perhaps hearing that the Heike would secretly take the Cloistered Emperor that night and flee outside the Capital, the Cloistered Emperor secretly left the Palace accompanied only by Uma-no-Kami Suketoki, son of Azechi Dainagon Sukekata-kyō, and made a procession to Kurama. People did not know this. Among the Heike samurai there was a man called Kitsunai Saemon-no-Jō Sueyasu. He was a clever warrior and was employed by the Retired Emperor as well. He happened to be on night watch at the Hōjūji Palace that night; hearing whispers and noise in the direction of the usual palace, and ladies-in-waiting weeping secretly, wondering what it was, he heard a voice say, "The Cloistered Emperor has suddenly disappeared; where has he gone?" "Ah, how terrible." Saying this, he immediately raced to Rokuhara and reported this to the Minister, who said "Come, it must be a mistake," but without waiting to hear, he hurriedly raced to Hōjūji Palace and looked; indeed, he was not there. Of the ladies-in-waiting serving in his presence, Nii-Dono, Tango-Dono, and others, not one moved. "What is this? What is this?" he asked, but there was not a single person who said "I know where he went"; everyone seemed bewildered.

[7.13.6] Meanwhile, as it was said that the Cloistered Emperor was not within the Capital, the disturbance in the Capital was extraordinary. How much more so, the panic of the Heike people; even if enemies had broken into their houses, it seemed it would not surpass this, as there is a limit. For days the Heike had prepared to take the Retired Emperor and the Emperor and make a procession to the western provinces, but now that he had abandoned them thus, they felt like rain not pooling at the base of a reliable tree (hopeless).

[7.13.7] "Even so, accomplish at least the Emperor's procession," they said, and at the hour of the Hare (6 AM), when the Imperial Palanquin had already arrived, the Emperor was six years old this year, and being still young, was taken without understanding anything. His mother Kenreimon-in rode in the same palanquin. "Transfer the Naishidokoro (Mirror), the Sacred Jewel, and the Sacred Sword. Take along the Seal, Keys, Time Tablet, Genjō, and Suzuka (biwas) as well." Although Taira no Dainagon Tokitada-kyō commanded this, in the extreme haste and panic, many things were left behind. They forgot to take the Imperial Sword of the Day Room, etc. Only three people—this Tokitada-kyō, Kura-no-Kami Nobumoto, and Sanuki Chūjō Tokizane—accompanied in court dress. The Palace Guards and attendants wore armor and helmets and carried bows and arrows to accompany them. The procession went west on Seventh Avenue and south on Suzaku.

[7.13.8] Dawn broke on the twenty-fifth of the seventh month. The sky had already opened, clouds trailed on the eastern peaks, the dawn moon was white and clear, and the cock crow was busy. Such a thing was not seen even in dreams. Now indeed they realized that the sudden flurry of moving the capital some years ago was a portent that it would be like this.

[7.13.9] The Regent Lord also accompanied the procession and went out, but at Shichijō Omiya, seeing a youth with bound hair run quickly in front of his carriage, he saw the characters "Haru no Hi" (Spring Day) revealed on the youth's left sleeve. If one writes "Haru no Hi," it reads "Kasuga"; thinking reliably that Kasuga Daimyōjin, protector of the Hossō sect, was protecting the descendants of the Great Weaver Crown, he heard what seemed to be the voice of that youth:

lg.l: What shall I do with the withering end leaves of the wisteria (Fujiwara)? I shall leave it to the Spring Day (Kasuga).

div.p: [7.13.10] He summoned Shindō Saemon-no-Jō Takanao, who was attending, close and said, "Carefully considering the state of affairs, although the Emperor is going, the Retired Emperor is not; what do you think of the future being unreliable?" He exchanged glances with his ox-driver. Immediately understanding, he turned the carriage around, went up Omiya as if flying, and entered Chisoku-in near Kitayama.
[7.14.1] The Heike samurai Etchū Jirō Hyōe Moritsugu heard this and frequently came forward saying he would chase and stop him, but he was restrained by others and stopped.

[7.14.2] Although Komatsu Sanmi Chūjō Koremori-kyō had anticipated this for days, when facing it, it was sad. His wife was the daughter of the late Naka-no-Mikado Shin-Dainagon Narichika-kyō. Her peach-like face blooming in the dew, her rouged cheeks making eyes coquettish, her willow hair disordered by the wind—it did not seem there could be another person like her. There was a young lord called Rokudai Gozen who was turning ten years old, and his sister, a princess of eight years. Since these people all yearned not to be left behind, the Sanmi Chūjō said, "As I have said for days, I am accompanying the clan and fleeing to the western provinces. I should take you anywhere, but since enemies are waiting on the road, it is difficult to pass with peace of mind. Even if you hear that I have been killed, you must absolutely not change your appearance (become a nun). The reason is, you should marry whatever kind of person, save yourself, and raise the young ones. Why should there not be someone who shows affection?" Though he tried to console her, his wife made no reply this way or that, but pulled her clothes over her head and lay down. When he was about to depart, she clung to his sleeve and said, "In the Capital I have no father, no mother; after being abandoned by you, to whom should I look? Hearing you say 'Marry whatever kind of person' is indeed resentful. Because of karma from previous lives, a person may pity me, but would they show affection to every person? We pledged to accompany each other anywhere, vanish as dew on the same field, and become water scum at the same bottom; so the intimate words of our awakenings at night have all become lies. If it were only myself, what would I do? Realizing the misery of being abandoned, I would stay. To whom do you intend to entrust the young ones, and what do you intend for them to do? It is hateful that you leave us." Since she partly resented and partly yearned for him, the Sanmi Chūjō said, "Truly, since you were thirteen and I was fifteen, we have seen each other; I pledged to enter fire and sink in water together, and not be left behind or go ahead until the destined parting road; but if I go to the battle camp in such a wretched state, taking you along, and show you misery under the sky of a journey where the destination is unknown, that would be terrible. Moreover, this time there is no preparation. If we settle peacefully in any bay, I will send someone from there to welcome you." So saying, he made up his mind and stood up. He went out to the corridor of the middle gate, put on his armor, had his horse brought near, and as he was about to mount, the young lord and princess ran out, clung to their father's armor sleeves and skirt, and said, "Where are you going? I will go too, I will go too." As they each yearned and wept, feeling the bonds of the floating world, the Sanmi Chūjō looked all the more helpless.

[7.14.3] Meanwhile, his younger brothers, Shin-Sanmi Chūjō Sukemori-kyō, Sachūjō Kiyotsune, the same Shōshō Arimori, Tango Jijū Tadafusa, and Bitchū-no-Kami Moromori—five brothers on horseback—rode inside the gate, stopped in the courtyard, and called out in voices, "The Imperial Procession must have been delayed far; why are you here until now?" The Sanmi Chūjō mounted his horse and rode out, but turned back again, rode up to the edge of the veranda, lifted the blinds with the tip of his bow, and said, "Look at this, everyone. Because the young ones yearned so much, I was trying to console them somehow, and thus my unexpected lateness." Before he finished speaking, he wept, and the people waiting in the courtyard all dampened the sleeves of their armor.

[7.14.4] Here, there were samurai called Saitō Go and Saitō Roku; the elder was nineteen, the younger seventeen. They held onto the left and right reins of the Sanmi Chūjō's horse and said they would serve him anywhere; the Sanmi Chūjō said, "When your father Saitō Bettō went down to the northern provinces, although you frequently said you would accompany him, saying he had a specific intent, he left you behind, went down to the northern provinces, and finally died in battle; as an old retainer, he must have known beforehand that it would be like this. Leaving that Rokudai and going, there is no one to support him with peace of mind. You two, bend reason and stay." Since he commanded this, powerless, they suppressed their tears and stayed. His wife said, "For years and days, I never thought beforehand that you were such a heartless person." And she lay down writhing and weeping. The young lord, princess, and ladies-in-waiting tumbled out beyond the blinds, and without caring who heard, screamed and shouted at the top of their voices. These voices remained at the bottom of his ears, so that even above the rising waves of the Western Sea and the sound of the blowing wind, he must have felt he heard them.
