[7.14.5] As the Heike fled the Capital, they set fire all at once to Rokuhara, Ike-dono, Komatsu-dono, Hachijō, West Eighth Avenue, and the houses of the clan nobles and courtiers, over twenty places, and the residences of the people of the next ranks, and forty or fifty thousand lay houses in the Capital and Shirakawa, burning them all down.

div.head: 7.15. The Imperial Visit of the Holy Lord

div.p: [7.15.1] Some were places of the Holy Lord's visitation. The Phoenix Gate vainly leaves its foundation, and the Imperial Palanquin leaves only its tracks. Some were the grounds of the Empresses' and Consorts' pleasures and banquets. The storm in the Pepper Room sounds sad, and the color of the dew in the Side Courts is sorrowful. The dressing mirrors and emerald curtains, the foundations of the halberd forest and the fishing pavilions, the seats of ministers and the dwellings of high officials—making the management of many days empty, they became ashes and embers in an hour. How much more so the thatched huts of the retainers? How much more so the houses of the common people? The places reached by the remaining flames covered several tens of chō in every direction. Thinking that strong Wu suddenly perished and the dew of the Gusu Tower moved to thorns and brambles, and violent Qin already declined and the smoke of the Xianyang Palace hid the Jing and Wei rivers, must have been like this; it is indeed pitiable. For days they had solidified the steepness of Hangu and the Two Passes, but they were broken by the Northern Barbarians; now they relied on the depth of the Jiang, He, Jing, and Wei rivers, but they were taken by the Eastern Barbarians. How could they have planned it? That suddenly being driven out of the village of propriety, weeping, they would entrust themselves to the boundaries of ignorance. Yesterday they were divine dragons sending down rain from above the clouds. Today they are like dried fish losing water beside a shop. Fortune and misfortune share the same road; prosperity and decline flip like a palm. It is now before our eyes; who would not grieve at this? In the old days of Hōgen they flourished like spring flowers, but in the present Juei era, they have fallen like autumn maple leaves.

[7.15.2] Hatakeyama Shōji Shigetada, Oyamada Bettō Arishige, and Utsunomiya Saemon-no-Jō Asatsuna, who had come up to the Capital for the Great Watch duty in the seventh month of the past fourth year of Jishō, had been imprisoned until Juei; at this time they were about to be beheaded, but Shin-Chūnagon Tomomori-kyō spoke: "If your fortune has run out, even if you cut off the heads of these hundred or thousand men, it will be difficult to hold the world. How their wives and children and followers in their hometowns must be grieving and lamenting. If by some wonder your destiny opens up and you return to the Capital again, this will be remembered as a grateful kindness. Just bend reason and send them back to their home provinces." Because he said this, the Minister (Munemori) said, "This reasoning is quite right." And he granted them leave. These men touched their heads to the ground and, shedding tears, said, "Since we have had our worthless lives saved from the past Jishō era until now, we will accompany you anywhere and see the destination of the Imperial Procession." Though they spoke frequently, the Minister said, "Your souls must all be in the eastern provinces; there is no way we should take only your empty shells to the western provinces. Go down quickly." Since he said this, they suppressed their tears and went down. Since these too were their masters for over twenty years, the tears of parting were hard to suppress.

[7.16.1] Satsuma-no-Kami Tadanori returned from somewhere; with five samurai horsemen and one youth, totaling seven horsemen including himself, he turned back and went to the residence of Gojō-no-Sanmi Shunzei-kyō; looking, he saw the gates were closed and not opening. When he announced himself as Tadanori, those inside made a commotion, saying, "A fugitive has returned." Satsuma-no-Kami got off his horse and personally spoke in a loud voice: "There are no special details; having something to say to the Sanmi-dono, Tadanori has returned. Even if you do not open the gate, please come out to this edge." When he said this, Shunzei-kyō said, "That may be so. If it is that person, it should not be harmful. Let him in." So they opened the gate and met face to face. The nature of the situation was somehow moving. Satsuma-no-Kami spoke: "Since asking you to be my teacher years ago, I have not thought of it lightly, but for these two or three years, with the commotions in Kyoto and the rebellions in the provinces all being matters concerning our house, although I did not intend negligence, I have not constantly visited. The Lord has already left the Capital. The fate of the clan has already ended. I heard there is to be a compilation of an Anthology (Senzai Wakashū); I had thought that for the honor of my lifetime, I would receive the favor of having even one poem included, but immediately the world's disturbance occurred, and since there has been no news of it, I consider it my sole regret. If the world quiets down, surely there will be an Imperial order for the anthology. If, among the scrolls here, there is an appropriate one, and I receive the favor of even one poem, I will feel happy even in the shade of the grass and will become a distant protector." So saying, from among the poems he had composed over the days, he had written down over one hundred that he thought were excellent poems in a scroll; thinking "this is the end" when he was about to depart, he had taken it and held it; taking it out from the joint of his armor, he presented it to Shunzei-kyō. The Sanmi opened it, looked, and said, "Since you have left me such a keepsake, I shall absolutely not treat it with negligence. Do not doubt it. Even so, your coming here right now shows emotion that is exceptionally deep, and the pathos is felt especially strongly; tears of gratitude are hard to suppress." When he said this, Satsuma-no-Kami rejoiced and said, "Now, whether I sink to the bottom of the waves of the Western Sea, or expose my corpse in the mountains and fields, I have nothing left to regret in this floating world. Farewell then." And mounting his horse, tightening his helmet cords, he rode off toward the west. As the Sanmi stood watching him far into the distance, there was what seemed to be Tadanori's voice, reciting loudly: "The road ahead is far; I send my thoughts to the evening clouds of Ganyama." Shunzei-kyō felt the parting exceedingly regrettable, and suppressing his tears, went inside. Later, when the world quieted and he compiled the Senzai Shū, remembering Tadanori's appearance as it was and the words he left behind, it was moving now more than ever; although there were many appropriate poems in that scroll, since he was a person under Imperial Censure, without revealing his name, one poem composed on the topic "Flower at the Old Hometown" was included as "Anonymous."

lg.l: The capital of Shiga by the rippling waves is in ruins, but the mountain cherries remain as of old.

div.p: [7.16.2] Since he had become an enemy of the court, there was nothing to be done about the details, but it was a regrettable matter.

[7.17.1] The son of Master of Repairs Tsunemori, Kōgōgū-no-Suke Tsunemasa, had served at the Omuro Palace of Ninna-ji in boy's attire when he was young; even in such haste, remembering that parting fondly, he raced to the Ninna-ji Palace with five or six samurai, got off his horse in front of the gate, and sent word: "The clan's fortune is exhausted and today we are already leaving the Imperial Capital. The only thing I regret in this floating world is parting from my Lord. Since I began serving at the age of eight, until I performed my coming-of-age ceremony at thirteen, other than when I was ill, I never left your presence even for a short time; that I must head for the wave paths of a thousand li in the Western Sea from today, and do not know what day or time I shall return, is regrettable. I wish to visit your presence once more and see my Lord, but since I am already armored in helmet and sleeve, and carrying bow and arrow, having become a strange appearance, I feel hesitation." Thus he spoke. The Omuro (Abbot) thought it pitiful and said, "Just come without changing that appearance."
Tsunemasa that day wore a hitatare of purple brocade and armor of light green hue, carried a sword with long metal fittings, bore arrows with speckled feathers, held a lacquered rattan bow under his arm, took off his helmet and hung it on the high cord, and knelt in the garden before the Abbot. The Omuro immediately appeared, had the blinds raised high, and when he summoned him saying "Come here, come here," he ascended to the main veranda. He summoned Tōhyōe Arinori, who was accompanying him. He brought the biwa (lute) in a red brocade bag. Tsunemasa took this and placed it before the Abbot, saying, "I have brought 'Seizan' (Green Mountain) which you bestowed upon me some years ago. Although the parting is exceedingly regrettable, it is painful that such a famous item should become dust in the countryside. If by some wonder our destiny opens and we return to the Capital again, at that time I will ask for it back." As he spoke weeping, the Omuro thought it pitiful and composed one poem and gave it to him.

lg.l: Regretting the parting from you whom I never tire of, I wrap the memento for the future and keep it.

div.p: [7.17.2] Tsunemasa was given the inkstone and wrote:

lg.l: Though the water of the bamboo pipe changes, still I never tire of living in the Palace.

div.p: [7.17.3] Then he bid farewell and left; numerous page boys, rising youth, temple officials, and attendant monks clung to Tsunemasa's sleeves, held him back, regretted the parting, and there was no one who did not shed tears. Among them, Dainagon Hōin Gyōkei, who had been his junior master when Tsunemasa was young, was the son of Hamuro Dainagon Mitsuyori-kyō. Regretting the parting excessively, he escorted him as far as the banks of the Katsura River, but since it could not go on, he took his leave there, and as they parted weeping, the Hōin composed this thought:

lg.l: It is sad; whether old trees or young trees, the mountain cherries; leaving late or early, no flowers will remain.

div.p: [7.17.4] In Tsunemasa's reply:

lg.l: Travel robes, night after night spreading one sleeve; thinking of it, I will go far away.

div.p: [7.17.5] Then, he suddenly raised the red banner he had kept rolled up. The samurai waiting here and there said "There it is!", raced to gather, and with a force of about one hundred horsemen raising their whips and quickening their horses, before long they caught up with the Imperial Procession.

[7.18.1] When this Tsunemasa was seventeen, he received the order of Imperial Messenger to Usa and went down; at that time he brought Seizan, went to Usa, faced the shrine, and played secret pieces; although they were not things usually heard, the shrine maidens in attendance all wrung the sleeves of their green robes. Even the servants who did not know the music surely did not mistake it for a passing shower. These were magnificent matters.

[7.18.2] That biwa called Seizan (Green Mountain): long ago in the reign of Emperor Ninmyō, in the spring of the third year of Kashō, when Kamon-no-Kami Sadatoshi crossed to Tang, he met the Tang biwa master Lian Chengwu, and learned three pieces; he brought back three biwas, Genjō, Shishimaru, and Seizan, but perhaps the Dragon God desired it, for waves and wind rose roughly, and Shishimaru sank to the bottom of the sea. Now two biwas have been transmitted and are the treasures of the Emperors of our court.

[7.18.3] Around the Ōwa era of the holy reign of Murakami, in the middle of the night of the fifteenth (full moon), when the new moon was white and clear and the cool wind blew freshly, the Emperor played Genjō in the Seiryōden. At that time, a person like a shadow appeared before him and sang the accompaniment magnificently with an elegant and noble voice. The Emperor put down the biwa and asked, "Who are you? Where do you come from?" "This is the Tang biwa master Lian Chengwu, who taught the three pieces to Sadatoshi long ago; because I left one secret piece among the three, I have sunk into the demon path. Now, because the sound of your biwa plectrum sounded exquisite, I have come. I wish to transmit this piece to you, my Lord, and attain Buddhahood." Saying this, he took Seizan which was standing before the Emperor, tuned the strings, and transmitted the secret piece to the Lord. Among the three pieces, Jōgen and Sekijō are these. After that, both Lord and subjects regarded it with awe, and did not play this biwa, but presented it to the Omuro (Ninna-ji); because Tsunemasa was a most beloved child attendant when he was young, it is said he was entrusted with it. The plectrum guard was a painting of purple wisteria; because the dawn moon rising from between the green trees on the peak of a summer mountain was painted on the face, it was named Seizan (Green Mountain). It was a rare masterpiece not inferior to Genjō.

[7.19.1] Ike-no-Dainagon Yorimori-kyō also set fire to the Ike-dono and left, but pausing at the southern gate of Toba, he said "I have forgotten something," cut off his red emblem (of the Heike), and returned to the Capital with his force of over three hundred horsemen. The Heike samurai Etchū Jirō Hyōe Moritsugu raced to the presence of the Minister (Munemori) and said, "Look there, Ike-dono is staying behind, and many samurai are attaching themselves to him and staying; this seems treacherous. I fear to touch the Dainagon, but I will shoot an arrow at his samurai." When he said this, the Minister said, "Let unrighteous people who forget the heavy favors of many years and do not see this situation through to the end be as they are." So, powerless, he stopped. "Now, what about the sons of Lord Komatsu?" he asked. "Not one has appeared yet," they said. At that time, the New Chūnagon (Tomomori) shed tears profusely and said, "Not even a day has passed since we left the Capital, and how pitiful it is that people's hearts change. Since they thought the future would be like this, they said we should manage somehow within the Capital." And he looked at the Minister with deep resentment.

[7.19.2] Now, regarding the reason Ike-dono stayed behind: Hyōe-no-Suke Yoritomo constantly showed affection to Yorimori, saying, "I absolutely do not think lightly of you. I consider you just as the late Ike-dono (Zenni). Hachiman Daibosatsu be my witness." Besides frequently declaring this in written oaths, every time a punitive envoy went up to hunt down the Heike, he showed favor saying, "Make sure not to draw a bow against the samurai of Ike-dono." So saying "The fate of the Heike clan is exhausted and they have already fled the Capital; now I shall be saved by Hyōe-no-Suke," it was heard that he returned to the Capital. He went and secluded himself at the Tokiwa Palace of Ninna-ji where Hachijō-nyoin was staying. This was because he was accompanying the lady-in-waiting called Saishō-dono, the wet nurse's child of the Retired Empress. Though he said, "If anything happens, Yorimori, please save me," the Retired Empress said, "Now, if the world were a normal world [I could help, but now I cannot]." And she spoke without hope. Generally, even if Hyōe-no-Suke harbors good intentions, how will the other Genji behave? He had separated from his clan rashly. He felt like he was attached neither to the waves nor the shore. Meanwhile, the sons of Lord Komatsu, starting with Sanmi Chūjō Koremori-kyō, six brothers with a force of about a thousand horsemen, caught up with the Imperial Procession at the Rokuda riverbed in Yodo. The Minister waited for them and said happily, "Why until now?" Sanmi Chūjō said, "Because the young ones yearned so much, I was late trying to console them somehow." The Minister asked, "Why did you not act resolutely and bring Rokudai-dono along?" Koremori-kyō said, "The future is not reliable either." And the way he shed tears at the painful question was sad.

[7.19.3] Who were the fleeing Heike? Former Minister of the Interior Munemori-kō, Taira no Dainagon Tokitada, Taira no Chūnagon Norimori, Shin-Chūnagon Tomomori, Shuri-no-Daibu Tsunemori, Uemon-no-Kami Kiyomune, Hon-Sanmi Chūjō Shigehira, Komatsu Sanmi Chūjō Koremori, Shin-Sanmi Chūjō Sukemori, Echizen Sanmi Michimori; among the courtiers, Kura-no-Kami Nobumoto, Sanuki Chūjō Tokizane, Sachūjō Kiyotsune, Komatsu Shōshō Arimori, Tango Jijū Tadafusa, Kōgōgū-no-Suke Tsunemasa, Sama-no-Kami Yukimori, Satsuma-no-Kami Tadanori, Noto-no-Kami Noritsune, Musashi-no-Kami Tomoakira, Bitchū-no-Kami Moromori, Awaji-no-Kami Kiyofusa, Owari-no-Kami Kiyosada, Wakasa-no-Kami Tsunetoshi, Hyōbu-no-Shōyū Masaaki, Kurando Tayū Narimori, Tayū Atsumori; among the monks, Nii Sōzu Senshin, Hosshōji Shugyō Nōen, Chūnagon Risshi Chūkai, Kyōjubō Ajari Yūen; among the samurai, governors, police commissioners, guards, and officials numbering one hundred and sixty; in total a force of over seven thousand horsemen; these are the few remaining who survived the repeated battles in the eastern and northern provinces over these two or three years. Resting the Jeweled Palanquin at Sekido-in in Yamazaki, bowing toward Otokoyama (Hachiman), Taira no Dainagon Tokitada-kyō prayed: "Namu Kimyō Chōrai Hachiman Daibosatsu, starting with the Lord, please let us return to the Capital." It was indeed sad. As each looked back, feeling the sky was misty, only smoke rose heartlessly. Taira no Chūnagon Norimori-kyō:

lg.l: How fleeting; as the Master departs into the clouds, the traces rise as smoke.

div.p: [7.19.4] Shuri-no-Daibu Tsunemori:

lg.l: Looking back at my hometown as a field of burnt plains, I go on a path of waves that is also smoke (uncertain).

div.p: [7.19.5] Truly, separating from their hometown by a single sheet of smoke and dust, heading for a cloud road of ten thousand li ahead, the hearts of the people can be surmised and are pitiable.

[7.19.6] Higo-no-Kami Sadayoshi heard that the Genji were waiting at Kawajiri, and intending to scatter them, set out with over five hundred horsemen, but since it was a mistake, while returning, he met the Imperial Procession in the vicinity of Udono. Sadayoshi jumped off his horse, put his bow under his arm, knelt before the Minister, and said, "Where are you fleeing to? If you go down to the western provinces, being called fugitives, you will be scattered and killed here and there and leave a floating name (infamy), which is regrettable. You should settle things within the Capital." When he said this, the Minister said, "Do you not know, Sadayoshi? Kiso has already attacked up from the northern provinces with over fifty thousand horsemen and filled Higashi-Sakamoto on Mt. Hiei. Around midnight this night, the Cloistered Emperor also disappeared. If it were only ourselves, what would we do? But showing misery before the eyes of the Retired Empress and Nii-Dono is painful, so we have carried out the Imperial Procession, taken the people along, and thought to make a stand." When he said this, Sadayoshi said, "If that is so, Sadayoshi asks for leave to settle things in the Capital." And entrusting the force of over five hundred horsemen he had brought to the sons of Lord Komatsu, he turned back to the Capital with a hand force of about thirty horsemen.

[7.19.7] Hearing that Sadayoshi was returning to kill the remaining Heike partisans in the Capital, Ike-Dainagon panicked greatly, saying "It must be about Yorimori." Sadayoshi set up a large curtain at the burnt ruins of West Eighth Avenue and stayed one night, but since not a single one of the Heike lords returned, feeling disheartened, saying he would not be trampled by Genji horses, he dug up the grave of Lord Komatsu, faced the bones, and weeping said: "Ah, how terrible, look at the end of your clan. Although it has been written since ancient times that 'Those who live must die; when pleasure is exhausted, sadness comes,' I have not seen such sadness before my eyes. You realized such things first, prayed to the Buddhas, Gods, and Three Treasures beforehand, and hastened your passing. I feel grateful. At that time, Sadayoshi should have accompanied you in death, but living a worthless life, meeting such misery now is regrettable. At the time of my death, please welcome me to the same Buddha Land." Weeping and lamenting from afar, he sent the bones to Kōya, had the surrounding earth thrown into the Kamo River, and perhaps thinking the state of the world unreliable, fled to the eastern provinces, meeting his master later. Since he had entrusted Utsunomiya [to the Heike] and shown him kindness, perhaps due to that friendship, when Sadayoshi relied on Utsunomiya and went down, it is heard that he was treated well.

div.head: 7.20. Fleeing Fukuhara

div.p: [7.20.1] The Heike, other than Komatsu Sanmi Chūjō Koremori-kyō, brought their wives and children starting with the Minister, but since they could not take along people of lower rank, not knowing the time of future meeting, they abandoned them all and fled. Even if one sets a time saying "On such a day, such a time, I will surely return," waiting is long. How much more so, since this was the last day, the very limit, both those going and those staying dampened each other's sleeves. Since hereditary friendship and the heavy favors of years and days were hard to forget, old and young alike looked only back and could not advance forward. Some spent the day with waves as pillows on the rocky shore, parting the eight-fold tide paths; some pushing through distance and braving steepness, whipping their horses or poling boats, fled with various thoughts.

[7.20.2] The Heike arrived at the old capital of Fukuhara; the Minister summoned hundreds of appropriate samurai, old and young, and spoke: "The accumulated merit of ancestors is exhausted in the house, and the accumulated evil calamity has reached our persons; therefore, abandoned by the gods and discarded by the Lord, leaving the Imperial Capital and drifting in travel lodgings, what hope can we have? However, even sheltering under the same tree is a bond of no shallow past life; scooping from the same stream is a deep connection of other lives. How much more so, you are not retainers who followed us for a short time, but hereditary housemen of generations. Some have close friendship different from others; some have deep hereditary favor. In the old days of the family's prosperity, I looked after you privately through waves of favor. Now why should you not repay that favor? Furthermore, the Emperor of Ten Good Deeds, bearing the Three Sacred Treasures, is with us; do you not intend to accompany the Imperial Procession to whatever end of the fields or depths of the mountains?" When he spoke thus, old and young all shed tears and said, "Even base birds and beasts have hearts to repay kindness and virtue. How much more so, as human beings, how could we not know that principle? For over twenty years, raising wives and children and looking after followers has entirely been due to the Lord's favor. Especially in the custom of those involved with bow and horse, we consider double-heartedness a shame. If so, outside of Japan, to Silla, Baekje, Koryo, Khitan, to the ends of the clouds and ends of the sea, we will accompany the Imperial Procession and manage somehow." When they spoke with one voice, everyone seemed encouraged.

[7.20.3] They spent one night in the old village of Fukuhara. It was the season of early autumn, and the moon was in its last quarter. Late at night, the sky was quiet; on the grass pillow of the travel bed, dew and tears contended, and everything was sad. Not expecting to return, they looked at the places built by the late Lay Priest Prime Minister: the Hill Palace for flower viewing in spring, the Shore Palace for moon viewing in autumn, the Spring Pavilion, Pine Shade Pavilion, Riding Ground Pavilion, Two-Story Gallery Pavilion, Snow Viewing Palace, Kaya Palace, the mansions of people, the Village Palace built by Gojō Dainagon Kunitsuna-kyō; the Mandarin Duck tiles and jeweled pavements had all run wild in three years; old moss blocked the paths, and autumn grass closed the gates. Pines grew on the tiles, and ivy flourished on the fences. Terraces tilted and were moss-covered; only the pine wind passed through. Blinds were broken and bedrooms exposed; only moonlight entered. When day broke, they set fire to the Fukuhara Palace, and starting with the Emperor, everyone boarded the ships. Though it was not as long as leaving the Capital, the parting from here was also regrettable. The evening smoke of fishermen burning seaweed, the morning voice of deer on the peaks, the sound of waves lapping at the shores, the reflection of the moon lodging in sleeves, the crickets chirping in the thousand grasses—everything seen by the eye and touched by the ear aroused pathos and pained the heart. Yesterday ten thousand horsemen lined their bits at the foot of the Eastern Barrier; today seven thousand people untied their cables on the waves of the Western Sea; the sea of clouds was deep, and the blue sky was already darkening. Evening mist separated the solitary islands, and the moon floated on the sea. Parting the waves of distant bays, pulled by the tide, the going ships went up into the clouds of the mid-sky. As days passed, the Capital was separated by mountains and rivers and became a distant place above the clouds. Thinking they had come far, the only thing that did not exhaust itself was tears. Seeing a flock of white birds on the waves, they thought sadly, "Could those be the 'Capital Birds' (Miyako-dori) with the nostalgic name that Ariwara no Nani-gashi asked about at the Sumida River?" On the twenty-fifth of the seventh month of the second year of Juei, the Heike completely fled the Capital.

div.note: [] [1] Nihon Koten Bungaku Taikei (Tokyo: Iwanami Shoten, 1957, vol. 33; hereafter cited as NKBT) reads "without delay".
[] [5] Our copy-text reads "greatly panicked". The character 'ni' was added to our text from the standard text in NKBT.

div.head: 8.1. The Imperial Progress to the Mountain Gate

div.p:
[8.1.1] On the twenty-fourth day of the seventh month of the second year of Juei, around midnight, the Cloistered Emperor, accompanied only by the son of the Azechi Dainagon Sukekata, Uma-no-kami Suketoki, secretly left the palace and made an imperial progress to Kurama. The monks of Kurama Temple said, "This is still too close to the capital and is dangerous," so he braved the steep and difficult passes of Shino-no-mine and Yakuō-zaka, and proceeded to the Jakkō-bō palace in the Gedatsu valley of Yokawa. The great multitude [of monks] rose up and said, "The imperial progress should be to the Eastern Pagoda."
Thus he proceeded to the En'yū-bō palace in the Southern Valley of the Eastern Pagoda. When this happened, both the multitude of monks and the warriors guarded the En'yū-bō. The Cloistered Emperor left the Sentō Palace for Mount Tendai, the Emperor left the Phoenix Gate for the Western Sea, and the Regent Lord went to the depths of Yoshino or somewhere. The Lady Cloistered Emperor and the princes fled and hid themselves in places like Yawata, Kamo, Saga, Uzumasa, Nishiyama, and the outskirts of Higashiyama. The Heike have fled, but the Genji have not yet entered to replace them. Already this capital has become a masterless village. Since the creation of the world, it was not thought that such a thing could happen. Even in the prophetic records of Prince Shōtoku, the events of today are strange.

[8.1.2] When it was heard that the Cloistered Emperor had crossed over to Mount Tendai, the people who galloped to join him included the Lay Priest Lord of that time [Fujiwara no Motofusa], the former Kampaku Matsu-dono, the current Regent Konoe-dono, the Dajo-daijin, the Ministers of the Left and Right, the Naidaijin, Dainagon, Chunagon, Sangi, and courtiers of the Third, Fourth, and Fifth ranks; indeed, of all those counted as people in the world, who placed their hopes in office and rank, and who held estates and posts, not a single one was left out. At En'yū-bō, so many came and gathered that above the hall, below the hall, outside the gate, and inside the gate, it was full without a gap. It seemed to be the honor of the prospering Mountain Gate sect.

[8.1.3] On the twenty-eighth day of the same month, the Cloistered Emperor returned to the capital. Kiso guarded him with more than fifty thousand horsemen. The Omi Genji, Yamamoto-no-Kaja Yoshitaka, raising a white banner, served in the vanguard. That the white banner, which had not been seen for these twenty-odd years, entered the capital today, was a rare thing indeed.

[8.1.4] In the meantime, Jurō Kurōdo Yukiie crossed the Uji Bridge and entered the capital. The son of Mutsu-no-Shin-Hangan Yoshiyasu, Yada-no-Hangandai Yoshikiyo, went up to the capital via Oeyama. The Genji of Settsu and Kawachi provinces likewise broke into the capital like clouds and mist. Generally, the capital was filled with the forces of the Genji. Kadenokōji Chunagon Tsunefusa-kyō and the Kebiishi Betto Saemon-no-kami Saneie waited on the veranda of the Cloistered Emperor's palace and summoned Yoshinaka and Yukiie. Kiso wore a hitatare of red brocade, armor laced with Chinese damask, carried a sword of impressive make, bore arrows with spotted feathers, held a rattan-wrapped bow under his arm, took off his helmet and hung it on the high cords, and waited. Jurō Kurōdo wore a hitatare of dark blue brocade, armor with scarlet lacing, carried a sword with gold fittings, bore arrows with large black feathers, held a lacquered rattan-wrapped bow under his arm, and he too took off his helmet, hung it on the high cords, and knelt and waited. An order was handed down that the former Naidaijin Lord Munemori and the rest of the Heike family should be chastised. The two men received it with awe in the garden. Each stated that they had no lodging. Kiso was given the residence of Daizen-no-Taiyu Naritada at Rokujo Nishinotoin. Jurō Kurōdo was given the thatched palace called the Southern Hall of the Hōjūji-dono. The Cloistered Emperor grieved that the Emperor had been taken by his maternal relatives, the Heike, and was drifting on the waves of the Western Sea, so he issued a decree to the western provinces that the Emperor and the Three Sacred Treasures should be returned to the capital, but the Heike did not heed it.

[8.1.5] As for the princes of the Takakura Retired Emperor, besides the Emperor, there were three. The Heike, intending to make the Second Prince the Crown Prince, took him along and fled to the western provinces. The Third and Fourth Princes were in the capital. On the fifth day of the same eighth month, the Cloistered Emperor welcomed these princes; first, when the Third Prince, who was five years old, was told "Come here, come here," he looked at the Cloistered Emperor and became very difficult, so saying "Quickly, quickly," he was taken out. After that, when the Fourth Prince, who was four years old, was told "Come here," he did not hesitate in the least, and immediately went onto the Cloistered Emperor's lap, sitting most delightfully. The Cloistered Emperor shed tears profusely and said, "Truly, if he were a stranger, looking at such an old priest, why would he think to be friendly? This is indeed my true grandchild. He does not differ in the slightest from the the late Retired Emperor when he was young. To think I had not seen such a memento until now!"
And he could not stop his tears. The Nii-dono of Jōdo-ji, who at that time was still called Tango-dono and was serving in his presence, said, "Well then, the succession will likely be settled on this Prince."
The Cloistered Emperor asked, "Is there a specific reason?" She replied, "In a private divination, it was interpreted that 'If the Fourth Prince ascends to the throne, he shall be the master of the land of Japan for a hundred reigns.' "

[8.1.6] His mother was the daughter of Shichijō Shuri-no-Taiyu Nobutaka-kyō. When Kenreimon-in was still the Empress, she served in her apartments, and while the Emperor summoned her frequently, princes were born one after another. Since Lord Nobutaka had many daughters, he wished by any means to make one an Imperial Consort or Empress; hearing that there was a saying that if one keeps a thousand white chickens in one's house, an Empress will certainly come forth from that house, he gathered and kept a thousand white chickens; perhaps because of this, this daughter bore many princes. Lord Nobutaka was secretly pleased, but he was hesitant before the Heike and afraid of the Empress, so there was no one to treat them with ceremony; but the Lay Priest Prime Minister's wife, the Nii-dono of Hachijo, said, "It should not be painful; I will raise him and make him the Crown Prince."
So she assigned many wet nurses and raised him.

[8.1.7] Among them, the Fourth Prince was the foster child of the Nii-dono's elder brother, the Hosshōji administrator Noen Hoshi. When the Seal of the Law [Noen], accompanying the Heike, fled to the western provinces, in the excessive confusion, he left his wife and the Prince in Kyoto and went down; but he hurriedly sent a person up from the west saying, "Bring my wife and the Prince and come down carefully." The wife was exceedingly happy, and taking the Prince along, she went out as far as West Shichijō, but the woman's elder brother, Kii-no-kami Norimitsu, said, "Are you possessed by something crazy? This Prince's fortune is about to open up right now."
Saying this, he stopped them; on the following day, the carriage of welcome came from the Cloistered Emperor. Although one might say everything was as it should be, for the Fourth Prince, Kii-no-kami Norimitsu appeared as a man of service. However, after the Fourth Prince ascended the throne, he did not recall that kindness, and as years and months passed without imperial favor, perhaps because his feelings were too much to bear, he composed two poems and scribbled them in the palace.

lg.l: Call out one note and cry, O cuckoo, of the midnight of old at the Tadasu Woods.
Even inside the cage, I envy the yamagara bird, hiding its body in the house of the evening faces.

div.p:
[8.1.8] The Emperor saw this and said, "Ah, how pitiless. So he has lived in the world until now. It is foolish that I have not thought of this until today."
Thus he received imperial favor and it is heard that he was promoted to the Senior Third Rank.

[8.2.1] On the tenth day of the same eighth month, official appointments were held in the Retired Emperor's palace. Kiso became Sama-no-kami and was given Echigo Province. Moreover, he was given the decree of the Asahi Shogun [General of the Morning Sun]. Jurō Kurōdo became Bingo-no-kami. When Kiso disliked Echigo, he was given Iyo. When Jurō Kurōdo disliked Bingo, he was given Bizen. Besides them, more than ten Genji became provincial governors, police commissioners, gate guards, and military guards.

[8.2.2] On the sixteenth day of the same month, the official positions of more than one hundred and sixty people of the Heike clan were halted, and their name plaques in the palace were scraped off. Among them, Hei Dainagon Tokitada-kyō, Kurano-kami Nobumoto, and Sanuki-no-Chujo Tokizane—these three were not scraped off. This was because decrees were sent many times to that Tokitada-kyō that the Emperor and the Three Sacred Treasures should be returned to the capital.

[8.2.3] On the seventeenth day of the same eighth month, the Heike arrived at Dazaifu in Mikasa District, Chikuzen Province. Kikuchi Jiro Takanao had served in the Heike's train from the capital, but saying he would open the barrier at Otsuyama for them, he crossed over to Higo Province, shut himself in his own castle, and though summoned, he did not come. At that time, only the Iwato High Priest Okura Tanenao served them. The warriors of the two islands of Kyushu, while sending letters of acceptance saying they would come immediately, did not come. The Heike went to Anraku-ji Temple, composed poems, linked verses, and performed services; the Hon-Sanmi Chujo Shigehira-kyō wrote:

lg.l: The longing for the old capital where we used to live; surely even the god thinks of the past.

div.p: [8.2.4] People who heard this all shed tears.

[8.2.5] On the twentieth day of the same month, by the decree of the Cloistered Emperor in the capital, the Fourth Prince ascended the throne at the Kan'in Palace. As for the Regent, the original Regent Konoe-dono was not changed; the Head Chamberlain and Kurōdo were appointed, and everyone withdrew. The Third Prince's wet nurse wept and grieved and regretted, but it was to no avail. Although it is said that there are not two suns in the sky nor two kings in the land, due to the evil deeds of the Heike, two kings existed in the capital and the country.

[8.2.6] Long ago, Emperor Montoku passed away on the twenty-third day of the eighth month of the second year of Ten'an. That many of his princely sons placed their hopes on the throne was due to secret prayers. The First Prince, Imperial Prince Koretaka, was also called the Prince of Ono. He took the capacity of a ruler to heart, illuminated the safety and danger of the four seas in his palm, and held the order and disorder of a hundred kings in his mind. Thus he appeared to be a lord who should have taken the name of a sage. The Second Prince, Imperial Prince Korehito, was born of the daughter of the Regent of that time, Lord Chujin [Fujiwara no Yoshifusa], the Empress of Somedono. Since the whole clan of nobles lined up to support him, this too was a matter difficult to set aside. That one had the caliber to preserve culture and inherit the body. This one had the physiognomy of a minister to assist the myriad affairs of state. Both that one and this one were touching, and regarding both, the Emperor was troubled. For the prayers of the First Prince, Imperial Prince Koretaka, there was Kakimoto-no-Ki Sojo Shinzei, the head abbot of Toji and a disciple of Kobo Daishi. For the prayers of the Second Prince, Imperial Prince Korehito, the guardian monk of his maternal grandfather Lord Chujin, the Osho Eryo of Mt. Hiei, undertook them. They were high priests not inferior to each other. People whispered to each other that the matter would likely be difficult to resolve quickly. When the Emperor passed away, the nobles held a council. "If we subjects, using our own judgment, select and enthrone someone, it will resemble favoring and discarding based on private reasons, and the multitude will turn up their lips. It is unknown; let us conduct horse racing and sumo wrestling to know their fortune, and depending on victory or defeat, offer the Imperial Throne."
Thus the decision was made.

[8.2.7] On the second day of the same ninth month, the two Princes proceeded to the Ukon Riding Grounds. Here, princes and nobles, adorning their flowery sleeves and lining up their jeweled bits, overlapped like clouds and ranged like stars; since this was a rare and excelling event, a magnificent sight for the realm, the courtiers and cloud-guests who had for some days given their hearts, dividing into both sides, clasped their hands and broke their hearts. Which of the high priests performing prayers would be negligent? Shinzei set up an altar at Toji, and Eryo set up an altar at the Shingon-in of the Palace and performed rites; thinking that if he announced that Eryo had failed, Bishop Shinzei might relax his mind, Eryo made an announcement that Osho Eryo had failed, and prayed breaking his liver and gall. Already the ten rounds of horse racing began. In the first four rounds, the First Prince, Imperial Prince Koretaka, won. In the latter six rounds, the Second Prince, Imperial Prince Korehito, won. Next, saying there should be sumo wrestling, from Koretaka's side, a man named Natora Uhyoe-no-Kami, a terrifying person who had the strength of sixty men, was put forth. From Imperial Prince Korehito's house, a man named Yoshio Shosho, small of stature and seemingly unable to match even one hand, was brought forth upon application, saying there had been an oracle in a dream. Natora and Yoshio came together, firmly took their grips, and withdrew. After a while, Natora picked up Yoshio Shosho, lifted him, and threw him about two jo. He just landed on his feet and did not fall. Yoshio again quickly approached, gave a shout, and tried to take Natora down. Natora also gave a voice and tried to take down Yoshio. Neither appeared inferior. However, Natora was a large man and gained the advantage in bulk. Yoshio looked in danger, so from the house of the Second Prince Imperial Prince Korehito's mother, the Empress of Somedono, messengers ran repeatedly like the teeth of a comb, saying, "Our side already looks to be the losing color. What shall we do?"
[_][1] When this was said, Osho Eryo, who was performing the rite of Dai-Itoku, said, "This is a distressing thing."
He smashed his own skull with a single-pronged vajra, mixed it with milk, burned it in the Goma fire, raised black smoke, and when he rubbed with all his might, Yoshio won the sumo match. The Prince ascended the throne. This is Emperor Seiwa. Later he was called the Emperor of Mizunoo. From that time on, it has been transmitted that at the Mountain Gate [Enryakuji], even in trivial matters, if Eryo smashed his skull, two emperors ascended the throne, and when the noble rank brandished the sword of wisdom, the Chancellor [Sugawara no Michizane] accepted it. Could this have been only due to Dharma power? Besides that, we hear it was all the arrangement of Amaterasu Omikami. The Heike heard this transmitted in the western provinces. "It is unsettling. We should have taken the Third Prince and the Fourth Prince and gone down."
When they regretted this, Hei Dainagon Tokitada-kyō said, "In that case, the son of Prince Takakura, whom Kiso has made his lord, was made to become a monk by his wet nurse Sanuki-no-kami Shigehide, taken along, and fled to the northern provinces; he will likely ascend the throne." Then certain people said, "How can a monk-prince be made to ascend the throne?"
Tokitada said, "That may be so, but there are probably precedents in foreign lands for a returned-to-secular-life king; in our court, when Emperor Temmu was still the Crown Prince, deferring to Prince Otomo, he shaved his hair and hid himself in the depths of Yoshino, but he destroyed Prince Otomo and in the end ascended the throne. Also, Empress Koken developed the great Bodhi mind, took the tonsure, and was called the Nun Hoki, but she ascended the throne again and was called Empress Shotoku. Much less should there be any details [problems] with the returned-to-secular-life Prince whom Kiso has made his lord."
Thus he spoke.

[8.2.8] On the second day of the same ninth month, a noble imperial envoy was sent from the Cloistered Emperor to Ise. The imperial envoy was heard to be Sangi Naganori. Although there are traces of the three generations of Suzaku, Shirakawa, and Toba Retired Emperors sending noble imperial envoys to Ise, these were all before they became monks. I hear this is the first instance of an example after becoming a monk.

[8.3.1] Meanwhile in Tsukushi, although there was talk that a palace should be built, the capital was not yet determined. The Emperor moved to the residence of the Iwato High Priest Okura Tanenao. Since the people's houses were in the midst of fields and paddies, though they did not pound cloth, it could be called the Village of Tochi. Since the palace was in the mountains, it felt like the log palace [of Asakura], and conversely, there were elegant aspects. First an imperial progress was made to Usa Shrine. The residence of the High Priest Kinmichi became the Imperial Palace. The shrine grounds became the dwelling place of the nobles and courtiers. In the corridors were officials of the fifth and sixth ranks; in the garden were the warriors of Shikoku and Chinzei, wearing helmets and armor and carrying bows and arrows, lined up like clouds and mist. The old cinnabar jewel-fence appeared to be adorned again. At the dawn of the seven-day retreat, there was a dream oracle for the Minister Lord [Munemori]. The door of the precious sanctuary was pushed open, and in a voice exceedingly noble and divine:

lg.l: In the gloom of the world there are no gods; for what do you pray with all your heart?

div.p: [8.3.2] The Minister Lord was startled and his breast was agitated,

lg.l: Thinking "even so" [there is hope], both my heart and the sound of insects have weakened utterly at the end of autumn.

div.p: [8.3.3] He recited this old poem under his breath, seemingly disheartened.

[8.3.4] In the meantime, it became past the tenth day of the ninth month. The evening storm stripping the reed leaves, the bed of single sleeping alone, the sleeves spread out getting damp; the sadness of the deepening autumn, though said to be everywhere, is difficult to endure in the sky of travel. The night of the thirteenth of the ninth month has a moon that has gained fame, but on that night, due to tears recalling the capital, it was cloudy from within and not clear. Remembering the evenings when they composed verses on the enduring moon above the clouds of the nine-fold palace as if they were present now, Satsuma-no-kami Tadanori:

lg.l: Of the friends with whom I viewed the moon this night last year, do only they recall me in the capital?

div.p: [8.3.5] Shuri-no-Taiyu Tsunemori:

lg.l: It is longing! Through the whole night of this night last year, the person I pledged with comes to mind.

div.p: [8.3.6] Kogo-no-Miya-no-Suke Tsunemasa:

lg.l: Not vanishing like the dew on the withered fields I pushed through to come here, I look at the moon of an unexpected village.

div.p: [8.3.7] Bungo Province was the province of Gyobu-kyō Sanmi Yorisuke-kyō. His son Yoritsune Ason was placed there as a deputy. From the capital to Yoritsune, a message was sent saying: "The Heike have been cast out by the gods and abandoned by the sovereign, left the imperial capital, and have become fugitives drifting on the waves. It is strange that the people of Chinzei receive and treat them well. In this province, you must not obey. Unite in one mind and drive them out." Yoritsune Ason ordered this to the resident of the province, Ogata no Saburo Koreyoshi.

[8.3.8] This Koreyoshi was the descendant of a terrifying being. . For example, there was a woman in a remote mountain village in Bungo Province long ago. To the place of a certain person's only daughter, who had no husband, a man came night after night without the mother knowing; as months and years piled up, she became pregnant. The mother, suspicious of this, asked, "Who is the person who comes to you?" She said, "I see him come, but I do not know his leaving." The mother taught her, "In that case, when the man is about to leave, attach a mark and follow where the thread leads to see." The daughter, following her mother's instruction, stuck a needle into the collar of the light blue kariginu worn by the man returning in the morning, attached a spool of thread called a 'shizu-no-odamaki,' and when she followed where the thread led, in Bungo Province, at the border of Hyuga, at the foot of a peak called Ubadake, it led into a large rock cave. When the woman stood at the mouth of the rock cave and listened, there was a groaning with a loud voice. When she said, "I have come this far to seek you; I will see you," he said, "I am not in a human form here; if you see my form, your liver and soul will surely not stay in your body. Go back quickly, quickly. The child you have conceived should be a boy. Taking up bow and arrow and weapons, there will be no one to equal him in the two islands of Kyushu." The woman spoke again, "Even so, whatever form you may be, how should I forget our daily intimacy? We will see each other's forms." Being told this, saying "Then [look]," from within the rock cave, a great serpent, seemingly five or six shaku in reclining height and fourteen or five jo in length, crawled out with a shaking motion. The needle she thought she stuck in the collar of the kariginu was stuck right in the windpipe of the great serpent. The woman, seeing this, felt her liver and soul leave her body, and the more than ten attendants she had brought fell down, panicked, screamed, and ran away. The woman returned, and before long gave birth; it was a boy. The maternal grandfather, O-dayu, intended to raise him and see; when he grew up, before he was even ten years old, his back was large, his face long, and he was tall. He had his coming-of-age ceremony at seven; since his maternal grandfather was called O-dayu, this one was named O-da. In summer and winter, since large chapped cracks split open without gaps on his hands and feet, he was called Akagari [Chapped] O-da. The said great serpent is the shintai of the Hochio Myojin worshipped in Hyuga Province. This Ogata no Saburo is the grandson of the fifth generation of Akagari O-da. Since he was the descendant of such a terrifying being, calling the governor's order a decree of the Retired Emperor, he sent circular letters to the two islands of Kyushu, and appropriate warriors followed and attached themselves to Koreyoshi.

[8.4.1] The Heike had now settled the capital in Tsukushi and there was talk that a palace should be built, but when it was heard that Koreyoshi had rebelled, there was an uproar of "What is this?" Hei Dainagon Tokitada-kyō said, "That Koreyoshi is a retainer of the Komatsu-dono. One of the Komatsu-dono's sons should face him, persuade him, and see."
Since this was said to be true, the Komatsu New Sanmi Chujo Sukemori-kyō crossed over to Bungo Province with more than five hundred horsemen and tried to persuade him in various ways, but Koreyoshi did not obey. Furthermore, he said, "I should arrest you right now here, my lord, but thinking it a small matter amidst great matters, if I do not arrest you, what amount of thing is it to let you pass? Quickly, quickly return to Dazaifu, and just be together [with the others] and do whatever you will."
Saying this, he chased him back. Using Koreyoshi's second son, Nojiri Jiro Koremura, as a messenger, he said to Dazaifu, "Since the Heike are lords of heavy obligation, I should take off my helmet, unstring my bow, and join you, but it is the Cloistered Emperor's decision that you be quickly driven out of the nine provinces. You should probably leave quickly."
When he sent this message, Hei Dainagon Tokitada-kyō, in scarlet-tied hakama, a hitatare of kudzu thread, and a tall eboshi, went out to face Koremura and proclaimed, "Now our Lord is the direct line of the forty-ninth generation from the Heavenly Grandson, the eighty-first generation Human Sovereign. Amaterasu Omikami and Sho-Hachiman-gu surely protect our Lord. Especially, the late Dajo-daijin Lay Priest Lord quieted the rebellions of Hogen and Heiji twice, and moreover, he treated the people of Chinzei like his own children. The villains of the eastern and northern provinces have been cajoled by Yoritomo and Yoshinaka, and thinking it true that if they accomplish the deed they will be entrusted with provinces and given manors, for you to follow Bungo's order based on that nose is not right."
Thus he proclaimed. Since the Bungo Governor Gyobu-kyō Sanmi Yorisuke-kyō had an exceedingly large nose, he proclaimed thus. Koremura returned and told this to his father, who said, "What is this? The past is the past, the present is the present; if that is the case, quickly drive them out of the nine provinces."
Hearing that he was gathering forces, the Heike samurai Gendayu Hangan Sadasada and Settsu Hangan Morizumi said, "This is outrageous for our future peers. We will arrest him."
With their force of more than three thousand horsemen, they set out for Koyanohon-sho in Chikugo Province and fought for one day and one night. However, Koreyoshi's forces overlapped like clouds and mist, so their strength did not suffice and they withdrew.

[8.4.2] Hearing that Ogata no Saburo Koreyoshi was already attacking with a force of over thirty thousand horsemen, the Heike fled Dazaifu without even taking their belongings. Leaving the vicinity of the sacred rope of Tenman Tenjin, on whom they had relied so much, with helpless hearts, and since there were no palanquin bearers, the Onion-Flower Palanquin was heard only in name, and the Emperor rode in a waist-palanquin. Beginning with the Empress Dowager, the noble ladies held up the hems of their hakama, and the nobles and courtiers from the Minister Lord down tucked up their sashinuki; going out the gate of Mizuki, walking barefoot, striving to be first, to be ahead, they fled to the port of Hakozaki. At that time, the falling rain was like wheel axles, and the blowing wind raised the sand. Distinguishing between falling tears and falling rain, neither could be seen. Worshipping Sumiyoshi, Hakozaki, Kashii, and Munakata from afar, they prayed only for the Emperor's return to the old capital. Braving the precipitous difficulties of Tarumi-yama and Uzura-hama, they headed toward the boundless flat sands. Since they were not accustomed to walking, the blood coming from their feet dyed the sand; red hakama increased in color, and white hakama became red-hemmed. How could the suffering of Genjo Sanzo braving the Flowing Sands and the Onion Range surpass this? However, that was for the sake of seeking the Law, so there must have been benefit for self and others. This was because of hateful enemies, so thinking of the suffering of the next world as well is sad. Harada Tayu Tanenao joined the Heike with more than two thousand horsemen. Yamaga Hyodo-ji Hideto came to meet the Heike with several thousand horsemen, but since Tanenao and Hideto were exceedingly at discord, Tanenao turned back from the road thinking it would be bad. Passing the place called the port of Ashiya, remembering it was the name of a village when they passed from the capital to Fukuhara, it was dearer than any village, and they were moved by sadness anew. Though they thought to flee to Silla, Paekche, Koryo, Khitan, to the end of the clouds and the end of the sea, the waves and wind were against them and they could not; accompanied by Hyodo-ji Hideto, they holed up in Yamaga Castle. Hearing that enemies were approaching Yamaga too, they boarded small boats and crossed over to Yanagi-no-Ura in Buzen Province throughout the night. Here, although there was talk that a palace should be built, since they had no means, it was not built. Also hearing that the Genji were approaching from Nagato, they took over fishermen's small boats and floated on the sea.

[8.4.3] The third son of the Komatsu-dono, the Left Chujo Kiyotsune, was a person who originally felt things deeply; saying "We have been attacked and driven from the capital by the Genji, and driven out of Chinzei by Koreyoshi. We are like fish caught in a net. Where can we go to escape? I am not a person who will live out my life."
Clearing his mind in the moonlight, he stood on the roof of the boat, recited poetry to a transverse flute, and quietly reading sutras and chanting the Nembutsu, he sank into the sea. Men and women wept and grieved, but it was to no avail.

[8.4.4] Nagato Province was the province of the New Chunagon Tomomori-kyō. The deputy was a man called Kii-no-Gyobu-no-Taiyu Michisuke. Hearing that the Heike were riding in small boats, he mustered more than one hundred large ships and presented them. The Heike transferred to these and crossed over to the land of Shikoku. Under the direction of Shigeyoshi, the interior of Shikoku was mobilized, and at Yashima in Sanuki, a plank-roofed palace shaped like a temporary shelter or a residence was built. During that time, they could not make the strange people's houses the Imperial Palace, so the ship was decided as the Palace. The nobles and courtiers from the Minister Lord down spent their days in fishermen's huts and piled up their nights in humble beds; floating the dragon prow and cormorant neck [of the imperial boat] in the sea, the temporary palace on the waves had no time of quiet. They sank into the deep sorrow of the tide immersing the moon, and feared for their fragile lives like reed leaves covered in frost. The voices of plovers clamoring on the sandbar increased the resentment of dawn, and the sound of oars hitting the gunwales pained their hearts at midnight. Seeing white herons flocking on distant pines, they doubted if the Genji were raising white banners; hearing wild geese crying on the distant sea, they were startled wondering if soldiers were rowing boats all night. The clearing storm invaded their skin, the color of emerald eyebrows and rosy faces gradually faded; facing the blue waves, their eyes were pierced, and the tears of longing for their home in a foreign land were hard to suppress. What replaced the green curtains and red bedroom was the reed screen of a native hut; even in the humbleness of a reed-fire burning house, different from the smoke of incense burners, the ladies-in-waiting, in inexhaustible brooding, could not stop their crimson tears, their green eyebrows were disheveled, and they did not look like themselves.

div.head: 8.5. The Decree of the Barbarian-Subduing General

div.p:
[8.5.1] In the meantime, the Kamakura Former Uhyoe-no-Suke Yoritomo, while remaining there, received the decree of Seii Taishogun [Barbarian-Subduing General]. The imperial envoy was heard to be the Sasho-no-sho Nakahara no Yasusada. He arrived in the Kanto on the fourteenth day of the tenth month. Hyoe-no-Suke proclaimed, "Yoritomo has incurred imperial censure for years, but now relying on the honor of military valor, while remaining here, I receive the decree of Seii Taishogun. How should I receive it privately? I will receive it at the Wakamiya Shrine."
So he went to proceed to Wakamiya. Hachiman stands at Tsurugaoka. The terrain does not differ from Iwashimizu; there is a corridor, a tower gate, and he looked down on ten-odd cho of built road. A council was held: "Now, who should receive the decree?" Miura-no-Suke Yoshizumi should receive it. The reason is, he is the descendant of Miura Heitaro Tametsugu, a warrior renowned in the eight provinces. Moreover, since his father O-suke was a soldier who gave his life for his lord, it was heard to be to illuminate the darkness of the underworld for that Yoshiaki. The imperial envoy of the decree, Yasusada, was accompanied by two house-men and ten retainers. The decree was put in a letter bag and hung around the neck of a servant. Miura-no-Suke Yoshizumi was also accompanied by two house-men and ten retainers. The two house-men were Wada Saburo Munezane and Hiki Toshiro Yoshikazu. For the ten retainers, ten daimyo were suddenly outfitted one by one. For Miura-no-Suke's attire on that day, he wore a kachi-hitatare, black-laced armor, carried a sword of impressive make, bore twenty-four large black-feathered arrows, held a rattan-wrapped bow under his arm, took off his helmet and hung it on the high cords, and bending his waist, received the decree. Yasusada said, "Who is the person receiving the decree? Name yourself."
Miura-no-Suke did not name himself as Miura-no-Suke, but named his real name, Miura no Arajiro Yoshizumi. The decree was placed in a lacquered box. He presented it to Hyoe-no-Suke. After a while, the lacquered box was returned. Because it was heavy, when Yasusada opened it and looked, one hundred ryo of gold dust had been put in. At the worship hall of Wakamiya, sake was offered to Yasusada. Saiin-no-Jikan Chikayoshi served. One person of the Fifth Rank served as the escort. Three horses were led out. One was saddled. The samurai of the Omiya, Kano Kudo Ichiro Suketsune, led it. An old thatched house was prepared and he was put in. Two ryo of thick wadded silk garments, ten layers of kosode put in a long chest were provided; one thousand rolls of indigo-dyed white cloth were piled up. Cups and plates were abundant and beautiful.

[8.5.2] On the following day, he went to Hyoe-no-Suke's mansion. There were inner and outer samurai quarters, totaling sixteen bays. In the outer samurai quarters, house-men and retainers lined their shoulders and crossed their knees in rows. In the inner samurai quarters, the Genji of the clan sat in the upper seats, and in the lower seats, daimyo and shomyo sat in order. Yasusada was seated above the Genji. After a while, he went to the main hall. In the wide aisle, tatami with purple borders were spread, and Yasusada was seated. Above, tatami with Korean borders were spread, the bamboo blinds were rolled high, and Hyoe-no-Suke-dono came out. He wore a hoi and a tall eboshi. His face was large and he was short of stature. His appearance was elegant and his speech clear. First he stated the details one by one. "The Heike, fearing Yoritomo's power, have fled the capital. After that, Kiso-no-Kaja and Jurō Kurōdo broke in, and with faces of fame, they acquired offices and ranks as they pleased; moreover, that they refuse provinces is outrageous. Hidehira of the North has become Mutsu-no-kami, and Satake Shiro Takayoshi has become Hitachi-no-kami, so they do not obey Yoritomo's orders. I would like to receive a decree to quickly chastise them."
The Sasho-no-sho said, "This time Yasusada too is an envoy who should present his name list [as a vassal], so I will go up first and immediately write it and send it. My younger brother, Shi-no-Taiyu Shigeyoshi, also says the same."
Hyoe-no-Suke laughed and said, "For Yoritomo's status at present, I do not even think of each of your name lists. However, since you say so, you must think so. " Immediately he said he should go up to the capital today. Saying he should stay just for today, he was detained.

[8.5.3] On the following day, he went to Hyoe-no-Suke's mansion. He was given one set of belly-armor laced with light green thread, one sword made in white [mounting], and a rattan-wrapped bow with field arrows. Thirteen horses were led out. Three were saddled. For twelve house-men and retainers, hitatare, kosode, wide-mouthed trousers, extending to horses and saddles, and thirty packhorses were given. From the station exiting Kamakura to the station of Kagami, ten koku of rice were placed at every station. Since it was abundant, it was heard that it was applied to almsgiving.

[8.6.1] Yasusada went up to the capital, visited the Cloistered Emperor, and reported in detail on the state of the Kanto within the imperial garden; the Cloistered Emperor was impressed, and the nobles and courtiers all smiled with satisfaction. While Hyoe-no-Suke was thus imposing, Kiso Sama-no-kami was guarding the capital; the boorishness of his standing and sitting behavior, and the obstinacy of his speech and words were limitless. It stands to reason; since he lived from the age of two until thirty in the mountain village called Kiso in Shinano Province, how could he be refined? At one time, there was a person called Nekoma Chunagon Mitsutaka-kyō. He had something to discuss with Kiso and came to visit. When the retainers said, "Nekoma-dono has come saying he has something to discuss in an audience," Kiso laughed greatly and said, "Does a cat [Neko] have an audience with a human?"
"This is a noble called Nekoma Chunagon-dono. It is thought to be the name of his residence."
When they said this, Kiso said, "In that case," and met him. Still unable to say Nekoma-dono, he said, "Prepare something for Lord Cat [Neko-dono] who has come rarely." When the Chunagon heard this and said, "Just now, I cannot stay," Kiso said, "How can that be, when you have come on a hungry [ketoki] occasion?" Understanding that anything fresh is called unsalted [mushio], he urged, "Here are unsalted hiratake mushrooms, quickly, quickly. " Nei no Koyata served. In a rustic bowl that was extremely large and deep, rice was piled high, and with three kinds of side dishes, it was served with hiratake mushroom soup. It was placed before Kiso in the same manner. Kiso took chopsticks and ate. Since Nekoma-dono did not eat due to the filthiness of the bowl, Kiso pressed him, "That is Yoshinaka's purification bowl."
The Chunagon, though he did not want to eat, thought it would be bad [to refuse], so he took chopsticks and made a pretense of eating. Kiso saw this and pressed him, saying, "Lord Cat is a small eater. You have left the renowned cat leftovers [neko-oroshi]. Scratch [eat] it up. " The Chunagon-dono, having his interest spoiled by such things, did not utter a single word of the matter he came to discuss, and immediately hurried back.

[8.6.2] Kiso thought that a person with office and rank should not go out for official duty in a hitatare, so for the first time he put on a hoi, but from the tip of his formal eboshi to the hem of his sashinuki, he was truly obstinate [clumsy]. However, he rode in a carriage. It was ill-suited and worse than wearing armor, carrying arrows, holding a bow, and riding a horse. The ox-carriage was the ox-carriage of the Minister of Yashima. The ox-driver was also his. Since it is the custom to follow the world, he was captured and used, but because it was too dazzling, the ox, which was kept and fed, was an excellent beast, so when going out the gate, if given one lash, how could it be good? It flew out, and Kiso fell on his back inside the carriage. Spreading his left and right sleeves like the spreading wings of a butterfly, he tried to get up and get up, but how could he get up? Kiso, unable to say ox-driver, said, "Hey, young ox-groom [ushi-warawa], hey, young ox-groom."
The driver understood this as saying "do it" [yare] to the carriage, so he made it gallop five or six cho. Imai Shiro Kanehira whipped his stirrups, caught up, and scolded, "How can you treat the carriage like this?" The driver replied, "The ox's nose is strong." Thinking he would fix it inside, he said, "Hold on to the hand-rest there." Kiso grabbed the hand-rest with a 'mute' grip [reverse grip/clumsy grip] and asked, "Ah, what preparation; is this the arrangement of the ox-groom, or the style of the Lord?"
Then he arrived at the Retired Emperor's palace, had the carriage unhitched, and was about to get down from the back, when a capital servant who was employed said, "As for the carriage, when you board, you board from the back. When you get down, you get down from the front."
Though he said this, Kiso said, "How can I pass through just because it is a carriage?"
And in the end he got down from the back. Although there were many other funny things, out of awe, I do not speak of them.

[8.7.1] While remaining at Yashima in Sanuki, the Heike conquered eight provinces of the Sanyodo and six provinces of the Nankaido, totaling fourteen provinces. Kiso Sama-no-kami heard this, and saying it was not a peaceful matter, immediately dispatched a punitive force. The general of the punitive force was Yada-no-Hangandai Yoshikiyo, and the samurai general was a resident of Shinano Province, Unno Yaheishiro Yukihiro; totaling a force of more than seven thousand horsemen, they galloped down the Sanyodo, floated boats at the crossing of Mizushima in Bitchu Province, and were about to approach Yashima.

[8.7.2] On the first day of the same intercalary tenth month, a small boat appeared at the crossing of Mizushima. While watching to see if it was a fisherman's boat or an angler's boat, it was not so, but a message boat from the Heike side. Seeing this, the Genji shouted and screamed from their more than five hundred dried-out boats and went down. The Heike pushed toward them with more than a thousand boats. The general of the main force on the Heike side was New Chunagon Tomomori-kyō, and the general of the rear guard was Noto-no-kami Noritsune. Noto-dono proclaimed, "Now men, do you do battle loosely? Do you not think it miserable to be taken alive by the scoundrels of the northern provinces? Bind the boats of our side together!"
Thus, they tied the stern ropes and prow ropes of more than a thousand boats together, put hawser cables in between, and laid planks across for walking, so the tops of the boats were level. Both Genji and Heike raised war cries, exchanged arrows, and mutually pushed their boats together and attacked and fought. Those far away were shot with bows, those near were cut with swords; some were caught with rakes and taken, some were taken. Some grappled and entered the sea. Some stabbed each other and died. They decided victory and defeat as they thought and as they wished. The samurai general of the Genji side, Unno Yaheishiro, was killed. Seeing this, the general Yada-no-Hangandai Yoshikiyo boarded a small boat with seven retainers, advanced to the very front and fought, but however it happened, they trampled the boat and it sank, and they all died. Since the Heike had stood saddled horses inside their boats, they brought the boats alongside, led the horses down, whipped and rode them, shouted and attacked, so the generals of the Genji force were killed. They fled, trying to be first. The Heike won the battle of Mizushima and wiped away the shame of Kaikei [previous defeats].

[8.8.1] Kiso Sama-no-kami heard this, and saying it was not a peaceful matter, galloped down to the Sanyodo with ten thousand horsemen. The Heike samurai and resident of Bitchu Province, Seno Taro Kaneyasu, had been taken alive by the hand of Kuramitsu Jiro Narizumi, a resident of Kaga Province, during the battles in the northern provinces, and was entrusted to Narizumi's younger brother, Kuramitsu Saburo Nariuji. Since he was a renowned warrior of great strength, Lord Kiso thought, "Should I lose such a valuable man?" and did not behead him; and since he was a person of elegant spirit and sentiment, Kuramitsu also treated him with courtesy. It was like Su Wu being imprisoned in the barbarian land, or Li Ling not returning to the Han court. It is said that being attached to a distant foreign land is a place where men of old grieved. With curtains of leather and felt, they warded off the wind and rain; with mutton and mare's milk, they satisfied their hunger and thirst. Following orders to cut trees and mow grass all day long without time for sleep at night, Kaneyasu thought only of how he might spy an opening to kill the enemy and see his old master once more; the extent of his heart was indeed terrifying.

[8.8.2] One time, Seno Taro met Kuramitsu Saburo and said, "Since I have been spared my worthless life since last fifth month, whom should I think of as my master [but Kiso]? From now on, if there is a battle, I will ride in the vanguard and offer my life to Lord Kiso. Seno in Bitchu, which Kaneyasu used to govern, is a place good for horse fodder. Please speak to him about this."
When he said this, Kuramitsu reported this situation. Lord Kiso said, "He speaks of an admirable thing. In that case, make Seno the guide and go down first. Truly, make him prepare horse fodder and such."
Kuramitsu Saburo accepted with awe and joy, and with a force of about thirty horsemen, with Kaneyasu in the lead, went down to Bitchu. Seno's heir, Kotaro Muneyasu, was serving with the Heike, but hearing that his father had been granted leave by Lord Kiso and was going down, he mustered his long-time retainers and went up to meet him with a force of about fifty horsemen; they met at the provincial capital of Harima and went down together. When they stayed at the station of Mitsuishi in Bizen Province, people close to Seno came out bringing sake. While they held a joyful banquet throughout the night, the warrior guards, Kuramitsu Saburo, and their attendants, more than thirty people in all, were dead drunk and could not rise; they stabbed every one of them to death. Bizen Province was the province of Jurō Kurōdo. They also attacked and killed the deputy who was at the provincial capital. He announced: "Kaneyasu has been granted leave and has come down; those who have a mind to aspire to the Heike, with Kaneyasu in the lead, shoot a single arrow at Lord Kiso's descent!"
When he broadcast this, the warriors of the three provinces of Bizen, Bitchu, and Bingo sent their horses, weapons, and suitable attendants to the Heike side, and the remaining old men, some tying the cords of persimmon-dyed hitatare, some tucking up the hems of cotton kosode, wearing kusari-haramaki [chain belly-bands], inserting a few arrows in mountain-quivers or high-quivers, gathered in haste to Seno, carrying what they could. In total, the force was more than two thousand men; with Seno Taro in the lead, they built a fortification at the narrow pass of Sasano in the Nawate of Fukuryuji in Bitchu Province, digging a moat two jo wide and two jo deep, pulling up abatis, raising high towers, setting up shields, and arranging their arrow-points, they waited, saying 'Now, come!'.

[8.8.3] The deputy placed in Bizen Province by Jurō Kurōdo was killed by Seno, and while his servants were fleeing up to the capital, they met Lord Kiso at a place called Funasaka on the border of Harima and Bizen. When they reported this, Lord Kiso regretted it, saying, "It is not a peaceful matter. I should have cut off his head and discarded it."
Imai Shiro said, "Indeed, that is so; his face did not look like that of an ordinary man; though I said a thousand times to cut him, you spared him. " "Thinking about it, what does it matter? Chase him and kill him."
Thus he ordered. Imai Shiro said, "First, I will go down and see," and galloped down with more than three thousand horsemen. The Fukuryuji Nawate was about one take wide [approx. 1.8m] measured by a bow, and the distance was one 'ri' of the Western Road. Since there were deep paddies on the left and right and the horses' feet could not reach firm ground, though the hearts of the three thousand horsemen advanced, their horses could only walk in single file. When Kanehira pushed near and looked, Seno Taro stood forth on a tower and raised a great voice, "The kindness of each of you in sparing my worthless life from last fifth month until now, this is how I have prepared to repay it!"
He had gathered several hundred superior strong-bowmen, arranged their arrow-points, and they shot rapidly and scatteringly without ceasing. There was no way to face them. Beginning with Imai Shiro, the eager warriors such as Tate, Nei, Miyazaki Saburo, Suwa, and Fujisawa, tilting the neck-plates of their helmets, cleared away the men and horses that were shot and killed, filled in the moat, shouted war cries, and attacked. Some rode into the deep paddies on the left and right, not caring that their horses' flanks and chests were buried or that the water stood up to their bellies, and attacked in swarms; others did not shy away from valleys or cliffs, and they attacked and attacked, fighting all day until sunset. When night fell, the mustered warriors that Seno had gathered were all attacked and driven off; those who were saved were few, and those who were killed were many. Seno Taro, having his fortification at the Sasano Pass destroyed, retreated and set up shields at the edge of the Itakura River in Bitchu Province to wait. When Imai Shiro immediately pushed on and attacked, they defended as long as they had arrows in their mountain-quivers and bamboo-quivers, but when they had shot them all, they fled, trying to be first. Seno Taro was reduced to just three horsemen, master and retainers; reaching the edge of the Itakura River, they were fleeing toward Mitoroyama when Kuramitsu Jiro Narizumi, who had captured Seno in the northern provinces and whose younger brother had been killed, appeared. "It is not a peaceful matter. As for Seno, I will take him alive again."
Breaking from the group, he chased after him. Catching up to within about one cho, he called, "Ho, Seno-dono! Is it proper for a warrior to show his back to the enemy? Turn back, turn back!"
Being told this, he crossed the Itakura River to the west, pulled up in the middle of the river, and waited. Kuramitsu galloped up, lined up his horse, grappled firmly, and they fell with a crash. Since they were of equal great strength, they were on top, on bottom, rolling over each other; rolling into a deep pool at the river bank, Kuramitsu was not a swimmer, but Seno was an excellent swimmer, so he took Kuramitsu at the bottom of the water, pressed him down, pulled up the skirts of his armor, and stabbed him three times with his sword so that the hilt and fist went through, and took his head. Since his own horse was injured, he mounted the enemy Kuramitsu's horse and fled; meanwhile, Seno's heir Kotaro Muneyasu did not ride a horse but fled on foot accompanied by a retainer; although he was a man of twenty-two or twenty-three, he was excessively fat and could not run even one cho. He took off his armor and discarded it and walked, but he could not manage. His father abandoned him and fled about ten-odd cho. He met a retainer and said, "When Kaneyasu fights facing a thousand or ten thousand enemies day after day, all four directions seem clear and bright, but this time, because I have abandoned Kotaro and gone on, the way ahead seems completely dark and I cannot see. Even if Kaneyasu survives and joins the Heike side again, it would be shameful for fellow warriors to say, 'Kaneyasu, a man over sixty, sparing his short life, abandoned his only child and fled.'"
The retainer said, "Indeed that is so; this is what I meant when I said please just stay in one place and meet your fate. Please turn back."
So saying "Then," he turned back. Kotaro was lying down with his feet swollen this much. When he said, "Since you cannot catch up, I have returned to die together in one place," Kotaro shed tears profusely and said, "Since this body is a worthless thing, I should have committed suicide, but that I should cause even your life to be lost is perhaps one of the Five Cardinal Sins. Please just escape quickly, quickly."
Though he said this, the father said, "Since I have made up my mind," and as they were resting, Imai Shiro rode in the vanguard and chased them with a force of about fifty horsemen, shouting war cries. Seno Taro had seven or eight arrows remaining, and he shot rapidly and scatteringly. Not caring for life or death, he instantly shot down five or six enemy horsemen. After that, he drew his sword, first cut off Kotaro's head, then broke into the midst of the enemy, fought wildly, killed many enemies, and finally died in battle. The retainer also fought not a bit inferior to his master, but suffering many serious wounds and tired from fighting, he tried to commit suicide but was taken alive. He died one day later. The heads of these three, master and retainers, were hung at Sagi-no-mori in Bitchu Province. Lord Kiso saw this and said, "Ah, what a brave warrior. This is indeed what one should call a match for a thousand. I should have saved such regrettable men and seen them [in my service]. "

[8.9.1] Meanwhile, Lord Kiso gathered his forces at Manju-no-sho in Bitchu Province and was about to attack Yashima. During that time, Higuchi Jiro Kanemitsu, who had been left as caretaker in the capital, sent a messenger saying, "Jurō Kurōdo-dono, while you are absent, has been using the Cloistered Emperor's favorites to slander you in various ways. Leave the war in the western provinces for a while and hurry up to the capital."
