Kiso said "In that case" and galloped up, continuing day and night. Thinking perhaps that it would be bad [to stay], Jurō Kurōdo went down to Harima via the Tamba road to avoid Kiso. Kiso passed through Settsu Province and entered the capital.

[8.9.2] The Heike, intending to defeat Kiso, appointed New Chunagon Tomomori-kyō and Hon-Sanmi Chujo Shigehira-kyō as Generals, and Etchu Jiro Hyoe Moritsugu, Kazusa Goro Hyoe Tadamitsu, Aku-Shichibyoe Kagekiyo, and Iga Heinai Zaemon Ienaga as Samurai Generals; with a total force of more than twenty thousand horsemen, they embarked on over a thousand ships, crossed over to the land of Harima, and took up position at Muroyama. Jurō Kurōdo likely thought to fight the Heike and reconcile with Kiso. He attacked Muroyama with a force of more than five hundred horsemen. The Heike stretched their camp into five arrays. The first array was solidified by Etchu Jiro Hyoe Moritsugu with over two thousand horsemen; the second array by Iga Heinai Zaemon Ienaga with over two thousand horsemen; the third array by Kazusa Goro Hyoe Tadamitsu and Aku-Shichibyoe Kagekiyo with over three thousand horsemen; the fourth array by Hon-Sanmi Chujo Shigehira-kyō with over three thousand horsemen; and the fifth array by New Chunagon Tomomori-kyō with over ten thousand horsemen.
Jurō Kurōdo Yukiie attacked with more than five hundred horsemen, shouting war cries. The first array, Etchu Jiro Hyoe Moritsugu, acted as if to greet them for a while, then suddenly opened the center and let them pass. The second array, Iga Heinai Zaemon Ienaga, likewise opened and let them pass. The third array, Kazusa Goro Hyoe and Aku-Shichibyoe, both opened and let them pass. The fourth array, Hon-Sanmi Chujo Shigehira-kyō, also opened and let them in. Since they had agreed beforehand from the first to the fifth array, they trapped the enemy inside and raised a war cry all at once with a roar. Jurō Kurōdo, having no way to flee now, thought he had been tricked, and without turning his face or sparing his life, fought his last battle here. The Heike samurai said, "Grapple with the Genji General!" and advanced striving to be first, but indeed there was not a single warrior who could line up and grapple with Jurō Kurōdo. The warriors upon whom the New Chunagon relied most, called Ki no Shichi Zaemon, Ki no Hachiemon, and Ki no Kuro, were all killed there by Jurō Kurōdo. Thus Jurō Kurōdo's more than five hundred horsemen were reduced to a mere thirty or so; all four directions were enemies, and his own side had no troops. Though he did not know how he should escape, he resolved himself and broke through the midst of the enemy that was like clouds and mist. However, while he himself was not wounded, his house-men and retainers, more than twenty horsemen, were mostly wounded; they boarded a boat from Takasago in Harima Province, were rowed out, and arrived at the bay of Fukiin in Izumi Province. From there they crossed over to Kawachi and holed up in Nagano Castle. The Heike, having won the two battles of Muroyama and Mizushima, gained increasing strength.

[8.10.1] Generally, the capital was overflowing with the forces of the Genji, and there was much looting in various places. Not even sparing the domains of Kamo and Hachiman, they cut green rice fields to make fodder for horses. They broke open people's storehouses to take things, stole goods being carried by, and stripped off clothes. People said, "When the Heike were in the capital, we only feared the Rokuhara-dono in general. There was no stripping of clothes; the Genji are inferior to the Heike in exchange. " There was an imperial messenger from the Cloistered Emperor to Kiso Sama-no-kami. The order was handed down: "Quiet the violence." The messenger was the son of Iki-no-kami Tomochika, a man called Iki-no-Hangan Tomoyasu. Since he was a master of the drum superior in the realm, people of the time called him the Drum Hangan. Kiso met him, and before making a reply, asked, "Now, that you are called the Drum Hangan, do you want to be beaten by ten thousand people, or stretched [skinned]? " Tomoyasu did not make a reply, returned to the Retired Emperor's palace, and said, "Yoshinaka is an insolent fellow.[_][2] He will surely become an enemy of the court right now. Please quickly chastise him."
So the Cloistered Emperor immediately made up his mind. However, without giving orders to appropriate warriors, he gave orders to the head abbot of the Mountain [Hieizan] and the administrators of the temples, and summoned the evil monks of the Mountain and Miidera. As for the forces summoned by the nobles and courtiers, they were stone-throwers, slingers, worthless crossroad-ruffians, and beggar priests.

[8.10.2] Hearing that Kiso Sama-no-kami had fallen out of favor with the Cloistered Emperor, the people of the five home provinces who had at first followed Kiso all turned their backs and went to the Cloistered Emperor's side. The Shinano Genji, Murakami no Saburo Hangandai, also turned his back on Kiso and went to the Cloistered Emperor. Imai Shiro said, "This is an extraordinary crisis. Even so, how can we do battle facing the Emperor of the Ten Virtues? Take off your helmet, unstring your bow, and surrender."
But Kiso became greatly angry and said, "Since I left Shinano, beginning with the battles of Omi and Aida, I attacked Tonamiyama, Kurosaka, Shiozaka, and Shinohara in the northern provinces, and Fukuryuji Nawate, Sasano-no-seko, and Itakura Castle in the western provinces, but I have never shown my back to the enemy. Even if he is the Emperor of the Ten Virtues, I cannot take off my helmet, unstring my bow, and surrender. For instance, should those who guard the capital keep a horse and not ride it? If we mow however many rice fields to make horse fodder, is there reason for the Cloistered Emperor to blame us so strongly? Since there is no military rice, even if the young men loot a little in the outskirts now and then, why should it be such a terrible thing? If they went to the houses of Ministers or the palaces of Princes, that would be wrong. I feel this is the evil mischief of the Drum Hangan. Beat that drum and throw it away! This will be Yoshinaka's last battle. There is also the place where Yoritomo will hear of it. Prepare for battle, men!"
And he set out. The forces of the northern provinces had all fled, so there were merely six or seven thousand horsemen. Saying it was the lucky precedent of his battles, he formed them into seven groups. First, he dispatched Higuchi Jiro Kanemitsu with more than two thousand horsemen to the rear guard in the direction of Ima-Kumano. The remaining six groups set out, establishing a signal to come out from the alleys and streets where each was stationed to the riverbed and unite at the Shichijo Riverbed.

[8.10.3] The battle was on the morning of the nineteenth of the eleventh month. It was heard that more than twenty thousand military soldiers were holed up in the Retired Emperor's palace, the Hōjūji-dono. For the identification mark of the imperial side, they wore pine needles. When Kiso pushed to the west gate of Hōjūji-dono and looked, the Drum Hangan Tomoyasu, having received the post of battle administrator, wore a hitatare of red brocade, intentionally did not wear armor, but wore only a helmet. On the helmet, the Four Deva Kings were written in stamped gold. He climbed up and stood on the western mud wall of the palace; holding a halberd in one hand and shaking a vajra bell with the other hand, occasionally he performed dance motions. The young nobles and courtiers laughed, saying, "It is without taste. A tengu has possessed Tomoyasu. " Tomoyasu raised a great voice and shouted, "In the past, when an imperial decree was read facing them, withered grass and trees bloomed and bore fruit, and evil demons and evil gods obeyed. Just because it is the latter age, how can you face the Emperor of the Ten Virtues and draw a bow? The arrows you loose will return and strike your own bodies. The swords you draw will cut your own bodies."
When he shouted such things, Kiso said, "Do not let him speak," and raised a war cry with a roar.

[8.10.4] Meanwhile, Higuchi Jiro Kanemitsu, who had been sent to the rear guard, joined in the war cry from the direction of Ima-Kumano. Since they put fire inside their turnip-headed arrows and shot them into the palace of Hōjūji-dono, and the wind was violent at the time, fierce fire flamed up to the heavens, and the flames left no gap in the sky. The battle administrator Tomoyasu fled before anyone else. Since the administrator fled, the government army of more than twenty thousand men fled, trying to be first. In their excessive panic, those who took bows did not know arrows, and those who took arrows did not know bows. Some planted their naginatas upside down and pierced their own feet; some hung things on the ends of their bows and, unable to remove them, threw them away and fled. The end of Shichijo was guarded by the Genji of Settsu Province, but they fled west along Shichijo. Since it had been announced from the palace before the battle, "Prepare for fugitives and kill them," the residents of the capital set up shields on roofs and gathered stones for throwing; waiting there, when the Settsu Genji fled, saying "Ah, fugitives!", they threw stones and beat them severely. Although they said, "This is the Cloistered Emperor's side, do not make a mistake," the people said, "Do not let them speak! It is an imperial decree, just kill them, kill them!" While they beat them, some abandoned their horses and crawled away to escape. Some were beaten to death. The end of Hachijo was guarded by the mountain monks; those with shame died in battle, and those with impudent faces fled.

[8.10.5] Mondo-no-Kami Chikashige, wearing a belly-band with light green lacing under a light blue kariginu, rode a white dappled horse and fled up the riverbed. Imai Shiro Kanehira chased him and shot through his neck bone, shooting him down. He was the son of Sei-Daigeki Yorinari. People said, "It is not right for a doctor of the Myogyo-do [Confucian classics] to wear helmet and armor. " The Shinano Genji, Murakami Saburo Hangandai, who had turned his back on Kiso and gone to the Cloistered Emperor's side, was also killed. Beginning with him, on the Cloistered Emperor's side, Omi-no-Chujo Tamekiyō and Echizen-no-Kami Nobuyuki were also shot to death and their heads taken. Hoki-no-Kami Mitsunaga and his son Hangan Mitsutsune were killed, father and son together. The grandson of Azechi Dainagon Sukekata-kyō, Harima-no-Shosho Masakata, also went out to the battle array in armor and tall eboshi, but was taken alive by Higuchi Jiro. The Tendai Abbot Meiun Daisojo and the temple administrator Prince Enkei had come to the palace and shut themselves in, but since black smoke was already sweeping over them, they mounted their horses and hurriedly went out to the riverbed. The warriors shot at them relentlessly. Meiun Daisojo and Prince Enkei were also shot down from their horses and their heads were taken. Bungo Governor Gyobu-kyō Sanmi Yorisuke-kyō had also shut himself in the palace, but the fire was already sweeping over, so he hurriedly fled out to the riverbed. His clothes were all stripped off by the servants of the warriors, and he stood stark naked. Since it was the morning of the nineteenth of the eleventh month, the wind on the riverbed must have been terrible. The Sanmi had a brother-in-law, a monk called Echizen Hokkyo Shoi. His intermediate priest went out to the riverbed to see the battle, and encountering the Sanmi standing naked, said "Ah, how wretched," and ran up to him. This priest was wearing two white kosode and a robe, so he should have taken off a kosode and dressed him. He did not do so, but took off the robe and threw it over him. He covered his head with the short robe like a quiver, without a sash. From behind, it must have looked unsightly. He was accompanied by a priest in white robes, but instead of walking quickly, he stopped here and there, asking "Whose house is that? Whose residence is this? Where is this?"
along the road, so everyone who saw him clapped their hands and laughed.

[8.10.6] The Cloistered Emperor rode in a palanquin and made an imperial progress elsewhere. The warriors shot at him relentlessly. Bungo-no-Shosho Munenaga was serving in a hitatare of magnolia texture and a folded eboshi, and when he shouted, "This is the Imperial Progress of the Cloistered Emperor! Do not make a mistake!", the soldiers all got down from their horses and bowed. When asked, "Who is it?", he named himself as a resident of Shinano Province, Yashima Shiro Yukitsuna. Immediately he placed his hands on the palanquin, forced him into the Gojo Palace, and guarded him strictly.

[8.10.7] The Emperor floated a boat on the pond and boarded it. The warriors shot arrows incessantly, but Shichijo Jijū Nobukiyo and Kii-no-Kami Norimitsu were attending the boat and said, "This is the Emperor crossing! Do not make a mistake!" The soldiers all got down from their horses and bowed. They had him make an imperial progress to the Kan'in Palace. The wretchedness of the ceremony of the imperial progress was beyond words.

div.head: 8.11. The Battle of Hōjūji

div.p:
[8.11.1] While Omi-no-Kami Minamoto no Kurōdo Nakakane, who was on the Cloistered Emperor's side, was guarding and defending the west gate of Hōjūji-dono with a force of about fifty horsemen, the Omi Genji Yamamoto-no-Kaja Yoshitaka galloped up and said, "Now, protecting whom are you doing battle? I hear the Retired Emperor and the Emperor have gone elsewhere."
Nakakane said "In that case," shouted, and charged into the midst of the large enemy force, fighting scatteringly and breaking through. He was reduced to eight horsemen, master and retainers. Among the eight was a monk-warrior of the Kusaka Party of Kawachi called Kagabo. He rode a white dappled horse that was extremely hard-mouthed. When he said, "This horse is pulling against the sun [unruly/badly positioned], and I do not think I can ride it," Kurōdo said, "Come then, swap with my horse," and swapped his chestnut horse with a white underside to the tail; charging into the force at Kawara-zaka where Nei no Koyata was waiting with about two hundred horsemen, five of the eight were killed there. They were reduced to just three horsemen, master and retainers. Kagabo swapped for his master's horse because his own was pulling, but he was finally killed there. Among Minamoto no Kurōdo's house-men was a person called Shinano Jiro Kurōdo Nakayori. Separated by the enemy, he did not know Kurōdo's whereabouts. Seeing the chestnut horse with the white underside to the tail running out, he called a servant and said, "The horse here looks like Minamoto no Kurōdo's horse. He must have been killed already. We pledged that if we died, we would die in one place; it is sad that we should be killed in different places. Into which force did you see him enter?" When he said, "He charged into the force at Kawara-zaka. Shortly after, the horse came out from that force," Nakayori said, "In that case, you go back quickly, quickly from here."
Sending word of his final moments to his hometown, he charged into the midst of the enemy alone, raised a great voice, and named himself: "The ninth-generation descendant of Imperial Prince Atsumi, the second son of Shinano-no-Kami Nakashige, Shinano Jiro Kurōdo Nakayori, age twenty-seven. Let those who think they are someone come meet me; I will see you!"
Breaking through vertically, horizontally, in spider-legs and cross shapes, galloping around and fighting, he took many enemies, and finally died in battle. Kurōdo did not know this even in a dream; taking one retainer of his elder brother Kawachi-no-Kami, three horsemen in all, master and retainers, they fled pointing south; meanwhile, the Regent Lord, fearing the battle in the capital, was going to Uji, and they caught up with him at Kowatayama. Thinking they were the remnants of Kiso, he stopped his carriage and asked, "Who are you?" They named themselves "Nakakane, Nakanobu." "What is this? I thought you were villains of the northern provinces; it is admirable that you have come. Stay close and guard me."
Being told this, they accepted with awe, escorted him to the Fuke-dono in Uji, and then these people fled to Kawachi Province. On the following twentieth day, Kiso Sama-no-kami rode out to the Rokujo Riverbed and hung up in a row the heads cut off yesterday; they numbered more than six hundred and thirty. Among them, the heads of Tendai Abbot Meiun Daisojo and the temple administrator Prince Enkei were also hung. There was no one who saw this who did not shed tears; Kiso, with his force of more than seven thousand horsemen, turned his horses' noses to the east, and raised a war cry three times, such that the heavens echoed and the earth shook. Inside the capital, there was uproar again. However, this was heard to be a cry of joy.

[8.11.2] Sangi Naganori, the son of the late Shonagon Nyudo Shinzei, went to the Gojo Palace where the Cloistered Emperor had moved and said, "I have something to report to the Lord. Open up and let me pass."
But the warriors did not permit it. Powerless, he stepped into a certain small hut, suddenly shaved his hair, became a monk, put on black-dyed robes and hakama, and said, "In this state, what objection should there be? Let me in."
At that time, they permitted him. Coming before the Cloistered Emperor, when he reported in detail about the principal people who had been killed this time, the Cloistered Emperor shed tears profusely and said, "I did not think in the slightest that Meiun was a person who should die an unnatural death. This time, he must have taken the place of my own life, which was in danger."
And he could not stop his tears.

[8.11.3] On the twenty-first of the same month, Kiso summoned his house-men and retainers and held a council. "Now Yoshinaka has faced the Lord of the whole heaven and won the battle. Shall I become the Emperor? Shall I become the Cloistered Emperor? Although I think to become the Emperor, it is not right to become a child [Emperor Antoku/Go-Toba were children]. Although I think to become the Cloistered Emperor, it would be regrettable to become a monk. Alright, alright, then I will become Kampaku."
When he said this, Taiyu-bo Kakumei, who served as his secretary, said, "As for Kampaku, the descendants of Taishokkan, the Fujiwara clan, become it. Since my Lord is a Genji, that cannot come to pass. " "In that case, there is nothing to be done," he said, and forcing himself into the post of Betto of the Retired Emperor's Stables, he governed Tamba Province. It was sad that he did not know that one is called Cloistered Emperor [Ho-o] if there is an Imperial Out-of-the-World [monastic vows], and that while the Emperor has not yet had his coming of age, he remains in child form.

[8.11.4] He took the daughter of the former Kampaku Matsu-dono and forced himself to become Matsu-dono's son-in-law. On the twenty-third day of the same eleventh month, beginning with Sanjo Chunagon Asakata-kyō, the official positions of forty-nine nobles and courtiers were halted and they were dismissed. In the time of the Heike, forty-three people were dismissed, but since this was forty-nine people, it exceeded the evil deeds of the Heike.

[8.11.5] Meanwhile, the Kamakura Former Hyoe-no-Suke Yoritomo sent his younger brothers, Gama-no-Kaja Noriyori and Kuro-no-Kaja Yoshitsune, saying they should quiet Kiso's violence; but hearing that he had already burned down the Hōjūji-dono, captured the Cloistered Emperor, and the realm had become darkness, they said, "There is no way to just go up and do battle. From here we will report the details to the Kanto."
While they were at the place of the Atsuta High Priest in Owari Province, Kunai-Hangan Tomochika and To-nai Zaemon Tokinari, who served in the North Face [imperial guard] and intended to complain of this matter, galloped down to Owari Province; when they complained of these circumstances one by one, the Kuro Noble Scion said, "This is for the Kunai-Hangan to go down to the Kanto. If a messenger who does not know the details is questioned in return, doubts will remain."
So Tomochika galloped down to Kamakura. Fearing the war, his servants had all fled and disappeared, so he took along his heir, Kunai-tokoro Tomoshige, who was fifteen. When he arrived in the Kanto and reported this, Hyoe-no-Suke was greatly surprised and said, "First, that the Drum Hangan Tomoyasu proposed an outrageous thing, caused the palace to be burned, and caused high priests and noble priests to be destroyed is strange. As for Tomoyasu, he is already a person who has violated imperial command. If you use him, a serious matter will arise again."
When he reported this to the capital by fast horse, the Drum Hangan, intending to explain himself, galloped down continuing day and night. Hyoe-no-Suke said, "Do not show that fellow my eyes; do not give him an audience."
But every day he went to Hyoe-no-Suke's mansion. Finally, losing face, he returned up to the capital. It was heard that later he lived in a place near Inari, barely keeping his life.

[8.11.6] Kiso Sama-no-kami sent a messenger to the Heike side saying, "Come up to the capital; becoming one, let us attack the eastern provinces."
Although the Minister Lord was pleased, Hei Dainagon and New Chunagon said, "Even if the world has come to an end like this, it is not right to be cajoled by Yoshinaka and return to the capital. Since the Emperor of the Ten Virtues possesses the Three Sacred Treasures, you should say: take off your helmet, unstring your bow, and come here as a prisoner."
Since they replied in this way, Kiso did not heed it. Summoning Kiso to the place of the Lay Priest Lord Matsu-dono, he said that although Lord Kiyomori was such an evildoer, because he performed rare good deeds, he kept the world peaceful for over twenty years. Since there is no one who keeps the world with only evil deeds, saying that the official posts of people who were halted without specific reason should all be restored, though he was entirely like a wild barbarian, he obeyed and restored the posts of the people who had been dismissed. Matsu-dono's son, Lord Moroie, who was then still Chunagon Chujo, was forcibly made Minister and Regent by Kiso's arrangement. Since the post of Minister was not open at the time, he borrowed the post of Tokudaiji Sadai-sho Sanesada-ko, who was Naidaijin at that time, and made him Naidaijin. Because people's mouths are busy, they called the new Regent Lord the "Borrowed Minister."

[8.11.7] On the tenth day of the same twelfth month, the Cloistered Emperor left the Gojo Palace and made an imperial progress to the residence of Daizen-no-Taiyu Naritada at Rokujo Nishinotoin. On the thirteenth of the same month, the year-end rites were held. Next, rank conferrals and appointments were held, and by Kiso's arrangement, people's posts were set as he thought. The Heike in the western provinces, Hyoe-no-Suke in the eastern provinces, and Kiso in the capital held sway. It was like when Wang Mang seized the world between the Former Han and Later Han and ruled for eighteen years. Since the barriers on all four sides were closed, public tribute was not presented, and the autumn tax grain did not come up, so the high and low people in the capital were just like fish in little water. While being in danger, the year ended, and it became the third year of Juei.

div.note: [] [1] Nihon Koten Bungaku Taikei (Tokyo: Iwanami Shoten, 1957, vol. 33; hereafter cited as NKBT) reads 仰ければ.

div.p:
[9.1.1] On the first day of the first month of the third year of Juei, the Retired Emperor's palace was the residence of Daizen-no-Taiyu Naritada at Rokujo Nishinotoin; saying that the appearance of the palace was not as it should be, and since it was not a place where ceremonies should be performed, there was no formal audience. Since there was no formal audience for the Retired Emperor, the Small Court Banquet at the Palace was also not held. The Heike saw in the New Year on the shore of Yashima in Sanuki Province; although it was the beginning of the year, the ceremonies of the first day and the third day were not proper; although the Emperor was present, the seasonal banquets were not held, and there was no Prayer to the Four Quarters. Neither was the river-deer fish presented. Nor did the vine-stems of Yoshino arrive. "Although the world is in turmoil, things were never like this in the capital," they all said to one another.
Although the green-yang spring had come, the wind blowing in the bay was soft, and the sunlight was becoming mild, the people of the Heike felt as if they were always confined in ice, differing not from the cold-suffering bird. The willows on the eastern and western banks mingled late and early growth; the blooming and falling of the plums on southern and northern branches were already different; remembering and talking continuously of the amusements they used to have—Chinese poetry and Japanese verse, music, kickball, small bow archery, fan-matching, picture-matching, root-matching, insect-matching—on flowery mornings and moonlit nights, they found it difficult to pass the long days; it was pitiable.

[9.1.2] On the eleventh day of the same first month, Kiso Sama-no-kami Yoshinaka visited the Retired Emperor and reported that he would set out for the western provinces to chastise the Heike. On the thirteenth day, just as it was heard he was departing, the Former Hyoe-no-Suke Yoritomo from the eastern provinces, saying he would quiet Kiso's violence, dispatched a military force of several tens of thousands of horsemen. Hearing that they had already arrived in Mino and Ise provinces, Kiso was greatly surprised, pulled up the planks of the bridges at Uji and Seta, and divided and dispatched his military forces. At that time he had no troops. Saying that the bridge at Seta was the main approach, he dispatched Imai Shiro Kanehira with more than eight hundred horsemen. To the Uji bridge, he sent Nishina, Takanashi, and Yamada Jiro with more than five hundred horsemen. To Imoarai, he sent his uncle Shida Saburo Senjo Yoshinori with more than three hundred horsemen. It was heard that the Great General of the main force attacking from the eastern provinces was the Gama Noble Scion Noriyori, the Great General of the rear guard was the Kuro Noble Scion Yoshitsune, and with more than thirty major daimyo of the main line, the total force was over sixty thousand horsemen. At that time, the Lord of Kamakura [Yoritomo] had famous horses called Ikeizuki [Pond-Living/Bit-Lively] and Surusumi [Rubbed Ink]. Kajiwara Genda Kagesue earnestly requested Ikeizuki, but the Lord of Kamakura said, "This is the horse that Yoritomo shall ride wearing armor should an emergency arise. Surusumi is also a famous horse not inferior to it."
And he gave Surusumi to Kajiwara.

[9.1.3] When Sasaki Shiro Takatsuna came to ask for leave, whatever the Lord of Kamakura thought, he said, "Although there are many who desire it, know this [keep it secret]," and he gave Ikeizuki to Sasaki.
Sasaki accepted with awe and said, "With this horse, Takatsuna shall surely be the first to cross the Uji River. If you hear that I have died at Uji River, please think that I was beaten to the vanguard by another. If you hear that I am still alive, please think that I have surely taken the vanguard."
And he left his presence. The gathered daimyo and shomyo all whispered to one another, "What a rough manner of speech."

[9.1.4] Leaving Kamakura, some went via Ashigara, some took the road over Hakone; as they went up in their various ways, Kajiwara Genda Kagesue rode up to a high place at Ukishimagahara in Suruga Province, waited a while, and looked at the many horses; saddle after saddle, crupper after crupper of various colors, some led by the bit, some led by double bits, passing through in numbers unknown, thousands and tens of thousands; thinking happily that surely there was no horse superior to Surusumi which he had been given, a horse that appeared to be Ikeizuki appeared.

[9.1.5] It bore a saddle with gold rims, a small-fused crupper, was chewing white foam, and although many grooms were attending it, it pranced and came out without allowing itself to be led. Kajiwara Genda rode up and asked, "Whose horse is that?"
"It is the horse of Sasaki-dono."
At that time Kajiwara muttered, "He is an unsettling man. It is regrettable that the Lord thought to prefer Sasaki over Kagesue, who serves him in the same way. Shall I go up to the capital and grapple and die with Imai, Higuchi, Tate, and Nei, who are heard to be the Four Deva Kings of Lord Kiso's house? Or shall I head to the western provinces and fight and die against the Heike samurai heard to be a match for a thousand? But with this favoritism, that too is pointless. Here I will grapple with Sasaki, stab him and be stabbed, and two good samurai will die and inflict a loss on Lord Hyoe-no-Suke."
And he waited. Sasaki Shiro came walking out innocently. Kajiwara lined up his horse, intending to grapple him down, thinking he would knock him down facing him, but first he addressed him. "How now, Sasaki-dono, have you been given Ikeizuki?"
When he said this, Sasaki thought, "Ah, I heard this man also desired it secretly," and quickly coming up with a plan, said: "Indeed, I am going up for this great matter, and surely the bridges at Uji and Seta will be pulled. I had no horse to ride to cross the river. I thought to ask for Ikeizuki, but hearing that even Kajiwara-dono's request was not granted, much less would it be given to Takatsuna; thinking that whatever censure I might receive later, so be it, on the night I was to depart at dawn, arranging it with the grooms, I stole Ikeizuki, which was so treasured, and am going up. How about that? " Kajiwara's anger was soothed by these words, and saying, "Envious! In that case, Kagesue should have stolen it too!", he laughed loudly and withdrew.

[9.2.1] The horse Sasaki Shiro had been given was a black chestnut horse, extremely thick and powerful, but because it bit at horses and people on its side, it was named Ikeizuki [Living-Biter/Bit-Lively]. It was heard to be a horse of eight sun [in height]. Surusumi, which Kajiwara was given, was also extremely thick and powerful, but because it was truly black, it was named Surusumi [Rubbed Ink]. Both were famous horses not inferior to each other.

[9.2.2] From Owari Province, they divided into two forces, main and rear guard, and attacked up [towards Kyoto]. The Great General of the main force was the Gama Noble Scion Noriyori; the people accompanying him were Takeda Taro, Kagami Jiro, Ichijo Jiro, Itagaki Saburo, Inage Saburo, Hangaya Shiro, Kumagai Jiro, and Inomata Koheiroku in the lead; the total force was more than thirty-five thousand horsemen, and they arrived at Noji and Shinohara in Omi Province. The Great General of the rear guard was the Kuro Noble Scion Yoshitsune; the people accompanying him were Yasuda Saburo, Ouchi Taro, Hatakeyama Shoji Jiro, Kajiwara Genda, Sasaki Shiro, Kasuya Tota, Shibuya Umanojo, and Hirayama Mushadokoro in the lead; the total force was more than twenty-five thousand horsemen; passing through Iga Province, they pushed to the approaches of the Uji Bridge. At both Uji and Seta the bridges were pulled; irregular stakes were driven into the water bottom, a great rope was stretched across, and abatis were tied and floated in the current. Since it was after the twentieth of the first month, the snow of old on the high peaks of Hira and the mountains of Shiga had melted, the ice in the valleys had thawed, and the water was high for the season. The white waves surged and fell violently, the rapids roared loudly, and the swirling water was fast. Although dawn was already breaking faintly, the river mist hung deep, and neither the hair of horses nor the lacing of armor was distinct.
Here, the Great General Kuro Noble Scion advanced to the edge of the river, looked across the surface of the water, and perhaps wishing to test the hearts of the men, said, "What shall we do? Should we go around to Yodo or Imoarai? Or should we wait for the water to drop?"
Hatakeyama, who was then twenty-one years old, advanced and said, "There was much talk of this river in Kamakura. It is not as if an unknown sea or river has suddenly appeared. Since this river is the outflow of the lake of Omi, even if we wait and wait, the water will not dry up. And who will build a bridge for us? In the battles of Jisho, did Ashikaga Matataro Tadatsuna cross as a demon or god? Shigetada shall test the rapids."
With the Tan Party as his core, just as more than five hundred horsemen were lining up their bits tightly, from the direction of the islet of Tachibana to the northeast of Byodoin, two warriors came galloping out, whipping and whipping their horses. One rider was Kajiwara Genda Kagesue, the other was Sasaki Shiro Takatsuna. To the eyes of others it did not look like anything special, but since they were secretly set on being first, Kajiwara was about one dan ahead of Sasaki. Sasaki Shiro called out, "This river is the greatest river in the western provinces! Your belly-band looks stretched. Tighten it!"
Being told this, Kajiwara thought it might be so; stepping through his stirrups, he threw the reins over the horse's neck, untied the belly-band and tightened it. In that interval, Sasaki galloped past him swiftly and plunged into the river with a splash. Kajiwara, perhaps thinking he had been tricked, immediately followed and plunged in. "How now, Sasaki-dono, do not fail by trying to achieve high fame! There is likely a great rope at the bottom of the water."
When he said this, Sasaki drew his sword, and cutting and cutting the great ropes that caught on his horse's feet, riding the horse called Ikeizuki, the best in the world, although the Uji River is fast, he crossed it straight as a line and rode up on the opposite bank. Surusumi, which Kajiwara rode, was pushed downstream in a slant from the middle of the river and rode up far below. Sasaki stood up in his stirrups, raised a great voice, and named himself: "The fourth son of Sasaki Saburo Hideyoshi, descendant of the ninth generation from Emperor Uda, Sasaki Shiro Takatsuna, is the Vanguard of the Uji River! Let those who think they are someone grapple with Takatsuna!"
And he attacked with a shout. Hatakeyama immediately crossed with more than five hundred horsemen. From the opposite bank, an arrow loosed by Yamada Jiro struck Hatakeyama's horse deep in the forehead; as it weakened, he dismounted into the middle of the river using his bow as a staff. The waves beat up to the tops of his helmet, but he did not mind. Diving along the bottom of the water, he arrived at the opposite bank. Just as he was about to climb up, someone grabbed him firmly from behind. "Who is it?"
he asked. "Shigechika," was the reply. "What, Ogushi?"
"Yes." Ogushi no Jiro was Hatakeyama's godson [eboshigo]. "The water was too fast and my horse was washed away. Powerless, I have attached myself to you."
When he said this, Hatakeyama said, "You fellows are always helped by men like Shigetada," and lifting Ogushi up, he threw him onto the bank. Being thrown up, he stood up straight and named himself: "A resident of Musashi Province, Ogushi Jiro Shigechika, is the Vanguard of the Uji River [Foot soldier vanguard]! " Both enemy and ally heard this and laughed all at once. After that, Hatakeyama mounted a spare horse and rode up. Wearing a hitatare of fish-pattern damask and armor with scarlet lacing, riding a dappled horse with coin patterns, saddled with a gold-rimmed saddle, he advanced to the very front of the enemy; someone said, "Who is the person attacking here? Name yourself!"
He replied, "A house-man of Lord Kiso, Nagase Hangandai Shigetsuna."
Hatakeyama, intending to celebrate the war god for the day, rode alongside, grabbed him firmly, pulled him down, twisted off his head, and had it attached to the saddle-tie of Honda Jiro. Beginning with this, the force from Lord Kiso's side guarding the Uji Bridge held out and defended for a while, but when the great force of the eastern provinces crossed and attacked, they were scattered and chased, fleeing toward Kowatayama and Fushimi. Seta was crossed by Inage Saburo Shigenari at the Tagami Sovereign's Ford.

[9.3.1] Since the battle was won, when a courier brought a record of the battle to the Lord of Kamakura, the Lord of Kamakura first asked the messenger, "What of Sasaki?"
He replied, "He was the very first at Uji River."
When he opened the journal and looked, it was written: "Vanguard of Uji River, Sasaki Shiro Takatsuna; Second, Kajiwara Genda Kagesue. "

[9.3.2] Hearing that Uji and Seta were broken, Kiso Sama-no-kami, intending to say a final farewell, galloped to the Retired Emperor's palace at Rokujo-dono. At the palace, beginning with the Cloistered Emperor, the nobles and courtiers said, "The world will be lost right now. What shall we do?" and clasped their hands; there was no prayer they did not make. Although Kiso went as far as the gate, hearing that the forces of the eastern provinces had already attacked as far as the riverbed, he had no way to clear the way and report, so he turned back. Since there was a lady he had begun to see for the first time at a place in Rokujo Takakura, he broke in there, and intending to regret the final parting, he did not leave immediately. There was a man called Echigo Chuta Iemitsu who had just joined him; he said, "Why do you stay so relaxed? The enemy has already attacked as far as the riverbed; you will die a dog's death."
But since he still did not leave, saying "In that case, I will go before you and wait for you at the Mountain of Death," he cut his belly and died. Lord Kiso said, "It is a suicide to urge me on," and immediately set out. With a resident of Kozuke Province, Nawa Taro Hirozumi, in the lead, his force did not exceed about one hundred horsemen. When they rode out to the Rokujo Riverbed and looked, about thirty horsemen, appearing to be forces of the eastern provinces, came out. Among them, two warriors advanced. One was Shioya Goro Korehiro, the other was Teshigawara Gosaburo Arinao. Shioya said, "Should we wait for the rear guard?" Teshigawara said, "If the first line is broken, the remaining party will not be whole; just attack!" and attacked with a shout. Since Kiso fought as if today were his limit, the forces of the eastern provinces advanced to take him.

[9.3.3] The Great General Kuro Yoshitsune had the soldiers do the fighting, and being concerned about the Retired Emperor's palace, intending to guard it, he first galloped to the Rokujo-dono with five or six horsemen in proper armor. At the palace, Daizen-no-Taiyu Naritada climbed onto the eastern mud wall of the palace, and when he looked around trembling and trembling, white banners were raised, warriors had fought with their helmets tilted back, their shooting sleeves blowing in the wind, kicking up black smoke, galloping up. Naritada said, "Kiso has come again; ah, how wretched!"
Saying "This time the world is lost," both Lord and subjects were in an uproar. Naritada spoke again, "The warriors galloping up now have different hat-tokens; they appear to be the forces of the eastern provinces entering the capital for the first time today."
Before he finished speaking, Kuro Yoshitsune galloped to the gate, got down from his horse, knocked on the gate, and raised a great voice: "It is the younger brother of Former Hyoe-no-Suke Yoritomo from the eastern provinces, Kuro Yoshitsune, who has arrived. Please open up."
When he said this, Naritada, in excessive happiness, jumped down hurriedly from the mud wall and injured his hip, but confused by joy he did not feel the pain; crawling and crawling he went and reported this, and the Cloistered Emperor was greatly impressed and immediately had the gate opened and let him in. For Kuro Yoshitsune's attire on that day, he wore a hitatare of red brocade, armor with purple shading, tightened the cords of a helmet with hoe-shaped crests, carried a sword with gold fittings, bore arrows with spotted feathers, and held a rattan-wrapped bow, the grip of which was wrapped in paper cut about one sun wide in a left-hand winding. He appeared to be the token of the Great General of the day. The Cloistered Emperor looked from the lattice window of the middle gate and said, "They are imposing men; have them all name themselves."
When he ordered this, first the Great General Kuro Yoshitsune, next Yasuda Saburo Yoshisada, Hatakeyama Shoji Jiro Shigetada, Kajiwara Genda Kagesue, Sasaki Shiro Takatsuna, and Shibuya Umanojo Shigesuke named themselves. Although the armor of the six warriors accompanying Yoshitsune was of various colors, their countenances and character were all not inferior. Daizen-no-Taiyu Naritada received the order and summoned Kuro Yoshitsune to the edge of the great floor; when he asked in detail about the battle, Yoshitsune accepted with awe and said, "Concerning Yoshinaka's rebellion, Yoritomo was greatly surprised, and dispatched Noriyori and Yoshitsune, beginning a force of more than thirty main warriors and sixty thousand horsemen. Noriyori is coming from Seta and has not yet arrived. Yoshitsune attacked and took the Uji approach, and first galloped here to guard this palace. Yoshinaka was fleeing up the riverbed, so I had soldiers chase him, and by now they have surely taken him."
He spoke as if it were nothing. The Cloistered Emperor was greatly impressed and said, "It is admirable. The remnants of Kiso might come and commit violence. You guard this palace well."
When he ordered this, Yoshitsune accepted with awe, and while he secured the four gates and waited, soldiers galloped and gathered, and before long they became about ten thousand horsemen.

[9.3.4] Kiso, thinking that if something happened he would take the Cloistered Emperor, flee to the western provinces, and unite with the Heike, had prepared twenty strong men and waited, but hearing that Kuro Yoshitsune had galloped to the palace and was guarding it, he said "In that case" and charged into the midst of the great force of tens of thousands of horsemen with a shout. Although he was about to be killed many times, he broke through and broke through and passed. Kiso shed tears and said, "If only I had known it would be like this, I would not have sent Imai to Seta. Since our childhood days on bamboo horses, we pledged that if we die we would die in one place; it is sad that we should be killed in different places. I want to hear what has become of Imai."
As he headed up the riverbed, enemies attacked between Rokujo Riverbed and Sanjo Riverbed; turning back and turning back, with a meager small force, he drove back the great force of the enemy like clouds and mist five or six times. He crossed the Kamo River quickly and headed for Awataguchi Matsuzaka. Last year when he left Shinano, it was heard he had more than fifty thousand horsemen; today when passing Shinomiya Riverbed, he was reduced to seven horsemen, master and retainers. Much more is the sky of the journey in the intermediate state [after death] imagined to be sad.

div.head: 9.4. The End of Kiso

div.p: [9.4.1] Lord Kiso had brought two female attendants from Shinano, Tomoe and Yamabuki. Yamabuki was ill and stayed in the capital. Among them, Tomoe was white of complexion and long of hair, and her features were truly superior. She was a rare strong archer, a fine soldier, a warrior worth a thousand, ready to face demon or god, whether mounted or on foot. She was a rider of unbroken horses and could ride down dangerous slopes; when there was a battle, she was made to wear heavy armor, given a large sword and a strong bow, and sent to face the first General of one side. There was no one who could equal her repeated fame. Thus, this time too, while many men fled or were killed, Tomoe was not killed even among the last seven.

[9.4.2] It was heard that Kiso was heading toward the Tamba road via Nagasaka. Also it was heard that he was heading to the northern provinces via the Ryuge Pass. Although it was so, saying "I want to hear the whereabouts of Imai," he fled toward Seta; Imai Shiro Kanehira also, who had been guarding Seta with more than eight hundred horsemen, was reduced to about fifty, and furling his banner, anxious about his master, was returning to the capital when he met Lord Kiso at Uchide-no-hama in Otsu. Recognizing each other from about one cho away, master and retainer galloped their horses and came together. Lord Kiso took Imai's hand and said, "Yoshinaka should have died at Rokujo Riverbed, but longing for your fate, I broke through many enemies and have escaped this far."
Imai Shiro said, "Your words are truly gracious.[][1] Kanehira also should have died in battle at Seta, but anxious about your fate, I have come this far. " Lord Kiso said, "Our bond has not yet rotted. Yoshinaka's forces were separated by the enemy and scattered in the woods; they must be in this area. Raise the banner I had you furl and hold."
So he raised Imai's banner. Whether forces fleeing from the capital or men fleeing from Seta, spotting Imai's banner, more than three hundred horsemen galloped and gathered. Lord Kiso was greatly pleased and said, "With this force, why should we not fight a last battle? Whose troop is that seen massing over there?"
"I hear it is Ichijo Jiro-dono of Kai."
"How large is the force?" "I hear it is more than six thousand horsemen."
"Then they are a good enemy. Since we are to die anyway, let us engage a good enemy and die in battle in the midst of a great force."
And he advanced to the very front.

[9.4.3] For Kiso Sama-no-kami's attire on that day, he wore a hitatare of red brocade, armor with Chinese damask lacing, tightened the cords of a helmet with hoe-shaped crests, carried a large sword of impressive make, carried the few remaining stone-striking arrows that he had shot in that day's battle high on his back, held a rattan-wrapped bow, and rode the famous horse called Kiso's Demon Roan, extremely thick and powerful, with a gold-rimmed saddle. Standing up in his stirrups, he raised a great voice and named himself: "You have heard of him in days past, Kiso-no-Kaja. Now you see him, Sama-no-Kami and Iyo-no-Kami, the Asahi Shogun Minamoto no Yoshinaka! I hear you are Ichijo no Jiro of Kai. We are mutually good enemies. Kill Yoshinaka and show him to Hyoe-no-Suke!"
Shouting this, he attacked. Ichijo Jiro said, "The one who named himself just now is the Great General. Do not let him escape, do not let him leak through, young men, kill him!"
Trapping him in the midst of the great force, they advanced to take him. Kiso's more than three hundred horsemen broke through the six thousand horsemen vertically, horizontally, in spider-legs and cross shapes, and when they came out the back, they were reduced to about fifty horsemen. As they broke through there and went on, Doi Jiro Sanehira blocked them with more than two thousand horsemen. Breaking through there and going on, engaging four or five hundred horsemen there, two or three hundred here, a hundred and forty or fifty, a hundred, breaking through and going on, they were reduced to five horsemen, master and retainers. Even among the five, Tomoe had not been killed. Lord Kiso said, "You are a woman, so flee quickly, quickly to wherever. Yoshinaka intends to die in battle. If I am wounded, I will commit suicide; it would not be right for it to be said that Lord Kiso took a woman along for his last battle."
Though he said this, she still did not flee, but being told too much, she said, "Ah, for a good enemy. I will show you a last battle."
Waiting there, Onda Hachiro Moroshige, known in Musashi Province for great strength, appeared with about thirty horsemen. Tomoe charged into them, rode alongside Onda Hachiro, grabbed him firmly, pulled him down, pressed him against the front pommel of her saddle, kept him from moving a bit, twisted off his head and discarded it. After that, she took off her armor and abandoned it, and fled toward the eastern provinces. Tezuka Taro died in battle. Tezuka no Betto fled.

[9.4.4] Imai Shiro and Lord Kiso, reduced to two horsemen, master and retainer, the Lord said, "My armor, which I usually do not feel at all, has become heavy today."
Imai Shiro said, "Your body is not yet tired, and your horse has not weakened. For what reason should you feel one suit of armor to be heavy? That is because you have no forces on your side, so you feel cowardly. Even if Kanehira is alone, think of me as a thousand warriors. I have seven or eight arrows, so I will shoot defense arrows for a while. What is seen over there is called the Pine Grove of Awazu. Please commit suicide inside those pines."
As they went on, a fresh troop of about fifty warriors appeared. "My Lord, please enter that pine grove. Kanehira will hold off this enemy."
Lord Kiso said, "Yoshinaka should have died in the capital, but I fled this far to die in one place with you. Rather than be killed in different places, let us die together in one place."
Saying this, he lined up his horse's nose and was about to attack, but Imai Shiro jumped down from his horse, took the bit of his master's horse, and said, "However great the fame a warrior has had for years and days, if he fails at the last moment, it is a lasting flaw. Your body is tired. There are no forces following. If you are separated by the enemy, grappled down by the worthless retainer of some nobody, and killed, it would be regrettable for it to be said that Lord Kiso, known throughout Japan, was killed by such-and-such's retainer. Just please enter that pine grove."
Lord Kiso said, "In that case," and galloped toward the Pine Grove of Awazu.

[9.4.5] Imai Shiro, all alone, charged into the midst of about fifty horsemen, stood up in his stirrups, raised a great voice, and named himself: "You have heard of him by sound in days past, now see him with your eyes! Lord Kiso's foster brother Imai no Shiro Kanehira, aged thirty-three. Even the Lord of Kamakura surely knows that such a person exists. Kill Kanehira and present him [to Yoritomo]!"
He notched and shot the remaining eight arrows rapidly and scatteringly. Not caring for life or death, he instantly shot down eight enemies. After that, he drew his sword and galloped here and there, cutting around; there was no one to face him. He captured many weapons. Saying "Just shoot him!", they surrounded him and shot like rain, but since his armor was good, it did not pierce, and since they did not shoot at the gaps, he was not wounded.

[9.4.6] Lord Kiso was galloping alone toward the Pine Grove of Awazu, but since it was about sunset on the twenty-first of the first month, thin ice had formed. Not knowing there was a deep paddy, he rode his horse straight in, and not even the horse's head could be seen. Though he spurred and whipped, it did not move. Anxious about Imai's fate, as he turned his helmet to look back, Ishida Jiro Tamehisa of Miura chased him, drew his bow fully, and shot him with a twang. Since it was a painful wound, as he slumped forward with his helmet crest touching the horse's neck, two of Ishida's retainers fell upon him and finally took Lord Kiso's head. Piercing it on the tip of a sword and holding it high, he raised a great voice: "Kiso-dono, who has been heard of throughout Japan these days, has been killed by Miura no Ishida Jiro Tamehisa!"
Hearing this while fighting, Imai Shiro said, "Now, protecting whom should I do battle? See this, lords of the east, the example of the suicide of the toughest warrior in Japan!"
placing the tip of his sword in his mouth, he leaped headfirst from his horse, was pierced, and died. Thus the Battle of Awazu ended.

div.note: [] [1] Nihon Koten Bungaku Taikei (Tokyo: Iwanami Shoten, 1957, vol. 33; hereafter cited as NKBT) has 。 at this point.

div.p:
[9.5.1] Imai's elder brother, Higuchi Jirō Kanemitsu, intending to kill Jurō Kurando, had crossed over to Nagano Castle in Kawachi Province, but he failed to kill him there. Hearing that he was in Nagusa in Kii Province, he immediately continued across after him, but hearing that there was battle in the Capital, he rushed back up. At the great bridge of the Yodo crossing, he met a servant of Imai. "Ah, how wretched; to where are you crossing over? Our lord has been slain. Lord Imai has committed suicide."
When he said this, Higuchi Jirō let tears fall freely and said, "Listen to this, men; those people who intend to show their loyalty to the lord, flee from here to wherever you can, enter the priesthood and become monks, set up the practice of pilgrim beggary, and pray for his afterlife. Kanemitsu will go up to the Capital and die fighting; I intend to enter into the lord's presence in the netherworld and see Imai Shirō once more."
When he said this, the force of over five hundred horsemen held back there and held back here, and as they fled away, upon emerging from the southern gate of Toba, that force had become merely some twenty horsemen. As it was rumored that Higuchi Jirō was entering the Capital this very day, the warrior bands and noble houses rushed toward Shichijō, Suzaku, and Yotsuzuka. Under Higuchi's command, there was a man called Chino Tarō. He galloped into the midst of the enemy who had rushed in great numbers to Yotsuzuka, and raising a great voice, shouted, "Is there anyone among you from the command of Lord Ichijō Jirō of Kai?"
When he asked this, they roared with laughter, saying, "Is war waged only by the hand of the strong Lord Ichijō Jirō? Encounter anyone!"
Being laughed at, he named himself: "The person who speaks thus is a resident of the Upper Shrine of Suwa in Shinano Province, the son of Chino Dayū Mitsuie, Chino Tarō Mitsuhiro; I am not strictly seeking the hand of Lord Ichijō Jirō, but his younger brother Chino Shichirō is there. Mitsuhiro has two children waiting in Shinano Province; alas, they will wonder if their father died well. It is because I intend—in the place where they would lament, wondering if I died badly—to die fighting in front of my brother Shichirō, and let my children hear of it with certainty. I will not choose my enemy."
Saying this, he galloped and clashed there, galloped and clashed here; having grappled and dropped three enemy horsemen, he pressed alongside the fourth enemy he encountered, grappled and fell with a thud, pierced him through, and died.

[9.5.2] As Higuchi Jirō had become entangled with the Kodama party, the men of Kodama gathered together and said, "The reason that we and others who are accustomed to taking up the bow and arrow try to enter into the broad center is that, for the sake of a single moment's breath when a natural event occurs, we think to extend our lives for a short while. Thus, although Higuchi Jirō has become entangled with us, he surely must think the same. For our merit this time, let us claim Higuchi's life."
Saying this, they sent a messenger: "In days past, within Lord Kiso's circle, you were known as Imai and Higuchi, but now Lord Kiso has been slain. Why should you suffer? Become a surrenderer in our midst. In exchange for the reward of merit, we shall save just your life. Enter the priesthood, become a monk, and pray for the afterlife."
When they said this, although Higuchi Jirō was a renowned warrior, perhaps his luck had run out; he became a surrenderer in the midst of the Kodama party. They reported this to the Noble Scion Kurō. It was reported to the Palace and he was to be pardoned, but the nobles and courtiers at the side, and the ladies of the apartments said, "When Kiso attacked the Hōjūji Palace, raised the war cry and tormented the Sovereign, and set fire, destroying and losing many people, the only voices there and here were those saying 'Imai' and 'Higuchi.' To pardon them would be regrettable."
Because this was said by each and every one of them, he was again condemned to death.

[9.5.3] On the twenty-second day of the same month, the new Regent was stopped, and the original Regent returned to office. Since he was changed within a mere sixty days, it is like a dream not yet fully seen. In the past, the Awata Kampaku lived for only seven days after stating his joy. Although this was sixty days, since festivals and appointments were held during that interval, it is not without memories.

[9.5.4] On the twenty-fourth day of the same month, the heads of Kiso Sama-no-kami and five members of the remnants of his party were paraded through the main streets. Higuchi Jirō was a surrenderer, but because he earnestly requested to accompany the head, he was paraded wearing an indigo-dyed hunting robe and a tall hat. On the twenty-fifth day of the same month, Higuchi Jirō was finally beheaded. Noriyori and Yoshitsune spoke in various ways [for him], but it was said, "Called Imai, Higuchi, Tate, and Nenoi, they are the Four Heavenly Kings of Kiso. To pardon them would be the sorrow of rearing a tiger."
Thus, a specific order was given and he was beheaded. We hear in tradition that when the land of the tiger and wolf declined and the feudal lords rose like bees, although the Duke of Pei entered the Xianyang Palace first, fearing that Xiang Yu would come later, he did not violate the women or wives, nor did he plunder the gold, silver, and jewels; guarding the Hangu Pass in vain, he gradually destroyed his enemies and was able to govern the realm. Thus, even though Kiso Sama-no-kami entered the Capital first, had he obeyed the commands of Ason Yoritomo, he would not have been inferior to the stratagems of that Duke of Pei.

[9.5.5] Since around the winter of last year, the Heike left the Yashima coast of Sanuki Province, pushed across to the Naniwa lagoon in Settsu Province, and residing in the old capital of Fukuhara, they constructed a fortress at Ichinotani in the west, and designated the Ikuta Forest in the east as the main gate. Within that, the forces garrisoned at Fukuhara, Hyōgo, Itayado, and Suma were warriors summoned from the eight provinces of the Sanyōdō and the six provinces of the Nankaidō, comprising fourteen provinces in total, whom they had subdued. It was rumored to be over one hundred thousand horsemen. At Ichinotani, the north is mountain, the south is sea, the entrance is narrow and the interior is wide. The cliffs are high, differing nothing from a standing folding screen. From the edge of the northern mountains to the distant shallows of the southern sea, they piled up great stones, cut great trees to lay abatis, and in the deep places they lined up large ships to serve as shield-walls; in the high towers on the face of the castle, warriors of Shikoku and Chinzei, rumored to be match for a thousand men each, wore armor and helmets and carried bows and arrows, sitting in rows like clouds and mist. Beneath the towers, saddled horses stood in lines, ten and twenty deep. They constantly beat great drums to create a chaotic din. The force of the drawn bows hung before their chests like the half-moon, and the light of the three-foot swords held at their waists lay across like autumn frost. As many red banners were set up in the high places, their fluttering in the heavens as they were blown by the spring breeze differed nothing from flames of fire burning upward.

[9.6.1] After the Heike crossed over to Fukuhara, the warriors of Shikoku did not submit to them. Among them, the local officials of Awa and Sanuki disobeyed the Heike and intended to attach themselves to the Genji, but they said, "Though we were those who followed the Heike until yesterday or today, even if we go to the side of the Genji starting today, surely we will not be employed. Come, let us shoot a single arrow at the Heike and make that our face [proof of loyalty] when we go." Hearing that the Kadowaki Chūnagon, his son the Echizen Sanmi, and Noto-no-kami, the father and sons three, were at Shimotsui in Bizen Province, thinking to attack them, they approached with over ten ships of war. Noto-no-kami heard this: "What evil fellows. Those fellows who cut grass for our horses until yesterday or today have indeed changed their vows. If that is the case, kill them without letting a single one escape!" Saying this, they boarded small boats, and saying "Don't spare them, don't let them escape," as they attacked, the warriors of Shikoku, thinking only to shoot a single arrow for appearance's sake and then retreat, were attacked severely; thinking it was hopeless, they retreated to a distance and fled up toward the Capital, but they arrived at the harbor of Fukura in Awaji Province. In that province there were two Genji; the youngest sons of the late Rokujō Hogan Tameyoshi, known as Kamo no Kaja Yoshitsugu and Awaji no Kaja Yoshihisa; the warriors of the western provinces relied on them as generals and constructed a fortress to wait, but when Lord Noto immediately pressed and attacked, they fought for one day and Kamo no Kaja died fighting. Awaji no Kaja suffered a severe wound and committed suicide. Lord Noto cut off the heads of over one hundred and thirty warriors who shot defensive arrows, recorded a list of the executed, and sent it to Fukuhara.

[9.6.2] Kadowaki Chūnagon went up to Fukuhara from there. As for his sons, because Kōno Shirō of Iyo did not come when summoned, thinking to chastise him, they crossed over to Shikoku. First the elder brother, Echizen Sanmi Michimori Kyō, arrived at Hanazono Castle in Awa Province. When it was heard that the younger brother, Noto-no-kami, was crossing to Yashima in Sanuki, Kōno Shirō Michinobu, since the resident of Aki Province Numata Jirō was his maternal uncle[][2], thinking to unite with him, pushed across to Aki Province. Noto-no-kami heard this, and immediately leaving Yashima in Sanuki, he pursued them; already hanging upon Minoshima in Bingo Province, on the next day he approached Numata Castle. Numata Jirō, uniting with Kōno Shirō, fought in defense. When Lord Noto immediately pressed and attacked, they fought in defense for one day and one night; Numata Jirō, perhaps thinking it hopeless, took off his helmet and came as a surrenderer. Kōno Shirō still did not submit; his force was over five hundred horsemen, but having been reduced to merely some fifty horsemen by fighting, as he went out of the castle, he was hemmed in amidst some two hundred horsemen of Lord Noto's samurai, Taira no Hei-Hyoue Tamekazu, and reduced to seven horsemen, master and servants; intending to board a rescue boat, as they fled toward the beach along a narrow path, Taira no Hei-Hyoue's son, Sanuki Shichirō Yoshinori, being a peerless master of the bow, chased them and shot down five of the seven in quick succession. Kōno Shirō had become just two horsemen, master and servant. Sanuki Shichirō pressed alongside the retainer whom Kōno thought of in exchange for his own life, grappled him and fell, and was taking him and pressing him down and about to cut his head, when Kōno Shirō turned back, cut off the head of Sanuki Shichirō who was on top of the retainer, threw it into a deep paddy field, and raising a great voice, shouted, "Kōno Shirō Ochi no Michinobu, age twenty-one, this is how I do battle. Those people who think themselves worthy, stay!"
Saying this, he slung his retainer over his shoulder, fled swiftly from there, boarded a small boat, and crossed over to Iyo Province. Although Lord Noto had let Kōno escape, he took Numata Jirō, who was a surrenderer, along with him and went to Fukuhara.

[9.6.3] Also, the resident of Awaji Province, Amako Rokurō Tadakage, disobeying the Heike, communicated his intent to the Genji; loading rice provisions and weapons into two large ships, as he was going up toward the Capital, Lord Noto heard this at Fukuhara and pushed off and floated some ten small boats to pursue him. Amako Rokurō turned back to engage off the coast of Nishinomiya and fought in defense. Being severely attacked, perhaps thinking it hopeless, he retreated and arrived at Fukei Bay in Izumi Province. The resident of Kii Province, Sonobe Hyōe Tadayasu, also disobeying the Heike and intending to join the Genji, heard that Amako Rokurō was at Fukei having been attacked by Lord Noto, so he rushed there with a force of some one hundred horsemen and united with him. When Lord Noto immediately continued to attack, they fought in defense for one day and one night; Amako Rokurō and Sonobe Hyōe, perhaps thinking it hopeless, made their house-men and retainers shoot defensive arrows, and fleeing with their own bodies, went up to the Capital. Lord Noto cut off the heads of the warriors who shot defensive arrows, over two hundred men, and went to Fukuhara. Also, the resident of Iyo Province Kōno Shirō Michinobu, the resident of Bungo Province Usuki Jirō Koretaka, and Ogata Saburō Koreyoshi, acting in agreement, with a total force of over two thousand men, pushed across to Bizen Province and holed up in Imaki Castle. Noto-no-kami heard this, and rushing down from Fukuhara with over three thousand horsemen, attacked Imaki Castle. When Lord Noto said, "Those fellows are formidable enemies. I would receive more troops," and it was rumored that a great force of tens of thousands of horsemen was being directed from Fukuhara, the warriors inside the castle fought to the limit of their ability, and having achieved taking heads and making names, said, "The Heike are a great force. We are a small force. It is hopeless no matter what. Let us flee from here and extend our breath for a while."
Thus, Usuki Jirō and Ogata Saburō boarded boats and pushed across to Chinzei. Kōno crossed to Iyo. Lord Noto said, "Now there are no enemies to destroy," and went to Fukuhara. The nobles and courtiers of the Heike clan, beginning with the Lord Minister, gathered together and all together expressed their admiration for Lord Noto's repeated high renown.

div.head: 9.7. The Muster at Mikusa

div.p:
[9.7.1] On the twenty-ninth day of the First Month, Noriyori and Yoshitsune visited the Cloistered Emperor; when they reported that they would depart for the western provinces for the pursuit and chastisement of the Heike, the order was given: "In this realm, there are Three Sacred Treasures handed down from the Age of Gods. The Sacred Mirror, the Sacred Jewel, and the Treasure Sword are they. Make your plans so that you return them to the Capital without incident."
The two men listened with awe and withdrew.

[9.7.2] On the fourth day of the Second Month of the same year, at Fukuhara, saying it was the anniversary of the death of the late Lay Monk Prime Minister, a Buddhist service was performed as per form. Although they did not know the days and months passing in the morning and evening military preparations, last year had come around to this year, and it had become a spring of sorrow. If the world were the world [as it should be], there would have been undertakings of erecting stupas and services of offerings to Buddhas and monks, but the noble sons and daughters only gathered together, and there was nothing but weeping.

[9.7.3] On this occasion, rank conferment and appointments were conducted, and both monks and laymen were made officials. When it was said by the Lord Minister that Kadowaki Chūnagon should become a Shō-nii Dainagon, Lord Norimori,

lg.l: Is this myself, existing until today? I see a dream within a dream.

div.p: [9.7.4] Thus he replied, and in the end he did not become Dainagon; the son of the Senior Secretary Nakahara no Morinao, Suō-no-Suke Morizumi, became Senior Secretary. Hyōbu-no-Shōyū Masaaki was made a Go-i Kurōdo, and was called Kurōdo Shōyū. In the past, when Masakado subdued the eight provinces of the East, set up a capital in the Sōma District of Shimōsa, called himself the Taira Prince, and appointed the hundred officials, there was no Calendar Scholar. This cannot be likened to that. Although it is said they fled the old capital, the Sovereign possesses the Three Kinds of Divine Treasures and is equipped with the rank of the Ten Thousand Chariots. Even if rank conferment and appointments are conducted, it is not a wrong thing.

[9.7.5] Since it was rumored that the Taira clan had already attacked up to Fukuhara and would return into the Capital, the joy of the people remaining in the old hometown was not ordinary. Because the Nii no Sōzu Senshin was a fellow lodger of the Kajii Prince for many years, he communicated with him by the convenience of the wind. From the Prince also, there were constant tidings. He wrote, "Thinking of the state of the sky on your journey is truly pitiable. The Capital also is not quiet," and at the end there was one verse of a poem.

lg.l: The heart that longs for that direction unbeknownst to others, I send along with the setting moon.

div.p: [9.7.6] The Sōzu pressed this to his face, unable to hold back tears of sorrow.

[9.7.7] Meanwhile, Komatsu Sanmi Chūjō Koremori Kyō, as the years separated and the days piled up, lamented and grieved only about the wife and young people he had left behind in the old hometown. Even in the letters that naturally passed back and forth by the convenience of merchants, hearing painfully of his wife's condition in the Capital, although he thought, "In that case, I will send for her and we will be in one place somehow," thinking, "Whatever may happen to me, for her sake it would be painful," he endured, spending his days and nights; in this, the depth of his utmost intent was revealed.

[9.7.8] Meanwhile, the Genji should have approached on the fourth day, but hearing it was the anniversary of the late Lay Monk Prime Minister, in order to let them perform the Buddhist service, they did not approach. The fifth day was West Obstructed, the sixth day was the Way of Void day; it was decided that on the seventh day at the Hour of the Rabbit [6 a.m.], the Genji and Heike arrows would meet at the eastern and western wooden gate entrances of Ichinotani. Nevertheless, saying that the fourth day was an auspicious day, the great generals of the main force and the rear force divided the troops into two hands and departed the Capital. For the main force, the great general was Gama no Onzōshi Noriyori; the people accompanying him were Takeda Tarō Nobuyoshi, Kagami Jirō Tōmitsu, same [Kagami] Kojirō Nagakiyo, Yamana Jirō Akiyoshi, same [Yamana] Saburō Yoshiyuki; the samurai generals were Kajiwara Heizō Kagetoki, his heir Genta Kagesue, second son Heiji Kage-taka, same [Kajiwara] Saburō Kageie, Inage Saburō Shigenari, Hangaya Shirō Shigetomo, same [Hangaya] Gorō Yukishige, Oyama Koshirō Tomomasa, same [Oyama] Nakanuma Gorō Munemasa, Yūki Shichirō Tomomitsu, Sanuki Shirō Dayū Hirotsuna, Onodera Zenji Tarō Michitsuna, Soga Tarō Sukenobu, Nakamura Tarō Tokitsune, Edo Shirō Shigeharu, Tamai Shirō Sukekage, Ōkōzu Tarō Hiroyuki, Shō Saburō Tadaie, same [Shō] Shirō Takaie, Katsu Daihachirō Yukihira, Kugai Jirō Shigemitsu, Kawahara Tarō Takanao, same [Kawahara] Jirō Morinao, and Fujita Saburō Dayū Yukiyasu as the van; with a total force of over fifty thousand horsemen, they departed the Capital at the first point of the Hour of the Dragon [8 a.m.] on the fourth day of the Second Month, and at the Hour of the Monkey-Rooster [4-6 p.m.] on that day, they took up encampment at Koyano in Settsu Province. The great general of the rear force was the Noble Scion Kurō Yoshitsune; the people accompanying him likewise were Yasuda Saburō Yoshisada, Ōuchi Tarō Koreyoshi, Murakami Hōgandai Yasukuni, Tashiro Kaja Nobutsuna; the samurai generals were Doi Jirō Sanehira, his son Yatarō Tōhira, Miura no Suke Yoshizumi, his son Heiroku Yoshimura, Hatakeyama Shōji Jirō Shigetada, same [Hatakeyama] Nagano Saburō Shigekiyo, Sahara Jūrō Yoshitsura, [][3]Wada Kotarō Yoshimori, same [Wada] Jirō Yoshishige, same [Wada] Saburō Munezane, Sasaki Shirō Takatsuna, same [Sasaki] Gorō Yoshikiyo, Kumagai Jirō Naozane, his son Kojirō Naoie, Hirayama Mushadokoro Sueshige, Amano Jirō Naotsune, Ogawa Jirō Sukeyoshi, Hara Saburō Kiyomasu, Kaneko Jūrō Ietada, same [Kaneko] Yoichi Chikanori, Watayanagi Yagorō Kiyotada, Beppu Kotarō Kiyoshige, Tatara Gorō Yoshiharu, his son Tarō Mitsuyoshi, Kataoka Tarō Tsuneharu, Genpachi Hirotsuna, Ise Saburō Yoshimori, Ōshū Satō Saburō Tsuginobu, same [Satō] Shirō Tadanobu, Eda Genzō, Kumai Tarō, and Musashibō Benkei as the van; with a total force of over ten thousand horsemen, departing the Capital at the same time on the same day, hanging onto the Tanba road, and striking across two days' road in one day, they arrived at Ono-hara, the eastern mountain entrance of the Mikusa mountain which is the border between Harima and Tanba.

div.note: [] [3] NKBT reads "Wada Kotarō Yoshimori. Same [Wada] Jirō Yoshishige. Same [Wada] Saburō Munezane,".

div.p: [9.8.1] On the Heike side, the great generals were Komatsu Shin-Sanmi Chūjō Sukemori, same [Komatsu] Shōshō Arimori, Tango Jijū Tadafusa, and Bitchū-no-Kami Morimori; the samurai generals were Hirauchi Hyōe Seike and Ebi Jirō Morikata as the leaders; with a total force of over three thousand horsemen, three ri distant from Ono-hara, they took up encampment at the western mountain entrance of Mount Mikusa. That night, around the Hour of the Dog [8 p.m.], the Noble Scion Kurō summoned Doi Jirō and said, "The Heike are three ri distant from here; since they are holding the western mountain entrance of Mount Mikusa with a large force, should we approach for a night attack tonight, or a battle tomorrow?" Tashiro Kaja came forward and said, "If we delay until a battle tomorrow, the Heike force will gain confidence. The Heike are over three thousand horsemen; our force is over ten thousand horsemen; we have a distant advantage. I believe we should choose a night attack." When he said this, Doi Jirō said, "How well Lord Tashiro speaks. In that case, let us attack immediately." Thus they set out. When the soldiers voiced various concerns, saying, "It is dark, indeed dark; what shall we do?", the Noble Scion Kurō said, "What of the usual great torches?" Doi Jirō said, "There is such a thing," and set fire to the lay houses of Ono-hara. Beginning with this, having set fire to the fields, mountains, grass, and trees, it was not in the least inferior to daytime, and they crossed over the mountain of three ri.

[9.8.2] As for this person called Tashiro Kaja, his father was a descendant of the former Governor of Izu Province, Chūnagon Tametsuna. His mother was the daughter of Kanō-no-Suke Shigemitsu, whom [the father] had courted and with whom he had conceived him; he was entrusted to his maternal grandfather and raised to take up the bow and arrow. If one inquires into his lay lineage, he is the fifth-generation grandson of the third prince of the Retired Emperor Go-Sanjō, Prince Sukehito. His lay lineage was fine, and having taken up the bow and arrow, he was also fine.

[9.8.3] On the Heike side, not knowing that there would be a night attack that night, they said, "The battle will surely be a battle tomorrow. In battle, sleepiness is a serious matter. Sleep well and then do battle." Thus, although there were some in the vanguard who took precautions themselves, the men of the rearguard, some making pillows of helmets, others making pillows of the sleeves of armor or quivers, lay down without knowing before or after. Around midnight, ten thousand Genji horsemen pushed near and raised the war cry with a roar. On the Heike side, they panicked in excess; those taking bows knew not their arrows, those taking arrows knew not their bows, and trying not to be struck by horses, they opened the center and let them pass. The Genji chased the fleeing enemy there, and pressed and attacked them here, so that over five hundred Heike soldiers were slain in short order. There were many wounded. The great generals Komatsu Shin-Sanmi Chūjō, the Shōshō, and Tango Jijū, perhaps feeling ashamed, boarded a boat from Takasago in Harima Province and crossed over to Yashima in Sanuki. Bitchū-no-Kami took Hirauchi Hyōe and Ebi Jirō along with him and went to Ichinotani.

[9.9.1] Using Aki Umano-suke Noriyuki as a messenger, the Lord Minister said to the various Heike nobles, "It seems Kurō Yoshitsune has attacked and taken the Mikusa position and has already intruded. The mountain side is critical. Let each of you proceed there." But everyone declined. When he sent word to Lord Noto, saying, "Although it is a repeated request, will you proceed there?", Lord Noto replied, "I like it because I think of battle as a matter of importance for myself alone. Like hunting or fishing, if I were to say I will go to the place where the footing is good, or I will not go to the place where it is bad, surely I would not win in battle. However many times, Noritsune will accept the direction toward the strong side and proceed there. I will crush at least one side. Please set your mind at ease." He spoke reassuringly. The Lord Minister rejoiced extraordinarily, and with Etchū Zenji Moritoshi as the van, he attached over ten thousand horsemen to Lord Noto. Accompanied by his elder brother Echizen Sanmi Michimori Kyō, they fortified the mountain side. The place called the mountain side is the base of Hiyodorigoe. Michimori Kyō welcomed his wife to Lord Noto's temporary hut and regretted their final parting. Lord Noto became very angry and admonished him, saying, "This side is considered the strong side, and thus Noritsune has been directed here. Truly it must be strong. If the Genji drop suddenly from the mountain above right now, we will not be able to pick up what we should pick up. Even if we hold bows, if we do not nock arrows, it will be difficult to succeed. Even if we nock arrows, if we do not pull, it will be even worse. Much less, if you are relaxed like that, of what use will you be?" Perhaps thinking it was true, he hurriedly put on his armor and sent the person back. toward evening on the fifth day, the Genji departed Koyano and gradually approached the Ikuta Forest. Looking out over Suzume-matsubara, Mikage-no-matsu, and the direction of Koyano, the Genji had taken up positions in various groups and were burning distant fires. Gazing at them as the night deepened, they were like the moon rising from the edge of the mountains. The Heike also said, "Burn distant fires," and at the Ikuta Forest too, they burned them as per form. Looking out as the dawn broke, they were like the stars in a clear sky. This must be what was composed in the past as the fireflies of the riverbank; now indeed they realized it. The Genji took position there and rested their horses, took position here and fed their horses; they did not hurry. On the Heike side, thinking "Now they attack, now they attack," they had no peace of mind.

[9.9.2] At dawn on the sixth day, the Noble Scion Kurō divided the more than ten thousand horsemen into two hands; first, he dispatched Doi Jirō Sanehira with over seven thousand horsemen to the western approach of Ichinotani. With over three thousand horsemen himself, intending to descend Hiyodorigoe behind Ichinotani, he circled around to the rear from the Tanba road. The soldiers said to each other, "This is a renowned bad place. If we are to die anyway, we want to die facing the enemy; we do not want to die falling in a bad place. Ah, is there a guide for this mountain?" The resident of Musashi Province, Hirayama Mushadokoro, came forward and said, "Sueshige knows the way." The Noble Scion said, "You are a person born and raised in the eastern provinces; that you are a guide for the mountains of the western provinces which you see for the first time today is not very truthful."
