Hirayama spoke again: "That is not something thought to be your command. Poets know the blossoms of Yoshino and Hatsuse; brave men know the guidance behind the castle where the enemy is holed up." This again sounded arrogant.

[9.9.3] Also, a resident of Musashi Province called Beppu Kotarō Kiyoshige, a young warrior turning eighteen years old, came forward and said, "My father, the monk Yoshishige, taught me: 'Be attacked by enemies, and also hunt across mountains; when you are lost in the deep mountains, throw the reins over an old horse and drive it ahead of you; it will certainly come out onto a path.' Thus he taught me." The Noble Scion said, "What a graceful thing to say. Though snow buries the fields and plains, there is a saying that an old horse knows the way." Thus, placing a mirror saddle on a white-dappled old horse, fitting a white bit, tying the reins and throwing them over, they drove it ahead, and entered into the unknown deep mountains. Since it was early in the Second Month, the snow on the peaks had melted in patches, and there were places that looked like blossoms. The warblers of the valley sang, and there were places lost in mist. Looking up, the white snow was dazzling and towering; looking down, the blue mountains were jagged and the cliffs were high. The snow on the pines had not yet fully melted, and the narrow mossy path was faint. At times when the storm blew, one might mistake it for plum blossoms; as they went, whipping their horses east and west and hastening their steeds, the sun set on the mountain path, so they all dismounted and took up encampment. Musashibō Benkei came bringing an old man. When the Noble Scion asked, "Who is that?", he said, "He is a hunter of this mountain." "Then he must know the way. Speak as it is," he commanded. "How could I not know?"
"What do you think about descending from here to the Heike fortress at Ichinotani?"
"It is absolutely impossible. In places called the thirty-jo valley and the fifteen-jo rocky point, there is no way for people to pass. Much less, horses are unthinkable. Moreover, inside the castle they have dug pitfalls and planted diamond-spikes to wait for you, I say." "Now, do deer pass through such a place?" "Deer do pass through. When the world becomes warm, saying the grass is deep, the deer of Harima cross over to Tanba; when the world becomes cold, saying they will eat in the shallow snow, the deer of Tanba cross over to Inamino in Harima." The Noble Scion said, "In that case, it is a riding ground. Is it likely that where deer pass, horses cannot pass? Immediately, serve as guide." He said that he himself was old and it would be impossible. "Do you not have a child?" "I have," he said, and presented a youth called Kumaō, turning eighteen years of age. Immediately they tied up his hair; since the father was called Washio Shōji Takehisa, they named him Washio Saburō Yoshihisa, made him ride in the lead, and took him along as a guide. After the chastisement of the Heike, when [Yoshitsune] had a falling out with the Lord of Kamakura and was killed in Ōshū, this was the soldier who died in the same place as Washio Saburō Yoshihisa.

[9.10.1] Until around midnight on the sixth day, Kumagai and Hirayama were in the rearguard. Kumagai Jirō called his son Kojirō and said, "In this company, when we descend the bad place, there will be no question of who is first. Come, from here let us head toward the Harima road that Doi has been ordered to take, and charge the very front of Ichinotani." Kojirō said, "That is appropriate. Naoie also wanted to say this. In that case, let us approach immediately." Kumagai said, "Truly, Hirayama is also in this company; he is a man who does not like crowded battles. Watch Hirayama's state and come back." He sent a servant. As expected, Hirayama had set out before Kumagai, and was sitting alone muttering, "I don't know about others, but as for Sueshige, I won't pull back a single step." When the servant, pretending to feed the horse, struck it saying, "What a hateful long feed for a horse," [Hirayama] said, "Do not do that; that horse's remaining time is only tonight." And he set out. The servant ran back and hurriedly reported this, so Kumagai said, "Just as I thought," and immediately he also set out. Kumagai wore a dark blue hitatare and armor laced with red leather, hung a crimson horo cloak, and rode a renowned horse called Gonda-kurige. Kojirō wore a hitatare dyed once with arrowheads and armor laced with rough cord, and rode a white-cream horse called Seirō. The standard-bearer wore a dirt-colored hitatare and armor with small cherry blossoms on yellow, and rode a yellow-dun horse. Making the valley they would descend on the left hand, and walking their horses toward the right hand, they passed an old road called the fields of Tai where people had not passed for years, and came out onto the wave-beaten shore of Ichinotani. At a place called Shioya near Ichinotani, as it was still deep night, Doi Jirō Sanehira was holding back with over seven thousand horsemen. Kumagai slipped past there from the wave-beaten shore under the cover of night, and pressed upon the western wooden gate of Ichinotani. At that time, as it was still deep night, on the enemy side too it was silent and there was no sound. Not a single horseman of his allies followed. Kumagai Jirō called his son Kojirō and said, "There must be many people who have set their hearts on being first, saying 'Me too, me too.' Do not think narrowly that it is only Naozane. Although we have already approached, they must be holding back in this vicinity waiting for the dawn. Come, let us announce our names." Walking close to the shield wall, he raised a great voice and announced, "The resident of Musashi Province, Kumagai Jirō Naozane, and his son Kojirō Naoie, are the vanguard of Ichinotani!" On the Heike side, they said, "Good, good, make no sound. Let the enemy tire their horses' legs. Make them exhaust their supply of arrows." And there was no one to acknowledge him.

[9.10.2] Meanwhile, a single warrior followed behind. When asked "Who is it?", he answered "Sueshige." "Who is asking?" "It is Naozane." "Why, since when have you been here, Lord Kumagai?" "Naozane has been here since evening," he answered. "Sueshige too should have approached immediately after, but I was tricked by Narita Gorō and have been delayed until now. Since we pledged that if Narita died, we would die in the same place, thinking 'Let us go,' as we approached together, he restrained me saying, 'Don't be too hasty in the first charge, Lord Hirayama. To charge first means that because one charges leaving the friendly forces behind, high renown or failure becomes known to people. If just one horseman charges into a great force and is slain, what is the point?' Thinking that was true, I let him go up the small slope first, and pulling my horse's head downward, while I waited for the friendly forces, Narita also came out following; thinking we would ride side by side and discuss the manner of battle, it was not so; he looked coldly at Sueshige, and immediately galloped past; thinking, 'Ah, this person tricked me and intends to charge first,' although he was five or six tan ahead, eyeing him and thinking 'That fellow's horse looks weaker than my horse,' I whipped and whipped my horse and caught up, and shouting 'What a dishonest person to trick someone like Sueshige!', I rode past him and approached; he must be far behind, surely I will not even see his shadow."

[9.10.3] Meanwhile, as the dawn gradually broke, Kumagai and Hirayama, these and those, held back as five horsemen. Although Kumagai had announced his name earlier, hearing Hirayama, perhaps thinking to announce it [again], he walked close to the shield wall again, raised a great voice, and shouted, "The resident of Musashi Province who announced himself before, Kumagai Jirō Naozane, and his son Kojirō Naoie, are the vanguard of Ichinotani. Samurai of the Heike who think yourselves worthy, meet Naoie, meet him!" Hearing this, saying "Come, let us capture the Kumagai parent and child who have been announcing themselves all night," who were the Heike samurai who advanced? Etchū Jirōbyōe Moritsugu, Kazusa Gorōbyōe Tadamitsu, Aku-shichibyōe Kagekiyo, Gotō Nai Tsunetsune; beginning with these, some twenty renowned warriors opened the wooden gate and charged out. Here, Hirayama wore a hitatare with a dense eye-pattern, armor with scarlet lacing, hung a horo cloak with two stripes, and rode a renowned horse called Mekasuge. The standard-bearer wore armor with black leather lacing, a helmet with an iron neck-guard, and rode a rusty-cream horse. "The resident of Musashi Province who charged first in both the Hōgen and Heiji battles, Hirayama Mushadokoro Sueshige!" naming himself thus, he and his standard-bearer, two horsemen, lined up their horses' noses, shouted, and charged. When Kumagai charged, Hirayama followed; when Hirayama charged, Kumagai followed. Not to be outdone by each other, entering by turns, whipping and whipping, they attacked until fire flew. The Heike samurai, being attacked severely, perhaps thinking it hopeless, pulled back quickly inside the castle, and blocked it facing outward toward the enemy. Kumagai had his horse's belly shot; as it sprang up, he crossed his legs and stood down. His son Kojirō Naoie also, announcing his age as sixteen, attacked and fought until he thrust his horse's nose against the shield wall, but he had his left elbow shot, jumped down from his horse, and stood side by side with his father. "How is it, Kojirō, are you wounded?" "I am." "Always keep your armor tight, don't let them scratch the lining, tilt your neck-guard, don't let them shoot the inside of your helmet," he taught him. Kumagai threw away the arrows standing in his armor, glared inside the castle, and raising a great voice, shouted, "Since leaving Kamakura around the winter of last year, I have offered my life to the Captain of the Guards, and resolved to expose my corpse at Ichinotani; I am Naozane. Is Etchū Jirōbyōe, who names himself as having high renown in the two battles of Muroyama and Mizushima, not here? Are Kazusa Gorōbyōe and Aku-shichibyōe not here? Is Lord Noto not present? High renown depends on the enemy. One cannot achieve it by meeting just anyone. Meet Naozane, meet him!" Hearing this, Etchū Jirōbyōe, as he liked fine attire, wore a hitatare with dark blue shading, armor with red lacing, rode a white-dappled horse, and setting his eyes on the Kumagai father and son, walked his horse toward them. The Kumagai father and son, determined not to be separated, stood side by side, placed their swords to their foreheads, did not retreat a single step, and advanced ever forward. Etchū Jirōbyōe, perhaps thinking it hopeless, turned back. Kumagai saw this and said, "Why, that looks like Etchū Jirōbyōe. Would you choose your enemy? Press alongside Naozane and grapple, grapple!" Although he said this, saying "Let it be so," he [Etchū] turned back. Aku-shichibyōe saw this and said, "What dirty behavior for a lord," and was about to ride out to grapple, but his armor sleeve was held back. "Our lord's crisis is not limited to this. It should not be," he was restrained, and did not grapple. After that, Kumagai mounted a spare horse, shouted, and charged. Hirayama also, in the confusion of the Kumagai father and son fighting, rested his horse's breath and he too followed. On the Heike side, there were few warriors on horseback; the soldiers on top of the towers gathered their arrow-points and shot like falling rain, but the enemies were few, the allies were many; lost in the crowd, they were not hit by arrows. Although ordered, "Just press alongside and grapple, grapple," the Heike horses were ridden often and fed rarely; they had stood long in ships, and were like carvings. Kumagai and Hirayama's horses were great horses fed and fed again; if they struck one blow, they would surely kick them all over, so there was not a single warrior who pressed alongside and grappled. Hirayama had the standard-bearer he valued in exchange for his own life shot, broke into the midst of the enemy, and immediately took the head of that enemy and came out. Kumagai also took many heads. Although Kumagai approached first, because the gate was not opened, he did not charge in. Although Hirayama approached later, because the gate was opened, he charged in. Thus did Kumagai and Hirayama dispute the first and second charge.

[9.11.1] Meanwhile, Narita Gorō also arrived. Doi Jirō charged first, and his force of over seven thousand horsemen raised various flags, shouted and screamed, and attacked and fought. At the main gate, Ikuta Forest, the Genji had also solidified their position with over fifty thousand horsemen; within that force, there were men called Kawahara Tarō and Kawahara Jirō, residents of Musashi Province. Kawahara Tarō called his younger brother Jirō and said, "Although the great lords do not lower their hands themselves, they take the high renown of their retainers as their honor. For us, if we do not lower our hands ourselves, it is difficult to succeed. While the enemy is placed before us, to sit waiting without shooting even a single arrow feels overly impatient; Takanao intends to first slip inside the castle and shoot one arrow. If I do so, it is unlikely I will return alive, one in ten million. You, remain behind and stand as a witness for the future." When he said this, Kawahara Jirō let tears fall freely and said, "What a regrettable thing you say. If of two brothers, the elder is slain and the younger remains behind alone, how much glory can he sustain? Rather than being slain in different places, let us be together whatever happens." So saying, they called their servants near, sent word of their final state to their wives and children, and without even mounting horses, wearing gaiters and leaning on their bows as staffs, they climbed over the abatis of Ikuta Forest and entered inside the castle. In the starlight, the color of their armor was not clear. Kawahara Tarō raised a great voice and announced, "The residents of Musashi Province, Kawahara Tarō Kisaichi Takanao and same Jirō Morinao, are the vanguard of the Genji main force at Ikuta Forest!" On the Heike side, hearing this, they said, "There are no men as terrifying as the warriors of the eastern provinces. If just two have entered into a great force such as this, what kind of thing might they do? Good, good, spare them for a while." Thus there was no one who said to shoot. Since these brothers were peerless masters of the bow, as they shot rapidly and unceasingly, just when [the Heike] said, "They are hard to spare, kill them!", there were brothers known in the western provinces as strong archers and elite soldiers, residents of Bitchū Province, Manabe Shirō and Manabe Gorō; Shirō was placed at Ichinotani, but Gorō was at Ikuta Forest; seeing this, he drew his bow fully and shot with a whistle. Kawahara Tarō had his armor breastplate pierced through to the back, and as he clung to his bow-staff and crouched down, his younger brother Jirō ran up, slung his brother onto his shoulder, and was about to climb over the abatis, when Manabe's second arrow struck him outside the tassets of his armor, and they lay down on the same pillow. Manabe's servants met them and took the heads of the Kawahara brothers. When these were entered into the inspection of the New Chūnagon, he said, "Ah, brave men. These should be called soldiers equal to a thousand; what a pity to see them without saving them."

[9.11.2] At that time, the servants shouted, "The Kawahara brothers have just charged first inside the castle and have been slain!" Kajiwara heard this: "It is a failure of the lords of my party that caused the Kawahara brothers to be slain. Now the time is right, attack!" And he raised the war cry with a roar. Immediately following, over fifty thousand horsemen raised the war cry all at once. Making the foot soldiers remove the abatis, Kajiwara's five hundred horsemen shouted and charged. Because the second son Heiji Kagetaka advanced to charge too far ahead, his father Heizō sent a messenger saying, "The great general commands that there will be no reward for anyone who charges ahead when the rear force does not follow." Heiji held back for a moment, and saying,

lg.l: "The birch-wood bow inherited by the warrior; once drawn, does one return it?"

div.p: [9.11.3] "Tell him that!" And he shouted and charged. "Don't let Heiji be killed, follow, men! Don't let Kagetaka be killed, follow, men!" Saying this, his father Heizō, elder brother Genta, and same Saburō followed. Kajiwara's five hundred horsemen charged into the midst of the great force and fought wildly; reduced to merely some fifty horsemen, they pulled back quickly and came out. Whatever happened, Kagesue was not seen among them. "How is it, where is Genta, retainers?" he asked. "He seems to have gone in deep and been slain," they said. Kajiwara Heizō heard this: "I think of existing in the world only for the sake of my children; if Genta is slain, even if my life is saved, what is the use? Turn back!" And he turned back. Kajiwara raised a great voice and announced his name: "I am the descendant of Kamakura Gongorō Kagemasa, who in the old days, during Lord Hachiman's Later Three Years War, when attacking the Senbuku Kanazawa fortress in Dewa Province, at the age of sixteen, charged the very front, had his left eye shot into the plate of his helmet bowl, shot an arrow in return, shot down that enemy, and raised his name for future generations; I am Kajiwara Heizō Kagetoki, a soldier equal to a thousand! Those people who think yourselves worthy, kill Kagetoki and show him to your lord!" And he shouted and charged. The New Chūnagon said, "Kajiwara is a soldier renowned in the eastern provinces. Don't spare him, don't let him escape, kill him!" As they hemmed him in amidst a great force and attacked, Kajiwara, not knowing his own fate, wondering where Genta was, charged vertically and horizontally, in spider-legs and cross-shapes, breaking through and circling around amidst tens of thousands of horsemen searching; meanwhile, Genta had fought until his helmet was pushed back, had his horse shot, became a foot soldier, and with a cliff of some two jo at his back, hemmed in amidst five enemies, with two retainers standing left and right, without looking back, sparing not his life, he fought in defense, making this his end. Kajiwara found him: "You are not yet slain!" He hurriedly jumped down from his horse: "Kagetoki is here; however it may be, Genta, even if you die, do not show your back to the enemy!" Parent and child together killed three of the five enemies and wounded two, and saying, "For one who takes up the bow and arrow, charging and retreating depend on the moment; come, Genta," they came out together. This is Kajiwara's Second Charge.

[9.12.1] Beginning with this, the warriors of Chichibu, Ashikaga, Miura, Kamakura, and of the parties Inomata, Kodama, Noiyo, Yokoyama, the West Party, the Tsuzuki Party, and private parties, generally the Genji and Heike fought confusedly, entering by turns, announcing names by turns; the voices of shouting and screaming echoed in the mountains, and the sound of horses galloping past each other was like thunder. The arrows shot back and forth were no different from falling rain. There were those who hung the wounded on their shoulders and retreated to the rear. There were those who fought bearing light wounds. There were those who bore painful wounds and died fighting. Or, pressing alongside, grappling and falling, stabbing each other and dying. Or, taking and pressing down and cutting the head; or having it cut. Either way, no gap could be seen. Although it was thus, it did not seem that the Genji main force alone could succeed; but the Noble Scion Kurō circled to the rear and at dawn on the seventh day, rode up Hiyodorigoe behind Ichinotani and was about to descend; perhaps startled by that force, two stags and one doe fell down into the Heike fortress at Ichinotani. Seeing this, the soldiers inside the castle panicked, saying, "Even deer close to villages should fear us and enter deep into the mountains; that deer fall into the midst of such a great force is strange. No matter how, the Genji are dropping them from the mountain above." The resident of Iyo Province, Takechi no Mushadokoro Kiyonori, came forward and said, "Whatever it may be, there is no reason to let escape something that has come out from the direction of the enemy." He shot and stopped the two stags, and let the doe pass without shooting. The Former Governor of Etchū restrained him, saying, "What a pointless way for a lord to shoot deer. With that one arrow just now, you could defend against ten enemies; it is sinful, and a waste of an arrow."

[9.12.2] The Noble Scion, overlooking the fortress from afar, said, "Let us drop horses and see." He drove saddled horses down. Some broke their legs, tumbled and fell. Some fell and went without mishap. Three saddled horses landed on top of the Former Governor of Etchū's heavy shed, shook themselves, and stood. The Noble Scion saw this: "If the masters are mindful when dropping the horses, they will not be damaged. Drop them! Make Yoshitsune your model!" Saying this, first some thirty horsemen charged the very front and descended. The great force all followed and descended. The nose-guards of the armor of the people descending in the rear guard touched the helmets of the vanguard. Since it was sand mixed with small stones, in a flowing slide, they dropped quickly for about two chō and held back at a flat place. Looking down below from there, moss-covered great boulders dropped like a well-bucket for fourteen or fifteen jō. The soldiers could not turn back saying "rearward," nor did it seem they could drop forward. Saying "This is the end," they held back dumbfounded; then Sahara Jūrō Yoshitsura came forward and said, "In the direction of Miura, we galloped over places like this morning and evening, even to flush out a single bird. It is a Miura riding ground!" And he charged the very front and descended, so the soldiers all followed and descended. Keeping their "Ei, ei" voices quiet, and trusting to their horses, they descended. Because of the excess terror, they descended with their eyes closed. It did not seem like the act of humans at all; it seemed solely the work of demons and gods. Before they had finished descending, they raised the war cry with a roar. Though it was the voice of over three thousand horsemen, echoing in the mountains, it sounded like over one hundred thousand horsemen. Murakami Hōgandai Yasukuni's detachment started fires, burning away all the Heike heavy sheds and temporary huts. The wind was strong at the time, and black smoke covered everything, so the Heike soldiers panicked in excess, and saying "If only we can save ourselves," many rushed into the sea in front. Although there were any number of prepared boats at the water's edge, with four or five hundred armed men trying to crowd onto a single boat saying "I will board first," how could it be good? Pushing out merely three chō from the water's edge, three large ships sank before their eyes. After that, saying that although they would load persons of quality, they should not load commoners, they swept them away with long swords and halberds. Knowing this would happen, they clung and grasped at the ships they tried to board; some had arms cut off, some had elbows lopped off, and they lay in lines at the water's edge of Ichinotani, turned to crimson. Noto-no-Kami Noritsune, a person who had not failed once in repeated battles, wondered what he thought this time; riding a horse called Usuzumi, he fled pointing toward the west. Boarding a ship from the Akashi coast in Harima Province, he crossed over to Yashima in Sanuki.

div.head: 9.13. The End of the Former Governor of Etchū

div.p: [9.13.1] At the main gate and at the beach side, the soldiers of Musashi and Sagami attacked and fought without sparing their lives. While the New Chūnagon was facing east and fighting, a messenger of the Kodama party came up from the mountain side and said, "Since you were the Governor of Musashi, the men of Kodama say this. Will you not look at your rear?" When the people from the New Chūnagon on down looked back at the rear, black smoke was billowing up. Just as they said, "Alas, the western side has been broken!", taking nothing that they should take, they strove to be first to flee.

[9.13.2] The Former Governor of Etchū Moritoshi was the samurai general of the mountain side, but perhaps thinking it was hopeless to flee now, he held back and waited for the enemy; Inomata no Ko-Heiroku Noritsuna, eyeing him as a good enemy, rode up whipping and stirruping, pressed alongside, grappled firmly, and they fell with a thud. Inomata was a tough man renowned in the eight provinces. It was rumored that he could easily tear apart deer antlers at the first or second branch. Although to the human eye the Former Governor of Etchū seemed to have the strength of twenty or thirty men, privately he had the great strength to push up and push down a boat that sixty or seventy men moved up and down, all by himself. Therefore, he took Inomata, pressed him down, and did not let him move. While lying underneath, Inomata tried to draw his sword, but [Etchū] spread his arms so he could not reach the hilt of his sword; he tried to speak, but being pressed down too strongly, his voice did not come out. He was about to have his head cut, but since his strength was inferior but his heart was strong, Inomata did not panic in the least; resting his breath for a while, and behaving as if it were not so, he said, "Now, did you hear me announce my name? To say one kills an enemy is a great merit only if one announces oneself to be heard, and makes the enemy announce himself, and takes the head. If you take a head whose name is unknown, of what use will it be to you?" Being told this, perhaps thinking it was true, he said, "I am a member of the original Heike, but because I am unworthy, at present I am a person called the Former Governor of Etchū Moritoshi, who has become a samurai. Who are you, my lord? Name yourself, I will hear." He announced himself: "The resident of Musashi Province, Inomata no Ko-Heiroku Noritsuna." "Looking carefully at the state of the world, the Genji side is strong, and the Heike side seems to have the color of defeat. Now if your lord were in the world, you might take an enemy's head and present it, and receive merit and reward. Bend reason and save Noritsuna. Let there be tens of people of your lordship's clan. In exchange for the reward of Noritsuna's merit, I will save them." When he said this, the Former Governor of Etchū became very angry: "Although Moritoshi is unworthy, still I am a member of the Heike. I do not think to rely on the Genji, nor do I think the Genji would rely on Moritoshi. What an evil lord to speak thus." And immediately he was about to cut his head, so Inomata said, "How improper; is there a way to cut the head of a surrenderer?" The Former Governor of Etchū said, "Then I will save you." And he pulled him up. The front was dried up like a field and was extremely hard, but the back was on the ridge of a wet paddy that was deep with mud, and the two men sat catching their breath with their waists against it.

[9.13.3] After a short while, a single warrior wearing armor laced with black leather and riding a cream-colored horse came galloping up. The Former Governor of Etchū looked suspiciously: "That is a person close to Noritsuna called Hitomi Shirō. Seeing Noritsuna, I believe he has come. It should not be painful." While saying this, thinking "When he approaches, if I grapple with the Former Governor of Etchū [sic: likely meant 'If I grapple him'], surely we will die together," he waited, and [Hitomi] approached to within one tan. The Former Governor of Etchū at first looked at the two men one glance at a time, but as he came gradually closer, he watched the galloping enemy intently; in the gap of not watching Inomata, [Inomata] stood up with force treading his legs, said "Ei!", thrust both hands against the breastplate of the Former Governor of Etchū's armor, and pushed him over backward into the wet paddy behind. As he tried to rise, Inomata jumped firmly on top of him, immediately pulled out the Former Governor of Etchū's waist sword, pulled up the tassets of his armor, and stabbed him three times so that hilt and fist went through and through, and took his head. Meanwhile Hitomi Shirō arrived. Thinking that in such a time there is no disputing, he pierced it on the tip of his sword, held it high, raised a great voice, and announced, "Inomata no Ko-Heiroku Noritsuna has slain the Heike samurai known in these days as a demon god, the Former Governor of Etchū Moritoshi!" And he added it to the first item of high renown for that day.

[9.14.1] Satsuma-no-Kami Tadanori was the great general of the western hand of Ichinotani; he wore a hitatare of dark blue brocade and armor with black thread lacing, and rode a thick and powerful black horse with a gold-flecked lacquer saddle. Surrounded amidst a force of some one hundred horsemen, he retreated calmly, holding back again and again; Okabe no Rokuyata Tadazumi of the Inomata party, eyeing him as a great general, whipped and stirruped and caught up to him, saying, "Now, what kind of person are you? Announce your name."
When he said this, [Tadanori] said, "This is an ally," and when [Okabe] looked inside the helmet as he looked back, his teeth were iron-black. Thinking, "Ah, among our allies there are no persons with attached iron [blackened teeth]; it must be a Heike noble."
he pressed alongside and grappled firmly. Seeing this, the soldiers numbering some one hundred horsemen, being temporary warriors from various provinces, did not join in, not even one horseman, and fled, each trying to be first. Satsuma-no-Kami said, "What evil fellows. If I say I am an ally, let me say it."
Since he was a man of great strength raised in Kumano and possessed of quick agility, he immediately drew his sword and stabbed Rokuyata twice on the horse and once as they fell and landed, three times in total. Since the two stabs were on the armor, they did not penetrate. The one stab thrust into the inside of the helmet, but because it was a slight wound, he did not die; just as [Tadanori] took him, pressed him down, and was about to cut his head, Rokuyata's page boy, galloping up from behind, drew his sword and cut off Satsuma-no-Kami's right arm from the elbow. Perhaps realizing that this was the end, he said, "Stand back for a moment; I will chant the Ten Recitations."
Grasping Rokuyata with his left arm, he threw him away about the length of a bow. After that, facing the west, he chanted the Ten Recitations in a loud voice: "Light shines everywhere, the ten directions of the world; the Buddha gathers those who invoke him and does not abandon them."
Before he had finished speaking, Rokuyata approached from behind and cut off Satsuma-no-Kami's head. Although he thought he had killed a fine great general, he did not know his name or who he was; but when he untied and looked at a letter attached to the quiver, there was a single poem composed on the topic "Traveling Lodging Flower."

lg.l: Overtaken by twilight, if I make the tree's shade my lodging, might the flower be tonight's host?

div.p: [9.14.2] Because "Tadanori" was written there, he knew it was Satsuma-no-Kami. Piercing it on the tip of his sword and holding it high, he raised a great voice and announced, "Okabe no Rokuyata Tadazumi has slain Lord Satsuma-no-Kami, who has been rumored of late as a general of the Heike side!" Hearing this, enemies and allies alike said, "Ah, how pitiable; a person who was a master of both martial arts and the way of poetry. What a regrettable great general." And there was none who did not shed tears and wet their sleeves.

[9.15.1] Hon-Sanmi Chūjō Shigehira Kyō was the vice-general of Ikuta Forest, but his force had all fled and been lost, and he had become just two horsemen, master and servant. As for the Sanmi Chūjō's attire on that day, he wore a hitatare embroidered with flocking plovers in white and yellow thread on dark blue, armor with purple shading at the bottom, and rode a renowned horse called Dōji Kage. His milk-brother Gotōbyōe Morinaga wore a hitatare with a dense eye-pattern, armor with scarlet lacing, and was made to ride the Sanmi Chūjō's treasured horse Yome-nashi Tsukige. Kajiwara Genta Kagesue and Shō no Shirō Takaie, eyeing him as a great general, whipped and stirruped and pursued him. Although there were any number of rescue boats at the water's edge, the enemy was pursuing from behind, and since there was no gap to escape, they crossed the Minato River and the Karumo River, and viewing the Lotus Pond on the right hand and putting the Grove of Colts on the left hand, they passed Itayado and Suma and fled pointing toward the west. He was riding a peerless, renowned horse. Since it did not seem the whipped and exhausted horses [of the pursuers] would catch up, and the distance only grew and grew, Kajiwara Genta Kagesue stood up spreading his stirrups, drew a far-flying arrow thinking "If only," and shot; since he had shot the Sanmi Chūjō's horse deep in the hindquarters and it weakened, Gotōbyōe Morinaga perhaps thought "My horse will be summoned," for he whipped his horse and fled away. The Sanmi Chūjō saw this and said, "How now, Morinaga? You did not vow thus in years and days past; abandoning me, where do you go?" But pretending not to hear, he ripped off the red badge attached to his armor, threw it away, and fled and fled. The Sanmi Chūjō [saw] the enemy approaching and his horse was weak; although he rode into the sea, the shallows stretched far and there was no way it would sink, so he dismounted, cut the sash of his armor, undid the cords, took off and discarded his weapons, and was about to cut his belly when, ahead of Kajiwara, Shō no Shirō Takaie galloped up matching whip and stirrup, hurriedly jumped down from his horse, and said, "It is improper. I will accompany you anywhere." He placed him upon his own horse, tied him to the front pommel of the saddle, and riding a spare horse himself, he returned.

[9.15.2] Gotōbyōe rode a peerless horse with long breath. Without it crying out, he escaped far; later he relied on the Kumano Monk and Onaka Hokkyō, but after the Hokkyō died, when the widowed nun went up to the Capital for a lawsuit, Morinaga accompanied her; since he was the Sanmi Chūjō's milk-brother, he was known to many, high and low. They said, "Ah, the shameless Morinaga. Though [Shigehira] treated him with such pity, without sharing his fate in the same place, how hateful that he accompanies an unexpected nun." When they flicked their fingernails [in disdain], it is said that Morinaga, indeed looking ashamed, hid his face with his fan.

[9.16.1] The battle having been lost, Kumagai Jirō Naozane said, "The Heike nobles will be fleeing toward the water's edge, intending to board rescue boats. Ah, I would grapple with a fine great general." As he walked his horse toward the beach, a single warrior riding a dappled-grey horse with a yellow-rimmed saddle, wearing a hitatare embroidered with cranes on silk and armor with light green lacing, with the cords of a helmet with hoe-shaped crests tied tight, wearing a sword with gold fittings, carrying arrows with mottled feathers and a rattan-wrapped bow, set his eyes on a ship in the offing and rushed into the sea, causing his horse to swim some five or six tan; Kumagai said, "That looks to be a great general. What a dishonest person to show your back to the enemy. Turn back!" When he raised his fan and beckoned, [the warrior] was beckoned and turned back. As he was about to ride up onto the beach, [Kumagai] pressed alongside, grappled firmly, and they fell with a thud; taking him and pressing him down, he was about to cut his head when he pushed up the helmet and looked: he was about sixteen or seventeen years old, lightly powdered, with blackened teeth. Since he was about the age of his own son Kojirō, and his face was truly beautiful, he did not know where to drive his sword. "Now, what kind of person are you? Announce your name. I will save you."
When he said this, [the youth] asked, "Who are you? " "I am not a person of significance, but I am the resident of Musashi Province, Kumagai Jirō Naozane," he announced. "In that case, having met you, I will not announce my name. For you, I am a good enemy. Even if I do not name myself, take my head and ask people; they will know."
Thus he spoke. "Ah, a great general. Even if I kill this one person, the battle which is to be lost will not be won. And even if I do not kill him, the battle which is to be won will surely not be lost. When Kojirō suffers even a slight wound, Naozane thinks it painful; when this lord's father hears that he has been slain, how much will he grieve? Ah, I would save him." Thinking this, he looked sharply behind him, and Doi and Kajiwara followed with some fifty horsemen. Kumagai held back his tears and said, "Although I wish to save you, the friendly forces are like clouds and mist. Surely you will not escape. Rather than having you fall into the hands of others, it is better that I hang you on Naozane's hand and perform memorial services for your afterlife." When he said this, [the youth] said, "Just take my head quickly." Kumagai was so full of pity that he did not know where to drive his sword; his eyes went dark and his mind faded, and he felt unaware of before and after, but since it was not a matter that could remain so, weeping and weeping, he cut the head. "Ah, there is no person as regretful as one who takes up the bow and arrow. If I had not been born in a martial house, why would I see such a sorrowful sight? What a heartless thing to kill him," he lamented, pressing his sleeve to his face and weeping bitterly. After quite a long time, since it could not remain so, as he took the armor hitatare to wrap the head, there was a flute in a brocade bag thrust into the waist [of the youth]. "Ah, how pitiable; at dawn today, those who were playing music within the castle were these people. Although there are tens of thousands of horsemen in the eastern forces at present, surely there is no person who brings a flute to the battle camp. The high nobility are indeed graceful." When he brought it to the inspection of the Noble Scion Kurō, there was no one who saw it who did not shed tears. Hearing later, it was the son of Shūri-no-Daibu Tsunemori, called Tayū Atsumori; he was seventeen years of age. It was from this that Kumagai's desire for religious awakening advanced. As for the said flute, it is said that his grandfather Tadamori was a master of the flute and had received it from the Retired Emperor Toba. Tsunemori had inherited it, and because Atsumori was talented, he held it. The name was called Koeda [Little Branch]. Although it is the logic of wild words and fancy phrases, that it finally became the cause for praising the Buddha Vehicle is moving.

[9.17.1] The youngest son of Kadowaki Chūnagon Norimori Kyō, Kurōdo Tayū Narimori, grappled with the resident of Hitachi Province Tsuchiya Gorō Shigeyuki and was slain. Shūri-no-Daibu Tsunemori's heir, Kōgū-no-Suke Tsunemasa, was fleeing toward the water's edge intending to board a rescue boat, but was hemmed in by the troops of Kawagoe Kotarō Shigefusa and was slain. His younger brothers, Wakasa-no-Kami Tsunetoshi, Awaji-no-Kami Kiyofusa, and Owari-no-Kami Kiyosada, three horsemen together, charged into the midst of the enemy, fought scattered battles, took many heads, and died fighting in one place.

[9.17.2] New Chūnagon Tomomori Kyō was the great general of Ikuta Forest, but his force had all fled and been lost; now becoming just three horsemen, master and servants, with his son Musashi-no-Kami Tomoakira and the samurai Kenmotsu Tarō Yorikata, they fled toward the water's edge intending to board a rescue boat. Here, men appearing to be of the Kodama party, carrying fan-banners, some ten horsemen, shouted and pursued them. Kenmotsu Tarō, being a peerless master of the bow, shot the neck bone of the standard-bearer who advanced in the very front with a whistle, and shot him down upside down from his horse. When a person among them appearing to be the general galloped up to grapple with the New Chūnagon, his son Musashi-no-Kami Tomoakira came in between, pressed alongside and grappled firmly, fell with a thud, took him and pressed him down and cut his head; as he was about to stand up, the enemy's page boy met him and killed Musashi-no-Kami. Kenmotsu Tarō fell upon him and killed the enemy's page boy who had killed Musashi-no-Kami. After that, he shot all the arrows he had, drew his sidearm and fought; although he killed many enemies, he had his left knee shot, and unable to stand up, he died fighting while sitting. In this confusion, the New Chūnagon was riding a peerless, renowned horse; making it swim over twenty chō on the surface of the sea, he arrived at the Lord Minister's ship. Many people were crowded onto the ship, and since there was no way to stable the horse, he drove it back. Awa Minbu Shigeyoshi said, "The horse will become the property of the enemy. I shall shoot it dead." And he fitted an arrow with one hand and went out, but the New Chūnagon said, "Let it become anything; it is the one who saved my life. It should not be." So having no choice, he did not shoot. This horse, yearning for the parting from its master, did not leave the ship for a while and swam toward the offing, but as it gradually became distant, it swam back to the empty water's edge. When it reached where its feet could stand, it looked back toward the ship and neighed two or three times. After that, as it went up on land and rested, Kawagoe Kotarō Shigefusa took it and presented it to the Cloistered Emperor, so it was immediately stood in the imperial stables. Originally it was a treasured horse of the Cloistered Emperor and stood in the First Stable, but it was said to be given when Lord Munemori became Naidaijin and expressed his joy. It was entrusted to the New Chūnagon, and the Chūnagon treasured this horse exceedingly; saying it was for the horse's prayers, on the first day of every month, he worshipped Taizan Fukun. Perhaps because of that, the horse's life was extended, and it was auspicious that it saved its master's life. Since this horse was from the Inoue lineage of Shinano Province, it was called Inoue Kuro [Inoue Black]. Later, because Kawagoe took and presented it, it was also called Kawagoe Kuro.

[9.17.3] The New Chūnagon went into the presence of the Lord Minister and spoke: "I have been left behind by Musashi-no-Kami. I have had Kenmotsu Tarō killed. Now I have become truly disheartened. What kind of parent am I, that while a son exists and intends to save his parent, seeing him grapple with an enemy; what kind of parent am I, that without saving the son being killed, I have escaped and come here like this? If it were about another person, how critical I would feel; but now that it has happened to myself, I realize now that life is indeed precious. I am ashamed of the thoughts inside people's hearts." Saying this, he pressed his sleeve to his face and wept bitterly; the Lord Minister heard this and said, "That he exchanged himself for the life of Musashi-no-Kami's father is rare. A person who was skilled and strong of heart, a fine great general; he was the same age as Kiyomune, sixteen this year." Looking toward where his son Emon-no-Kami was, he became tearful, so the Heike samurai sitting in rows, those with heart and those without, all wet the sleeves of their armor.

[9.18.1] When Lord Komatsu's youngest son, Bitchū-no-Kami Morimori, master and servants seven people, was fleeing in a small boat, a samurai of the New Chūnagon called Seiemon Kiminaga galloped up and said, "That looks like the boat of Lord Bitchū-no-Kami. I shall join you."
When he said this, they pulled the boat to the water's edge. A large man wearing armor jumping suddenly from a horse onto a boat; how could it be good? The boat was small and overturned completely. While Bitchū-no-Kami was floating and sinking, Hatakeyama's retainer Honda Jirō galloped up with fourteen or fifteen horsemen, pulled him up with a rake, and finally cut his head. It was said he was fourteen years of age.

[9.18.2] Echizen Sanmi Michimori Kyō was the great general of the mountain side; as for his attire on that day, he wore a hitatare of red brocade and armor with Chinese twill lacing, and rode a yellow-dun horse with a white-rimmed saddle. Having the inside of his helmet shot and being separated by the enemy, he was parted from his younger brother Lord Noto. Thinking to commit suicide in a quiet place, as he fled toward the east, he was hemmed in by the resident of Ōmi Province Sasaki Kimura Saburō Naritsuna and the resident of Musashi Province Tamai Shirō Sukekage, these and those seven horsemen, and was finally slain. Until that time, one samurai had accompanied him, but he too did not meet him at the final hour.

[9.18.3] Generally, as the eastern and western wooden gates fell in a short time, the Genji and Heike exhausted their numbers and were slain. In front of the towers and beneath the abatis, the corpses of men and horses were like mountains. The small bamboo fields of Ichinotani changed their green color and became crimson. At Ichinotani, Ikuta Forest, the side of the mountain, and the water's edge of the sea, those who died shot and cut were unknown; the heads cut and hung by the Genji were over two thousand men. The renowned people who were slain this time were Echizen Sanmi Michimori, his younger brother Kurōdo Tayū Narimori, Satsuma-no-Kami Tadanori, Musashi-no-Kami Tomoakira, Bitchū-no-Kami Morimori, Owari-no-Kami Kiyosada, Awaji-no-Kami Kiyofusa, Shūri-no-Daibu Tsunemori's heir Kōgū-no-Suke Tsunemasa, his younger brother Wakasa-no-Kami Tsunetoshi, and his younger brother Tayū Atsumori; ten people in all, it was said.

[9.18.4] The battle having been lost, beginning with the Sovereign, the people all boarded ships; the feelings in their hearts as they departed were indeed sad; pulled by the tide and following the wind, there were ships heading for the Kii route. Rowing out to the offing of Ashiya, there were ships rocked by the waves. Or passing from Suma along the coast of Akashi, with uncertain anchorage and rudder-pillows, with single-spread sleeves soaking wet, under the hazy spring moon, there was no one whose heart was not broken. Or rowing through the strait of Awaji, drifting by the rocks of Ejima, the wave-path sounding faintly, the plovers of the night losing their mates; are these too a kind of myself? Perhaps because they had not decided where their destination should be, there were ships resting in the offing of Ichinotani. Drifting thus to bays and islands, trusting to the wind and following the waves, it was difficult to know each other's death or life. The provinces they subdued were fourteen provinces; the force attached to them was over one hundred thousand horsemen. The approach to the Capital was a road of merely one day, so they had thought confidently that this time, surely; but Ichinotani too was attacked and fell, and the people all became disheartened.

div.head: 9.19. Kozaishō Drowns Herself

div.p:
[9.19.1] Among the samurai of Echizen Sanmi Michimori Kyō, there was a man called Mita no Takiguchi Tokikazu. Coming to the wife's ship, he said, "My lord was hemmed in below the Minato River amidst seven enemies and was finally slain. Among them, those who especially lowered their hands and killed him announced themselves as the resident of Ōmi Province Sasaki Kimura Saburō Naritsuna and the resident of Musashi Province Tamai Shirō Sukekage. Tokikazu also should have shared his fate in the same place and accompanied him in his final moments, but since he commanded beforehand, saying, 'Whatever becomes of Michimori, you must not discard your life; survive no matter what and look after my afterlife,' I have lived a worthless life and heartlessly escaped this far." Although he said this, the wife did not manage a reply of this or that, but pulled [her robe] over her head and lay face down. Although she heard he was certainly slain, thinking "Perhaps it is a mistake," or "Perhaps he might return alive," she spent two or three days with the feeling of waiting for a person who had gone out for no reason, but when four or five days passed, her reliance on "perhaps" weakened completely, and she became increasingly disheartened. The nurse lady-in-waiting, who alone attended her, also lay down on the same pillow and sank into grief. From the evening of the seventh day when she heard this, until the night of the thirteenth day, she did not rise. When it dawned it would be the fourteenth day; lying there until the evening had passed, intending to arrive at Yashima, as the night deepened and the inside of the ship became quiet, the wife said to the nurse lady-in-waiting, "These days past, I heard that the Sanmi was slain, but I existed not thinking it was true; but since this evening, I have decided that it is indeed so. Although everyone says he was slain below the Minato River or such, there is not a single person who says they met him alive after that. On the night when he intended to set out the next day, when I met him in a casual place, looking more disheartened than anything and lamenting, he said, 'In tomorrow's battle, I feel I will certainly be slain. After I become whatever happens, what will you do?' But since battle is a common thing, I did not think it would certainly be so; the regret of it! If only I had thought that was the limit, why did I not vow for the afterlife? Even to think of it is sad. Although I hid that my body had become not ordinary [pregnant] and did not speak of it for days, thinking he would not think deeply of me, I spoke of it; he seemed extraordinarily happy and said, 'Although Michimori has reached thirty, I have had no one called a child; ah, let it be a boy. Just to think of leaving a memento in the floating world. Now how many months is it? How is your feeling? Since it is a dwelling in a ship on the waves without a fixed time, what shall we do when your body becomes split [in labor]?' Such words were fleeting promises for the future. Is it true that at such times, nine out of ten women surely die? It is wretched to meet a shameful experience and die in vain. After my body becomes split safely, I think I would raise the young one and look at it as a memento of the deceased, but every time I look at the young one, I would only long for the person of the past, and though my thoughts would increase, surely there would be no comfort. In the end, it is a path I cannot escape. Even if by some wonder I endure this world, in the way of the world that does not follow one's heart, there are unexpected wonders. This too, when I think of it, is wretched. If I doze, he appears in my dreams; if I wake, his image stands before me. Rather than living and thinking somehow that I long for him, I have decided I simply want to enter the bottom of the water. It is painful that you alone will remain there and lament, but take what attire I have, give it to some monk, pray for the Bodhi of the deceased, and help my afterlife. Pass on the letter I have written to the Capital."
As she spoke in detail, the nurse lady-in-waiting let tears fall freely: "Abandoning young children, leaving behind aged parents, and accompanying you far to this place; how much do you think of my intent? Moreover, how could the thoughts of the wives of the people slain this time at Ichinotani be shallow? Therefore, you should not think of it as a matter for yourself alone. After you have safely split your body, raise the young person, and even in the cleft of a rock or tree, change your appearance, chant the Buddha's name, and pray for the Bodhi of the deceased. Even if you think 'definitely on the same lotus,' after you are reborn, in the space of the Six Paths and Four Births, to what path might you proceed? Meeting him is uncertain, so throwing yourself away is a pointless thing. Moreover, asking who should watch over the Capital and such, why do you speak like this? It is hateful to hear."
Saying this, she lamented and wept bitterly; the wife, perhaps thinking this matter was heard badly, said, "You should guess that, even against your heart. In the sadness of parting from a person, it is the common way to say one will throw oneself away in resentment of the world in general. But such a thing is a rare instance. If I truly resolved to do so, I would not do it without letting you know. The night has deepened. Come, let us sleep."
When she said this, the nurse lady-in-waiting, feeling sad that a person who had not even looked properly at hot water or water for these four or five days should speak thus, and thinking that she had truly resolved, said, "Generally, the matter of the Capital is a matter as it may be, but if you resolve to do such a thing, please take me with you even to the bottom of a thousand fathoms. I do not feel I could survive for a moment after being left behind by you." Saying such things, while she was at her side, in a moment when she dozed off a little, the wife softly got out to the edge of the boat; since it was the vast sea, she did not know which way was west, but perhaps thinking the edge of the mountain where the moon set was the sky of that direction, she quietly chanted the Nembutsu; the plovers crying on the white shoals of the offing, the sound of oars crossing the heavenly door; perhaps because of the moment, sorrow won out; chanting the Nembutsu about one hundred times in a suppressed voice, "Namu, Lord Teacher of the Western Paradise of Ultimate Bliss, Amida Nyorai, without mistaking the Original Vow, guide me to the Pure Land; the relationship of husband and wife that parted without satisfaction, welcome us certainly on the one lotus." Weeping and weeping, lamenting from afar, together with the voice chanting "Namu," she sank into the sea.

[9.19.2] Since it was around midnight as they pushed across from Ichinotani to Yashima, inside the boat it was quiet and people did not know this. Among them, a steersman who was not sleeping saw it and shouted, "How is that? From that boat, a most beautiful lady has just entered the sea!" The nurse lady-in-waiting woke with a start and groped by her side, but since she was not there, she cried out dumbfounded, "Oh no, oh no!" Many people went down and tried to pull her up, but even otherwise, as is the way of spring nights, it was hazy, and gathering clouds from all directions came floating, so although they dove and dove, the moon was dim and they could not see. After a while they brought her up, but she had already become a person not of this world. She wore a two-layer robe of glossed silk and white hakama. Both her hair and hakama were dripping wet; though they brought her up, it was in vain. The nurse lady-in-waiting clasped hand in hand, pressed face to face, and said, "Why, if you resolved to this extent, did you not take me with you to the bottom of a thousand fathoms? What a hateful person to leave me behind. Even so, speak one more word and let me hear it." She fainted and writhed in grief, but [][4]she did not manage a single word of reply, and the breath that was faintly passing had already ceased completely.

[9.19.3] Meanwhile, the moon of the spring night declined to the clouds, and the hazy sky grew bright; although she thought her regrets were inexhaustible, since it could not remain so, wrapping [the body] in a remaining suit of armor worn by the late Lord Sanmi to prevent it from floating up, she finally sank it in the sea. The nurse lady-in-waiting, saying she would not be left behind this time, tried to enter following her, but people held her back in various ways, so she could do nothing. Perhaps because there was no way to deal with her overwhelming thoughts, she cut her hair with her own hands, had the late Lord Sanmi's younger brother, Chūnagon Risshi Chūkai, shave her, and weeping and weeping, took the precepts and prayed for her mistress's afterlife. Although it is said there have been many since ancient times who were left behind by men, changing one's appearance is the common custom; to go as far as throwing away one's body is a rare thing. "A loyal subject does not serve two lords; a chaste woman does not see two husbands"; surely one should speak of such a thing.

[9.19.4] This wife was the daughter of Tō-Gyōbu-no-Kyō Norikata, a lady-in-waiting of Jōsaimon-in, the foremost beauty in the court; her name was called Kozaishō-dono. When this lady was sixteen, around the spring of Angen, the Cloistered Empress had a royal outing to view flowers at Hosshōji; Michimori Kyō, who was then still Chūgū-no-Suke, served there; seeing this lady just one glance, he began to think of her lovingly, and from then on her image alone stood pressed against his body, and there was no gap to forget her; he constantly composed poems and exhausted his words in letters lamenting his love, but only the number of letters piled up, and she did not accept them. When it had already been three years, Michimori Kyō wrote a letter saying "This is the limit" and sent it to Kozaishō-dono. Since he did not meet the lady-in-waiting who usually transmitted them, the messenger was returning in vain when, on the road, Kozaishō-dono happened to be going to the Palace from her home; the messenger met her on the road, and frustrated by the intent of returning in vain, ran quickly past the side of her carriage, and threw Michimori's letter inside the blinds of the carriage Kozaishō-dono was riding. When she asked her attendants, they said "We do not know." So when she opened this letter and looked, it was a letter from Michimori Kyō. There was no way to leave it in the carriage. Throwing it on the main street was also [inappropriate], so tucking it into the waist of her hakama, she went to the Palace. Now, while she was serving, there were many places indeed; she dropped the letter in the royal presence. The Cloistered Empress saw this, hurriedly had it picked up, and tucking it into the sleeve of her royal robe, said, "I have found a rare thing. Who is the owner?" The ladies-in-waiting only swore by ten thousand gods and Buddhas, "We do not know." Among them, Kozaishō-dono blushed and could not speak. The Cloistered Empress had known beforehand that it was Michimori Kyō's suit, so when she opened this letter and looked, the scent of the incense smoke was especially intimate, and the strokes of the brush were not ordinary. Saying in detail, "Because your heart is too strong, on the contrary, now I am happy," at the end there was one poem.

lg.l: My love is the round-log bridge of the Hosotani River; trodden over and over, the wet sleeves.

div.p: [9.19.5] The Cloistered Empress said, "This is a letter resenting that you do not meet. When a person's heart is too strong, on the contrary it becomes resentment." In the middle antiquity, there was one called Ono no Komachi; her face and form excelled in the world and her path of emotion was rare, so there was no one who saw her or heard of her who did not pain their liver and soul. However, perhaps because she took the name of having a strong heart, in the end, as the accumulation of people's thoughts, she had no means to prevent the wind, nor work to keep out the rain. Floating the moon and stars that were unclouded in her dwelling upon her tears, picking the young herbs of the fields and the parsley of the marshes, she spent her dew-like life. The Cloistered Empress said, "There should be a reply to this no matter what," and graciously summoned her inkstone and wrote a reply herself.

lg.l: Just rely on it, the round-log bridge of the Hosotani River; though trodden over, would you fall?

div.p: [9.19.6] The thoughts in the breast were revealed in the smoke of Fuji; the tears on the sleeves were the waves of the barrier of Kiyomi. Since looks are the flower of happiness, the Sanmi received this lady-in-waiting, and their mutual intent was not shallow. Thus, to the sky of the journey in the western sea, on the waves, and in the dwelling in the ship, he took her along, and they proceeded on the same path. Kadowaki Chūnagon was left behind by his heir Echizen Sanmi and his youngest son Narimori. As for people he relied on now, there were only Noto-no-Kami Noritsune and the monk Chūnagon Risshi Chūkai. He had looked upon this lady-in-waiting as a memento of the late Lord Sanmi, but since even she had become thus, he became very disheartened.

div.note: [] [4] NKBT reads "ichigon no henji nimo oyobazu" [she did not manage a single word of reply].

div.div:
10. 平家物語卷第十
10.1. The Parading of Heads
[10.1.1] On the seventh day of the Second Month of the third year of Juei, the heads of the Taira clan members killed at Ichinotani in Settsu Province entered the Capital on the twelfth day. The people connected to the Heike lamented together and grieved together, wondering what kind of sorrowful sights they would see regarding their own side. Among them, the wife of Komatsu Sanmi Chūjō Koremori Kyō, who was hiding at Daikakuji, felt especially anxious. Hearing that few of the clan members remained after being killed this time at Ichinotani, and that a single noble called the Sanmi Chūjō had been captured alive and was coming up, she pulled [her robes] over her head and lay down, saying, "That person would not be separated [from the others]." A certain lady-in-waiting came out and said, "The one called Sanmi Chūjō-dono is not that person [your husband]. It is the Hon-Sanmi Chūjō-dono [Shigehira]."
When she said this, [the wife] said, "In that case, surely he is among the heads," and she still did not feel at ease. On the thirteenth day of the same month, Tayū Hōgan Nakayori went out to the Rokujō riverbed and received the heads. Gama no Kaja Noriyori and Kurō Kaja Yoshitsune reported to the Throne that they should be paraded north along the main street of Higashinotōin and hung on the trees of the Prison Gate. The Cloistered Emperor, agonizing over how this matter should be handled, consulted with the Prime Minister, the Ministers of the Left and Right, the Palace Minister, and Horikawa Dainagon Tada-chika Kyō. The five nobles spoke: "Since ancient times, there is no precedent for the heads of those who have ascended to the rank of court noble to be paraded through the main streets. In particular, these people were ministers related by marriage during the time of the former Emperor, and have served the Imperial House for a long time. The petition of Noriyori and Yoshitsune should strictly not be permitted."
Since each spoke in unison, it was decided they should not be paraded, but Noriyori and Yoshitsune reported again: "If we think of the old days of Hōgen, they are the enemies of our grandfather Tameyoshi; if we consider the past of Heiji, they are the enemies of our father Yoshitomo. To soothe the wrath of our Lord, and to wipe away the shame of our father and grandfather, we have cast away our lives and destroyed the enemies of the Court. If the heads of the Taira clan are not paraded through the main streets this time, with what encouragement will we repel bandits from now on?"
Because the two men appealed incessantly, the Cloistered Emperor, being unable to do otherwise, finally had them paraded. The number of spectators was unknown. In the old days when they ranged their sleeves at the Imperial Palace, there were many who feared them. Now that their heads are paraded through the cross-streets, there is no one who does not pity and grieve for them.
[10.1.2] Saitō Go and Saitō Roku, who were attached to Komatsu Sanmi Chūjō Koremori Kyō's young son Rokudai Gozen, out of excessive anxiety, disguised their appearance and looked; although they recognized the heads, the head of Lord Sanmi Chūjō was not visible. However, because it was exceedingly sad and their tears which they could not wrap up were frequent, fearing the eyes of strangers, they hurriedly went to Daikakuji. When the wife asked, "Well, how was it, how was it?", they said, "Among the nobles of Lord Komatsu, only the head of Lord Bitchū-no-Kami was visible. The others were Sonjō, that head, that head."
When they said this, she said, "None of them seem like matters of other people," and she choked with tears. After a while, Saitō Go suppressed his tears and said, "Since we have been in seclusion for these past one or two years, we are not widely recognized by people. Although we should have looked for a while longer, we met a person who knew the information very distinctly, who said: 'The nobles of Lord Komatsu were fortifying Mount Mikusa, which is on the border of Harima and Tanba, in this battle, but they were defeated by Kurō Yoshitsune; Lord Shin-Sanmi Chūjō, Lord Komatsu Shōshō, and Lord Tamba Jijū boarded a ship from Takasago in Harima and crossed to Yashima in Sanuki. I wonder how they became separated. Among the brothers, only Lord Bitchū-no-Kami was slain at Ichinotani.'"
We asked, 'Now, what of the matter of Lord Sanmi Chūjō?' and he said in detail, 'That is because of a serious illness from before the battle, so he crossed to Yashima and did not proceed this time.'"
When he said this, she said, "That too must be because he has become sick from grieving too much about our affairs. On days when the wind blows, I vanish my liver [worry to death] wondering if he is riding a ship today; when they say there is a battle, I exhaust my heart wondering if he is being killed right now. Much less, who would treat such an illness with peace of mind? I wish to hear the details." When she said this, the fact that the young lord and the young lady asked, "Why did you not ask what his illness was?" was truly touching.
[10.1.3] Since the Sanmi Chūjō also had a heart that communicated, thinking, "How anxious they must feel in the Capital; even if I am not among the heads, they will wonder if I drowned in water or died struck by an arrow; surely they will not think I am a person existing in this world. I wish to let them know that my dew-like life still survives," he prepared one samurai and had him go up to the Capital. He wrote three letters. First, in the letter to his wife, "The Capital is full of enemies, and there cannot be a place for you alone; taking the young ones along, how sad you must feel. Although I think to welcome you here and be in one place somehow, whatever may happen to myself, for your sake it is painful," he wrote at length, and at the end there was one poem.
Though it be seaweed of a meeting place unknown to anyone, look upon the traces I leave behind as a memento.
[10.1.4] To the young people, he wrote, "How do you comfort yourselves in your tedium? I will welcome you hurriedly," writing unchanged words and sending them up. Receiving these letters, the messenger went up to the Capital and presented the letter to the wife; upon which she lamented and grieved anew. The messenger waited four or five days and asked to take his leave. The wife wrote her reply weeping and weeping. The young lord and young lady dyed their brushes [with ink] and asked, "Now, what should we say in reply to our father?", so she said, "Just say this and that, whatever you think." "Why have you not welcomed us until now? We long for you exceedingly; please welcome us quickly, quickly," they wrote in the same words; receiving these letters, the messenger returned to Yashima. Lord Sanmi Chūjō, first looking at the letters of the young people, seemed increasingly helpless. "Now, from this, I have no courage to loathe this defiled land. Since the ropes of attachment to the world are strong, I am sluggish in desiring the Pure Land. There is nothing better than to go up to the Capital from here along the mountains, see and be seen by my beloved ones once more, and then commit suicide." Thus he spoke, weeping and weeping.
10.2. The Palace Lady-in-Waiting
[10.2.1] On the same fourteenth day, the captured Hon-Sanmi Chūjō Shigehira Kyō was paraded east along Rokujō. In a small eight-leaf carriage, the front and rear blinds were raised, and the left and right viewing windows were opened. Doi Jirō Sanehira, wearing a hitatare of magnolia cloth and light armor, with over thirty horsemen of attendant soldiers, surrounded the carriage front and rear and guarded him. Seeing this, the high and low of the Capital said to each other, "Ah, how pitiable; what sin's retribution is this? Among the many noble sons, that he should become like this. Since he was a favorite son of both the Lay Priest Lord and the Nii-dono, the people of the clan also considered him important. When he visited the Cloistered Palace or the Imperial Palace, the old and the young gave up their places and treated him with respect. This is surely the punishment of the temples for his destroying the Southern Capital." He was paraded as far as the riverbed, turned back, and placed in the Hachijō Horikawa hall of the late Naka-no-Mikado Tō-Chūnagon Ienari Kyō, where Doi Jirō guarded him. From the Cloistered Emperor's palace, Kurōdo Saemon-no-Gon-no-Suke Sada'naga proceeded to Hachijō Horikawa as a messenger. He wore red robes and carried a sword and scepter. The Sanmi Chūjō wore a hitatare with dark blue shading and a tall eboshi cap upright. Seeing Sada'naga, whom he had thought nothing of in days past, he now felt like the sinners in the netherworld meeting an officer of the dark. The command was given: "If you wish to return to Yashima, send word into the clan and return the Three Sacred Treasures to the Capital. If so, it is the royal intention that you shall be returned to Yashima." The Sanmi Chūjō said, "Surely not a single person of the clan, from the Minister of the Center down, would propose to exchange the Three Sacred Treasures for the life of Shigehira, or a thousand or ten thousand men. If it were a woman, perhaps my mother the Ni-hon, or such, might speak so. Although that is so, since there is a fear in returning the Imperial command immediately while sitting here, I will try sending word." The messengers were Hei-San-Zaemon Shigekuni and the garden attendant Hanakata, it was said. Since private letters were not permitted, he sent word to the people by mouth. To his wife, the Dainagon-no-Suke, he also spoke by word. "Even in the sky of travel, you were my comfort and I was your comfort, but after being pulled apart, how sad you must feel. Since vows do not decay, in the next world we shall certainly be born together." As he sent this message weeping and weeping, Shigekuni also suppressed his tears and stood up.
[10.2.2] Among the samurai employed by the Sanmi Chūjō for years, there was a man called Moku-no-Uma-no-Jō Tomotoki. He was serving at the Hachijō-in; going to Doi Jirō's place, he said, "This is a person called so-and-so who served the Chūjō-dono in previous years; although I thought to accompany him to the western provinces, since I am a person who also serves at the Hachijō-in, I lacked the power and stayed behind; but seeing him on the main street today, I could not bear to look, and felt pity. If it is appropriate, receiving your permission, I would like to approach, enter his presence once more, speak of the past, and comfort him. Since I am not a person who takes up the bow and arrow to any extent, I have not done service in battle or war; I only served him morning and evening. Nevertheless, if you feel suspicious, please take charge of the sword at my waist, and bending the rules, grant me your permission." Since Doi Jirō was a samurai with a heart, he said, "For just you alone, what matter could there be? Nevertheless..." and asking for and taking the sword at his waist, he let him in. The Uma-no-Jō rejoiced extraordinarily, and hurriedly entering and looking, felt that [Shigehira] was truly deep in thought; seeing the state of his appearance, which was very withered, it was difficult for Tomotoki to suppress his tears. The Sanmi Chūjō also saw this, feeling like he was seeing a dream within a dream, and said nothing this or that. There was nothing but weeping. After quite a long time, having spoken of things past and present, he said, "Now, do you hear if the person you communicated with is still at the Palace?" "So I have heard." "When I went down to the western provinces, I did not send a letter, nor did I leave a word; she must think that the vows of many lives were all lies; that is shameful. I think I would send a letter; would you go and look for her?" When he said this, [Tomotoki] said, "Give me the letter and I will go." The Chūjō rejoiced extraordinarily, and immediately wrote it and gave it to him. The guarding warriors said, "What kind of letter is it? We will not let it be sent." When the Chūjō said, "Show it," they showed it. Saying "It should be no trouble," they let him take it. Tomotoki took it and went to the Palace, but since eyes were frequent during the day, he stood in a small hut near that vicinity and waited for the day to end; loitering near the lower entrance of the apartments, he listened; appearing to be this person's voice, [she said,] "Among so many people, that the Sanmi Chūjō should be captured alive and paraded through the main streets! Everyone says it is retribution for the sin of burning Nara. The Chūjō also said so. He said, 'Although I did not burn it intending to in my heart, since there were many evil troops, they set fires here and there and burned away many temple pagodas. Since the dew of the branch becomes the drops of the trunk, it will become the sin of me alone.' And truly I feel it is so." She lamented and wept bitterly. Uma-no-Jō, feeling pity that she thought of him even in this, said, "I speak to you." She asked, "From where?" When he said, "There is a letter from the Sanmi Chūjō-dono," perhaps because of the excess of her suppressed thoughts for the lady-in-waiting who had been shy and not seen for years, she said, "Where, where?", ran out, and took the letter with her own hands and looked at it; the state of being taken from the western provinces, the future of a body that knew not today or tomorrow, he wrote in detail, and at the end there was one poem.
Though I am a body that floats a notorious name on the River of Tears, I wish for one more meeting.
[10.2.3] The lady saw this, and saying nothing this or that, put the letter in her bosom and did nothing but weep. After quite a long time, since it could not remain so, there was a reply. Writing of the heart that had spent two years in pain and gloom,
Though for your sake I too float a notorious name, I would become debris at the bottom with you.
[10.2.4] Tomotoki took it and went. The guarding warriors said again, "We will see it," so he showed it. Saying "It should be no trouble," he presented it. The Sanmi Chūjō saw this, and perhaps his thoughts increased all the more; he said to Doi Jirō, "How would it be if I were to meet once more with the lady-in-waiting I was with for years, as there are things I wish to say?" Sanehira, being a samurai with a heart, said, "Truly, if it is a matter of a lady-in-waiting or such, why should it be trouble?" and permitted it. The Chūjō rejoiced extraordinarily, borrowed a carriage from someone, and sent to welcome her, so the lady-in-waiting, without taking anything, rode in it and came. When they pulled the carriage close to the veranda and announced it, the Chūjō came out to the carriage approach to meet her, and saying, "Since the warriors are watching, do not get down," he pulled up the blinds of the carriage, clasped hand in hand, pressed face to face, and for a while said nothing, but did nothing but weep. After quite a long time, the Chūjō said, "Even when I went down to the western provinces, I wanted to see you once more, but in the general disturbance of the world, there was no opportunity to speak, and I went down. After that, I wanted to somehow send a letter and receive a reply, but in the way of travel that does not follow one's heart, there was no gap in the morning and evening battles, and I spent the months and years in vain. Now seeing my state unknown to others, it was so that I should meet you again." Saying this, he pressed his sleeve to his face and lay face down. The insides of each other's hearts could be guessed and were pitiable. Thus, when the night was half over, saying "These days the main streets are disorderly, so quickly...", he sent her back. As he sent the carriage out, the Chūjō, suppressing tears of parting, weeping and weeping and holding her sleeve,
Meeting and dew-like life together, surely tonight alone is the limit.
[10.2.5] The lady-in-waiting, suppressing tears,
Since we part saying it is the limit, the dew-like body must vanish before you.
[10.2.6] So the lady-in-waiting went to the Palace. After that, since the guarding warriors did not permit it, having no power, only letters passed occasionally. This lady-in-waiting was the daughter of Minbu-no-Kyō Nyūdō Chikannori. Her face and form excelled in the world, and she was a person of deep emotion. Hearing that the Chūjō was taken to the Southern Capital and beheaded, immediately she changed her appearance, withered away in dark black robes, and prayed for his afterlife Bodhi; it was truly moving.
10.3. The Imperial Decree to Yashima
[10.3.1] Meanwhile, Hei-San-Zaemon Shigekuni and the garden attendant Hanakata arrived at Yashima and presented the Imperial Decree. The Minister of the Center and the nobles and courtiers of the clan gathered and opened the Imperial Decree.
The One Sacred Body has left the palace of the Northern Gate and traveled to various provinces; the Three Sacred Treasures are buried in the Four Kingdoms of the Southern Sea, passing several years; this is the utmost grief of the Royal House, the foundation of a ruined country. Now, that Shigehira Kyō is a rebellious subject who burned Tōdaiji. By rights, according to the request of Ason Yoritomo, he should be executed, but separating him alone from his kin, he has already been captured alive. The caged bird longs for the clouds; floating far in the Southern Sea of a thousand li, the returning goose loses its mate; surely his heart communicates halfway to the Ninefold Enclosure. If you return the Three Sacred Treasures, that Minister shall be pardoned; the Imperial Decree is thus. Thus communicated as above. Fourteenth day of the Second Month of the third year of Juei. Presented by Daizen-no-Daibu Naritada Presented to the Taira Dainagon-dono
[10.3.2] Thus it was written.
10.4. The Written Reply
[10.4.1] The Lord Minister spoke the gist of the Imperial Decree to Taira Dainagon. To the Nii-dono, he wrote a letter in detail and sent it. "If you think to see me once more, speak well to the Lord Minister about the matter of the Sacred Mirror. If not, I do not feel I will be able to enter your presence in this world."
Thus it was written. The Nii-dono saw this, and saying nothing this or that, put the letter in her bosom and lay face down. It was guessed that in her heart she truly felt so, and it was pitiable. Meanwhile, beginning with Taira Dainagon Tokitada Kyō, the nobles and courtiers of the Taira clan gathered and discussed the gist of the written reply.
