The Nii-dono, pressing the Chūjō's letter to her face, slid open the shoji behind where the people were sitting in rows, fell down before the Lord Minister, and weeping and weeping said, "The wretchedness of what that Chūjō has sent from the Capital! Indeed, what kind of things must he be thinking in his heart? Just out of pity for me, return the Sacred Mirror to the Capital." The Lord Minister said, "Truly Munemori also feels so, but even so, the reputation in the world would be worthless. Moreover, since what Yoritomo would think is shameful, returning the Sacred Mirror immediately is impossible. Furthermore, the preservation of the Imperial reign is solely due to the Sacred Mirror. The sadness for a child depends on the situation. Should we exchange the Emperor and all the close family members for the Chūjō alone?"
When he said this, the Nii-dono spoke again: "After being left behind by the late Lay Priest, I did not think I should live for even a moment, but because of the pain of the Sovereign traveling like this without a fixed time, and thinking I would let the Lord be in his reign, I have survived until now. After hearing that the Chūjō was captured alive at Ichinotani, my liver and soul do not accompany my body, and although I think somehow to meet him once more in this world, since he does not appear even in dreams, my chest is blocked all the more and I cannot let hot water or water pass my throat. Now, after seeing this letter, I have no way to divert my thoughts. If I hear that the Chūjō is no more in the world, I intend to proceed on the same path. Before you make me feel things again, just kill me."
Because she screamed and shouted, feeling that truly she must think so and it was touching, the people shed tears and all cast their eyes down. In the opinion of New Chūnagon Tomomori, he said, "Even if we return the Three Sacred Treasures to the Capital, it is unlikely they will return Shigehira. We should just state the situation without hesitation in the written reply."
The Lord Minister said, "This view is most appropriate," and stated the written reply. The Nii-dono wrote a reply to the Chūjō weeping and weeping, and although she was blinded by tears and did not know where the brush stood, making her intent her guide, she wrote a letter in detail and gave it to Shigekuni. The wife, Dainagon-no-Suke-dono, did nothing but weep, and did not make a reply at all. It was guessed that in her heart she must truly feel so, and it was touching. Shigekuni also, wringing the sleeves of his hunting robe, departed the presence weeping and weeping. Taira Dainagon Tokitada summoned the garden attendant Hanakata: "Are you Hanakata?" "I am." "Since you have come this far as the Cloistered Emperor's messenger, braving many wave-paths, you should have one memory of a lifetime." Saying this, he branded the mark "Namikata" [Wave-person] on Hanakata's face. When he went up to the Capital, the Cloistered Emperor saw this and laughed, saying, "Well, well, it can't be helped; call him Namikata."
The Imperial Decree of the fourteenth day of this month arrived at the coast of Yashima in Sanuki Province on the twenty-eighth day of the same, and we have respectfully received it as above. However, considering the matter based on this, Tsunemori Kyō and others, several members of this house, have already been executed at Ichinotani in Sesshū. Why should we rejoice at the pardon of Shigehira alone? Now, our Lord received the abdication of the late Takakura-in, and his reign has already been four years; when we inquire into the ancient customs of Yao and Shun, because the eastern barbarians and northern savages have formed parties and entered the Capital in droves, and the grief of the young Emperor and the Empress Mother is extremely deep, and the resentment of the maternal relatives and close retainers is not shallow, he has traveled to the Nine Provinces for a time. If there is no return, how should the Three Sacred Treasures leave the Jewel Body [the Emperor]? Now, the subject takes the Lord as his heart, and the Lord takes the subject as his body. If the Lord is peaceful then the subject is peaceful; if the subject is peaceful then the country is peaceful. If the Lord grieves above, the subject does not enjoy below. If one grieves in the heart, there is no joy outside the body. Since our ancestor Taira General Sadamori pursued and chastised Sōma Kojirō Masakado, we have pacified the eight eastern provinces, transmitted it to sons and grandsons, punished the plotting subjects who are enemies of the Court, and down to generation after generation, have protected the sacred fortune of the Imperial House. Thus, when my deceased father, the late Prime Minister, was in the battles of Hōgen and Heiji, he weighted the Imperial command heavy and slighted his private life. It was solely for the Lord, and not for himself. In particular, that Yoritomo, in the twelfth month of the first year of Heiji past, due to the rebellion of his father Sama-no-Kami Yoshitomo, although the order was given that he should be repeatedly punished, was the one whom the late Lay Priest Prime Minister out of excess of mercy interceded for and pardoned. However, forgetting the vast favor of the past and possessing no fragrant [grateful] intent, suddenly with a wolf's body he disorderly raises a rebellion like bees; that his utmost stupidity is extreme is needless to say. Is he one who quickly invites the heavenly punishment of the gods, and secretly expects the destruction of defeat? Now, the sun and moon do not dim their brightness for the sake of one thing. An enlightened king does not bend his laws for the sake of one person. Do not discard his good because of one evil; do not cover his merit because of a small flaw. Moreover, if you do not forget the service of this house for several generations, and the repeated loyalty of my deceased father, perhaps the Lord would graciously make a royal visit to Shikoku. At that time, we subjects will receive the Imperial Decree, return again to the old capital, and wipe away the shame of Kaikei. If not so, we shall go to Kikai, Koryo, India, or China. How sad. In the reign of the eighty-first human king, shall the spirit treasures of the Age of Gods of our court finally become the treasures of a foreign country in vain? You should convey these points and report them to the Throne in an appropriate manner. Munemori truly in awe, bowing head, speaks respectfully. Twenty-eighth day of the Second Month of the third year of Juei. Written by Junior First Rank Taira Ason Munemori
[10.4.2] Thus it was written.
10.5. The Precepts
[10.5.1] The Sanmi Chūjō heard this and regretted, "Surely it must be so. How badly the people of the clan must have thought of me," but it was in vain. Indeed, since he did not feel that they would return the Three Sacred Treasures, the heavy treasures of our court, regretting the loss of Shigehira Kyō alone, he had anticipated the gist of this written reply from beforehand; but while the situation was not yet stated, he felt gloomy without specific reason; now that the reply had arrived and it was decided that he would be sent down to the Kanto, all his reliance weakened completely, he felt helpless in all things, and he felt the regret of leaving the Capital anew. The Sanmi Chūjō summoned Doi Jirō and said, "I think I would like to become a monk; how would that be?" Sanehira reported this to the Noble Scion Kurō. When it was reported to the Cloistered Palace, he said, "After showing him to Yoritomo, we will arrange this and that. How can we permit it right now?" So he reported this reason. "In that case, I think I would like to meet once more with a holy man I have pledged with for years, and discuss matters of the afterlife; how would that be?" he asked. "Who is the holy man?" "He is a person called Hōnen-bō of Kurodani." "In that case, it should be no trouble." And he permitted it. The Chūjō rejoiced extraordinarily, invited the holy man, and weeping and weeping said, "That I was captured alive this time was so that I should enter the Shōnin's presence again. Now, how should Shigehira fare in the afterlife? While I was myself, I was distracted by service, fettered by administration, and only deepened my heart of arrogance, conversely not looking back at the rise and fall of the future. Much less, since luck ran out and the world became disordered, fighting here, disputing there, only the evil heart of thinking to destroy others and save myself blocked me, and a good heart never arose. In particular, regarding the matter of the burning of the Southern Capital, whether called the King's command or military command, since the law of serving the Lord and following the world is hard to escape, I proceeded there to quiet the evil deeds of the monks, and it came to the accidental destruction of the temples; although it was a sequence of events beyond my power, since it is said that the blame returns to the one person who was the great general at the time, I feel it must become the sinful karma of Shigehira alone. Moreover, that I thus expose my shame here and there unbeknownst to others, I realize is solely the retribution for that. Now I wish to shave my head, keep the precepts, and earnestly practice the Buddha way, but since I have become such a body, I cannot leave my heart to my heart. Since it is a future where I know not today or tomorrow, no matter what practice I perform, it is regrettable that I do not feel I can be saved by a single action. Considering the transformed acts of my whole life, my sinful karma is higher than Mount Sumeru, and I have not stored up even a speck of dust of good karma. If my life ends in vain like this, the bitter fruit of the Fire, Blood, and Sword is not to be doubted. I pray that the Shōnin, giving rise to mercy and bestowing pity, if there is a method by which such an evil person can be saved, show it to me." At that time, the Shōnin choked with tears and for a while did not speak. After quite a long time, he said, "That receiving a human body which is truly hard to receive, you should return in vain to the Three Paths, though one grieves, there is still more grief. However, that now you loathe the defiled land and desire the Pure Land, discarding the evil heart and giving rise to the good heart, the Buddhas of the three worlds surely rejoice. Regarding that, although the paths of leaving [suffering] are various, for the capacities of the disorderly time of the Latter Law, the recitation of the Name is considered superior. Dividing the intent into nine grades, and shrinking the practice into six characters, it is convenient for any foolish and dull person to chant. Do not humble yourself because your sins are deep. Those of the Ten Evils and Five Grave Offenses achieve birth in the Pure Land if they turn their hearts. Do not cut off hope because your merit is small. If you exert a heart of one thought or ten thoughts, He will come to welcome you. Explaining 'Solely praising the Name goes to the West,' if you solely praise the Name, you go to the West. Preaching 'Thought by thought calling the Name is constant repentance,' he taught that if you chant Amida thought by thought, it is repenting. If you rely on 'The sharp sword is this name of Amida,' demons will not approach. If you keep in mind 'One voice of chanting removes all sins,' it is seen that sins are all removed. The ultimate of the Pure Land sect contains various details, but in general this is the essential. However, the attainment or non-attainment of birth depends on the presence or absence of faith. Just believe deeply and do not produce doubt in the least. If you believe deeply in this teaching, and without disliking time, place, or various conditions of walking, standing, sitting, or lying, and without forgetting the heart's thought and mouth's chanting in the Three Actions and Four Dignities, make the end of your life the term, leave the realm of this suffering region, and are born in that Land of No Retrogression, what doubt can there be?" Because he taught thus, the Chūjō rejoiced extraordinarily and said, "Next, I think I would like to keep the precepts; is it impossible without becoming a monk?" He replied, "It is the common custom of the world that even people who do not become monks keep the precepts." Making a gesture of applying a razor to his forehead and shaving, he administered the Ten Precepts, so the Chūjō shed tears of joy and received and kept them. The Shōnin also felt everything was moving, and feeling his eyes go dark, preached the precepts weeping and weeping. Appearing to be an offering, he had Tomotoki summon an inkstone that had been left with a samurai who had come constantly to play in years past, and presented it to the Shōnin, saying weeping and weeping, "Please do not give this to others; placing it in a place where your eyes will constantly fall, thinking 'This is his thing,' please perform the Nembutsu equating it with me every time you see it. In your spare time, if you would perform a transfer of merit of even one scroll of sutra, it would be appropriate." The Shōnin did not manage a reply of this or that, but taking it and putting it in his bosom, wringing his black-dyed sleeves, he returned weeping and weeping. This inkstone was one that his father, the Lay Priest Prime Minister, had presented much gold dust to the Emperor of the Song Dynasty, and appearing to be a return gift, was sent to 'Taira Great Minister of Wada in Japan,' it was said. The name was called Matsukage [Pine Shade].
10.6. Down the Coastal Road
[10.6.1] In the meantime, because the Former Captain of the Guards of Kamakura, Yoritomo, had spoken incessantly regarding the Hon-Sanmi Chūjō, saying "Then send him down," he was handed over from the hands of Doi Jirō Sanehira to the lodging of the Noble Scion Kurō. On the tenth day of the Third Month of the same year, accompanied by Kajiwara Heizō Kagetoki, he was sent down to Kamakura. Having been captured alive in the western provinces, even returning to the Capital was mortifying; now that he was proceeding toward the East of the Barrier, the inside of his heart could be guessed and was pitiable. When he reached the Shinomiya riverbed, he recalled how in the past, Semimaru, the fourth prince of Engi, cleared his heart in the storm of the Barrier and played the biwa here; and how the person called Hakuga-no-Sanmi walked here for three years—on days when the wind blew and days it did not, on nights when rain fell and nights it did not—and stood listening, finally inheriting the three melodies; imagining the old times of the straw hut's floor, it was moving. Crossing over Mount Ausaka, letting the horses trample the Karasaki Bridge of Seta with a roar, passing the village of Noji where skylarks rose, the waves of the bay of Shiga hung with spring, Mirror Mountain clouded in mist; putting the high peak of Hira to the north, the bulk of Ibuki approached. Although he did not intend to stop his heart there, what was rough yet on the contrary graceful were the wooden eaves of the guardhouse at the Fuwa Barrier; how the tide-dried flats of Narumi were; as his sleeves withered with tears, he reached Yatsuhashi in Mikawa Province, where that certain Ariwara composed "wearing a Chinese robe, I have become accustomed [to the journey]," and the spider-leg [branching] path was moving. As he crossed the bridge of Hamana, the wind was clear in the treetops of the pines, and the sound of waves clamoring in the inlet; even otherwise travel is melancholy, but in the twilight that exhausts the heart, he arrived at the station of Ikeda. That night he was lodged with Jijū, the daughter of the bathhouse owner of the station headman. Jijū, seeing the Sanmi Chūjō, said, "In the past, I did not think of it even in tradition, but the wonder of your entering such a place today," and she presented a poem.
In the sky of travel, in the gloom of a clay-walled hut, how you must long for your old home.
[10.6.2] In the Sanmi Chūjō's reply:
I do not even long for my old home in this sky of travel; for the Capital is not my final dwelling place.
[10.6.3] The Chūjō said, "She has done this gracefully. What kind of person is the owner of this poem?" When he asked this, Kagetoki spoke with awe: "Does my lord not know her even now? That is the one whom the Great Minister of Yashima, when he was Governor of this province, summoned and made his most beloved; she kept her old mother here and asked incessantly for leave, but since he did not grant it, around the beginning of the Third Month:
What shall I do? Though the spring of the Capital is regrettable, the familiar flowers of the East must be scattering.
[10.6.4] Composing this, she was granted leave and went down; she is the most famous person on the Coastal Road."
Thus he spoke.
[10.6.5] As days passed since leaving the Capital, the Third Month was half over, and spring was already about to end. The blossoms on the distant mountains looked like lingering snow; the bays and islands were covered in mist; as he continued to think of things past and future, saying "Then, what kind of wretchedness of karma is this?", the only thing that was not exhausted was tears. That he had not a single child, his mother the Nii-dono lamented, and his wife the Dainagon-no-Suke considered it a regrettable thing, and they prayed to ten thousand gods and Buddhas, but there was no effect. "It was well that there were none. If there were even a child, how painful it would be," he said; this was a forced matter. Even when hanging upon Saya-no-Nakayama [Mount Saya-in-the-Middle], since he did not feel he would cross it again [alive], the number of sorrows increased and his sleeves were severely soaked. Crossing helplessly over the ivy-covered path of Mount Utsu, and passing Tegoshi, there was a snow-white mountain far away to the north. When he asked, they said it was Shirane of Kai. At that time, the Sanmi Chūjō suppressed his falling tears and continued his thoughts thus:
Though it is a life I do not regret, until today I have seen the white peak of Kai with a strong face.
[10.6.6] Passing the Barrier of Kiyomi, when they came to the skirts of Fuji, to the north the blue mountains were jagged and the wind blowing the pines was whistling. To the south the blue sea was vast and the waves striking the shore were boundless. Crossing Mount Ashigara, where the bright god marked the poem "If you love, you should love; even if you do not love, it is so," passing the forest of Koyurugi, the Mariko River, Koiso, the bay of Ōiso, Yatsumato, Togami-ga-hara, and Mikoshi-ga-saki; although he thought it a journey he did not hurry, as the days piled up, he entered Kamakura.
Shutterstock
10.7. Senju-no-mae
[10.7.1] The Captain of the Guards [Yoritomo] hurriedly met him and said, "Now, since I resolved to soothe the wrath of our Lord and wipe away the shame of my father, destroying the Heike was within my expectations, but I did not think that you would properly enter my presence. In this manner, I feel as if the Great Minister of Yashima has entered my presence. Now, regarding the destruction of the Southern Capital, was it the command of the late Lay Priest Prime Minister? Or was it your own plan at the time? It is truly an extraordinary sinful deed."
When he said this, the Sanmi Chūjō said, "First, the matter of the burning of the Southern Capital was not the order of the late Lay Priest, nor was it the initiation of Shigehira's foolish mind. While I proceeded there to quiet the evil deeds of the monks, that it came to the accidental destruction of the temples was a sequence of events beyond my power. In the past, the Genji and Heike disputed left and right and were the guardians of the Imperial House, but the fact that the fortune of the Genji declined in recent years is not something I should speak of now as new. This house has pacified enemies of the court repeatedly since Hōgen and Heiji; the rewards were more than we deserved, and graciously being the maternal relatives of the Lord of the whole heaven, the promotions of the clan numbered over sixty men; for the last twenty years and more, there was nothing but enjoyment and glory. Now again, our luck has run out, and Shigehira has been captured and come down as far as here. Regarding that, the saying that for one who kills an enemy of the Emperor, the imperial favor will not be exhausted for seven generations, was an utter falsehood. Before our eyes, the late Lay Priest Lord was about to lose his life for the sake of the Lord on repeated occasions. However, with merely the luck of his one generation, should his descendants become like this? Thus, after our luck ran out and we left the Capital, I thought I would expose my corpse in the mountains and fields and flow my name on the waves of the western sea, but I did not think even in the least that I would come down as far as here. I only regret the karma of my previous lives. However, there is a text saying that Tang of Shang was imprisoned at Xiatai and King Wen was imprisoned at Youli. It was like this even in ancient times. Much more so in the latter age. The custom of taking up the bow and arrow is that losing one's life at the hands of an enemy is absolutely not a shame. Only, for your kindness, please cut off my head quickly."
Saying this, he spoke nothing after that. Kagetoki heard this and shed tears, saying, "Ah, a great general." The people sitting in rows in that seat all wet their sleeves. The Captain of the Guards also said, "I absolutely do not think of the Heike specially as my private enemies. Only the command of the Emperor is heavy." Saying, "Since he is the enemy of the great temples who destroyed the Southern Capital, the monks will surely have claims," he was entrusted to the resident of Izu Province, Kanō-no-Suke Muneshige. That state, like a sinner of the Saha world being handed over to the hands of the Ten Kings every seven days in the netherworld, seemed like this and was moving.
[10.7.2] However, Kanō-no-Suke was a man of feeling, so he did not treat him very severely; he treated him kindly in various ways, prepared a bathroom, and had him take a bath. Since the sweat from the road was unpleasant, he thought he would purify his body and be done with it; a lady-in-waiting of about twenty years of age, white-skinned and clean, truly graceful and beautiful, wearing a robe with a tie-dye pattern and a dyed bath-wrap, pushed open the door of the bathroom and entered. Again after a while, a girl of about fourteen or fifteen, wearing a robe with small dark shading and hair reaching the floor, entered carrying a comb in a handled washbasin. With this lady-in-waiting assisting, he bathed for quite a long time, washed his hair, and got out. Then, that lady-in-waiting took her leave and was returning; "If it were a man, you might think it boorish. Thinking that a woman would be less painful, I have been sent. Lord Captain of the Guards commanded, 'Whatever you may desire, ask and speak of it.'"
The Chūjō said, "Now that I have become a body like this, what should I say? The only thing I desire is to become a monk."
When he said this, she returned and reported this reason. The Captain of the Guards said, "That is unthinkable. If he were Yoritomo's private enemy, perhaps. He is a person I have received as an enemy of the Court. It absolutely cannot be."
Thus he spoke. The Sanmi Chūjō said to the guarding warrior, "Now, the lady-in-waiting just now was a graceful person. What is her name?" When he asked this, [the warrior] said, "She is the daughter of the headman of Tegoshi; saying her face and form and heart are gracefully touching, she has been employed for these two or three years; her name is called Senju-no-mae."
Thus he spoke.
[10.7.3] That evening rain fell a little and all things were lonely; the said lady-in-waiting entered having [servants] carry a biwa and a koto.
Kanō-no-Suke recommended sake and served it. He himself brought along ten or more house-men and retainers and sat near the presence. Senju-no-mae poured the sake. The Chūjō accepted a little, and seemed most unamused; Kanō-no-Suke said, "Perhaps you have heard it. Since the Lord of Kamakura commanded, 'Make sure to comfort him well. Do not be negligent and have Yoritomo resented,' and Muneshige is a person of Izu Province, although in Kamakura I am on a journey, I shall serve you to the extent my heart can reach. Whatever it may be, speak and recommend it to him."
When he said this, Senju put down the sake cup and recited the Rōei line "Assuming the heavy robes of silk damask, she resents the heartlessness in the weaver woman" once or twice; the Sanmi Chūjō said, "Kitano Tenjin has vowed to fly three times a day to protect the person who recites this Rōei. However, Shigehira has been abandoned in this world. What is the use even if I join in? If it is something that might lighten my sins, I shall follow." When he said this, Senju-no-mae immediately recited the Rōei "Though called the Ten Evils, He welcomes and receives," and sang clearly the Imayō "Those who desire the Pure Land should all chant the Name of Amida" four or five times, so at that time he tilted the cup. Senju-no-mae received it and offered it to Kanō-no-Suke. When Muneshige drank, she played the koto clearly. The Sanmi Chūjō said, "Although this music is normally called the Five Constant Pleasures, for Shigehira it should be viewed as the Pleasure of the Afterlife." Saying he would play the 'Hurry for Rebirth' [Ōjō-no-kyū], he playfully took the biwa, tuned it to the rank-mode [ōshiki-chō], and played the 'Royal Palace Hurry' [Ōjō-no-kyū]. As the night gradually deepened and his heart cleared in all things, he said, "Oh, unexpected; that there was such a graceful person even in the East. Whatever it may be, one more voice." When he said this, Senju-no-mae again sang the Shirabyōshi song "Sheltering together in the shade of one tree, or scooping from the same stream, all these are the karma of former lives," counting the rhythm truly interestingly and clearly, so the Chūjō also recited the Rōei "The lamp goes dark, counting the lines of Lady Yu's tears." For example, the meaning of this Rōei is: in the past in China, Han Gaozu and Xiang Yu of Chu disputed the throne and fought seventy-two times; every battle Xiang Yu won. However, in the end, when Xiang Yu lost a battle and was destroyed, he intended to ride a horse called Zhui that flew a thousand li in a day and flee together with his empress called Lady Yu, but whatever the horse thought, it planted its feet and did not move. Xiang Yu shed tears and lamented and grieved all night, saying, "My power has already failed. Now there is no direction to flee. The enemy's attack is not a matter of concern; the sadness is parting from this Empress." The lamp grew dark and Lady Yu shed tears in helplessness. As the night deepened, the soldiers raised the war cry on four sides. Perhaps recalling how Minister Tachibana made this sentiment into a poem, the Sanmi Chūjō sounded most graceful.
[10.7.4] In the meantime, as the night broke, the warriors took their leave and went out. Senju-no-mae also returned. That morning, when Lord Captain of the Guards happened to be reading the Lotus Sutra in his Buddha hall, Senju-no-mae arrived. Lord Captain of the Guards smiled and said, "Senju certainly acted as an interesting go-between." The Assistant of the Saiin, Chikayoshi, who happened to be writing something in his presence, asked, "What matter was it?" "I had thought for days that those people of the Heike had no other business outside of armor and bows and arrows, but standing and listening all night to the sound of this Sanmi Chūjō's biwa pick and his humming, he is a gracefully touching person." Chikayoshi said, "Everyone should have listened last night, but I happened to be ill and did not listen. After this I shall constantly stand and listen. The Heike have originally been poets and talented men for generations. In past years when likening these people to flowers, this Sanmi Chūjō-dono was likened to the peony flower." When he said this, [Yoritomo] said, "Truly he was a graceful person," and "The manner of the sound of the biwa pick and the Rōei is a rare thing even for the future." Perhaps it became a seed of longing for Senju-no-mae on the contrary. Thus, hearing that the Chūjō was taken to the Southern Capital and beheaded, immediately she changed her appearance, withered away in dark black robes, went to Zenkōji in Shinano Province to pray, mourned his afterlife Bodhi, and it is rumored that she herself also achieved the long-cherished desire for rebirth [in the Pure Land]. 10.8. Yokobue
[10.8.1] In the meantime, although Komatsu Sanmi Chūjō Koremori Kyō was physically in Yashima, his heart traveled to the Capital. Since only the images of his wife and young people whom he had left in his old home stood beside him, and there was no gap to forget them, saying, "I am a body without worth to exist," at dawn on the fifteenth day of the Third Month of the third year of Juei, stealing out of the mansion at Yashima in disguise, he took along three people: Yosabyōe Shigekage, a page boy called Ishidō-maru, and a servant called Takisato because he understood boats; boarding a small boat from the coast of Yūki in Awa Province, rowing through the Naruto Strait, he headed for the Kii route. Passing Waka, Fukiage, and the deity of Tamatsushima who appeared as Sotōri-hime, and the shrine of Hinokuma-Kunikakasu, he arrived at the harbor of Kii. From there, although he thought to go up to the Capital along the mountains and see his beloved people once more if he could see them, saying, "It is mortifying enough that Hon-Sanmi Chūjō was captured alive and paraded through the main streets, exposing his shame in the Capital and Kamakura; that this body too should be imprisoned and spill blood on my father's corpse is wretched," though his heart urged him a thousand times, contending heart against heart, he proceeded to the honorable mountain of Kōya.
[10.8.2] At Kōya there was a holy man whom he had known for years. He was the son of Saitō Saemon Moreyori of Sanjō, a person called Saitō Takiguchi Tokiyori. Originally he was a samurai of the Komatsu Lord. When he was serving at the palace at the age of thirteen, there was a woman called Yokobue [Transverse Flute], a servant of Kenreimon-in. Takiguchi loved her most. His father heard this and strongly admonished him, saying, "I intend to make you the son-in-law of a worthy person and have you serve comfortably; why have you begun to think of a worthless person?" Takiguchi said, "The person known as Xi Wangmu existed in the past but is not here now. The one called Dongfang Shuo also, I only hear his name but do not see him with my eyes. The world where old and young are uncertain is no different from the flash of a flint; even if a person has long life, he does not pass seventy or eighty; within that, the time of physical prime is merely some twenty years. In a dream-illusion world, what is the use of seeing an ugly person even for a moment? If I try to see a desirable person, it resembles disobeying my father's command. This is a Good Friend [spiritual guide]. Nothing is better than to loathe the floating world and enter the true path." So saying, at the age of nineteen he cut his topknot and dwelt at the Ōjō-in in Saga, practicing earnestly. Yokobue heard this and thought, "Though he may abandon me, how resentful that he even changed his appearance [became a monk]. Even if he turns his back on the world, why did he not let me know? Though his heart may be strong, I will seek him out and express my resentment." Thinking thus, she left the Capital one evening and wandered toward Saga. Since it was after the tenth of the Second Month, the scent of unrelated things was nostalgic in the spring wind of the village of Umezu, and the moonlight on the Ōi River was also hazy, enclosed in mist. She must have wondered for whose sake was this extraordinary sadness. Although she heard it was Ōjō-in, since she did not know clearly which hut it was, resting here and loitering there, her [][2]searching was pitiful. There was the sound of recitation in a dilapidated monk's hut. Hearing it as the voice of Takiguchi Nyūdō, she sent word via a woman she had brought along, saying, "I have come searching this far. I wish to see his changed appearance just once more." Takiguchi Nyūdō's heart pounded, and looking through a gap in the shoji, seeing her truly travel-weary appearance felt painful, and any person of the Way would have become weak-hearted. Immediately he sent someone out, saying, "There is absolutely no such person here. You must have the wrong gate." And in the end he turned her away without meeting her. Yokobue felt heartless and resentful, but being powerless, she suppressed her tears and returned. Takiguchi Nyūdō met with a fellow monk and said, "This place is quiet and there are no obstacles to the Nembutsu, but since I have shown this dwelling to a woman I parted from without satisfaction, even if my heart is strong once, if she yearns for me again, my heart will be moved. I take my leave." Leaving Saga, he went up to Kōya and lived at the Shōjōshin-in. Hearing that Yokobue had also changed her appearance [become a nun], Takiguchi Nyūdō sent one poem.
Though I resented it until I shaved my head; how happy to enter the true path of the birch-wood bow.
[10.8.3] In Yokobue's reply:
Even if you shaved your head, why should you resent it? It is not a heart that should pull back the birch-wood bow.
[10.8.4] Yokobue was at Hokkeji in Nara, perhaps due to the accumulation of her thoughts, but before long, she finally passed away. Takiguchi Nyūdō heard this conveyed, and since he lived clearing his practice even more deeply, his father also forgave his unfilial conduct. Close friends and all employed him, calling him the Saint of Kōya.
[10.8.5] When the Sanmi Chūjō sought him out and saw him, when he was in the Capital, he was a flamboyant samurai, arranging his dress folds and stroking his sidelocks in hunting robes and tall eboshi cap. Seeing him today for the first time after he became a monk, although he was not yet thirty, he was thin and emaciated in the guise of an old monk, wearing dark black robes and a similar stole; a person of the Way who had put his thoughts into it, he seemed enviable. The appearance of the Seven Sages of Jin or the Four Hoaryheads of Han dwelling in the bamboo grove of Shangshan did not seem to surpass this. [] [2] NKBT reads "tazune kanuru zo" [unable to find].
10.9. The Chapter on Kōya
[10.9.1] Takiguchi Nyūdō, seeing the Sanmi Chūjō, said, "This is a person who does not seem like reality. How have you escaped from Yashima to here?"
When he said this, the Sanmi Chūjō said, "It is thus: like ordinary people, I left the Capital and fled down to the western provinces, but since I did not feel I could ever forget the longing for the young ones I left in my old home, and perhaps my thoughtful appearance seemed conspicuous without saying anything, the Lord Minister and the Nii-dono also kept their distance thinking this person has two hearts like Ike-no-Dainagon; thinking 'I am a body without worth to exist,' I became more and more unsettled, wandered out, and escaped this far. Although I thought to somehow go up to the Capital along the mountains and see my beloved ones once more if I could see them, since the matter of Hon-Sanmi Chūjō was mortifying, that too is impossible. I think I would rather become a monk here and enter the fire or the bottom of the water. However, I have a long-cherished desire to visit Kumano."
When he said this, [Takiguchi] said, "The dream-illusion world will be as it will be. The darkness of the long night [after death] must be wretched."
Thus he spoke. Immediately Takiguchi Nyūdō acted as guide, and they made a pilgrimage to the halls and pagodas, and visited the Inner Sanctuary (Okunoin).
[10.9.2] Mount Kōya is two hundred li from the Imperial Castle, far from the Capital and villages, without human voices; the mountain air rings in the treetops, and the shadows of the setting sun are quiet. The eight-leaf peaks and eight valleys; truly the heart must become clear. The colors of flowers burst at the bottom of the forest mist, and the sound of bells echoes in the clouds of the peaks. Pines grow on the tiles, moss covers the walls, and the stars and frost [years] seem long. Now, in the time of the Engi Emperor, there was a revelation in a dream, and he presented a robe of cypress-bark color; the Imperial Messenger Chūnagon Sukezumi Kyō, accompanied by the Hannyaji Sōjō Kangen, came to this mountain, opened the doors of the mausoleum, and was about to dress him in the robe, but a thick mist separated them and the Great Teacher [Kōbō Daishi] could not be seen. Here Kangen shed tears of deep grief, and said, "Since I left my compassionate mother's womb and entered my master's room, I have never violated the prohibitions. So why should I not see him?" And casting his five limbs to the ground, he confessed and wept, so the mist gradually cleared, and like the moon emerging, the Great Teacher was seen. At that time Kangen shed tears of joy and dressed him in the robe. Since his hair had grown long, that he shaved it was auspicious. Although the Imperial Messenger and the Sōjō saw and worshipped him, the Sōjō's disciple, the Naigu of Ishiyama, Junyū, was serving then as a child, and he lamented and was depressed because he did not see the Great Teacher; so the Sōjō took his hand and pressed it against the Great Teacher's knee, and that hand was fragrant for his whole life, it is said. I hear that the transferred fragrance was transferred to the scriptures of Ishiyama and exists even now. In his reply to the Emperor, the Great Teacher said, "In the past I met Sattva [Vajrasattva] and received all the mudras and mantras face to face. Uttering a peerless vow, I wait in a foreign land of the border region. Day and night pitying the ten thousand people, I dwell in the compassionate vow of Fugen. Manifesting Samadhi in the fleshly body, I wait for the descent/birth of Jishi [Maitreya]."
Thus he spoke. That Mahākāśyapa is enclosed in the cave of Cock's Foot and waits for the wind of the Shizu spring seems like this too. Since his entry into eternal meditation was at the first point of the Hour of the Tiger on the twenty-first day of the Third Month of the second year of Jōwa, the past is over three hundred years; waiting for the dawn of the three assemblies of the Compassionate Lord's appearance in the world after five billion six hundred seventy million years in the future is indeed long.
10.10. Koremori Becomes a Monk
[10.10.1] "Thinking 'today, tomorrow' regarding the uncertainty of Koremori's body, like the crying of the bird of the Snow Mountains..." saying this, he became tearful, which was touching. Blackened by the salt breeze, thin and emaciated from inexhaustible thoughts, although he did not look like that person, still he excelled the people of the world. That night he returned to Takiguchi Nyūdō's hermitage and spoke of things past and present all night. When he looked at the holy man's conduct, on the platform of ultimate depth, it seemed he was polishing the jewel of truth; and the sound of the bell in the late night and early morning seemed to wake one from the sleep of birth and death. If he could escape, he must have wished to be like this. When it dawned, he invited a holy man called Chikaku Shōnin of Tōzen-in and was about to become a monk; summoning Yosabyōe and Ishidō-maru, he said, "Although Koremori has inescapable thoughts accompanying his body, since I am a body difficult to escape on a narrow path, even if I pass away in vain, there are many people in the world these days. Why should you not survive in whatever manner? See through my end whatever it may be, then hurry up to the Capital, save your own bodies, raise your wives and children, and also pray for Koremori's afterlife."
When he said this, the two men wept bitterly and for a while could not answer; after a while Yosabyōe suppressed his tears and said, "Shigekage's father Yosa-Zaemon Kageyasu was in the service of the late Lord during the rebellion of Heiji, but he grappled with Kamada Hyōe near Nijō Horikawa and was killed by Aku-Genta. Why should Shigekage be inferior? At that time I was not yet two years old, so I do not remember it at all. I was left behind by my mother at seven. Although there was not a single close relative to pity me, the late Great Minister said, 'That is the child of a person who exchanged his life for mine,' and raised me in his presence; when I was said to be nine years of age, on the night of my lord's coming of age, he took up my hair and graciously said, 'The character Mori is the character of the house, so it attaches to five generations. The character Shige to Matsuō [Pine King].' So saying, he named me Shigekage. Moreover, regarding my childhood name being called Matsuō, when my father held me and presented me at the celebration of the fiftieth day after birth, saying 'Since this house is called Komatsu [Small Pine], I name him in celebration,' he named me Matsuō. That my father died instead [of the lord] I consider my own divine blessing. I have lived receiving favor even from my fellow retainers. Thus, even at the time of his end, although he discarded the matters of this world and did not speak a single thing, he summoned Shigekage close to his presence and said, 'Ah, what a pity; you have spent your time thinking of Shigemori as a memento of your father, and Shigemori thinking of you as a memento of Kageyasu. I thought that in the coming appointments I would make you Yukie-no-Jō and call you as I called your father Kageyasu, but it is sad to die in vain; ensure that you do not go against the Shōshō-dono's heart.' Thus he spoke. Therefore, did you think me a person who would abandon you and flee if any matter should arise in these days? I am ashamed of the inside of your heart. That I receive your command 'There are many people in the world these days' means, as it is now, they are all retainers of the Genji. Even if I were to enjoy and prosper after my lord has become a god or Buddha, would I pass a thousand years of age? Even if I maintained ten thousand years, would there not be an end in the end? What Good Friend could surpass this?"
So saying, he cut his topknot with his own hands and, weeping and weeping, had Takiguchi Nyūdō shave him. Ishidō-maru saw this and cut his hair from the hairline. Since he too had served since he was eight and [Koremori] had pitied him no less than Shigekage, he had the same Takiguchi Nyūdō shave him. As he watched these men go before him like this, he felt more and more helpless. Since it could not remain so, chanting three times "Transmigrating in the Three Worlds, unable to cut off ties of affection; abandoning affection and entering the Unconditioned, is the true repayment of kindness," he finally shaved his head. "Ah, after letting my beloved ones see my unchanged figure once more, if it were to come to this, I would have no regrets." Saying this was sinful. The Sanmi Chūjō and Yosabyōe were the same age, twenty-seven this year. Ishidō-maru was eighteen.
[10.10.2] After quite a long time, he summoned the servant Takisato and said, "You, return quickly from here to Yashima. You must not go up to the Capital. The reason is, although in the end it cannot be hidden, I feel that if they hear of this situation correctly, they will immediately change their appearance [become nuns/monks]. Go to Yashima and say to the people: 'As you have seen, the world in general has become sluggish. Since the unreasonableness of all things seemed to increase, without letting each of you know, it has come to this. In the western provinces the Left Chūjō [Kiyotsune] was lost. At Ichinotani Bitchū-no-Kami was slain. Now that I too have become thus, how uncomfortable each of you must feel; I think painfully only of that. Now, the armor called Karakawa [Chinese Leather] and the sword called Kogarasu [Little Crow] have been transmitted in this house from Taira General Sadamori, and Koremori corresponds to the ninth generation in the direct line. If by some wonder the world is restored, give them to Rokudai.' Say this." Thus he spoke. Takisato said, "After I see how my lord becomes whatever happens, I shall go to Yashima." So saying "Then," he took him along. He also took Takiguchi Nyūdō along as a Good Friend. Leaving Kōya in the guise of mountain ascetic practitioners, they came out to the east of Uchiyama in the same province. Beginning with the Prince of Fujishiro, as they bowed and worshipped at Prince after Prince, in front of the Prince of Iwashiro north of the Chisato Beach, they encountered some seven or eight horsemen in hunting attire. Thinking they would surely be captured, each put his hand to the sword at his waist and was about to cut his belly, but although they approached, without any sign of stopping, as they hurriedly dismounted and passed by bowing deeply, wondering "Who is it that knows us?", they hastened their feet all the more; this was a person called Yuasa Shichirōbyōe Munemitsu, son of the resident of that province Yuasa Gon-no-Kami Muneshige. When his retainers said, "What kind of person is that?", Shichirōbyōe let tears fall freely and said, "Ah, how awe-inspiring; that is the heir of Lord Minister Komatsu, Lord Sanmi Chūjō. How has he escaped from Yashima to here? He has already changed his appearance. Yosabyōe and Ishidō-maru have also become monks and are accompanying him. I wanted to approach and enter his presence, but thinking he might feel hesitation, I passed by. Ah, what a pitiful state." Saying this, he pressed his sleeve to his face and wept bitterly, so the retainers also all shed tears.

10.11. Pilgrimage to Kumano
[10.11.1] As they gradually pressed on, days passed and they hung upon the Iwata River. Thinking, "Those who cross the current of this river even once will have their evil karma, passions, and beginningless sins extinguished," he felt reliant indeed. Arriving at the Main Shrine [Hongū], he knelt before the Shōjō-den; offering Dharma gifts for a while and worshipping the form of the mountain, neither heart nor words could encompass it. The mist of the protection of Great Compassion trailed over Mount Kumano, and the manifestation of the gods, peerless in miracles, left traces at the Otonashi River. On the shore of the One Vehicle practice, the moon of response was unclouded; in the garden of the repentance of the six senses, the dew of delusion did not form. Every single thing was nothing but reliable. As the night deepened and people quieted, he made his petition; remembering even that his father, the Great Minister, had spoken before this shrine, saying, "Take my life and save my afterlife," it was moving. "The original ground is Amida Nyorai. Without mistaking the Original Vow of embracing and never abandoning, guide me to the Pure Land."
Among the things he said, that he prayed, "May the wife and children I left in my old home be peaceful," was sad. Although he loathed the floating world and entered the true path, feeling that his delusions were still not exhausted, these were moving things.
[10.11.2] When it dawned, boarding a boat from the Main Shrine, he proceeded to the New Shrine [Shingū]. Worshipping at Kamikura, the rock-pines towered high, the storm breaking the dream of delusions; the flowing water flowed clearly, and it seemed the waves rinsed away the grime of dust. Bowing to worship the shrine of Asuka, passing the pine grove of Sano, he proceeded to the honorable mountain of Nachi. The water of the waterfall, surging and falling in three layers, struck up to several thousand jō; the spiritual image of Kannon appeared on the rock, so it should be called Mount Fudaraku. At the bottom of the mist, the voice of reciting the Lotus Sutra could be heard; it should be called Mount Ryōju. Now, since the Avatar left traces on this mountain, there is no one, high or low, noble or humble of our land, who does not carry his steps here, incline his head, join his palms, and be involved in its benefits. Thus the monks lined up their roof tiles [dwellings], and priests and laymen ranged their sleeves. Around the summer of Kanna, the Cloistered Emperor Kazan escaped the imperial throne of the Ten Virtues, and at the old site of the hermitage where he practiced for the Pure Land of the Nine Grades, appearing to recall the past, the cherry blossoms on the old trees had opened.
[10.11.3] Among the monks sequestered at Nachi, there was one who appeared to know this Sanmi Chūjō well, and he told his companion: "Thinking, 'What kind of person is this practitioner here?', it is the heir of the Komatsu Great Minister, Lord Sanmi Chūjō. Around the spring of Angen, when that lord was still known as Shii-no-Shōshō, there was a celebration for the fiftieth birthday at the Hōjūji Palace; his father, the Komatsu Lord, was Minister of the Center and Commander of the Left. His uncle, Lord Munemori, was Chūnagon and Commander of the Right, and took his seat below the stairs. Besides them, Sanmi Chūjō Tomomori, Tō-Chūnagon Shigehira, and others—the people of the clan prospered, making that day their clear day; from among those standing by the fence, this Lord Sanmi Chūjō, wearing cherry blossoms in his cap, came out and danced 'Seigaiha'; his flower-like figure flattering the dew, his dancing sleeves fluttering in the wind, illuminated the earth and made the heavens shine too. The Cloistered Empress sent the Kampaku-dono as a messenger and draped a robe over him; his father the Great Minister stood from his seat, received it, placed it on his right shoulder, and bowed to the Cloistered Emperor. His honor seemed to have few equals. How enviable the courtiers at his side must have thought him. Among the ladies-in-waiting of the Palace, he was the person of whom it was said, 'He reminds one of the arbutus among the trees of the deep mountains.' Just now I saw him as a person awaiting the position of Minister or Commander, but today, to see his appearance withered away like this—I had not imagined it beforehand. Although it is said to be the way of the world that changes as it moves, it is a sad matter."
Saying this, he pressed his sleeve to his face and wept bitterly, so the monks sequestered at Nachi, sitting in rows of whatever number, all wet the sleeves of their inner robes.
10.12. Koremori Drowns Himself
[10.12.1] Having accomplished the pilgrimage to the three mountains without incident, from the front of the Prince called Hama-no-Miya, poling a single-leaf boat, he floated onto the blue sea of ten thousand li. Far in the offing there is a place called Yamanari Island. Having the boat rowed there, he went up on the shore, shaved a large pine tree, and the Chūjō wrote his ancestral inscription. "Grandfather Prime Minister Taira Ason Kiyomori Kō, Dharma name Jōkai; Father Minister of the Center and Commander of the Left Shigemori Kō, Dharma name Jōren; his son Sanmi Chūjō Koremori, Dharma name Jōen, age twenty-seven years; on the twenty-eighth day of the Third Month of the third year of Juei, enters the water at the offing of Nachi."
Having written this, he boarded the boat again and rowed out to the offing. Although it was a path he had resolved upon, now that the time had come, there was nothing that was not helpless and sad. Since it was the twenty-eighth day of the Third Month, the sea path was misty far away, a scene to urge sadness. Even just the general spring, the sky as it grows dark is melancholy; much more, since it was his limit today, how helpless he must have felt. Seeing the fishing boats in the offing appearing to vanish into the waves, yet not sinking completely, he must have thought of his own fate. Even the geese crying as they headed for the northern provinces, taking along their own company and returning saying "now," made him want to send a message to his old home; he left no corner of thought unvisited, even to the resentment of Su Wu in the Hu country. "Then, what is this matter? It is because my delusions are not yet exhausted."
Reconsidering, he faced west, joined his hands, and chanted the Nembutsu, but even in his heart: "Since they cannot know in the Capital that this very moment is the limit, they must be waiting for tidings on the wind saying 'now, now.' Since in the end it cannot be hidden, hearing that I am a person not of this world, how much will they lament?"
As he continued to think thus, he stopped the Nembutsu, disarranged his joined palms, and said to the Holy Man, "Ah, a person's body is something that should not have things called wife and children. Not only do they make one thoughtful in this world, but the regret is that they become hindrances to the Bodhi of the afterlife. Even right now, I remember them. Since leaving such things in my heart would deepen my sin, I repent." Thus he spoke. The Holy Man also felt it was pitiable, but thinking, "If I too am weak-hearted, it will [][3]not do," he wiped away his tears, behaved as if it were not so, and said: "Truly, you must think so. Whether high or low, the path of affection is a matter beyond one's power. Among them, since it is said that for husband and wife to align pillows for one night is the karma of five hundred lifetimes, the vows of previous lives are not shallow. Those who are born must die, those who meet must part; this is the custom of the floating world. Since there is the example of the dew of the branch and the drops of the trunk, although there is a difference of slowness or speed, could there be an absence of parting, later or sooner, in the end? The vow of the autumn evening at Lishan Palace also finally became the beginning of broken hearts; the favor of the former life at Gansen Palace also was not without end. Songzi and Meisheng had regrets all their lives. Even those of Equal Enlightenment and the Ten Stages follow the decree of birth and death. Even if you boast of the pleasure of long life, you cannot escape this grief. Even if you maintain an age of one hundred years, this resentment should be thought of as the same thing. The heretic called the Demon King of the Sixth Heaven possesses the six heavens of the World of Desire as his own, and begrudging that the sentient beings of this world should leave birth and death, sometimes becomes a wife, sometimes becomes a husband, and hinders this; but the Buddhas of the three worlds think of all sentient beings as one child, and try to encourage them into the Land of No Retrogression of the Pure Land; because the things called wife and children have been the bonds transmigrating in birth and death since the beginningless distant past, the Buddha admonishes against them heavily. Even so, do not think weakly in your heart. The ancestor of the Genji, Iyo-nyūdō Yoriyoshi, saying he would chastise the barbarians of Ōshū, Abe no Sadatō and Munetō, by imperial command, cut off the heads of over sixteen thousand people in the space of twelve years. Besides that, the beasts of the mountains and fields, the fish of the rivers; the number of lives he cut off was unknown thousands of thousands. However, at the time of his end, because he gave rise to the Bodhi-mind of a single thought, I hear he achieved the long-cherished desire for rebirth. In particular, since the merit of becoming a monk is vast, the sins of previous lives will surely all be extinguished. Even if a person built a tower of seven treasures reaching to the thirty-third heaven, it cannot reach the merit of one day of becoming a monk. Even if one made offerings to a hundred Arhats for a hundred thousand years, it is preached that the merit cannot reach the merit of one day of becoming a monk. Even Yoriyoshi, who was deep in sin, achieved rebirth because his heart was fierce. Needless to say. Since my lord surely does not have such sinful karma, why should you not go to the Pure Land? Moreover, the Avatar of this mountain is the original ground Amida Nyorai. Beginning from the vow of no three evil paths, up to the vow of obtaining the three dharma tolerances, there is not one of the individual vows that is not a vow for the conversion of sentient beings. Among them, in the eighteenth vow, it is preached: 'If I attain Buddhahood, if the sentient beings of the ten directions, with sincere faith and desire to be born in my country, even to ten thoughts, are not born, I will not take correct enlightenment'; thus there is reliance on one thought or ten thoughts. Just believe deeply and do not produce doubt in the least. If you exert a non-dual earnest thought and chant either once or ten times, Amida Nyorai, shrinking his body of sixty trillion nayuta Ganges-sands, in a form of sixteen feet, surrounded hundredfold and thousandfold by Kannon, Seishi, countless holy multitudes, transformation Buddhas and Bodhisattvas, performing music and singing, will come to welcome you right now out of the eastern gate of Paradise; so even if you think your body sinks to the bottom of the blue sea, you will ascend upon purple clouds. If you become a Buddha, attain liberation, and open enlightenment, regarding the matter of returning to the old home of the Saha world and guiding your wife and children—'Returning to the defiled land to save humans and gods'—there should be no doubt at all."
Saying this, he struck a gong and encouraged the Nembutsu. Thinking "What an appropriate Good Friend," the Chūjō suddenly overturned his delusions, faced west, joined his hands, chanted the Nembutsu in a loud voice about a hundred times, and with the voice chanting "Namu," entered into the sea. Yosabyōe-nyūdō and Ishidō-maru also, chanting the Name likewise, followed and entered the sea. [] [3] NKBT reads "kanawaji to omoi" [thinking it would not do].
10.13. Three-Day Heike
[10.13.1] The servant Takisato also intended to follow and enter, but the Holy Man held him back, so he could do nothing. "How sadly you intend to violate his dying command. For one of low rank, it is even more sad. Now just pray for his afterlife."
Although he taught him weeping and weeping, in the sadness of serving him to the end, [Takisato] did not remember the matter of future filial piety, but fell rolling in the bottom of the boat, shouting and screaming; the state was such that the sadness of the servant Chandaka returning to the royal palace with the horse Kanthaka when Prince Siddhartha entered Mount Dandaka in the past did not seem to surpass this. For a while they pushed the boat around and looked to see if they might float up, but the three together had sunk deep and were not seen. Before long, reading sutras and chanting Nembutsu, he transferred merit saying, "May the past spirits go to the One Buddha Pure Land"; this was moving.
[10.13.2] In the meantime, the setting sun declined to the west, and the sea surface became dark; although they thought their regrets were inexhaustible, they rowed the empty boat back. The drops from the oars of the crossing boat, the tears flowing from the Holy Man's sleeves; one could not distinguish which was which. The Holy Man returned up to Kōya. Takisato went to Yashima weeping and weeping. When he took out the letter for the younger brother, Lord New Sanmi Chūjō, and presented it, he said, "Ah, how wretched; the regret that he did not think of us as much as we relied on him. Thinking that he communicated his intent to Yoritomo like Ike-no-Dainagon and went to the Capital, the Lord Minister and the Nii-dono placed distance between us, but so, he has thrown his body away in the offing of Nachi. Then, that we did not sink in one place together but lie in different places is sad. Was there nothing he said by word?"
When he asked this, [Takisato] said, "What he said to say was: In the western provinces Lord Left Chūjō was lost. At Ichinotani Lord Bitchū-no-Kami was slain. Now that I too have become thus, I think painfully only of how uncomfortable you will feel." When he spoke in detail even about the Karakawa [armor] and Kogarasu [sword], saying "Now I do not feel I should survive either," he pressed his sleeve to his face and wept bitterly; feeling it was truly reasonable, it was touching. Since he resembled the late Sanmi Chūjō-dono closely, those who saw him shed tears. The samurai gathered and did nothing but weep. The Lord Minister and the Nii-dono also said, "We thought this person had communicated his intent to Yoritomo like Ike-no-Dainagon and gone to the Capital, but it was not so," and they lamented and grieved anew.
[10.13.3] On the first day of the Fourth Month, the Former Captain of the Guards of Kamakura, Yoritomo, was made Senior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade. Originally he was Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade, so that he suddenly exceeded five ranks was extraordinary. This was rumored to be the reward for the pursuit and chastisement of Kiso Sama-no-Kami Yoshinaka.
[10.13.4] On the third day of the same month, saying Sutoku-in should be worshipped as a god, a shrine was built at the end of Ōimikado where the battle was in the past, and the spirit was transferred. This was the instruction of the Cloistered Emperor, and it was rumored that the Palace did not know of it.
[10.13.5] On the fourth day of the Fifth Month, Ike-no-Dainagon Yorimori went down to the Kanto; Lord Captain of the Guards sent messengers repeatedly with written vows saying, "I absolutely do not think of you as foolish. I consider only that the late Ike-dono is present. I will repay the favor of the late Nun to the Dainagon-dono."
Although he had separated from the clan and stayed behind, he had existed with no other thought than vanishing his liver and soul, thinking, "Although the Captain of the Guards thinks thus, how will the other Genji be?" but since [Yoritomo] said from Kamakura, "Thinking I look upon the late Nun, enter my presence quickly," the Dainagon went down.
[10.13.6] There was a samurai called Yaheibyōe Munekiyo. He was the number one hereditary retainer, but he did not go down with him. When asked "Why?", he said, "I think I will not accompany you this time. The reason is, although my lord exists like this, the matter of the nobles of the clan drifting on the waves of the western sea feels painful, and since I do not yet feel at peace, I will settle my heart a little and join you later."
Thus he spoke. The Dainagon felt bitter and ashamed, and said, "Truly, regarding the matter of separating from the clan and remaining behind, I myself do not think it was excellent, but since my body was hard to discard and life was dear, I remained against my better judgment. After that, it is not that I should not go down. Going on a distant journey, how can you not see me off? If you thought it unacceptable, why did you not say so when I stayed behind? Great and small matters, I consulted entirely with you."
When he said this, Munekiyo sat up straight and spoke with awe: "High or low, for a human body is there anything as dear as life? Also, it is said that one discards the world but does not discard the body. I do not consider your staying behind as evil; because the Captain of the Guards also had his worthless life saved, today he meets such fortune. I hear that he does not forget even now that when he was exiled, by the command of the late Nun, I escorted him as far as the station of Shinohara; so surely if I went down accompanying you, he would offer gifts and entertainment. Regarding that, it would be painful. Since it would be repeatedly shameful if the nobles crossing to the western provinces or the samurai heard of it, please bend and let me stay behind just this time. Since my lord stayed behind and exists thus, why should you not go down? Regarding your proceeding on a distant journey, truly I feel anxious, but if you were going down to attack enemies, I should be the very first vanguard, but even if I do not go this time, there will be absolutely no lack for you. If the Captain of the Guards asks, you should say there is a matter of illness."
When he said this, the samurai with heart who heard it all shed tears. The Dainagon also felt ashamed, but since it was not a situation where he could stay, he departed immediately.
[10.13.7] On the sixteenth day of the same month, he arrived down in Kamakura. The Captain of the Guards hurriedly met him and first asked, "Has Munekiyo accompanied you?" When he said, "There was a matter of illness at the time, so he did not come down," [Yoritomo] said, "Why? What was he suffering from? He bears a grudge. In the past when I was with Munekiyo, I do not forget even now that he treated me with gratitude in everything I touched, so I decided he would surely come down accompanying you. I longed to see him quickly, but how resentful that he has not come down." Saying this, he prepared many documents and tried to give horses, saddles, armor, and various other things; the appropriate daimyo said "Me too, me too" and prepared gifts, but since he did not come down, high and low thought it a regrettable thing.
[10.13.8] On the ninth day of the Sixth Month, Ike-no-Dainagon went up to the Capital from the Kanto. The Captain of the Guards said, "Please stay like this for a while," but he said, "They must be anxious in the Capital," and hurriedly went up; he reported to the Cloistered Emperor that not one place of his manors and private lands should be different, and that he should be returned to Dainagon. He presented thirty saddled horses, thirty bare horses, and thirty long chests filled with feathers, gold, dyed goods, and rolled silk. Since the Captain of the Guards treated him thus, daimyo and minor lords said "Me too, me too" and presented gifts. The horses alone reached three hundred. Not only was his life saved, but he returned to the Capital with profit attached.
[10.13.9] On the eighteenth day of the same month, with Higo-no-Kami Sadayoshi's uncle Hirata Nyūdō Sadatsugu as general, the residents of the two provinces of Iga and Ise marched out to Ōmi Province; the descendants of the Genji marched out and did battle. The residents of the two provinces were struck down without a single one remaining. That they were hereditary retainers of the Heike for generations and did not forget old friendship was moving, but that they thought to rise was presumptuous. The "Three-Day Heike" refers to this.
[10.13.10] In the meantime, the communications on the convenience of the wind to Komatsu Sanmi Chūjō Koremori Kyō's wife had been cut off and it had been a long time, so she thought painfully, "What has happened?" Although she waited, thinking "Surely there will be tidings once a month," spring passed and summer also deepened. Hearing that there were people who said "Sanmi Chūjō is no longer at Yashima," out of excess anxiety, she managed to send a person to Yashima; but he did not return quickly, and summer passed and it became autumn. At the end of the Seventh Month, that messenger returned. When the wife asked, "Well, how is it, how is it?", he said, "Leaving Yashima at dawn on the fifteenth day of the Third Month past, he went to Kōya; at Kōya he shaved his head, and from there proceeded to Kumano. Having spoken well of matters of the afterlife, he threw his body into the sea in the offing of Nachi; so the servant Takisato who accompanied him told me."
When he said this, the wife said, "Just as I thought; I felt it was strange," and pulling [her robes] over her head, she lay down. The young lord and young lady also wept and grieved with their voices. The young lord's nurse lady-in-waiting wept and said, "This is not something to be surprised at now. It is a matter anticipated from days past. Like Lord Hon-Sanmi Chūjō, if he had been captured alive and returned to the Capital, how painful it would have been; that he shaved his head at Kōya, proceeded to Kumano, spoke well of matters of the afterlife, and passed away with right mindfulness at the end is a joy amidst lamentation. Therefore, you should consider it a matter of peace of mind. Now, consider raising the young people even in the space between rocks and trees."
Thus she comforted her in various ways, but it did not seem that she could endure her thoughts and survive. Immediately she changed her appearance [became a nun], performed Buddhist services as per form, and prayed for his afterlife.
10.14. Fujito
[10.14.1] Hearing this relayed, the Captain of the Guards of Kamakura said, "Ah, if he had come to me without distance, I would have saved at least his life. I do not think foolishly of the matter of the Komatsu Minister. The reason is, that I was interceded for and my sentence commuted to exile through the messenger of the late Nun of Ike was solely the fragrant favor of that Minister. Since how could I forget that favor, I do not think of his sons as strangers. Much less, now that he has become a monk and such, is there need for details?"
Thus he spoke.
[10.14.2] In the meantime, after the Heike returned to Yashima in Sanuki, it was rumored: "Tens of thousands of fresh troops from the eastern provinces have arrived in the Capital and are attacking down." They also said together: "From Chinzei, the Usuki, Hetsugi, and Matsura parties have united and are pushing across." Hearing that and hearing this, there was nothing but surprising the ears and vanishing the liver and soul. This time at Ichinotani, the people of the clan were killed with few remaining, and more than half of the leading samurai were destroyed. Now that their power was exhausted, Awa Minbu-no-Daibu Shigeyoshi's brothers talked to the people of Shikoku, and saying "Even so," they relied on them as high mountains and deep seas. The ladies-in-waiting gathered and did nothing but weep. Thus it became the twenty-fifth day of the Seventh Month. Saying, "Today of last year we left the Capital; before long it has come around," they spoke of things that were wretched and flustered, and wept and laughed.
[10.14.3] On the twenty-eighth day of the same month, the enthronement of the new Emperor took place. I hear that this was the first time since Emperor Jimmu for eighty-two generations that an enthronement precedent occurred without the Sacred Mirror, Sacred Jewel, and Treasure Sword. On the sixth day of the Eighth Month, appointments were held, and Gama no Kaja Noriyori became Mikawa-no-Kami. Kurō Kaja Yoshitsune was made Saemon-no-Jō. Receiving the decree of an Imperial Envoy, he was called Kurō Hōgan.
[10.14.4] In the meantime, the wind on the reeds gradually pierced the body, the dew under the bush clover became increasingly heavy, the rice leaves rustled with the voices of resentful insects, and the scene of tree leaves scattering all at once; even for one who did not think of things, the sky of travel in deepening autumn must be sad. Much more, the insides of the hearts of the Heike people can be guessed and are pitiable. In the past within the Ninefold Enclosure, they played with the spring blossoms; now at the bay of Yashima, they grieved at the autumn moon. Generally, even composing poems on the clear moon, they imagined how tonight in the Capital might be, and clearing their hearts and shedding tears, they spent their days and nights. Sama-no-Kami Yukimori continued his thoughts thus:
Because my Lord lives there, this too is the moon of the Palace [Kumoi], but what I still long for is the Capital.
[10.14.5] On the twelfth day of the Ninth Month of the same year, Mikawa-no-Kami Noriyori, saying it was for the pursuit and chastisement of the Heike, set out for the western provinces. The people accompanying him were Ashikaga Kurōdo Yoshikane, Kagami Kojirō Nagakiyo, Hōjō Koshirō Yoshitoki, Saiin-no-Jikan Chikayoshi; as samurai generals, Doi Jirō Sanehira, his son Yatarō Tōhira, Miura-no-Suke Yoshizumi, his son Heiroku Yoshimura, Hatakeyama Shōji Jirō Shigetada, same Nagano Saburō Shigekiyo, Inage Saburō Shigenari, Hangaya Shirō Shigetomo, same Gorō Yukishige, Oyama Koshirō Tomomasa, same Naganuma Gorō Munemasa, Tsuchiya Saburō Mune-tō, Sasaki Saburō Moritsuna, Hatta Shirō Musha Tomoie, Anzai Saburō Akimasu, Ōgo Saburō Sanehide, Amano Tōnai Tōkage, Hiki Tōnai Tomomune, same Tōshirō Yoshikazu, Chūjō Tōji Ienaga, Ippon-bō Shōgen, Tosabō Shōshun; beginning with these, with a total force of over thirty thousand horsemen, they left the Capital and arrived at Muro in Harima.
[10.14.6] On the Heike side, hearing that the great generals Komatsu New Sanmi Chūjō Sukemori, same Shōshō Arimori, and Tango Jijū Tadafusa, with samurai generals Hida Saburō Saemon Kage-tsune, Etchū Jirōbyōe Moritsugu, Kazusa Gorōbyōe Tadamitsu, and Aku-Shichibyōe Kagekiyo as the van, had boarded over five hundred warships and arrived at Kojima in Bizen, the Genji left Muro, and this too being Bizen Province, took up position at Nishikawajiri and Fujito.
[10.14.7] The meeting place of the Genji and Heike camps was separated by about five chō of sea surface. Since there was no way to cross easily without boats, the great force of the Genji lodged on the facing mountain and spent days in vain. From the Heike side, young men eager for action rode small boats and had them rowed out, raised fans, and beckoned, "Cross here!" While the Genji said, "It is not peaceful; what shall we do?", entering the night of the twenty-fifth day of the same month, Sasaki Saburō Moritsuna won over a man of the shore, gave him a white kosode, wide-mouthed trousers, and a sword with white scabbard, and coaxing him, asked, "Is there a place in this sea where one can cross by horse?" The man said, "Although there are many men of the shore, those who know the guide [path] are rare. I know it well. For example, there is a place like a river shoal; at the beginning of the month it is in the east, at the end of the month it is in the west. The crossing of the shoals on both sides is about ten chō of sea surface. This shoal can be crossed easily on your horse."
When he said this, Sasaki rejoiced extraordinarily, and without letting his own house-men or retainers know, slipped out with just that man alone; becoming naked, he tried crossing the place like the said shoal, and indeed it was not very deep. There were places reaching the knees, waist, and shoulders; there were places where the sidelocks got wet. Deep places he swam, and reached the shallow places by swimming. The man said, "South of here is far shallower than north. Where the enemy gathers arrow-points and waits, you cannot succeed naked. Please return from here."
When he said this, Sasaki said "Indeed," and as he returned, thinking, "Since he is a low-born man belonging nowhere, he might be persuaded by others and teach them the guide; I alone should know," he stabbed the man to death, cut off his head, and discarded it.
[10.14.8] Around the Hour of the Dragon [8 a.m.] on the twenty-sixth day of the same month, the Heike again rode small boats and had them rowed out, raised fans, and beckoned, "Genji, cross here!" Sasaki knew the guide beforehand. Wearing a hitatare with a dense eye-pattern and armor with black thread lacing, riding a white-dappled grey horse, with seven house-men and retainers, he dashed in quickly and crossed. When the Great General Mikawa-no-Kami said, "Restrain him, stop him!", Doi Jirō Sanehira matched whip and stirrup and caught up, saying, "How now, Lord Sasaki, are you mad with something possessing you? Without the permission of the Great General, it is disorderly conduct; stop!" Although he said this, [Sasaki] did not listen with his ears and crossed, so Doi Jirō, unable to restrain him, immediately followed and crossed. The water touched the horses' flanks and breast-straps; there were places reaching the belly, places crossing the saddle-basin; deep places they made them swim, and rode up onto shallow places. Great General Mikawa-no-Kami saw this and said, "We have been tricked by Sasaki. It was shallow! Cross, cross!" Since he ordered thus, the great force of over thirty thousand horsemen all dashed in and crossed. On the Heike side, saying "Alas," they pushed out boats and floated them, gathered arrow-points, and shot rapidly and unceasingly. The Genji soldiers, making nothing of this, tilted the neck-guards of their helmets, rode and transferred onto the Heike boats, shouted and screamed, and attacked and fought. Genji and Heike fought confusedly; there were those who died treading down boats and sinking them. There were those who were turned back and flustered in panic. After fighting all day, when night fell, the Heike boats floated in the offing. The Genji rode up onto Kojima and rested the breath of men and horses. When it dawned, the Heike rowed back to Yashima. Although the Genji felt fierce in heart, since they had no boats, they did not chase and attack. Saying, "Although there have been soldiers who crossed rivers by horse from ancient times to the present, crossing the sea by horse is unknown in India or China, and is a rare instance in our country," it was recorded in the letter of the Lord of Kamakura granting Kojima in Bizen to Sasaki.
10.15. Preparations for the Great Thanksgiving Service
[10.15.1] On the twenty-seventh day of the same month, in the Capital, Kurō Hōgan Yoshitsune was made Kebiishi Go-i-no-Jō [Police Commissioner of the Fifth Rank], and was called Kurō Tayū Hōgan. In the meantime, it became the Tenth Month. At Yashima, the wind blowing the bay was severe and the waves striking the shore were high; soldiers did not come to attack, and the passing of merchant guests was rare, so they wished to hear tidings of the Capital; somehow the sky clouded over, hail scattered, and they felt increasingly as if they were vanishing. In the Capital, saying there should be a Great Thanksgiving Service [Daijō-e], there was a royal purification procession. Tokudaiji Sadai-shō Sanesada Kō, who was then Naidaijin, served as Naiben [Chief of Ceremony]. Two years ago, at the royal purification procession of the former Emperor, the Heike Naidaijin Munemori Kō was under the sun-shade; arriving at the pavilion under the sun-shade, the spectacle of Dragon Banners standing before him, the hairline of his cap, the hang of his sleeves, even to the hem of his over-trousers, appeared especially superior. Besides that, the people of the clan, Sanmi Chūjō Tomomori, Tō-Chūnagon Shigehira, and other Guards officers serving at the reins; indeed there was no one to stand beside them. Today Kurō Hōgan Yoshitsune served in the vanguard. Unlike Kiso and such, he was accustomed to the Capital, but he was still inferior to the refuse of the Heike.
[10.15.2] On the eighteenth day of the Eleventh Month of the same year, the Great Thanksgiving Service was accomplished. Since the time of Jishō and Yōwa past, the people and peasants of the various provinces and seven circuits, tormented by the Genji and destroyed by the Heike, abandoned their homes and stoves and mingled in the mountains and forests; in spring they forgot the thought of eastern planting, and in autumn they did not manage the work of western harvest. Although one wonders how such a great ceremony could be performed, since it was not something that could remain undone, it was accomplished as per form.
[10.15.3] If Mikawa-no-Kami Noriyori had continued to attack immediately, the Heike would have been destroyed, but resting at Muro and Takasago, gathering playgirls and prostitutes, he spent his days and months only in play and frolic. Although there were many daimyo and minor lords of the eastern provinces, since it was a matter of following the command of the Great General, they lacked the power. With only the waste of the province and the trouble of the people, this year also finally ended.
