11. 平家物語卷第十一
11.1. Reverse Oars
[11.1.1] On the tenth day of the First Month of the second year of Genryaku, Kurō Taiyu Hōgan Yoshitsune went to the Palace of the Cloistered Emperor, and through the Treasurer Yasutsune Ason, reported thus: "The Heike have been cast out by the gods of heaven and earth, and abandoned by the Sovereign; they have left the Imperial Capital and become fugitives drifting upon the waves. However, it is regrettable that for these three years, we have not crush them, and they block many provinces; this time, as for Yoshitsune, I shall not return to the Royal City until I have crushed the Heike, even if I must go as far as Kikai, Koryo, India, or China." When he spoke thus with such confidence, the Cloistered Emperor was greatly impressed and ordered, "Make ready, join night to day, and decide the victory." Thus was the command given. The Judge returned to his lodgings and proclaimed to the warriors of the eastern provinces: "I, Yoshitsune, as deputy of the Lord of Kamakura, have received a Cloistered Decree to pursue and strike down the Heike. On land, as far as the horses' hooves can reach; on sea, as far as the oars can go, we shall attack. Those who have even a little bit of a double heart should return from here quickly." So he proclaimed.
[11.1.2] Meanwhile, at Yashima, time passed as quickly as a galloping horse passes a gap; the First Month ended and it became the Second Month. The spring grass withered, startled by the autumn wind; the autumn wind ceased, and it became spring grass again. Sending off and welcoming the seasons, already three years had passed. It was heard: "From the capital, fresh warriors from the eastern provinces, tens of thousands of horsemen, are arriving and attacking downwards."
They also said to one another: "From Chinzei, the Usuki, Hetsugi, and Matsura bands have agreed together and are crossing over."
Hearing this and hearing that, they only startled their ears and vanished their souls [in fear]; there was nothing else. The ladies-in-waiting, beginning with the Cloistered Lady and the Nun of the Second Rank, gathered together and lamented and grieved with one another, saying, "What kind of misery are we to see again? What kind of sorrowful things must we hear?"
The New Middle Counselor Tomomori said: "Although the men of the eastern and northern provinces received significant heavy favors, they forgot those favors, changed their oaths, and followed Yoritomo and Yoshinaka. I thought that at least the western provinces would be so [loyal], and when we were in the capital, I thought things would turn out somehow. Since it is not a matter of my body alone, I weak-heartedly wandered out, and the regret of seeing such misery today is great." So he spoke. Truly it seemed reasonable and was pitiful.
[11.1.3] On the third day of the same Second Month, Kurō Taiyu Hōgan Yoshitsune left the capital, and gathering ships at Watanabe in the province of Settsu, was about to attack Yashima. Mikawa-no-kami Noriyori also left the capital on the same day, and outfitting war snips from Kanzaki in Settsu province, intended to head for the San'yōdō.
[11.1.4] On the thirteenth day of the same month, Imperial envoys were sent to the Great Shrine of Ise, Iwashimizu, Kamo, and Kasuga. "Return the Sovereign and the Three Sacred Treasures without incident." It was ordered that the officials of the the Department of Divinities and the priests of the various shrines should offer prayers at their main shrines and sanctuaries to this effect.
[11.1.5] On the sixteenth day of the same month, at both Watanabe and Kanzaki, the ships that had been outfitted for days were about to untie their moorings. Just then, a north wind blew violently, breaking trees; the ships were severely damaged by the great waves and could not launch. For repairs, they stayed that day. At Watanabe, the great and small lords gathered and discussed: "Now, we are not yet trained in the ways of naval warfare; how should we proceed?"
Kajiwara spoke: "In this battle, I should like to fit the ships with reverse oars." The Judge asked, "What are reverse oars?" Kajiwara said, "When one wishes to ride a horse, it is easy to turn to the left or the right. As for a ship, pushing it back quickly is a serious matter. I should like to place oars at the stern and the bow, insert side rudders, and make it so we can push easily in any direction." When he said this, The Judge said, "Regarding battle, if one intends not to retreat even a single step, yet the alignment is bad, retreating is the usual custom. But what good is it to prepare to flee from the start? First of all, it is a bad omen for our departure. Whether you set up reverse oars or return oars, on your boats, my lords, you may set up a hundred or a thousand. As for Yoshitsune, I shall remain with the original oars." When he said this, Kajiwara spoke: "What is called a fine great general is one who advances where he should advance, and retreats where he should retreat, preserving himself and destroying the enemy; this is what is considered a good great general. One who knows only one direction is called a 'Wild Boar Warrior' and is not considered fine." When he said this, The Judge said, "I know not of boars or deer; in battle, attacking straight on and winning is what feels good." The samurai, fearing Kajiwara, did not laugh loudly, but signaled with their eyes and noses and whispered amongst themselves. They whispered that The Judge and Kajiwara were about to fight each other.
[11.1.6] Gradually the sun set and night fell; The Judge said, "Since the ship repairs are done and they are like new, each of you celebrate with a variety of food and a bottle of sake, my lords." Saying this, he acted as if making preparations, loading weapons and military provisions onto the ships and loading the horses. Then he said, "Do it quickly." But the sailors and helmsmen said, "Although this wind is a tailwind, it is a wind that exceeds the ordinary. In the open sea it must be blowing severely. How can we do this?" When they said this, The Judge became very angry and said, "Whether dying at the ends of fields and mountains, or drowning and perishing at the bottom of the sea and rivers, all this is the karma of previous lives. When venturing onto the sea, what is the use of saying the wind is strong? If I said we should cross against a headwind, that would be wrong. It is a tailwind, and just because it is a little excessive, in this great matter of ours, how can you say we will not cross? If they do not prepare the ships, shoot them to death one by one, you fellows." Thus he ordered. Sato Saburobyōe Tsugunobu of Oshu, Ise Saburo Yoshimori, holding arrows in one hand, stepped forward and said, "Why do you offer details? It is the lord's decision; do it quickly, quickly. If you do not prepare the boats, we will shoot you to death one by one." When they said this, the sailors and helmsmen heard it and said, "Being shot to death is the same thing; if the wind is strong, just die running." So, out of more than two hundred ships, only five ships ventured out and ran. The remaining ships, perhaps fearing the wind or perhaps fearing Kajiwara, all stayed behind. The Judge said, "Just because people do not go, it is not the case that we should stay; in normal times the enemy would also be cautious. It is when we push across in such great wind and great waves, when they do not expect it, that we can defeat the intended enemy." So he spoke. As for the five ships, first was The Judge's ship, then Tashiro no Kaja, Goto Byōe father and son, the Kaneko brothers, and Yodo no Enai Tadatoshi; these were the ships the ship magistrates rode. The Judge said, "Do not burn bonfires on each ship. Make Yoshitsune's ship the main ship, and guard the bonfires at the stern and bow. If many fires are seen, the enemy will be afraid and take precautions." Saying this, they ran all night; a place that takes three days to cross, they crossed in just three hours. Departing Watanabe and Fukushima at the Hour of the Ox on the sixteenth day of the Second Month, by the dawning Hour of the Rabbit, they were blown ashore at the land of Awa.
11.2. Katsuura and The Osaka Crossing
[11.2.1] When the night had already dawned, a few red banners flashed on the beach. The Judge saw this and said, "Look there, they have made preparations to celebrate us. If we attach the boats broadly and try to lower the horses by tilting the gangplanks, we will become targets for the enemy and be shot. Before we reach the beach, drive the horses down and make them swim to the shore. When the horses find footing and the water is up to the saddle girths, mount them quickly and gallop, men." Thus he commanded. Since weapons and provisions had been loaded onto the five ships, there were only fifty-some horses standing there. When they came close to the beach, they mounted quickly, and when they shouted and charged, the hundred-some men on the beach could not withstand them even for a moment, and quickly withdrew about two chō and retreated. The Judge stood on the water's edge, letting the horses rest their breath, and calling Ise Saburo Yoshimori, he said, "Among that force, there must be someone suitable. Capture one person and bring him here. I have things to ask." Yoshimori reverently acknowledged this, galloped alone into the enemy, said something, and brought back a man of about forty years, wearing black leather-laced armor, having made him take off his helmet and loosen his bowstring. The Judge asked, "Who are you?" He replied, "A resident of this province, Kondo Roku Chikale of Sakanishi." "Whatever family you are from, do not take off your armor. I shall take you as a guide to Yashima at once. Do not take your eyes off that man. If he tries to flee, shoot him to death, men." Thus he commanded. "What is this place called?" When asked, he replied, "It is called Katsuura." The Judge laughed and said, "No flattery." He replied, "It is certainly Katsuura. Because the lower classes speak easily, they call it Katsura, but in characters it is written Katsuura [Victory Inlet]."
The Judge said, "Listen to this, my lords. How auspicious it is that Yoshitsune, heading to battle, has arrived at Katsuura. Is there anyone in this vicinity who might shoot arrows at our rear for the Heike?" "There is the younger brother of Awa Minbu Shigeyoshi, called Sakurama no Suke Yoshito." "Come then, let us kick him aside and pass through." Saying this, he selected about thirty horsemen from Kondo Roku's force of about one hundred and added them to his own force. When they pressed upon Yoshito's castle and looked, three sides were swamp, and one side was a moat. They pressed in from the moat side and raised a battle cry. The soldiers inside the castle aligned their arrowheads and shot furiously, nocking and pulling. The Genji soldiers made nothing of this. Tilting the neck-guards of their helmets, shouting and screaming, they attacked and entered; Sakurama no Suke must have thought he could not prevail. He made his retainers shoot defensive arrows, and since he possessed an excellent horse, he whipped it and barely escaped. The Judge cut off the heads of the twenty-some soldiers who had shot defensive arrows, offered them to the god of war, raised a shout of victory, and said, "The departure is good."
The Judge called Kondo Roku Chikaie and asked, "How large is the Heike force at Yashima?" "It surely does not exceed one thousand horsemen." "Why so few?" "Like this, fifty or a hundred horsemen have been stationed at the various inlets and islands of Shikoku. Furthermore, the heir of Awa Minbu Shigeyoshi, Tauchi Saemon Noriyoshi, has crossed over to Iyo with more than three thousand horsemen to attack Kono Shiro, who did not come when summoned." "Well then, that is a good opening. How far is the road from here to Yashima?" "It is a two-day journey." "Then let us approach before the enemy hears." Saying this, they broke into a trot, walking, galloping, and holding back, and crossed the mountain called Osaka Pass on the border of Awa and Sanuki throughout the night.
[11.2.2] Around midnight, he walked alongside a man holding a folded letter and chatted with him. Since it was a night affair, the man did not dream that this was the enemy. Perhaps he thought they were soldiers of his own side going to Yashima. Relaxing his guard, he chatted in detail. "Where is that letter going?" "I am going to the Minister's palace at Yashima." "Who is sending it?" "A lady is sending it from the capital." "What is the matter?" When asked, he said, "Surely it is nothing special. Since the Genji have already come forth to the mouth of the Yodo River, she is likely reporting that." "Indeed, that must be so. I am also going to Yashima, but I do not yet know the way; guide me." When he said this, the man said, "Since I go often, I know the way. I shall accompany you." When he said this, The Judge said, "Take that letter." Snatching the letter, he said, "Tie this fellow up. Do not commit a sin by cutting off his head." And tying him to a tree in the mountains, they passed on. Now, opening the letter and looking at it, it really seemed to be a lady's letter, and it was written: "I hear that Kurō is a sharp man, so I believe he will attack without disliking great wind or great waves. Do not scatter your forces, but be cautious."
The Judge said, "This is a letter given to Yoshitsune by Heaven. I shall show it to the Lord of Kamakura." And he put it away deeply.
[11.2.3] At the Hour of the Tiger on the dawning eighteenth day, they rode down to a place called Hiketa in the province of Sanuki and rested the men and horses. From there, passing through Niuya and Shiratori, they approached the fortress of Yashima. Again summoning Kondo Roku Chikaie, he asked, "What is the state of the mansion at Yashima?" "Since you do not know, it is extremely shallow. When the tide is low, between the mainland and the island, the water does not even reach the belly of a horse." When he said this, The Judge said, "Then let us attack at once." Setting fire to the village of Takamatsu, they attacked the fortress of Yashima.
[11.2.4] At Yashima, the heir of Awa Minbu Shigeyoshi, Tauchi Saemon Noriyoshi, had crossed to Iyo with more than three thousand horsemen to attack Kono Shiro, who did not come when summoned; he failed to kill Kono, but took the heads of more than one hundred and fifty of his retainers and brought them to the Palace at Yashima. "It is not appropriate to inspect the heads of rebels at the Palace." So saying, they inspected them at the lodging of the Minister. There were one hundred and fifty-six heads. While they were inspecting the heads, the men made a commotion, saying, "A fire has broken out in the direction of Takamatsu."
"Since it is daytime, surely it is not an accident. It seems the enemy has attacked and set the fire. Surely they are a great force. If we are hemmed in, we cannot prevail. Board quickly, quickly." Since the ships were lined up on the beach in front of the Great Gate, they boarded, crying "Me too, me too!" The Cloistered Lady, the Northern Mandokoro, the Nun of the Second Rank, and the other ladies were taken onto the Imperial Ship. The Minister and his son boarded one ship. The other people boarded as they thought best, and while some rowed out about one chō, or seven or eight tan, or five or six tan, the Genji soldiers, seventy or eighty horsemen in plain armor, suddenly appeared on the beach in front of the Great Gate. Since it was the height of low tide on the tidal flat, there were places where the horses stood up to their chests or bellies. There were also shallower places. From amidst the rising smoke that was dark with the mist, they raised white flags all at once; the Heike must have thought their luck had run out and seen them as a great force. The Judge, intending not to let the enemy see a small force, appeared in groups of five or six, seven or eight, or ten horsemen.
11.3. The End of Tsugunobu
[11.3.1] For his attire that day, Kurō Taiyu Hōgan wore a hitatare of red brocade, armor laced with purple graduating to white at the bottom, carried a gold-mounted sword, bore mottled arrows, held a rattan-wrapped bow at the middle, glared towards the ships, and raising a great voice, announced his name: "Imperial Envoy of the Cloistered Emperor, Kebiishi of the Fifth Rank, Minamoto no Yoshitsune." Next, the resident of Izu Province Tashiro no Kaja Nobutsuna, the resident of Musashi Province Kaneko Juro Ietada and Yoichi Chikanori of the same, and Ise Saburo Yoshimori announced their names. Continuing to announce their names, Goto Byōe Sanemoto, his son Shinbyōe Motokiyo, Sato Saburobyōe Tsugunobu of Oshu and Shirobyōe Tadanobu of the same, Eda Genzo, Kumai Taro, and Musashibo Benkei came galloping, shouting their names one after another. On the Heike side, saying "Shoot them down there!", some ships shot long-range arrows, and some ships shot rapid arrows.
The Genji soldiers, turning to their left, shot as they passed; turning to their right, they shot as they passed; making the beached ships their shelter and a place to rest their horses, [][1] they shouted and screamed and attacked and fought.
[11.3.2] Goto Byōe Sanemoto, being an old soldier, did not fight, but first broke into the Palace, set fire here and there, and burned it away into smoke in a short time. The Minister called his samurai and asked, "Well, how large is the Genji force?" "At present, there are merely seventy or eighty horsemen," they replied.
"Ah, how vexing. Even if we took them by separating each hair of their heads one by one, they would not be enough for this force. That we did not hem them in and kill them, but panicked and boarded the ships, letting them burn the Palace, is truly unsettling. Is Lord Noto not here? Go ashore and have a battle." "I have heard," he said, and taking Etchu Jirobyōe Moritsugu with him, he boarded a small boat and took up a position on the beach of the Great Gate which had been burned away.
The Judge's eighty-some horsemen approached to arrow range and held back. Etchu Jirobyōe Moritsugu stood forth at the front of the boat, raised a great voice, and spoke: "I hear you have announced your names, but separated by the far distance of the sea, those names and real names are not clear. Who is the Great General of the Genji today?" Ise Saburo Yoshimori walked his horse forward and spoke: "It goes without saying: the descendant of the tenth generation of Emperor Seiwa, younger brother of the Lord of Kamakura, Kurō Taiyu Hōgan-dono." Moritsugu said, "There is such a thing. Is he the little page who, in the Battle of Heiji some years ago, had his father killed and became an orphan, was a child at Kurama, later became a servant to a gold merchant, and wandered off to Oshu carrying provisions on his back?" Thus he spoke. Yoshimori said, "Do not speak of the Lord just because your tongue is flexible. Are you the fellows who were chased down in the Battle of Tonamiyama, escaped with your miserable lives, wandered the Hokuriku road, and went up to the capital weeping and begging?" Thus he spoke. Moritsugu spoke again: "Saturated with the benevolence of our Lord, for what lack would we beg? I heard that it was you fellows who became bandits at Mount Suzuka in Ise to feed your wives and children and sustain yourselves." When he said this, Kaneko Juro Ietada said, "Useless insults, my lords. Who is inferior when it comes to telling lies and trading insults? Last spring at Ichi-no-tani, you surely saw the extent of the skill of the young lords of Musashi and Sagami." Just as he spoke, his younger brother Yoichi, who was by his side, did not let him finish speaking, but drew a twelve-fist-length arrow and released it with a whistle. It stood in the breastplate of Moritsugu's armor, piercing through to the lining. After that, the battle of words ceased.
[11.3.3] Noto-no-Kami Noritsune said, "Naval warfare has its ways," and without wearing armor hitatare, he wore a small-sleeved robe of Kara-weave dye, donned armor laced with Kara-damask, belted a strongly made great sword, bore twenty-four hawk-feather arrows, and held a rattan-wrapped bow.
Since he was the strongest archer and finest soldier in the Royal City, there was no one who moved before his arrow point without being shot through. Among them, he aimed to shoot Kurō Taiyu Hōgan down, but the Genji side realized this, and Sato Saburobyōe Tsugunobu of Oshu, his brother Shirobyōe Tadanobu, Ise Saburo Yoshimori, Gen Hachi Hirotsuna, Eda Genzo, Kumai Taro, Musashibo Benkei, and other warriors worth a thousand men each, crying "Me too, me too," lined up their horses' heads and blocked the Great General's arrow path, so he could not reach him. "You rabble in the arrow path, get out of there!" he said, and nocking and pulling repeatedly, he shot furiously; ten-some armored horsemen were shot down in the arrow field. Among them, Sato Saburobyōe of Oshu, who had advanced to the very front, was shot right through from the left shoulder to the right armpit; unable to endure for even a moment, he fell headlong from his horse with a thud. Among Lord Noto's boys was a strong man of great power named Kikuo; wearing a belly-band laced with light green, tightening the cords of a three-plate helmet, and unsheathed a white-hilted naginata, he ran forward to take Saburobyōe's head. Sato Shirobyōe, determined not to let his brother's head be taken, drew his bow and shot with a whistle. The arrow pierced right through the joining of the boy's belly-band to the other side, and he fell down in a sitting position like a dog. Seeing this, Noto-no-Kami hurriedly jumped down from the boat, and holding his bow in his left hand, lifted Kikuo-maru with his right hand and threw him clattering into the boat; although his head was not taken by the enemy, he died because it was a severe wound. This boy was originally a servant of the Sanmi of Echizen, but after the Sanmi was killed, he was employed by his younger brother Noto-no-Kami. He was eighteen years of age. Because he had let this boy be killed, he felt it was excessively pitiful, and after that he did not fight.
[11.3.4] The Judge had Sato Saburobyōe carried to the rear of the camp, dismounted from his horse, took his hand, and asked, "Saburobyōe, how do you feel?" Under his breath, he replied, "I believe this is the end." "Do you have any regrets?" he asked. "What regrets should I have? Only that I regret dying without seeing my lord rule in your time. Apart from that, for one who takes up the bow and arrow, to be struck by an enemy's arrow and die is something expected from the start. Above all, that it will be told in tales of future generations that in the Genpei War, a man called Sato Saburobyōe Tsugunobu of Oshu died in place of his lord's life on the beach of Yashima in Sanuki Province, is the honor of this life for one who takes up the bow and arrow, and a memory for the other world." Before he could finish speaking, he grew weaker and weaker; The Judge shed tears freely and asked, "Is there a noble priest in this vicinity?" Finding one, he said, "My wounded man is passing away just now; recite the sutras for one day and mourn him." He placed a gold-rimmed saddle on a black horse, thick and powerful, and gave it to that priest. This was the horse called Tayūguro, which he had received when he became a Lieutenant of the Fifth Rank. It was on this horse that he had descended the Hiyodori Pass at Ichi-no-tani. The soldiers who saw this, beginning with his younger brother Shirobyōe, all shed tears and said, "To lose one's life for the sake of this lord is not regrettable in the slightest, not even as much as dew or dust."
[] [1] Nihon Koten Bungaku Taikei (Tokyo: Iwanami Shoten, 1957, vol. 33; hereafter cited as NKBT) reads "shouting and screaming, they attacked and fought".
11.4. Nasu no Yoichi
[11.4.1] Meanwhile, men of Awa and Sanuki who had turned against the Heike and were waiting for the Genji came from this peak and that cave, fourteen or fifteen horsemen, or twenty, appearing one after another, so that The Judge's force soon became more than three hundred horsemen. "Today the sun has set; we cannot decide the victory." Just as they were withdrawing, a single small boat, beautifully decorated, rowed towards the beach from the open sea. When it was about seven or eight tan from the shore, it turned sideways. While they wondered what this was, from within the boat, a lady of perhaps eighteen or nineteen years, truly elegant and beautiful, wearing a five-layer robe of willow combination and crimson hakama, placed a fan with a red sun circle on a pole, set it up on the gunwale of the boat, and beckoned towards the land. The Judge called Goto Byōe Sanemoto and asked, "What is that?" He replied, "It seems she is saying to shoot it. However, if the Great General steps forward to the arrow path and looks at the beauty, I suspect it is a plot to have a skilled archer aim and shoot him down. Be that as it may. I believe she is challenging us to shoot the fan."
"Who is there on our side who can shoot it?" he asked. "Among the many skilled archers, there is Yoichi Munetaka, son of Nasu no Taro Suketaka, a resident of Shimotsuke Province; though he is a small soldier, he is skilled." "What is the proof?" he asked. "When competing at chasing birds and the like, he is a man who invariably shoots down two out of three." "Then summon him." So he was summoned. Yoichi was a man of about twenty at that time. Wearing a hitatare of red brocade with collar and sleeve edges of a different color, and armor laced with light green, he belted a sword with silver fittings; carrying mottled arrows that remained from that day's battle, he carried them high on his back, and attached a whistling arrow with staghorn fittings and hawk feathers mixed with thin mottled feathers. Holding a rattan-wrapped bow under his arm, he took off his helmet and hung it on the cords, and bowed before The Judge. "Now, Munetaka, shoot the center of that fan and let the Heike see." Yoichi reverently replied, "It is uncertain whether I can shoot it. If I should miss, it would be a lasting disgrace to your side. Perhaps you should order someone who can do it for certain."
The Judge became very angry and said, "Those lords who left Kamakura and headed for the western provinces must not disobey Yoshitsune's command. Anyone who harbors even a little objection should return from here quickly." Yoichi perhaps thought it would be bad to refuse again, so he said, "I do not know about others, but since it is your command, I will try to do it." Leaving the presence, he mounted a black horse, thick and powerful, with small tasseled cruppers and a saddle rubbed with circular patterns. Fixing his grip on the bow and gathering the reins, he walked towards the water's edge; the soldiers of his side watched his back from afar and said, "This young man seems certain to do it." The Judge also looked on with confidence. Since the arrow distance was a little far, he rode into the sea about one tan, but the fan still seemed to be about seven tan away. It was around the Hour of the Rooster on the eighteenth day of the Second Month; just then the north wind was fierce, and the waves striking the shore were high. The boat was tossed up and down and drifted, so the fan also fluttered on the pole without staying still. In the open sea, the Heike lined up their ships all across to watch. On land, the Genji lined up their bits to watch this. There was no one who did not think it a grand spectacle. Yoichi closed his eyes and prayed, "Namu Hachiman Great Bodhisattva, and especially the gods of my own province, Nikko Gongen of Utsunomiya, and Nasu Yuzen Great Deity, I pray, let me shoot the center of that fan. If I miss this, I shall break my bow and commit suicide, and never face people again. If you intend for me to return once more to my home province, do not let this arrow miss." When he prayed thus in his heart and opened his eyes, the wind had weakened a little, and the fan had become easier to shoot. Yoichi took the whistling arrow, nocked it, pulled well, and released it with a whistle. Since he was a small soldier, the arrow was twelve fists and three fingers long, and the bow was strong; it resonated long across the bay, and without error, leaving about one inch from the rivet of the fan, it cut through with a hiss. As the whistling arrow entered the sea, the fan flew up into the sky. For a moment it flashed in the empty sky, then tossed once or twice by the spring wind, it fell suddenly into the sea. When the crimson fan with the red sun drifted on the white waves, shining in the setting sun, floating and sinking and rocking, out at sea the Heike tapped their gunwales in admiration. On land, the Genji tapped their quivers and made a commotion.
11.5. The Dropped Bow
[11.5.1] Perhaps unable to endure his emotion at the excessive delight of it, a man of about fifty years appeared from within the boat, wearing armor laced with black leather and holding a white-hilted naginata, and danced excellently at the place where the fan had stood. Ise Saburo Yoshimori walked his horse up behind Yoichi and said, "It is the command; do it." This time, he took a middle arrow, nocked it, pulled well, and shot the man right through the neck bone with a whistle and a thud, shooting him down headfirst into the bottom of the boat. On the Heike side there was no sound; on the Genji side they again tapped their quivers and made a commotion. Some said, "Ah, well shot." Others said, "It is heartless."
The Heike must have thought this deplorable; three warriors landed on the beach, one with a shield, one with a bow, and one with a naginata, and setting up the shield, they beckoned, "Approach, enemy."
The Judge said, "Hey, young retainers with strong horses, gallop close and kick them scattering." Five horsemen—Mihoya Shiro, To-shichi, and Juro, residents of Musashi Province; Niu no Shiro, resident of Kozuke Province; and Kiso no Nakaji, resident of Shinano Province—rode together, shouting. From behind the shield, with a lacquered shaft and a great arrow fitted with a black horo, the enemy shot Mihoya no Juro, who had advanced to the very front, right through the breast-strap of his horse's left side, burying the arrow so deep the nock was hidden. As the horse fell with a thud like a folding screen being knocked over, the master stepped over the right leg, dismounted to the left, and immediately drew his sword. Since the enemy came attacking from the shadow of the shield brandishing a great naginata, Mihoya no Juro, perhaps thinking his small sword could not match the great naginata, turned and fled; the enemy immediately continued to chase him. Just when it looked like he would sweep him with the naginata, he did not, but tucked the naginata under his left arm, reached out his right hand, and tried to grab the neck-guard of Mihoya Juro's helmet. Juro ran trying not to be grabbed. Three times he grabbed and missed; the fourth time he grabbed firmly. For a moment, they seemed to halt. Then, tearing it off completely from the bowl-plate, Juro escaped. The remaining four horsemen, sparing their horses, did not charge but sat watching. Mihoya Juro fled into the shadow of his own side's horses and rested his breath. The enemy did not come in pursuit, but resting on his naginata as a staff, he raised the neck-guard of the helmet high, lifted his great voice, and announced his name before returning: "You have heard of me by rumor these past days. Now behold me with your eyes. I am the one known to the children of the capital as Akushichibyōe Kagekiyo of Kazusa."
[11.5.2] The Heike, recovering their spirits at this, said, "Do not let Akushichibyōe be killed. Continue, men!" And another two hundred-some men landed on the beach, set up shields in a shield-wall, and beckoned, "Approach, enemy."
The Judge saw this and said, "This is unsettling." Placing Goto Byōe father and son and the Kaneko brothers in the front, Sato Shirobyōe of Oshu and Ise Saburo on the left and right, and Tashiro no Kaja in the rear, eighty-some horsemen shouted and charged; since the Heike soldiers were mostly foot soldiers and did not ride horses, they retreated to avoid being hit by the horses and all boarded the ships. The shields were kicked and scattered like divination sticks. The Genji soldiers, riding on their victory, rode into the water until it reached their horses' bellies and fought attacking. While The Judge was fighting deep in the water, someone from inside a ship used a rake to hook the neck-guard of The Judge's helmet, striking it clatteringly two or three times; while his own soldiers were knocking it away with swords and naginata, somehow The Judge dropped his bow. He bent down and tried to rake it in with his whip to pick it up; his soldiers said, "Just leave it, sir." But in the end he picked it up and returned laughing. The elders snapped their fingers and said, "That was a regrettable thing, sir. Even if it were a treasure worth a thousand or ten thousand pieces of gold, how could you exchange it for your life?" When they said this, The Judge said, "If I picked it up because I regretted losing the bow, that would be one thing. If it were a bow that took two men to string, or perhaps three men to string, like my uncle Tametomo's bow, I would even drop it on purpose and let them take it. But it would be regrettable if the enemy took up this weak little bow and mocked me, saying 'This is the bow of the Great General of the Genji, Kurō Yoshitsune.' That is why I picked it up at the risk of my life." When he said this, everyone was impressed by it.
[11.5.3] Meanwhile, as the sun set, the Heike ships floated in the offing, and the Genji withdrew to land, taking up positions in the fields and mountains of Mure and Takamatsu. The Genji soldiers had not slept for these three days. The night before last, when they left Watanabe and Fukushima, they were tossed by great waves and did not sleep a wink; yesterday they fought at Katsuura in Awa Province and crossed the mountains all night; today again they spent the whole day fighting; so they were all exhausted, and some using helmets as pillows, others using armor sleeves or quivers as pillows, they lay down oblivious to front or rear. Among them, The Judge and Ise Saburo did not sleep. The Judge climbed to a high place and looked into the distance to see if the enemy was approaching; Ise Saburo hid in a hollow, waiting to shoot the horses in the belly first if the enemy approached. On the Heike side, with Noto-no-Kami as Great General, five hundred-some horsemen prepared to make a night attack, but Etchu Jirobyōe Moritsugu and Ebi Jiro Morikata disputed over the vanguard, and while they did so, the night dawned in vain. If they had only made a night attack, how could the Genji have withstood it? That they did not attack was indeed the end of their luck.
11.6. The Battle of Shido
[11.6.1] When it dawned, the Heike boarded their ships and rowed away to Shido Bay in the same province. From among his three hundred-some riders, The Judge selected eighty-some men and horses and chased after them. The Heike saw this and said, "The enemy is a small force. Let us hem them in and kill them." And a thousand-some men landed on the beach again, shouting and screaming, and attacked and fought. Meanwhile, the two hundred-some riders who had remained behind at Yashima came galloping late. The Heike saw this and said, "Look, the main force of the Genji continues. There must be tens of thousands of riders. If we are hemmed in, we cannot prevail." So they boarded their ships again, and pulled by the tide and following the wind, pointing nowhere in particular, they fled and went. In Shikoku they were all chased down by Kurō Taiyu Hōgan, and they could not enter the Nine Provinces [Kyushu]; they seemed truly like living beings in the intermediate state [between death and rebirth].
[11.6.2] The Judge sat down at Shido Bay and was inspecting the heads, when he called Ise Saburo Yoshimori and said: "Awa Minbu Shigeyoshi's heir, Tauchi Saemon Noriyoshi, crossed over to Iyo with three thousand-some riders to attack Kono Shiro Michinobu who did not come when summoned; he failed to kill Kono, but cut off the heads of one hundred and fifty family members and retainers and brought them to the Palace at Yashima yesterday; but I hear he is arriving here today. You go to face him, deceive him somehow, and bring him here." When he ordered this, Yoshimori reverently accepted, and without being given even a single banner, with a force of merely sixteen riders, all in white gear, he galloped out to face him. Yoshimori met Noriyoshi. The white banners and red banners waved at each other separated by about two chō. Ise Saburo Yoshimori sent a messenger and said, "I am called Ise Saburo Yoshimori, a retainer of the Great General of the Genji, Kurō Taiyu Hōgan-dono; I have come this far because I have matters to speak of to your General. Since this is not for the purpose of battle, I have no armor, nor do I carry a bow and arrow; please open up and let me enter." When he said this, the soldiers of the three thousand-some riders opened the center and let him pass. Yoshimori rode up alongside Noriyoshi and said, "You may have heard a little of this: the younger brother of the Lord of Kamakura, Kurō Taiyu Hōgan-dono, received a Cloistered Decree and headed to the western provinces to pursue and strike down the Heike; the day before yesterday at Katsuura in Awa Province, your uncle Sakurama no Suke was killed. Yesterday he attacked Yashima and burned away the Imperial Palace entirely; he captured the Minister father and son alive, and Lord Noto committed suicide. Of the other lords, some died in battle, others entered the sea. The few remaining partisans were all killed at Shido Bay. Your father, Awa Minbu-dono, came as a surrendered prisoner, and I, Yoshimori, am keeping him; he lamented all night, saying, 'Alas, Tauchi Saemon knows not even a dream of this, and tomorrow he will fight and be killed; what a pity,' and out of excessive love he wished to let you know this, so I have come this far. Now, whether you fight and die in battle, or come as a surrendered prisoner and see your father one more time, it is entirely your plan." When he said this, Tauchi Saemon, though a renowned soldier, perhaps had his luck run out. "It does not differ in the slightest from what I have heard." Saying this, he took off his helmet, loosened his bowstring, and gave them to his retainer. Since the General behaved this way, the soldiers of the three thousand-some riders were all like this. Accompanied by merely sixteen riders, he came shamelessly as a surrendered prisoner. "Yoshimori's strategy was truly terrific." Even The Judge was impressed. Immediately Tauchi Saemon's weapons were taken, and he was entrusted to Ise Saburo. "Now, what about those troops?" When he asked, the men of the distant provinces said, "Whom should we think of as whom? We shall consider the one who calms the disorder of the world and rules the province to be our lord." Since they said this, saying it was quite right, he added the three thousand-some riders to his own force.
[11.6.3] On the twenty-second day of the same month, around the Hour of the Dragon, the two hundred-some ships that had remained at Watanabe, with Kajiwara in the lead, arrived at the beach of Yashima. "Shikoku has been entirely attacked and taken by Kurō Taiyu Hōgan. What use is there to meet now? A flower that missed the meeting, an iris on the sixth day, a pledge after the quarrel." So they laughed.
[11.6.4] After The Judge left the capital, the priest of Sumiyoshi, Nagamori, went to the Cloistered Palace and reported through the Treasurer Yasutsune Ason: "On the past sixteenth day at the Hour of the Ox, the sound of a whistling arrow came from the Third Sanctuary of this shrine and went pointing toward the West." When he said this, the Cloistered Emperor was greatly impressed, and sent swords and various sacred treasures via Nagamori to the Great Deity. Long ago, when Empress Jingu attacked Silla, the Great Shrine of Ise assigned the rough spirits of two gods to accompany her. The two gods stood at the stern and bow of the Imperial Ship, and Silla was easily attacked and conquered. After returning to the court, one god stayed in the district of Sumiyoshi in Settsu Province. This is Sumiyoshi Daimyojin. The other god left traces in the district of Suwa in Shinano Province. This is Suwa Daimyojin. Not forgetting the punishment of ancient times, surely now too they will destroy the enemies of the court; thus the Sovereign and subjects felt encouraged.
11.7. Cockfighting and The Battle of Dan-no-ura
[11.7.1] Meanwhile, Kurō Taiyu Hōgan Yoshitsune crossed over to the land of Suo and joined with his brother Mikawa-no-kami. The Heike arrived at Hikushima in Nagato Province. The Genji arrived at Katsuura in Awa Province and won the battle of Yashima. Hearing that the Heike arrived at Hikushima, it is strange that the Genji arrived at Oitsu in the same province.
[11.7.2] Kumano Betto Tanzo was a man who owed heavy debts of gratitude to the Heike, but suddenly forgetting those debts, he said, "Should I join the Heike, or should I join the Genji?" He performed sacred Kagura music at the New Shrine of Tanabe and prayed to the Avatar. There was an oracle saying, "Just follow the white flag." Still doubting, he took seven white cocks and seven red cocks and made them fight before the Avatar to decide victory. Not a single red cock won; all were defeated. So he decided to join the Genji. Gathering the members of his family, in all a force of more than two thousand men, riding in more than two hundred ships, he placed the sacred emblem of Nyakuoji on a ship, painted the Diamond Child on the top of the banner, and when they saw him approaching Dan-no-ura, both Genji and Heike bowed. However, when he joined the Genji side, the Heike were disappointed. Also, a resident of Iyo Province, Kono Shiro Michinobu, riding in one hundred and fifty warships, came rowing and became one with the Genji. The Judge felt empowered and gained strength. The Genji ships were three thousand; the Heike ships were one thousand-some, with a few Chinese ships mixed in. As the Genji force gained weight, the Heike force was declining.
[11.7.3] In the second year of Genryaku, on the twenty-fourth day of the Third Month at the Hour of the Rabbit, at Akamaseki in Moji, Buzen Province, the arrow exchange between Genji and Heike was decided. On that day, The Judge and Kajiwara were about to fight each other. Kajiwara said to The Judge, "Grant the vanguard today to Kagetoki." The Judge said, "If Yoshitsune were not here, perhaps." He said, "You are the Great General." The Judge said, "Unthinkable; the Lord of Kamakura is the Great General. Since Yoshitsune is a person who has received a commission, I am just the same as you lords."
Kajiwara, unable to obtain the vanguard, muttered, "By nature, this lord is difficult to be a master of samurai."
The Judge heard this and said, "The biggest fool in Japan!" And he placed his hand on the hilt of his sword. Kajiwara said, "I have no master other than the Lord of Kamakura." And he too placed his hand on the hilt of his sword. At that, his heir Genta Kagesue, second son Heiji Kagetaka, and third son Kageie gathered in one place with their father. Seeing The Judge's mood, Sato Shirobyōe Tadanobu of Oshu, Ise Saburo Yoshimori, Gen Hachi Hirotsuna, Eda Genzo, Kumai Taro, Musashibo Benkei, and other warriors worth a thousand men each, surrounded Kajiwara and advanced to kill him. However, Miura-no-Suke held onto The Judge, and Doi Jiro grabbed Kajiwara; rubbing their hands, the two men said, "While holding such a great matter before us, if allies fight, the Heike will gain strength. Above all, it will not be peaceful when the Lord of Kamakura hears of it." So they spoke, and The Judge calmed down. Kajiwara did not advance. From that time, Kajiwara began to hate The Judge, and in the end he slandered him and destroyed him; so it was heard later.
[11.7.4] Now, the distance between the Genji and Heike lines on the surface of the sea was thirty-some chō. Since Moji, Akama, and Dan-no-ura have a boiling and falling tide, the Genji ships faced the tide and were pushed back against their will. The Heike ships came out following the tide. Since the tide was fast in the open sea, Kajiwara stuck to the shore, and where he passed enemy ships, he hooked them with rakes; father, sons, master and retainers, fourteen or fifteen men, boarded and transferred, drew weapons, slashed around furiously at stern and bow, took many spoils, and were recorded as the first in renown for that day. Already, both Genji and Heike armies met and raised their battle cries. It seemed that above, it was heard as far as the Brahma Heaven, and below, the Dragon Gods of the sea were startled. The New Middle Counselor Tomomori stood on the deckhouse of his ship, raised a great voice, and said: "The battle is decided today. Men, you must not have even a little thought of retreating. Even if one is called a peerless famous general or brave warrior in India, China, or our court of Japan, if fate is ended, one cannot prevail. However, the name is regrettable. Do not look weak to the men of the eastern provinces. For when should we spare our lives? Think only of this." When he said this, Hida Saburo Saemon Kagehisa, who was serving in his presence, ordered: "Listen to this, samurai."
Kazusa Akushichi Byōe came forward and said, "Though Bando warriors may talk big on horseback, when would they have trained for naval warfare? At best they are like fish climbing a tree. I will pick them up one by one and put them in the sea." So he spoke. Etchu no Jirobyōe spoke: "If you grapple, grapple with the Great General Minamoto no Kurō. Kurō is pale and small in stature, and his buckteeth stick out noticeably. However, since he constantly changes his hitatare and armor, it is hard to distinguish him quickly." So he spoke. Kazusa Akushichi Byōe spoke: "Though his heart be fierce, what of that little page? I will tuck him under my arm and put him in the sea." So he spoke. The New Middle Counselor gave orders like this, and went to the presence of the Minister and said, "The samurai look good today. However, Awa Minbu Shigeyoshi seems to have changed his heart. I should like to cut off his head." When he said this, the Minister said, "Without any visible proof, how can we cut off his head? He is a man who has served so well." "Summon Shigeyoshi." When he was summoned, wearing a hitatare of magnolia cloth and armor of washed leather, he bowed in the presence. "Well, Shigeyoshi, have you changed your heart? You look bad today. Order the men of Shikoku to fight well. Do not be cowardly." When he said this, Shigeyoshi said, "Why should I be cowardly?" And he left the presence. The New Middle Counselor thought, "Ah, I wish I could cut off that fellow's head," and gripping the hilt of his sword as if to crush it, he looked frequently at the Minister, but since there was no permission, he could do nothing.
[11.7.5] The Heike made their thousand-some ships into three groups. Yamaga no Hyodo Ji Hideto rowed in the vanguard with five hundred-some ships. The Matsura band followed in the second group with three hundred-some ships. The Heike lords followed in the third group with two hundred-some ships. Yamaga no Hyodo Ji Hideto was the finest soldier in the Nine Provinces; choosing five hundred soldiers who, while not his equal, were superior to the ordinary, he placed them at the bows and sterns of the ships, lined up their shoulders all across, and shot five hundred arrows at once. Since the Genji had three thousand-some ships, their numbers were indeed many, but since they were shot at from various places, it did not seem there were fine soldiers anywhere. The Great General Kurō Taiyu Hōgan fought advancing to the very front. Neither shields nor armor could withstand it, and they were shot through and scattered. The Heike thought their side had won, and beating their attack drums furiously, they raised a shout of victory.
11.8. Long Distance Arrows
[11.8.1] On the Genji side, Wada Kotaro Yoshimori did not board a ship, but rode his horse, holding back on the beach; taking off his helmet and giving it to someone, stepping deep into his stirrups, he pulled well and shot; anything within three chō he shot strongly without missing. Among the arrows, one seemed to have been shot particularly far; he beckoned, "Return that arrow."
The New Middle Counselor ordered it brought and looked at it; it was a white shaft with crane fletchings mixed with root-white feathers, thirteen fists and two fingers long; about one fist from the binding, "Wada Kotaro Taira no Yoshimori" was written in lacquer. Although there were many fine soldiers on the Heike side, perhaps there were few who could shoot long distance arrows; after a while, Nii no Kishiro Chikakiyo, a resident of Iyo Province, was summoned, given this arrow, and shot it back. This too shot right across more than three chō from the open sea to the beach, and struck deeply into the left arm of Miura no Ishida Sakon Taro, who was holding back more than one tan behind Wada Kotaro. The Miura men saw this and laughed, saying, "How funny that Wada Kotaro thought there was no one who could shoot a long distance arrow better than himself, and disgraced himself. Look at that."
Wada Kotaro heard this, and saying "This is unsettling," boarded a small boat, had it rowed out, and nocking and pulling repeatedly amidst the Heike forces, shot furiously; many men were shot to death or wounded. Also, shooting a large white-shafted arrow into the ship where The Judge was riding from the open sea, the enemy beckoned in the manner of Wada, "Return this."
The Judge had it pulled out and looked at it; it was a white shaft fletched with copper pheasant tail feathers, fourteen fists and three fingers long, and "Nii no Kishiro Chikakiyo, resident of Iyo Province" was written on it. The Judge called Goto Byōe Sanemoto and asked, "Who is there on our side who can shoot this arrow?" He replied, "Among the Kai Genji, Asari no Yoichi-dono is a fine soldier." "Then call him." When he was called, Asari no Yoichi appeared. The Judge said, "They shot this arrow from the open sea and beckoned to shoot it back. Can you do it?" "Let me see it." Testing it with his fingernail, he said, "This shaft is a little weak. The length is also a bit short. If it is all the same, I shall do it with Yoshinari's own gear." taking a lacquered rattan bow about nine feet long, and nocking a lacquered shaft fitted with a black horo, fifteen fists long which he grasped in his great hand, he pulled well and released it with a whistle. It shot right across more than four chō, and struck Nii no Kishiro Chikakiyo, who was standing on the prow of a great ship, right in the middle of his chest with a whistle and a thud, shooting him down upside down into the bottom of the ship. Whether he lived or died was unknown. Asari no Yoichi was a skilled fine soldier from the start. It was heard that he shot running deer at two chō without missing. After that, Genji and Heike, not sparing their lives in battle, shouted and screamed and attacked and fought. Neither appeared inferior. However, since the Heike side possessed the Ten Virtues Sovereign and the Three Sacred Treasures, the Genji thought "How will it be?" and felt it was dangerous; for a moment, something that seemed like a white cloud drifted in the empty sky, but it was not a cloud; a single white banner with no owner floated down and the cord caught on the prow of the Genji ship. The Judge said, "This is Hachiman Great Bodhisattva manifesting himself." Rejoicing, he washed his hands and rinsed his mouth, and bowed to it. The soldiers all did likewise. Also, from the direction of the Genji, one or two thousand fish called dolphins came swimming towards the Heike. The Minister saw this and called the Doctor Seishin, saying: "Dolphins are always numerous, but never like this. Divine what this means." When he ordered this, he said, "If these dolphins turn back, the Genji will be destroyed. If they swim through, your side's battle is dangerous." Before he could finish speaking, they swam straight through under the Heike ships. "The world is over now." So he spoke.
[11.8.2] Awa Minbu Shigeyoshi had served the Heike faithfully for these three years, and in repeated battles had fought defending them without sparing his life, but his son Tauchi Saemon having been captured, perhaps he thought he could not prevail; he suddenly changed his heart and agreed with the Genji. On the Heike side, as a stratagem, they had put fine men in the warships, and put common soldiers in the Chinese ships, preparing to hem in and kill the Genji if they attacked the Chinese ships thinking them attractive targets; but due to Awa Minbu's betrayal, the Genji paid no attention to the Chinese ships, but attacked the warships where the Great General was riding in disguise. The New Middle Counselor regretted a thousand times, saying "Unsettling! I should have cut down that Shigeyoshi and discarded him," but it was no use. Meanwhile, the soldiers of Shikoku and Chinzei all turned against the Heike and attached to the Genji. Those who had followed and arrived until now drew their bows against their lords and drew their swords against their masters. If they tried to land on the far shore, the waves were high and it was difficult. If they tried to approach this beach, the enemy waited with arrow points lined up. The struggle for the country between Genji and Heike seemed limited to this day.
11.9. The Former Emperor Jumps
[11.9.1] The Genji soldiers already boarded the Heike ships; the sailors and helmsmen were shot to death or cut to death and could not manage the ships, falling prostrate in the bottoms of the ships. The New Middle Counselor Tomomori boarded a small boat and went to the Imperial Ship. "The world now seems to be like this. Throw all unsightly things into the sea." Saying this, he ran around the stern and bow, sweeping and wiping, picking up dust, and cleaning with his own hands. The ladies-in-waiting asked with their mouths, "Middle Counselor-dono, how is the battle?" He laughed loudly and said, "You shall see some rare eastern men." "What sort of joke is this now?" And they shouted and screamed with their voices. The Nun of the Second Rank, seeing this state of affairs, had expected it for days; wearing a double-layered robe of dark grey mournful colors, tucking up her glossed hakama high at the sides, holding the Sacred Jewel under her arm, wearing the Sacred Sword at her waist, and holding the Sovereign in her arms, she said, "Though my body is a woman's, I will not fall into the enemy's hands. I am accompanying the Sovereign. Those who have the intention, follow quickly." And she stepped out to the gunwale. Although the Sovereign was eight years old this year, he looked far more mature than his age, and his appearance was beautiful, illuminating the vicinity. His black hair hung loosely down his back. With a surprised look, he asked, "Nun, where are you taking me?" Facing the young Lord, she suppressed her tears and spoke: "Do you not know, my Lord? Though by the power of the Ten Good Precepts practiced in previous lives, you were born as the master of ten thousand chariots, drawn by evil karma, your luck has already ended. First, face East and say farewell to the Great Shrine of Ise, then trust in the Welcoming of the Pure Land of the West, face West, and say the Nembutsu. Since this country is a land of sorrow called the Millet-Scattered Border Land, I am taking you to a magnificent place called the Pure Land of Ultimate Bliss." When she spoke weeping, he wore a dove-grey robe, his hair tied in loops; drowning in tears, he placed his small beautiful hands together, first bowed to the East to say farewell to the Great Shrine of Ise, then faced West and said the Nembutsu. The Nun of the Second Rank immediately held him and comforting him saying, "Under the waves there is a capital too," she entered the bottom of a thousand fathoms. Ah tragic, the impermanent spring wind suddenly scattered the flower of his appearance; heartless, the rough waves of separation sank the Jade Body. Though the Palace was named Long Life to determine a long dwelling, and the Gate was called Ageless to write of a door that does not age, not yet within ten years of age, he became debris at the bottom of the water. The reward of the Ten Virtues Imperial Throne was truly futile. The Dragon above the clouds descended and became a fish at the bottom of the sea. On top of the pavilion of the Great Brahma High Terrace, inside the Palace of Sakra, long ago commanding the nine clans within the Enju Gates, now in a boat under the waves, to lose his life in a single moment is indeed sad.
11.10. The End of Lord Noto
[11.10.1] The Imperial Lady [Kenreimon-in] saw this scene; putting heavy stones and inkstones into her left and right pockets, she entered the sea, but Gengo Umanojo of the Watanabe band, not knowing who she was, hooked her hair with a rake and pulled her up. The ladies-in-waiting said with their voices, "Ah, how terrible, that is the Imperial Lady." He reported this to The Judge and hurriedly transferred her to the Imperial Ship. Dainagon-no-Suke tried to enter the sea holding the box of the Naishidokoro [Sacred Mirror], but the hem of her hakama got caught on the gunwale, she tripped and fell, and the soldiers detained her. Then the warriors twisted off the lock of the box of the Naishidokoro and were about to open the lid when suddenly their eyes went dark and their noses bled. Taira Dainagon, who had been captured, said, "That is the Naishidokoro. It is something ordinary mortals must not look at." So the soldiers all backed away. After that, The Judge consulted with Taira Dainagon and tied it up as before.
[11.10.2] Meanwhile, Kadowaki Taira Chūnagon Norimori and Shuri-no-Daibu Tsunemori, brothers, carrying anchors on top of their armor and taking hand in hand, entered the sea. Komatsu New Sanmi Chūjō Sukemori, his brother Shōshō Arimori, and cousin Sama-no-Kami Yukimori took hand in hand and sank together in one place. Although people did this, the Minister father and son showed no sign of entering the sea; standing on the gunwale and looking around in all directions, they seemed bewildered, so the samurai, out of excessive disgust, passed by them and pushed the Minister into the sea. The Right Gate Watch [Kiyomune] saw this and immediately jumped in. Everyone else sank because they entered carrying or holding heavy objects on top of heavy armor. This father and son did not do so, and since they were excellent swimmers, they did not sink. The Minister thought, "If the Right Gate Watch sinks, I too shall sink; if he is saved, I too shall be saved."
The Right Gate Watch also thought, "If Father sinks, I too shall sink; if he is saved, I too shall be saved." While they swam around looking at each other's eyes, Ise Saburo Yoshimori rowed a small boat up and first pulled the Right Gate Watch up with a rake. The Minister saw this, and since he did not sink at all, he too was taken.
[11.10.3] The Minister's wet nurse's son, Hida Saburo Saemon Kagehisa, boarded a small boat, transferred to Yoshimori's boat, and saying "Who is taking my lord?", drew his sword and rushed at him. Yoshimori appeared to be in danger, but Yoshimori's page stepped in between to prevent his master from being killed, and struck at Kagehisa. By Kagehisa's striking sword, Yoshimori's page had his helmet bowl split, and with the second stroke his head was cut off. Yoshimori still appeared to be in danger, but from a neighboring ship, Hori Yataro Chikatsune pulled well and shot with a thud. As Kagehisa flinched from being shot inside his helmet, Hori Yataro transferred to Yoshimori's ship, grappled Saburo Saemon, and pinned him down. Hori's retainer followed his master and transferred, lifted the skirt of Kagehisa's armor, and stabbed him twice. Hida Saburo Saemon Kagehisa was a renowned strong man of great power, but his luck must have run out. He was wounded, enemies were many, and finally he was killed there. The Minister was taken alive and watched his milk-brother being killed before his eyes; how must he have felt?
[11.10.4] Generally, there was no one who survived facing the arrow point of Noto-no-Kami Noritsune. Having shot all the arrows he had, perhaps thinking this was the end, he wore a hitatare of red brocade and armor laced with Kara-damask, drew a strongly made great sword, removed the sheath of a white-hilted great naginata, and holding them in left and right hands, he slashed around; there was no one to face him, and many men were killed. The New Middle Counselor sent a messenger saying, "Noto-dono, do not create too much sin. Is there a worthy enemy?" He understood, "Then I should grapple with the Great General." Holding his weapons with shortened handles, he transferred to a Genji ship, shouting and screaming, and attacked and fought. However, since he did not know The Judge by sight, he rushed around eyeing any warrior with fine armor, thinking "Is that The Judge?" The Judge also realized this beforehand and positioned himself to face him, but dodging this way and that, he was not grappled by Lord Noto. However, somehow, he rode his ship against The Judge's ship, and eyeing him saying "There!", he jumped at him; The Judge must have thought he could not prevail; tucking his naginata under his arm, he jumped nimbly onto a ship of his own side about two jō away. Lord Noto was perhaps inferior in agility. He did not jump after him immediately. Thinking "this is the end," he threw his sword and naginata into the sea, took off his helmet and discarded it. He tore off the skirt of his armor and discarded it, wearing only the cuirass; with disheveled hair and spreading his great hands, he stood there. He truly looked like a terrifying deity. To say it was frightening is an understatement. Lord Noto raised a great voice and said, "Those who think themselves worthy, come grapple with Noritsune and take me alive. I intend to go down to Kamakura, meet Yoritomo, and say one word. Come, come." Although he said this, there was not a single person who approached. Here there was a resident of Tosa Province, son of the District Headman of Aki Saneyasu who ruled the village of Aki, named Aki Taro Sanemitsu; he was a strong man of great power possessing the strength of thirty men. There was one retainer not a bit inferior to himself, and his younger brother Jiro was also a tough man superior to the ordinary. Aki Taro saw Lord Noto and said, "However fierce his heart may be, if we three grapple him, even if he were a demon ten jō tall, how could we not subdue him?" Master and retainers, three men, rode a small boat, pushed alongside Lord Noto's boat, boarded with a shout, tilted their neck-guards, drew their swords, and attacked all at once. Lord Noto did not panic in the slightest; waiting for Aki Taro's retainer who advanced first to grapple with him, he kicked him into the sea with a thud. Grasping Aki Taro who approached next under his left arm, and tucking the brother Jiro under his right arm, he squeezed them tight once, and saying, "Come on then, you fellows, accompany me on the mountain of death," at the age of twenty-six, he entered the sea.
11.11. The Naishidokoro Enters the Capital
[11.11.1] The New Middle Counselor said, "I have seen what I should see; now I shall commit suicide." Calling his milk-brother Iga Hei-nai Saemon Ienaga, he asked, "Well, surely you will not break our promise of many days?" He replied, "Is there any need for details?"
He helped the Middle Counselor put on two suits of armor, and wearing two suits of armor himself, they clasped their hands together and entered the sea. Seeing this, twenty-some samurai, determined not to be left behind, clasped hand in hand and sank in one place. Among them, Etchu Jirobyōe, Kazusa Gorobyōe, Akushichibyōe, and Hida Shirobyōe, somehow having escaped, fled from there too. On the surface of the sea, red banners and red streamers were thrown away and discarded; it was like red maple leaves on the Tatsuta River scattered by the storm. The white waves approaching the shore also turned pale red. The empty ships without masters, pulled by the tide and following the wind, rocked and went pointing nowhere; it was truly sad. As for the captives: Former Minister of the Center Lord Munemori, Taira Dainagon Tokitada, Uemon-no-Kami Kiyomune, Kura-no-Kami Nobumoto, Sanuki Chūjō Tokizane, Hyobu-no-Shōyu Masaaki, and the Minister's young lord who was eight years old; as for the monks, Nii Sozu Senshin, Hosshōji Shigyō Noen, Chūnagon Risshi Chūkai, Kyōjō-bō Ajari Yūen; as for the samurai, Gen Taiyu Hōgan Suesada, Settsu Hōgan Morizumi, Kitsunai Saemon Sueyasu, Tonai Saemon Nobuyasu, and Awa Minbu Shigeyoshi father and son; in all thirty-eight people. Kikuchi Jiro Takanao and Harada Taiyu Tanenao had come as surrendered prisoners with their retainers before the battle. As for the ladies-in-waiting: the Imperial Lady, the Northern Mandokoro, the Lady of the Corridor, Dainagon-no-Suke, Daini-no-Suke, Jibu-kyo-no-Tsubone, and others; it was heard there were forty-three people. [][2] At the end of the spring of the second year of Genryaku, in what kind of times, did one sink to the bottom of the sea while the Hundred Officials floated on the waves? The Mother of the Country and the court ladies followed the hands of the eastern barbarians and western savages; the ministers and high courtiers were captured by the soldiers of the myriads of armies; as they returned to their old village, some lamented like Zhu Maichen not wearing brocade, and others grieved like Wang Zhaojun going to the Hu lands, thinking "Is it like this?"
[11.11.2] On the third day of the Fourth Month, Kurō Taiyu Hōgan Yoshitsune reported to the Cloistered Palace through Gen Hachi Hirotsuna: "On the past twenty-fourth day of the Third Month, at Ta-no-ura Moji-no-Seki in Buzen Province and Dan-no-ura Akama-no-Seki in Nagato Province, we attacked and defeated the Heike and have returned the Three Sacred Treasures without incident." When this was reported, high and low within the Cloistered Palace were in a tumult. Hirotsuna was summoned into the courtyard, and upon asking the details of the battle, out of excessive admiration, the Emperor made him a Lieutenant of the Left Gate Watch. "Go and see if the Naishidokoro [Sacred Mirror] is certainly returning." Saying this, on the fifth day, Tou no Hangan Nobumori, who served in the North Face, was sent to the western provinces. Without even returning to his lodging, he immediately received a horse from the Cloistered Emperor, raised his whip, and galloped down pointing west.
[11.11.3] On the fourteenth day of the same month, Kurō Taiyu Hōgan Yoshitsune went up toward the capital accompanied by the Taira men and women captives, and they arrived at Akashi Bay in Harima Province. Since it is a famous bay, as the night deepened the moon shone clear, not inferior to the autumn sky. The ladies-in-waiting gathered and wept together in suppressed voices, saying things like, "When we passed here some years ago, we did not think it would be like this."
Daini-no-Suke gazed intently at the moon, and having no regrets left in her thoughts, with her bed floating in tears, she continued her thoughts thus:
As I gaze, it has dwelt in my tear-soaked sleeves; O Moon, tell me tales of the Cloud-Well.
[11.11.4] Jibu-kyo-no-Tsubone:
The moonlight is unchanged from when I saw it above the clouds; depending on where it dwells, things are sad.
[11.11.5] Dainagon-no-Suke:
Though I sleep on a journey at Akashi Bay, it is the moon that dwells in the same waves.
[11.11.6] "Indeed, how sad you must be, and how you must long for the past." Although The Judge was a fierce warrior, since he was a man of emotion, he felt it deeply and thought it pitiful.
[11.11.7] On the twenty-fifth day of the same month, hearing that the Naishidokoro and the Box of the Sacred Jewel had arrived at Toba, people went from the Palace to welcome them; it was heard they were Madenokōji Chūnagon Tsunefusa-kyō, Takakura Saishō Chūjō Yasumichi, Gon-no-Uchūben Kanetada, Saemon-no-Gon-no-Suke Chikamasa, Enami Chūjō Kintoki, Tajima Shōshō Noriyoshi; and for the samurai, Izu Kurōdo Taiyu Yorikane, Ishikawa Hōgandai Yoshikane, and Saemon-no-Jō Aritsuna. At the Hour of the Rat that night, the Naishidokoro and the Box of the Sacred Jewel entered the hall of the Dajōkan. The Sacred Sword was lost. The Sacred Jewel was floating on the sea, and it was heard that Kataoka Taro Tsuneharu picked it up. [] [2] NKBT has a period at this point.
11.12. The Sword
[11.12.1] In our court, there are three Spirit Swords handed down from the Age of Gods. They are the Totsuka Sword, the Ama-no-Hayakiri Sword, and the Kusanagi Sword. The Totsuka Sword is kept at the Furu Shrine in Isonokami in Yamato Province. The Ama-no-Hayakiri Sword is said to be at the Atsuta Shrine in Owari Province. The Kusanagi Sword is in the Imperial Palace. This is the current Sacred Sword. To speak of the origin of this sword: long ago, when Susano-o-no-Mikoto built a palace in the village of Soga in Izumo Province, eight-colored clouds always rose there; the Mikoto saw this and composed this poem:
Eight clouds rise; Izumo the eight-fold fence to enclose a spouse; making an eight-fold fence, oh that eight-fold fence.
[11.12.2] This is considered the beginning of the thirty-one syllables. I hear that naming the province Izumo is also because of this.
[11.12.3] Long ago, when the Mikoto descended to the headwaters of the Hi River in Izumo Province, there were earthly deities, a husband deity and wife deity, called Ashinazuchi and Tenazuchi. They had a beautiful daughter. She was called Inada-hime. Parent and child, the three of them were weeping. The Mikoto asked, "What is the matter?" and they replied, saying, "I had eight daughters. All have been swallowed by a great serpent. Now the one remaining maiden is about to be swallowed too. That great serpent has eight tails and eight heads. It crawls and spreads over eight peaks and eight valleys. Spirit trees and strange grasses grow on its back. No one knows how many thousands of years it has passed. Its eyes are like the light of the sun and moon. Every year it swallows a human. When parents are swallowed, the children grieve; when children are swallowed, the parents grieve; and the sound of wailing in the villages south and north never ceases." The Mikoto felt pity, and transforming this maiden into a sacred comb, he stuck it in his hair; he put sake into eight vats, made the figures of beautiful women, and set them on a high hill. Their reflections were cast in the sake. The great serpent thought they were humans, drank the reflections until satisfied, and lay down drunk; the Mikoto drew the Totsuka Sword he carried and cut the great serpent to pieces. However, one tail could not be cut at all. The Mikoto thought it strange, and tearing it open with the back of his sword to look, there was a single Spirit Sword. He took this and offered it to Amaterasu Omikami. She said, "This is the sword I dropped long ago in the High Plain of Heaven."
Because gathered clouds always covered it when it was in the great serpent's tail, it was called the Ama-no-Murakumo [Heavenly Gathering Clouds] Sword. The Great Deity obtained this and made it a treasure of the Imperial Palace. After that, when she sent down the Heavenly Grandson as Lord of the Central Land of Reed Plains, she presented this sword along with the Sacred Mirror. Until the time of the ninth Emperor, Kaika Tenno, it resided in the same hall [as the Emperor], but reaching the reign of the tenth Emperor, Sujin Tenno, he feared its spiritual power, and when he moved Amaterasu Omikami to the wide stone fence of the village of Kasanui in Yamato Province, he enclosed this sword in the shrine of Amaterasu Omikami. At that time, he had the sword re-forged to be his protection. Its spiritual power was not inferior to the original sword.
[11.12.4] For three generations from Sujin Tenno to Keiko Tenno, the Ama-no-Murakumo Sword was worshiped and kept at the shrine of Amaterasu Omikami; but in the sixth month of the fortieth year of Keiko Tenno's reign, when the eastern barbarians rebelled, his son Yamato Takeru-no-Mikoto, whose heart was fierce and whose strength surpassed others, was selected; when he went down to the East, he visited Amaterasu Omikami to say farewell, and through his aunt Yamato-hime-no-Mikoto, the Spirit Sword was bestowed upon the Mikoto with the words, "Be prudent and do not be negligent." Now, when he went down to Suruga Province, the rebels of that place deceived him, saying, "There are many deer in this province. Please hunt and amuse yourself." Bringing him out, they set fire to the fields and were about to burn him to death; the Mikoto drew the Spirit Sword he wore and mowed down the grass; within one ri in every direction, the grass was all mowed down. When the Mikoto set a counter-fire, the wind suddenly blew over toward the rebels, and the evil band was entirely burned to death. Because of this, the Ama-no-Murakumo Sword was named the Kusanagi [Grass-Mowing] Sword. The Mikoto invaded further into the interior, and for three years he struck down and pacified rebels in various places, and attacking and subjugating the evil bands of the provinces, he was returning to the capital; but he fell ill on the road, and in the seventh month of his thirtieth year, he finally passed away in the vicinity of Atsuta in Owari Province. It is strange that his soul became a white bird and ascended to heaven. The captive barbarians were presented to the Imperial Palace by his son Takehiko-no-Mikoto. The Kusanagi Sword was placed in the shrine of Atsuta. In the seventh year of the reign of Emperor Tenji, the Silla monk Dogyo stole this sword intending to make it a treasure of his own country, but while he had it hidden in a boat on his journey, wind and waves shook him and he was about to sink to the bottom of the sea. Knowing immediately that it was the curse of the Spirit Sword, he confessed his crime and did not accomplish his goal. He returned it as before. However, in the first year of Shuchō of Tenmu Tenno, it was summoned and placed in the Imperial Palace. This is the current Sacred Sword. Its spiritual power is swift and fierce. When the Cloistered Emperor Yozei was afflicted with madness and drew the Spirit Sword, the night palace flashed as if with lightning. In excess of terror he threw it away, and it rang by itself and inserted itself into the scabbard. In ancient times it was thus miraculous. Saying that even though the Nun of the Second Rank sank into the sea with it under her arm, it should not be easily lost, they summoned excellent divers to search for it, and had noble priests shut themselves in spiritual temples and shrines to pray offering various sacred treasures, but in the end it was lost. The experts of that time discussed it, saying: "Long ago Amaterasu Omikami made a vow to protect the hundred kings; since that vow has not yet changed and the stream of Iwashimizu has not yet run dry, the light of the sun has not yet fallen to the earth; even though it is the degenerate Latter Day, surely the end of the Imperial fortune has not come." Among them, a certain Doctor offered his opinion: "The great serpent that was cut and killed by Susano-o-no-Mikoto long ago at the headwaters of the Hi River in Izumo Province, having a deep desire to regret the Spirit Sword, used the eight heads and eight tails as a sign, became the Child Emperor of the eightieth generation of human kings, took back the Spirit Sword, and sank to the bottom of the sea." So he spoke. Since it became a treasure of the Divine Dragon at the bottom of the thousand-fathom sea, it seems reasonable that it will not return to the human world a second time.
11.13. The Family Paraded through the Streets
[11.13.1] Meanwhile, hearing that the Second Prince was returning, a carriage was sent from the Cloistered Emperor to welcome him. Having been taken by the Heike against his will and drifting on the waves of the western sea for three years, his mother and his wet nurse, the wife of Jimyōin Saishō, had thought of his case as painful; but since he returned without any particular incident, they gathered together and wept with joy.
[11.13.2] On the twenty-sixth day of the same month, the Taira captives entered the capital. They were all in small eight-leaf carts. The front and rear blinds were raised, and the side windows opened. The Minister wore a hunting robe. The Right Gate Watch, in a white hitatare, rode in the back of his father's cart. Taira Dainagon Tokitada-kyō's cart also followed. His son Sanuki Chūjō Tokizane should have been paraded in the same cart, but due to illness he was not paraded. Kura-no-Kami Nobumoto, having suffered wounds, entered by a side road. The Minister, who had been such a brilliant and pure person, was emaciated and unlike his former self. However, he looked around in all directions and did not seem to be in the depths of depression; the Right Gate Watch hung his head and did not lift his eyes, looking deeply thoughtful. Doi Jiro Sanehira, wearing a hitatare of magnolia cloth and light armor, surrounded and guarded them with thirty-some riders in front and behind the carts. The spectators were not limited to those in the capital, but came gathering from distant and near provinces, mountains and temples, old and young. From the southern gate of Toba, along the constructed road, to the Four Mounds, they were packed tightly together, I know not how many tens of millions. People could not look back; carts could not turn their wheels. Although it was said that the human seed had perished due to the famines of Jisho and Yowa and the wars in the eastern and western provinces, it seemed there were still many remaining. Leaving the capital and skipping one year, since the interval was quite short, they had not forgotten the glorious events. The state of those whom they had feared and trembled before today was hard to distinguish between dream and reality. Down to the heartless mystic men and women, there was none who did not shed tears and wring their sleeves. How much more must those who were familiar and intimate have felt? Many who had received favors for years and served since the time of their fathers and ancestors had attached themselves to the Genji because of the difficulty of throwing away their lives, but since they could not suddenly forget their old affection, surely they felt sad. Thus, there were many who pressed their sleeves to their faces and did not lift their eyes.
[11.13.3] The Minister's ox-driver was Saburomaru, the younger brother of Jiromaru who had been killed when he mishandled the cart during Kiso's visit to the Cloistered Palace. In the western provinces he had become a hunter, but his desire to drive the Minister's cart one more time was deep, so at Toba he spoke to The Judge: "Although those called ox-drivers and servants are the lowest of the low and should not have feelings, my gratitude for being employed for years is not shallow. If it is appropriate, receiving your permission, I should like to serve the Minister's cart for the last time." Because he pleaded earnestly, The Judge said, "There is no objection; do it quickly," and permitted it.
