Rejoicing beyond measure, he dressed properly, took a driving rope from his bosom and replaced the other, and though he could not see the way ahead for tears, he pressed his sleeve to his face, leaving it to the ox's steps, and drove weeping. The Cloistered Emperor stopped his carriage at Rokujo Higashi-no-Toin and looked. The carts of the nobles and courtiers were also lined up together. Since they had served him so closely, the Cloistered Emperor was soft-hearted and thought it pitiful. The attendants thought it was just a dream. "In past days we thought, 'Somehow, if only those people would look at us, if only we could catch the end of their words,' so who could have thought it would be like this?" Saying this, high and low shed tears. Years ago, when Lord Munemori became Palace Minister and went to give thanks, beginning with Kazan-in Dainagon, twelve nobles attended in his procession. As for courtiers, sixteen men led by the Head of the Kurōdo, Chikamune, rode in the vanguard. Nobles and courtiers alike glittered as if today were the day; there were four Middle Counselors, and even three Sanmi Chūjō. At that time, this Taira Dainagon was Captain of the Left Gate Watch. He was summoned to the presence, received gifts, and was treated with hospitality; it was a splendid ceremony. Today, not a single court noble or courtier followed him; likewise, twenty-some samurai who were captured at Dan-no-ura wore white hitatare and were paraded tied to horses. After being paraded east along Rokujo to the riverbed, they returned, and the Minister father and son were at Kurō Hōgan's lodging at Rokujo Horikawa. Although food was served, their chests were choked and blocked, and they could not even lift their chopsticks. Though they did not speak to each other, they met each other's eyes and shed tears without pause. Though night came, they did not loosen their clothes, but lay down spreading one sleeve; seeing him cover his son, the Right Gate Watch, with his sleeve, Gen Hachi Byōe, Eda Genzo, and Kumai Taro, who were guarding them, watched and said, "Ah, whether high or low, there is nothing as sad as the path of love. Even if he covers him with his sleeve, how much good will it do? How deep is his affection in this extremity." Saying this, the fierce warriors all shed tears.
11.14. The Mirror
[11.14.1] On the twenty-eighth day of the same month, the Former Captain of the Guards of Kamakura, Yoritomo Ason, was promoted to Junior Second Rank. It is a rare imperial favor to skip a rank and advance two steps, but this was already three steps. He should have been made Third Rank, but since the Heike had held that rank, he disliked it. At the Hour of the Rat that night, the Naishidokoro entered the Unmeiden from the hall of the Dajōkan. The Sovereign made an Imperial visit, and extraordinary Kagura was performed for three nights. It was splendid that Ukon-no-Shōgen O-ie no Kata received a special imperial command and performed the secret Kagura piece called "Yudate Miyabito" transmitted in his house, and received praise. As for this song, no one knew it except the musician called his grandfather Hachijō Hōgan Suketada. Because he kept it too secret, he did not teach it to his child Oyakata, but transmitted it to Emperor Horikawa during his reign and died; the Lord taught it to Oyakata. The depth of his intention not to let the Way be lost brings tears of admiration that are hard to suppress.
[11.14.2] Now, regarding the Naishidokoro: long ago, when Amaterasu Omikami was about to shut herself in the Rock Cave of Heaven, she cast a mirror, intending somehow to leave her image for her descendants to see. Thinking this still did not suit her mind, she cast it again. The first mirror is the shrine of Hinokuma and Kunikakasu in Kii Province. The later mirror she gave to her child Ama-no-Oshi-Homimi-no-Mikoto, saying, "Live in the same palace with this."
Now, when Amaterasu Omikami shut herself in the Rock Cave of Heaven and the world became dark, the eight hundred myriads of deities gathered in a divine assembly and performed Kagura at the mouth of the Rock Cave; Amaterasu Omikami, unable to contain her interest, opened the Rock Cave a crack and looked; seeing that their faces looked white to one another, I hear that the word "omoshiro" [interesting/white-faced] began from this. At that time, a god of great strength called Koyane Tachikarao approached, and saying "Eei!", opened it; from this it is said that [doors] cannot be built [without shouting]. Now, the Naishidokoro resided in the same hall until the time of the ninth Emperor, Kaika Tenno, but reaching the reign of the tenth Emperor, Sujin Tenno, he feared its spiritual power and moved it to a separate hall. In recent times it resides in the Unmeiden. One hundred and sixty years after the capital was moved, at the Hour of the Rat on the twenty-third day of the ninth month of the fourth year of Tentoku in the reign of Emperor Murakami, a fire broke out for the first time inside the Palace enclosure. Since the fire came out from the Guardhouse of the Left Gate, the Unmeiden where the Naishidokoro resided was close by. Since it was just midnight, neither the ladies-in-waiting nor the court ladies happened to be present, and there was no time to take the Naishidokoro out. Lord Onomiya rushed there, but the Naishidokoro was already burning. While he shed tears thinking "The world is over now," the Naishidokoro flew out of the flames by itself and hung on the top of a cherry tree at the Southern Hall; its light was brilliant, no different from the morning sun emerging from the mountain edge. At that time, Lord Onomiya thought, "The world has not yet ended," and could not stop his tears of joy. Kneeling on his right knee and spreading his left sleeve, he spoke weeping: "Long ago Amaterasu Omikami made a vow to protect the hundred kings; if that vow has not yet changed, O Divine Mirror, lodge in Saneyori's sleeve." Before he could finish speaking these words, it flew and transferred. Immediately wrapping it in his sleeve, he transferred it to the morning assembly hall of the Dajōkan. Recently it resides in the Unmeiden. In this world, who would have thought to receive it [back]? The Divine Mirror too should not have lodged [with us again]. The ancient times were indeed glorious.
11.15. The Matter of the Letters
[11.15.1] Taira Dainagon Tokitada-kyō father and son were also near Kurō Hōgan's lodging. Now that the world had become like this, one might think "come what may," but Dainagon, perhaps still valuing his life, summoned his son Sanuki Chūjō and said, "A box of letters that should not be scattered has been taken by The Judge. If this is seen by the Genji of the Second Rank in Kamakura, many people will be harmed, and my own life will not be spared; what shall we do?" The Chūjō said, "I hear that The Judge is generally a man of emotion, and moreover, he does not ignore matters where ladies-in-waiting complain and lament, no matter how serious. Why should it be difficult? Since you have many daughters, show him one, and after becoming intimate, perhaps you should ask him." The Dainagon shed tears freely and wept, saying, "When I was in the world, I thought of my daughters as [potential] Imperial Consorts or Empresses. I never even thought of showing them to ordinary people."
The Chūjō said, "Now you must absolutely not have such thoughts. There is the daughter of your current wife who is eighteen." But the Dainagon felt that was still too sad, so the daughter of his previous wife, who was twenty-three, was seen by The Judge. Although she was a little older, since her face and form were beautiful and her heart was elegant, The Judge thought her precious; although he had the daughter of Kawagoe Taro Shigeyori as his original wife, he set this one up in a separate quarter and treated her with respect. Now, when the lady spoke of the matter of the said letters, The Judge did not even break the seal, but hurriedly sent them to Tokitada-kyō. The Dainagon rejoiced beyond measure and immediately burned and discarded them. It was heard that it was unclear what kind of letters they were.
[11.15.2] With the Heike destroyed, the provinces soon quieted down, and there was no trouble for people traveling. Since the capital was also peaceful, people said things like, "There is no one like Kurō Hōgan. What has the Genji of the Second Rank in Kamakura done? We wish the world were entirely as The Judge wills." The Genji of the Second Rank heard this leaked and said, "What is this? The Heike were easily destroyed because I, Yoritomo, planned well and sent up soldiers. If it were Kurō alone, how could he have pacified the world? Boasting that people speak thus, he makes the world his own selfish way. Although there are many people, that he became the son-in-law of Taira Dainagon and handles the Dainagon is unacceptable. Also, without fear of the world, there is no reason to take the Dainagon's son-in-law [into service]. Even if he comes down here, surely he will behave excessively." So he spoke.
12. 平家物語卷第十二
12.1. Great Earthquake
[12.1.1] The Heike had all perished, and the western provinces had quieted down. The provinces followed the provincial governors, and the manors remained with the estate lords. Just as high and low felt secure, on the ninth day of the Seventh Month of the same year, around the Hour of the Horse, the great earth shook violently for a long time. Within the red districts, in the vicinity of Shirakawa, the Six Victorious Temples were all broken and destroyed. The nine-storied pagoda shook down its top six stories. At the Tokuchōju-in, the thirty-three bay hall was shaken down to seventeen bays. Beginning with the Imperial Palace, people's houses, and in general the shrines and temples in every place, and the humble dwellings of the commoners, all broke and collapsed; the sound was like thunder, and the rising dust was like smoke. The sky darkened, and the light of the sun could not be seen; old and young alike lost their souls, and birds and beasts all exhausted their hearts. Also, distant provinces and near provinces were like this. The great earth split and water gushed forth; massive rocks broke and rolled into valleys. Mountains collapsed and buried rivers; the sea drifted and flooded the beaches. Ships rowing by the shore were tossed by waves; horses walking on land lost their footing. If a flood comes overflowing, one can climb a peak and arguably be saved. If a fierce fire comes burning, one can cross a river and escape for a while. The only sad thing was the great earthquake. Unless one were a bird, it was difficult to soar in the sky; unless one were a dragon, it was hard to ascend to the clouds. The number of those buried and killed in Shirakawa, Rokuhara, and within the capital was unknown. Among the Four Great Elements, water, fire, and wind constantly cause harm, but regarding the great earth, it usually does not cause strange disasters. Saying "What is this that has happened?", high and low set up sliding doors and partitions, and every time the heavens rumbled and the earth moved, they cried "Now we die," and chanting the Nembutsu with their voices, the shouting and screaming was immense. Even those of seventy, eighty, or ninety years said that although the world might end, they did not think it would be today or tomorrow, and made a great clamor; the young children heard this and their weeping and grieving was limitless. The Cloistered Emperor had just made an Imperial visit to Imakumano at that time, but since many people were killed and there was pollution of death, he hurriedly returned to Rokuhara. On the way, how much must the Sovereign and subjects have distressed their hearts? The Emperor rode in the Phoenix Palanquin and made an Imperial visit to the edge of the pond. The Cloistered Emperor set up a tent in the south garden and stayed there. As for the Cloistered Lady and the Princesses, since their palaces were all shaken down, some rode in palanquins, others rode in carriages, and went out. The Astronomy Doctors came running and said that at the Hour of the Boar or Rat in the evening, the great earth would certainly shake again; to say it was frightening is an understatement. Long ago, in the Great Earthquake of the eighth day of the Third Month of the third year of Saikō in the reign of Emperor Montoku, I hear the head of the Buddha at Tōdaiji was shaken down. Also, in the Great Earthquake of the fifth day of the Fourth Month of the second year of Tengyō, I hear the Emperor left the Palace and set up a fifty-foot tent in front of the Jōneiden and stayed there. Since that was in ancient times, there is no need to speak of it. I do not think there will be anything like this incident even hereafter. The Ten Virtues Sovereign left the capital and sank his body to the bottom of the sea; Ministers and High Courtiers were paraded along the main avenues and their heads were hung at the prison gate. Since vengeful spirits have been frightening things from ancient times to the present, thinking "How will the world be?", there was no person with a heart who did not lament and grieve.
12.2. The Dyer's Affair
[12.2.1] On the twenty-second day of the same Eighth Month, saying it was the true head of the late Sama-no-Kami Yoshitomo, father of the Kamakura Genji of the Second Rank Yoritomo-kyō, Mongaku Shōnin of Takao hung it around his neck, had a disciple hang Kamada Hyōe's head around his neck, and went down to Kamakura. What he dug up and presented around the fourth year of Jishō was not the real head of Sama-no-Kami. As a stratagem to urge rebellion, he wrapped a random old skull in white cloth and presented it; having raised a rebellion and conquered the world, believing entirely that it was his father's head, he now found it again and went down. This was because a dyer man who had been employed by Yoshitomo for years out of pity, grieving that the head had hung at the prison gate for years with no one to pray for its afterlife, met with the Otoneri of the time, asked for it, took it down, and saying, "Although Hyōe-no-Suke-dono is an exile, he is a person with a promising future. If he comes out into the world, he might search for it," he stored it deeply away in a place called Engakuji in Higashiyama; Mongaku heard of this, took that dyer man, and went down with him.
Hearing that they arrived in Kamakura today, the Genji of the Second Rank went to the Katase River to meet them. From there he changed into mourning clothes and entered Kamakura weeping. He had the holy man stand on the main floor, and standing in the courtyard himself, he received his father's head; it was pitiful. There was no great or small lord seeing this who did not shed tears. Clearing away the steep rocks, he built a new hall, dedicated it to his father, and named it Shōchōju-in. The Court also thought such matters pitiful, and awarded the rank of Palace Minister and Senior Second Rank to the grave of the late Sama-no-Kami Yoshitomo. It was heard that the Imperial Envoy was Sadaiben Kanetada. Because Yoritomo-kyō's fame for military valor was superior, not only did he establish himself and raise his house, but it was splendid that the grant of office and rank extended to the spirit of his deceased father.
12.3. Taira Dainagon Exiled
[12.3.1] On the twenty-third day of the same Ninth Month, since it was communicated from the Lord of Kamakura to the Court that the remaining partisans of the Heike in the capital should be sent to the provinces, it was heard that Taira Dainagon Tokitada-kyō was sent to Noto Province, his son Sanuki Chūjō Tokizane to Kazusa Province, Kura-no-Kami Nobumoto to Aki Province, Hyobu-no-Shōyu Masaaki to Oki Province, Nii Sozu Senshin to Awa Province, Hosshōji Shigyō Noen to Bingo Province, and Chūnagon Risshi Chūkai to Musashi Province. Some to the waves of the western sea, some to the ends of the clouds of the eastern barrier; not expecting where their end would be, not knowing the time of meeting again, holding back tears of parting, the hearts of those who went to their respective places can be guessed and were pitiful. Among them, Taira Dainagon went to where Kenreimon-in was living at Yoshida and said, weeping: "Tokitada's blame is heavy, and today I already head for my place of exile. While I was within the same capital, I wished to hear news of your vicinity, but thinking of what state you will finally be in, I leave with heavy thoughts, and the journey's sky will be unbearable."
The Imperial Lady said, "Truly, as a remnant of the past, only you were left. Now, who will there be to show pity and mourn me?" And she could not hold back her tears.
[12.3.2] This Dainagon was the grandson of Dewa-no-Zenji Tomonobu, and the son of Hyobu-no-Gon-no-Taifu, posthumously awarded Minister of the Left, Tokinobu. He was the elder brother of the late Kenshunmon-in and the maternal relative of the Retired Emperor Takakura. His reputation in the world and the sparkle of his time were splendid. Since the wife of the Lay Priest Prime Minister, the Nun of the Second Rank of Hachijō, was also his elder sister, his concurrent offices and positions were as he thought and as he wished. Thus, in no time he rose to become a Dainagon of the Senior Second Rank. He also became Bettō of the Kebiishi three times. During this person's administration of the office, he arrested thieves and robbers, and without ceremony cut off their right arms at the elbow and cast them out. Therefore he was called the Evil Bettō. When a Cloistered Decree was sent to the western provinces saying the Sovereign and the Three Sacred Treasures should be returned to the capital, branding the face of the messenger of the Cloistered Decree, Hanagata, with the characters "Namigata," was also the deed of this Dainagon. Since he was the brother of the late Imperial Lady, the Cloistered Emperor wished to see him as a keepsake, but because of such evil deeds, his anger was not shallow. Although Kurō Hōgan had become intimate with him and thought to somehow intercede for him, it was not granted. His son Jijū Tokiie, who had turned sixteen, was left out of the exile and stayed with his uncle Tokimitsu-kyō. Together with his mother, Daini-no-Suke-dono, he clung to the Dainagon's sleeve and held him back, regretting the parting limited to this moment. Although the Dainagon spoke stoutly, "Is this a parting that will last forever?", surely he felt sad.
After his years had advanced and his age declined, parting finally from his wife and children with whom he was so intimate, looking back from the distant clouds at the capital he was used to living in, heading for the journey on the northern road he had only heard of by name in the past, as he went far down, passing Shiga and Karasaki, and then the inlet of Mano and the bay of Katada, the Dainagon recited weeping:
That I might return is uncertain; like the net pulled at Katada, my tears cannot be held by the mesh.
[12.3.3] Yesterday drifting on the waves of the western sea, he piled the resentment of the suffering of meeting with those one hates inside a small boat; today buried under the snow of the northern provinces, he layered the sadness of the suffering of parting from those one loves on the clouds of his home.
12.4. Tosabō Is Slain
[12.4.1] In the meantime, although ten daimyo were assigned to Kurō the Magistrate [Yoshitsune] by the Lord of Kamakura [Yoritomo], because it was rumored that he had secretly incurred his suspicion, they united their hearts and one by one they all went down [from the capital] completely. Besides being brothers, they had specially made a pledge of father and son; since chasing and attacking Kiso Yoshinaka in the first month of last year, they repeatedly attacked and dropped the Heike, and in the spring of this year destroyed them completely, quieting the whole heaven and clearing the four seas. At the point where rewards should be performed, what kind of details exist that such rumors are heard? Thus from the One Above beginning respectfully down to the ten thousand people below, they hold suspicion. This matter is because last spring, when arranging boats from Watanabe in Settsu Province to cross to Yashima, there was a dispute about setting up reverse oars, and having been greatly shamed, Kajiwara thought of it with malice and constantly slandered him. "Surely he has a rebellious heart. If I send up daimyo, they will pull up the bridges at Uji and Seta, and it will become a disturbance throughout the capital, which would be rather bad," [Yoritomo thought], so he summoned Tosabō Shōshun and said, "You, monk, go up, and under the guise of making a pilgrimage, deceive and kill him."
When he said this, Shōshun received it with awe, and without returning to his lodging, he left from the presence and immediately went up to the Capital.
[12.4.2] On the 29th day of the same 9th month, although Tosabō arrived at the Capital, he did not visit the Magistrate's palace even by the next day. Hearing that Tosabō had come up, [Yoshitsune] summoned him via Musashibō Benkei, and he was brought immediately. The Magistrate said, "How is it, is there no letter from the Lord of Kamakura?"
"Since there was no specific matter, a letter was not presented. As for his saying 'Speak by word of mouth,' it was 'That until this time there are no particular details in the Capital, I think it is because you are present there. Make preparations and guard well. Say that.' Thus indeed he spoke." The Magistrate said, "By no means is that so; you are a messenger coming up to kill Yoshitsune. If he sent up daimyo, they would pull up the bridges of Uji and Seta and it would become a disturbance of the Capital, which would be rather bad. He has ordered you, monk, to come up and under the guise of a pilgrimage, to deceive and kill me, has he not?" When he said this, Shōshun was greatly surprised and said, "Depending on what, just now, should such a thing exist? Because of a trifling vow, I have come up for the purpose of a pilgrimage to Kumano." At that time the Magistrate said, "Because of Kagetoki's slander, Yoshitsune is not allowed into Kamakura, and without even being granted an audience, I am driven up [to Kyoto]; how is this?" Shōshun said, "How is that matter? regarding myself, strictly there is no duplicity behind me. I shall write and submit a written oath." Because he said this, the Magistrate said, "Be that as it may, if you are thought well of by the Lord of Kamakura..." and saying this, his mood became exceedingly bad. Shōshun, in order to escape immediate harm, while sitting there wrote seven written oaths; some he burned and drank, some he offered to shrines, and having relaxed [Yoshitsune's suspicion], he returned, and circulating the order to the the Great Watch Guards, he intended to attack that very night. As for the Magistrate, he most dearly loved a woman called Shizuka, the daughter of a Shirabyōshi dancer named Iso Zenji. Shizuka also did not leave his side. Shizuka spoke: "The main street seems to be entirely warriors. If there is no mobilization from here, is there any reason for the men of the Great Watch Guards to make this much noise? Alas, I think this is the work of the 'Written Oath Monk' from this afternoon. I wish to send someone to see."
Saying this, she employed three or four Kamuro [servant girls] who had been servants of the late Lay Priest Prime Minister of Rokuhara; she sent two of them, but although time passed they did not return. Thinking a woman would not be trouble, she sent one foot-soldier to see. Before long he came running back and said, "Those who appeared to be the Kamuro were both cut down at Tosabō's gate. At the lodging, they are tightly pulling saddles onto horses, and inside the great curtains, arrow-bearers, bow-holders, and men are all fully equipped and are setting out to attack just now. It does not look like the appearance of a pilgrimage in the slightest."
Because he said this, the Magistrate heard it and immediately set out to fight. Shizuka took a long armor protector and threw it over him. Just tying the high cords, he took his long sword and when he went out, a horse was saddled and pulled up in front of the middle gate; jumping onto this, he said "Open the gate!" and had the gate opened; just where he was waiting thinking 'now, now', after a short while forty or fifty horsemen in straight armor pushed toward the front of the gate, and raised a battle cry with a roar. The Magistrate stood up spreading his stirrups, and raising a great voice, said "Whether in a night attack or a day battle, a person who could easily kill Yoshitsune is not known in the land of Japan!" Saying this, he shouted and charged as just one horseman, and the fifty or so men opened the center and let him pass. In the meantime, soldiers who were a match for a thousand, such as Eda Genzō, Kumai Tarō, and Musashibō Benkei, immediately followed and attacked and fought. After that, retainers, hearing that a night attack had entered the palace, came running from that mansion and this lodging. Before long, sixty or seventy horsemen gathered, so although Tosabō attacked fiercely, he could not reach a battle [victory], and being scattered miserably, those who were saved were few, and those who were killed were indeed many. Shōshun rarely escaped that place and fled into the depths of Kurama, but because Kurama was the Magistrate's old mountain home, those monks bound Tosabō, and the next day sent him to the Magistrate's place. It is said he was hiding in a place called Sōjō-ga-tani. They dragged Shōshun into the main courtyard and sat him down. He was wearing a foot-soldier's hitatare and a soft cap. The Magistrate laughed and said, "How is it, monk, you have been struck by your written oaths."
Tosabō was not the least bit agitated, and sitting up straight, sneered and said: "Since I wrote it on a certain matter, indeed I have been struck."
Thus he spoke. "To honor the lord's command and make light of one's private life, the extent of your intention is most admirable. Monk, if you value your life, how about I send you back to Kamakura?"
Tosabō said, "What dishonest words you speak. If I say I value it, will you save me, my lord? From the time I received the command from the Lord of Kamakura saying 'Although he is a monk, he is the one who will aim for him,' I offered my life to the Lord of Kamakura. Why should I take it back? Just, for a favor, quickly take my head."
Because he said this, [Yoshitsune] said "Then cut him," and having him dragged out to the riverbed of Rokujō, he was cut. There was no person who did not praise him.
12.5. The Magistrate Flees the Capital
[12.5.1] Here, a miscellaneous servant called Adachi Shinzaburō was sent to serve the Magistrate, with the instruction "Although that fellow is of low rank, he is an exceedingly clever fellow. Employ him."
but [Yoritomo] said "Secretly watch Kurō's behavior and let me know. " Seeing that Shōshun was cut, Shinzaburō ran down joining night to day, and when he told this to the Lord of Kamakura, he ordered that his younger brother Mikawa-no-Kami Noriyori should go up as the punitive force. Although he declined earnestly, because he was ordered repeatedly, unable to do otherwise he prepared his gear and came to say farewell. Because [Yoritomo] said "Don't you imitate Kurō," fearing these words, he took off his gear and stopped his going up to the Capital. Although he wrote ten written oaths a day saying there was absolutely no disloyalty, and read them aloud inside the courtyard at night, writing and submitting a thousand written oaths in a hundred days, it was not granted and in the end he was killed. After that, hearing that Hōjō Shirō Tokimasa was going up as the Great General of the punitive force, the Magistrate decided to flee toward the Chinzei [Kyushu] direction; there, Ogata Saburō Koreyoshi was a man of such power that he did not let the Heike into the Nine Provinces but drove them out, so the Magistrate said "Be relied upon by me. " He said, "If that is so, Kikuchi Jirō Takanao who is in your service is my enemy of many years. Give him to me, and I will cut off his head and be relied upon [serve you]. " Because he was given over without hesitation, he was dragged out to the riverbed of Rokujō and cut. After that Koreyoshi agreed gallantly.
[12.5.2] On the 2nd day of the same 11th month, Kurō Taiyu the Magistrate went to the Cloistered Emperor's Palace, and through Minister of the Treasury Yasutsune Ason, reported: "Regarding the matter of Yoshitsune performing the loyalty of service for the sake of the Lord, it does not extend to speaking it newly and freshly now. However, because Yoritomo, relying on the slander of retainers, tries to strike Yoshitsune, I think I shall go down toward the Chinzei direction for a while. I wish to be granted one letter of authority from the Board of the Cloistered Emperor. "[][1] Because this was said, the Cloistered Emperor consulted with the nobles, saying "Regarding this article, how should it be regarding what Yoritomo will hear in return?"
Because each of them said in unison, "If Yoshitsune remains in the Capital and the great forces of the Kanto burst in, the violence in Kyoto will not cease. If he goes down to a distant province, for a while there will not be that fear,"
beginning with Ogata Saburō, and the Usuki, Hetsugi, and Matsura clans, generally the men of Chinzei were granted a letter from the Board saying they should obey his command with Yoshitsune as General; with a force of over 500 horsemen, at the hour of the Rabbit [6 AM] on the 3rd, without making the slightest trouble in Kyoto, and without raising wind or waves, he went down. A Genji of Settsu Province, Ōta Tarō Yorimoto, said "Can I let them pass right in front of my gate without shooting a single arrow?"
and chased and caught them at a place called Kawaratsu and attacked and fought. Since the Magistrate had over 500 horsemen and Ōta Tarō had over 60 horsemen, they surrounded them inside saying "Don't let any remain, don't let any leak out," and attacked severely, so Ōta Tarō himself was wounded, many of his house-children and retainers were killed, he had his horse's belly shot, and retreated. The Magistrate cut off the heads and offered them to the God of War, and rejoicing that "The setting out is good," he got on boats from Daimotsu-no-Ura and went down, but just then the west wind blew violently and they were washed up on the coast of Sumiyoshi, and he fled and hid in the depths of Yoshino. Attacked by the Yoshino monks, he fled to Nara. Attacked by the Nara monks, he again returned and entered the Capital, headed to the North Country, and finally went down to the North. As he had abandoned the ten or so ladies-in-waiting he had brought from the Capital at the coast of Sumiyoshi, they stamped their hakama on the sand under the pines, and spreading their sleeves, lay down weeping; the Shinto priests of Sumiyoshi took pity on them and sent them all to the Capital. Generally, the boats of the Uncle whom the Magistrate relied upon, Shida Saburō Sensei Yoshinori, Jūrō Kurōdo Yukiie, and Ogata Saburō Koreyoshi were washed up on various bays and islands, and they did not know each other's fate. The sudden blowing of the west wind was also thought to be because of the angry spirits of the Heike. On the 7th of the same 11th month, Hōjō Shirō Tokimasa entered the Capital with over 60,000 horsemen as the deputy of the Minamoto Second Rank Lord Yoritomo of Kamakura. The next day, the 8th, he visited the Cloistered Emperor, and when he reported that Iyo-no-Kami Minamoto Yoshitsune, Bizen-no-Kami the same Yukiie, and Shida Saburō Sensei the same Yoshinori should be pursued and attacked, a Cloistered Decree was immediately issued. On the past 2nd day, leaving it to the purport of Yoshitsune's application, a Board Letter was made to disobey Yoritomo; on the 8th, relying on Lord Yoritomo's petition, a Cloistered Decree to pursue and attack Yoshitsune is issued. The uncertainty of the world that changes in the morning and transforms in the evening is indeed pathetic.
[12.5.3] In the meantime, the Lord of Kamakura was granted the title of Constable General of the Land of Japan, and regarding his statement that he should be assigned soldier-provisions rice according to the plot of land, the Cloistered Emperor said "The fact that those who destroyed the enemies of the Court since ancient times were granted half the country is seen in the Muryōgikyō [Sutra of Immeasurable Meanings]. However, in our court there is not yet such a precedent. This is an excessive petition by Yoritomo."
But the nobles deliberated, and because the lords all said in unison "The points Lord Yoritomo says are half reasonable," it is said the permission was given. Constables were placed in the provinces, and Stewards were appointed to the manors. There was no way to hide even a single hair. For this kind of matter with the Lord of Kamakura, although there were many people in the Court, it was reported via Yoshida Dainagon Tsunefusa Kyō. This Dainagon was heard to be a proper person. People who had been tied to the Heike, after the Genji world became strong, sent letters or dispatched messengers and flattered in various ways, but this person did not act despicably. Thus, even in the time of the Heike when they confined the Cloistered Emperor in the Toba Palace and placed Betto [administrators] of the Rear Palace, Kageyu-kōji Chūnagon and this Tsunefusa Kyō, these two alone were made Betto of the Rear Palace. He is the son of Provisional Right Middle Controller Mitsufusa Ason. In his twelfth year, his father Ason passed away, so although he was an orphan, his promotion did not stagnate, and combining the three key posts, passing through Head of the Secretaries, Sangi, Daiben, and Dazai-no-Sochi, he reached Senior Second Rank Dainagon. Although he surpassed others, he was not surpassed by others. Thus, a person's good and evil, like an awl passing through a bag, is never hidden in the end. He was a rare person. [] [1] Nihon Koten Bungaku Taikei (Tokyo: Iwanami Shoten, vol. 33, 1957; hereafter cited as NKBT) reads "thus he spoke".
12.6. Rokudai
[12.6.1] It was announced by Hōjō Shirō to the strategists: "Regarding the fellows who are found who can be called descendants of the Heike, it should depend on the request [for reward]. " The people of the Capital knew the information, and saying "We will receive rewards," searching for them was sad. Because of this, many were found. Though they were children of low rank, calling forth those with white skin and good eyebrows, saying "This is the young lord of that Captain, the son of that Lieutenant," though the fathers and mothers wept and grieved, while saying "That is what the helper said, that is what the wet-nurse said," they put the utterly young ones in water or buried them in the earth, and the slightly older ones they pressed to death or stabbed to death. There was no way to compare the grief of the mothers and the lamentation of the wet-nurses. Since the Hōjō also had many descendants, they did not think this was a fine thing, but since it is the custom that follows the world, they could not do otherwise.
[12.6.2] Among them, there was the young lord of the Komatsu Third Rank Lieutenant General, called Rokudai Gozen; besides being of the direct lineage of the Heike, his age was also mature. Saying they would take him by any means, they divided their forces and searched, but as they could not find him and were about to go down [leave], a certain lady-in-waiting came out to Rokuhara and said "West from here, deep in Henshōji, north of a mountain temple called Daikakuji, at a place called Shōbu-dani [Iris Valley], the wife of the Komatsu Third Rank Lieutenant General, the young lord, and the young lady are present."
Because she said this, Tokimasa immediately attached men to spy on that area, and in a certain monk's hut, ladies-in-waiting and few people were living in a very fearful and stealthy manner. When they peeked through a gap in the fence, a white puppy ran out, and as he went to catch it, a beautiful young lord came out; one who seemed to be the wet-nurse lady said "Ah, how wretched, someone might see you," and hurriedly pulled him in. Thinking "This is certainly that person," they ran back quickly and reported thus, so the next day the Hōjō set out for that place, surrounded the four sides, sent a person in and had him say: "Hearing that the young lord of the Heike Komatsu Third Rank Lieutenant General, Rokudai Gozen, is here, the person called Hōjō Shirō Tokimasa, deputy of the Lord of Kamakura, has come to receive him; please bring him out quickly."
Because this was said, when the Mother heard this, she did not remember anything at all. Saitō Go and Saitō Roku ran around and looked, but warriors surrounded the four sides, and they did not know from which way to let him escape. The wet-nurse lady also fell down before him, and screamed without sparing her voice. Though normally they did not even speak things loudly and lived stealthily in hiding, now everyone who was in the house raised their voices in unison and wept and grieved. The Hōjō heard this and thought it very painful, and wiping his tears, waited intently. After a while, he spoke again: "Since the world is not yet quiet, thinking that some untidy thing might happen, I have come to receive him. There will be no special matter [execution]. Please bring him out quickly."
Because this was said, the young lord said to his Mother: "Since I will not escape in the end, please let me go out quickly. If the warriors break in and search, they will see your wretched appearances. Even if I go out, if I remain for a while, I will ask for leave and return. Do not grieve painfully. " His comforting her was pitiful.
[12.6.3] Since it could not be helped, the Mother weeping stroked his hair and put clothes on him, and as she was about to send him out, she took out a small and beautiful rosary of black wood, and said "With this, until whatever happens, chant the Nembutsu and go to Paradise."
and gave it to him; the young lord took this and said "I will be separated from my Mother today. Now, somehow, I want to go to the place where my Father is."
That he said this was pathetic. Hearing this, his sister the young princess who was ten years old ran out saying "I too will go to Father's place," but the wet-nurse lady held her back. Rokudai Gozen, although this year he was only twelve, was taller than an ordinary fourteen or fifteen year old, and his face and form were graceful, so thinking "I will not show weakness to the enemy," tears spilled over even from the gaps of the sleeves he pressed [to his face]. Then he rode in the palanquin. The warriors surrounded him front, back, left and right, and left. Saitō Go and Saitō Roku went attached to the left and right of the palanquin. The Hōjō got off his fresh horse and made him ride, but he did not ride, and ran barefoot from Daikakuji to Rokuhara. The Mother and the wet-nurse lady looked up to heaven and threw themselves on the ground, writhing and grieving. "These past days, gathering the Heike children, there are those put in water, there are those buried in earth. Since it is heard they press them to death, stab them to death, and do various things, as for my child, how will they destroy him? Since he is a little grown, they will surely cut his head. People's children are placed with wet-nurses and such, and there are times when they see them. Even so, the path of affection is a sad custom. How much more so with this one, after he was born, for one day or half a moment I have not let him from my body. Thinking it like having a thing people do not have, the one whom I raised between the two of us morning and evening, after separating without satisfaction from the person I relied upon, since then, putting the two left and right was my only comfort; though one is here, one is not. After today, what shall I do? During these three years, though it is a thing I anticipated while erasing my liver and heart night and day, indeed I did not expect it yesterday or today; while I deeply relied on the Kannon of Hase for years, the sadness that in the end he is taken. Perhaps even now they have destroyed him."
There was nothing but repeating this and weeping. Though the night was deep, feeling her chest choked up, she did not doze even a dew-drop, but after a while she spoke to the wet-nurse lady: "Just now in a dream I dozed a little, this child came riding on a white horse, and saying 'Because I thought of you too fondly, I have asked for leave for a short while and have come,' he sat by my side, and thinking of the world somewhat resentfully, he wept copiously, but before long being startled awake, I groped by my side asking if he was young, but there was no one. Even if it is a dream, the sadness that I awaken without even a moment."
Thus she told her. The wet-nurse lady also wept. The long night was hard to brighten, and the bed was afloat with tears.
[12.6.4] Since there is a limit, the rooster called the dawn and the night opened. Saitō Roku returned. When she asked "Well, how is it, how is it?" he said "Until just now there is no special matter. Here is a letter."
and taking it out, presented it. When she opened and looked at it: "How painfully you must be thinking. Until just now there is no special matter. Before long I miss everyone."
He had written quite maturely. The Mother saw this, and did not say this or that. She put the letter in her breast pocket and lay face down. Truly, it was surmised how it must be in her heart, and it was pathetic.
[12.6.5] Thus as the time passed far along, Saitō Roku said, "I am uneasy about the time, so I shall return."
and the Mother weeping wrote a reply and gave it to him. Saitō Roku said farewell and left. The wet-nurse lady, in the helplessness of her heart even if she blamed it, ran out and without pointing anywhere, while walking about that area crying entrusting it to her legs, a certain person said "Deep in here there is a mountain temple called Takao. That Saint, called Mongaku-bō, is thought of as a man of great importance by the Lord of Kamakura, and it is said he desires high-ranking children to make them his disciples."
Hearing this, she thought she had heard a happy thing, and without saying so to the Mother, she went alone searching into Takao, and facing the Saint, said: "A young lord who was raised from within my blood and became twelve this year was taken by warriors yesterday. Will you not beg for his life and make him your disciple?"
and fell down before the Saint, crying and screaming without sparing her voice. Truly she appeared helpless. The Saint felt pity and asked the details of the matter. She got up and weeping said "I raised the child of a person close to the wife of the Heike Komatsu Third Rank Lieutenant General; did people call him the young lord of the Young Lieutenant General? Yesterday warriors took him and left. " "Well, who was the warrior called?"
"He called himself Hōjō."
The Saint said "Well then, I will go face him and ask."
and went out. Although these were not words to be relied upon, since the Saint spoke thus, feeling a little better she hurriedly returned to Daikakuji, and when she told this to the Mother, "Thinking you had gone out to throw yourself [in water], I was thinking I too would throw myself into whatever abyss or river," she asked the details of the matter. When she told exactly what the Saint had said, "Ah, beg for him and show him to me once more," she joined her hands and wept.
[12.6.6] The Saint went to face Rokuhara and asked the details of the matter. Hōjō said "In the command of the Lord of Kamakura: 'I hear the descendants of the Heike are hiding in large numbers in the Capital. Among them I hear the son of the Komatsu Third Rank Lieutenant General exists in the womb of the daughter of the New Dainagon of Nakamikado. Besides being of the direct lineage of the Heike, the age is said to be mature. Find him by any means and destroy him.' Because I received this command, these days, although I have taken a few of the youngest ones of the branch families, I did not know the location of this young lord, and being unable to find him, I was about to go down in vain, but unexpectedly, hearing of him the day before yesterday, although I received him yesterday, because he is uncommonly beautiful, he is too dear and I have kept him without doing this or that to him yet."
Since he said this, the Saint said "Well then, let me see him," and went to see the place where the young lord was; he was wearing a double-woven hitatare and had a black wood rosary through his hands. The appearance of his hair and his build were truly noble and beautiful, and he did not look like a person of this world. Seeming not to have slept at ease last night, that his face was a little thin made him seem all the more painfully lovely. Seeing the Saint, what did he think? Because he became tearful, the Saint seeing this also involuntarily wrung his black-dyed sleeves. Even if in a future world he became some kind of enemy, feeling it sad that one should destroy him, he said to Hōjō: "Seeing this young lord, is it a matter of a previous life? I feel him too dear. Give me a delay of twenty days. I will go to the Lord of Kamakura and ask for custody. When I, the Saint, thinking to let the Lord of Kamakura be in the world, though I was myself an exile, went up to the Capital to ask for a Cloistered Decree, the fact that at the end of the Fuji River, where I did not know the way, I crossed at night and was about to be washed away; meeting highwaymen in the mountains of Takechi, throwing away my property and escaping only with my life; going to the the Cage Palace at Fukuhara, and attaching myself to the Former Right Commander of the Guards Lord Mitsuyoshi, when I requested and brought forth the Cloistered Decree; regarding the promise at that time: 'Speak whatever great matter. Whatever the Saint says, Yoritomo will grant for one lifetime.' indeed he said. Since then, regarding the repeated service he has seen, it is not for me to speak of it freshly now; he values the promise and takes life lightly. Unless a Receiving God attaches to the Lord of Kamakura, surely he will not have forgotten."
Saying this, he departed at that dawn. Saitō Go and Saitō Roku heard this, and thinking of the Saint as a living Buddha, joined their hands and shed tears. Hurriedly going to Daikakuji, when they told this reason, how happy must have been the heart of the Mother who heard this. However, since it was Kamakura's decision, it was uncertain how it would be, but since the Saint spoke confidently and went down, plus the life delay of twenty days, the Mother and the wet-nurse lady extended their hearts a little, and thought reliantly that it was solely the help of Kannon.
[12.6.7] Thus while they spent the time, the passing of twenty days was like a dream. The Saint had not yet appeared; thinking "what has become of it," it was rather painful, and now again they writhed and grieved. Hōjō also made a clamor saying "The days of Mongaku-bō's promise have also passed; I cannot stay in the Capital like this and end the year. Now I will go down."
Though Saitō Go and Saitō Roku clenched their hands and crushed their livers and souls, the Saint still did not appear, and since he did not even send a messenger, there was only thought. These returned to Daikakuji and said "The Saint has not yet come up, and Hōjō will go down at dawn."
and pressing their left and right sleeves to their faces, shed tears in drops. How sad must have been the heart of the Mother who heard this. "He should have said to bring Rokudai to the place where he would meet the Saint, who is perhaps delayed. If he begged for him and is coming up, what shall we do about the sadness if he cuts him first? So, does he look like he will destroy him quickly?"
When she said this, "He seems to be doing it around this dawn. The reason is, the house-children and retainers of Hōjō who have been serving him these days, thinking it exceedingly regretful, some are chanting the Nembutsu. Some are shedding tears."
"So, how is this child?"
"When people are looking, he behaves as if it were not so and counts his rosary, but when people are not there, he presses his sleeves to his face and sobs in tears. " "It must indeed be so. Though he is young, he is a person of mature heart. Thinking his life is limited to tonight, how forlorn he must be. He said if there was a moment he would ask for leave and come, but though it exceeds twenty days, he does not go there, nor is he seen here. After today, again which day or which time we shall meet is not known. Now, what will you do?" she said. "We will serve him anywhere; if he passes away, we will take his bones and offer them to the mountain of Koya, become monks and enter the priesthood, and pray for his future life; that is what we have decided. " "Then, since I feel overly anxious, return quickly."
Because she said this, the two men weeping took their leave and went out. In the meantime, on the 16th of the same 12th month, Hōjō Shirō took the young lord and finally left the Capital. Saitō Go and Saitō Roku were blinded by tears and could not see the destination, but thinking "at least to the final place," they went in attendance weeping. Hōjō said "Ride a horse," but they did not ride. Saying "Since it is the final attendance, it will not be painful," while shedding tears of blood, they went down entrusting it to their legs. Rokudai Gozen parted completely from his Mother and the wet-nurse lady whom he felt it so hard to leave, and looking back at the familiar Capital as elsewhere in the clouds, the inside of his heart as he headed for the Eastern Road limited to today, can be surmised to be pathetic. If there was a warrior hastening his pony, he lost his liver wondering if he would cut his head; if there were people exchanging words, he exhausted his heart thinking 'is it now already?'. Though he thought it was Shinomiya Kawara, crossing Ausaka Mountain, it became the bay of Otsu. Though he peered to see if it was Awazu-ga-hara, today also quickly ended. Passing province after province and post-station after post-station, in the journey, they arrived in Suruga Province. It was heard that the young lord's dew-like life was limited to today.
[12.6.8] At the pine grove of Senbon, the warriors all got down and set the palanquin down, spread a skin rug, and seated the young lord. Hōjō Shirō came close before the young lord and said: "That I have brought you this far is no other matter. Thinking that perhaps on the road we might meet the Saint, I waited and passed the time. The extent of my intention has been seen. Since it is difficult to know the Lord of Kamakura's mind beyond the mountain [Hakone], I shall announce that I destroyed you in Omi Province. Whoever speaks, since it is a matter of the result of karma, surely it will not be granted."
Because he said this weeping, the young lord did not make a reply this way or that. He summoned Saitō Go and Saitō Roku close and said "After I have become howsoever [dead], you return to the Capital, and ah, indeed, you must not say I was cut on the road. The reason is, although in the end it will not be hidden, if they hear this appearance correctly and grieve excessively, even in the shadows of the grass I will feel it painful and it will become a hindrance to my future life. You should say you escorted me to Kamakura."
Because he said this, the livers and souls of the two men vanished completely, and for a while they could not even reach a reply. After a while Saitō Go fell down suppressing his tears, saying "I do not feel that after being left behind by my lord I can live and go up safely to the Capital. " Since it had already become the final moment, his hair was hanging on his shoulders, and he brushed it to the front with his exceedingly beautiful hand; the guarding warriors looked and said "Ah, how pitiful. Still he has his heart."
and all wet their sleeves. After that he faced west, joined his hands, and quietly chanting the Nembutsu, he stretched his neck and waited. Kano Kudō San Chikatoshi was chosen as the executioner, and holding his long sword at his side, he went around behind from the left, and was about to cut him, but his eyes went dark and his heart vanished, and not knowing where to strike the sword, he became unconscious front and rear, so saying "I do not feel I can do it, please order another person," he threw down the sword and withdrew. Saying "Then, cut him that one, cut him this one," while they were choosing an executioner, one monk wearing black-dyed robes riding a cream-colored horse raised his whip and galloped up. "Ah, how pitiful, inside that pine grove, Lord Hōjō is cutting the exceedingly beautiful young lord!"
Because he said this, the men ran and gathered in large numbers; this monk said "Ah, worry!" and waved his hands and beckoned, but still in uncertainty, he took off the hat he was wearing, raised it up and beckoned. Hōjō said "There are details [a reason]." and where he waited, this monk ran up, hurriedly jumped off his horse, rested his breath for a while, and said "The young lord is pardoned. The Lord of Kamakura's letter is here."
and taking it out, presented it. When Hōjō opened and looked at it, truly,
Regarding the request of the Holy Man of Takao to receive custody of the son of Komatsu Third Rank Lieutenant General Koremori whom it is said was found; hand him over without making suspicion.
[12.6.9] To Lord Hōjō Shirō Yoritomo
[12.6.10] Thus it was written and had his seal. After reading it repeatedly two or three times, saying "Admirable, admirable," when he put it down, not to speak of Saitō Go and Saitō Roku, even Hōjō's house-children and retainers all shed tears of joy.
12.7. Hase-Rokudai
[12.7.1] In the meantime, Mongaku-bō also came out abruptly, and saying he had begged for and received the young lord, his expression was truly imposing. Because he said, "When he said 'This young lord's father, the Third Rank Lieutenant General, was the Great General of the first battle. Whoever speaks for him, it will not be granted,' although I spoke abusive words such as 'If you break Mongaku's heart, how will there be divine protection?', still saying 'It will not be granted,' he went down to hunt in Nasuno; consequently, Mongaku also attended the hunting grounds, and gradually spoke and begged for and received him. You must have thought it slow." Hōjō said, "The days of the promise which was said to be twenty days have also passed. Thinking there was no pardon from the Lord of Kamakura, as I was going down taking him with me, indeed, I might have committed an error here." and on the horses which were saddled and led up, he let Saitō Go and Saitō Roku ride and sent them up [to the Capital]. Escorting them himself far into the distance, he said "Although I wish to accompany you for a while, there are important matters I must report to the Lord of Kamakura. I take my leave." saying this, he parted and went down. Truly he was deep in compassion.
[12.7.2] The Saint took receipt of the young lord, and galloping up joining night to day, in the area of Atsuta in Owari Province, this year also already ended. Entering the night of the dawn of the 5th of the First Month, they arrived up at the Capital. Since Mongaku-bō had a lodging cell at a place called Nijō-Inokuma, he put him in there, and resting him for a while, about midnight they went to Daikakuji. Though they knocked on the gate, since there was no one, there was no sound. From a break in the earthen wall, the white dog the young lord used to keep ran out, and when it faced him wagging its tail, that the young lord asked "Where is Mother?" was a compelling matter. Saitō Roku crossed the earthen wall, opened the gate and let them enter. It did not look like a place where people had lived recently. "Thinking somehow to live out my worthless life, it was for the sake of thinking I wanted to see once more the person whom I miss. Now that this is so, what has become of her?" Saying this, that he wept and grieved all night long was truly felt to be reasonable and pathetic. Waiting for the night to brighten, when they asked a person of the nearby village, he said "We heard that within the year she went to the Great Buddha. We heard that during the First Month she is secluded at Hase-dera, but after that, people have not been seen commuting to her lodging."
Because he said this, Saitō Go hurriedly went to Hase and found them, and when he told this reason, the Mother and the wet-nurse lady did not feel it was reality at all, saying "Now that this is so, is it a dream, is it a dream?" Hurriedly she came out to Daikakuji, and seeing the young lord, even in her happiness, the only thing that came first was tears. Although she said "Quickly, become a monk," the Saint felt it a waste and did not let him become a monk. Saying "I will welcome him immediately," he placed him in Takao, and it is heard he also visited the secluded condition of the Northern Lady [the Mother]. Since the Great Compassion and Mercy of Kannon saves those with sin and those without sin, although it is said there are many such examples in the past, it was a rare thing.
[12.7.3] In the meantime, as Hōjō Shirō was going down taking Rokudai Gozen with him, he met the messenger of the Lord of Kamakura at Kagami Post Station; when he asked "How is it?", [the messenger] said "I hear that Jūrō Kurōdo-dono and Shida Saburō Sensei-dono are in agreement with Kurō the Magistrate. It is his mood that you are to kill them. " Hōjō said, "As for myself, I have brought an important prisoner." and regarding his nephew Hōjō Heiroku Tokisada who was going down in escort, from the Woods of Oiso he stopped him saying "Quickly, you return, find out the places where these people are, and kill them." Heiroku returned to the Capital and while searching, a monk appeared who said he knew the location of Jūrō Kurōdo-dono. When he asked that monk, he said "I do not know in detail; there is a monk who says he knows."
Because he said this, they pushed in and bound and arrested that monk. "For what reason am I bound?" "Because you know the location of Jūrō Kurōdo-dono, we bind you."
"Then you should have said 'Tell us.' Binding me roughly, how is that? I hear he is at Tennōji."
"Then, prepare yourselves." Saying this, with Heiroku's son-in-law Ogasawara Jūrō Kunihisa, Shigehara Kurō, Kuwabara Jirō, and Hattori Heiroku as the vanguard, a force of over thirty horsemen set out for Tennōji. Jūrō Kurōdo had two lodgings. They were at the places of the valley head-student musician Kaneharu, and men called Hata Roku and Hata Shichi. Making two groups, they pushed close. Jūrō Kurōdo was at Kaneharu's place, but seeing men with gear break in, he fled out the back. The head-student had two daughters. Both were Kurōdo's beloveds. Capturing these, when they asked Kurōdo's whereabouts, the elder sister said "Ask the younger sister." The younger sister said "Ask the elder sister." Since it was a matter of fleeing suddenly, surely he did not let anyone know, but taking [the women], they went up to the Capital.
[12.7.4] Although Kurōdo fled toward Kumano, because the only samurai who attended him had sore feet, indeed he stayed at a place called Yagi-gō in Izumi Province. The man who was the master of that [house], recognizing Kurōdo, ran up to the Capital all night long, and when he told Hōjō Heiroku, he said "The men of the Tennōji group have not yet come up; whom should I send?" and calling a retainer called Dai-Genji Muneharu, "Is that mountain monk who left his shrine still here?" "He is so." "Then call him." Saying this, when he was called, the said monk appeared. "Jūrō Kurōdo is present. Kill him, present him to the Lord of Kamakura, and receive a reward."
When he said this, he said "I have received it. Give me men. " "Dai-Genji, go down immediately, though there are no men." Saying this, he added just fourteen or fifteen grooms and miscellaneous servants and sent them. This was a man called Hitachi-bō Masaaki. He arrived down in Izumi Province, ran into that house and looked, but he was not there. He broke the floorboards and searched, and looked inside the lacquered closet, but he was not there. Hitachi-bō stood on the main road and looked; catching a woman who seemed to be a farmer's wife carrying a long item passing by, he said "Is there a place in this area where suspicious travelers are staying? If you do not say, I will cut you down." When he said this, she said "In the house that was searched just now, until last night two very normal travelers were staying, but I wonder if they left this morning. In that large house visible over there is where they are now."
Because she said this, when Hitachi-bō, wearing sleeves over a belly-band with black leather lacing and carrying a great sword, ran into that house and looked, a man of about fifty years, wearing a foot-soldier's hitatare and a folded hat, was handling a Chinese flask and sweets, and was about to offer sake with sake-servers, when seeing a monk equipped with gear break in, he covered his face and fled, so immediately he followed and chased him. Kurōdo said "That monk. Ya, that is not him. Yukiie is here." When he ran back to look, he was wearing a white kosode and only wide-mouthed trousers; in his left hand he held a small sword with gold work, and in his right hand he held a large field-sword. Hitachi-bō said "Throw down your sword." Kurōdo laughed greatly. Hitachi-bō ran up and cut forcefully. Clashing with a clang, he leaped back. Again he approached and cut. Clashing with a clang, he leaped back. Meeting and fleeing, they fought for about an hour. As Kurōdo was about to retreat into the lacquered closet behind him, Hitachi-bō said "It is unseemly. Do not enter." Because he said this, saying "Yukiie thinks so too," again he leaped out and fought. Hitachi-bō threw away his sword, grappled forcefully, and they fell with a thud. Getting on top and being on bottom, where they were rolling together, Dai-Genji came out abruptly. Because he was too panicked, he did not draw the sword he carried, but grasping a stone, he struck Kurōdo's forehead with a crack and broke it. Kurōdo laughed greatly and said "Because you are a low-ranking fellow. With a sword or halberd one strikes the enemy. Is there a way of striking an enemy with pebbles?" Hitachi-bō ordered "Bind his legs."
Although Hitachi-bō said to bind the enemy's legs, being too panicked, he bound four legs [hands and feet]. After that, hanging a rope on Kurōdo's neck, binding him, raising him up and pushing him down: "Give me water." When he said this, they washed dried rice and gave it to him. Since he took the water, but put the dried rice aside without eating, Hitachi-bō took it and ate it. "Are you a mountain monk?" "I am a mountain monk." "Who are you called?" "I am a person called Hitachi-bō Masaaki of the North Valley of the Western Pagoda." "Then, are you the monk who said he would serve Yukiie?" "I am so." "Are you Yoritomo's messenger? Or Heiroku's messenger?" "I am the Lord of Kamakura's messenger. Truly, did you think you would kill the Lord of Kamakura?" "After coming to this state, if I say I did not think so, how is it? If I say I thought so, how is it? Regarding the method [of fighting], how did you think of it?" When he said this, he said "Although I have met many things on the mountain, I have not yet met such a tough thing as this; I feel I have met three good enemies."
"So, how do you think of Masaaki?" When he said this, [Yukiie] said "That is, now that I am taken..." "Bring that sword near." Saying this, when he looked, Kurōdo's sword was not chipped in one place; Hitachi-bō's sword was chipped in forty-two places. Immediately making a post-horse stand and putting him on it, as they went up, that night they stayed at the place of the Mistress of Eguchi, and ran messengers all night long. Around the hour of the Horse [noon] the next day, as Hōjō Heiroku came down with a force of about 100 horsemen raising flags, they met at the Akai River in Yodo. "It is a Cloistered Decree saying he should not be entered into the Capital. The Lord of Kamakura's mood is also that way. Quickly give his head, enter it into the Lord of Kamakura's inspection, and receive a reward."
Because he said this, saying "Then [so be it]," they cut Jūrō Kurōdo's head at the Akai River.
[12.7.5] Hearing that Shida Saburō Sensei Yoshinori was hiding in the mountains of Daigo, they pushed near and searched, but he was not there. Hearing he had fled toward Iga, with Hattori Heiroku as the vanguard, they set out for Iga Province. While it was heard he was at a mountain temple called Sendo, as they pushed near and were about to arrest him, wearing a lined kosode and only wide-mouthed trousers, with a waist-sword wound in gold, he cut his belly and lay down. Hattori Heiroku took his head. Immediately having it carried, they went up to the Capital, and when they showed it to Hōjō Heiroku, he said "Immediately have it carried and go down, enter it into the Lord of Kamakura's inspection and receive a reward." Because he said this, Hitachi-bō and Hattori, each having the heads carried, went down to Kamakura, and when they entered them for inspection, he said "Admirable," and Hitachi-bō was exiled to Kasai. "Having gone down completely, I thought I would receive a reward, but it is not so; moreover, the article of being sentenced to exile is an unexpected order. If I knew it would be like this, why did I throw away my life?" Though he regretted it, it was of no use. However, in the second year he was called back, and saying "As for a person who killed a Great General, since there is no divine protection, I admonished you for a short time," [Yoritomo] gave him two places, Tada Manor in Tajima Province and Hamuro in Settsu Province, and he returned up [to the Capital]. Since Hattori Heiroku was a person in the service of the Heike, his confiscated Hattori [lands] were returned to him.
12.8. Rokudai Is Slain
[12.8.1] In the meantime, since Rokudai Gozen gradually became fourteen or fifteen, his face and form were more and more beautiful, such that the area shone and sparkled. The Mother looked at this and said, "Alas, if the world were the world [of the Heike], by now he would be a Captain of the Guards." That she said this was an unnecessary thing. The Lord of Kamakura constantly felt uncertain, and at every opportunity asked the Saint of Takao: "Well, regarding Minister Koremori's son, how is he? Like the way Yoritomo was pardoned long ago, is he a benevolent man who will destroy the enemies of the Court and clear the shame of Kaikei?" When he asked this, in the Saint's reply: "This is a bottomlessly foolish man. Please set your heart at ease." Although he said this, the Lord of Kamakura still seemed not satisfied in his heart, saying "He is the Saint who, if he [Rokudai] just raises a rebellion, will immediately take his side. However, during Yoritomo's one lifetime, who would overturn it? The end of the descendants is unknown." That he said this was fearful; the Mother heard this, and saying "It will not be granted no matter what. Quickly become a monk," around the spring of the fifth year of Bunji when Rokudai Gozen was called sixteen, he cut off his beautiful hair around his shoulders, and in persimmon robes and hakama, preparing a portable shrine and such, he asked leave of the Saint and went out on a pilgrimage. Saitō Go and Saitō Roku also dressed in the same manner and attended him. First going to Koya, he found Takiguchi Nyudo who had been his father's spiritual friend, and hearing in detail the order of his becoming a monk and the appearance of his end, saying that he also wanted to see his traces, he went to Kumano. Before the Shrine on the Beach, looking across at the mountain-shaped island where his father crossed over, although he thought he wanted to cross, since the wind and waves faced him and it was not granted, unable to do otherwise, even while gazing out, asking the white waves approaching from the offing "Where has my father sunk?", indeed he thought he wanted to ask. Thinking fondly "Is the sand of the shore my father's bones?", his sleeves withered with tears, and though not the robes of a salt-scooping diver, they did not seem to have a moment to dry. Staying one night on the beach, chanting the Nembutsu and reading sutras, with the tip of his finger drawing the shape of a Buddha in the sand; when it dawned, inviting a noble monk, he performed a service for the sake of his father, and turning the merit of the good deeds entirely to the holy spirit, saying farewell to the dead, weeping he went up to the Capital.
[12.8.2] Komatsu-dono's son, Tango-no-Jijū Tadafusa, fled from the battle of Yashima and was existing without his destination being known, but relying on a resident of Kii Province, Yuasa Gon-no-Kami Muneshige, he was secluded in the castle of Yuasa. Hearing this, Etchū Jirōbyōe, Kazusa Gorōbyōe, Aku-Shichibyōe, Hida Shirōbyōe and lesser soldiers who thought fondly of the Heike, hearing that he had arrived, the residents of the two provinces of Iga and Ise ran and gathered, saying "Me too, me too." Hearing that hundreds of horsemen of excellent men were holed up there, the Kumano Betto received orders from the Lord of Kamakura, and during two or three months, attacked and fought eight times. Because the soldiers inside the castle defended without sparing their lives, each time the attacking side was scattered, and the Kumano monks exhausted their numbers and were killed. The Kumano Betto sent a courier to the Lord of Kamakura: "Regarding the matter of the battle of Yuasa in this province, within two or three months we have approached and fought eight times. However, since the soldiers inside the castle defend without sparing their lives, each time our side is driven down, and we cannot crush the enemy. I report that I should be given two or three nearby provinces to attack and drop them."
The Lord of Kamakura said "That article would be an expense to the provinces and a trouble to the people. The villains in the place where they are holed up are surely thieves of the sea and mountains. Mountain bandits and pirates should guard strictly and solidify the mouth of the castle and watch." Because they made that decision, indeed afterward there was not a single person [who joined them]. The Lord of Kamakura, in a stratagem, said: "If one or two of the young lords of Komatsu-dono remain alive, I shall save them. The reason is, that Ike-no-Zenni acted as a messenger and soothed [Kiyomori] into exiling Yoritomo was solely the chaotic favor of that Minister [Shigemori]."
Because he said this, Tango-no-Jijū came out to Rokuhara and announced his name. Immediately they sent him down to the Kanto. The Lord of Kamakura met him, and saying "Go up to the Capital. There is a thing I have in mind in a remote area," he deceived him and sent him up, and sending men in pursuit, cut him near the bridge of Seta.
[12.8.3] Outside of the six young lords of Komatsu-dono, there was one called Tosa-no-Kami Munezane. From age three he was the adopted son of the Oimikado Minister of the Left Tsunemune Kyō, becoming a stranger of a different surname; abandoning the way of military arts and fond only of literature, this year he became eighteen; although there was no search from the Lord of Kamakura, fearing the world he was driven out, and losing his future path, he went to the Great Buddha's Shunjō-bō [Chōgen] and said: "I am a person called Tosa-no-Kami Munezane, the youngest child of the Komatsu Minister. From age three becoming the adopted son of Oimikado Minister of the Left Tsunemune, becoming a stranger of a different surname, throwing away the path of military arts and being fond only of literature, I have reached the age of eighteen. Although there is no search from the Lord of Kamakura, fearing the world I have been driven out. Saint, please make me a disciple."
and he cut off his topknot. "If you think even that is fearful, report to Kamakura, and indeed if the sin is deep, send me anywhere." Because he said this, the Saint thought him most dear, made him become a monk, placed him for a while in a place called the Oil Warehouse of Todaiji, and reported this to the Kanto. "In any case, I will see him and decide this or that. First send him down." Because he said this, the Saint unable to do otherwise sent him down to the Kanto. From the day this person left Nara, he cut off the names of food and drink, and without letting hot or cold water into his throat, crossing Ashigara, at a place called Sekimoto, finally he passed away. Saying "Since it is a path that will not be granted no matter what," that he resigned himself was fearful.
[12.8.4] In the meantime, on the 7th of the 11th Month of the first year of Kenkyū [1190], the Lord of Kamakura went up to the Capital, and on the 9th day became Senior Second Rank Dainagon. On the 11th, he held the post of Right Commander of the Guards concurrently with Dainagon. Before long he resigned both posts and on the 4th of the 12th Month went down to the Kanto. On the 13th day of the 3rd Month of the third year of Kenkyū, the Cloistered Emperor died. His age was sixty-six. The sound of the Yoga bells was limited to that night; the voice of reciting the One Vehicle ended at that dawn.
[12.8.5] Saying the Great Buddha Dedication should be on the 13th of the 3rd Month of the sixth year of the same, in the middle of the 2nd Month the Lord of Kamakura again went up to the Capital. On the 12th, he went to the Great Buddha Hall; summoning Kajiwara, he said "South of the Tegai Gate, separated by ten or so of the Great Assembly [monks], a suspicious man is visible. Capture him and bring him." When he said this, Kajiwara received the order and immediately arrested and brought him. He was a man who shaved his beard but did not cut his topknot. "What person are you?" When he asked, "Now that my fate has run out to this extent, it does not extend to saying this or that. I am a samurai of the Heike called Satsuma Chūmutsu Iesuke."
"Thinking what, have you become thus?" "Thinking 'perhaps', I have been aiming for you." "The extent of your intention is imposing." Saying this, the dedication ended and he entered the Capital, and [Iesuke] was cut at the Rokujō riverbed.
[12.8.6] Around the winter of the first year of Bunji, the descendants of the Heike, one-year-olds and two-year-olds, not leaving any, to the extent of saying they would open the womb and look, were hunted, taken and destroyed. When it was thought not even one existed now, there was the youngest child of the New Middle Counselor called Iga Taiyu Tomotada. When the Heike fled the Capital, he was three years old and was abandoned, but his wet-nurse Kii Jirōbyōe Tamenori raised him, and hiding here and there, they were living stealthily in a place called Ota in Bingo Province. Since he gradually became an adult, as the Stewards and Constables of the districts and villages became suspicious, he went up to the Capital and was present stealthily at a place called the First Bridge of Hosshōji. Here, the grandfather Lay Priest Prime Minister, saying "when a spontaneous matter occurs," intended to make it a fortress, so he dug a double moat and planted bamboo on the four sides. Pulling up reverse barricades, in the day there was no sound of people; when it became night, many ordinary fellows gathered, made Chinese poems, read Japanese poems, and played music; while they were playing, somehow it leaked out; at that time, the person whom people feared was a person called Ichijō-no-Nii Nyūdō Yoshiyasu. His samurai, Shinbyōe Mototsuna, son of Gotōbyōe Motokiyo, found out "There is a traitor at the First Bridge," and on the 7th of the 10th Month of the 7th year of Kenkyū, at one point of the hour of the Dragon [7-9 AM], with a force of one hundred forty or fifty horsemen, ran to face the First Bridge, and screaming and shouting, attacked and fought. The men inside the fortress, over thirty of them, baring their shoulders from big sleeves, from the shadows of the bamboo nocked and pulled, nocked and pulled and shot severely, so many horses and men were shot to death and there was no way to face them. "In the meantime, there is a traitor at the First Bridge," hearing this transmitted, the warriors in the Capital ran and gathered, saying "Me too, me too." Before long it became one or two thousand horsemen, so they broke down the small houses in the vicinity and brought them close, filled in the moat, and screaming and shouting, attacked and entered. The soldiers inside the castle drew their striking weapons and ran out; some died fighting, some bore painful wounds and committed suicide. Iga Taiyu Tomotada had reached the age of sixteen, but bearing painful wounds he committed suicide; his wet-nurse Kii Jirōbyōe Nyudo carried him onto his knees, and shedding tears in drops, chanting the Ten Invocations in a high voice, he cut his belly and died. His sons Hyōe Tarō and Hyōe Jirō both died fighting. The thirty or so men inside the castle generally died fighting or committed suicide, and fire was set to the mansion; the warriors ran in, and piercing the heads they had each taken on the tips of swords and halberds, they ran to the Second Rank Lay Priest's place. Sending a carriage out to the main street of Ichijō, the heads were inspected. There were a few people who recognized Kii Jirōbyōe Nyudo's head. Regarding Iga Taiyu's head, how could people recognize it? They fetched this person's mother, called Jibu-Kyō-no-Tsubone who was serving Hachijō-In, and showed it to her. "At the time called three years old, after he went down to the West Country accompanied by the late Middle Counselor, whether he was alive or dead, I did not know his whereabouts; however, indeed there are features that recall the late Middle Counselor." Because she wept saying this, indeed people knew it was Iga Taiyu's head.
[12.8.7] The Heike samurai Etchū Jirōbyōe Moritsugu fled to Tajima Province and was living as the son-in-law of Kehi Shirō Michihiro. Michihiro did not know he was Etchū Jirōbyōe. However, with an air that an awl does not stay in a bag, when it became night, he pulled out his father-in-law's horses and galloped them. Because he did things like diving 14, 15 chō or 20 chō to the bottom of the sea, as the Steward and Constable became suspicious, somehow it leaked out. The Lord of Kamakura issued a letter of instruction. "I hear that Tajima Province resident Asakura Tarō Taiyu Takakiyo and Heike samurai Etchū Jirōbyōe Moritsugu are residing in this province. Summon and present them." Thus the order was sent down. Since Kehi Shirō was Asakura Taiyu's son-in-law, he called him and deliberated "How shall we bind him?" Deciding "We should bind him in the bathhouse," they put him in the bath, and five or six strong men went down together and tried to bind him, but if they grappled he threw them down, if they got up he kicked them down. Mutually their bodies were wet, and they could not get a grip. However, since strong power is no match for the power of a multitude, twenty or thirty men approached, beat and weakened him with the backs of swords and shafts of halberds, bound and arrested him, and immediately presented him to the Kanto; having him dragged into the presence, the details of the matter were asked. "How is it, while being called a samurai of the same Heike, it appears you are a relative by marriage; why did you not die?"
"That is because the Heike were destroyed too easily, so thinking 'perhaps', I was aiming for you. Thinking of the sharpness of only swords and the sharpness of the steel of arrowheads was for the sake of the Lord of Kamakura, but now that my fate has run out to this extent, it does not extend to saying this or that."
"The extent of your intention is imposing. If you rely on Yoritomo, how about I save you and employ you?" When he said this, "A brave warrior does not serve two masters. If you relax your heart toward a person like Moritsugu, you will certainly regret it later. Just, as a favor, quickly take my head."
Because he said this, saying "Then cut him," they dragged him out to the beach of Yuigahama and cut him. There was no one who did not praise him.
[12.8.8] Since the Emperor of that time made amusement his main concern, and the path of government was entirely at the will of Kyō-no-Tsubone, people's laments also did not cease. Because the King of Wu liked swordsmen, those who incurred wounds in the realm were unceasing. Because the King of Chu loved slender waists, there were many women who starved to death in the palace. Since the subordinates follow the likes of the Superior, grieving at the danger of the world, people with heart lamented together. Here, Mongaku was originally a fearful Saint, and he meddled in matters he should not meddle in. Since the Second Prince did not neglect his studies and made right principles his priority, he planned by any means to have this Prince ascend to the throne, but while the Former Right General Lord Yoritomo was present it was not granted; when Lord Yoritomo passed away on the 13th of the 1st Month of the tenth year of Kenkyū, immediately as he was about to raise a rebellion, it suddenly leaked out, and officials were attached to his lodging at Nijō-Inokuma, he was arrested, and at over eighty he was exiled to Oki Province. When Mongaku left the Capital, he said "Facing the waves of this much old age, regarding a body that does not know today or tomorrow, even if it is an Imperial censure, that I am not placed in a remote area of the Capital but am exiled as far as Oki Province, the Garden-servant Lad is not peaceful. In the end, I will welcome him to the province where Mongaku is exiled." That he said this was fearful. Because this Lord [Emperor Go-Toba] loved the ball of the Gitchō stick too much, Mongaku spoke abuse in this way. Thus, raising a rebellion in Jōkyū, although there are many provinces, that he was moved to Oki Province is strange. It is heard that even in that province, Mongaku's angry spirit was rough and constantly spoke to him.
[12.8.9] In the meantime, regarding Rokudai Gozen, who was living as a devotee at Takao called Sanmi Zenji: "He is that person's child. He is that person's disciple. Even if he shaved his head, surely he did not shave his heart."
Saying this, because it was said repeatedly from the Lord of Kamakura, ordering Adachi Hangand Kagemori, he was arrested and sent down to the Kanto. Ordering Okabe Gon-no-Kami Yasutsuna, a resident of Suruga Province, he was cut at the Tagoshi River. That he was preserved from the age of twelve until over thirty was heard to be solely the benefit of the Kannon of Hase. From that, indeed, the descendants of the Heike were extinguished forever.
